Paragraph: Contributing
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: If you want to contribute to linux-insides, please follow these simple rules:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 1.  Press the fork button:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: fork
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 2.  Clone the repository from your account with:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: git clone git@github.com:your_github_username/linux-insides.git
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 3.  Create a new branch with:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: git checkout -b "linux-bootstrap-1-fix"
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: You can name it however you want.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 4.  Make your changes.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 5.  Don't forget to add yourself in contributors.md.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 6.  Commit and push your changes, then make a pull request from Github.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: IMPORTANT
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Please, don't forget to update your fork. While you made your changes, the content of the master branch can change because other pull requests were merged and it can create conflicts. This is why you have to rebase on master every time before pushing your changes and check that your branch doesn't have any conflicts with master.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Thank you.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 0x Contribution Guide
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: We welcome contributions from anyone on the internet and are grateful for even the smallest contributions. This document will help get you setup to start contributing back to 0x.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Getting started
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 1.  Fork 0xproject/0x-monorepo
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 2.  Clone your fork
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 3.  Follow the installation & build steps in the repo's top-level README.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 4.  Setup the recommended Development Tooling.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 5.  Open a PR with the [WIP] flag against the development branch and describe the change you are intending to undertake in the PR description. (see our branch naming conventions)
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Before removing the [WIP] tag and submitting the PR for review, make sure:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - It passes our linter checks (yarn lint)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - It is properly formatted with Prettier (yarn prettier)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - It passes our continuous integration tests (See: Enabling code coverage checks on your fork for instructions on getting the submit-coverage test to pass on forks)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - You've created/updated the corresponding CHANGELOG entries.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Your changes have sufficient test coverage (e.g regression tests have been added for bug fixes)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Branch structure
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: We have two main branches:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - master represents the most recently released (published on npm) version of the codebase.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - development represents the current development state of the codebase.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: ALL PRs should be opened against development.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Branch names should be prefixed with fix, feature or refactor.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - e.g fix/missing-import
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - If the PR only edits a single package, add it's name too
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - e.g fix/subproviders/missing-import
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: CHANGELOGs
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: At 0x we use Semantic Versioning for all our published packages. If a change you make corresponds to a semver bump, you must modify the package's CHANGELOG.json file accordingly.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Each CHANGELOG entry that corresponds to a published package will have a timestamp. If no entry exists without a timestamp, you must first create a new one:
Label: SC – Submit the changes
SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: If an entry without a timestamp already exists, this means other changes have been introduced by other collaborators since the last publish. Add your changes to the list of notes and adjust the version if your PR introduces a greater semver change (i.e current changes required a patch bump, but your changes require a major version bump).
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Development Tooling
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: We strongly recommend you use the VSCode text editor since most of our code is written in TypeScript and it offers amazing support for the language.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Linter
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: We use TSLint with custom configs to keep our code-style consistent.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Use yarn:lint to lint the entire monorepo, and PKG={PACKAGE_NAME} yarn lint to lint a specific package.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: If you want to change a rule, or add a custom rule, please make these changes to our tslint-config package. All other packages have it as a dependency.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Integrate it into your text editor:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - VSCode: vscode-tslint
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Atom: linter-tslint
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Auto-formatter
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: We use Prettier to auto-format our code. Be sure to either add a text editor integration or a pre-commit hook to properly format your code changes.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: If using the Atom text editor, we recommend you install the following packages:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - VSCode: prettier-vscode
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Atom: prettier-atom
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Unenforced coding conventions
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: A few of our coding conventions are not yet enforced by the linter/auto-formatter. Be careful to follow these conventions in your PR's.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: 1.  Unused anonymous function parameters should be named with an underscore + number (e.g _1, _2, etc...)
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: 2.  There should be a new-line between methods in a class and between test cases.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: 3.  If a string literal has the same value in two or more places, it should be a single constant referenced in both places.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: 4.  Do not import from a project's index.ts (e.g import { Token } from '../src';). Always import from the source file itself.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: 5.  Generic error variables should be named err instead of e or error.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: 6.  If you must cast a variable to any - try to type it back as fast as possible. (e.g., const cw = ((zeroEx as any)._contractWrappers as ContractWrappers);). This ensures subsequent code is type-safe.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: 7.  Our enum conventions coincide with the recommended TypeScript conventions, using capitalized keys, and all-caps snake-case values. Eg GetStats = 'GET_STATS'
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: 8.  All public, exported methods/functions/classes must have associated Javadoc-style comments.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Fix submit-coverage CI failure
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: If you simply fork the repo and then create a PR from it, your PR will fail the submit-coverage check on CI. This is because the 0x CircleCI configuration sets the COVERALLS_REPO_TOKEN environment variable to the token for 0xProject/0x-monorepo, but when running the check against your fork the token needs to match your repo's name your-username/0x-monorepo.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: To facilitate this check, after creating your fork, but before creating the branch for your PR, do the following:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 1.  Log in to coveralls.io, go to Add Repos, and enable your fork. Then go to the settings for that repo, and copy the Repo Token identifier.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 2.  Log in to CircleCI, go to Add Projects, click the Set Up Project button corresponding to your fork, and then click Start Building. (Aside from step 3 below, no actual set up is needed, since it will use the .circleci/config.yml file in 0x-monorepo, so you can ignore all of the instruction/explanation given on the page with the Start Building button.)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 3.  In CircleCI, configure your project to add an environment variable, with name COVERALLS_REPO_TOKEN, and for the value paste in the Repo Token you copied in step 1.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Now, when you push to your branch, CircleCI will automatically run all of the checks in your own instance, and the coverage check will work since it has the proper Repo Token, and the PR will magically refer to your own checks rather than running them in the 0x CircleCI instance.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Development workflow
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: To get started with the project, run yarn bootstrap in the root directory to install the required dependencies for each package:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: yarn bootstrap
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: While developing, you can run the example app to test your changes.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: To start the packager:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: yarn example start
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: To run the example app on Android:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: yarn example android
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: To run the example app on iOS:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: yarn example ios
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: To run the example app on Web:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: yarn example web
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Make sure your code passes TypeScript and ESLint. Run the following to verify:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
yarn typescript
yarn lint

Paragraph: To fix formatting errors, run the following:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: yarn lint --fix

Paragraph: Remember to add tests for your change if possible. Run the unit tests by:

Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Commit message convention
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: We follow the conventional commits specification for our commit messages:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - fix: bug fixes, e.g. fix crash due to deprecated method.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - feat: new features, e.g. add new method to the module.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - refactor: code refactor, e.g. migrate from class components to hooks.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - docs: changes into documentation, e.g. add usage example for the module..
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - test: adding or updating tests, eg add integration tests using detox.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - chore: tooling changes, e.g. change CI config.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Our pre-commit hooks verify that your commit message matches this format when committing.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Code of Conduct
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Our Pledge
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: We as members, contributors, and leaders pledge to make participation in our community a harassment-free experience for everyone, regardless of age, body size, visible or invisible disability, ethnicity, sex characteristics, gender identity and expression, level of experience, education, socio-economic status, nationality, personal appearance, race, religion, or sexual identity and orientation.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: We pledge to act and interact in ways that contribute to an open, welcoming, diverse, inclusive, and healthy community.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Our Standards
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Examples of behavior that contributes to a positive environment for our community include:
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: - Demonstrating empathy and kindness toward other people
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: - Being respectful of differing opinions, viewpoints, and experiences
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: - Giving and gracefully accepting constructive feedback
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: - Accepting responsibility and apologizing to those affected by our mistakes, and learning from the experience
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: - Focusing on what is best not just for us as individuals, but for the overall community
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Examples of unacceptable behavior include:
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph:
- The use of sexualized language or imagery, and sexual attention or
advances of any kind
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: - Trolling, insulting or derogatory comments, and personal or political attacks
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: - Public or private harassment
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph:
- Publishing others' private information, such as a physical or email
address, without their explicit permission
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph:
- Other conduct which could reasonably be considered inappropriate in a
professional setting
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Enforcement Responsibilities
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Community leaders are responsible for clarifying and enforcing our standards of acceptable behavior and will take appropriate and fair corrective action in response to any behavior that they deem inappropriate, threatening, offensive, or harmful.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Community leaders have the right and responsibility to remove, edit, or reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, and other contributions that are not aligned to this Code of Conduct, and will communicate reasons for moderation decisions when appropriate.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Scope
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: This Code of Conduct applies within all community spaces, and also applies when an individual is officially representing the community in public spaces. Examples of representing our community include using an official e-mail address, posting via an official social media account, or acting as an appointed representative at an online or offline event.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Enforcement
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Instances of abusive, harassing, or otherwise unacceptable behavior may be reported to the community leaders responsible for enforcement at [INSERT CONTACT METHOD]. All complaints will be reviewed and investigated promptly and fairly.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: All community leaders are obligated to respect the privacy and security of the reporter of any incident.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Enforcement Guidelines
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Community leaders will follow these Community Impact Guidelines in determining the consequences for any action they deem in violation of this Code of Conduct:
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: 1. Correction
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Community Impact: Use of inappropriate language or other behavior deemed unprofessional or unwelcome in the community.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Consequence: A private, written warning from community leaders, providing clarity around the nature of the violation and an explanation of why the behavior was inappropriate. A public apology may be requested.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: 2. Warning
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Community Impact: A violation through a single incident or series of actions.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Consequence: A warning with consequences for continued behavior. No interaction with the people involved, including unsolicited interaction with those enforcing the Code of Conduct, for a specified period of time. This includes avoiding interactions in community spaces as well as external channels like social media. Violating these terms may lead to a temporary or permanent ban.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: 3. Temporary Ban
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Community Impact: A serious violation of community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Consequence: A temporary ban from any sort of interaction or public communication with the community for a specified period of time. No public or private interaction with the people involved, including unsolicited interaction with those enforcing the Code of Conduct, is allowed during this period. Violating these terms may lead to a permanent ban.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: 4. Permanent Ban
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Community Impact: Demonstrating a pattern of violation of community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior, harassment of an individual, or aggression toward or disparagement of classes of individuals.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Consequence: A permanent ban from any sort of public interaction within the community.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Before we get started: Please note that this project is released with a Contributor Code of Conduct to ensure that this project is a welcoming place for everyone to contribute to. By participating in this project you agree to abide by its terms.

Paragraph: - Fork the project.

Paragraph: Reporting a bug
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: So you've found a bug, and want to help us fix it? Before filing a bug report, please double-check the bug hasn't already been reported. You can do so on our issue tracker. If something hasn't been raised, you can go ahead and create a new issue with the following information:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - On which page did the error happen?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - How can the error be reproduced?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - If possible, please also provide an error message or a screenshot to illustrate the problem
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: If you want to be really thorough, there is a great overview on Stack Overflow of what you should consider when reporting a bug.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: It goes without saying that you're welcome to help investigate further and/or find a fix for the bug. If you want to do so, just mention it in your bug report and offer your help!
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Contributing to an existing issue
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: Finding an issue to work on
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: We've got a few open issues and are always glad to get help on that front. You can view the list of issues here. Most of the issues are labelled, so you can use the labels to get an idea of which issue could be a good fit for you. (Here's a good article on how to find your first bug to fix).
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: Before getting to work, take a look at the issue and at the conversation around it. Has someone already offered to work on the issue? Has someone been assigned to the issue? If so, you might want to check with them to see whether they're still actively working on it.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: If the issue is a few months old, it might be a good idea to write a short comment to double-check that the issue or feature is still a valid one to jump on.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph:
Feel free to ask for more detail on what is expected: are there any more details or specifications you need to know?
And if at any point you get stuck: don't hesitate to ask for help.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: Making your contribution
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: We've outlined the contribution workflow here. If you're a first-timer, don't worry! GitHub has a ton of guides to help you through your first pull request: You can find out more about pull requests here and about creating a pull request here.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Our labels
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: - beginner: One of our most important kinds of issues! These issues have been marked by the maintainers as small, low-impact changes and fixes, ideal for those just dipping their toes for the first time into the world of contributing to Open Source software. These are by no means any less important than any other issues! We'd appreciate if our more experienced contributors would leave these to our newer compatriots so we can be as fair as possible to everyone.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: - blocked: We will generally mark an issue as blocked if it requires more context for us to fix, is waiting on an updated version of a library that the issue depends on, or is waiting on a maintainer to do something before it can be answered. There may be other conditions in which we'll mark an issue as blocked, and we'll make this clear in the issue comments.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: - bug: An issue gets marked as a bug if (surprise!) the issue is linked to a bug in our code or something broken in our infrastructure. Bugs are usually the highest priority kind of issue as they will affect our users.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: - bugsnag: If an issue or exception in production code has been flagged via Bugsnag, it is labelled with this automatically.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: - documentation: If an issue requires changes or clarification to our documentation (READMEs, wiki, code comments, etc.) then it will be marked with this issue. These issues normally do not pertain to code changes and are ideal for those who don't necessarily want to get their hands dirty with code.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: - duplicate: If an issue has been reported before, it will be marked with this label. This flags that a previous issue may not have been fixed as expected, or in the case of things we don't intend to fix or issues currently in discussion in another open issue, it means that we are likely to close the issue.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: - enhancement: These are improvements to the codebase that are "nice to have", and are usually medium to high impact but low importance. This includes improvements to features that already exist and may be assigned a milestone to give you an idea as to when it might be implemented. These are great for contributors that might have some extra spare time on their hands and would prefer to change existing code rather than add large chunks of brand new code.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: - feature: An issue will be marked with this label if it adds a new, discrete functional element to the codebase. They will generally require large amounts or effort to implement, require changes to both front-end view templates and back-end code, and assume prior knowledge of the codebase, making these the most tricky kinds of issues to close. However, they can be the most rewarding to close for the intrepid!
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: - help wanted: Issues will be marked with this label by the maintainers if we'd like outside contributors to pitch in with code or opinions before we close them. These do not assume any skill level and are great opportunities for all members of our community to steer the direction of the project.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: - i18n: Issues related to localisation or translation are marked with these labels. They can range from missing translations for a specific language to grammatical issues and cultural differences. These will usually require a specialist in a non-English language to close.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: - invalid: These are rare, and normally have been submitted in error.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: - needs rebase: You will find this label normally attached to pull requests, and means that the maintainers would like to you squash commits or rebase existing commits from master into your branch before we can merge your pull request. A maintainer will clarify this in the comment thread.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: - question: Issues can be marked with this label by anybody who would like other contributors or maintainers to answer a specific question before an issue can be closed. These normally do not assume any skill level (although may sometimes require maintainers to have the final say on them) and are great opportunities for all members of our community to steer the direction of the project.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: - refactoring: If an issue requires code to be refactored before a particular change can be made, or if you spot inelegant patterns or implementations in code that you feel could be better, then feel free to add this label to an issue. If the issue is the latter type, please be careful about the language you use in these threads. For example, things like "this code sucks!" or "you must be an idiot!" are unacceptable!. Programmers have feelings too and there are ways to suggest code changes without insulting people!
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: - security: If you spot an issue related to security issues (e.g. invalid SSL certs, potential CSRF issues), mark it with this label. Don't forget to be a good OSS citizen and always report zero-day issues through a private channel to minimise impact to your fellow users!
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: - UX: These issues relate to how the site works, or more holistically, how the site feels to the end user, and will normally be related to the front-end of the website. These issues might typically relate to confusion stemming from navigation, form elements, input validation, or breaks in user flows.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: - visual design: This relates to visual elements of the site that could be improved or are broken. This may be as simple as a change to a CSS colour or font size but may stretch all the way to things that do not render as expected on mobile devices. These are usually good issues for people with front-end development experience to tackle.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: - wontfix: This means that, after considering your issue in full, your issue is outside of the intended scope of the project and is not something we'd like to add to the codebase right now or in the future. These are used sparingly and are intended to be rare, and are never used without reasoned justification.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: Additional info
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Especially if you're a newcomer to Open Source and you've found some little bumps along the way while contributing, we recommend you write about them. Here's a great article about why writing about your experience is important; this will encourage other beginners to try their luck at Open Source, too!
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: License and Contributions

Paragraph: Contribution Guidelines
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 30 seconds of code is powered by the community, so feel free to contribute in any way you can to help us!
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Tools
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Before you begin contributing, you should install the integration-tools globally on your machine:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: npm install -g @30-seconds/integration-tools
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: This will allow you to use our customized tools for all of our content repositories.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: How you can help
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: - Submit pull requests with new snippets (see guidelines below) or snippet updates (tags, descriptions, explanations, typos, examples, code improvements).
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: - Open issues for things you want to see added, modified, discuss ideas or help out with existing issues.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: Ground rules
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Breaking any of these rules will result in your pull request being closed. Please follow these guidelines above all else:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Always be polite and respectful to others and try to follow the advice of the moderators/collaborators/owners.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Only modify snippet files, never modify the generated files in the snippet_data directory.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Use the integration tools commands to generate new snippets, ensuring they have the correct name and are in the correct location.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Follow snippet format exactly, otherwise your snippets will not be recognized correctly by the tools responsible for publishing them on the website. This includes such things as spacing and empty lines - if you accidentally make a mistake, consult the repository's snippet template.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Snippets should solve real-world problems, no matter how simple and should be abstract enough to be applied to different scenarios.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Snippet creation
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: After installing the integration tools, you can run the following command:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: create-new-snippet <my-snippet-name>
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Replace <my-snippet-name> with the name of the snippet you are adding.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Snippet guidelines
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Snippets must have all their frontmatter sections (title, tags etc.) filled.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Snippet titles must correspond to the filename and follow the language and repository's naming conventions.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Snippet tags must be comma-separated, contain a primary tag as seen on the website as their first tag and an expertise tag (beginner, intermediate or advanced) as their last tag.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Snippet descriptions must be short and to the point. Explain what the snippet does and detail how the snippet works and the language features used in it.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Snippet code and examples must be enclosed in appropriate, language-tagged blocks as shown in the snippet template, be short and use modern techniques and features. Also make sure to test your code before submitting.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - If your snippet contains arguments with default parameters, explain what happens if they are omitted when calling the function and what the default case is. Specify default parameters for arguments only if necessary.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - If your snippet uses recursion, use the recursion tag and explain the base cases.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Try to strike a balance between readability, brevity, and performance.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Always use soft tabs (2 spaces), never hard tabs.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Leave a single space after a comma (,) character (both in the description and code).
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Define multiple variables on the same line, if possible. Use meaningful names (e.g. letter instead of lt) and follow existing conventions as seen in other snippets. Do not use trailing or leading underscores in variable names.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Contribution Guidelines
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Hi there, and thanks for your interest in the C# ALGORITHMS repository. This document serves as a set of general guidelines for open-source contribution.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Please follow the Contributor Code of Conduct for all your interactions.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Types of Contributions
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Please note that an issue is required for all project contributions. The following is a list of the different types of contributions:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - To help keep the project running smoothly
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Report Bugs
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Fix Bugs
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - To help improve existing functionality
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Change Request
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Implement Changes
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - To help increase the projects functionality
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Feature Request
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Algorithm Request
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Data Structure Request
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Communication and Issues
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Please make sure you check out the issues first, someone might have started working on a similar idea already. If you are sure that what you want to contribute is new, then please open an issue describing what you want to implement before you decide to submit a PR.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Please refer to the Issue Templates to see the different types of contributions.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Submitting a Pull Requests
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Pull requests should be submitted from your cloned repository's master branch to the upstream master branch. Please make sure that you rebase your local branch against the upstream branch before you submit your pull request.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Please make sure to refer to the Pull Request Guideline when submitting a new one.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Coding Conventions
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: We follow the official Microsoft C# Coding Conventions (see: below). Most of the styleguide is supported by default on Visual Studio, but you need to set it up as a policy from the Solution/Project properties window, in case you are using Visual Studio Community.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Please refer to the following guidelines:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - MS C# Coding Conventions
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - MS Framework Design Guidelines
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: NuGet and 3rd Party Libraries
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: If your implementation depends on a 3rd party library, and you think it is critical, then please communicate this before you change the solution/projects references. We are striving to provide a bare-bones library of data structures and algorithms.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: In all cases, you should not commit the installed 3rd party libraries into the project. The README document will provide all the steps anyone would need to compile the library on their machine.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Source Code Testing
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: You should write a test for every data structure and algorithm you implement. The test should be created under the UnitTest project and in the corresponding packages:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - AlgorithmsTests: Package hosting unit tests for the Algorithms project.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - DataStructuresTests: Package hosting unit tests for the Data Structures project.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Steps
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 1.  Fork the repo.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 2.  Add a breaking test for your change.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 3.  Make the tests pass.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 4.  Push your fork.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 5.  Submit a pull request.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Code Style
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Running the tests using rake (with no args) will also check for style issues in the code. Ideally all submissions would pass these checks. If the code style is causing issues (particularly the method or class size) we can work with you to correct it. Don't let it stop you from contributing.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Contributing
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: While not required to contribute, we recommend RVM to manage your rubies.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 1.  Read the Contributor Code of Conduct
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 2.  Fork it
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 3.  Clone the project git clone git@github.com:[YOUR GITHUB USERNAME]/aasm.git
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 4.  cd aasm
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 5.  Create your feature branch git checkout -b my-new-feature
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 6.  Write tests for your changes (feature/bug)
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 7.  Write your (feature/bugfix)
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 8.  Install the dependencies appraisal install
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 9.  Run the tests appraisal rspec
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 10. Commit your changes git commit -am 'Added some feature'
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 11. Push to the branch git push origin my-new-feature
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 12. Create new Pull Request
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Contributing to YamlDotNet
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Welcome!
Thanks for your interest in contributing to this project. Any contribution will
be gladly accepted, provided that they are generally useful and follow the
conventions of the project.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: If you are considering a contribution, please read and follow these guidelines.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Pull requests
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: All contributions should be submitted as pull requests.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 1.  Please create one pull request for each feature. This results in smaller pull requests that are easier to review and validate.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 2.  Avoid reformatting existing code unless you are making other changes to it.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Cleaning-up of usings is acceptable, if you made other changes to that file.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - If you believe that some code is badly formatted and needs fixing, isolate that change in a separate pull request.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 1.  Always add one or more unit tests that prove that the feature / fix you are submitting is working correctly.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 2.  Please describe the motivation behind the pull request. Explain what was the problem / requirement. Unless the implementation is self-explanatory, also describe the solution.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Of course, there's no need to be too verbose. Usually one or two lines will be enough.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Project organization
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: The main project, YamlDotNet.csproj, is organized in three main namespaces: Core, RepresentationModel and Serialization. The Core namespace contains everything that is related to reading and writing YAML. The RepresentationModel has classes that represent a YAML stream, similar to XmlDocument for XML. The Serialization namespace contains classes to serialize and deserialize object graphs to / from YAML.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Unit tests are all contained in the project named YamlDotNet.Test.csproj.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: The PerformanceTests folder contains various projects that contain performance tests that compare various versions of YamlDotNet to detect the impact of new features.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Building / multiplatform
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
The project uses a cake script to specify the build recipe.
If you are on Windows, use the build.ps1 script to build the project:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: .\build.ps1 -Target Package
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: You should see an output similar to this.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: If you are on Linux, use build.sh:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: .\build.sh --target Package
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Alternatively, if you want to avoid installing the build tools, there is another script that uses a docker container to build. Just replace build.sh by docker-build.sh:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: .\docker-build.sh --target Package
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Build targets
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: The following table describes the most important build targets:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
|           Target             |                   Description                      |                          Example                            |
|------------------------------|----------------------------------------------------|-------------------------------------------------------------|
| Clean                        | Deletes the build output.                          | .\build.ps1 -Target Clean                                 |
| Build                        | Builds a single configuration.                     | .\build.ps1 -Target Build -Configuration Release-Unsigned |
| Test                         | Runs unit tests on a single configuration.         | .\build.ps1 -Target Test -Configuration Release-Unsigned  |
| Build-Release-Configurations | Builds all the release configurations.             | .\build.ps1 -Target Build-Release-Configurations          |
| Test-Release-Configurations  | Runs unit tests on all the release configurations. | .\build.ps1 -Target Test-Release-Configurations           |
| Package                      | Build the NuGet package.                           | .\build.ps1 -Target Package                               |
| Document                     | Generates the samples documentation.               | .\build.ps1 -Target Document                              |
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
Building for Unity requires installing
Visual Studio Tools for Unity.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Target platforms
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: The project targets the following platforms:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: - .NET Framework 4.5
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: - .NET Framework 3.5
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: - .NET Framework 2.0
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: - .NET Standard 2.1
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: - .NET Standard 1.3
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: - Unity Subset v3.5
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: In the csproj, the TargetFrameworks element also targets the following platforms for technical reasons:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: - net40: this is a hack used to target Unity. That target is overriden and in reality it targets Unity Subset v3.5.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: - .NET Core 3.0: this is to benefit from nullable annotations in the BCL.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Build configurations
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: The following table describes the available build configurations:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
| Configuration |             Description                                                             |
|---------------|-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| Debug         | Default debug build.                                                                |
| Release       | Release build.                                                                      |
| Debug-AOT     | Builds the AOT tests project, that tests compatibility with mono's AOT compilation. |
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
There are a few differences between the various target platforms,
mainly in the reflection API. In order to adapt the code to each platform,
#if ... #endif sections are used. When possible, such sections should be placed
in the Helpers/Portability.cs file. An effective technique is to define an extension
method that is used through the code, and has different implementations depending
on the build variables.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: AOT compatibility
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Some platforms - such as IOS - forbid dynamic code generation. This prevents Just-in-Time compilation (JIT) from being used. In those cases, one can use Mono's Ahead-of-Time compilation (AOT). This results on a precompiled assembly that does not rely on JIT. There are some limitations however, most of them related to usage of generics.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: In order to ensure that YamlDotNet is compatible with AOT compilation, an automatic test has been created that runs on every commit on Travis CI. That test exercises the serializer and deserializer to help identify AOT-related problems.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Coding style
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Attempt to follow the SOLID principles. In particular, try to give each type a single responsibility, and favor composition to combine features.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: As long as you keep the code readable, I don't care too much about any specific coding convention. There are only a few rules that should be honored:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Use 4 spaces to indent.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Each class / interface / struct / delegate goes to its own file.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - The only acceptable exception is for small and closely related types.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Use sane indentation rules. Break long lines when needed, but don't be obsessive:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - This is OK:
Label: DC – Deal with the code
DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - This is OK too:
Label: DC – Deal with the code
DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - This is not very good:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Traverse(new ObjectDescriptor(value.Value, underlyingType, value.Type, value.ScalarStyle), visitor, currentDepth);
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - This is awful:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
Traverse(new ObjectDescriptor(value.Value,
underlyingType,
value.Type,
value.ScalarStyle),
visitor,
currentDepth);
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: How to Contribute to Abseil
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
We'd love to accept your patches and contributions to this project. There are
just a few small guidelines you need to follow.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
NOTE: If you are new to GitHub, please start by reading Pull Request
howto
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Contributor License Agreement
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Contributions to this project must be accompanied by a Contributor License
Agreement. You (or your employer) retain the copyright to your contribution,
this simply gives us permission to use and redistribute your contributions as
part of the project. Head over to https://cla.developers.google.com/ to see
your current agreements on file or to sign a new one.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
You generally only need to submit a CLA once, so if you've already submitted one
(even if it was for a different project), you probably don't need to do it
again.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Contribution Guidelines
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Potential contributors sometimes ask us if the Abseil project is the appropriate
home for their utility library code or for specific functions implementing
missing portions of the standard. Often, the answer to this question is "no".
We
understood by everyone and so that contributors can have a better intuition
about whether Abseil might be interested in adopting a new library.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Priorities
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Although our mission is to augment the C++ standard library, our goal is not to
provide a full forward-compatible implementation of the latest standard. For us
to consider a library for inclusion in Abseil, it is not enough that a library
is useful. We generally choose to release a library when it meets at least one
of the following criteria:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- Widespread usage - Using our internal codebase to help gauge usage, most
of the libraries we've released have tens of thousands of users.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- Anticipated widespread usage - Pre-adoption of some standard-compliant
APIs may not have broad adoption initially but can be expected to pick up
usage when it replaces legacy APIs. absl::from_chars, for example,
replaces existing code that converts strings to numbers and will therefore
likely see usage growth.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- High impact - APIs that provide a key solution to a specific problem,
such as absl::FixedArray, have higher impact than usage numbers may signal
and are released because of their importance.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- Direct support for a library that falls under one of the above - When we
want access to a smaller library as an implementation detail for a
higher-priority library we plan to release, we may release it, as we did
with portions of absl/meta/type_traits.h. One consequence of this is that
the presence of a library in Abseil does not necessarily mean that other
similar libraries would be a high priority.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: API Freeze Consequences
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Via the
Abseil Compatibility Guidelines, we
have promised a large degree of API stability. In particular, we will not make
backward-incompatible changes to released APIs without also shipping a tool or
process that can upgrade our users' code. We are not yet at the point of easily
releasing such tools. Therefore, at this time, shipping a library establishes an
API contract which is borderline unchangeable. (We can add new functionality,
but we cannot easily change existing behavior.) This constraint forces us to
very carefully review all APIs that we ship.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Coding Style
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
To keep the source consistent, readable, diffable and easy to merge, we use a
fairly rigid coding style, as defined by the
google-styleguide project. All patches
will be expected to conform to the style outlined
here.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Guidelines for Pull Requests
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- If you are a Googler, it is preferable to first create an internal CL and
have it reviewed and submitted. The code propagation process will deliver
the change to GitHub.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Create small PRs that are narrowly focused on addressing a single
concern. We often receive PRs that are trying to fix several things at a
time, but if only one fix is considered acceptable, nothing gets merged and
both author's & review's time is wasted. Create more PRs to address
different concerns and everyone will be happy.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- For speculative changes, consider opening an Abseil
issue and discussing it first.
If you are suggesting a behavioral or API change, consider starting with an
Abseil proposal template.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Provide a good PR description as a record of what change is being
made and why it was made. Link to a GitHub issue if it exists.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Don't fix code style and formatting unless you are already changing that
line to address an issue. Formatting of modified lines may be done using
git clang-format. PRs with irrelevant changes won't be merged. If
you do want to fix formatting or style, do that in a separate PR.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Unless your PR is trivial, you should expect there will be reviewer comments
that you'll need to address before merging. We expect you to be reasonably
responsive to those comments, otherwise the PR will be closed after 2-3
weeks of inactivity.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Maintain clean commit history and use meaningful commit messages.
PRs with messy commit history are difficult to review and won't be merged.
Use rebase -i upstream/master to curate your commit history and/or to
bring in latest changes from master (but avoid rebasing in the middle of a
code review).
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Keep your PR up to date with upstream/master (if there are merge conflicts,
we can't really merge your change).
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- All tests need to be passing before your change can be merged. We
recommend you run tests locally (see below)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Exceptions to the rules can be made if there's a compelling reason for doing
so. That is - the rules are here to serve us, not the other way around, and
the rules need to be serving their intended purpose to be valuable.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - All submissions, including submissions by project members, require review.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: If you have Bazel installed, use bazel test --test_tag_filters="-benchmark" ... to run the unit tests.

If you are running the Linux operating system and have
Docker installed, you can also run the linux_*.sh

Label: No categories identified.

If a committer is no longer interested or cannot perform the committer duties listed above, they
should volunteer to be moved to emeritus status. In extreme cases this can also occur by a vote of
the committers per the voting process below.

Paragraph: Conflict resolution and voting
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
In general, we prefer that technical issues and committer status/TSC membership are amicably worked out
between the persons involved. If a dispute cannot be decided independently, the TSC can be
called in to decide an issue. If the TSC themselves cannot decide an issue, the issue will
be resolved by voting. The voting process is a simple majority in which each TSC receives one vote.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Contributing
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Please send pull requests against the development branch instead of master. The
master branch is reserved to contain only the latest official public release of
the framework.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Please stick to C# 4.0 (avoid features from C# 5, 6 and 7)
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: If possible, when contributing code to the framework, please avoid using C# language features from above C# 4.0. There are at least two reasons for this restriction:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: 1.  Mono: To keep compatibility with the most widespread versions of Mono (4.x). If you take a look at our Travis-CI builds, you might see that the builds are actually done and run using Mono, so using any language feature that is not supported there will cause a failing build;
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: 2.  Unity: Some language features might not be accessible when targeting .NET 3.5, which for a long time has been the only .NET Framework version that could be run from inside Unity.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: More specifically, when submitting pull-requests, please avoid using:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - The nameof(.) operator;
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Expression-bodied members;
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Null-conditional operators
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - string interpolation
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - async/await *
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - value tuples
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: * Unless you can guard those sections using conditional compilation clauses (i.e. #if NET35) and either exclude those code sections from the .NET 3.5 / Mono 4.0 builds or provide specific (possibly non-optimal) implementations for those platforms. Please take a look at the Accord.Compat namespace for help in filling missing functionality from higher platform versions if you run into any of those cases.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Please use Visual Studio's default code formatting
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: If possible, please use the same code formatting style as the default format offered by Visual Studio. This is the style that Visual Studio will format your code with when pressing Ctrl+E, D while in the editor.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Requirements
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
For non-bug-fixes, please open an issue first and discuss your idea to make sure we're on the same page.
Alternatively, prepend your PR title with [discuss] to have a conversation around the code.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: All PRs:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 1.  Must not break the test suite (yarn test), nor reduce test coverage (yarn coverage). If you're fixing a bug, include a test that would fail without your fix.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 2.  Must respect the .eslintrc.js (yarn test:lint). Ideally your editor supports eslint. Especially since the project is quite new, feel free to query default rules with us that don't make sense, or disable rules in a particular scope when it makes sense, together with a comment explaining why.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 3.  Must be isolated. Avoid grouping many, unrelated changes in a single PR.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 4.  GitHub now allows auto-squashing of commits in a PR, so no need to rebase your commits before final submission.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 1.  From Getting Started, your work should ideally be in its own feature branch.

Paragraph: Contributing to Actionhero
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: First, THANK YOU.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Actionhero would not be the success it is today without the contributions of many people. Actionhero is a community-led open source project. Thank you for taking the time to help out this open source project, and create something we can all use!
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: The Actionhero community
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Before you begin your contribution, please let us know in the Actionhero Slack team, which is available at https://slack.actionherojs.com. There are community members who can help you, and you may want to team up with another community member. This also helps ensure that more than one person isn't working on the same thing.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: By engaging the with Actionhero community or contributing to this or related projects, you agree to our Code of Conduct.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Pull Requests
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: All changes to Actionhero should be sent in as Pull Requests to our Github Project. Changes by any other method will be instantly rejected. GitHub allows us to coordinate and communicate in a single place. Pull requests also allow us to run our test suite against all new code to ensure that things still work the way they are supposed to after your change.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Testing
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Actionhero is a large project with lost of different servers and tools. We don't expect you to know about everything, that's why we have a robust test suite. This allows us to ensure that no matter who makes a change, Actionhero will continue to work the way it is supposed to.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: With that in mind, all new features to Actionhero must also include additions to the test suite to ensure that in the future, we can maintain your work. When writing tests, write the smallest test that ensures that your work is tested. IE: if you write a new initializer, you probably can test the method directly and you don't need an action test or an integration test.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Every contribution to the codebase should have an associated test
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Be sure that your changes pass the test suite! Run npm test to run the full test suite.
You will need redis and node.js installed. We also have an integration which relies on chromedriver (an automated chrome browser). You can install this on OSX via brew install chromedriver No other external dependencies are needed.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: If you need help writing tests, please ask for help in the slack team
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Linting
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: We use prettier.js to manage our lint rules. We run prettier as part of our test suite, and your contributions must pass. Prettier is very opinionated and inflexible such that we cannot inject our own opinions. There are no eslint/jshint files to manage in this project.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Documentation
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: If your contribution adds a new feature of modifies an existing behavior, document your changes using Typedoc. We use Typedoc to automatically document Actionhero, and build https://docs.actionherojs.com on every push to the master branch or merge of your Pull Request. There are many plugins to help you with this, and are built into editors like VSCode.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: If you are documenting code, inline JSdocs are preferred. The only exceptions are tutorials, which are stand-alone markdown files in the ./tutorials directory of the www.actionherojs.com project. An example of a newly documented method would be:
Label: DC – Deal with the code
DC – Deal with the code
DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: The "marketing" www.actionherojs.com site is built via this project separately.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
We'd love to accept your sample apps and patches! Before we can take them, we
have to jump a couple of legal hurdles.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Please fill out either the individual or corporate Contributor License Agreement
(CLA).
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- If you are an individual writing original source code and you're sure you
own the intellectual property, then you'll need to sign an individual CLA.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- If you work for a company that wants to allow you to contribute your work,
then you'll need to sign a corporate CLA.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Follow either of the two links above to access the appropriate CLA and
instructions for how to sign and return it. Once we receive it, we'll be able to
accept your pull requests.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Contributing A Patch
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 1.  Submit an issue describing your proposed change to the repo in question.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 2.  The repo owner will respond to your issue promptly.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
3.  If your proposed change is accepted, and you haven't already done so, sign a
Contributor License Agreement (see details above).
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 4.  Fork the desired repo, develop and test your code changes.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
5.  Ensure that your code adheres to the existing style in the sample to which
you are contributing. Refer to the
Google Cloud Platform Samples Style Guide for the
recommended coding standards for this organization.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 6.  Ensure that your code has an appropriate set of unit tests which all pass.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 7.  Submit a pull request.
Label: CF – Contribution flow
