Paragraph: Useful Scripts
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: - npm run bootstrap This runs lerna bootstrap which will install dependencies in this repository's packages and cross-link packages where necessary.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: - npm run build This compiles TypeScript code in each package (this is especially important if one package relies on changes in another when you're running tests). This is just an alias for lerna run tsc.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: - npm run format This checks that formatting has been applied with Prettier.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: - npm test This runs all Jest tests in all packages in this repository.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
- If you need to run tests for only one package, you can pass normal Jest CLI options:
$ npm test -- packages/toolkit
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: - npm run create-package [name] This runs a script that automates a couple of parts of creating a new package.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Creating a Package
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 1.  In a new branch, create a new Lerna package:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: $ npm run create-package new-package
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: This will ask you some questions about the new package. Start with 0.0.0 as the first version (look generally at some of the other packages for how the package.json is structured).
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 2.  Add tsc script to the new package's package.json file:
Label: BW – Build local workspace
BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 3.  Start developing ?.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Contributing
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
First off, thank you for considering contributing to Active Admin. It's people
like you that make Active Admin such a great tool.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Where do I go from here?
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
If you've noticed a bug or have a feature request, make one! It's
generally best if you get confirmation of your bug or approval for your feature
request this way before starting to code.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
If you have a general question about activeadmin, you can post it on Stack
Overflow, the issue tracker is only for bugs and feature requests.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Fork & create a branch
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
If this is something you think you can fix, then fork Active Admin and create
a branch with a descriptive name.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: A good branch name would be (where issue #325 is the ticket you're working on):
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: git checkout -b 325-add-japanese-translations
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Get the test suite running
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Make sure you're using a recent ruby and have the bundler gem installed, at
least version 1.14.3.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: You'll also need chrome installed in order to run cucumber scenarios.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Now install the development dependencies:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: bundle install
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Then install javascript dependencies with Yarn (requires a current version of Node.js):
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: bin/yarn install
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: JS assets are located in app/javascript/active_admin. The config will take care of compiling a complete bundle with Rollup using the build script and exported to app/assets/javascripts/active_admin/base.js ready to be used by Sprockets.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: To update javascript bundle run (add -w flag for watch mode):
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: bin/yarn build
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Now you should be able to run the entire suite using:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: bin/rake
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
The test run will generate a sample Rails application in tmp/test_apps to run the
tests against.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
If you want to test against a Rails version different from the latest, make sure
you use the correct Gemfile, for example:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: export BUNDLE_GEMFILE=gemfiles/rails_60/Gemfile
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Warning SCSS assets are aimed to be used indifferently with Sprockets and webpacker.
As such, make sure not to use any sass-rails directives such as asset-url or image-url.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Implement your fix or feature
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
At this point, you're ready to make your changes! Feel free to ask for help;
everyone is a beginner at first :smile_cat:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: View your changes in a Rails application
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
Active Admin is meant to be used by humans, not cucumbers. So make sure to take
a look at your changes in a browser.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: To boot up a test Rails app:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: bin/rake local server
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
This will automatically create a Rails app if none already exists, and store it
in the tmp/development_apps folder.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
You should now be able to open http://localhost:3000/admin in your browser.
You can log in using:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
User: admin@example.com
Password: password
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
If you need to perform any other commands on the test application, just pass
them to the local rake task. For example, to boot the rails console:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: bin/rake local console
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Or to migrate the database, if you create a new migration or just play around
with the db:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: bin/rake local db:migrate
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Get the style right
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
Your patch should follow the same conventions & pass the same code quality
checks as the rest of the project. bin/rake lint will give you feedback in
this regard. You can check & fix style issues by running each linter
individually. Run bin/rake -T lint to see the available linters.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Make a Pull Request
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
At this point, you should switch back to your master branch and make sure it's
up to date with Active Admin's master branch:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
git remote add upstream git@github.com:activeadmin/activeadmin.git
git checkout master
git pull upstream master
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Then update your feature branch from your local copy of master, and push it!
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
git checkout 325-add-japanese-translations
git rebase master
git push --set-upstream origin 325-add-japanese-translations
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Finally, go to GitHub and make a Pull Request :D
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
CircleCI will run our test suite against all supported Rails versions. We care
about quality, so your PR won't be merged until all tests pass. It's unlikely,
but it's possible that your changes pass tests in one Rails version but fail in
another. In that case, you'll have to setup your development environment (as
explained in step 3) to use the problematic Rails version, and investigate
what's going on!
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Keeping your Pull Request updated
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
If a maintainer asks you to "rebase" your PR, they're saying that a lot of code
has changed, and that you need to update your branch so it's easier to merge.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
To learn more about rebasing in Git, there are a lot of good
resources but here's the suggested workflow:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
git checkout 325-add-japanese-translations
git pull --rebase upstream master
git push --force-with-lease 325-add-japanese-translations
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Merging a PR (maintainers only)
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: A PR can only be merged into master by a maintainer if:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - It is passing CI.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- It has been approved by at least two maintainers. If it was a maintainer who
opened the PR, only one extra approval is needed.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - It has no requested changes.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - It is up to date with current master.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Any maintainer is allowed to merge a PR if all of these conditions are
met.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Shipping a release (maintainers only)
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Maintainers need to do the following to push out a release:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Switch to the master branch and make sure it's up to date.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- Make sure you have chandler properly configured. Chandler is used to
automatically submit github release notes from the changelog right after
pushing the gem to rubygems.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Run one of bin/rake release:prepare_{prerelease,prepatch,patch,preminor,minor,premajor,major}, push the result and create a PR.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Review and merge the PR. The generated changelog in the PR should include all user visible changes you intend to ship.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Run bin/rake release from the target branch once the PR is merged.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Contributing guidelines
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: We gladly accept bugfixes, but are not actively looking to add new gateways. Please follow the guidelines here to ensure your work is accepted.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: New Gateways
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: We're not taking on many new gateways at the moment. The team maintaining ActiveMerchant is small and with the limited resources available, we generally prefer not to support a gateway than to support a gateway poorly.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Please see the ActiveMerchant Guide to Contributing a new Gateway for information on creating a new gateway. You can place your gateway code in your application's lib/active_merchant/billing folder to use it.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: We would like to work with the community to figure out how gateways can release and maintain their integrations outside of the the ActiveMerchant repository. Please join the discussion if you're interested or have ideas.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Gateway placement within Shopify is available by invitation only at this time.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Issues & Bugfixes
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Reporting issues
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: When filing a new Issue:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Please make clear in the subject what gateway the issue is about.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Include the version of ActiveMerchant, Ruby, ActiveSupport, and Nokogiri you are using.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Pull request guidelines
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: When submitting a pull request to resolve an issue:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 1.  Fork it and clone your new repo
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 2.  Create a branch (git checkout -b my_awesome_feature)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 3.  Commit your changes (git add my/awesome/file.rb; git commit -m "Added my awesome feature")
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 4.  Push your changes to your fork (git push origin my_awesome_feature)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 5.  Open a Pull Request
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Version/Release Management
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Contributors don't need to worry about versions, this is something Committers do at important milestones:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 1.  Check the semantic versioning page for info on how to version the new release.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 2.  Update the  ActiveMerchant::VERSION constant in lib/active_merchant/version.rb.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 3.  Add a CHANGELOG entry for the new release with the date
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 4.  Tag the release commit on GitHub: bundle exec rake tag_release
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 5.  Release the gem to rubygems using ShipIt
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Contributing to Ransack
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Please take a moment to review this document to make contributing easy and
effective for everyone involved!
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Ransack is an open source project and we encourage contributions.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Please do not use the issue tracker for personal support requests. Stack
Overflow is a better place for that where a wider community can help you!
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Filing an issue
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Good issue reports are extremely helpful!  Please only open an issue if a bug
is caused by Ransack, is new (has not already been reported), and can be
reproduced from the information you provide.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Steps:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
1.  Use the GitHub issue search — check if the issue has already been
reported.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
2.  Check if the issue has been fixed — try to reproduce it using the
master branch in the repository.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
3.  Isolate the real problem — make sure the issue is really a bug in
Ransack and not in your code or another gem.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
4.  Report the issue by providing the link to a self-contained
gist like this or
this. Please use
these code examples as a bug-report template for your Ransack issue!
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: If you do not provide a self-contained gist and would like your issue to be reviewed, do provide at a minimum:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- A comprehensive list of steps to reproduce the issue, or even better, a
passing/failing test spec.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- Whether you are using Ransack through another gem like ActiveAdmin,
SimpleForm, etc.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - The versions of Ruby, Rails, Ransack and the database.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Any relevant stack traces ("Full trace" preferred).
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Issues filed without the above information or that remain open without activity
for 14 days will be closed. They can be re-opened if actionable information to reproduce the issue is provided.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Pull requests
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
We gladly accept pull requests to fix bugs and, in some circumstances, add new
features to Ransack. If you'd like to contribute and wonder what would be
helpful, simply run a search for "FIXME" and "TODO" on the codebase :smiley:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
If you're new to contributing to open source, welcome! It can seem scary, so
here is a [great blog post to help you get started]
(http://robots.thoughtbot.com/8-new-steps-for-fixing-other-peoples-code),
step by step.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
Before issuing a pull request, please make sure that all specs are passing,
that any new features have test coverage, and that anything that breaks
backward compatibility has a very good reason for doing so.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Here's a quick guide:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 1.  Fork the repo.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 2.  Create a thoughtfully-named branch for your changes (git checkout -b my-new-feature).
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
3.  Install the development dependencies by running bundle install.
To install rails other than latest (set in Gemfile): RAILS='5-2-stable' bundle install
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: $ RAILS='5-2-stable' bundle install
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
4.  Begin by running the tests. We only take pull requests with passing tests,
and it's great to know that you have a clean slate:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: $ bundle exec rake spec
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: The test suite runs by default with SQLite3. To run the test suite with PostgreSQL or MySQL, use:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
$ DB=pg bundle exec rake spec (`DB=postgres` & `DB=postgresql` work too)
$ DB=mysql bundle exec rake spec
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: For Postgres and MySQL, databases are expected to exist, called 'ransack'. To create use these commands (assuming OS X and Homebrew):
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Postgres
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: $ createdb ransack
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: MySQL
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
$ mysql -u root
mysql> create database ransack;
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: The test suite runs by default
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: To run only the tests in a particular file: bundle exec rspec <path/to/filename>
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: $ bundle exec rspec spec/ransack/search_spec.rb
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: To run a single test in that file: bundle exec rspec <path/to/filename> -e "test name"
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: $ bundle exec rspec spec/ransack/search_spec.rb -e "accepts a context option"
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
5.  Hack away! Please use Ruby features that are compatible down to Ruby 2.3.
Since version 2.3.1, Ransack no longer maintains Ruby 2.2 compatibility.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
6.  Add tests for your changes. Only refactoring and documentation changes
require no new tests. If you are adding functionality or fixing a bug, we
need a test!
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 7.  Make the tests pass.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
8.  Update the Change Log. If you are adding new functionality, document it in
the README.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 9.  Make sure git knows your name and email address in your ~/.gitconfig file:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
$ git config --global user.name "Your Name"
$ git config --global user.email "contributor@example.com"
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
10. Commit your changes (git commit -am 'Add feature/fix bug/improve docs').
If your pull request only contains documentation changes, please remember
to add [skip ci] to the beginning of your commit message so the Travis
test suite doesn't :runner: needlessly.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
11. If necessary, rebase your commits into logical chunks, without errors. To
interactively rebase and cherry-pick from, say, the last 10 commits:
git rebase -i HEAD~10, then git push -f.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
12. Push the branch up to your fork on GitHub
(git push origin my-new-feature) and from GitHub submit a pull request to
Ransack's master branch.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
At this point you're waiting on us. We like to at least comment on, if not
accept, pull requests within three business days (and, typically, one business
day). We may suggest some changes or improvements or alternatives.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Some things that will increase the chance that your pull request is accepted:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Include tests that fail without your code, and pass with it.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Update the README, the change log, the wiki documentation... anything that is
affected by your contribution.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Use idiomatic Ruby and follow the syntax conventions below.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Syntax:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Indent with two spaces, no tabs.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - 80 characters per line.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - No trailing whitespace. Blank lines should not have any space.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Prefer &&/|| over and/or.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - MyClass.my_method(my_arg) not my_method( my_arg ) or my_method my_arg.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - a = b and not a=b.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- a_method { |block| ... } and not a_method { | block | ... } or
a_method{|block| ...}.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Prefer simplicity, readability, and maintainability over terseness.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Follow the conventions you see used in the code already.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: And in case we didn't emphasize it enough: We love tests!
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Our Pledge
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
In the interest of fostering an open and welcoming environment, we as
contributors and maintainers pledge to making participation in our project and
our community a harassment-free experience for everyone, regardless of age, body
size, disability, ethnicity, gender identity and expression, level of experience,
nationality, personal appearance, race, religion, or sexual identity and
orientation.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Our Standards
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph:
Examples of behavior that contributes to creating a positive environment
include:
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: - Using welcoming and inclusive language
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: - Being respectful of differing viewpoints and experiences
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: - Gracefully accepting constructive criticism
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: - Focusing on what is best for the community
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: - Showing empathy towards other community members
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Examples of unacceptable behavior by participants include:
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph:
- The use of sexualized language or imagery and unwelcome sexual attention or
advances
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: - Trolling, insulting/derogatory comments, and personal or political attacks
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: - Public or private harassment
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph:
- Publishing others' private information, such as a physical or electronic
address, without explicit permission
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph:
- Other conduct which could reasonably be considered inappropriate in a
professional setting
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Our Responsibilities
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph:
Project maintainers are responsible for clarifying the standards of acceptable
behavior and are expected to take appropriate and fair corrective action in
response to any instances of unacceptable behavior.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph:
Project maintainers have the right and responsibility to remove, edit, or
reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, and other contributions
that are not aligned to this Code of Conduct, or to ban temporarily or
permanently any contributor for other behaviors that they deem inappropriate,
threatening, offensive, or harmful.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Scope
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
This Code of Conduct applies both within project spaces and in public spaces
when an individual is representing the project or its community. Examples of
representing a project or community include using an official project e-mail
address, posting via an official social media account, or acting as an appointed
representative at an online or offline event. Representation of a project may be
further defined and clarified by project maintainers.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Enforcement
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Instances of abusive, harassing, or otherwise unacceptable behavior may be
reported by contacting the project maintainer at Sergio Cambra. All
complaints will be reviewed and investigated and will result in a response that
is deemed necessary and appropriate to the circumstances. The project team is
obligated to maintain confidentiality with regard to the reporter of an incident.
Further details of specific enforcement policies may be posted separately.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Project maintainers who do not follow or enforce the Code of Conduct in good
faith may face temporary or permanent repercussions as determined by other
members of the project's leadership.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Attribution
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
This Code of Conduct is adapted from the Contributor Covenant, version 1.4,
available at http://contributor-covenant.org/version/1/4
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
If you want to contribute get in touch with the project members and ask for guidance.
This project is a community driven project, so get in touch if you want to participate.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: Unit tests
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Activiti uses now AssertJ
as alternative to default JUnit assertions. This makes tests more readable and provides clearer failure messages.
Please, make sure that you are using AssertJ assertions for every new test.
I.e.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - assertThat(myBoolean).isTrue(); instead of assertTrue(myBoolean);
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - assertThat(actual).isEqualTo(expected); instead of assertEquals(expected, actual);
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - assertThat(myList).containsExactly("a", "b", "c"); instead of assertTrue(myList.contains("a", "b", "c"));
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Branches naming convention
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
If you are creating branches directly in the main repository, this is
the naming convention to be used for branches:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - username-issueNumber-anythingYouWant
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: This document specifies how to contribute code to CAF.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Git Workflow
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Please adhere to the following Git naming and commit message conventions.
Having a consistent work flow and style reduces friction and makes organizing
contributions a lot easier for all sides.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Branches
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Our main branch is master. It reflects the latest development changes for
the next release and should always compile. Nightly versions use the
master. Users looking for a production-ready state are encouraged to use
the latest release version instead.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Push trivial bugfixes (e.g. typos, missing includes, etc.) consisting of a
single commit directly to master. Otherwise, implement your changes in a
topic or bugfix branch and file a pull request on GitHub.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Implement new features and non-trivial changes in a topic branch with
naming convention topic/short-description.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Implement fixes for existing issues in a bugfix branch with naming
convention issue/$num, where $num is the issue ID on GitHub.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Simply use a fork of CAF if you are an external contributor.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Pull Requests
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Check the following steps to prepare for a merge into master after completing
work in a topic or bugfix branch (or fork).
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Squash your commits into a single one if necessary. Each commit should
represent a coherent set of changes.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Wait for a code review and the test results of our CI.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Address any review feedback and fix all issues reported by the CI.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - A maintainer will merge the pull request when all issues are resolved.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Commit Message Style
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Summarize the changes in no more than 50 characters in the first line.
Capitalize and write in an imperative present tense, e.g., "Fix bug" as
opposed to "Fixes bug" or "Fixed bug".
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Suppress the dot at the end of the first line. Think of it as the header of
the following description.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Leave the second line empty.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Optionally add a long description written in full sentences beginning on the
third line. Indent at 72 characters per line.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Coding Style
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
When contributing source code, please adhere to the following coding style,
which is loosely based on the Google C++ Style
Guide and the coding
conventions used by the C++ Standard Library.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Example for the Impatient
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: // libcaf_example/caf/example/my_class.hpp
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: #pragma once
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: #include <string>
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: // use "//" for regular comments and "///" for doxygen
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
namespace caf {
namespace example {
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: General
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Use 2 spaces per indentation level.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Use at most 80 characters per line.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Never use tabs.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Never use C-style casts.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Never declare more than one variable per line.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- Only separate functions with vertical whitespaces and use comments to
document logical blocks inside functions.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- Use .hpp as suffix for header files and .cpp as suffix for implementation
files.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Bind * and & to the type, e.g., const std::string& arg.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Never increase the indentation level for namespaces and access modifiers.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Use the order public, protected, and then private in classes.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- Always use auto to declare a variable unless you cannot initialize it
immediately or if you actually want a type conversion. In the latter case,
provide a comment why this conversion is necessary.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Never use unwrapped, manual resource management such as new and delete.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Prefer using T = X over typedef X T.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- Insert a whitespaces after keywords: if (...), template <...>,
while (...), etc.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Put opening braces on the same line:
Label: DC – Deal with the code
DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- Use standard order for readability: C standard libraries, C++ standard
libraries, OS-specific headers (usually guarded by ifdef), other libraries,
and finally (your) CAF headers. Include caf/config.hpp before the standard
headers if you need to include platform-dependent headers. Use angle brackets
for system includes and doublequotes otherwise.

- All names except macros and template parameters should be

Paragraph:
- Types and variables should be nouns, while functions performing an action
should be "command" verbs. Classes used to implement metaprogramming
functions also should use verbs, e.g., remove_const.

- Private and protected member variables use the suffix _ while getter and
setter functions use the name without suffix:

for generic function arguments. Suffix both with s for

Paragraph: Headers
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- Each .cpp file has an associated .hpp file.
Exceptions to this rule are unit tests and main.cpp files.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- Each class has its own pair of header and implementation files and the
relative path for the files are derived from the full class name. For
example, the header file for caf::example::my_class of libcaf_example is
located at libcaf_example/caf/example/my_class.hpp and the source file at
libcaf_example/src/example/my_class.cpp.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - All header files use #pragma once to prevent multiple inclusion.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Do not #include when a forward declaration suffices.

Paragraph:
- Each library component must provide a fwd.hpp header providing forward
declarations for all types used in the user API.

Paragraph:
- Each library component should provide an all.hpp header that contains the
main page for the documentation and includes all headers for the user API.

Paragraph: - Use inline for small functions (rule of thumb: 10 lines or less).

Paragraph: Template Metaprogramming
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
Despite its power, template metaprogramming came to the language pretty
much by accident. Templates were never meant to be used for compile-time
algorithms and type transformations. This is why C++ punishes metaprogramming
with an insane amount of syntax noise. In CAF, we make excessive use of
templates. To keep the code readable despite all the syntax noise, we have some
extra rules for formatting metaprogramming code.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- Break using name = ... statements always directly after = if it
does not fit in one line.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- Consider the semantics of a metaprogramming function. For example,
std::conditional is an if-then-else construct. Hence, place the if-clause
on its own line and do the same for the two cases.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- Use one level of indentation per "open" template and place the closing >,
>::type or >::value on its own line. For example:
Label: DC – Deal with the code
DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- Note that this is not necessary when simply defining a type alias.
When dealing with "ordinary" templates, indenting based on the position of
the opening < is ok, e.g.:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

using response_handle_type = response_handle<Subtype, message,
ResponseHandleTag>;

Paragraph: Contribution Guidelines
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: This library is the culmination of the expertise of many members of the open source community who have dedicated their time and hard work. The best way to ask for help or propose a new idea is to create a new issue while creating a Pull Request with your code changes allows you to share your own innovations with the rest of the community.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: The following are some guidelines to observe when creating issues or PRs:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Be friendly; it is important that we can all enjoy a safe space as we are all working on the same project and it is okay for people to have different ideas
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Use code blocks; it helps us help you when we can read your code! On that note also refrain from pasting more than 30 lines of code in a post, instead create a gist if you need to share large snippets
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Use reasonable titles; refrain from using overly long or capitalized titles as they are usually annoying and do little to encourage others to help :smile:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Be detailed; refrain from mentioning code problems without sharing your source code and always give information regarding your board and version of the library
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Issues
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: If you need help with using Duality, please consider asking the community first. The forum is the right place to gather advice and evidence about potential bugs and problems and many issues are discussed there before proceeding to be reported officially on GitHub. The following lists contain a sample of core points you should include in your issue report.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: (Of course, if you already have all the evidence, feel free to submit a new issue right away!)
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Bug Reports
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Short summary of the problem in 1-3 sentences in the first paragraph. Followed by a more thorough description of the issue (if applicable)
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - A few easy steps to reproduce the behavior. Provide sample code and Resources where useful.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Complete logfiles (if applicable)
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Screenshots (if applicable and useful)
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - An existing workaround (if applicable)
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Feature Requests
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - The use cases you see for this feature.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - If there are other ways to achieve the same, describe them and describe how your feature would be an improvement.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Side effects and implications of having this feature.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Mockup screenshots (if applicable)
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - A sketch of potential implementations (if applicable and useful)
Label: No categories identified.

Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Discovering the project structure
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
AdAdawy source code is an Android project organized in modules.
There are four main modules:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - app: The Android application itself
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - tcpdump: A module dedicated to build pcap library and tcpdump binary
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - webserver: A module dedicated to build a simple HTTP server binary based on mongoose
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - libraries/RootCommands: A vendorize Android library to run root shell commands
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
The three last modules are independant and used by the app module.
Modalirazing the application allow faster build time and simplier maintainance.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Building the project
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
Building the project will require the latest versions of Android SDK (Software Development Kit) and NDK (Native Development kit).
They can easily be installed or updated using Android Studio.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Building with Gradle
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
1.  Ensure you have Android SDK and NDK installed.
If not:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: - Option 1: Install Android Studio or,
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
- Option 2: Install command line tools and install build tools and ndk bundle with sdk manager:
tools/bin/sdkmanager "build-tools;x.y.z" ndk-bundle where x.y.z is the latest version
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
2.  Export ANDROID_HOME environment variable pointing to your Android SDK:
export ANDROID_HOME=/path/to/your/sdk
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
3.  Launch a build:
./gradlew assembleRelease
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: The first full build of the apk could take a lot of time, about 20 minutes, whereas an incremental build of the app module takes less than a dozen of seconds.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Running on emulator
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: In order to test the application on emulator, disable the root check in the Constants source file.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: How can I contribute?
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: Reporting bugs
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Note: Before submitting a bug report, please use the GitHub search on Issues page to check if there is already similar reports.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: How do I submit a (good) bug report?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Use a clear and descriptive title for the issue to identify the problem.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Describe the exact steps which reproduce the problem in as many details as possible.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- Provide specific examples to demonstrate the steps.
Include hosts sources or domains you use, web pages URL you test.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Describe the behavior you observed after following the steps and point out what exactly is the problem with that behavior.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Explain which behavior you expected to see instead and why.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- If you're reporting that AdAway crashed, include a logcat.
Use adb logcat if you have developer settings enabled on your device or use any application like CatLog to save logs.
Include the crash report in the issue in a code block, a file attachment, or put it in a gist and provide link to that gist.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- Specify which version of AdAway you're using.
You can get the exact version by opening in-app help and checking the last About tab.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- Specify the Android version and the ROM you're using.
You can also include any root or customization related information like Magisk or SuperSU version and Xposed modules is installed.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Suggesting enhancements
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: How do I submit a (good) enhancement suggestion?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Enhancement suggestions are welcome.
After refining your idea or discussing it on development forum, create an issue and provide the following information:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Use a clear and descriptive title for the issue to identify the suggestion.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Provide a step-by-step description of the suggested enhancement in as many details as possible, including specific examples.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Describe the current behavior and explain which behavior you expected to see instead and why.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Explain why this enhancement would be useful to most users.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Translating to your language
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Translations are also welcome.
Moreover, they do not require a development environment, only a web browser.
So if you want to complete or edit your language support for the application, check the translation guide.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Critical is an open source project. It is licensed using the
Apache Software License 2.0.
We really appreciate pull requests and bug reports, here are our guidelines:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
1.  If filing a bug report, please verify the issue is with Critical first. A good sanity check is:
does the issue have to do with styles not being correctly captured? If so, test with Penthouse.
If it works with Penthouse then it's a Critical bug and we encourage you to open up a new ticket with details.
Does the bug have to do with inlining styles, general module failures or installation issues? Those are also
possibly Critical bugs and we will strive to take a look at them.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
2.  Working on a patch? File a bug at https://github.com/addyosmani/critical/issues (if there
isn
to get the discussion started early. We are happy to discuss it in a new issue beforehand.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 3.  Make sure that patches provide justification for why they should be merged.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Contributing
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: AdonisJs is a community driven project. You are free to contribute in any of the following ways.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Coding style
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Fix bugs by creating PR's
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Share an RFC for new features or big changes
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Report security issues
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Be a part of the community
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Coding style
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Majority of AdonisJs core packages are written in Typescript. Having a brief knowledge of Typescript is required to contribute to the core. Learn more about the same.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Fix bugs by creating PR's
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: We appreciate every time you report a bug in the framework or related libraries. However, taking time to submit a PR can help us in fixing bugs quickly and ensure a healthy and stable eco-system.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Go through the following points, before creating a new PR.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 1.  Create an issue discussing the bug or short-coming in the framework.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 2.  Once approved, go ahead and fork the REPO.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 3.  Make sure to start from the develop, since this is the upto date branch.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 4.  Make sure to keep commits small and relevant.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 5.  We follow conventional-commits to structure our commit messages. Instead of running git commit, you must run npm commit, which will show you prompts to create a valid commit message.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 6.  Once done with all the changes, create a PR against the develop branch.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Share an RFC for new features or big changes
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Sharing PR's for small changes works great. However, when contributing big features to the framework, it is required to go through the RFC process.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: What is an RFC?
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: RFC stands for Request for Commits, a standard process followed by many other frameworks including Ember, yarn and rust.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: In brief, RFC process allows you to talk about the changes with everyone in the community and get a view of the core team before dedicating your time to work on the feature.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: The RFC proposals are created as issues on adonisjs/rfcs repo. Make sure to read the README to learn about the process in depth.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Report security issues
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: All of the security issues, must be reported via email and not using any of the public channels. Learn more about the security policy
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: We follow a strict Code of Conduct to make sure everyone is respectful to each other.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Get Help or Ask a Question
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph:
If you're not sure how to do something with A-Frame, please post a question
(and any code you've tried so far) to Stack Overflow under the 'aframe'
tag. Questions there will automatically create notifications in
Slack, and are easier for others to find so new developers can learn

Paragraph: File an Issue
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 1.  Search the issue tracker for similar issues.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 2.  Specify the version of A-Frame in which the bug occurred.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 3.  Specify information about your browser and system (e.g., "Firefox Nightly on OS X")
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 4.  Describe the problem in detail (i.e., what happened and what you expected would happen).
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 5.  If possible, provide a small test case with CodePen, a link to your application, and/or a screenshot. You can fork this sample pen.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Contribute Code to A-Frame
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph:
Check out the issues labeled help wanted (easy) or help wanted
(hard) for good issues to tackle. Here's how to submit a pull request (PR):
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: 1.  Have a GitHub account with SSH keys set up.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 2.  Fork the repository on GitHub.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 3.  Clone your fork of the repository locally (i.e., git clone git@github.com:yourusername/aframe).
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 4.  Run npm install to get dependencies and npm start to serve the test examples.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 5.  Create a branch to work in (i.e., git checkout -b mybranch).
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 6.  Make changes to your fork of the repository, commit them, and push them (i.e., git add -A . && git commit -m 'My Changes (fixes #1234)' && git push origin mybranch).
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 7.  If necessary, write unit tests (guide) and run with npm test.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 8.  Submit a pull request to the master branch. If you head to the A-Frame repository after running git push from earlier, you should see a pop up to submit a pull request.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 9.  Address review comments if any.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
As per usual with open source, you would agree to license your contributions
under the MIT License.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Add Glitch Examples to Documentation
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph:
We like to have simple and interesting Glitch
examples listed on relevant documentation pages. Glitch lets people remix/fork
examples and code right in the browser with live updates. If you have a Glitch
that might be useful in the documentation, request to add it!
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: 1.  Have a Glitch example ready. Remix the base A-Frame Glitch to maintain consistency and formatting. Follow best practices.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 2.  Go to the bottom of the documentation page on aframe.io you wish to update.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 3.  Click Edit Page GitHub button.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 4.  Add Glitch examples to the examples piece in the header, with title and src. See example.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
If a Glitch example needs to be updated for whatever reason, we can remix the
Glitch and update the src URL.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
Thanks for your interest in contributing to git-crypt!  git-crypt is
open source software and welcomes contributions in the form of code,
documentation, bug reports, or anything else that improves git-crypt.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: When contributing code, please consider the following guidelines:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
- You are encouraged to open an issue on GitHub or send mail to
git-crypt-discuss@lists.cloudmutt.com to discuss any non-trivial
changes before you start coding.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
- Please mimic the existing code style as much as possible.  In
particular, please indent code using tab characters with a width
of 8.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
- To minimize merge commits, please rebase your changes before opening
a pull request.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
- To submit your patch, open a pull request on GitHub or send a
properly-formatted patch to git-crypt-discuss@lists.cloudmutt.com.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
Finally, be aware that since git-crypt is security-sensitive software,
the bar for contributions is higher than average.  Please don't be
discouraged by this, but be prepared for patches to possibly go through
several rounds of feedback and improvement before being accepted.
Your patience and understanding is appreciated.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: What?

Paragraph: Individuals making significant and valuable contributions are given commit-access to the project to contribute as they see fit. This project is more like an open wiki than a standard guarded open source project.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Rules
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: There are a few basic ground-rules for contributors:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 1.  No --force pushes or modifying the Git history in any way.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 2.  Non-master branches ought to be used for ongoing work.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 3.  External API changes and significant modifications ought to be subject to an internal pull-request to solicit feedback from other contributors.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 4.  Internal pull-requests to solicit feedback are encouraged for any other non-trivial contribution but left to the discretion of the contributor.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 5.  Contributors should attempt to adhere to the prevailing code-style.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Writing Reporters
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph:
Nerve supports pluggable reporters, which means that you can easily add
a reporter by making your own gem that contains your reporter available for
require at nerve/reporter/#{name.downcase}. If you do this please do
submit a PR with a link to your gem/repo and we can reference it from the
README.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph:
In general it is preferred to keep reporters that require specific dependencies
out of nerve because that way you can select the version of dependencies that
you need (for example if you have a particular version of the docker api or
etcd). That being said, if your reporter has no external dependencies
(e.g. files) or is extremely common (e.g. zookeeper, etcd), we may choose to
support it in the repo itself.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: Writing Checks
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph:
We welcome additional service checks into the core of nerve.
However, your checks must follow a few guidelines or they will not be accepted:
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: - be sure to respect timeouts; checks that do not time-out will not be accepted
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: - do NOT shell out; this becomes very expensive when done frequently
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - use well-tested, stable, core libraries whenever possible
Label: No categories identified.

Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Contributions are welcome and are greatly appreciated! Every little bit helps, and credit will always be given. By contributing, you agree to abide by the code of conduct.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Reporting Issues and Asking Questions
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: For support or usage questions like StackOverflow with a react-sketchapp tag first.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: We ask you to do this because StackOverflow does a much better job at keeping popular questions visible. Unfortunately good answers get lost and outdated on GitHub.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Some questions take a long time to get an answer. If your question gets closed or you don't get a reply on StackOverflow for longer than a few days, we encourage you to post an issue linking to your question. We will close your issue but this will give people watching the repo an opportunity to see your question and reply to it on StackOverflow if they know the answer.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Please be considerate when doing this as this is not the primary purpose of the issue tracker.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Help Us Help You
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: On both websites, it is a good idea to structure your code and question in a way that is easy to read to entice people to answer it. For example, we encourage you to use syntax highlighting, indentation, and split text in paragraphs.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Please keep in mind that people spend their free time trying to help you. You can make it easier for them if you provide versions of the relevant libraries and a runnable small project reproducing your issue. You can put your code on JSBin or, for bigger projects, on GitHub. Make sure all the necessary dependencies are declared in package.json so anyone can run npm install && npm start and reproduce your issue.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Contributing
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Ace is a community project and wouldn't be what it is without contributions! We actively encourage and support contributions. The Ace source code is released under the BSD License. This license is very simple, and is friendly to all kinds of projects, whether open source or not. Take charge of your editor and add your favorite language highlighting and keybindings!
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Feel free to fork and improve/enhance Ace any way you want. If you feel that the editor or the Ace community will benefit from your changes, please open a pull request. To protect the interests of the Ace contributors and users we require contributors to sign a Contributors License Agreement (CLA) before we pull the changes into the main repository. Our CLA is the simplest of agreements, requiring that the contributions you make to an ajax.org project are only those you're allowed to make. This helps us significantly reduce future legal risk for everyone involved. It is easy, helps everyone, takes ten minutes, and only needs to be completed once.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: There are two versions of the agreement:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 1.  The Individual CLA: use this version if you're working on the Cloud9 SDK or open source projects in your spare time, or can clearly claim ownership of copyright in what you'll be submitting.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 2.  The Corporate CLA: have your corporate lawyer review and submit this if your company is going to be contributing to the Cloud9 SDK and/or open source projects.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: If you want to contribute to the Cloud9 SDK and/or open source projects please go to the online form, fill it out and submit it.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Happy coding, Cloud9

Paragraph: Code review process
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
The bigger the pull request, the longer it will take to review and merge. Try to break down large pull requests in smaller chunks that are easier to review and merge.
It is also always helpful to have some context for your pull request. What was the purpose? Why does it matter to you?

Anyone can file an expense. If the expense makes sense for the development of the community, it will be "merged" in the ledger of our open collective by the core contributors and the person who filed the expense will be reimbursed.

Paragraph: Checklist before creating a Pull Request
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Submit only relevant commits. We don't mind many commits in a pull request, but they must be relevant as explained below.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Use a feature branch The pull request should be created from a feature branch, and not from dev. See below for why.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- No merge-commits
If you have commits that looks like this "Merge branch 'my-branch' into dev" or "Merge branch 'dev' of github .com/akkadotnet/akka.net into dev" you're probaly using merge instead of rebase locally. See below on Handling updates from upstream.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Squash commits Often we create temporary commits like "Started implementing feature x" and then "Did a bit more on feature x". Squash these commits together using interactive rebase. Also see Squashing commits with rebase.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Descriptive commit messages If a commit's message isn't descriptive, change it using interactive rebase. Refer to issues using #issue. Example of a bad message ~~"Small cleanup"~~. Example of good message: "Removed Security.Claims header from FSM, which broke Mono build per #62". Don't be afraid to write long messages, if needed. Try to explain why you've done the changes. The Erlang repo has some info on writing good commit messages.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - No one-commit-to-rule-them-all Large commits that changes too many things at the same time are very hard to review. Split large commits into smaller. See this StackOverflow question for information on how to do this.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Tests Add relevant tests and make sure all existing ones still passes. Tests can be run using the command
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - No Warnings Make sure your code do not produce any build warnings.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: After reviewing a Pull request, we might ask you to fix some commits. After you've done that you need to force push to update your branch in your local fork.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Title and Description for the Pull Request
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Give the PR a descriptive title and in the description field describe what you have done in general terms and why. This will help the reviewers greatly, and provide a history for the future.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Especially if you modify something existing, be very clear! Have you changed any algorithms, or did you just intend to reorder the code? Justify why the changes are needed.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Getting started
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Make sure you have a GitHub account.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Fork, clone, add upstream to the Akka.NET repository. See Fork a repo for more detailed instructions or follow the instructions below.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Fork by clicking Fork on https://github.com/akkadotnet/akka.net
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Clone your fork locally.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: git clone https://github.com/YOUR-USERNAME/akka.net
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Add an upstream remote.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: git remote add upstream https://github.com/akkadotnet/akka.net
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: You now have two remotes: upstream points to https://github.com/akkadotnet/akka.net, and origin points to your fork on GitHub.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Make changes. See below.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Unsure where to start? Issues marked with up for grabs are things we want help with.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: See also: Contributing to Open Source on GitHub
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: New to Git? See https://help.github.com/articles/what-are-other-good-resources-for-learning-git-and-github
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Making changes
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Never work directly on dev or master and you should never send a pull request from master - always from a feature branch created by you.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Pick an issue. If no issue exists (search first) create one.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Get any changes from upstream.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
git checkout dev
git fetch upstream
git merge --ff-only upstream/dev
git push origin dev     #(optional) this makes sure dev in your own fork on GitHub is up to date
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: See https://help.github.com/articles/fetching-a-remote for more info
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Create a new feature branch. It's important that you do your work on your own branch and that it's created off of dev. Tip: Give it a descriptive name and include the issue number, e.g. implement-testkits-eventfilter-323 or 295-implement-tailchopping-router, so that others can see what is being worked on.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git checkout -b my-new-branch-123
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Work on your feature. Commit.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Rebase often, see below.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Make sure you adhere to Checklist before creating a Pull Request described above.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Push the branch to your fork on GitHub
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git push origin my-new-branch-123
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Send a Pull Request, see https://help.github.com/articles/using-pull-requests to the dev branch.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: See also: Understanding the GitHub Flow (we're using dev as our master branch)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Handling updates from upstream
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: While you're working away in your branch it's quite possible that your upstream dev may be updated. If this happens you should:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Stash any un-committed changes you need to
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git stash
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Update your local dev by fetching from upstream
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
git checkout dev
git fetch upstream
git merge --ff-only upstream/dev
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Rebase your feature branch on dev. See Git Branching - Rebasing for more info on rebasing
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
git checkout my-new-branch-123
git rebase dev
git push origin dev     #(optional) this makes sure dev in your own fork on GitHub is up to date
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: This ensures that your history is "clean" i.e. you have one branch off from dev followed by your changes in a straight line. Failing to do this ends up with several "messy" merges in your history, which we don't want. This is the reason why you should always work in a branch and you should never be working in, or sending pull requests from dev.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: If you're working on a long running feature then you may want to do this quite often, rather than run the risk of potential merge issues further down the line.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Making changes to a Pull request
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
If you realize you've missed something after submitting a Pull request, just commit to your local branch and push the branch just like you did the first time. This commit will automatically be included in the Pull request.
If we ask you to change already published commits using interactive rebase (like squashing or splitting commits or  rewriting commit messages) you need to force push using -f:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git push -f origin my-new-branch-123
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: The build server isn't picking up a Pull request that I've modified
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: The build server relies on git commit timestamps to keep track of new builds that it needs to perform. When updating a PR, sometimes the timestamp of the latest commit in the PR isn't updated. This leads the build server to think that the PR has already been built and tested. In order to force the build server to rebuild and test the updated PR, please follow the instructions outlined in this post How can one change the timestamp of an old commit in Git?.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: All my commits are on dev. How do I get them to a new branch?
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: If all commits are on dev you need to move them to a new feature branch.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: You can rebase your local dev on upstream/dev (to remove any merge commits), rename it, and recreate dev
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
git checkout dev
git rebase upstream/dev
git branch -m my-new-branch-123
git branch dev upstream/dev
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Or you can create a new branch off of dev and then cherry pick the commits
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
git checkout -b my-new-branch-123 upstream/dev
git cherry-pick rev           #rev is the revisions you want to pick
git cherry-pick rev           #repeat until you have picked all commits
git branch -m dev old-dev     #rename dev
git branch dev upstream/dev   #create a new dev
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: What to do with feature branch after the pull request is merged and closed ?
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: After a pull request has been merged and closed you can delete the feature branch.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Get latest changes from the upstream
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
git checkout dev
git fetch upstream
git merge --ff-only upstream/dev
git push origin dev
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Remove the branch locally
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git branch -d my-new-branch-123
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Remove the branch on remote
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git push origin --delete my-new-branch-123
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Code review process

Paragraph:
The bigger the pull request, the longer it will take to review and merge. Try to break down large pull requests in smaller chunks that are easier to review and merge.
It is also always helpful to have some context for your pull request. What was the purpose? Why does it matter to you?
