Paragraph: Code of Conduct
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Help us keep Kitten Tricks open and inclusive. Please read and follow our Code of Conduct.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Got a Question or Problem?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Please do not open issues for general support questions as we want to keep GitHub issues for bug reports and feature requests. You've got much better chances of getting your question answered on StackOverflow where the questions should be tagged with tag Kitten Tricks.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: StackOverflow is a much better place to ask questions since:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - there are thousands of people willing to help on StackOverflow
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - questions and answers stay available for public viewing so your question / answer might help someone else
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - StackOverflow's voting system assures that the best answers are prominently visible.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: To save your and our time, we will be systematically closing all the issues that are requests for general support and redirecting people to StackOverflow.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Found an Issue?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: If you find a bug in the source code or a mistake in the documentation, you can help us by submitting an issue to our GitHub Repository. Including an issue reproduction is the absolute best way to help the team quickly diagnose the problem. Screenshots and error stack traces are also helpful.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Please follow this simple checklist before submitting:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - If you have a question about using Kitten Tricks, please ask on the StackOverflow.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - It is required that you clearly describe the steps necessary to reproduce the issue you are running into. Although we would love to help our users as much as possible, diagnosing issues without clear reproduction steps is extremely time-consuming and simply not sustainable.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - The issue list of this repository is exclusively for bug reports and feature requests. Non-conforming issues will be closed immediately.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Issues with no clear steps to reproduce will not be triaged. If an issue is labeled with "needs info" and receives no further replies from the author of the issue for more than 5 days, it will be closed.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - If you think you have found a bug, or have a new feature idea, please start by making sure it hasn't already been reported. You can search through existing issues to see if there is a similar one reported. Include closed issues as it may have been closed with a solution.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Next, create a new issue that thoroughly explains the problem. Please fill out the populated issue form before submitting the issue.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Want a Feature?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: You can request a new feature by submitting an issue to our GitHub Repository. If you would like to implement a new feature, please submit an issue with a proposal for your work first, to be sure that we can use it. Please consider what kind of change it is:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- For a Major Feature, first open an issue and outline your proposal so that it can be
discussed. This will also allow us to better coordinate our efforts, prevent duplication of work,
and help you to craft the change so that it is successfully accepted into the project.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Small Features can be crafted and directly submitted as a Pull Request.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Submitting an Issue Before you submit an issue, search the archive, maybe your question was already answered.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: If your issue appears to be a bug, and hasn't been reported, open a new issue. Help us to maximize the effort we can spend fixing issues and adding new features by not reporting duplicate issues. Please make sure to fill out the populated issue form before submitting the issue.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: You can file new issues by providing the information here.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Submitting a Pull Request (PR)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Before you submit your Pull Request (PR) consider the following guidelines:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Search GitHub for an open or closed PR
that relates to your submission. You don't want to duplicate effort.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Make your changes in a new git branch:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git checkout -b my-fix-branch master
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Read the developer documentation.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Create your patch, including appropriate test cases.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Follow our Coding Rules.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Test your changes.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Commit your changes using a descriptive commit message that follows our commit message conventions. Adherence to these conventions is necessary because release notes are automatically generated from these messages.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git commit -a
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Note: the optional commit -a command line option will automatically "add" and "rm" edited files.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Push your branch to GitHub:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git push my-fork my-fix-branch
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - In GitHub, send a pull request to master.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - If we suggest changes then:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Make the required updates.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Rebase your branch and force push to your GitHub repository (this will update your Pull Request):
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
git rebase master -i
git push -f
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: That's it! Thank you for your contribution!
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: After your pull request is merged
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
After your pull request is merged, you can safely delete your branch and pull the changes
from the main (upstream) repository:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Delete the remote branch on GitHub either through the GitHub web UI or your local shell as
follows:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git push my-fork --delete my-fix-branch
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Check out the master branch:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git checkout master -f
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Delete the local branch:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git branch -D my-fix-branch
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Update your master with the latest upstream version:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git pull --ff upstream master
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Coding Rules
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: To ensure consistency throughout the source code, keep these rules in mind as you are working:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - All features or bug fixes must be tested by one or more specs (unit-tests).
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - All public API methods must be documented following JsDoc notation.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Commit Message Guidelines
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
We have very precise rules over how our git commit messages can be formatted.  This leads to more
readable messages that are easy to follow when looking through the project history.  But also,
we use the git commit messages to generate the Kitten Tricks change log.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Commit Message Format
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Each commit message consists of a header, a body and a footer.  The header has a special
format that includes a type, a scope and a subject:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
<type>(<scope>): <subject>
<BLANK LINE>
<body>
<BLANK LINE>
<footer>
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: The header is mandatory and the scope of the header is optional.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Any line of the commit message cannot be longer 100 characters! This allows the message to be easier
to read on GitHub as well as in various git tools.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Revert
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
If the commit reverts a previous commit, it should begin with revert: , followed by the header of
the reverted commit. In the body it should say: This reverts commit <hash>., where the hash is
the SHA of the commit being reverted.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Type
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Must be one of the following:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - feat: A new feature
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - fix: A bug fix
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - docs: Documentation only changes
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- style: Changes that do not affect the meaning of the code (white-space, formatting, missing
semi-colons, etc)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - refactor: A code change that neither fixes a bug nor adds a feature
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - perf: A code change that improves performance
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - test: Adding missing tests or correcting existing tests
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- build: Changes that affect the build system, CI configuration or external dependencies
(example scopes: gulp, broccoli, npm)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - chore: Other changes that don't modify src or test files
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - relese: Release version commit
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Scope
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
The scope could be anything specifying place of the commit change. For example
menu, sidebar, etc.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Subject
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: The subject contains succinct description of the change:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - use the imperative, present tense: "change" not "changed" nor "changes"
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - don't capitalize first letter
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - no dot (.) at the end
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Body
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Optional. Just as in the subject, use the imperative, present tense: "change" not "changed" nor "changes".
The body should include the motivation for the change and contrast this with previous behavior.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Footer
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Optional. The footer should contain any information about Breaking Changes and is also the place to
reference GitHub issues that this commit Closes.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Breaking Changes should start with the word BREAKING CHANGE: with a space or two newlines.
The rest of the commit message is then used for this.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Next, create a new issue that thoroughly explains the problem. Please fill out the populated issue form before submitting the issue.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Want a Feature?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
You can request a new feature by submitting an issue to our GitHub
Repository. If you would like to implement a new feature, please submit an issue with
a proposal for your work first, to be sure that we can use it.
Please consider what kind of change it is:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- For a Major Feature, first open an issue and outline your proposal so that it can be
discussed. This will also allow us to better coordinate our efforts, prevent duplication of work,
and help you to craft the change so that it is successfully accepted into the project.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Small Features can be crafted and directly submitted as a Pull Request.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Submitting an Issue
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Before you submit an issue, search the archive, maybe your question was already answered.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
If your issue appears to be a bug, and hasn't been reported, open a new issue.
Help us to maximize the effort we can spend fixing issues and adding new
features by not reporting duplicate issues. Please make sure to fill out the populated issue form before submitting the issue.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: You can file new issues by providing the information here.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Submitting a Pull Request (PR)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Before you submit your Pull Request (PR) consider the following guidelines:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Search GitHub for an open or closed PR
that relates to your submission. You don't want to duplicate effort.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Make your changes in a new git branch:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git checkout -b my-fix-branch master
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Read the developer documentation.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Create your patch, including appropriate test cases.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Follow our Coding Rules.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Test your changes with our supported browsers and screen readers.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Run npm run release:validate, as described in the developer documentation,
and ensure that all tests pass, linter & build has no errors.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Commit your changes using a descriptive commit message that follows our
commit message conventions. Adherence to these conventions
is necessary because release notes are automatically generated from these messages.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git commit -a
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Note: the optional commit -a command line option will automatically "add" and "rm" edited files.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Push your branch to GitHub:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git push my-fork my-fix-branch
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - In GitHub, send a pull request to nebular:master.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - If we suggest changes then:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Make the required updates.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Re-run npm run release:validate to ensure tests are still passing, linter & build has no errors.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Rebase your branch and force push to your GitHub repository (this will update your Pull
Request):
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
git rebase master -i
git push -f
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: That's it! Thank you for your contribution!
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: After your pull request is merged
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
After your pull request is merged, you can safely delete your branch and pull the changes
from the main (upstream) repository:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Delete the remote branch on GitHub either through the GitHub web UI or your local shell as
follows:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git push my-fork --delete my-fix-branch
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Check out the master branch:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git checkout master -f
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Delete the local branch:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git branch -D my-fix-branch
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Update your master with the latest upstream version:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git pull --ff upstream master
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Coding Rules
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: To ensure consistency throughout the source code, keep these rules in mind as you are working:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - All features or bug fixes must be tested by one or more specs (unit-tests).
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - All public API methods must be documented following JsDoc notation.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Commit Message Guidelines
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
We have very precise rules over how our git commit messages can be formatted.  This leads to more
readable messages that are easy to follow when looking through the project history.  But also,
we use the git commit messages to generate the Nebular change log.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Commit Message Format
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Each commit message consists of a header, a body and a footer.  The header has a special
format that includes a type, a scope and a subject:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
<type>(<scope>): <subject>
<BLANK LINE>
<body>
<BLANK LINE>
<footer>
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: The header is mandatory and the scope of the header is optional.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Any line of the commit message cannot be longer 100 characters! This allows the message to be easier
to read on GitHub as well as in various git tools.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Revert
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
If the commit reverts a previous commit, it should begin with revert: , followed by the header of
the reverted commit. In the body it should say: This reverts commit <hash>., where the hash is
the SHA of the commit being reverted.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Type
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Must be one of the following:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - feat: A new feature
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - fix: A bug fix
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - docs: Documentation only changes
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- style: Changes that do not affect the meaning of the code (white-space, formatting, missing
semi-colons, etc)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - refactor: A code change that neither fixes a bug nor adds a feature
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - perf: A code change that improves performance
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - test: Adding missing tests or correcting existing tests
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- build: Changes that affect the build system, CI configuration or external dependencies
(example scopes: gulp, broccoli, npm)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - chore: Other changes that don't modify src or test files
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - release: Release version commit
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Scope
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
The scope could be anything specifying place of the commit change. For example
menu, sidebar, etc.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Subject
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: The subject contains succinct description of the change:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - use the imperative, present tense: "change" not "changed" nor "changes"
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - don't capitalize first letter
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - no dot (.) at the end
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Body
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Optional. Just as in the subject, use the imperative, present tense: "change" not "changed" nor "changes".
The body should include the motivation for the change and contrast this with previous behavior.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Footer
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Optional. The footer should contain any information about Breaking Changes and is also the place to
reference GitHub issues that this commit Closes.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Breaking Changes should start with the word BREAKING CHANGE: with a space or two newlines.
The rest of the commit message is then used for this.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Code of Conduct
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Help us keep ngx-admin open and inclusive. Please read and follow our Code of Conduct.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Got a Question or Problem?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Please do not open issues for general support questions as we want to keep GitHub issues for bug reports and feature requests. You've got much better chances of getting your question answered on StackOverflow where the questions should be tagged with tag ngx-admin.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: StackOverflow is a much better place to ask questions since:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - there are thousands of people willing to help on StackOverflow
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - questions and answers stay available for public viewing so your question / answer might help someone else
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - StackOverflow's voting system assures that the best answers are prominently visible.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: To save your and our time, we will be systematically closing all the issues that are requests for general support and redirecting people to StackOverflow.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Found an Issue?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
If you find a bug in the source code or a mistake in the documentation, you can help us by
submitting an issue to our GitHub Repository. Including an issue
reproduction (via CodePen, JsBin, Plunkr, GitHub repo, etc.) is the absolute best way to help the team quickly
diagnose the problem. Screenshots and error stack traces are also helpful.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Please follow this simple checklist before submitting:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - If you have a question about using ngx-admin, please ask on the StackOverflow.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - It is required that you clearly describe the steps necessary to reproduce the issue you are running into. Although we would love to help our users as much as possible, diagnosing issues without clear reproduction steps is extremely time-consuming and simply not sustainable.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - The issue list of this repository is exclusively for bug reports and feature requests. Non-conforming issues will be closed immediately.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Issues with no clear steps to reproduce will not be triaged. If an issue is labeled with "needs info" and receives no further replies from the author of the issue for more than 5 days, it will be closed.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - If you think you have found a bug, or have a new feature idea, please start by making sure it hasn't already been reported. You can search through existing issues to see if there is a similar one reported. Include closed issues as it may have been closed with a solution.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Next, create a new issue that thoroughly explains the problem. Please fill out the populated issue form before submitting the issue.
Label: No categories identified.

Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
You can request a new feature by submitting an issue to our GitHub
Repository. If you would like to implement a new feature, please submit an issue with
a proposal for your work first, to be sure that we can use it.
Please consider what kind of change it is:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- For a Major Feature, first open an issue and outline your proposal so that it can be
discussed. This will also allow us to better coordinate our efforts, prevent duplication of work,
and help you to craft the change so that it is successfully accepted into the project.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Small Features can be crafted and directly submitted as a Pull Request.
Label: No categories identified.

Help us to maximize the effort we can spend fixing issues and adding new
features by not reporting duplicate issues. Please make sure to fill out the populated issue form before submitting the issue.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
<type>(<scope>): <subject>
<BLANK LINE>
<body>
<BLANK LINE>
<footer>
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: The header is mandatory and the scope of the header is optional.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Any line of the commit message cannot be longer 100 characters! This allows the message to be easier
to read on GitHub as well as in various git tools.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Revert
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
If the commit reverts a previous commit, it should begin with revert: , followed by the header of
the reverted commit. In the body, it should say: These reverts commit <hash>., where the hash is
the SHA of the commit being reverted.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Type
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Must be one of the following:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - feat: A new feature
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - fix: A bug fix
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - docs: Documentation only changes
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- style: Changes that do not affect the meaning of the code (white-space, formatting, missing
semi-colons, etc)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - refactor: A code change that neither fixes a bug or adds a feature
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - perf: A code change that improves performance
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - test: Adding missing tests or correcting existing tests
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- build: Changes that affect the build system, CI configuration or external dependencies
(example scopes: gulp, broccoli, npm)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - chore: Other changes that don't modify src or test files
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - release: Release version commit
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Scope
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - For components ui module the scope should be the name of the component that was affected:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: style(button): add styles for pressed state
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - For changes in other modules (like moment or date-fns) the scope should be module name:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: feat(date-fns): description of awesome feature
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Subject
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: The subject contains a succinct description of the change:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - use the imperative, present tense: "change" not "changed" nor "changes"
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - don't capitalize the first letter
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - no dot (.) at the end
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Body
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Optional. Just as in the subject, use the imperative, present tense: "change" not "changed" nor "changes".
The body should include the motivation for the change and contrast this with previous behavior.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Footer
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Optional. The footer should contain any information about Breaking Changes and is also the place to
reference GitHub issues that this commit Closes.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Breaking Changes should start with the word BREAKING CHANGE: with space or two newlines.
The rest of the commit message is then used for this.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Contributing to Sucrase
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Intro
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Thanks for taking a look at the project and thinking about contributing!
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: There are two main ways to communicate about Sucrase development:
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph:
- Join the Gitter room and feel free to ask
questions or discuss anything.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph:
- File an issue or PR in this repository. Issues don't need to be bug reports;
usage questions or suggests are fine.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph:
All contributions and interactions are expected to follow the
Code of Conduct.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: What kinds of contributions make sense?
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph:
There are lots of ways to contribute to Sucrase! The easiest way to get started
is to just starting using Sucrase for a project and see what issues you run
into. Did you run into any bugs? Were the details confusing? Is there a way to
make it easier to use? All of those would be great issues to file in this
repository!
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: In addition to filing issues, there are lots of ways to contribute:
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: - Fix bugs. Be sure to also include a regression test for any bug fix!
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph:
- Add more tests or test infrastructure. Right now, Sucrase runs on a few open
source projects as part of its test suite, but it would always be great to add
more.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: - Add better performance tests.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: - Add better documentation, like a Getting Started guide.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: - Write more integrations for Sucrase, like a Browserify plugin.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph:
Contributing features, refactors, and performance improvements to the "core" of
Sucrase (the parser and the transformers) may need some more thought and care.
See the Project Vision for some thoughts on what
types of improvements make sense for the project, and make sure to start a
discussion before getting too deep in the code. Some problems may be best solved
outside of the core Sucrase code, or may be better as a fork of Sucrase.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph:
See this issue for some
more concrete suggestions.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: Getting started
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Sucrase uses yarn for everything.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
git clone git@github.com:alangpierce/sucrase.git
cd sucrase
yarn  # Install dependencies.
yarn test  # Run tests.
yarn build  # Build Sucrase.
yarn fast-build  # Quickly build Sucrase for development.
yarn release 1.2.3  # Run the release script, releasing version 1.2.3.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
I'd also recommend getting your editor set up nicely to handle TypeScript,
Prettier, and Mocha.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
Contributions should follow the normal GitHub pull request process: fork the
repo, make a new branch with your change, push the branch, and create a pull
request with a meaningful title and description, including any interesting
details of the change and references to any issues closed by the change.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Code structure
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
The code is organized as a monorepo (with one primary sucrase package and
several smaller packages/projects). Here are the most important directories:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- The src directory is where the main code lives. Much of the code is in the
parser subdirectory, which is a heavily modified fork of Babel's parser. The
rest of the code handles transforming the code given the result of the parser.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- The test directory has all tests, generally broken down by which transform
is most relevant. Nearly all tests simply give code as input and assert the
output code. Running a test in debug mode and stepping through different parts
of the code is a great way to learn how Sucrase works!
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- The website directory contains the full code for the
sucrase.io website.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- The integrations directory has several small packages integrating Sucrase
with Webpack, Jest, etc.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- The example-runner directory has code to clone various open source projects,
run Sucrase on them, then run the tests to make sure that the Sucrase output
was correct. You can run all example projects with yarn run-examples.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- The generator directory contains some some utilities for generating code
used in Sucrase, and can be run using yarn generate.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- The benchmark directory contains some some simple benchmarks, which can be
run with yarn benchmark.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- The script directory has all build scripts (written in TypeScript and
compiled with Sucrase).
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Compiling MonoTorrent
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Pre-requisites
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: - A version of the .NET framework, .NET Core or Mono which can compile .NET Standard 2.0 projects.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: - Any IDE which can compile C# code.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: MSBuild:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
To build using MSBuild, execute the following command:
$ msbuild /restore
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Makefiles:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
To build using the Makefile, execute the following command:
$ make
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Using an IDE:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: You can open src\MonoTorrent.sln in any IDE.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: How to use the sample applications
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: MonoTorrent Client
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: To run the sample client you need to do the following:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 1)  Make sure that MonoTorrent.dll and SampleClient.exe are in the same folder
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 2)  Create a folder in that directory called "Torrents".
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 3)  Put any number of .torrent files into the Torrents directory. This files will all be loaded by the sample client.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
4)  Launch SampleClient.exe to begin downloading. All files will be downloaded to a directory called "Downloads".
Note: Only statistics will only be shown for the first .torrent loaded into the engine. So there is no real point
in loading more than one .torrent into the engine.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
Developer Notes:
There are a few important things developers should note before creating a gui/service using the library. Firstly
there is no guarantee what thread the events will be fired on, so if you're doing GUI updates, you will need to
make sure that you perform your actual GUI update in a threadsafe manner.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: The Tracker
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
The code of the Tracker is located in MonoTorrent.Tracker. There is one sample Tracker implementation
in MonoTorrent.TrackerApp.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
The Tracker is a piece of Software which listens for HttpRequests. Each Request can either be an Announce
or Scrape request. Therefore the Tracker needs code which handles HttpRequests. The Tracker was programmed
in such a way that it is independent of the http handling code. The http handling code is called Frontend.
There are currently two Frontends implemented. The first uses the class HttpListener. This implementation
got most attention. The second one uses the Asp.Net infrastructe and the HttpHandles classes. It therefore
could be used in xsp2, mod_mono or even in IIS. But the second implementation was just a proof of concept
and is not tested but should be functional. There exists and Frontend directory which contains all the
Frontend handling code.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
There is also a Backend part of the Tracker. The backend is responsible for storing the Informations per
Torrent which should be Announced to the peers. There is currently one Backend implementation which uses
the .Net internal Datastructes List<> and Dictionary<> called SimpleTorrentManager. A Backend needs to
implement the ITorrentManager interface.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
If you would like to start the Tracker the TrackerEngine is the class you would like to use. The sequence
below is enough to start the Tracker:
Label: CF – Contribution flow
CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Adding Torrents is easy too. Just get an Tracker instance and call AddTorrent:
Label: CF – Contribution flow
CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
The two code snippets are enough to start a simple tracker. If you would like to tune the Tracker to use
less Bandwidth you can set various things in the Tracker instance. One such thing would be to use the
compact response format:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Tracker.Instance.AllowNonCompact = true;
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
The other place where you can tune is to implement the IIntervalAlgorithm. An implementor can controll at
which rate the peers should request an Announce or Scrape. Currently we have an static implementation
which uses static defaults taken from the original BitTorrent implementation. It's even possible to higher
the intervals based on the number of peers using the Torrent.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
Tracker.cs is the code where everything is glued together. It is something like the heart of the Tracker
implementation.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
Howto Test:
If you want to test the Tracker just compile it with MonoDevelop. The Tracker searches (and creates if not
found) for a directory named ./torrents. In this Directory every Torrent is loaded on startup. To test
the Torrent you need some torrents pointing at the Tracker. This can be done with the unit test. Just
run gnunit2 and load the Common.dll in src/bin/Debug. Copy the single.torrent and torrentcreator.torrent
into src/bin/Debug/torrents and start the Tracker in MonoDevelop. Then you can load the Torrents in Azureus
or BitTorrent and check if the Tracker reacts on Announces and Scrapes.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Contributing Guidelines
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Thank you for your interest in contributing to our project. Whether it's a bug report, new feature, correction, or additional
documentation, we greatly value feedback and contributions from our community.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Please read through this document before submitting any issues or pull requests to ensure we have all the necessary
information to effectively respond to your bug report or contribution.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Reporting Bugs/Feature Requests
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: We welcome you to use the GitHub issue tracker to report bugs or suggest features.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
When filing an issue, please check existing open, or recently closed, issues to make sure somebody else hasn't already
reported the issue. Please try to include as much information as you can. Details like these are incredibly useful:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - A reproducible test case or series of steps
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - The version of our code being used
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Any modifications you've made relevant to the bug
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Anything unusual about your environment or deployment
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Contributing via Pull Requests
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Contributions via pull requests are much appreciated. Before sending us a pull request, please ensure that:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 1.  You are working against the latest source on the master branch.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 2.  You check existing open, and recently merged, pull requests to make sure someone else hasn't addressed the problem already.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 3.  You open an issue to discuss any significant work - we would hate for your time to be wasted.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: To send us a pull request, please:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 1.  Fork the repository.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 2.  Modify the source; please focus on the specific change you are contributing. If you also reformat all the code, it will be hard for us to focus on your change.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 3.  Ensure local tests pass.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 4.  Commit to your fork using clear commit messages following the Conventional Commit Guideline.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 5.  Send us a pull request, answering any default questions in the pull request interface.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 6.  Pay attention to any automated CI failures reported in the pull request, and stay involved in the conversation.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
GitHub provides additional document on forking a repository and
creating a pull request.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Finding contributions to work on

Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: Instructions
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: These steps will guide you through contributing to this project:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Fork the repo
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Clone it and install dependencies
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
git clone https://github.com/YOUR-USERNAME/typescript-library-starter
npm install
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Keep in mind that after running npm install the git repo is reset. So a good way to cope with this is to have a copy of the folder to push the changes, and the other to try them.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Make and commit your changes. Make sure the commands npm run build and npm run test:prod are working.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Finally send a GitHub Pull Request with a clear list of what you've done (read more about pull requests). Make sure all of your commits are atomic (one feature per commit).
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Contributing
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
When contributing to this repository, please first discuss the change you wish to make via issue, email, or any other
method with the owner of this repository before making a change.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Please note we have a code of conduct, please follow it in all your interactions with the project.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Pull Request Process
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 1.  Ensure any install or build dependencies are removed before the end of the layer when doing a build.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 2.  Ensure that your changes comply with the project's coding guidelines and that it's sufficiently documented.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
3.  Update the README.md with details of changes to the interface, this includes new environment variables, exposed
ports, useful file locations and container parameters.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 4.  Target the develop branch for your Pull Requests as this is were new changes are introduced.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
5.  After being successfully reviewed pull requests will be merged to develop branch and will finally be included in an
upcoming release.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Code of Conduct
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Our Pledge
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph:
In the interest of fostering an open and welcoming environment, we as contributors and maintainers pledge to making
participation in our project and our community a harassment-free experience for everyone, regardless of age, body size,
disability, ethnicity, gender identity and expression, level of experience, nationality, personal appearance, race,
religion, or sexual identity and orientation.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Our Standards
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Examples of behavior that contributes to creating a positive environment include:
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: - Using welcoming and inclusive language.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: - Being respectful of differing viewpoints and experiences.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: - Gracefully accepting constructive criticism.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: - Focusing on what is best for the community.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: - Showing empathy towards other community members.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Examples of unacceptable behavior by participants include:
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: - The use of sexualized language or imagery and unwelcome sexual attention or advances.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: - Trolling, insulting/derogatory comments, and personal or political attacks.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: - Public or private harassment.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: - Publishing others' private information, such as a physical or electronic address, without explicit permission.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: - Other conduct which could reasonably be considered inappropriate in a professional setting.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Our Responsibilities
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph:
Project maintainers are responsible for clarifying the standards of acceptable behavior and are expected to take
appropriate and fair corrective action in response to any instances of unacceptable behavior.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph:
Project maintainers have the right and responsibility to remove, edit, or reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits,
issues, and other contributions that are not aligned to this Code of Conduct, or to ban temporarily or permanently any
contributor for other behaviors that they deem inappropriate, threatening, offensive, or harmful.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Scope
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph:
This Code of Conduct applies both within project spaces and in public spaces when an individual is representing the
project or its community. Examples of representing a project or community include using an official project e-mail
address, posting via an official social media account, or acting as an appointed representative at an online or offline
event. Representation of a project may be further defined and clarified by project maintainers.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Enforcement
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph:
Instances of abusive, harassing, or otherwise unacceptable behavior may be reported by contacting the project owner at
alextselegidis@gmail.com. All complaints will be reviewed and investigated and will result
in a response that is deemed necessary and appropriate to the circumstances. The project owner is obligated to maintain
confidentiality with regard to the reporter of an incident. Further details of specific enforcement policies may be
posted separately.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph:
Project maintainers who do not follow or enforce the Code of Conduct in good faith may face temporary or permanent
repercussions as determined by other members of the project's leadership.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: - src/ contains source code.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - apis/ defines outgoing API requests.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - common/ contains commonly used files.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - components/ contains UI components.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - core/ processes visualization.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - layouts/ layout tracers.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - renderers/ renders visualization data.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - tracers/ interprets visualizing commands into visualization data.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - files/ contains markdown or skeleton files to be shown in the code editor.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - reducers/ contains Redux reducers.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Atlas Contributing Guide
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Welcome to create Pull Requests or open Issues for bugfix, doc, example, suggestion and anything.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Branch Management
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
master
?
dev         <--- PR(hotfix/typo/3rd-PR)
? PR
{domain}-feature-{date}
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Atlas Branches
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 0.  master branch
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 0. master is the latest (pre-)release branch.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 1.  dev branch
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 0. dev is the stable developing branch. Github Release is used to publish a (pre-)release version to master branch.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 0. It's RECOMMENDED to commit hotfix (like typo) or feature PR to dev.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 2.  {domain}-feature-{date} branch
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 0. The branch for a developing iteration, e.g. core-feature-20170118 is an atlas-core developing iteration which is done at 2017.01.18. {domain} consists of core, update, plugin and aapt.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 0. DO NOT commit any PR to such a branch.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Branch Name
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: {module}-{action}-{shortName}
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - {module}, see commit log module
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - {action}
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - feature: checkout from {module} and merge to {module} later. If {module} not exists, merge to dev
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - bugfix: like feature, for bugfix only
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - hotfix: checkout from master or release tag, merge to master and {module} later. If {module} not exists, merge to dev
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: for example:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - core-bugfix-memory
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - plugin-feature-redex
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - update-hotfix-sequence
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Commit Log
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: [{module}] {description}
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - {module}
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Including: atlas-core, atlas-aapt, atlas-update, atlas-gradle-plugin, atlas-doc, atlas-website, atlas-demo, test, all
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - {description}
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - It's RECOMMENDED to close issue with syntax close #66 or fix #66, see the doc for more detail. It's useful for responding issues.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: for example:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - [all] close #66, add refreshing for memory
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - [atlas-doc] fix #68, update some instruction
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - [atlas-demo] remove abc
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Contributor License Agreement
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: In order to contribute code to Atlas, you (or the legal entity you represent) must sign the Contributor License Agreement (CLA).
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: You can read and sign the Alibaba CLA online.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: For CLA assistant service works properly, please make sure you have added email address that your commits linked to GitHub account.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Please read How to setting your Email address in Git and How to adding an email address to your GitHub Account.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Contribution Guide
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Cobar is a community driven open source project and we welcome any contributor.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: This document outlines some conventions about development workflow, commit message formatting, contact points and other resources to make it easier to get your contribution accepted.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Pre submit pull request/issue flight checks
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Before you move on, please make sure what your issue and/or pull request is, a simple bug fix or an architecture change.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: In order to save reviewers' time, each issue should be filed with template and should be sanity-checkable in under 5 minutes.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Is this a simple bug fix?
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Bug fixes usually come with tests. With the help of continuous integration test, patches can be easy to review. Please update the unit tests so that they catch the bug!
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Is this an architecture improvement?
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Some examples of "Architecture" improvements:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Converting structs to interfaces.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Improving test coverage.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Decoupling logic or creation of new utilities.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Making code more resilient (sleeps, backoffs, reducing flakiness, etc).
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: If you are improving the quality of code, then justify/state exactly what you are 'cleaning up' in your Pull Request so as to save reviewers' time.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
If you're making code more resilient, test it locally to demonstrate how exactly your patch changes
things.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Workflow
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Step 1: Fork in the cloud
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 1.  Visit https://github.com/alibaba/cobar
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 2.  Click Fork button (top right) to establish a cloud-based fork.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Step 2: Clone fork to local storage and develop
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Step 3: Create a pull request
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 1.  Visit your fork at https://github.com/$user/cobar (replace $user obviously).
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 2.  Click the Compare & pull request button next to your branch.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Step 4: get a code review
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
Once your pull request has been opened, it will be assigned to reviewers,
Those reviewers will do a thorough code review, looking for
correctness, bugs, opportunities for improvement, documentation and comments,
and style.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
Commit changes made in response to review comments to the same branch on your
fork.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
Very small PRs are easy to review. Very large PRs are very difficult to
review.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Code style
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: The IntelliJ IDEA default java code style is Recommended?in every project has .editorconfig file, for more information please visit http://editorconfig.org/
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Commit message style
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Please follow this style to make Cobar easy to review, maintain and develop.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
<subsystem>: <what changed>
<BLANK LINE>
<why this change was made>
<BLANK LINE>
<footer>(optional)
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
The first line is the subject and should be no longer than 70 characters, the
second line is always blank, and other lines should be wrapped at 80 characters.
This allows the message to be easier to read on GitHub as well as in various
git tools.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: If the change affects more than one subsystem, you can use comma to separate them like util/codec,util/types:.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: If the change affects many subsystems, you can use * instead, like *:.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
For the why part, if no specific reason for the change,
you can use one of some generic reasons like "Improve documentation.",
"Improve performance.", "Improve robustness.", "Improve test coverage."
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Contributing Guide
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Hi! I’m really excited that you are interested in contributing to Formily. Before submitting your contribution though, please make sure to take a moment and read through the following guidelines.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Issue Reporting Guidelines
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Pull Request Guidelines
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Git Commit Specific
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Issue Reporting Guidelines
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - The issue list of this repo is exclusively for bug reports and feature requests. Non-conforming issues will be closed immediately.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - For simple beginner questions, you can get quick answers from
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - For more complicated questions, you can use Google or StackOverflow. Make sure to provide enough information when asking your questions - this makes it easier for others to help you!
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Try to search for your issue, it may have already been answered or even fixed in the development branch.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Check if the issue is reproducible with the latest stable version of Formily. If you are using a pre-release, please indicate the specific version you are using.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - It is required that you clearly describe the steps necessary to reproduce the issue you are running into. Issues with no clear repro steps will not be triaged. If an issue labeled "need repro" receives no further input from the issue author for more than 5 days, it will be closed.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - For bugs that involves build setups, you can create a reproduction repository with steps in the README.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: If your issue is resolved but still open, don’t hesitate to close it. In case you found a solution by yourself, it could be helpful to explain how you fixed it.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Pull Request Guidelines
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Only code that's ready for release should be committed to the master branch. All development should be done in dedicated branches.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Checkout a new topic branch from master branch, and merge back against master branch.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Work in the src folder and DO NOT checkin dist in the commits.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Make sure npm test passes.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - If adding new feature:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Add accompanying test case.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Provide convincing reason to add this feature. Ideally you should open a suggestion issue first and have it greenlighted before working on it.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - If fixing a bug:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - If you are resolving a special issue, add (fix #xxxx[,#xxx]) (#xxxx is the issue id) in your PR title for a better release log, e.g. update entities encoding/decoding (fix #3899).
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Provide detailed description of the bug in the PR. Live demo preferred.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Add appropriate test coverage if applicable.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Git Commit Specific
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Your commits message must follow our git commit specific.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - We will check your commit message, if it does not conform to the specification, the commit will be automatically refused, make sure you have read the specification above.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - You could use git cz with a CLI interface to replace git commit command, it will help you to build a proper commit-message, see commitizen.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - It's OK to have multiple small commits as you work on your branch - we will let GitHub automatically squash it before merging.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Contributing to Nacos
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Welcome to Nacos! This document is a guideline about how to contribute to Nacos.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: If you find something incorrect or missing, please leave comments / suggestions.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Before you get started
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Code of Conduct
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Please make sure to read and observe our Code of Conduct.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Contributing
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Nacos welcome new participants of any role, including user, contributor, committer and PMC.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: We encourage new comers actively join in Nacos projects and involving from user role to committer role, and even PMC role. In order to accomplish this, new comers needs to actively contribute in Nacos project. The following paragraph introduce how to contribute in Nacos way.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Open / pickup an issue for preparation
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: If you find a typo in document, find a bug in code, or want new features, or want to give suggestions, you can open an issue on GitHub to report it.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: If you just want to contribute directly you can choose the issue below.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: - Contribution Welcome: Heavily needed issue, but currently short of hand.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: - good first issue: Good for newcomers, new comer can pickup one for warm-up.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: We strongly value documentation and integration with other projects such as Spring Cloud, Kubernetes, Dubbo, etc. We are very glad to work on any issue for these aspects.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: Please note that any PR must be associated with a valid issue. Otherwise the PR will be rejected.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: Begin your contribute
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Now if you want to contribute, please create a new pull request.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: We use the develop branch as the development branch, which indicates that this is a unstable branch.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Further more, our branching model complies to https://nvie.com/posts/a-successful-git-branching-model/. We strongly suggest new comers walk through the above article before creating PR.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Now, if you are ready to create PR, here is the workflow for contributors:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 1.  Fork to your own
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 2.  Clone fork to local repository
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 3.  Create a new branch and work on it
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 4.  Keep your branch in sync
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 5.  Commit your changes (make sure your commit message concise)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 6.  Push your commits to your forked repository
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 7.  Create a pull request to develop branch.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: When creating pull request:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 1.  Please follow the pull request template.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 2.  Please create the request to develop branch.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 3.  Please make sure the PR has a corresponding issue.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 4.  If your PR contains large changes, e.g. component refactor or new components, please write detailed documents about its design and usage.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 5.  Note that a single PR should not be too large. If heavy changes are required, it's better to separate the changes to a few individual PRs.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 6.  After creating a PR, one or more reviewers will be assigned to the pull request.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 7.  Before merging a PR, squash any fix review feedback, typo, merged, and rebased sorts of commits. The final commit message should be clear and concise.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: If your PR contains large changes, e.g. component refactor or new components, please write detailed documents about its design and usage.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Code review guidance
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Committers will rotate reviewing the code to make sure all the PR will be reviewed timely and by at least one committer before merge. If we aren't doing our job (sometimes we drop things). And as always, we welcome volunteers for code review.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Some principles:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Readability - Important code should be well-documented. API should have Javadoc. Code style should be complied with the existing one.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Elegance: New functions, classes or components should be well designed.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Testability - 80% of the new code should be covered by unit test cases.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Maintainability - Comply with our PMD spec, and 3-month-frequency update should be maintained at least.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Now how about try become a committer?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Generally speaking, contribute 8 non-trivial patches and get at least three different people to review them (you'll need three people to support you). Then ask someone to nominate you. You're demonstrating your:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - at least 8 PR and the associated issues to the project,
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - ability to collaborate with the team,
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - understanding of the projects' code base and coding style, and
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - ability to write good code (last but certainly not least)
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: A current committer nominates you by slacking the team on the Nacos issue with label "nomination"
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - your first and last name
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - a link to your Git profile
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - an explanation of why you should be a committer,
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Elaborate the top 3 PR and the associated issues the nominator has worked with you that can demonstrate your ability.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Two other committer need to second your nomination. If no one objects in 5 working days (China), you're a committer. If anyone objects or wants more information, the committers discuss and usually come to a consensus (within the 5 working days). If issues cannot be resolved, there's a vote among current committers.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: In the worst case, this can drag out for two weeks. Keep contributing! Even in the rare cases where a nomination fails, the objection is usually something easy to address like "more patches" or "not enough people are familiar with this person's work."
Label: No categories identified.
