Paragraph: Pull Request Guidelines
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Only code that's ready for release should be committed to the master branch. All development should be done in dedicated branches.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Checkout a new topic branch from master branch, and merge back against master branch.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - If adding new feature:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Add accompanying test case.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Provide convincing reason to add this feature. Ideally you should open a suggestion issue first and have it greenlighted before working on it.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - If fixing a bug:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - If you are resolving a special issue, add (fix #xxxx[,#xxx]) (#xxxx is the issue id) in your title for a better release log,
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Provide detailed description of the bug in the PR. Live demo preferred.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Add appropriate test coverage if applicable.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Git Commit Specific
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Your commits message must follow our git commit specific.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - We will check your commit message, if it does not conform to the specification, the commit will be automatically refused, make sure you have read the specification above.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Providing Feedback
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: We are happy to hear any feedbacks or are delighted to ask any questions. You can join our Dingding Group or ask away on Stack Overflow using the tag Pipcook
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Contributing Guide
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Hi! I’m really excited that you are interested in contributing to Rax. Before submitting your contribution though, please make sure to take a moment and read through the following guidelines.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Issue Reporting Guidelines
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Pull Request Guidelines
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Git Commit Specific
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Development Workflow
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
After cloning rax, run npm install to fetch its dependencies.
Run npm run setup link and bootstrap project before development.
Then, you can run several commands:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: - npm run lint checks the code style.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: - npm test runs the complete test suite.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: - npm test -- --watch runs an interactive test watcher.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: - npm test <pattern> runs tests with matching filenames.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: - npm run build creates lib and dist folder with all the packages.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Issue Reporting Guidelines
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - The issue list of this repo is exclusively for bug reports and feature requests. Non-conforming issues will be closed immediately.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - For simple beginner questions, you can get quick answers from
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - For more complicated questions, you can use Google or StackOverflow. Make sure to provide enough information when asking your questions - this makes it easier for others to help you!
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Try to search for your issue, it may have already been answered or even fixed in the development branch.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Check if the issue is reproducible with the latest stable version of Rax. If you are using a pre-release, please indicate the specific version you are using.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - It is required that you clearly describe the steps necessary to reproduce the issue you are running into. Issues with no clear repro steps will not be triaged. If an issue labeled "need repro" receives no further input from the issue author for more than 5 days, it will be closed.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - For bugs that involves build setups, you can create a reproduction repository with steps in the README.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - If your issue is resolved but still open, don
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Pull Request Guidelines
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Only code that's ready for release should be committed to the master branch. All development should be done in dedicated branches.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Checkout a new topic branch from master branch, and merge back against master branch.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Work in the src folder and DO NOT checkin dist in the commits.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Make sure npm test passes.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - If adding new feature:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Add accompanying test case.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Provide convincing reason to add this feature. Ideally you should open a suggestion issue first and have it greenlighted before working on it.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - If fixing a bug:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - If you are resolving a special issue, add (fix #xxxx[,#xxx]) (#xxxx is the issue id) in your PR title for a better release log, e.g. update entities encoding/decoding (fix #3899).
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Provide detailed description of the bug in the PR. Live demo preferred.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Add appropriate test coverage if applicable.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Git Commit Specific
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Your commits message must follow our git commit specific.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - We will check your commit message, if it does not conform to the specification, the commit will be automatically refused, make sure you have read the specification above.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - You could use git cz with a CLI interface to replace git commit command, it will help you to build a proper commit-message, see commitizen.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - It's OK to have multiple small commits as you work on your branch - we will let GitHub automatically squash it before merging.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Contributing to Sentinel
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Welcome to Sentinel! This document is a guideline about how to contribute to Sentinel.
If you find something incorrect or missing, please leave comments / suggestions.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Before you get started
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Code of Conduct
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Please make sure to read and observe our Code of Conduct.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Setting up your development environment
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: You should have JDK 1.8 or later installed in your system.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Contributing
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
We are always very happy to have contributions, whether for typo fix, bug fix or big new features.
Please do not ever hesitate to ask a question or send a pull request.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
We strongly value documentation and integration with other projects.
We are very glad to accept improvements for these aspects.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: GitHub workflow
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: We use the master branch as the development branch, which indicates that this is a unstable branch.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Here are the workflow for contributors:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 1.  Fork to your own
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 2.  Clone fork to local repository
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 3.  Create a new branch and work on it
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 4.  Keep your branch in sync
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 5.  Commit your changes (make sure your commit message concise)
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 6.  Push your commits to your forked repository
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 7.  Create a pull request
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
Please follow the pull request template.
Please make sure the PR has a corresponding issue.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
After creating a PR, one or more reviewers will be assigned to the pull request.
The reviewers will review the code.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
Before merging a PR, squash any fix review feedback, typo, merged, and rebased sorts of commits.
The final commit message should be clear and concise.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Open an issue / PR
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: We use GitHub Issues and Pull Requests for trackers.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
If you find a typo in document, find a bug in code, or want new features, or want to give suggestions,
you can open an issue on GitHub to report it.
Please follow the guideline message in the issue template.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
If you want to contribute, please follow the contribution workflow and create a new pull request.
If your PR contains large changes, e.g. component refactor or new components, please write detailed documents
about its design and usage.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Note that a single PR should not be too large. If heavy changes are required, it's better to separate the changes
to a few individual PRs.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Code review
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: All code should be well reviewed by one or more committers. Some principles:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Readability: Important code should be well-documented. Comply with our code style.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Elegance: New functions, classes or components should be well designed.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Testability: Important code should be well-tested (high unit test coverage).
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Contributing to AliceVision
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Alice Vision relies on a friendly and community-driven effort to create an open source photogrammetry solution.
In order to foster a friendly atmosphere where technical collaboration can flourish,
we recommend you to read the code of conduct.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Contributing Workflow
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: The contributing workflow relies on Github Pull Requests.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
1.  If it is an important change, we recommend you to discuss it on the mailing-list
before starting implementation. This ensure that the development is aligned with other developments already started and will be efficiently integrated.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 2.  Create the corresponding issues.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
3.  Create a branch and start a PR starting by [WIP], like "[WIP] My new feature" so everyone can follow the development.
Explain the implementation in the PR description with links to issues.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
4.  Implement the new feature(s). Add unit test if needed.
One feature per PR is ideal for review, but linked features can be part of the same PR.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 5.  When it is ready for review, remove "WIP" from the PR name.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
6.  The reviewers will look over the code and ask for changes, explain problems they found,
congratulate the author, etc. using the github comments.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
7.  After approval, one of the developers with commit approval to the official main repository
will merge your fixes into the "develop" branch.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 8.  If not already the case, your name will be added to the contributors list.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Contributing to Meshroom
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Meshroom relies on a friendly and community-driven effort to create an open source photogrammetry solution.
In order to foster a friendly atmosphere where technical collaboration can flourish,
we recommend you to read the code of conduct.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Contributing Workflow
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: The contributing workflow relies on Github Pull Requests.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
1.  If it is an important change, we recommend you to discuss it on the mailing-list
before starting implementation. This ensure that the development is aligned with other
developpements already started and will be efficiently integrated.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 2.  Create the corresponding issues.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
3.  Create a branch and draft a pull request "My new feature" so everyone can follow the development.
Explain the implementation in the PR description with links to issues.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
4.  Implement the new feature(s). Add unit test if needed.
One feature per PR is ideal for review, but linked features can be part of the same PR.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 5.  When it is ready for review, mark the pull request as ready for review.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
6.  The reviewers will look over the code and ask for changes, explain problems they found,
congratulate the author, etc. using the github comments.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
7.  After approval, one of the developers with commit approval to the official main repository
will merge your fixes into the "develop" branch.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Contributing to SoloPi
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Solo? is released under the Apache 2.0 license, and follows a very standard Github development process, using Github tracker for issues and merging pull requests into master . If you would like to contribute something, or simply want to hack on the code this document should help you get started.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Sign the Contributor License Agreement
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Before we accept a non-trivial patch or pull request we will need you to sign the Contributor License Agreement. Signing the contributor
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: To get started, sign the Contributor License Agreement.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Code Conventions
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: None of these is essential for a pull request, but they will all help.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: 1.  Make sure all new .java files to have a simple Javadoc class comment with at least an @author tag identifying you, and preferably at least a paragraph on what the class is for.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: 2.  Add the ASF license header comment to all new .java files (copy from existing files in the project)
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: 3.  Add yourself as an @author to the .java files that you modify substantially (more than cosmetic changes).
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: 4.  Add some Javadocs.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: 5.  When writing a commit message please follow these conventions, if you are fixing an existing issue please add Fixes gh-XXXX at the end of the commit message (where XXXX is the issue number).
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Contributing
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Thanks for considering contributing!  We want AllenNLP to be the way to do cutting-edge NLP research, but we cannot
get there without community support.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: How Can I Contribute?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Bug fixes and new features
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Did you find a bug?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
First, do a quick search to see whether your issue has already been reported.
If your issue has already been reported, please comment on the existing issue.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Otherwise, open a new GitHub issue.  Be sure to include a clear title
and description.  The description should include as much relevant information as possible.  The description should
explain how to reproduce the erroneous behavior as well as the behavior you expect to see.  Ideally you would include a
code sample or an executable test case demonstrating the expected behavior.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Do you have a suggestion for an enhancement?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: We use GitHub issues to track enhancement requests.  Before you create an enhancement request:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- Make sure you have a clear idea of the enhancement you would like.  If you have a vague idea, consider discussing
it first on a GitHub issue.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Check the documentation to make sure your feature does not already exist.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Do a quick search to see whether your enhancement has already been suggested.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: When creating your enhancement request, please:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Provide a clear title and description.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Explain why the enhancement would be useful.  It may be helpful to highlight the feature in other libraries.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Include code examples to demonstrate how the enhancement would be used.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Making a pull request
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: When you're ready to contribute code to address an open issue, please follow these guidelines to help us be able to review your pull request (PR) quickly.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 1.  Initial setup (only do this once)
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: If you haven't already done so, please fork this repository on GitHub.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Then clone your fork locally with
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: git clone https://github.com/USERNAME/allennlp.git
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: or
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: git clone git@github.com:USERNAME/allennlp.git
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: At this point the local clone of your fork only knows that it came from your repo, github.com/USERNAME/allennlp.git, but doesn't know anything the main repo, https://github.com/allenai/allennlp.git. You can see this by running
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: git remote -v
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: which will output something like this:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
origin https://github.com/USERNAME/allennlp.git (fetch)
origin https://github.com/USERNAME/allennlp.git (push)
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: This means that your local clone can only track changes from your fork, but not from the main repo, and so you won't be able to keep your fork up-to-date with the main repo over time. Therefor you'll need to add another "remote" to your clone that points to https://github.com/allenai/allennlp.git. To do this, run the following:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: git remote add upstream https://github.com/allenai/allennlp.git
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Now if you do git remote -v again, you'll see
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
origin https://github.com/USERNAME/allennlp.git (fetch)
origin https://github.com/USERNAME/allennlp.git (push)
upstream https://github.com/allenai/allennlp.git (fetch)
upstream https://github.com/allenai/allennlp.git (push)
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Finally, you'll need to create a Python 3.6 or 3.7 virtual environment suitable for working on AllenNLP. There a number of tools out there that making working with virtual environments easier, but the most direct way is with the venv module in the standard library.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Once your virtual environment is activated, you can install your local clone in "editable mode" with
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
pip install -e .
pip install -r dev-requirements.txt
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: The "editable mode" comes from the -e argument to pip, and essential just creates a symbolic link from the site-packages directory of your virtual environment to the source code in your local clone. That way any changes you make will be immediately reflected in your virtual environment.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 2.  Ensure your fork is up-to-date
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Once you've added an "upstream" remote pointing to https://github.com/allenai/allennlp.git, keeping your fork up-to-date is easy:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
git checkout master  # if not already on master
git pull --rebase upstream master
git push
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 3.  Create a new branch to work on your fix or enhancement
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Commiting directly to the master branch of your fork is not recommended. It will be easier to keep your fork clean if you work on a seperate branch for each contribution you intend to make.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: You can create a new branch with
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
# replace BRANCH with whatever name you want to give it
git checkout -b BRANCH
git push -u origin BRANCH
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 4.  Test your changes
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Our continuous integration (CI) testing runs a number of checks for each pull request on GitHub Actions. You can run most of these tests locally, which is something you should do before opening a PR to help speed up the review process and make it easier for us.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: First, you should run black to make sure you code is formatted consistently. Many IDEs support code formatters as plugins, so you may be able to setup black to run automatically everytime you save. black.vim will give you this functionality in Vim, for example. But black is also easy to run directly from the command line. Just run this from the root of your clone:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: black .
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Our CI also uses flake8 to lint the code base and mypy for type-checking. You should run both of these next with
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: make lint
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: and
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: make typecheck
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: We also strive to maintain high test coverage, so most contributions should include additions to the unit tests. These tests are run with pytest, which you can use to locally run any test modules that you've added or changed.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: For example, if you've fixed a bug in allennlp/nn/util.py, you can run the tests specific to that module with
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: pytest -v tests/nn/util_test.py
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Our CI will automatically check that test coverage stays above a certain threshold (around 90%). To check the coverage locally in this example, you could run
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: pytest -v --cov allennlp.nn.util tests/nn/util_test.py
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: If your contribution involves changes to any docstrings, you should make sure the API documentation can build without errors. For that, just run
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: make build-docs
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: If the build fails, it's most likely due to small formatting issues. If the error message isn't clear, feel free to comment on this in your pull request.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: You can also serve and view the docs locally with
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: make serve-docs
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: And finally, please update the CHANGELOG with notes on your contribution in the "Unreleased" section at the top.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
After all of the above checks have passed, you can now open a new GitHub pull request.
Make sure you have a clear description of the problem and the solution, and include a link to relevant issues.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: We look forward to reviewing your PR!
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: New models
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Do you have a new state-of-the-art model?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: We are always looking for new models to add to our collection. The most popular models are usually added to the official AllenNLP Models repository, and in some cases to the AllenNLP Demo.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: If you think your model should be part of AllenNLP Models, please create a pull request in the models repo that includes:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Any code changes needed to support your new model.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- A link to the model itself.  Please do not check your model into the GitHub repository, but instead upload it in the
PR conversation or provide a link to it at an external location.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: In the description of your PR, please clearly explain the task your model performs along with the relevant metrics on an established dataset.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Feedback and Contribution
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
We welcome any input, feedback, bug reports, and contributions via Altair's
GitHub Repository. In particular, we
welcome companion efforts from other visualization libraries to render the
Vega-Lite specifications output by Altair. We see this portion of the effort
as much bigger than Altair itself: the Vega and Vega-Lite specifications are
perhaps the best existing candidates for a principled lingua franca of data
visualization.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
We are also seeking contributions of additional Jupyter notebook-based examples
in our separate GitHub repository: https://github.com/altair-viz/altair_notebooks.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
The altair users mailing list can be found at
https://groups.google.com/forum/#!forum/altair-viz. If you are working on
Altair, you can talk to other developers in the #altair channel of the Vega
slack.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: How To Contribute Code to Alatir
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Setting Up Your Environment
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Install the latest version of Altair locally using
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: $ pip install git+https://github.com/altair-viz/altair/
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
Next step is to fork the repository on GitHub and clone the fork to you local
machine. For more details on forking see the GitHub
Documentation.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: $ git clone https://github.com/YOUR-USERNAME/altair.git
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
You can have a single clone of the repository that points to both your fork and
the main package repository. These pointers to GitHub are called "remotes" .
On your local clone you should run:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
$ git remote add upstream https://github.com/altair-viz/altair.git
$ git checkout master
$ git pull upstream master
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
And then you'll have all the updates in the master branch of your local fork.
Note that git will complain if you've committed changes to your local master
branch that are not on upstream (this is one reason it's good practice to never
work directly on your master branch).
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Creating a Branch
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Once your local environment is up-to-date, you can create a new git branch which will
contain your contribution:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: $ git checkout -b <branch-name>
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
With this branch checked-out, make the desired changes to the package.
Note that Altair code uses the black
code formatter, which you can apply to your modifications by installing
and running black on the local directory:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
$ pip install black
$ black .
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: When you are happy with your changes, you can commit them to your branch by runing
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
$ git add <modified-file>
$ git commit -m "Some descriptive message about your change"
$ git push origin <branch-name>
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Finally you will need to submit a pull request (PR) on GitHub asking to merge
your example branch into altair master. For details on creating a PR see GitHub
documentation Creating a pull
request. You can
add more details about your example in the PR such as motivation for the
example or why you thought it would be a good addition.  You will get feed back
in the PR discussion if anything needs to be changed. To make changes continue
to push commits made in your local example branch to origin and they will be
automatically shown in the PR.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Hopefully your PR will be answered in a timely manner and your contribution will
help others in the future.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Testing your Changes
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
When you submit a pull request, Altair's continuous integration test suite will
run a number of tests to validate the correctness of your code. It can be helpful
when debugging to run those tests locally; to do this first install Altair's
development requirements:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: $ pip install -r requirements_dev.txt
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: and then run the test suite with:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: $ make test
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Adding Examples
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
We are always interested in new examples contributed from the community.  These
could be everything from simple one-panel scatter and line plots, to more
complicated layered or stacked plots, to more advanced interactive features.
Before submitting a new example check the Altair Example
Gallery to make sure that
your idea has not already been implemented.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Once you have an example you would like to add there are a few guide lines to follow.
Every example should:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - be saved as a stand alone script in the altair/examples/ directory.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- have a descriptive docstring, which will eventually be extracted for the
documentation website.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - contain a category tag.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- define a chart variable with the main chart object (This will be used both in
the unit tests to confirm that the example executes properly, and also
eventually used to display the visualization on the documentation website).
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- not make any external calls to download data within the script (i.e. don't
use urllib). You can define your data directly within the example file,
generate your data using pandas and numpy, or you can use data
available in the vega_datasets package.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
The easiest way to get started would be to adapt examples from the Vega-Lite
example gallery which are missing
in the altair gallery. Or you can feel free to be creative and build your own
visualizations.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Often it is convenient to draft an example outside of the main repository, such
as Google Colab, to avoid difficulties
when working with git. Once you have an example you would like to add, follow the
same contribution procedure outlined above.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Some additional notes:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- all examples should be in their own file in the altair/examples directory, and
the format and style of new contributions should generally match that of existing examples.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- The file docstring will be rendered into HTML via
reStructuredText, so use that
format for any hyperlinks or text styling. In particular, be sure you include
a title in the docstring underlined with ---, and be sure that the size of
the underline exactly matches the size of the title text.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- If your example fits into a chart type but involves significant configuration
it should be in the case studies category. If your example doesn't fit well
into any category then it can be included in the other charts category.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- For consistency all data used for a visualization should be assigned to the
variable source. Then source is passed to the alt.Chart object. See
other examples for guidance.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- Example code should not require downloading external datasets. We suggest
using the vega_datasets package if possible.
If you are using the vega_datasets package there are multiple ways to refer
to a data source. If the dataset you would like to use is included in local
installation (vega_datasets.local_data.list_datasets()) then the data can
be referenced directly, such as source = data.iris(). If the data is not
included then it should be referenced by URL, such as source = data.movies.url. This is to ensure that Altair's automated test suite does
not depend on availability of external HTTP resources.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Note that examples shown on the altair website
are only updated when a new version is released so your new example might not show
up there for a while.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: How to Contribute to the Android Beacon Library
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: This project welcomes code contributions from the communityProposed code changes should be submitted as a pull request on Github. Please follow the following guidelines when submitting a pull request.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Style
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Code style should generally follow the Android coding style
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: API Changes
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Changes generally should not break the existing API and should be backward compatible with the current release version If the PR does represent a breaking change, the title or description must make this clear. Breaking changes will be held for the next major version release of the library.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Testing
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: PRs must include testing information to ensure the changes are functional and do not adversely affect other library functionsTesting information must include one or more of the following:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 1. Automated Robolectric tests:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Robolectric tests are required for most changes, and should be submitted along with the PRExceptions include Bluetooth or Android OS-level changes that cannot be tested with Robolectric. Examples of Robolectric tests exist in the src/test folder.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Robolectric test updates are absolutely required if existing Robolectric tests exists for the modified code.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Regardless of whether Robolectric tests are added or modified, all tests must be passing on the branch of the PR when running ./gradlew test
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 2. Manual tests:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Changes affecting Bluetooth scanning, addressing device-specific issues often cannot be adequately tested using Robolectric since it stubs out Bluetooth and Android OS system callsChanges of this nature must be manually tested on a physical device. Manual tests should be performed with the library's reference application, if possible.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: When submitting a PR, a description of any manual testing performed should include:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Mobile device model and Android OS version.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Description of beacon device and configuration used during testing (if applicable)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - A description of the steps taken to do the manual testing
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - A description of the conditions witnessed that verify the code works as designed and that other functions are not broken
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 3. Changes that cannot be tested manually or with Robolectric
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: In some rare cases where changes cannot be verified manually (e.g. some intermittent issues), a description may be included of why testing cannot be performed and describing why the change is low-risk and can be verified by code reviewFor such changes to be considered low-risk they typically must be very small
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: License
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Any code submitted must be the work of the author, or if third party must be covered by the same Apache 2 license as this library or the Android Open Source ProjectOnce submitted, the code is covered under the terms of the license of this library.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Contributing
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: We encourage any form of contribution, whether that be issues, comments, or pull requests. If you are going to be submitting a PR, there are a few things we would appreciate that you do to keep the codebase clean:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Write tests. We try as close to 100% code coverage as possible on this repo so any new code that gets written should have accompanying tests.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Follow the linter. We use our ESLint configuration with Airbnb JavaScript Styleguide, and we run npm run lint in our Travis builds.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Ask questions if you aren't sure. If you have any questions while implementing a fix or feature, feel free to create an issue and ask us. We're happy to help!
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Submission Guidelines
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Submitting an Issue
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Before you submit an issue, please search the issue tracker, maybe an issue for your problem already exists and the discussion might inform you of workarounds readily available.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Submitting a Pull Request (PR)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Before you submit your Pull Request (PR) consider the following guidelines:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
1.  Search GitHub for an open or closed PR
that relates to your submission. You don't want to duplicate effort.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
2.  Be sure that an issue describes the problem you're fixing, or documents the design for the feature you'd like to add.
Discussing the design up front helps to ensure that we're ready to accept your work.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 3.  Fork the amejiarosario/dsa.js repo.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 4.  Make your changes in a new git branch:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git checkout -b my-fix-branch master
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 5.  Create your patch, including appropriate test cases.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 6.  Run the full test suite, and ensure that all tests pass.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
7.  Commit your changes using a descriptive commit message that follows our
commit message conventions. Adherence to these conventions
is necessary because release notes are automatically generated from these messages.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git commit -a
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Note: the optional commit -a command line option will automatically "add" and "rm" edited files.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 8.  Push your branch to GitHub:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git push origin my-fix-branch
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 9.  In GitHub, send a pull request to dsa.js:master.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - If we suggest changes then:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Make the required updates.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Re-run the test suites to ensure tests are still passing.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Rebase your branch and force push to your GitHub repository (this will update your Pull Request):
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
git rebase master -i
git push -f
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: That's it! Thank you for your contribution!
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: After your pull request is merged
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
After your pull request is merged, you can safely delete your branch and pull the changes
from the main (upstream) repository:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Delete the remote branch on GitHub either through the GitHub web UI or your local shell as follows:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git push origin --delete my-fix-branch
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Check out the master branch:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git checkout master -f
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Delete the local branch:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git branch -D my-fix-branch
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Update your master with the latest upstream version:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git pull --ff upstream master
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Commit Message Guidelines
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
We have some guidelines how our git commit messages can be formatted.  This leads to more
readable messages that are easy to follow when looking through the project history.  But also,
we use the git commit messages to generate the change log.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Commit Message Format
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Each commit message consists of a header, a body and a footer.  The header has a special
format that includes a type, a scope and a subject:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
<type>(<scope>): <subject>
<BLANK LINE>
<body>
<BLANK LINE>
<footer>
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Example of a commit with header, body and footer:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: fix(linked-list): insert in the middle bug
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: When inserting an item on the middle of a linked list one reference was not being updated properly.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Fixes: #8
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: The header is mandatory and the scope of the header is optional.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Any line of the commit message cannot be longer 100 characters! This allows the message to be easier
to read on GitHub as well as in various git tools.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: The footer should contain a closing reference to an issue if any.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: docs(changelog): update changelog to beta.5
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: fix(release): need to depend on latest rxjs and zone.js
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: The version in our package.json gets copied to the one we publish, and users need the latest of these.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Revert
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: If the commit reverts a previous commit, it should begin with revert: , followed by the header of the reverted commit. In the body it should say: This reverts commit <hash>., where the hash is the SHA of the commit being reverted.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Type
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Must be one of the following:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - fix: A bug fix
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - feat: A new feature
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - chore: Changes to our CI configuration files and scripts (example scopes: Circle, BrowserStack, SauceLabs)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Scope
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: The scope should be the name of the npm package affected (as perceived by the person reading the changelog generated from commit messages.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: The following is an example of supported scopes:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - list
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - map
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - tree
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - graph
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - sorting
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - etc.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Subject
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: The subject contains a succinct description of the change:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - use the imperative, present tense: "change" not "changed" nor "changes"
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - don't capitalize the first letter
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - no dot (.) at the end
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Body
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Just as in the subject, use the imperative, present tense: "change" not "changed" nor "changes".
The body should include the motivation for the change and contrast this with previous behavior.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Footer
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
The footer should contain any information about BREAKING CHANGES and is also the place to
reference GitHub issues that this commit Closes.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Closes #234
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Breaking Changes should start with the word BREAKING CHANGE: on the footer with a space or two newlines. The rest of the commit message is then used for this.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Examples of breaking changes include:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - removal or redefinition of existing API arguments
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - changing return values
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - removing or modifying existing properties on an options argument
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - adding or removing errors
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - altering expected timing of an event
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - changing the side effects of using a particular API
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Generating Changelog
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: We use these three sections in changelog: new features, bug fixes, breaking changes.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: List of all subjects (first lines in commit message) since last release:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git log <last tag> HEAD --pretty=format:%s
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
# example
git log 1.1.0..HEAD --pretty=format:%s
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: New features in this release
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git log <last release> HEAD --grep feat
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
# examples
git log 1.2.0..HEAD --pretty=format:"- %s [commit](https://github.com/amejiarosario/dsa.js/commit/%H)" --grep "BREAKING CHANGE:"
git log 1.2.0..HEAD --pretty=format:"- %s [commit](https://github.com/amejiarosario/dsa.js/commit/%H)" --grep "^feat\S*:"
git log 1.2.0..HEAD --pretty=format:"- %s [commit](https://github.com/amejiarosario/dsa.js/commit/%H)" --grep "^fix\S*:"
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Submitting useful bug reports
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Please search existing issues first to make sure this is not a duplicate.
Every issue report has a cost for the developers required to field it; be
respectful of others' time and ensure your report isn't spurious prior to
submission. Please adhere to sound bug reporting principles.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Development ideology
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Truths which we believe to be self-evident:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- It's an asynchronous world.  Be wary of anything that undermines
async principles.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- The answer is not more options.  If you feel compelled to expose
new preferences to the user it's very possible you've made a wrong
turn somewhere.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- There are no power users. The idea that some users "understand"
concepts better than others has proven to be, for the most part, false.
If anything, "power users" are more dangerous than the rest, and we
should avoid exposing dangerous functionality to them.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Code style
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: The amphp project adheres to the PSR-2 style guide.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: To apply code standards you can run php-cs-fixer with following composer command:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: composer code-style
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Running the tests
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Run the test suite from root directory:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: composer test
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Contributing to AMP HTML
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: The AMP HTML project strongly encourages your participation and contributions!
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: We hope you'll become an ongoing participant in our open source community but we also welcome one-off contributions for the issues you're particularly passionate about.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: How would you like to help?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Report a bug
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Make a suggestion
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Contribute code/features
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Get started with open source
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Participate in ongoing discussions
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: If you have questions about using AMP or are encountering problems using AMP on your site please visit our support page for help.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Report a bug
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: File an issue if you find a bug in AMP. Provide a detailed description and steps for reproducing the bug; screenshots and working examples that demonstrate the problem are appreciated!
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: The community regularly monitoring issues and will try to fix open bugs quickly according to our prioritization guidelines.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Make a suggestion
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: File a "feature request" issue if you have a suggestion for a way to improve AMP or a request for a new AMP feature.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: If you are suggesting a feature that you are intending to implement, please see the Contributing code/features section below for next steps.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Contribute code/features
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: We'd love to have your help contributing code and features to AMP!
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: See the Contributing code and features document for details on the process you can use to add code/features.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Get started with open source
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: If you are new to contributing to an open source project, Git/GitHub, etc. welcome! We are glad you're interested in contributing to AMP and we want to help make your open source experience a success.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: The Getting Started End-to-End Guide provides step-by-step instructions for everything from creating a GitHub account to getting your code reviewed and merged. Even if you've never contributed to an open source project before you'll soon be building AMP, making improvements and seeing your code live across the web.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: The community has created a list of Good First Issues specifically for new contributors to the project. Feel free to find one of the unclaimed Good First Issues that interests you, claim it by adding a comment to it and jump in!
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: If you're interested in helping out but can't find a Good First Issue that matches your skills/interests, sign up for our Slack and then reach out in the #welcome-contributors channel or send a Direct Message to mrjoro.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: If you run into any problems we have plenty of people who are willing to help; see the How to get help section of the Getting Started guide.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph:
Drogon is an open source project at its heart and every contribution is
welcome. By participating in this project you agree to stick to common sense and
contribute in an overall positive way.

Paragraph: Getting Started
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 1.  Fork, then clone the repository: git clone git@github.com:your-username/drogon.git
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
2.  Follow the official installation steps on
DocsForge. It
make sure to have the drogon_ctl executable in your shellPATH
environment variable in case you use a terminal.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
Now you can create branches, start adding features & bugfixes to the code, and
create pull requests.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Pull Requests
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Feel free to create a pull request
if you think you can contribute to the project. You will be listed as a
contributor, agree to
this document, and the
LICENSE.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
There are also some recommendations you can follow. These aren
but they will make the development more straightforward:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
1.  If you are unsure about a specific change, have questions, or want to get
feedback about a feature you want to introduce, open a new
issue (please make sure that there
is no previous issue about a similar topic).
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
2.  You should branch off the current state of the master branch, and also
merge it into your local branch before creating a pull request if there were
other changes introduced in the meantime.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 3.  You can use the following branch names to make your intent clearer:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- bugfix/123-fix-template-parser when you want to fix a bug in the
template parser.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- feature/123-add-l10n-and-i18n if you want to add localization (l10n) and
internationalization (i18n) as a new feature to the project.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- If there
and just use the descriptive part: bugfix/fix-typo-in-docs.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
4.  Write a brief, but good, and descriptive commit message / pull request title in English,
e.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: If you follow these recommendations your pull request will have more success:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
1.  Keep the style consistent to the project, when in doubt refer to the Google
C++ Style Guide.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
2.  Please write all comments in English. Comments for new public API introduced by
your pull request must be added and written in Doxygen format.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
3.  Format the code with clang-format (>= 8.0.0). The configuration is already
provided in the .clang-format file, just run the ./format.sh script
before submitting your pull request.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
4.  Install Google Test, and write a test
case.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
1.  In case it is a bugfix, it
version, but works in the new one. This way regressions can be tracked
over time.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
2.  If you add a feature, it is best to write the test as if it would be an
example how to use the newly introduced feature and to test all major,
newly introduced code.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: What branch do I work from? How do I even pull request?

Paragraph: These are the branches in this project, and what they're for.

Paragraph: - master
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - This branch is for the current release of anchor, so 0.* releases. If you wish to submit a PR with a fix, please do it from this branch.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - pre-1.0-develop
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - This branch is for active development on the current relase, so 0.* etc. If you wish to PR with a feature that doesn't make a fix, please do so to this branch, but please make sure your branches are up to date.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - develop
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - This is for active development on the next major release of Anchor, so 1.0+, feel free to take a look at this, though please don't rely on this for your projects as it's still a WIP.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: We're planning on cleaning everything up once 1.0 is released, so if you're able to follow these guidelines, it will make things much easier for us.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Why won't you merge my PR?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: This may be the case if you've not followed our guidelines, your code does not do as suggested, it doesn't work or if we simply haven't had the time to take a look at it properly and ensure it's working correctly.

Paragraph: How to submit feature requests
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: If you would like to add submit a feature request then please go to our Feathub page. If it's not already on the list then please add it and provide a description in the comments section. If it already exists then please give the existing entry a thumbs up. :+1:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: How to submit issues
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Please follow the below points:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Check if bug is consistent in different environments
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Check if its been reported and solved in the Anchor forum
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Check if there is an issue that already covers or relates to it (including closed issues)
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Give an accurate and concise title to issue
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Prefix title of issue with Bug: or Feature:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Explain bug briefly but in detail
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Give guidance on how to reproduce bug
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Add screenshots when possible
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Follow the templates that autofill the editor - failure to follow the template will result in closure of the issue without resolution
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: ProTip: Check out this example issue for reference on good bug reporting.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Keep in mind that when you submit an issue, you are the maintainer of that issue. The team or community may ask for more detail on specifics about the issue, so cooperating is always great. However, due to there being a large number of issue reports that suddenly become inactive, we request that you keep checking back.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: If the issue remains inactive (or dormant) for two to four weeks (depending on the issue), we may close it, assuming that it's been fixed. If you just happen to be late back to the party, simply bump the issue with a comment making sure to include any updates.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: It is important to note that this is for house cleaning purposes, rather than for shrugging off issues. Cooperation is requested.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: When writing your code, always follow standards
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: If you're familiar with open source software, you probably know how important coding guidelines and standards are. Most common are (in order of appearance) PEAR, Zend(Framework) and PSR-1/PSR-2.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
Since the PHP-FIG and their standards gain more and more followers and Anchor uses composer, which supports PSR-0 and PSR-4, all code should follow PSR-1 and PSR-2.
More help on best practices for PHP development can be found on PHP the right way.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: When working on a file, always enforce coding standards for the whole file. This increases the consistency of the code with every contribution! If you don't, we may reject your pull requests.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Contributing
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Contributions are welcome and will be fully credited.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Pull Requests
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - PSR-2 Coding Standard.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Document any change in behaviour - Make sure the README.md and any other relevant documentation are kept up-to-date.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Create feature branches - Don't ask us to pull from your master branch.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - One pull request per feature - If you want to do more than one thing, send multiple pull requests.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Pull requests go against develop branch - So we can test it before merging it onto master.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Send coherent history - Make sure each individual commit in your pull request is meaningful. If you had to make multiple intermediate commits while developing, please squash them before submitting.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Contributing to libui
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: libui is an open source project that openly accepts contributions. I appreciate your help!
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Rules for contributing code
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: While libui is open to contributions, a number of recent, significantly large contributions and uncontributed forks have recently surfaced that do not present themselves in a form that makes it easy for libui to accept them. In order to give your contribution a high chance of being accepted into libui, please keep the following in mind as you prepare your contribution.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Commit messages and pull request description
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: libui does not enforce rules about the length or detail that a commit message. I'm not looking for an essay. However, single-word descriptions of nontrivial changes are not acceptable. I should be able to get a glimpse of what a commit does from the commit message, even if it's just one sentence to describe a trivial change. (Yes, I know I haven't followed this rule strictly myself, but I try not to break it too.) And a commit message should encompass everything; typically, I make a number of incremental commits toward a feature, so the commit messages don't have to be too long to explain everything.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Your pull request description, on the other hand, must be a summary of the sum total of all the changes made to libui. Don't just drop a pull request on me with a one-line-long elevator pitch of what you added. Describe your proposed API changes, implementation requirements, and any important consequences of your work.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Code formatting
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: libui uses K&R C formatting rules for overall code structure: spaces after keywords like if, { on the same line as a statement with a space, { on its own line after a function or method signature (even those inside the class body), no space after the name of a function, etc.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Use hard tabs, NOT spaces, for indentation. I use a proportional-width font and my text editor doesn't set tabs to a multiple of the space width, so I will be able to tell. If you use a fixed-width font, I suggest setting a tab width of 4 spaces per tab, but don't put diagrams in comments with hard tabs, because not everyone does this.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Expressions should have a space around binary operators, and use parentheses where it would help humans gather the meaning of an expression, regardless of whether a computer could tell what is correct.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: When breaking expressions into multiple lines, always break after an operator, such as , or &&.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: There should be a newline between a function's variables and a function's code. After that, you can place newlines to delimit different parts of a function, but don't go crazy.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: In the event you are unsure of something, refer to existing libui code for examples. I may wind up fixing minor details later anyway, so don't fret about getting minor details right the first time.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Naming
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: libui uses camel-case for naming, with a handful of very specific exceptions (namely GObject method names, where GObject itself enforces the naming convention).
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: All public API names should begin with ui and followed by a capital letter. All public struct field names should begin with a capital letter. This is identical to the visibiilty rules of Go, assuming a package name of ui.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Private API names uipriv and be followed by a capital letter. This avoids namespace collisions in static libraries.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Static functions and static objects do not have naming restrictions.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Acronyms should NOT be mixed-case. http for the first word in a camel-case name, HTTP for all else, but NEVER Http. This is possibly the only aspect of the controversial nature of code style that I consider indefensibly stupid.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: API documentation
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: (TODO I am writing an API documentation tool; once that becomes stable enough I can talk about documenting libui properly. You'll see vestiges of it throughout ui.h, though.)
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Other commenting
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: (TODO write this part)
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Compatibility
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: libui takes backward compatibility seriously. Your code should not break the current compatibility requirements. All platforms provide a series of macros, defined in the various uipriv_*.h files (or winapi.hpp on Windows), that specify the minimum required version. If you find yourself needing to remove these or ignore resultant warnings or errors, you're probably breaking compatibility.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Choosing to drop older versions of Windows, GTK+, and OS X that I could have easily continued to support was not done lightly. If you want to discuss dropping support for an older version of any of these for the benefit of libui, file an issue pleading your case (see below).
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: GTK+ versions are harder to drop because I am limited by Linux distribution packaging. In general, I will consider bumping GTK+ versions on a new Ubuntu LTS release, choosing the earliest version available on the major distributions at the time of the previous Ubuntu LTS release. As of writing, the next milestone will be after April 2018, and the target GTK+ version appears to be 3.18, judging by Ubuntu 16.04 LTS alone. This may be bumped back depending on other distros (or it may not be bumped at all), but you may wish to keep this in mind as you write.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: (TODO talk about future.c/.cpp/.m files)
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: As for language compatibility, libui is written in C99. I have no intention of changing this.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: As for build system compatibility, libui uses CMake 3.1.0. If you wish to bump the version, file an issue pleading your case (but see below).
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: If you do plead your case, keep in mind that "it's old" is not a sufficient reason to drop things. If you can prove that virtually no one uses the minimum version anymore, then that is stronger evidence. The best evidence, however, is that not upgrading will hold libui back in some significant way
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Windows-specific notes
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: The Windows backend of libui is written in C++ using C++11.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Despite using C++, please refrain from using the following:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - using C++ in ui_windows.h (this file should still be C compatible)
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - smart pointers
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - namespaces
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - using namespace
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - ATL, MFC, WTL
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: The following are not recommended, for consistency with the rest of libui:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - variable declarations anywhere in a function (keep them all at the top)
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - for (int x... (C++11 foreach syntax is fine, though)
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - omitting the struct on type names for ordinary structs
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: The format of a class should be
Label: DC – Deal with the code
DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: GTK+-specific notes
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Avoid GNU-specific language features. I build with strict C99 conformance.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: OS X-specific notes
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Avoid GNU-specific/clang-specific language features. I build with strict C99 conformance.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: libui is presently not ARC-compliant. Features that require ARC should be avoided for now. I may consider changing this in the future, but it will be a significant change.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: To ensure maximum compiler output in the event of a coding error, there should not be any implicit method calls in Objective-C code. For instance, don't do
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: [[array objectAtIndex:i] method]
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Instead, cast the result of objectAtIndex: to the appropriate type, and then call the method. (TODO learn about, then decide a policy on, soft-generics on things other than id)
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: The format of a class should be
Label: DC – Deal with the code
DC – Deal with the code
DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: @implementation name
Label: DC – Deal with the code
DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: @end
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Contributing to C++ Insights {#contributing}
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Thanks for considering contributing to C++ Insights.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: C++ Insights follows a Code of Conduct which aims to foster an open and welcoming environment.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: In brief
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
C++ Insights is a clang tooling project. Therefore it requires libclang to be installed. You can compile it either with
g++ or clang++.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: The current C++ language version used is C++17.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Contribute
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
There is a Travis CI running which compiles the code on Linux and macOS. Currently, it is limited to a out-of-source
build. Windows is not supported yet. Please check the Travis CI status for each PR. The macOS build runs the unit tests.
Code coverage runs on one of the Linux images.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Fixing an Issue
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Create a test named: Issue<ISSUE_NUMBER>.cpp and a Issue<ISSUE_NUMBER>.expect with the transformed code after the fix.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Contribute new functionality
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: CONTRIBUTING
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: AsyncHttpClient is an open-source project made by developers for developers!
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: If you would like to contribute to the project, it's really great. You can contribute in a variety of ways:
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: - Help us with test cases and examples for the Wiki (and kindly follow our Coding Standards)
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: - If you have a good idea/patch for the project, create a pull request
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: - Found a bug? You're more than welcome to submit an issue
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: - Help other fellow developers solve their problems, you're welcome to do so in issues
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: We do require certain guidelines to be followed so that the quality of the project remains top-notch:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: PULL requests
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: When you submit a patch or a new functionality for the project, you must open a pull request. We will get to the pull request as soon as possible, investigate what functionality or bug fixes have been added and decide whether to include it in the library or not -- for the benefit of everyone.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: You agree that all contributions that you make to the library will be distributed further under the same license as the library itself (Apache V2).
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Don't be discouraged if your pull request is rejected. This is not a deadline and sometimes with a proper explanation on your side, we are persuaded to merge in the request. Just remember that this is a library for everyone and as such must meet certain, generic rules that we would like to believe are following.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: ISSUES
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Read the ISSUES?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: The issues system is the place to report bugs and not for submitting patches or new functionality. As helpful as we would like to be, we cannot replace the developer and we certainly do not see what you're seeing. So when you come to report an issue, follow these simple rules:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Report bugs in the English language only
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Use Markdown to format your issue in a fashionable way (easier to read): Familiarize yourself
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - If the issue is due to a crash, include the stack trace -- throwable.printStackTrace() -- and any other detail that will shed light on the problem
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - We need to see the source code (minus certain details that you think are confidential) that caused the problem in the first place, so include it too
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Opening issues without providing us with the information necessary to debug and fix it is useless; so we will close such issues within 7 days period
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: CODING STANDARDS
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: We need you to follow certain rules when sending source code contributions. These are the basic principles that we ourselves abide to and we require that you do so as well:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Do not use the Tab character (it's in first place for a reason)
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Indentation is 4 spaces
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Include the copyright info (as in other files) at the top of the class file
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - You must provide proper Javadoc, including description, in English for both public and protected methods, classes and properties
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Group packages that belong to the same top-level package together, followed by an empty line
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Add an empty line after and before class/interface declarations, methods and constructors
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Add an empty line before and after a group of properties
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Do not catch generic Exception/Throwable errors, but always catch the most specific type of the exception/error
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: How to become a contributor and submit your own code
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Contributor License Agreements
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
We'd love to accept your sample apps and patches! Before we can take them, we
have to jump a couple of legal hurdles.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
Please fill out either the individual or corporate Contributor License Agreement
(CLA).
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
- If you are an individual writing original source code and you're sure you
own the intellectual property, then you'll need to sign an [individual CLA]
(http://code.google.com/legal/individual-cla-v1.0.html).
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
- If you work for a company that wants to allow you to contribute your work,
then you'll need to sign a [corporate CLA]
