Paragraph: Reporting issues
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Make sure that what you are experiencing is actually an error and that it lies
with homeshick (often it can be a git configuration error)
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Questions
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
If you have a question be sure to read
the documentation first.
Often you will find the answer to it there.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Description
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: As with bug reports everywhere else:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - state the action(s) you took
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - explain what outcome you expected
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - describe the actual result
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
You will also need to report which operating system you encountered the issue on
and which shell you used (type echo $SHELL in your terminal if you are unsure).
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Reproducing
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Unless you ran in to a heisenbug,
it should be possible to reproduce the
bug in a testing environment. To that end run
$HOME/.homesick/repos/homeshick/test/interactive and reproduce the bug.  This
script drops you into a new shell where $HOME is set to an (almost) empty
temporary folder. If you cannot reproduce the bug there, the error is likely
with your setup and not homeshick. Otherwise attach the commands you executed
in that environment to the issue.
Label: No categories identified.

Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Branching
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Work from and create pull requests on development, not master.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
master always represents the latest release since that is the way homeshick
updates itself. The development branch is where work is done for the next
release version of homeshick.

Paragraph: Code style
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Indent with tabs and align with spaces.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Label: DC – Deal with the code

- Run your changes through
shellcheck with test/shellcheck
and the bats testsuite with test/run
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
Use the supplied editorconfig file.
Most editors have editorconfig plugins
to apply these settings.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Content
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Every PR should only contain one feature change, bug fix or typo correction.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Commits should be atomic units of work, if they are not you should rebase them
so that they are (typo corrections from a previous change for example do not
justify a commit).
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Description
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
The PR should clearly describe what problem the change fixes.
A feature addition with no justification and use-case will be rejected.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Testing
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Unless the code-change is a refactor, you should always add unit tests.  When
fixing a bug there should be a new test case that fails with the old code and
succeeds with the new code. When introducing a new feature, it should be
tested extensively, a single test case will not suffice.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Note that bats does not fail a test case when using double brackets.
To assert variable values and file existance you must use single brackets!
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Also consider negative test cases (e.g. what happens when a non-existing
castlename is passed as an argument?).
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
You can read about the details of the testing framework in the
testing documentation.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Project Scope
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: The AngleSharp project ultimately tries to provide tools to parse, inspect, modify and interact with traditional web resources, such as HTML or CSS, for .NET development. Anything that is related to this goal will be considered. The project aims to be fully standards compliant. If your contribution is not following the standard, the chances of accepting it are limited.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Code License
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: This is an open source project falling under the MIT License. By using, distributing, or contributing to this project, you accept and agree that all code within the AngleSharp project and its libraries are licensed under MIT license.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Becoming a Contributor
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Until the project has enough contributors a BDFL model is followed. As such the sole key maintainer keeps the right to appoint GitHub members as regular project contributors. Nevertheless, usually appointing someone follows this process:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 1.  An individual contributes actively via discussions (reporting bugs, giving feedback to existing or opening new issues) and / or pull requests
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 2.  The individual is either directly asked, invited or asks for contributor rights on the project
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 3.  The individual uses the contribution rights to sustain or increase the active contributions
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Every contributor has to sign the contributor's license agreement (CLA) to establish a legal trust between the project and its contributors.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Modifying the code
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: AngleSharp and its libraries uses features from the latest versions of C# (e.g., C# 7). You will therefore need a C# compiler that is up for the job.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 1.  Fork and clone the repo.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 2.  First try to build the AngleSharp.Core libray and see if you get the tests running.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 3.  You will be required to resolve some dependencies via NuGet.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: AngleSharp itself does not have dependencies, however, the tests are dependent on NUnit.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: The build system of AngleSharp uses Cake. A bootstrap script (build.ps1 for Windows or build.sh for *nix systems) is included. Note, that at the moment AngleSharp may require NuGet 3.5, which looks for MSBuild pre-15, i.e., before Visual Studio 2017 on Windows systems. We aim to drop this requirement enitirely soon.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Code Conventions
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Most parts in the AngleSharp project are fairly straight forward. Among these are:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Always use statement blocks for control statements, e.g., in a for-loop, if-condition, ...
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - You may use a simple (throw) statement in case of enforcing contracts on argument
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Be explicit about modifiers (some files follow an older convention of the code base, but we settled on the explicit style)
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: There are a couple of rules, which are definitely not standard, but highly recommended for consistency and readability:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - AngleSharp uses the RHS convention, where types are always put on the right hand side if possible, i.e., preferring var under all circumstances
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - A single empty line between two non-simple statements (e.g., for-loop and if-condition) should be inserted
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Types are preferred to keywords (String instead of string or Int32 instead of int)
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - using statements must be inside the namespace declaration
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Development Workflow
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 1.  If no issue already exists for the work you'll be doing, create one to document the problem(s) being solved and self-assign.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 2.  Otherwise please let us know that you are working on the problem. Regular status updates (e.g. "still in progress", "no time anymore", "practically done", "pull request issued") are highly welcome.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 3.  Create a new branchmaster branch directly. It is reserved for releases. We recommend naming the branch to match the issue being addressed (feature/#777 or issue-777).
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 4.  Add failing tests for the change you want to make. Tests are crucial and should be taken from W3C (or other specification).
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 5.  Fix stuff. Always go from edge case to edge case.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 6.  All tests should pass now. Also your new implementation should not break existing tests.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 7.  Update the documentation to reflect any changes. (or document such changes in the original issue)
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 8.  Push to your fork or push your issue-specific branch to the main repository, then submit a pull request against devel.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Just to illustrate the git workflow for AngleSharp a little bit more we've added the following graphs.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Initially, AngleSharp starts at the master branch. This branch should contain the latest stable (or released) version.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Here we now created a new branch called devel. This is the development branch.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Now active work is supposed to be done. Therefore a new branch should be created. Let's create one:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git checkout -b feature/#777
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: There may be many of these feature branches. Most of them are also pushed to the server for discussion or synchronization.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git push -u origin feature/#777
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Now feature branches may be closed when they are done. Here we simply merge with the feature branch(es). For instance the following command takes the feature/#777 branch from the server and merges it with the devel branch.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
git checkout devel
git pull
git pull origin feature/#777
git push
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Finally, we may have all the features that are needed to release a new version of AngleSharp. Here we tag the release. For instance for the 1.0 release we use v1.0.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
git checkout master
git merge devel
git tag v1.0
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: (The last part is automatically performed by our CI system.)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Basic Files
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: The following files should not be edited directly in the current repository, but rather in the AngleSharp.GitBase repository. They are then synced via git pull from a different remote.

Paragraph:
.editorconfig

.gitattributes
.github/*
appveyor.yml
build.ps1

tools/anglesharp.cake

LICENSE

Paragraph: To sync manually:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
git remote add gitbase git@github.com:AngleSharp/AngleSharp.GitBase.git
git pull gitbase master
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Versioning
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: The rules of semver don't necessarily apply here, but we will try to stay quite close to them.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Prior to version 1.0.0 we use the following scheme:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 1.  MINOR versions for reaching a feature milestone potentially combined with dramatic API changes
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 2.  PATCH versions for refinements (e.g. performance improvements, bug fixes)
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: After releasing version 1.0.0 the scheme changes to become:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 1.  MAJOR versions at maintainers' discretion following significant changes to the codebase (e.g., API changes)
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 2.  MINOR versions for backwards-compatible enhancements (e.g., performance improvements)
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 3.  PATCH versions for backwards-compatible bug fixes (e.g., spec compliance bugs, support issues)
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Code style
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Regarding code style like indentation and whitespace, follow the conventions you see used in the source already. In general most of the C# coding guidelines from Microsoft are followed. This project prefers type inference with var to explicitly stating (redundant) information.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: It is also important to keep a certain async-flow and to always use ConfigureAwait(false) in conjunction with an await expression.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Branching Guidelines
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Master branch: master is the main development branch. Each stable public version is tagged using this branch.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Release branches: MAJOR.MINOR.x are release branches. They contains minor changes and bugfixes after release of first
major version. Only the latest release branch, and it won't contains new features from master branch and next releases.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Feature branches: They contains code for a features or a bugfix which needs several commits, and will be merged when
it is tested and ready.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Pull Request Guidelines
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Create and use a branch with a meaning full name, based on the develop branch.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Your pull request must contain only one feature or bugfix.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Run yarn dev to start the development environment.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Modify source files located in src/** and demo/**.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Keep only minimal changes for the feature or the fix.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - For a new feature, write a test by adding of modifying test files located in test/**.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Run tests with yarn test, and ensure all tests are passing.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Update README.md if required.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Build distribution files and demo app by running yarn build && yarn build-demo.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Build docs by running yarn build-docs (requires mkdocs installed).
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Create a Pull Request for your feature branch.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Git Commit Guidelines (from AngularJS)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
We have very precise rules over how our git commit messages can be formatted.  This leads to more
readable messages that are easy to follow when looking through the project history.  But also,
we use the git commit messages to generate the AngularJS change log.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Commit Message Format
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Each commit message consists of a header, a body and a footer.  The header has a special
format that includes a type, a scope and a subject:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
<type>(<scope>): <subject>
<BLANK LINE>
<body>
<BLANK LINE>
<footer>
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Any line of the commit message cannot be longer 100 characters! This allows the message to be easier
to read on github as well as in various git tools.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Type
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Must be one of the following:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - feat: A new feature
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - fix: A bug fix
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - docs: Documentation only changes
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- style: Changes that do not affect the meaning of the code (white-space, formatting, missing
semi-colons, etc)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - refactor: A code change that neither fixes a bug or adds a feature
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - perf: A code change that improves performance
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - test: Adding missing tests
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- chore: Changes to the build process or auxiliary tools and libraries such as documentation
generation
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Scope
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
The scope could be anything specifying place of the commit change. For example row,
task, header, options, css, readme, etc...
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Subject
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: The subject contains succinct description of the change:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - use the imperative, present tense: "change" not "changed" nor "changes"
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - don't capitalize first letter
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - no dot (.) at the end
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
###Body
Just as in the subject, use the imperative, present tense: "change" not "changed" nor "changes"
The body should include the motivation for the change and contrast this with previous behavior.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
###Footer
The footer should contain any information about Breaking Changes and is also the place to
reference GitHub issues that this commit Closes.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: A detailed explanation can be found in this document.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Release Guidelines
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Release are performed in interactive mode using release-it.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: yarn release -- [patch|minor|major] [--no-write]
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: The optional qualifier passed to task can be, as defined by semver:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - <version>: Will use the exact given version.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - patch: Will increment version to next patch (default).
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - minor: Will increment version to next minor.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - major: Will increment version to next major.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: .release.json is the release-it configuration.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: yarn dist automates the preparation of release, and can be run manually to check if everything works as expected.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Build angular-gantt.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Run tests.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Populate dist directory and demo/dist with distribution files.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Populate docs directory, containing docs, demo and files located on website.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Replace @@version by version number in docs directory and customize website title and meta tags.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Copy demo application into docs directory.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: yarn dist won't commit or push anything. A dry-run of the release process can also be performed using --no-write option.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Make sure both tasks are working properly before running yarn release without the --no-write option.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: yarn release will finally publish the release on github (release & tag) and npm (publish).
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: New Issues are for bug reports or feature requests only!!  Questions on how to use the grid should be posted to Stack Overflow or Gitter https://gitter.im/angular-ui/ui-grid.

Paragraph: Contributing to UI Grid
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Please take a moment to review this document in order to make the contribution
process easy and effective for everyone involved.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Following these guidelines helps to communicate that you respect the time of
the developers managing and developing this open source project. In return,
they should reciprocate that respect in addressing your issue or assessing
patches and features.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Developer guidelines
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: If you're a developer, please take a look at the Developer guidelines
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Using the issue tracker
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
The issue tracker is
the preferred channel for bug reports, features requests
and submitting pull requests, but please respect the following
restrictions:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- Please do not use the issue tracker for personal support requests (use
Stack Overflow ( Old Tag)
or our Gitter Chat).
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- Please do not derail or troll issues. Keep the discussion on topic and
respect the opinions of others.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Bug reports
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
A bug is a demonstrable problem that is caused by the code in the repository.
Good bug reports are extremely helpful - thank you!
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Guidelines for bug reports:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
1.  Use the GitHub issue search — check if the issue has already been
reported.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
2.  Check if the issue has been fixed — try to reproduce it using the
latest master or development branch in the repository.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
3.  Isolate the problem — ideally create a reduced test
case and a live example using plunker.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
A good bug report shouldn't leave others needing to chase you up for more
information. Please try to be as detailed as possible in your report. What is
your environment? What steps will reproduce the issue? What browser(s) and OS
experience the problem? What would you expect to be the outcome? All these
details will help people to fix any potential bugs.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Example:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Short and descriptive example bug report title
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
A summary of the issue and the browser/OS environment in which it occurs. If
suitable, include the steps required to reproduce the bug.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 1.  This is the first step
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 2.  This is the second step
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 3.  Further steps, etc.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: <url> - a link to the reduced test case
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Any other information you want to share that is relevant to the issue being
reported. This might include the lines of code that you have identified as
causing the bug, and potential solutions (and your opinions on their
merits).
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Feature requests
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Feature requests are welcome. But take a moment to find out whether your idea
fits with the scope and aims of the project. It's up to you to make a strong
case to convince the project's developers of the merits of this feature. Please
provide as much detail and context as possible. Please also see the note in the
Developer guidelines about implementing new features as plugins.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Pull requests
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
Good pull requests - patches, improvements, new features - are a fantastic
help. They should remain focused in scope and avoid containing unrelated
commits.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
Please ask first before embarking on any significant pull request (e.g.
implementing features, refactoring code, porting to a different language),
otherwise you risk spending a lot of time working on something that the
project's developers might not want to merge into the project.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
Please adhere to the coding conventions used throughout a project (indentation,
accurate comments, etc.) and any other requirements (such as test coverage).
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
Include Examples If possible, include links to a youtube video or GIF
demonstrating your fix or your feature. It will help us understand what you
are doing and why we want to merge it in.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
Adhering to the following this process is the best way to get your work
included in the project:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
1.  Fork the project, clone your fork,
and configure the remotes:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
# Clone your fork of the repo into the current directory
git clone https://github.com/<your-username>/ui-grid.git
# Navigate to the newly cloned directory
cd ui-grid
# Assign the original repo to a remote called "upstream"
git remote add upstream https://github.com/angular-ui/ui-grid.git
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 2.  If you cloned a while ago, get the latest changes from upstream:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
git checkout master
git pull upstream master
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
3.  Create a new topic branch (off the main project development branch) to
contain your feature, change, or fix:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git checkout -b <topic-branch-name>
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
4.  Commit your changes in logical chunks. Please adhere to these git commit
message guidelines
or your code is unlikely be merged into the main project. Use Git's
interactive rebase
feature to tidy up your commits before making them public.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 5.  Locally merge (or rebase) the upstream development branch into your topic branch:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git pull [--rebase] upstream master
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 6.  Squash your change into one commit
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git rebase -i master
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 7.  Push your topic branch up to your fork:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git push [--force] origin <topic-branch-name>
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
8.  Open a Pull Request
with a clear title and description.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
IMPORTANT: By submitting a patch, you agree to allow the project owners to
license your work under the terms of the MIT License.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Git Commit Guidelines
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
We have very precise rules over how our git commit messages can be formatted.  This leads to more
readable messages that are easy to follow when looking through the project history.  But also,
we use the git commit messages to generate the UIGrid change log.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Alternatively you can install commitizen OR
use the wizard. To use the wizard, run npm run commit in your terminal after staging your changes in git.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Commit Message Format
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
If you do not follow this style guide your commit message will fail to be created.
Each commit message consists of a header, a body and a footer.  The header has a special
format that includes a type, a scope and a subject:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
<type>(<scope>): <subject>
<BLANK LINE>
<body>
<BLANK LINE>
<footer>
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: The header is mandatory and the scope of the header is optional.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Any line of the commit message cannot be longer 100 characters! This allows the message to be easier
to read on GitHub as well as in various git tools.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Revert
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: If the commit reverts a previous commit, it should begin with revert: , followed by the header of the reverted commit. In the body it should say: This reverts commit <hash>., where the hash is the SHA of the commit being reverted.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Type
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Must be one of the following:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - feat: A new feature
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - fix: A bug fix
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - docs: Documentation only changes
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- style: Changes that do not affect the meaning of the code (white-space, formatting, missing
semi-colons, etc)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - refactor: A code change that neither fixes a bug nor adds a feature
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - perf: A code change that improves performance
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - test: Adding missing tests
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- chore: Changes to the build process or auxiliary tools and libraries such as documentation
generation
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Scope
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
The scope could be anything specifying place of the commit change. For example core,
infinite-scroll, pagination, cellnav, edit, importer, pinning, etc...
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Subject
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: The subject contains succinct description of the change:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - use the imperative, present tense: "change" not "changed" nor "changes"
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - don't capitalize first letter
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - no dot (.) at the end
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Body
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Just as in the subject, use the imperative, present tense: "change" not "changed" nor "changes".
The body should include the motivation for the change and contrast this with previous behavior.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Footer
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
The footer should contain any information about Breaking Changes and is also the place to
reference GitHub issues that this commit Closes.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Breaking Changes should start with the word BREAKING CHANGE: with a space or two newlines. The rest of the commit message is then used for this.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Report an Issue
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Help us make UI-Router better! If you think you might have found a bug, or some other weirdness, start by making sure
it hasn't already been reported. You can search through existing issues
to see if someone's reported one similar to yours.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
If not, then create a plunkr that demonstrates the problem (try to use as little code
as possible: the more minimalist, the faster we can debug it).
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Next, create a new issue that briefly explains the problem,
and provides a bit of background as to the circumstances that triggered it. Don't forget to include the link to
that plunkr you created!
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Note: If you're unsure how a feature is used, or are encountering some unexpected behavior that you aren't sure
is a bug, it's best to talk it out on
StackOverflow before reporting it. This
keeps development streamlined, and helps us focus on building great software.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Issues only! |
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
-------------|
Please keep in mind that the issue tracker is for issues. Please do not post an issue if you need help or support. Instead, see one of the above-mentioned forums or IRC. |
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Purple Labels
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: A purple label means that you need to take some further action.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Not Actionable - Need Info: Your issue is not specific enough, or there is no clear action that we can take. Please clarify and refine your issue.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Plunkr Please: Please create a plunkr
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - StackOverflow: We suspect your issue is really a help request, or could be answered by the community.  Please ask your question on StackOverflow.  If you determine that is an actual issue, please explain why.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: If your issue gets labeled with purple label, no further action will be taken until you respond to the label appropriately.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Contribute
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: (1) See the Developing section below, to get the development version of UI-Router up and running on your local machine.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: (2) Check out the roadmap to see where the project is headed, and if your feature idea fits with where we're headed.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: (3) If you're not sure, open an RFC to get some feedback on your idea.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: (4) Finally, commit some code and open a pull request. Code & commits should abide by the following rules:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Always have test coverage for new features (or regression tests for bug fixes), and never break existing tests
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Commits should represent one logical change each; if a feature goes through multiple iterations, squash your commits down to one
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Make sure to follow the Angular commit message format so your change will appear in the changelog of the next release.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Changes should always respect the coding style of the project
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Developing
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: UI-Router uses npm and Rollup.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Fetch the source code
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: The code for Angular UI-Router is split into two source repositories:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: - UI-Router Core (@uirouter/core on npm)
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: - UI-Router for Angular 1 (@ui-router/angularjs on npm)
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Clone both repositories into directories next to each other.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
mkdir uirouter
cd uirouter
git clone https://github.com/angular-ui/ui-router.git angularjs
git clone https://github.com/ui-router/core.git core
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Install dependencies
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Use npm to install the development dependencies for each repository.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
cd core
npm install
cd ../angularjs
npm install
cd ..
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Link the directories
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
This step is necessary if you need to modify any code in @uirouter/core.
Using npm, link @uirouter/core into @uirouter/angularjs
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
cd core
npm link
cd ../angularjs
npm link '@uirouter/core'
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: After executing these steps, @uirouter/angularjs will be depend on your local copy of @uirouter/core instead of the version listed in package.json.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Develop
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: These scripts may be run in the angularjs directory:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - npm run build: Compiles TypeScript source
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - npm run package: Compiles TypeScript source and creates the Rollup bundles.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - npm test: Runs the test suite (against Angular 1.2 through 1.5).
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - npm run watch: Continuously compiles the source and runs the test suite (when either source or tests change).
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Scripts of the same name (in the core directory) can be used.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - npm run build: Compiles @uirouter/core TypeScript source
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - npm test: Runs the @uirouter/core test suite
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - npm run watch: Continuously compiles the source and runs the @uirouter/core test suite (when core source or tests change).
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
If you've followed the linking instructions, it's useful to run both
npm run watch tasks (each task from @uirouter/core and @uirouter/angularjs).
This ensures that changes to either @uirouter/core and @uirouter/angularjs compile successfully and are run against their test suites.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Contributing to Angular DevKit
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
We would love for you to contribute to DevKit and help make it even better
than it is today! As a contributor, here are the guidelines we would like you
to follow:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Code of Conduct
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Question or Problem?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Issues and Bugs
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Feature Requests
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Submission Guidelines
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Coding Rules
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Commit Message Guidelines
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Signing the CLA
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Updating the Public API
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Code of Conduct
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Help us keep Angular open and inclusive. Please read and follow our Code of Conduct.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Got a Question or Problem?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Please, do not open issues for the general support questions as we want to keep GitHub issues for
bug reports and feature requests. You've got much better chances of getting your question answered
on StackOverflow where the questions
should be tagged with tag angular-cli or angular-devkit.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: StackOverflow is a much better place to ask questions since:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - there are thousands of people willing to help on StackOverflow
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - questions and answers stay available for public viewing so your question / answer might help someone else
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - StackOverflow's voting system assures that the best answers are prominently visible.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
To save your and our time we will be systematically closing all the issues that are requests for
general support and redirecting people to StackOverflow.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: If you would like to chat about the question in real-time, you can reach out via our gitter channel.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Found an Issue?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
If you find a bug in the source code or a mistake in the documentation, you can help us by
submitting an issue to our GitHub Repository. Even better, you can
submit a Pull Request with a fix.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Want a Feature?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
You can request a new feature by submitting an issue to our GitHub
Repository. If you would like to implement a new feature, please submit an issue with
a proposal for your work first, to be sure that we can use it.
Please consider what kind of change it is:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- For a Major Feature, first open an issue and outline your proposal so that it can be
discussed. This will also allow us to better coordinate our efforts, prevent duplication of work,
and help you to craft the change so that it is successfully accepted into the project.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Small Features can be crafted and directly submitted as a Pull Request.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Submission Guidelines
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Submitting an Issue
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Before you submit an issue, please search the issue tracker, maybe an issue for your problem already exists and the discussion might inform you of workarounds readily available.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: We want to fix all the issues as soon as possible, but before fixing a bug we need to reproduce and confirm it. Having a reproducible scenario gives us wealth of important information without going back & forth to you with additional questions like:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - version of Angular CLI used
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - .angular-cli.json or angular.json configuration
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - version of Angular DevKit used
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - 3rd-party libraries and their versions
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - and most importantly - a use-case that fails
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: A minimal reproduce scenario using allows us to quickly confirm a bug (or point out coding problem) as well as confirm that we are fixing the right problem.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: We will be insisting on a minimal reproduce scenario in order to save maintainers time and ultimately be able to fix more bugs. Interestingly, from our experience users often find coding problems themselves while preparing a minimal repository. We understand that sometimes it might be hard to extract essentials bits of code from a larger code-base but we really need to isolate the problem before we can fix it.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Unfortunately we are not able to investigate / fix bugs without a minimal reproduction, so if we don't hear back from you we are going to close an issue that don't have enough info to be reproduced.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: You can file new issues by selecting from our new issue templates and filling out the issue template.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Submitting a Pull Request (PR)
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Before you submit your Pull Request (PR) consider the following guidelines:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
- Search GitHub for an open or closed PR
that relates to your submission. You don't want to duplicate effort.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
- Please sign our Contributor License Agreement (CLA) before sending PRs.
We cannot accept code without this.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Make your changes in a new git branch:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: git checkout -b my-fix-branch master
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Create your patch, including appropriate test cases.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Follow our Coding Rules.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
- Run the full Angular CLI and DevKit test suite, as described in the developer documentation,
and ensure that all tests pass (coming soon).
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
- Commit your changes using a descriptive commit message that follows our
commit message conventions. Adherence to these conventions
is necessary because release notes are automatically generated from these messages.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: git commit -a
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Note: the optional commit -a command line option will automatically "add" and "rm" edited files.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Push your branch to GitHub:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: git push origin my-fix-branch
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - In GitHub, send a pull request to angular/angular-cli:master.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - If we suggest changes then:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Make the required updates.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Re-run the Angular DevKit test suites to ensure tests are still passing.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Once your PR is approved and you are done with any follow up changes:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Rebase to the current master to pre-emptively address any merge conflicts.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
git rebase master -i
git push -f
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
- Add the PR action: merge label and the correct
target label
(if PR author has the project collaborator status, or else the last reviewer
should do this).
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
- The current caretaker will merge the PR to the target branch(es) within 1-2
business days.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: That's it! ? Thank you for your contribution!
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: After your pull request is merged
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
After your pull request is merged, you can safely delete your branch and pull the changes
from the main (upstream) repository:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Delete the remote branch on GitHub either through the GitHub web UI or your local shell as follows:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git push origin --delete my-fix-branch
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Check out the master branch:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git checkout master -f
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Delete the local branch:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git branch -D my-fix-branch
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Update your master with the latest upstream version:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git pull --ff upstream master
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Coding Rules
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: To ensure consistency throughout the source code, keep these rules in mind as you are working:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - All features or bug fixes must be tested by one or more specs (unit-tests or e2e-tests).
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - All public API methods must be documented. (Details TBC).
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- We follow Google's JavaScript Style Guide, but wrap all code at
100 characters.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Commit Message Guidelines
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
We have very precise rules over how our git commit messages can be formatted.  This leads to more
readable messages that are easy to follow when looking through the project history.  But also,
we use the git commit messages to generate the Angular DevKit change log.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Commit Message Format
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Each commit message consists of a header, a body and a footer.  The header has a special
format that includes a type, a scope and a subject:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
<type>(<scope>): <subject>
<BLANK LINE>
<body>
<BLANK LINE>
<footer>
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: The header is mandatory and the scope of the header is optional.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Any line of the commit message cannot be longer 100 characters! This allows the message to be easier
to read on GitHub as well as in various git tools.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Revert
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: If the commit reverts a previous commit, it should begin with revert: , followed by the header of the reverted commit. In the body it should say: This reverts commit <hash>., where the hash is the SHA of the commit being reverted.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Type
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Must be one of the following:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - build: Changes that affect the build system or external dependencies. [2]
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - ci: Changes to our CI configuration files and scripts. [2]
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - docs: Documentation only changes.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - feat: A new feature. [1]
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - fix: A bug fix. [1]
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - refactor: A code change that neither fixes a bug nor adds a feature
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - release: A release commit. Must only include version changes. [2]
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - revert: A git commit revert. The description must include the original commit message. [2]
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - style: Changes that do not affect the meaning of the code (white-space, formatting, missing semi-colons, etc).
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - test: Adding missing tests or correcting existing tests.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
[1] This type MUST have a scope. See the next section for more information.
[2] This type MUST NOT have a scope. It only applies to general scripts and tooling.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Scope
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: The scope should be the name of the npm package affected as perceived by the person reading changelog generated from the commit messages.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: The following is the list of supported scopes:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - @angular/cli
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - @angular/pwa
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - @angular-devkit/architect
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - @angular-devkit/architect-cli
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - @angular-devkit/build-angular
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - @angular-devkit/build-ng-packagr
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - @angular-devkit/build-optimizer
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - @angular-devkit/build-webpack
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - @angular-devkit/core
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - @angular-devkit/schematics
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - @angular-devkit/schematics-cli
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - @ngtools/webpack
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - @schematics/angular
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - @schematics/schematics
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - @schematics/update
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Subject
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: The subject contains succinct description of the change:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - use the imperative, present tense: "change" not "changed" nor "changes"
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - don't capitalize first letter
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - be concise and direct
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - no dot (.) at the end
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Examples
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Examples of valid commit messages:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - fix(@angular/cli): prevent the flubber from grassing
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - refactor(@schematics/angular): move all JSON classes together
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Examples of invalid commit messages:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - fix(@angular/cli): add a new XYZ command
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: This is a feature, not a fix.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - ci(@angular/cli): fix publishing workflow
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: The ci type cannot have a scope.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Body
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Just as in the subject, use the imperative, present tense: "change" not "changed" nor "changes".
The body should include the motivation for the change and contrast this with previous behavior.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Footer
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
The footer should contain any information about Breaking Changes and is also the place to
reference GitHub issues that this commit Closes.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Breaking Changes should start with the word BREAKING CHANGE: with a space or two newlines. The rest of the commit message is then used for this.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: A detailed explanation can be found in this document.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Signing the CLA
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Please sign our Contributor License Agreement (CLA) before sending pull requests. For any code
changes to be accepted, the CLA must be signed. It's a quick process, we promise!
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - For individuals we have a simple click-through form.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- For corporations we'll need you to
print, sign and one of scan+email, fax or mail the form.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Updating the Public API
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Our Public API is protected with TS API Guardian. This is a tool that keeps track of public API surface of our packages.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: To test if your change effect the public API you need to run the API guardian on that particular package.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: For example in case @angular-devkit/core package was modified you need to run:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: yarn bazel test //etc/api:angular_devkit_core_api
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: You can also test all packages by running:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: yarn bazel test //etc/api ...
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: If you modified the public API, the test will fail. To update the golden files you need to run:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: yarn bazel run //etc/api:angular_devkit_core_api.accept
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Note: In some cases we use aliased symbols to create namespaces.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Example:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: import * as foo from './foo';
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: export { foo };
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
There are currently not supported by the API guardian.
To overcome this limitation we created _golden-api.ts in certain packages.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: When adding a new API, it might be the case that you need to add it to _golden-api.ts.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Contributing to AngularJS
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
We'd love for you to contribute to our source code and to make AngularJS even better than it is
today! Here are the guidelines we'd like you to follow:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Code of Conduct
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Questions and Problems
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Issues and Bugs
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Feature Requests
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Improving Documentation
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Issue Submission Guidelines
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Pull Request Submission Guidelines
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Signing the CLA
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Code of Conduct
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Help us keep AngularJS open and inclusive. Please read and follow our Code of Conduct.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Questions, Bugs, Features
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Got a Question or Problem?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Do not open issues for general support questions as we want to keep GitHub issues for bug reports
and feature requests. You've got much better chances of getting your question answered on dedicated
support platforms, the best being Stack Overflow.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Stack Overflow is a much better place to ask questions since:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - there are thousands of people willing to help on Stack Overflow
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- questions and answers stay available for public viewing so your question / answer might help
someone else
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Stack Overflow's voting system assures that the best answers are prominently visible.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
To save your and our time, we will systematically close all issues that are requests for general
support and redirect people to the section you are reading right now.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Other channels for support are:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - the Google Group discussion list
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - the AngularJS IRC
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - the AngularJS Gitter
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Found an Issue or Bug?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
If you find a bug in the source code, you can help us by submitting an issue to our
GitHub Repository. Even better, you can submit a Pull Request with a fix.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Please see the Submission Guidelines below.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Special Note for Localization Issues: AngularJS uses the Google Closure I18N library to
generate its own I18N files (the ngLocale module). This means that any changes to these files
would be lost the next time that we import the library.
Since the Closure library i18n data is itself auto-generated from the data of the
Common Locale Data Repository (CLDR) project, errors in the data should
be reported there. See also the Closure guide to i18n changes.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Missing a Feature?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: You can request a new feature by submitting an issue to our GitHub Repository.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: If you would like to implement a new feature then consider what kind of change it is:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- Major Changes that you wish to contribute to the project should be discussed first in an
GitHub issue that clearly outlines the changes and benefits of the feature.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- Small Changes can directly be crafted and submitted to the GitHub Repository
as a Pull Request. See the section about Pull Request Submission Guidelines, and
for detailed information the core development documentation.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Want a Doc Fix?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Should you have a suggestion for the documentation, you can open an issue and outline the problem
or improvement you have - however, creating the doc fix yourself is much better!
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
If you want to help improve the docs, it's a good idea to let others know what you're working on to
minimize duplication of effort. Create a new issue (or comment on a related existing one) to let
others know what you're working on.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
If you're making a small change (typo, phrasing) don't worry about filing an issue first. Use the
friendly blue "Improve this doc" button at the top right of the doc page to fork the repository
in-place and make a quick change on the fly. The commit message is preformatted to the right type
and scope, so you only have to add the description.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
For large fixes, please build and test the documentation before submitting the PR to be sure you
haven't accidentally introduced any layout or formatting issues. You should also make sure that your
commit message follows the Commit Message Guidelines.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Issue Submission Guidelines
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Before you submit your issue search the archive, maybe your question was already answered.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
If your issue appears to be a bug, and hasn't been reported, open a new issue. Help us to maximize
the effort we can spend fixing issues and adding new features, by not reporting duplicate issues.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
The "new issue" form contains a number of prompts that you should fill out to
make it easier to understand and categorize the issue.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
In general, providing the following information will increase the chances of your issue being dealt
with quickly:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Overview of the Issue - if an error is being thrown a non-minified stack trace helps
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Motivation for or Use Case - explain why this is a bug for you
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - AngularJS Version(s) - is it a regression?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Browsers and Operating System - is this a problem with all browsers or only specific ones?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- Reproduce the Error - provide a live example (using Plunker or
JSFiddle) or an unambiguous set of steps.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Related Issues - has a similar issue been reported before?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- Suggest a Fix - if you can't fix the bug yourself, perhaps you can point to what might be
causing the problem (line of code or commit)
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Here is a great example of a well defined issue: https://github.com/angular/angular.js/issues/5069.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: If you get help, help others. Good karma rulez!
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Pull Request Submission Guidelines
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Before you submit your pull request consider the following guidelines:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
- Search GitHub for an open or closed Pull Request
that relates to your submission. You don't want to duplicate effort.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Create the development environment
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Make your changes in a new git branch:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: git checkout -b my-fix-branch master
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Create your patch commit, including appropriate test cases.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Follow our Coding Rules.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - If the changes affect public APIs, change or add relevant documentation.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
- Run the AngularJS unit and E2E test suites, and ensure that all tests
pass. It is generally sufficient to run the tests only on Chrome, as our continuous integration test will
run the tests on additional browsers.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Run yarn grunt eslint to check that you have followed the automatically enforced coding rules
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
- Commit your changes using a descriptive commit message that follows our
commit message conventions. Adherence to the
commit message conventions is required, because release notes are
automatically generated from these messages.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: git commit -a
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Note: the optional commit -a command line option will automatically "add" and "rm" edited files.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Before creating the Pull Request, package and run all tests a last time:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: yarn grunt test
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Push your branch to GitHub:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: git push origin my-fix-branch
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- In GitHub, send a pull request to angular.js:master. This will trigger the check of the
Contributor License Agreement and the continuous integration tests.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
- If you find that the continuous integration tests have failed, look into the logs to find out
if your changes caused test failures, the commit message was malformed etc. If you find that the
tests failed or times out for unrelated reasons, you can ping a team member so that the build can be
restarted.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - If we suggest changes, then:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Make the required updates.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Re-run the AngularJS test suite to ensure tests are still passing.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Commit your changes to your branch (e.g. my-fix-branch).
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Push the changes to your GitHub repository (this will update your Pull Request).
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: You can also amend the initial commits and force push them to the branch.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
git rebase master -i
git push origin my-fix-branch -f
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
This is generally easier to follow, but separate commits are useful if the Pull Request contains
iterations that might be interesting to see side-by-side.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: That's it! Thank you for your contribution!
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: After your pull request is merged
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
After your pull request is merged, you can safely delete your branch and pull the changes
from the main (upstream) repository:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Delete the remote branch on GitHub either through the GitHub web UI or your local shell as follows:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git push origin --delete my-fix-branch
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Check out the master branch:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git checkout master -f
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Delete the local branch:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git branch -D my-fix-branch
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Update your master with the latest upstream version:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git pull --ff upstream master
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Signing the Contributor License Agreement (CLA)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Upon submmitting a Pull Request, a friendly bot will ask you to sign our CLA if you haven't done
so before. Unfortunately, this is necessary for documentation changes, too.
It's a quick process, we promise!
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - For individuals we have a simple click-through form.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- For corporations we'll need you to
print, sign and one of scan+email, fax or mail the form.
Label: SC – Submit the changes
