Paragraph: Contributing to Angular
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
We would love for you to contribute to Angular and help make it even better than it is today!
As a contributor, here are the guidelines we would like you to follow:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Code of Conduct
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Question or Problem?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Issues and Bugs
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Feature Requests
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Submission Guidelines
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Coding Rules
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Commit Message Guidelines
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Signing the CLA
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Code of Conduct
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Help us keep Angular open and inclusive.
Please read and follow our Code of Conduct.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Got a Question or Problem?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Do not open issues for general support questions as we want to keep GitHub issues for bug reports and feature requests.
Instead, we recommend using Stack Overflow to ask support-related questions. When creating a new question on Stack Overflow, make sure to add the angular tag.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Stack Overflow is a much better place to ask questions since:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - there are thousands of people willing to help on Stack Overflow
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - questions and answers stay available for public viewing so your question/answer might help someone else
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Stack Overflow's voting system assures that the best answers are prominently visible.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: To save your and our time, we will systematically close all issues that are requests for general support and redirect people to Stack Overflow.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: If you would like to chat about the question in real-time, you can reach out via our gitter channel.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Found a Bug?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
If you find a bug in the source code, you can help us by submitting an issue to our GitHub Repository.
Even better, you can submit a Pull Request with a fix.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Missing a Feature?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
You can request a new feature by submitting an issue to our GitHub Repository.
If you would like to implement a new feature, please consider the size of the change in order to determine the right steps to proceed:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- For a Major Feature, first open an issue and outline your proposal so that it can be discussed.
This process allows us to better coordinate our efforts, prevent duplication of work, and help you to craft the change so that it is successfully accepted into the project.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Note: Adding a new topic to the documentation, or significantly re-writing a topic, counts as a major feature.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Small Features can be crafted and directly submitted as a Pull Request.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Submission Guidelines
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Submitting an Issue
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Before you submit an issue, please search the issue tracker, maybe an issue for your problem already exists and the discussion might inform you of workarounds readily available.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
We want to fix all the issues as soon as possible, but before fixing a bug we need to reproduce and confirm it.
In order to reproduce bugs, we require that you provide a minimal reproduction.
Having a minimal reproducible scenario gives us a wealth of important information without going back and forth to you with additional questions.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: A minimal reproduction allows us to quickly confirm a bug (or point out a coding problem) as well as confirm that we are fixing the right problem.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
We require a minimal reproduction to save maintainers' time and ultimately be able to fix more bugs.
Often, developers find coding problems themselves while preparing a minimal reproduction.
We understand that sometimes it might be hard to extract essential bits of code from a larger codebase but we really need to isolate the problem before we can fix it.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Unfortunately, we are not able to investigate / fix bugs without a minimal reproduction, so if we don't hear back from you, we are going to close an issue that doesn't have enough info to be reproduced.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: You can file new issues by selecting from our new issue templates and filling out the issue template.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Submitting a Pull Request (PR)
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Before you submit your Pull Request (PR) consider the following guidelines:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
1.  Search GitHub for an open or closed PR that relates to your submission.
You don't want to duplicate existing efforts.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
2.  Be sure that an issue describes the problem you're fixing, or documents the design for the feature you'd like to add.
Discussing the design upfront helps to ensure that we're ready to accept your work.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
3.  Please sign our Contributor License Agreement (CLA) before sending PRs.
We cannot accept code without a signed CLA.
Make sure you author all contributed Git commits with email address associated with your CLA signature.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 4.  Fork the angular/angular repo.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 5.  Make your changes in a new git branch:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: git checkout -b my-fix-branch master
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 6.  Create your patch, including appropriate test cases.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 7.  Follow our Coding Rules.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 8.  Run the full Angular test suite, as described in the developer documentation, and ensure that all tests pass.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
9.  Commit your changes using a descriptive commit message that follows our commit message conventions.
Adherence to these conventions is necessary because release notes are automatically generated from these messages.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: git commit -a
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Note: the optional commit -a command line option will automatically "add" and "rm" edited files.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 10. Push your branch to GitHub:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: git push origin my-fix-branch
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 11. In GitHub, send a pull request to angular:master.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: If we ask for changes via code reviews then:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Make the required updates.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Re-run the Angular test suites to ensure tests are still passing.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Rebase your branch and force push to your GitHub repository (this will update your Pull Request):
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
git rebase master -i
git push -f
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: That's it! Thank you for your contribution!
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: After your pull request is merged
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: After your pull request is merged, you can safely delete your branch and pull the changes from the main (upstream) repository:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Delete the remote branch on GitHub either through the GitHub web UI or your local shell as follows:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git push origin --delete my-fix-branch
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Check out the master branch:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git checkout master -f
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Delete the local branch:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git branch -D my-fix-branch
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Update your master with the latest upstream version:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git pull --ff upstream master
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Coding Rules
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: To ensure consistency throughout the source code, keep these rules in mind as you are working:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - All features or bug fixes must be tested by one or more specs (unit-tests).
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - All public API methods must be documented.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - We follow Google's JavaScript Style Guide, but wrap all code at 100 characters.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: An automated formatter is available, see DEVELOPER.md.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Commit Message Format
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: This specification is inspired and supersedes the AngularJS commit message format.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
We have very precise rules over how our Git commit messages must be formatted.
This format leads to easier to read commit history.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Each commit message consists of a header, a body, and a footer.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
<header>
<BLANK LINE>
<body>
<BLANK LINE>
<footer>
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: The header is mandatory and must conform to the Commit Message Header format.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
The body is mandatory for all commits except for those of scope "docs".
When the body is required it must be at least 20 characters long.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: The footer is optional.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Any line of the commit message cannot be longer than 100 characters.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Commit Message Header
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
<type>(<scope>): <short summary>
?       ?             ?
?       ?             ??? Summary in present tense. Not capitalized. No period at the end.
?       ?
?       ??? Commit Scope: animations|bazel|benchpress|common|compiler|compiler-cli|core|
?                          elements|forms|http|language-service|localize|platform-browser|
?                          platform-browser-dynamic|platform-server|platform-webworker|
?                          platform-webworker-dynamic|router|service-worker|upgrade|zone.js|
?                          packaging|changelog|dev-infra|docs-infra|migrations|ngcc|ve
?
??? Commit Type: build|ci|docs|feat|fix|perf|refactor|style|test
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: The <type> and <summary> fields are mandatory, the (<scope>) field is optional.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Type
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Must be one of the following:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - build: Changes that affect the build system or external dependencies (example scopes: gulp, broccoli, npm)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - ci: Changes to our CI configuration files and scripts (example scopes: Circle, BrowserStack, SauceLabs)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - docs: Documentation only changes
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - feat: A new feature
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - fix: A bug fix
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - perf: A code change that improves performance
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - refactor: A code change that neither fixes a bug nor adds a feature
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - style: Changes that do not affect the meaning of the code (white-space, formatting, missing semi-colons, etc)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - test: Adding missing tests or correcting existing tests
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Scope
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: The scope should be the name of the npm package affected (as perceived by the person reading the changelog generated from commit messages).
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: The following is the list of supported scopes:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - animations
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - bazel
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - benchpress
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - common
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - compiler
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - compiler-cli
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - core
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - elements
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - forms
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - http
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - language-service
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - localize
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - platform-browser
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - platform-browser-dynamic
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - platform-server
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - platform-webworker
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - platform-webworker-dynamic
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - router
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - service-worker
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - upgrade
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - zone.js
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: There are currently a few exceptions to the "use package name" rule:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - packaging: used for changes that change the npm package layout in all of our packages, e.g. public path changes, package.json changes done to all packages, d.ts file/format changes, changes to bundles, etc.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - changelog: used for updating the release notes in CHANGELOG.md
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - dev-infra: used for dev-infra related changes within the directories /scripts, /tools and /dev-infra
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - docs-infra: used for docs-app (angular.io) related changes within the /aio directory of the repo
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - migrations: used for changes to the ng update migrations.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - ngcc: used for changes to the Angular Compatibility Compiler
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - ve: used for changes specific to ViewEngine (legacy compiler/renderer).
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - none/empty string: useful for style, test and refactor changes that are done across all packages (e.g. style: add missing semicolons) and for docs changes that are not related to a specific package (e.g. docs: fix typo in tutorial).
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Summary
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Use the summary field to provide a succinct description of the change:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - use the imperative, present tense: "change" not "changed" nor "changes"
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - don't capitalize the first letter
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - no dot (.) at the end
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Commit Message Body
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Just as in the summary, use the imperative, present tense: "fix" not "fixed" nor "fixes".
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Explain the motivation for the change in the commit message body. This commit message should explain why you are making the change.
You can include a comparison of the previous behavior with the new behavior in order to illustrate the impact of the change.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Commit Message Footer
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: The footer can contain information about breaking changes and is also the place to reference GitHub issues, Jira tickets, and other PRs that this commit closes or is related to.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
BREAKING CHANGE: <breaking change summary>
<BLANK LINE>
<breaking change description + migration instructions>
<BLANK LINE>
<BLANK LINE>
Fixes #<issue number>
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Breaking Change section should start with the phrase "BREAKING CHANGE: " followed by a summary of the breaking change, a blank line, and a detailed description of the breaking change that also includes migration instructions.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Revert commits
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: If the commit reverts a previous commit, it should begin with revert: , followed by the header of the reverted commit.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: The content of the commit message body should contain:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - information about the SHA of the commit being reverted in the following format: This reverts commit <SHA>,
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - a clear description of the reason for reverting the commit message.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Signing the CLA
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Please sign our Contributor License Agreement (CLA) before sending pull requests. For any code
changes to be accepted, the CLA must be signed. It's a quick process, we promise!

Paragraph: - For individuals, we have a simple click-through form.

Paragraph:
- For corporations, we'll need you to
print, sign and one of scan+email, fax or mail the form.

Paragraph: If you have more than one GitHub accounts, or multiple email addresses associated with a single GitHub account, you must sign the CLA using the primary email address of the GitHub account used to author Git commits and send pull requests.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Code of Conduct
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Help us keep the Angular and Firebase communities open and inclusive. Please read and follow the Angular Code of Conduct.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Got a Question or Problem?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
If you have questions about how to use AngularFire, please direct them to the Angular Google Group
discussion list or StackOverflow (include the firebase and angular tags!).
Please note that the Angular team's capacity to answer usage questions is limited.
Members of the Firebase team can be reached on Slack and via the Firebase Google Group.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Found an Issue?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
If you find a bug in the source code, you can help us by
submitting an issue to our GitHub Repository. Even better, you can
submit a Pull Request with a fix.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Want a Feature?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
You can request a new feature by submitting an issue to our GitHub
Repository. If you would like to implement a new feature, please submit an issue with
a proposal for your work first, to be sure that we can use it.
Please consider what kind of change it is:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- For a Major Feature, first open an issue and outline your proposal so that it can be
discussed. This will also allow us to better coordinate our efforts, prevent duplication of work,
and help you to craft the change so that it is successfully accepted into the project.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Small Features can be crafted and directly submitted as a Pull Request.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Initial Setup
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 1)  Create a fork of AngularFire (See Forking a Project)
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 2)  Clone your fork, CD into the directory, and install dependencies
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
$ git clone <your fork SSH/HTTPS from GitHub>
$ cd angularfire
$ yarn
$ yarn build
$ yarn test:all
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 3)  Make your changes in a new git branch:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: git checkout -b my-fix-branch master
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Submission Guidelines
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Submitting an Issue
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Help us to maximize the effort we can spend improving the product by not reporting duplicate issues.
Search the archives before you submit.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Providing the following information will increase the chances of your issue being dealt with quickly:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Overview of the Issue - if an error is being thrown a non-minified stack trace helps
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Angular Version - what version of Angular, Firebase, and AngularFire are you using?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Motivation for or Use Case - explain what are you trying to do and why the current behavior is a bug for you
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Browsers and Operating System - is this a problem with all browsers?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- Reproduce the Error - provide a live example (using StackBlitz (https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-fire-start))
or a unambiguous set of steps
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Related Issues - has a similar issue been reported before?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- Suggest a Fix - if you can't fix the bug yourself, perhaps you can point to what might be
causing the problem (line of code or commit)
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: You can file new issues by providing the above information here.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Submitting a Pull Request (PR)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Before you submit:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Ensure proposed changes or problem have already been clearly defined and
discussed in the issue tracker. We don't want you to burn time on code
that isn't a good fit for the project.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Search GitHub for an open or closed PR
that relates to your submission. You don't want to duplicate effort.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Please sign our Contributor License Agreement (CLA) before sending PRs.
We cannot accept code without this.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Review our Coding Rules (external link)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Review our Commit Message Guidelines (external link)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: How to submit:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Create your patch, including appropriate test cases.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Follow the Angular Coding Rules.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Run the full test suite (yarn test) and ensure that all tests pass.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Commit your changes using a descriptive commit message that follows the
Angular commit message conventions. Adherence to these conventions
is necessary because release notes are automatically generated from these messages.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git commit -a
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Note: the optional commit -a command line option will automatically "add" and "rm" edited files.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Push your branch to GitHub:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git push origin my-fix-branch
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - In GitHub, send a pull request to angular:master.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - If we suggest changes then:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Make the required updates.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Re-run the test suites to ensure tests are still passing.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Rebase your branch and force push to your GitHub repository (this will update your Pull Request):
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
git rebase master -i
git push -f
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: That's it! Thank you for your contribution!
Label: SC – Submit the changes

changes to be accepted, the CLA must be signed. It's a quick process, we promise!

Paragraph: Code of Conduct
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Help us keep Angular open and inclusive. Please read and follow our Code of Conduct.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Got a Question or Problem?
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Please do not open issues for general support questions as we want to keep GitHub issues for bug reports and feature requests. You've got much better chances of getting your question answered on StackOverflow where the questions should be tagged with tag angular-material2.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: StackOverflow is a much better place to ask questions since:
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: - there are thousands of people willing to help on StackOverflow
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: - questions and answers stay available for public viewing so your question / answer might help someone else
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: - StackOverflow's voting system assures that the best answers are prominently visible.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: To save your and our time, we will be systematically closing all the issues that are requests for general support and redirecting people to StackOverflow.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: If you would like to chat about the question in real-time, you can reach out via our gitter channel.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Found an Issue?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
If you find a bug in the source code or a mistake in the documentation, you can help us by
submitting an issue to our GitHub Repository. Including an issue
reproduction (via CodePen, JsBin, Plunkr, etc.) is the absolute best way to help the team quickly
diagnose the problem. Screenshots are also helpful.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: You can help the team even more and submit a Pull Request with a fix.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Want a Feature?

You can request a new feature by submitting an issue to our GitHub
Repository. If you would like to implement a new feature, please submit an issue with
a proposal for your work first, to be sure that we can use it.
Please consider what kind of change it is:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
- For a Major Feature, first open an issue and outline your proposal so that it can be
discussed. This will also allow us to better coordinate our efforts, prevent duplication of work,
and help you to craft the change so that it is successfully accepted into the project.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Small Features can be crafted and directly submitted as a Pull Request.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Submitting an Issue
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Before you submit an issue, search the archive, maybe your question was already answered.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
If your issue appears to be a bug, and hasn't been reported, open a new issue.
Help us to maximize the effort we can spend fixing issues and adding new
features by not reporting duplicate issues.  Providing the following information will increase the
chances of your issue being dealt with quickly:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Overview of the Issue - if an error is being thrown a non-minified stack trace helps
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- Angular and Material Versions - which versions of Angular and Material are affected
(e.g. 2.0.0-alpha.53)
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- Motivation for or Use Case - explain what are you trying to do and why the current behavior
is a bug for you
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Browsers and Operating System - is this a problem with all browsers?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- Reproduce the Error - provide a live example (using CodePen, JsBin,
Plunker, etc.) or a unambiguous set of steps
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- Screenshots - Due to the visual nature of Angular Material, screenshots can help the team
triage issues far more quickly than a text description.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Related Issues - has a similar issue been reported before?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- Suggest a Fix - if you can't fix the bug yourself, perhaps you can point to what might be
causing the problem (line of code or commit)
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: You can file new issues by providing the above information here.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Submitting a Pull Request (PR)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Before you submit your Pull Request (PR) consider the following guidelines:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Search GitHub for an open or closed PR
that relates to your submission. You don't want to duplicate effort.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Please sign our Contributor License Agreement (CLA) before sending PRs.
We cannot accept code without this.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Make your changes in a new git branch:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git checkout -b my-fix-branch master
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Create your patch, including appropriate test cases.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Follow our Coding Rules.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Test your changes with our supported browsers and screen readers.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Run the full Angular Material test suite, as described in the developer documentation,
and ensure that all tests pass.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Commit your changes using a descriptive commit message that follows our
commit message conventions. Adherence to these conventions
is necessary because release notes are automatically generated from these messages.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git commit -a
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Note: the optional commit -a command line option will automatically "add" and "rm" edited files.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Push your branch to GitHub:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git push my-fork my-fix-branch
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - In GitHub, send a pull request to components:master.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - If we suggest changes then:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Make the required updates.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Re-run the Angular Material test suites to ensure tests are still passing.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Rebase your branch and force push to your GitHub repository (this will update your Pull
Request):
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
git rebase master -i
git push -f
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: That's it! Thank you for your contribution!
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: After your pull request is merged
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
After your pull request is merged, you can safely delete your branch and pull the changes
from the main (upstream) repository:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Delete the remote branch on GitHub either through the GitHub web UI or your local shell as
follows:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git push my-fork --delete my-fix-branch
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Check out the master branch:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git checkout master -f
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Delete the local branch:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git branch -D my-fix-branch
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Update your master with the latest upstream version:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git pull --ff upstream master
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Coding Rules
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: To ensure consistency throughout the source code, keep these rules in mind as you are working:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - All features or bug fixes must be tested by one or more specs (unit-tests).
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - All public API methods must be documented. (Details TBD).
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- We follow Google's JavaScript Style Guide, but wrap all code at
100 characters.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Commit Message Guidelines
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
We have very precise rules over how our git commit messages can be formatted.  This leads to more
readable messages that are easy to follow when looking through the project history.  But also,
we use the git commit messages to generate the Angular Material change log.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Commit Message Format
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Each commit message consists of a header, a body and a footer.  The header has a special
format that includes a type, a package, a scope and a subject:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
<type>(<package>/<scope>): <subject>
<BLANK LINE>
<body>
<BLANK LINE>
<footer>
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
The header is mandatory. For changes which are shown in the changelog (fix, feat,
perf and revert), the package and scope fields are mandatory.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
The package and scope fields can be omitted if the change does not affect a specific
package and is not displayed in the changelog (e.g. build changes or refactorings).
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Any line of the commit message cannot be longer 100 characters! This allows the message to be easier
to read on GitHub as well as in various git tools.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Example:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: fix(material/button): unable to disable button through binding
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Fixes a bug in the Angular Material `button` component where buttons
cannot be disabled through an binding. This is because the `disabled`
input did not set the `.mat-button-disabled` class on the host element.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Fixes #1234
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Revert
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
If the commit reverts a previous commit, it should begin with revert: , followed by the header of
the reverted commit. In the body it should say: This reverts commit <hash>., where the hash is
the SHA of the commit being reverted.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Type
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Must be one of the following:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - feat: A new feature
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - fix: A bug fix
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - docs: Documentation only changes
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- style: Changes that do not affect the meaning of the code (white-space, formatting, missing
semi-colons, etc)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - refactor: A code change that neither fixes a bug nor adds a feature
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - perf: A code change that improves performance
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - test: Adding missing tests or correcting existing tests
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- build: Changes that affect the build system, CI configuration or external dependencies
(example scopes: gulp, broccoli, npm)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - chore: Other changes that don't modify src or test files
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Package
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
The commit message should specify which package is affected by the change. For example:
material, cdk-experimental, etc.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Scope
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
The scope could be anything specifying place of the commit change. For example
datepicker, dialog, etc.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Subject
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: The subject contains succinct description of the change:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - use the imperative, present tense: "change" not "changed" nor "changes"
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - don't capitalize first letter
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - no dot (.) at the end
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Body
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Just as in the subject, use the imperative, present tense: "change" not "changed" nor "changes".
The body should include the motivation for the change and contrast this with previous behavior.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Footer
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
The footer should contain any information about Breaking Changes or Deprecations and
is also the place to reference GitHub issues that this commit Closes.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Breaking Changes should start with the word BREAKING CHANGE: with a space or two newlines.
The rest of the commit message is then used for this.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Deprecations should start with the word DEPRECATED:. The rest of the commit message will be
used as content for the note.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: A detailed explanation can be found in this document.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Label: SC – Submit the changes

Please sign our Contributor License Agreement (CLA) before sending pull requests. For any code
changes to be accepted, the CLA must be signed. It's a quick process, we promise!
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Contributing to Angular Flex Layout
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
We would love for you to contribute to Angular Flex Layout and help make it ever better!
As a contributor, here are the guidelines we would like you to follow:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Code of Conduct
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Question or Problem?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Issues and Bugs
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Feature Requests
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Submission Guidelines
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Coding Rules

Paragraph: Code of Conduct
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Help us keep Angular open and inclusive. Please read and follow our Code of Conduct.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Got a Question or Problem?
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Please do not open issues for general support questions as we want to keep GitHub issues for bug reports and feature requests. You've got much better chances of getting your question answered on StackOverflow where the questions should be tagged with tag angular-flex-layout.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: StackOverflow is a much better place to ask questions since:
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: - there are thousands of people willing to help on StackOverflow
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: - questions and answers stay available for public viewing so your question / answer might help someone else
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: - StackOverflow's voting system assures that the best answers are prominently visible.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: To save your and our time, we will be systematically closing all the issues that are requests for general support and redirecting people to StackOverflow.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: If you would like to chat about the question in real-time, you can reach out via our gitter channel.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Found an Issue?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
If you find a bug in the source code or a mistake in the documentation, you can help us by
submitting an issue to our GitHub Repository. Including an issue
reproduction with StackBlitz IDE is the absolute best way to help the team quickly
diagnose the problem. Screenshots are also helpful.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: You can help the team even more and submit a Pull Request with a fix.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Want a Feature?
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
You can request a new feature by submitting an issue to our GitHub
Repository. If you would like to implement a new feature, please submit an issue with
a proposal for your work first, to be sure that we can use it.
Please consider what kind of change it is:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
- For a Major Feature, first open an issue and outline your proposal so that it can be
discussed. This will also allow us to better coordinate our efforts, prevent duplication of work,
and help you to craft the change so that it is successfully accepted into the project.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Small Features can be crafted and directly submitted as a Pull Request.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Submitting an Issue
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Before you submit an issue, search the archive, maybe your question was already answered.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
If your issue appears to be a bug, and hasn't been reported, open a new issue.
Help us to maximize the effort we can spend fixing issues and adding new
features by not reporting duplicate issues.  Providing the following information will increase the
chances of your issue being dealt with quickly:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Overview of the Issue - if an error is being thrown a non-minified stack trace helps
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- Angular and Flex Layout Versions - which versions of Angular and Flex Layout are affected
(e.g. 2.0.0-alpha.53)
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- Motivation for or Use Case - explain what are you trying to do and why the current behavior
is a bug for you
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Browsers and Operating System - is this a problem with all browsers?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Reproduce the Error - provide a live example (using StackBlitz IDE) or a unambiguous set of steps
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- Screenshots - Due to the visual nature of Angular Flex Layout, screenshots can help the team
triage issues far more quickly than a text description.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Related Issues - has a similar issue been reported before?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- Suggest a Fix - if you can't fix the bug yourself, perhaps you can point to what might be
causing the problem (line of code or commit)
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: You can file new issues by providing the above information here.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Submitting a Pull Request (PR)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Before you submit your Pull Request (PR) consider the following guidelines:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Search GitHub for an open or closed PR
that relates to your submission. You don't want to duplicate effort.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Please sign our Contributor License Agreement (CLA) before sending PRs.
We cannot accept code without this.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Make your changes in a new git branch:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git checkout -b my-fix-branch master
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Create your patch, including appropriate test cases.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Follow our Coding Rules.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Test your changes with our supported browsers and screen readers.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Run the full Angular Flex Layout test suite, and ensure that all tests pass.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Commit your changes using a descriptive commit message that follows our
commit message conventions. Adherence to these conventions
is necessary because release notes are automatically generated from these messages.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git commit -a
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Note: the optional commit -a command line option will automatically "add" and "rm" edited files.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Push your branch to GitHub:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git push my-fork my-fix-branch
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - In GitHub, send a pull request to flex-layout:master.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - If we suggest changes then:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Make the required updates.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Re-run the Angular Flex Layout test suites to ensure tests are still passing.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Rebase your branch and force push to your GitHub repository (this will update your Pull
Request):
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
git rebase master -i
git push -f
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: That's it! Thank you for your contribution!
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: After your pull request is merged
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
After your pull request is merged, you can safely delete your branch and pull the changes
from the main (upstream) repository:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Delete the remote branch on GitHub either through the GitHub web UI or your local shell as
follows:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git push my-fork --delete my-fix-branch
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Check out the master branch:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git checkout master -f
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Delete the local branch:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git branch -D my-fix-branch
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Update your master with the latest upstream version:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git pull --ff upstream master
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Coding Rules
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: To ensure consistency throughout the source code, keep these rules in mind as you are working:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - All features or bug fixes must be tested by one or more specs (unit-tests).
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - All public API methods must be documented. (Details TBD).
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- We follow Google's JavaScript Style Guide, but wrap all code at
100 characters.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Commit Message Guidelines
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
We have very precise rules over how our git commit messages can be formatted.  This leads to more
readable messages that are easy to follow when looking through the project history.  But also,
we use the git commit messages to generate the Angular Flex Layout change log.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Commit Message Format
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Each commit message consists of a header, a body and a footer.  The header has a special
format that includes a type, a scope and a subject:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
<type>(<scope>): <subject>
<BLANK LINE>
<body>
<BLANK LINE>
<footer>
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: The header is mandatory and the scope of the header is optional.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Any line of the commit message cannot be longer 100 characters! This allows the message to be easier
to read on GitHub as well as in various git tools.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Revert
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
If the commit reverts a previous commit, it should begin with revert: , followed by the header of
the reverted commit. In the body it should say: This reverts commit <hash>., where the hash is
the SHA of the commit being reverted.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Type
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Must be one of the following:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - feat: A new feature
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - fix: A bug fix
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - docs: Documentation only changes
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- style: Changes that do not affect the meaning of the code (white-space, formatting, missing
semi-colons, etc)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - refactor: A code change that neither fixes a bug nor adds a feature
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - perf: A code change that improves performance
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - test: Adding missing tests or correcting existing tests
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- build: Changes that affect the build system, CI configuration or external dependencies
(example scopes: gulp, broccoli, npm)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - chore: Other changes that don't modify src or test files
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Scope
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
The scope could be anything specifying place of the commit change. For example
datepicker, dialog, etc.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Subject
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: The subject contains succinct description of the change:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - use the imperative, present tense: "change" not "changed" nor "changes"
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - don't capitalize first letter
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - no dot (.) at the end
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Body
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Just as in the subject, use the imperative, present tense: "change" not "changed" nor "changes".
The body should include the motivation for the change and contrast this with previous behavior.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Footer
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
The footer should contain any information about Breaking Changes and is also the place to
reference GitHub issues that this commit Closes.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Breaking Changes should start with the word BREAKING CHANGE: with a space or two newlines.
The rest of the commit message is then used for this.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: A detailed explanation can be found in this document.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Please sign our Contributor License Agreement (CLA) before sending pull requests. For any code
changes to be accepted, the CLA must be signed. It's a quick process, we promise!
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - For individuals we have a simple click-through form.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- For corporations we'll need you to
print, sign and one of scan+email, fax or mail the form.

Paragraph: Code of Conduct
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph:
Please help us keep AngularJS Material open and inclusive by reading and following our
Code of Conduct.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph:
Please note that by using GitHub, you have also agreed to follow the
GitHub Terms of Service which
include guidelines on conduct.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph:
We are care deeply about our inclusive community and diverse group of members. As part of this,
we do take time away from development to enforce this policy through interventions in heated
discussions, one on one discussions to explain the policy to violators, and bans for repeat
violators.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Have a Question, Problem, or Idea?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
If you have questions or ideas regarding AngularJS Material, please direct these to the
AngularJS Material Forum.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Otherwise, do you:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Want to report a Bug?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Want to request an Enhancement?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 1. Want to report a Bug or Issue?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
If you find a bug in the source code or a mistake in the documentation, we recommend that you first
review the latest master version of the Online Documentation
and use one of the Demos to create a CodePen that reproduces the issue.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
If the issue can be reproduced in the latest master version, you can help us by submitting an issue
to our GitHub Repository. After the issue is triaged
(labels are applied to it), we invite you to submit a Pull Request with a proposed fix.
Your custom changes can be crafted in a repository fork and submitted
to the GitHub Repository as a Pull Request.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Important: Please review the Submission Guidelines below, before contributing to the
project.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 2. Want to request an Enhancement?
Label: No categories identified.
CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
- Major Changes that you wish to contribute to the project should be discussed first on our
AngularJS Material Forum, so that we can better
coordinate our efforts, prevent duplication of work, and help you to craft the change so that it is
successfully accepted into the project.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
- Small Changes can be crafted and submitted to the
GitHub Repository as a Pull Request.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Issue Guidelines
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Please note, this project is mature and stable with thousands of projects depending upon it.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
We welcome your enhancement requests, doc improvements, and issue reports.
However, we are not accepting major feature requests at this time.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
If you're thinking of contributing code or documentation to the
project, please review Submitting Pull Requests before beginning any work.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Submitting an Issue
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Before you submit an issue,
search the issues archive;
maybe the issue has already been submitted or considered. If the issue appears to be a bug,
and hasn't been reported, open a new issue.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Please do not report duplicate issues; help us maximize the effort we can spend fixing
issues and adding enhancements.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Providing the following information will increase the chances of your issue being dealt with
quickly:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- Issue Title - provide a concise issue title prefixed with a snake-case name of the
associated service or component (if any): <component>: <issue title>.
Adding the md- prefix should be avoided.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: e.g.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - menu-bar: does not support dark mode themes #11238
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - tooltip: memory leak on destroy #11133
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- Complete the full Issue Template - GitHub now supports issue templates and AngularJS Material
provides one to make submitting an issue with all of the required information more straightforward.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- Suggest a Fix - if you can't fix the bug yourself, perhaps you can point to what might be
causing the problem (line of code or commit).
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Be consistent with the code around you!
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Commit Messages
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Please write meaningful commit messages - they are used to generate the changelog, so the commit message should tell a user everything they need to know about a commit. Protractor follows AngularJS's commit message format.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: In summary, this style is
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
<type>(<scope>): <subject>
<BLANK LINE>
<body>
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Where <type> is one of [feat, fix, docs, refactor, test, chore, deps] and
<scope> is a quick descriptor of the location of the change, such as cli, clientSideScripts, element.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Testing your changes
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Test your changes on your machine by running npm start to start up the test application,
then npm test to run the test suite. This assumes you have a Selenium Server running
at localhost:4444.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
When you submit a PR, tests will also be run on the Continuous Integration environment
through Travis. If your tests fail on Travis, take a look at the logs - if the failures
are known flakes in Internet Explorer or Safari you can ignore them, but otherwise
Travis should pass.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

We would love for you to contribute to Angular 2 and help make it even better than it is
today! As a contributor, here are the guidelines we would like you to follow:

Paragraph: Code of Conduct
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Help us keep Angular open and inclusive. Please read and follow our Code of Conduct.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Got a Question or Problem?
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph:
If you have questions about how to use Angular 2 Universal, please direct them to Gitter.
There is also a Slack ground that we would be hapy to invite you to. Just ping @jeffwhelpley
or @gdi2290 on Twitter or Gitter.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Found an Issue?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
If you find a bug in the source code or a mistake in the documentation, you can help us by
submitting an issue to our GitHub Repository. Even better, you can
submit a Pull Request with a fix.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Want a Feature?
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
You can request a new feature by submitting an issue to our GitHub
Repository. If you would like to implement a new feature, please submit an issue with
a proposal for your work first, to be sure that we can use it. Angular 2 is in developer preview
and we are not ready to accept major contributions ahead of the full release.
Please consider what kind of change it is:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
- For a Major Feature, first open an issue and outline your proposal so that it can be
discussed. This will also allow us to better coordinate our efforts, prevent duplication of work,
and help you to craft the change so that it is successfully accepted into the project.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Small Features can be crafted and directly submitted as a Pull Request.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Submission Guidelines
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Submitting an Issue
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Before you submit an issue, search the archive, maybe your question was already answered.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
If your issue appears to be a bug, and hasn't been reported, open a new issue.
Help us to maximize the effort we can spend fixing issues and adding new
features, by not reporting duplicate issues.  Providing the following information will increase the
chances of your issue being dealt with quickly:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Overview of the Issue - if an error is being thrown a non-minified stack trace helps
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Angular Universal Version - what version of Angular is affected (e.g. 2.0.0-beta.6)
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Motivation for or Use Case - explain what are you trying to do and why the current behavior is a bug for you
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Browsers and Operating System - is this a problem with all browsers?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- Reproduce the Error - provide a live example (using Plunker,
JSFiddle or Runnable) or a unambiguous set of steps
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Related Issues - has a similar issue been reported before?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- Suggest a Fix - if you can't fix the bug yourself, perhaps you can point to what might be
causing the problem (line of code or commit)
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: You can file new issues by providing the above information here.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Submitting a Pull Request (PR)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Before you submit your Pull Request (PR) consider the following guidelines:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Search GitHub for an open or closed PR
that relates to your submission. You don't want to duplicate effort.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Please sign our Contributor License Agreement (CLA) before sending PRs.
We cannot accept code without this.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Make your changes in a new git branch:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git checkout -b my-fix-branch master
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Create your patch, including appropriate test cases.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Follow our Coding Rules.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Run the full Angular test suite, as described in the developer documentation,
and ensure that all tests pass.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Commit your changes using a descriptive commit message that follows our
commit message conventions. Adherence to these conventions
is necessary because release notes are automatically generated from these messages.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git commit -a
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Note: the optional commit -a command line option will automatically "add" and "rm" edited files.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Push your branch to GitHub:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git push origin my-fix-branch
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - In GitHub, send a pull request to universal:master.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - If we suggest changes then:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Make the required updates.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Re-run the Angular 2 test suites for JS and Dart to ensure tests are still passing.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Rebase your branch and force push to your GitHub repository (this will update your Pull Request):
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
git rebase master -i
git push -f
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: That's it! Thank you for your contribution!
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: After your pull request is merged
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
After your pull request is merged, you can safely delete your branch and pull the changes
from the main (upstream) repository:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Delete the remote branch on GitHub either through the GitHub web UI or your local shell as follows:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git push origin --delete my-fix-branch
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Check out the master branch:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git checkout master -f
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Delete the local branch:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git branch -D my-fix-branch
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Update your master with the latest upstream version:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git pull --ff upstream master
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Coding Rules
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: To ensure consistency throughout the source code, keep these rules in mind as you are working:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - All features or bug fixes must be tested by one or more specs (unit-tests).
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - All public API methods must be documented. (Details TBC).
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- We follow Google's JavaScript Style Guide, but wrap all code at
100 characters. An automated formatter is available, see
DEVELOPER.md.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Commit Message Guidelines
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
We have very precise rules over how our git commit messages can be formatted.  This leads to more
readable messages that are easy to follow when looking through the project history.  But also,
we use the git commit messages to generate the Angular change log.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Commit Message Format
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Each commit message consists of a header, a body and a footer.  The header has a special
format that includes a type, a scope and a subject:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
<type>(<scope>): <subject>
<BLANK LINE>
<body>
<BLANK LINE>
<footer>
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: The header is mandatory and the scope of the header is optional.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Any line of the commit message cannot be longer 100 characters! This allows the message to be easier
to read on GitHub as well as in various git tools.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Revert
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: If the commit reverts a previous commit, it should begin with revert: , followed by the header of the reverted commit. In the body it should say: This reverts commit <hash>., where the hash is the SHA of the commit being reverted.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Type
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Must be one of the following:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - feat: A new feature
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - fix: A bug fix
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - docs: Documentation only changes
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- style: Changes that do not affect the meaning of the code (white-space, formatting, missing
semi-colons, etc)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - refactor: A code change that neither fixes a bug nor adds a feature
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - perf: A code change that improves performance
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - test: Adding missing tests or correcting existing tests
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - build Changes that affect the build system, CI configuration or external dependencies (example scopes: gulp, broccoli, npm)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - chore: Other changes that don't modify src or test files
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Scope
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
The scope could be anything specifying place of the commit change. For example
express-engine, common, etc.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Subject
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: The subject contains succinct description of the change:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - use the imperative, present tense: "change" not "changed" nor "changes"
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - don't capitalize first letter
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - no dot (.) at the end
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Body
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Just as in the subject, use the imperative, present tense: "change" not "changed" nor "changes".
The body should include the motivation for the change and contrast this with previous behavior.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Footer
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
The footer should contain any information about Breaking Changes and is also the place to
reference GitHub issues that this commit Closes.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Breaking Changes should start with the word BREAKING CHANGE: with a space or two newlines. The rest of the commit message is then used for this.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: A detailed explanation can be found in this document.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Signing the CLA
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Please sign our Contributor License Agreement (CLA) before sending pull requests. For any code
changes to be accepted, the CLA must be signed. It's a quick process, we promise!
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - For individuals we have a simple click-through form.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- For corporations we'll need you to
print, sign and one of scan+email, fax or mail the form.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Read and contribute to the Wiki
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Make sure you read the Wiki.

Paragraph: Submitting Pull Requests
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: If you're changing the structure of the repository, please create an issue first.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: The release process is automated using semantic-release, for best release results follow these simple steps:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
git add --all
npm run commit
git push origin master
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Do not add/change the package.json version field.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Create unit tests for any new functionality you add in your commits.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Make sure you are on latest changes and that you run this command npm run clean:install after updating your local repository. If you can, please provide more information about your environment such as browser, operating system, node version, and npm version.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Contributing
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
All kinds of contributions to git-remote-dropbox are greatly appreciated. For
someone unfamiliar with the code base, the easiest way to contribute is
probably to submit a feature request or bug
report. If you want to dive into the source code, you can submit
a patch as well, either working on your own ideas or existing
issues.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Feature Requests
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Do you have an idea for an improvement to git-remote-dropbox? Please submit a
feature request. It's great to hear about new ideas.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
If you are inclined to do so, you're welcome to fork
git-remote-dropbox, work on implementing the feature yourself, and submit a
patch. In this case, it's highly recommended that you first open an
issue describing your enhancement to get early feedback on what you're
doing. This will help avoid wasted efforts and ensure that your work is
incorporated into the code base.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Bug Reports
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Did something go wrong with git-remote-dropbox? Sorry about that! Bug reports
are greatly appreciated!
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
When you submit a bug report, please include relevant information such
as git-remote-dropbox version, Git version, operating system, error messages,
and steps to reproduce the bug. The more details you can include, the easier it
is to find and fix the bug.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Patches
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Want to hack on git-remote-dropbox? Awesome!
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
You may find the documentation in DESIGN.md and the source code
helpful.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
If there are open issues, you're more than welcome to work on those -
this is probably the best way to contribute code to git-remote-dropbox. If you
have your own ideas, that's great too! In that case, before working on
substantial changes to the code base, it is highly recommended that you first
open an issue describing what you intend to work on.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
Patches are generally submitted as pull requests. Patches are also
accepted over email.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
Any changes to the code base should follow the style and coding conventions
used in the rest of the project. The version history should be clean, and
commit messages should be descriptive and properly
formatted.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: If you have any questions about anything, feel free to ask!
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Contributing to Ant Design Mobile
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: The following is a set of guidelines for contributing to Ant Design Mobile. Please spend several minutes in reading these guidelines before you create an issue or pull request.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Anyway, these are just guidelines, not rules, use your best judgment and feel free to propose changes to this document in a pull request.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Do your homework before asking a question
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: It's a great idea to read Eric Steven Raymond's How To Ask Questions The Smart Way twice before asking a question. But if you are busy now, I recommend to read Don't post homework questions first.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: The following guidelines are about How to avoid Homework Questions.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 1. Read the documentation.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: It sad but true that someone just glance(not read) Ant Design Mobile's documentation. Please read the documentation closely.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Tips: choose the corresponding documentation with versions selector which in the bottom-right corner.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 2. Make sure that your question is about Ant Design Mobile, not React
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Someone may think all of the questions that he/she meets in developing are about Ant Design Mobile, but it's not true. So, please read React's documentaion or just Google(not Baidu, seriously) your questions with keywork React first. If you are sure that your question is about Ant Design Mobile, go ahead.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 3. Read the FAQ and search the issues list of Ant Design Mobile
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Your questions may be asked and solved by others. So please spend several minutes on searching. Remember DRY, both code and questions.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: P.S.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 1.  FAQ
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 2.  Issues list
Label: No categories identified.

Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: It is a good habit which will save maintainers' time. Thank you!
Label: No categories identified.

Label: No categories identified.
