Paragraph: How to report a bug
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Before anything else, please make sure you are on the latest version, the bug you are experiencing may have been fixed already!
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Use the search function to see if someone else has already submitted the same bug report.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Try to describe the problem with as much detail as possible.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Some bugs may only occur on certain devices or versions of Android. Please add information about your device and the version of Android that is running on it (you can look these up under Settings ? About Phone), as well as which version of AntennaPod you are using.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - If the bug only seems to occur with a certain podcast, please include the URL of that podcast.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - If possible, add instructions on how to reproduce the bug.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - If possible, add a logfile to your post. This is especially useful if the bug makes the application crash. AntennaPod has an export logs feature for this.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Usually, you can take a screenshot of your smartphone by pressing Power + Volume down for a few seconds.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Please use the following template.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: How to submit a feature request
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Make sure you are using the latest version of AntennaPod. Perhaps the feature you are looking for has already been implemented.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Use the search function to see if someone else has already submitted the same feature request. If there is another request already, please upvote the first post instead of commenting something like "I also want this".
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - To make it easier for us to keep track of requests, please only make one feature request per issue.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Give a brief explanation about the problem that may currently exist and how your requested feature solves this problem.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Try to be as specific as possible. Please not only explain what the feature does, but also how. If your request is about (or includes) changing or extending the UI, describe what the UI would look like and how the user would interact with it.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Translating AntennaPod
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: If you would like to translate the app into another language or improve an existing translation, you can visit the Transifex project page. From there, you can either join a language team if it already exists or create a new language team.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Submit a pull request
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - If you want to work on a feature that has been requested or fix a bug that has been reported on the "issues" page, add a comment to it so that other people know that you are working on it.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Fork the repository.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Almost all changes of AntennaPod are done on the develop branch. If a new version of AntennaPod is released, the develop branch is merged into master. As a result, the master branch probably doesn't contain the latest changes when you are reading this. Please make sure that you are branching from develop! Otherwise, there might be a lot of merge-conflicts when merging your changes into develop and therefore it might take longer to review your pull-request. Exceptions are urgent issues that need to be fixed in the production version.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - If your pull request fixes a bug that has been reported or implements a feature that has been requested in another issue, try to mention it in the message, so that it can be closed once your pull request has been merged. If you use special keywords in the commit comment or pull request text, GitHub will close the issue(s) automatically.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - If possible, add unit tests for your pull request and make sure that they pass.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Please do not upgrade dependencies or build tools unless you have a good reason for it. Doing so can easily introduce bugs that are hard to track down.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - If you plan to do a change that touches many files (10+), please ask beforehand. This usually causes merge conflicts for other developers.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Please follow our code style. You can use Checkstyle within Android Studio using our coniguration file.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: ? Contribute
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Thanks for being interested in contributing to this project!
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Setup
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Clone this repo to your local machine and install the dependencies.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: yarn install
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Code Style
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Don't worry about the code style as long as you install the dev dependencies. Git hooks will format and fix them for you on committing.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Development
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: We use Storybook for rapid development and documenting. You can start it locally by
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: yarn storybook
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Contributing to existing functions
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Feel free to enhance the existing functions. Please try not to introduce breaking changes.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Contributing to new functions
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: There are some notes for adding new functions
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Before you start working, it's better to open an issue to discuss first.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Function names should start with use or create in lowercases.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - The implementation should be placed under packages/core as a folder and exposing in index.ts
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - In the core package, try not to introduce 3-rd party dependencies as this package is aim to be as lightweight as possible.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - If you do want to introduce 3-rd party dependencies, please contribute to add-ons.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Contributing to new add-ons
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: New add-ons are great welcome!
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Create a new folder under packages/, name it as your add-on name.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Add add-on details in scripts/packages.js
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Create README.md and readme.stories.tsx under that folder, package.json will be auto generated.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Add functions as you would do to the core package.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Run npm run update:readme to update the docs.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Project Structure
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Monorepo
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: We use monorepo for multiple packages
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
package
core/         - the core package
firebase/     - the Firebase add-on
<whatever>/   - add-ons named <whatever>
utils/        - utils
api.ts        - generated for API reference, you should always import form this file
api.2.ts      - API for Vue 2. DO NOT IMPORT from this file.
api.3.ts      - API for Vue 3. DO NOT IMPORT from this file.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Function Folder
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: A function folder typicality contains these 4 files:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
index.ts            # function source code itself
index.stories.tsx   # storybook demo
index.test.ts       # jest unit testing
index.md            # documentation
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: for index.ts you should export the function with name.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
// DO
export { useMyFunction }
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
// DON'T
export default useMyFunction
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: for index.md the first sentence will be displayed as the short intro in the function list, so try to keep it brief and clear.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: # useMyFunction
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: > This will be the intro. The detail descriptions...
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: for index.stories.tsx, you can duplicate for the other functions and modify it.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Thanks
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Thank you again for being interested in this project! You are awesome!
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Contributing to ANTLR 4
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 1.  Fork the antlr/antlr4 repo
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 2.  Install and configure EditorConfig so your text editor or IDE uses the ANTLR 4 coding style
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 3.  Build ANTLR 4
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 4.  Run the ANTLR project unit tests
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 5.  Create a pull request including your change
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Note: You must sign the contributors.txt certificate of origin with your pull request if you've not done so before.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Contributing to Aurora
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: I have found a bug!
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Please make sure that your bug was not already reported by searching the issues.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - If your bug was already reported and you have additional information to provide, please comment on the existing issue. Do not create a new issue that is a duplicate of an existing one (unless it has been closed).
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - If you cannot find your issue reported, please make a New Issue and follow the bug report template.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: I want to contribute code!
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Please first create your own fork of this repo if you do not already have one.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - If you have not done so yet, you will need to clone your repo onto your local machine for development. git clone https://github.com/your-username/Aurora.git
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - You will also need to add the main repo as an upstream to get updated commits. git remote add upstream https://github.com/antonpup/Aurora.git
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Make sure your fork is up-to-date with the latest dev branch on the main repo. git fetch upstream
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Create a feature or fix branch from the latest dev branch. git checkout -b feature/my-new-feature upstream/dev
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - If you plan on adding new features, please prefix your branch name with 'feature/'. For example feature/audio-layer-improvements.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - If you plan on fixing bugs, please prefix your branch name with 'fix/'. For example fix/layer-selection.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - If you are adding features and bug fixes, use 'feature/'.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - If you are adding or fixing multiple unrelated areas, please divide your code into different branches. For example, don't add a new device at the same time as you change how the overrides system works.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Please ensure that your code follows the existing conventions set out in the code (such as using auto properties where applicable, naming conventions, etc.).
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - When you have finished your feature or bug fix, push your changes to your remote branch. E.g. git push origin feature/my-cool-feature
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Create a new pull request on the main Aurora repo.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Add a descriptive title and description which includes a detailed list of what has been changed and any known issues. You may also wish to include screenshots, examples and important design decisions you made in the description too.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - A collaborator will review your PR and accept it or make suggestions on what should be changed.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: We appreciate your kind efforts in making Aurora a better software! :tada:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Contribution Guide
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
If you have any comment or advice, please report your issue,
or make any change as you wish and submit an PR.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Reporting New Issues
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Please specify what kind of issue it is.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Before you report an issue, please search for related issues. Make sure you are not going to open a duplicate issue.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Explain your purpose clearly in tags(see Useful Tags), title, or content.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: AntV group members will confirm the purpose of the issue, replace more accurate tags for it, identify related milestone, and assign developers working on it.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Submitting Code
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Pull Request Guide
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: If you are developer of AntV repo and you are willing to contribute, feel free to create a new branch, finish your modification and submit a PR. AntV group will review your work and merge it to master branch.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
# Create a new branch for development. The name of branch should be semantic, avoiding words like 'update' or 'tmp'. We suggest to use feature/xxx, if the modification is about to implement a new feature.
$ git checkout -b branch-name
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
# Run the test after you finish your modification. Add new test cases or change old ones if you feel necessary
$ npm test
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
# If your modification pass the tests, congradulations it's time to push your work back to us. Notice that the commit message should be wirtten in the following format.
$ git add . # git add -u to delete files
$ git commit -m "fix(role): role.use must xxx"
$ git push origin branch-name
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Then you can create a Pull Request at f2.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: No one can garantee how much will be remembered about certain PR after some time. To make sure we can easily recap what happened previously, please provide the following information in your PR.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 1.  Need: What function you want to achieve (Generally, please point out which issue is related).
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 2.  Updating Reason: Different with issue. Briefly describe your reason and logic about why you need to make such modification.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 3.  Related Testing: Briefly descirbe what part of testing is relevant to your modification.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 4.  User Tips: Notice for f2 users. You can skip this part, if the PR is not about update in API or potential compatibility problem.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Style Guide
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Eslint can help to identify styling issues that may exist in your code. Your code is required to pass the test from eslint. Run the test locally by $ npm run lint.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Commit Message Format
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: You are encouraged to use angular commit-message-format to write commit message. In this way, we could have a more trackable history and an automatically generated changelog.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
<type>(<scope>): <subject>
<BLANK LINE>
<body>
<BLANK LINE>
<footer>
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: ?1?type
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Must be one of the following:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - feat: A new feature
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - fix: A bug fix
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - docs: Documentation-only changes
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - style: Changes that do not affect the meaning of the code (white-space, formatting, missing semi-colons, etc)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - refactor: A code change that neither fixes a bug nor adds a feature
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - perf: A code change that improves performance
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - test: Adding missing tests
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - chore: Changes to the build process or auxiliary tools and libraries such as documentation generation
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - deps: Updates about dependencies
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: ?2?scope
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: The scope could be anything specifying place of the commit change.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: ?3?subject
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Use succinct words to describe what did you do in the commit change.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: ?4?body
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Feel free to add more content in the body, if you think subject is not self-explanatory enough, such as what it is the purpose or reasone of you commit.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: ?5?footer
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - If the commit is a Breaking Change, please note it clearly in this part.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - related issues, like Closes #1, Closes #2, #3
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: e.g.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: fix($compile): [BREAKING_CHANGE] couple of unit tests for IE9
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Older IEs serialize html uppercased, but IE9 does not...
Would be better to expect case insensitive, unfortunately jasmine does
not allow to user regexps for throw expectations.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Document change on antvis/f2#123
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Closes #392
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: BREAKING CHANGE:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Breaks foo.bar api, foo.baz should be used instead
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Look at these files for more detials.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Release
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: f2 uses semantic versioning in release process based on semver.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Branch Strategy
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: master branch is the latest stable version.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - just checkout develop branch from master
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - All new features will be added into master or next branch as well as all bug-fix except security issues. In such way, we can motivate developers to update to the latest stable version.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Release Strategy
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: In the release of every stable version, there will be a PM who has the following responsibilities in different stages of the release.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Preparation
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Set up milestone. Confirm that request is related to milestone.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Before Release
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Confirm that performance test is passed and all issues in current Milestone are either closed or can be delayed to later versions.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Open a new Release Proposal MR, and write History as node CHANGELOG. Don't forget to correct content in documentation which is related to the releasing version. Commits can be generated automatically.
$ npm run commits
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Nominate PM for next stable version.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Pull Request Guide
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: If you are developer of AntV repo and you are willing to contribute, feel free to create a new branch, finish your modification and submit a PR. AntV group will review your work and merge it to master branch.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
# Create a new branch for development. The name of branch should be semantic, avoiding words like 'update' or 'tmp'. We suggest to use feature/xxx, if the modification is about to implement a new feature.
$ git checkout -b branch-name
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
# Run the test after you finish your modification. Add new test cases or change old ones if you feel necessary
$ npm test
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
# If your modification pass the tests, congradulations it's time to push your work back to us. Notice that the commit message should be wirtten in the following format.
$ git add . # git add -u to delete files
$ git commit -m "fix(role): role.use must xxx"
$ git push origin branch-name
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Then you can create a Pull Request at g6.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: No one can guarantee how much will be remembered about certain PR after some time. To make sure we can easily recap what happened previously, please provide the following information in your PR.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 1.  Need: What function you want to achieve (Generally, please point out which issue is related).
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 2.  Updating Reason: Different with issue. Briefly describe your reason and logic about why you need to make such modification.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 3.  Related Testing: Briefly describe what part of testing is relevant to your modification.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 4.  User Tips: Notice for g6 users. You can skip this part, if the PR is not about update in API or potential compatibility problem.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Style Guide
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Eslint can help to identify styling issues that may exist in your code. Your code is required to pass the test from eslint. Run the test locally by $ npm run lint.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Commit Message Format
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: You are encouraged to use angular commit-message-format to write commit message. In this way, we could have a more trackable history and an automatically generated changelog.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
<type>(<scope>): <subject>
<BLANK LINE>
<body>
<BLANK LINE>
<footer>
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: ?1?type
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Must be one of the following:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - feat: A new feature
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - fix: A bug fix
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - docs: Documentation-only changes
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - style: Changes that do not affect the meaning of the code (white-space, formatting, missing semi-colons, etc)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - refactor: A code change that neither fixes a bug nor adds a feature
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - perf: A code change that improves performance
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - test: Adding missing tests
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - chore: Changes to the build process or auxiliary tools and libraries such as documentation generation
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - deps: Updates about dependencies
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: ?2?scope
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: The scope could be anything specifying place of the commit change.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: ?3?subject
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Use succinct words to describe what did you do in the commit change.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: ?4?body
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Feel free to add more content in the body, if you think subject is not self-explanatory enough, such as what it is the purpose or reasons of you commit.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: ?5?footer
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - If the commit is a Breaking Change, please note it clearly in this part.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - related issues, like Closes #1, Closes #2, #3
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: e.g.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: fix($compile): [BREAKING_CHANGE] couple of unit tests for IE9

not allow to user regexps for throw expectations.

Paragraph: This is for code contributions. For translations, see TRANSLATING.

Paragraph: Basic Guidelines
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Use an IDE.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Specifically, IntelliJ IDEA. Download the (free) Community Edition of it here. Some people use other tools, like VS Code, but I would personally not recommend them for Java development.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Always test your changes.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
Do not submit something without at least running the game to see if it compiles.
If you are submitting a new block, make sure it has a name and description, and that it works correctly in-game. If you are changing existing block mechanics, test them out first.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Do not make large changes before discussing them first.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
If you are interested in adding a large mechanic/feature or changing large amounts of code, first contact me (Anuken) via Discord (preferred method) or via e-mail (anukendev@gmail.com).
For most changes, this should not be necessary. I just want to know if you're doing something big so I can offer advice and/or make sure you're not wasting your time on it.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Style Guidelines
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Follow the formatting guidelines.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: This means:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - No spaces around parentheses: if(condition){, SomeType s = (SomeType)object
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Same-line braces.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - 4 spaces indentation
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - camelCase, even for constants or enums. Why? Because SCREAMING_CASE is ugly, annoying to type and does not achieve anything useful. Constants are less dangerous than variables, not more.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - No underscores for anything. (Yes, I know Bindings violates this principle, but that's for legacy reasons and really should be cleaned up some day)
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Do not use braceless if/else statements. if(x) statement else statement2 should never be done. In very specific situations, having braceless if-statements on one line is allowed: if(cond) return; would be valid.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Import this style file into IntelliJ to get correct formatting when developing Mindustry.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Do not use incompatible Java features (java.util.function, java.awt).
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
Android and RoboVM (iOS) do not support many of Java 8's features, such as the packages java.util.function, java.util.stream or forEach in collections. Do not use these in your code.
If you need to use functional interfaces, use the ones in arc.func, which are more or less the same with different naming schemes.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
The same applies to any class outside of the standard java.[n]io / java.net / java.util packages: Most of them are not supported.
java.awt is one of these packages: do not use it, ever. It is not supported on any platform, even desktop - the entire package is removed during JRE minimization.
In general, if you are using IntelliJ, you should be warned about platform incompatiblities.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Use arc collections and classes when possible.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
Instead of using java.util.List, java.util.HashMap, and other standard Java collections, use Array, ObjectMap and other equivalents from arc.struct.
Why? Because that's what the rest of the codebase uses, and the standard collections have a lot of cruft and usability issues associated with them.
In the rare case that concurrency is required, you may use the standard Java classes for that purpose (e.g. CopyOnWriteArrayList).
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: What you'll usually need to change:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - HashSet -> ObjectSet
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - HashMap -> ObjectMap
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - List / ArrayList / Stack -> Array
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - java.util.Queue -> arc.struct.Queue
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Many others
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Avoid boxed types (Integer, Boolean)
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Never create variables or collections with boxed types Array<Integer> or ObjectMap<Integer, ...>. Use the collections specialized for this task, e.g. IntArray and IntMap.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Do not allocate anything if possible.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
Never allocate new objects in the main loop. If you absolutely require new objects, use Pools to obtain and free object instances.
Otherwise, use the Tmp variables for things like vector/shape operations, or create static variables for re-use.
If using a list, make it a static variable and clear it every time it is used. Re-use as much as possible.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Avoid bloated code and unnecessary getters/setters.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
This is situational, but in essence what it means is to avoid using any sort of getters and setters unless absolutely necessary. Public or protected fields should suffice for most things.
If something needs to be encapsulated in the future, IntelliJ can handle it with a few clicks.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Do not create methods unless necessary.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Unless a block of code is very large or used in more than 1-2 places, don't split it up into a separate method. Making unnecessary methods only creates confusion, and may slightly decrease performance.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Where do I start? :traffic_light:

Paragraph: - Install and Start Elasticsearch
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Use easybutton-build.sh or configure and make to build everything
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Run make check from the top level directory, this will
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - run npm ci everywhere
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - run tests.pl and tests.pl --viewer in the tests directory
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Note: this will only work if viewer is not already running.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: You should now have test data loaded, so let's start the web app:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Move to the Moloch viewer directory
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Run npm ci
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Move to the vueapp directory
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Run npm ci
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Move back up to the viewer directory
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Before submitting a bug report:
Label: No categories identified.

Label: No categories identified.

Please follow these guidelines when submitting a bug:
Label: No categories identified.

Label: No categories identified.

Label: No categories identified.

Label: No categories identified.

Feature requests are tracked as GitHub Issues.
Please follow these guidelines when submitting a feature request:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Provide a clear and descriptive title
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Describe the suggested feature in as much detail as possible

Paragraph: - Use examples to help us understand the use case of the feature

Paragraph: - If you are requesting a minor improvement, describe the current behavior and why it is not sufficient

Paragraph: Upgrading Cyberchef
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 1.  Update the CyberChef version ("CYBERCHEFVERSION") in viewer/viewer.js
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 2.  Update the CyberChef version in viewer/Makefile.in (there are two version numbers on line 23)
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 3.  Run make in viewer or download the new version of the CyberChef zip file manually to the viewer/public directory
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 4.  Unzip and copy CyberChef_v*.html to viewer/public/CyberChef_v*.html
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 5.  Add <base href="./cyberchef/" /> in the <head> of viewer/public/CyberChef_v*.html
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 6.  Add the script section from the previous viewer/public/cyberchef.html file before the end </body></html> tags at the end of viewer/public/CyberChef_v*.html
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 7.  Delete the old CyberChef zip file
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 8.  Delete the old CyberChef html file
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 9.  Rename viewer/public/CyberChef_v*.html file to viewer/public/cyberchef.html
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Improving the documentation
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Documentation is massively important to help users make the most of Apache Camel and its probably the area that needs the most help!
So if you are interested in helping the documentation effort; whether its just to fix a page here or there, correct a link or even write a tutorial or improve what documentation is already there please do dive in and help!
We moved the documentation into the code (AsciiDoc). We are not using the wiki system anymore.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: To edit the documentation:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - It's easy as opening a Pull Request
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - You'll find on each component under src/main/docs an .adoc file
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - This file contains a static part and a dynamically generated part: the former can be edited directly in the .adoc file, while the latter needs your intervention on the javadoc
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Once you modify the javadoc, you'll need to rebuild the component and the .adoc will be automatically updated
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Create a commit and raise a Pull Request
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - If you want to add more documentation check for .adoc in codebase
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: For more information see How does the website work or How do I edit the website for more details.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: If you find a bug or problem
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Please raise a new issue in our issue tracker
If you can create a JUnit test case then your issue is more likely to be resolved quicker.
e.g. take a look at some of the existing unit tests cases
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Working on the code
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: We recommend to work on the code from github.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
git clone https://github.com/apache/camel.git
cd camel
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Build the project (fast build).
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: mvn clean install -Pfastinstall
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: If you intend to work on the code and provide patches and other work you want to submit to the Apache Camel project, then you can fork the project on github and work on your own fork. The custom work you do should be done on branches you create, which can then be committed and pushed upstream, and then submitted to Apache Camel as PRs (pull requests). You can find many resources online how to work on github projects and how to submit work to these projects.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Running checkstyle
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
Apache Camel source code is using a coding style/format which can be checked whether is complying using the checkstyle plugin.
To enable source style checking with checkstyle, build Camel with the -Psourcecheck parameter
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: mvn clean install -Psourcecheck
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Please remember to run this check on your code changes before submitting a patch or github PR. You do not need to run this against the entire project, but for example in the modules you work on. Lets say you do some code changes in the camel-ftp component, then you can run the check from within this directory:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
cd camel-ftp
mvn clean install -Psourcecheck
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Verify Karaf features
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Camel-Karaf lives now in his own repository, so to verify a Karaf feature you'll need to fork the following repository.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
To check a new Karaf feature or an existing one you should run a verification on the features.xml file. You'll need to follow these steps:
First thing to be done is running a full build of Camel. Then
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
cd platform/karaf/features/
mvn clean install
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: If you modified a component/dataformat or updated a dependency in the main camel repository, you'll first need to build the main camel locally and then run a full build of camel-karaf.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Apache Camel committers should work on the ASF git repo
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: If you are an Apache Camel committer then clone the ASF git repo at
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
git clone https://gitbox.apache.org/repos/asf/camel.git
cd camel
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: or
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
git clone https://github.com/apache/camel.git
cd camel
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Build the project (without testing).
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: mvn clean install -Dtest=false
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
PS: You might need to build multiple times (if you get a build error) because sometimes maven fails to download all the files.
Then import the projects into your workspace.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Creating patches
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: We recommend you create patches as github PRs which is much easier for us to accept and work with. You do this as any other github project, where you can fork the project, and create a branch where you work on the code, and then commit and push that code to your fork. Then navigate to the Apache Camel github webpage, and you will see that github in the top of the page has a wizard to send your recent work as a PR (pull request).
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Pull request at Github
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: There is also a Git repository at Github which you could fork. Then you submit patches as any other github project - eg work on a new feature branch and send a pull request. One of the committers then needs to accept your pull request to bring the code  to the ASF codebase. After the code has been included into the ASF codebase, you need to close the pull request because we can't do that...
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
When providing code patches then please include the Camel JIRA ticket number in the commit messages.
We favor using the syntax:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: CAMEL-9999: Some message goes here
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Manual patch files
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: We gladly accept patches if you can find ways to improve, tune or fix Camel in some way.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: We recommend using github PRs instead of manual patch files. Especially for bigger patches.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Most IDEs can create nice patches now very easily. e.g. in Eclipse just right click on a file/directory and select Team -> Create Patch. Then just save the patch as a file and attach it to the corresponding issue on our https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CAMEL[JIRA issue tracker].
If you're a command line person try the following to create the patch
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: diff -u Main.java.orig Main.java >> patchfile.txt
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: or
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git diff --no-prefix > patchfile.txt
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Submitting patches
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: The easiest way to submit a patch is to
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - create a new JIRA issue (you will need to register),
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - attach the patch or tarball as an attachment (if you create a patch file, but we recommend using github PRs)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- tick the Patch Attached button on the issue
We prefer patches has unit tests as well and that these unit tests have proper assertions as well, so remember to replace your system.out or logging with an assertion instead!
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Using the issue tracker
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Before you can raise an issue in the issue tracker you need to register with it. This is quick & painless.
Label: No categories identified.

There are multiple ways to contribute: report bugs, improve the docs, and

For instructions on this, start with the

Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: How to Contribute
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: When submitting a pull request (PR), please use the following guidelines:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Make sure your code respects existing formatting conventions. In general, follow
the same coding style as the code that you are modifying.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - For Intellij you can import our code style settings xml: druid_intellij_formatting.xml.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - For Eclipse you can import our code style settings xml: eclipse_formatting.xml.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Do add/update documentation appropriately for the change you are making.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- If you are introducing a new feature you may want to first write about your idea
for feedback to dev@druid.apache.org. Or create an issue
using "Feature/Change" template. Non-trivial features should include unit tests covering the new functionality. Open
a "Proposal" issue for large changes.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Bugfixes should include a unit test or integration test reproducing the issue.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Do not use author tags/information in the code.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Try to keep pull requests short and submit separate ones for unrelated
features, but feel free to combine simple bugfixes/tests into one pull request.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- If you are adding or updating a dependency, be sure to update the version, license, or notice information in
licenses.yaml as appropriate to help ease
LICENSE and NOTICE management for ASF releases.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: You can find more developers' resources in dev/ directory.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: GitHub Workflow
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 1.  Fork the apache/druid repository into your GitHub account
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: https://github.com/apache/druid/fork
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 2.  Clone your fork of the GitHub repository
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: git clone git@github.com:<username>/druid.git
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: replace <username> with your GitHub username.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 3.  Add a remote to keep up with upstream changes
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: git remote add upstream https://github.com/apache/druid.git
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: If you already have a copy, fetch upstream changes
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: git fetch upstream master
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 4.  Create a feature branch to work in
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: git checkout -b feature-xxx remotes/upstream/master
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
5.  Before submitting a pull request periodically rebase your changes
(but don't do it when a pull request is already submitted)
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: git pull --rebase upstream master
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 6.  Before submitting a pull request, combine ("squash") related commits into a single one
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: git rebase -i upstream/master
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: This will open your editor and allow you to re-order commits and merge them:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Re-order the lines to change commit order (to the extent possible without creating conflicts)
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Prefix commits using s (squash) or f (fixup) to merge extraneous commits.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 7.  Submit a pull-request
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: git push origin feature-xxx
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Go to your Druid fork main page
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: https://github.com/<username>/druid
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
If you recently pushed your changes GitHub will automatically pop up a
Compare & pull request button for any branches you recently pushed to. If you
click that button it will automatically offer you to submit your pull-request
to the apache/druid repository.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Give your pull-request a meaningful title.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - In the description, explain your changes and the problem they are solving.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 8.  Addressing code review comments
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
Address code review comments by committing changes and pushing them to your feature
branch.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: git push origin feature-xxx
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: If your pull request shows conflicts with master
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: If your pull request shows conflicts with master, merge master into your feature branch:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: git merge upstream/master
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: and resolve the conflicts. After resolving conflicts, push your branch again:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: git push origin feature-xxx
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
Avoid rebasing and force pushes after submitting a pull request, since these make it
difficult for reviewers to see what you've changed in response to their reviews. The Druid
committer that merges your change will rebase and squash it into a single commit before
committing it to master.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: FAQ
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Help! I merged changes from upstream and cannot figure out how to resolve conflicts when rebasing!
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Never fear! If you occasionally merged upstream/master, here is another way to squash your changes into a single commit:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 1.  First, rename your existing branch to something else, e.g. feature-xxx-unclean
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: git branch -m feature-xxx-unclean
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 2.  Checkout a new branch with the original name feature-xxx from upstream. This branch will supercede our old one.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: git checkout -b feature-xxx upstream/master
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 3.  Then merge your changes in your original feature branch feature-xxx-unclean and create a single commit.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
git merge --squash feature-xxx-unclean
git commit
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 4.  You can now submit this new branch and create or replace your existing pull request.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: git push origin [--force] feature-xxx:feature-xxx
Label: No categories identified.

Label: TC – Talk to the community

Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph:
- Subscribe to both Apache User List - user@ignite.apache.org
and Dev List - dev@ignite.apache.org lists with your personal (non-corporate) email address.
Optionally you can subscribe to Notifications List - notifications@ignite.apache.org.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: To subscribe to any list in the Apache Software Foundation you can send email to list_name-subscribe@ignite.apache.org, e.g., to dev-subscribe@ignite.apache.org and follow instructions.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph:
- Send a welcome message to the dev list to introduce yourself to the community and saying that you're going to contribute.
Request access to Apache Ignite JIRA in the same email sharing your JIRA ID.
Example of message:
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Hello Ignite Community!
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: My name is Aristarkh. I want to contribute to Apache Ignite and want to start with this issue - IGNITE-NNNNN, my JIRA username Aristarkh. Any help on this will be appreciated.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Thanks!
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Development
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Start by forking the dolphinscheduler GitHub repository, make changes in a branch and then send a pull request.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Set up your dolphinscheduler GitHub Repository
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: There are three branches in the remote repository currently:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: - master : normal delivery branch. After the stable version is released, the code for the stable version branch is merged into the master branch.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: - dev : daily development branch. The daily development branch, the newly submitted code can pull requests to this branch.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: - x.x.x-release : the stable release version.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: So, you should fork the dev branch.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: After forking the dolphinscheduler upstream source repository to your personal repository, you can set your  personal development environment.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
$ cd <your work direcotry>
$ git clone < your personal forked dolphinscheduler repo>
$ cd incubator-dolphinscheduler
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Set git remote as upstream
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Add remote repository address, named upstream
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: git remote add upstream https://github.com/apache/incubator-dolphinscheduler.git
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: View repository:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: git remote -v
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: There will be two repositories at this time: origin (your own warehouse) and upstream (remote repository)
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Get/update remote repository code (already the latest code, skip it).
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: git fetch upstream
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Synchronize remote repository code to local repository
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
git checkout origin/dev
git merge --no-ff upstream/dev
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: If remote branch has a new branch DEV-1.0, you need to synchronize this branch to the local repository.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
git checkout -b dev-1.0 upstream/dev-1.0
git push --set-upstream origin dev1.0
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Create your feature branch
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Before making code changes, make sure you create a separate branch for them.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: $ git checkout -b <your-feature>
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Commit changes
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: After modifying the code locally, submit it to your own repository:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git commit -m 'information about your feature'
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Push to the branch
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Push your locally committed changes to the remote origin (your fork).
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: $ git push origin <your-feature>
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Create a pull request
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: After submitting changes to your remote repository, you should click on the new pull request On the following github page.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Select the modified local branch and the branch to merge past to create a pull request.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Next, the administrator is responsible for merging to complete the pull request.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Contribute to Doris
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Thank you very much for your interest in the Doris project. We welcome your suggestions, comments (including criticisms), comments and contributions to the Doris project.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Your suggestions, comments and comments on Doris can be made directly through GitHub's [Issues] (https://github.com/apache/incubator-doris/issues/new/selection).
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: There are many ways to participate in and contribute to Doris projects: code implementation, test writing, process tool improvement, document improvement, and so on. Any contribution will be welcomed and you will be added to the list of contributors. Further, with sufficient contributions, you will have the opportunity to become a Commiter of Aapche with Apache mailbox and be included in the list of [Apache Commiters] (http://people.apache.org/committer-index.html).
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Any questions, you can contact us to get timely answers, including Wechat, Gitter (GitHub instant messaging tool), e-mail and so on.

Label: TC – Talk to the community

Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: - Subscribe to our [mailing list] (./subscribe-mail-list.md);
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Doris's code and documentation
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: As you can see from [GitHub] (https://github.com/apache/incubator-doris), Apache Doris (incubating) code base mainly consists of three parts: Frontend (FE), Backend (BE) and Broker (to support file reading on external storage systems such as HDFS). Documents are mainly the wiki on Doris website and GitHub, as well as the online help manual when running Doris. Details of these components can be found in the following table:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
| Component Name | Component Description | Related Language|
|--------|----------------------------|----------|
| [Frontend daemon (FE)] (https://github.com/apache/incubator-doris) | consists of a query coordinator and a metadata manager | Java|
| [Backend daemon (BE)] (https://github.com/apache/incubator-doris) | Responsible for storing data and executing query fragments | C++|
| [Broker] (https://github.com/apache/incubator-doris) | Read HDFS data to Doris | Java|
| Website | Doris Website | Markdown |
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
- [Github Wiki] (https://github.com/apache/incubator-doris/wiki); Doris Github Wiki; Markdown_;
| Doris Runtime Help Document | Online Help Manual at Doris Runtime | Markdown|
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Improving documentation
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Documentation is the most important way for you to understand Apache Doris, and it's where we need help most!
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Browse the document, you can deepen your understanding of Doris, can also help you understand Doris's function and technical details, if you find that the document has problems, please contact us in time;
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: If you are interested in improving the quality of documents, whether it is revising the address of a page, correcting a link, and writing a better introductory document, we are very welcome!
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Most of our documents are written in markdown format, and you can modify and submit document changes directly through docs/ in [GitHub] (https://github.com/apache/incubator-doris). If you submit code changes, you can refer to [Pull Request] (./pull-request.md).
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: If a Bug or problem is found
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: If a Bug or problem is found, you can directly raise a new Issue through GitHub's [Issues] (https://github.com/apache/incubator-doris/issues/new/select), and we will have someone deal with it regularly.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: You can also fix it yourself by reading the analysis code (of course, it's better to talk to us before that, maybe someone has fixed the same problem) and submit a [Pull Request] (./pull-request.md).
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Modify the code and submit PR (Pull Request)
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: You can download the code, compile and install it, deploy and run it for a try (refer to the [compilation document] (./installing/compilation.md)) to see if it works as you expected. If you have problems, you can contact us directly, ask questions or fix them by reading and analyzing the source code.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Whether it's fixing Bugs or adding Features, we're all very welcome. If you want to submit code to Doris, you need to create a new branch for your submitted code from the fork code library on GitHub to your project space, add the source project upstream, and submit PR.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: About how to submit a PR refer to [Pull Request] (./pull-request.md).
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Release Milestone Discussion
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: We will start the discussion about the bugs to fix and features of each release in the mailing list. You may subscribe our mailing list to give your valuable advice in the milestone dicussion.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: About our release plan, we will release a mior version at the end of every month. Here is some detail.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 1.  Assume our current stable release is 4.3.0. We will start the discussion of milestone of the release two versions ahead, which is 4.5.0 at the beginning of each month. At this time we should also kickoff the developing of the next release, which is 4.4.0.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 2.  Finish 4.4.0 developing at about 22th of this month and start the testing. And the 4.5.0 milestone discussion is frozen and published on the GitHub
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 3.  Vote in the mailing list for the 4.4.0 release at the end of this month.
Label: No categories identified.

Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Wiki: How to setup the dev environment
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Some hints about using code from other authors
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - About using some algorithms/formulas or inspired by other's work:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - We can be inspired from other people
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - But when you copy the code, even parts of files, it must remain under the copyright of the original authors.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - What's the right thing to do for the public good here? I'll go with:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Be transparent when implementing an existing idea/algorithm.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Reference where that idea/algorithm came from.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Use standard language when doing so (we need to define standard language).
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - "inspired by", "learned from" and "references to" are vague concepts in copyright.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - If any copyrightable expression is copied from the existing idea/algorithm, compare its licensing to our licensing policies and include licensing accordingly.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Check the original discussion about it in: https://lists.apache.org/list.html?legal-discuss@apache.org:lte=36M:echarts
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - About adding the license/header of 3rd-party work:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - https://www.apache.org/legal/src-headers.html#3party
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Licenses that are compatible with the Apache license:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - BSD and MIT are compatible with the Apache license but CC_BY_SA is not (https://apache.org/legal/resolved.html#cc-sa).
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Stack overflow:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - before intending to copy code from Stack overlow, we must check:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - https://apache.org/legal/resolved.html#stackoverflow
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LEGAL-471
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Wikipedia:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Wikipedia is licensed CC 4.0 BY_SA and is incompatible with the Apache license. So we should not copy code from Wikipedia.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Working in progress disclaimer:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - In some cases we might use the work in progress disclaimer and document the issues in that until they are fixed.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - https://incubator.apache.org/policy/incubation.html#disclaimers
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Heron includes a script to bootstrap an IntelliJ IDEA project. The project includes support for Heron
code styles and copyright headers.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: To bootstrap an IDEA project run the following from the root folder of the repo::
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: $ ./scripts/setup-intellij.sh
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: To bootstrap an Eclipse project fun the following from the root folder of the repo:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: $ ./scripts/setup-eclipse.sh
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
In general, contributions that fix bugs or add features (as opposed to stylistic, refactoring, or
"cleanup" changes) are preferred. If you're looking for places to contribute, issues with label
help-wanted
are good candidates. Please check with the mailing list
if your patch involves lots of changes.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph:
If you have any question or issues about troubleshooting,
you should post on mailing list instead
of opening GitHub issues.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Submitting a Patch
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
1.  Discuss your plan and design, and get agreement on
mailing list.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 2.  Implement proper unit tests along with your change. Verify that all tests can pass.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
3.  Submit a GitHub pull request that includes your change and test cases.
Describe clearly in your pull request the changes made. Verify that Travis CI passes.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 4.  Complete a code review by addressing the reviewer's comments.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 5.  A project committer will merge the patch to the master branch.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Orientation

Paragraph: Here's a list of repositories that contain Superset-related packages:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- apache/incubator-superset
is the main repository containing the apache-superset Python package
distributed on
pypi. This repository
also includes Superset's main TypeScript/JavaScript bundles and react apps under
the superset-frontend
folder.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- apache-superset/superset-ui
contains core Superset's
npm packages.
These packages are shared across the React apps in the main repository,
and in visualization plugins.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- apache-superset/superset-ui-plugins
contains the code for the default visualizations that ship with Superset
and are maintained by the core community.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- apache-superset/superset-ui-plugins-deckgl
contains the code for the geospatial visualizations that ship with Superset
and are maintained by the core community.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- github.com/apache-superset is the
Github organization under which we manage Superset-related
small tools, forks and Superset-related experimental ideas.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Types of Contributions
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Report Bug
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: The best way to report a bug is to file an issue on GitHub. Please include:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Your operating system name and version.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Superset version.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Detailed steps to reproduce the bug.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Any details about your local setup that might be helpful in troubleshooting.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
When posting Python stack traces, please quote them using
Markdown blocks.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Submit Ideas or Feature Requests
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: The best way is to file an issue on GitHub:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Explain in detail how it would work.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Keep the scope as narrow as possible, to make it easier to implement.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Remember that this is a volunteer-driven project, and that contributions are welcome :)
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: For large features or major changes to codebase, please create Superset Improvement Proposal (SIP). See template from SIP-0
Label: No categories identified.

Look through the GitHub issues. Issues tagged with #bug are
open to whoever wants to implement them.

Look through the GitHub issues. Issues tagged with

Superset could always use better documentation,
whether as part of the official Superset docs,

articles. See Documentation for more details.

If you are proficient in a non-English language, you can help translate
text strings from Superset's UI. You can jump in to the existing
language dictionaries at
superset/translations/<language_code>/LC_MESSAGES/messages.po, or
even create a dictionary for a new language altogether.
See Translating for more details.
