Paragraph: Pull Request Guidelines
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: A philosophy we would like to strongly encourage is
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Before creating a PR, create an issue.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: The purpose is to separate problem from possible solutions.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Bug fixes: If you
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Refactor: For small refactors, it can be a standalone PR itself detailing what you are refactoring and why. If there are concerns, project maintainers may request you to create a #SIP for the PR before proceeding.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Feature/Large changes: If you intend to change the public API, or make any non-trivial changes to the implementation, we requires you to file a new issue as #SIP (Superset Improvement Proposal). This lets us reach an agreement on your proposal before you put significant effort into it. You are welcome to submit a PR along with the SIP (sometimes necessary for demonstration), but we will not review/merge the code until the SIP is approved.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: In general, small PRs are always easier to review than large PRs. The best practice is to break your work into smaller independent PRs and refer to the same issue. This will greatly reduce turnaround time.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Finally, never submit a PR that will put master branch in broken state. If the PR is part of multiple PRs to complete a large feature and cannot work on its own, you can create a feature branch and merge all related PRs into the feature branch before creating a PR from feature branch to master.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Protocol
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Authoring
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Fill in all sections of the PR template.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Add prefix [WIP] to title if not ready for review (WIP = work-in-progress). We recommend creating a PR with [WIP] first and remove it once you have passed CI test and read through your code changes at least once.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Screenshots/GIFs: Changes to user interface require before/after screenshots, or GIF for interactions
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Recommended capture tools (Kap, LICEcap, Skitch)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - If no screenshot is provided, the committers will mark the PR with need:screenshot label and will not review until screenshot is provided.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Dependencies: Be careful about adding new dependency and avoid unnecessary dependencies.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - For Python, include it in setup.py denoting any specific restrictions and in requirements.txt pinned to a specific version which ensures that the application build is deterministic.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - For TypeScript/JavaScript, include new libraries in package.json
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Tests: The pull request should include tests, either as doctests, unit tests, or both. Make sure to resolve all errors and test failures. See Testing for how to run tests.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Documentation: If the pull request adds functionality, the docs should be updated as part of the same PR. Doc string are often sufficient, make sure to follow the sphinx compatible standards.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - CI: Reviewers will not review the code until all CI tests are passed. Sometimes there can be flaky tests. You can close and open PR to re-run CI test. Please report if the issue persists. After the CI fix has been deployed to master, please rebase your PR.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Code coverage: Please ensure that code coverage does not decrease.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Remove [WIP] when ready for review. Please note that it may be merged soon after approved so please make sure the PR is ready to merge and do not expect more time for post-approval edits.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - If the PR was not ready for review and inactive for > 30 days, we will close it due to inactivity. The author is welcome to re-open and update.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Reviewing
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Use constructive tone when writing reviews.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - If there are changes required, state clearly what needs to be done before the PR can be approved.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - If you are asked to update your pull request with some changes there's no need to create a new one. Push your changes to the same branch.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - The committers reserve the right to reject any PR and in some cases may request the author to file an issue.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Merging
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - At least one approval is required for merging a PR.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - PR is usually left open for at least 24 hours before merging.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - After the PR is merged, close the corresponding issue(s).
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Post-merge Responsibility
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Project maintainers may contact the PR author if new issues are introduced by the PR.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Project maintainers may revert your changes if a critical issue is found, such as breaking master branch CI.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Managing Issues and PRs
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: To handle issues and PRs that are coming in, committers read issues/PRs and flag them with labels to categorize and help contributors spot where to take actions, as contributors usually have different expertises.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Triaging goals
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - For issues: Categorize, screen issues, flag required actions from authors.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - For PRs: Categorize, flag required actions from authors. If PR is ready for review, flag required actions from reviewers.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: First, add Category labels (a.k.a. hash labels). Every issue/PR must have one hash label (except spam entry). Labels that begin with # defines issue/PR type:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
| Label           | for Issue                                                                                                                               | for PR                                                                                                                                            |
| --------------- | --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| #bug          | Bug report                                                                                                                              | Bug fix                                                                                                                                           |
| #code-quality | Describe problem with code, architecture or productivity                                                                                | Refactor, tests, tooling                                                                                                                          |
| #feature      | New feature request                                                                                                                     | New feature implementation                                                                                                                        |
| #refine       | Propose improvement that does not provide new features and is also not a bug fix nor refactor, such as adjust padding, refine UI style. | Implementation of improvement that does not provide new features and is also not a bug fix nor refactor, such as adjust padding, refine UI style. |
| #doc          | Documentation                                                                                                                           | Documentation                                                                                                                                     |
| #question     | Troubleshooting: Installation, Running locally, Ask how to do something. Can be changed to #bug later.                                | N/A                                                                                                                                               |
| #SIP          | Superset Improvement Proposal                                                                                                           | N/A                                                                                                                                               |
| #ASF          | Tasks related to Apache Software Foundation policy                                                                                      | Tasks related to Apache Software Foundation policy                                                                                                |
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Then add other types of labels as appropriate.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Descriptive labels (a.k.a. dot labels): These labels that begin with . describe the details of the issue/PR, such as .ui, .js, .install, .backend, etc. Each issue/PR can have zero or more dot labels.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Need labels: These labels have pattern need:xxx, which describe the work required to progress, such as need:rebase, need:update, need:screenshot.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Risk labels: These labels have pattern risk:xxx, which describe the potential risk on adopting the work, such as risk:db-migration. The intention was to better understand the impact and create awareness for PRs that need more rigorous testing.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Status labels: These labels describe the status (abandoned, wontfix, cant-reproduce, etc.) Issue/PRs that are rejected or closed without completion should have one or more status labels.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Version labels: These have the pattern vx.x such as v0.28. Version labels on issues describe the version the bug was reported on. Version labels on PR describe the first release that will include the PR.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Committers may also update title to reflect the issue/PR content if the author-provided title is not descriptive enough.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: If the PR passes CI tests and does not have any need: labels, it is ready for review, add label review and/or design-review.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: If an issue/PR has been inactive for >=30 days, it will be closed. If it does not have any status label, add inactive.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Revert Guidelines
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Reverting changes that are causing issues in the master branch is a normal and expected part of the development process. In an open source community, the ramifications of a change cannot always be fully understood. With that in mind, here are some considerations to keep in mind when considering a revert:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Availability of the PR author: If the original PR author or the engineer who merged the code is highly available and can provide a fix in a reasonable timeframe, this would counter-indicate reverting.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Severity of the issue: How severe is the problem on master? Is it keeping the project from moving forward? Is there user impact? What percentage of users will experience a problem?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Size of the change being reverted: Reverting a single small PR is a much lower-risk proposition than reverting a massive, multi-PR change.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Age of the change being reverted: Reverting a recently-merged PR will be more acceptable than reverting an older PR. A bug discovered in an older PR is unlikely to be causing widespread serious issues.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Risk inherent in reverting: Will the reversion break critical functionality? Is the medicine more dangerous than the disease?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Difficulty of crafting a fix: In the case of issues with a clear solution, it may be preferable to implement and merge a fix rather than a revert.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Should you decide that reverting is desirable, it is the responsibility of the Contributor performing the revert to:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Contact the interested parties: The PR's author and the engineer who merged the work should both be contacted and informed of the revert.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Provide concise reproduction steps: Ensure that the issue can be clearly understood and duplicated by the original author of the PR.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Put the revert through code review: The revert must be approved by another committer.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Setup Local Environment for Development
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: First, fork the repository on GitHub, then clone it. You can clone the main repository directly, but you won't be able to send pull requests.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
git clone git@github.com:your-username/incubator-superset.git
cd incubator-superset
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Documentation
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: The latest documentation and tutorial are available at https://superset.incubator.apache.org/.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Contributing to the official documentation is relatively easy, once you've setup
your environment and done an edit end-to-end. The docs can be found in the
docs/ subdirectory of the repository, and are written in the
reStructuredText format (.rst).
If you've written Markdown before, you'll find the reStructuredText format familiar.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Superset uses Sphinx to convert the rst files
in docs/ to the final HTML output users see.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Finally, to make changes to the rst files and build the docs using Sphinx,
you'll need to install a handful of dependencies from the repo you cloned:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: pip install -r requirements/documentation.txt
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
To get the feel for how to edit and build the docs, let's edit a file, build
the docs and see our changes in action. First, you'll want to
create a new branch
to work on your changes:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: git checkout -b changes-to-docs
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Now, go ahead and edit one of the files under docs/, say docs/tutorial.rst - change
it however you want. Check out the
ReStructuredText Primer
for a reference on the formatting of the rst files.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Once you've made your changes, run this command to convert the docs into HTML:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: make html
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
You'll see a lot of output as Sphinx handles the conversion. After it's done, the
HTML Sphinx generated should be in docs/_build/html. Navigate there
and start a simple web server so we can check out the docs in a browser:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
cd docs/_build/html
python -m http.server # Python2 users should use SimpleHTTPServer
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
This will start a small Python web server listening on port 8000. Point your
browser to http://localhost:8000, find the file
you edited earlier, and check out your changes!
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
If you've made a change you'd like to contribute to the actual docs, just commit
your code, push your new branch to Github:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
git add docs/tutorial.rst
git commit -m 'Awesome new change to tutorial'
git push origin changes-to-docs
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Then, open a pull request.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Images
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
If you're adding new images to the documentation, you'll notice that the images
referenced in the rst, e.g.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: .. image:: _static/images/tutorial/tutorial_01_sources_database.png
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
aren't actually stored in that directory. Instead, you should add and commit
images (and any other static assets) to the superset-frontend/images directory.
When the docs are deployed to https://superset.incubator.apache.org/, images
are copied from there to the _static/images directory, just like they're referenced
in the docs.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: For example, the image referenced above actually lives in superset-frontend/images/tutorial. Since the image is moved during the documentation build process, the docs reference the image in _static/images/tutorial instead.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: API documentation
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Generate the API documentation with:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
pip install -r requirements/documentation.txt
python setup.py build_sphinx
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Flask server
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: OS Dependencies
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Make sure your machine meets the OS dependencies before following these steps.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Developers should use a virtualenv.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: pip install virtualenv
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Then proceed with:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
# Create a virtual environemnt and activate it (recommended)
virtualenv -p python3 venv # setup a python3.6 virtualenv
source venv/bin/activate
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
# Install external dependencies
pip install -r requirements/local.txt
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
# Install Superset in editable (development) mode
pip install -e .
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
# Create an admin user in your metadata database
superset fab create-admin
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
# Initialize the database
superset db upgrade
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
# Create default roles and permissions
superset init
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
# Load some data to play with
superset load_examples
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
# Start the Flask dev web server from inside your virtualenv.
# Note that your page may not have css at this point.
# See instructions below how to build the front-end assets.
FLASK_ENV=development superset run -p 8088 --with-threads --reload --debugger
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
Note: the FLASK_APP env var should not need to be set, as it's currently controlled
via .flaskenv, however if needed, it should be set to superset.app:create_app()
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
If you have made changes to the FAB-managed templates, which are not built the same way as the newer, React-powered front-end assets, you need to start the app without the --with-threads argument like so:
FLASK_ENV=development superset run -p 8088 --reload --debugger
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Logging to the browser console
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: This feature is only available on Python 3. When debugging your application, you can have the server logs sent directly to the browser console using the ConsoleLog package. You need to mutate the app, by adding the following to your config.py or superset_config.py:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: from console_log import ConsoleLog
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
def FLASK_APP_MUTATOR(app):
app.wsgi_app = ConsoleLog(app.wsgi_app, app.logger)
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Then make sure you run your WSGI server using the right worker type:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: FLASK_ENV=development gunicorn "superset.app:create_app()" -k "geventwebsocket.gunicorn.workers.GeventWebSocketWorker" -b 127.0.0.1:8088 --reload
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: You can log anything to the browser console, including objects:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
from superset import app
app.logger.error('An exception occurred!')
app.logger.info(form_data)
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Frontend Assets
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Frontend assets (TypeScript, JavaScript, CSS, and images) must be compiled in order to properly display the web UI. The superset-frontend directory contains all NPM-managed front end assets. Note that there are additional frontend assets bundled with Flask-Appbuilder (e.g. jQuery and bootstrap); these are not managed by NPM, and may be phased out in the future.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: nvm and node
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: First, be sure you are using recent versions of NodeJS and npm. Using nvm to manage them is recommended. Check the docs at the link to be sure, but at the time of writing the following would install nvm and node:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
curl -o- https://raw.githubusercontent.com/creationix/nvm/v0.34.0/install.sh | bash
nvm install node
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Prerequisite
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Installing Dependencies
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Install third-party dependencies listed in package.json:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
# From the root of the repository
cd superset-frontend
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
# Install dependencies from `package-lock.json`
npm ci
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Building
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: You can run the Webpack dev server (in a separate terminal from Flask), which runs on port 9000 and proxies non-asset requests to the Flask server on port 8088. After pointing your browser to http://localhost:9000, updates to asset sources will be reflected in-browser without a refresh.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
# Run the dev server
npm run dev-server
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
# Run the dev server on a non-default port
npm run dev-server -- --devserverPort=9001
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
# Run the dev server proxying to a Flask server on a non-default port
npm run dev-server -- --supersetPort=8081
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
# Or proxy it to a remote backend so you can test frontend changes without
# starting the backend locally
npm run dev-server -- --superset=https://superset-dev.example.com
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Alternatively you can use one of the following commands.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
# Start a watcher that recompiles your assets as you modify them (but have to manually reload your browser to see changes.)
npm run dev
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
# Compile the TypeScript/JavaScript and CSS in production/optimized mode for official releases
npm run prod
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: If you run this service from somewhere other than your local machine, you may need to add hostname value to webpack.config.js at .devServer.public specifying the endpoint at which you will access the app. For example: myhost:9001. For convenience you may want to install webpack, webpack-cli and webpack-dev-server globally so that you can run them directly:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: npm install --global webpack webpack-cli webpack-dev-server
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Docker (docker-compose)
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: See docs here
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Updating NPM packages
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
Use npm in the prescribed way, making sure that
superset-frontend/package-lock.json is updated according to npm-prescribed
best practices.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Feature flags
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Superset supports a server-wide feature flag system, which eases the incremental development of features. To add a new feature flag, simply modify superset_config.py with something like the following:
Label: BW – Build local workspace
BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: If you want to use the same flag in the client code, also add it to the FeatureFlag TypeScript enum in superset-frontend/src/featureFlags.ts. For example,
Label: BW – Build local workspace
BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
superset/config.py contains DEFAULT_FEATURE_FLAGS which will be overwritten by
those specified under FEATURE_FLAGS in superset_config.py. For example, DEFAULT_FEATURE_FLAGS = { 'FOO': True, 'BAR': False } in superset/config.py and FEATURE_FLAGS = { 'BAR': True, 'BAZ': True } in superset_config.py will result
in combined feature flags of { 'FOO': True, 'BAR': True, 'BAZ': True }.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Git Hooks
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Superset uses Git pre-commit hooks courtesy of pre-commit. To install run the following:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
pip3 install -r requirements/integration.txt
pre-commit install
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Linting
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Lint the project with:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
# for python
tox -e flake8
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
# for frontend
cd superset-frontend
npm ci
npm run lint
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
The Python code is auto-formatted using Black which
is configured as a pre-commit hook. There are also numerous editor integrations.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Conventions
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Python
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Parameters in the config.py (which are accessible via the Flask app.config dictionary) are assummed to always be defined and thus should be accessed directly via,
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: blueprints = app.config["BLUEPRINTS"]
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: rather than,
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: blueprints = app.config.get("BLUEPRINTS")
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: or similar as the later will cause typing issues. The former is of type List[Callable] whereas the later is of type Optional[List[Callable]].
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Typing
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Python
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
To ensure clarity, consistency, all readability, all new functions should use
type hints and include a
docstring using Sphinx documentation.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
Note per PEP-484 no
syntax for listing explicitly raised exceptions is proposed and thus the
recommendation is to put this information in a docstring, i.e.,
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
import math
from typing import Union
Label: DC – Deal with the code
DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
:param x: A number
:returns: The square root of the given number
:raises ValueError: If the number is negative
"""
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: return math.sqrt(x)
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: TypeScript
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: TypeScript is fully supported and is the recommended language for writing all new frontend components. When modifying existing functions/components, migrating to TypeScript is appreciated, but not required. Examples of migrating functions/components to TypeScript can be found in #9162 and #9180.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Testing
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Python Testing
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
All python tests are carried out in tox
a standardized testing framework.
All python tests can be run with any of the tox environments, via,
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: tox -e <environment>
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: For example,
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: tox -e py36
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Alternatively, you can run all tests in a single file via,
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: tox -e <environment> -- tests/test_file.py
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: or for a specific test via,
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: tox -e <environment> -- tests/test_file.py:TestClassName.test_method_name
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Note that the test environment uses a temporary directory for defining the
SQLite databases which will be cleared each time before the group of test
commands are invoked.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Frontend Testing
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: We use Jest and Enzyme to test TypeScript/JavaScript. Tests can be run with:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
cd superset-frontend
npm run test
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Integration Testing
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: We use Cypress for integration tests. Tests can be run by tox -e cypress. To open Cypress and explore tests first setup and run test server:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
export SUPERSET_CONFIG=tests.superset_test_config
superset db upgrade
superset init
superset load_test_users
superset load_examples
superset run --port 8081
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Run Cypress tests:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
cd superset-frontend
npm run build
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
cd cypress-base
npm install
npm run cypress run
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
# run tests from a specific file
npm run cypress run -- --spec cypress/integration/explore/link.test.js
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
# run specific file with video capture
npm run cypress run -- --spec cypress/integration/dashboard/index.test.js --config video=true
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
# to open the cypress ui
npm run cypress open
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: See superset-frontend/cypress_build.sh.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Storybook
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Superset includes a Storybook to preview the layout/styling of various Superset components, and variations thereof. To open and view the Storybook:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
cd superset-frontend
npm run storybool
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: When contributing new React components to Superset, please try to add a Story alongside the component's jsx/tsx file.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Translating
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
We use Babel to translate Superset.
In Python files, we import the magic _ function using:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: from flask_babel import lazy_gettext as _
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
then wrap our translatable strings with it, e.g. _('Translate me').
During extraction, string literals passed to _ will be added to the
generated .po file for each language for later translation.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
At runtime, the _ function will return the translation of the given
string for the current language, or the given string itself
if no translation is available.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
In TypeScript/JavaScript, the technique is similar:
we import t (simple translation), tn (translation containing a number).
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: import { t, tn } from '@superset-ui/translation';
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Enabling language selection
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Add the LANGUAGES variable to your superset_config.py. Having more than one
option inside will add a language selection dropdown to the UI on the right side
of the navigation bar.
Label: No categories identified.
No categories identified.

Paragraph: Extracting new strings for translation
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: flask fab babel-extract --target superset/translations --output superset/translations/messages.pot --config superset/translations/babel.cfg -k _ -k __ -k t -k tn -k tct
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
You can then translate the strings gathered in files located under
superset/translation, where there's one per language. You can use Poedit
to translate the po file more conveniently.
There are some tutorials in the wiki.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: For the translations to take effect:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
# In the case of JS translation, we need to convert the PO file into a JSON file, and we need the global download of the npm package po2json.
npm install -g po2json
flask fab babel-compile --target superset/translations
# Convert the en PO file into a JSON file
po2json -d superset -f jed1.x superset/translations/en/LC_MESSAGES/messages.po superset/translations/en/LC_MESSAGES/messages.json
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
If you get errors running po2json, you might be running the Ubuntu package with the same
name, rather than the NodeJS package (they have a different format for the arguments). If
there is a conflict, you may need to update your PATH environment variable or fully qualify
the executable path (e.g. /usr/local/bin/po2json instead of po2json).
If you get a lot of [null,***] in messages.json, just delete all the null,.
For example, "year":["?"] is correct while "year":[null,"?"]is incorrect.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Creating a new language dictionary
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
To create a dictionary for a new language, run the following, where LANGUAGE_CODE is replaced with
the language code for your target language, e.g. es (see Flask AppBuilder i18n documentation for more details):
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
pip install -r superset/translations/requirements.txt
pybabel init -i superset/translations/messages.pot -d superset/translations -l LANGUAGE_CODE
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Then, extract strings for the new language.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Tips
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Adding a new datasource
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
1.  Create Models and Views for the datasource, add them under superset folder, like a new my_models.py
with models for cluster, datasources, columns and metrics and my_views.py with clustermodelview
and datasourcemodelview.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 2.  Create DB migration files for the new models
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 3.  Specify this variable to add the datasource model and from which module it is from in config.py:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: For example:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: ADDITIONAL_MODULE_DS_MAP = {'superset.my_models': ['MyDatasource', 'MyOtherDatasource']}
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: This means it'll register MyDatasource and MyOtherDatasource in superset.my_models module in the source registry.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Improving visualizations
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: To edit the frontend code for visualizations, you will have to check out a copy of apache-superset/superset-ui:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
git clone https://github.com/apache-superset/superset-ui.git
cd superset-ui
yarn
yarn build
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Then use npm link to create symlinks of the plugins/superset-ui packages you want to edit in superset-frontend/node_modules:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
cd incubator-superset/superset-frontend
npm link ../../superset-ui/plugins/[PLUGIN NAME]
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
# Or to link all core superset-ui and plugin packages:
# npm link ../../superset-ui/{packages,plugins}/*
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
# Start developing
npm run dev-server
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: When superset-ui packages are linked with npm link, the dev server will automatically load a package's source code from its /src directory, instead of the built modules in lib/ or esm/.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Note that every time you do npm install, you will lose the symlink(s) and may have to run npm link again.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Visualization Plugins
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
The topic of authoring new plugins, whether you'd like to contribute
it back or not has been well documented in the
So, You Want to Build a Superset Viz Plugin... blog post
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: To contribute a plugin to Superset-UI, your plugin must meet the following criteria:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - The plugin should be applicable to the community at large, not a particularly specialized use case
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - The plugin should be written with TypeScript
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - The plugin should contain sufficient unit/e2e tests
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - The plugin should use appropriate namespacing, e.g. a folder name of plugin-chart-whatever and a package name of @superset-ui/plugin-chart-whatever
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - The plugin should use them variables via Emotion, as passed in by the ThemeProvider
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - The plugin should provide adequate error handling (no data returned, malformatted data, invalid controls, etc.)
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - The plugin should contain documentation in the form of a populated README.md file
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - The plugin should have a meaningful and unique icon
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Above all else, the plugin should come with a commitment to maintenance from the original author(s)
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Submissions will be considered for submission (or removal) on a case-by-case basis.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Adding a DB migration
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 1.  Alter the model you want to change. This example will add a Column Annotations model.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Example commit
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 2.  Generate the migration file
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: superset db migrate -m 'add_metadata_column_to_annotation_model.py'
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: This will generate a file in migrations/version/{SHA}_this_will_be_in_the_migration_filename.py.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Example commit
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 3.  Upgrade the DB
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: superset db upgrade
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: The output should look like this:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
INFO  [alembic.runtime.migration] Context impl SQLiteImpl.
INFO  [alembic.runtime.migration] Will assume transactional DDL.
INFO  [alembic.runtime.migration] Running upgrade 1a1d627ebd8e -> 40a0a483dd12, add_metadata_column_to_annotation_model.py
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 4.  Add column to view
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Since there is a new column, we need to add it to the AppBuilder Model view.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Example commit
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 5.  Test the migration's down method
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: superset db downgrade
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: The output should look like this:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
INFO  [alembic.runtime.migration] Context impl SQLiteImpl.
INFO  [alembic.runtime.migration] Will assume transactional DDL.
INFO  [alembic.runtime.migration] Running downgrade 40a0a483dd12 -> 1a1d627ebd8e, add_metadata_column_to_annotation_model.py
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Merging DB migrations
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: When two DB migrations collide, you'll get an error message like this one:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
alembic.util.exc.CommandError: Multiple head revisions are present for
given argument 'head'; please specify a specific target
revision, '<branchname>@head' to narrow to a specific head,
or 'heads' for all heads`
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: To fix it:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 1.  Get the migration heads
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: superset db heads
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: This should list two or more migration hashes.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 2.  Create a new merge migration
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: superset db merge {HASH1} {HASH2}
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 3.  Upgrade the DB to the new checkpoint
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: superset db upgrade
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: SQL Lab Async
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
It's possible to configure a local database to operate in async mode,
to work on async related features.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: To do this, you'll need to:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- Add an additional database entry. We recommend you copy the connection
string from the database labeled main, and then enable SQL Lab and the
features you want to use. Don't forget to check the Async box
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- Configure a results backend, here's a local FileSystemCache example,
not recommended for production,
but perfect for testing (stores cache in /tmp)
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
from cachelib.file import FileSystemCache
RESULTS_BACKEND = FileSystemCache('/tmp/sqllab')
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Start up a celery worker
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: celery worker --app=superset.tasks.celery_app:app -Ofair
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Note that:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- for changes that affect the worker logic, you'll have to
restart the celery worker process for the changes to be reflected.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- The message queue used is a sqlite database using the SQLAlchemy
experimental broker. Ok for testing, but not recommended in production
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- In some cases, you may want to create a context that is more aligned
to your production environment, and use the similar broker as well as
results backend configuration
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Chart Parameters
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Chart parameters are stored as a JSON encoded string the slices.params column and are often referenced throughout the code as form-data. Currently the form-data is neither versioned nor typed as thus is somewhat free-formed. Note in the future there may be merit in using something like JSON Schema to both annotate and validate the JSON object in addition to using a Mypy TypedDict (introduced in Python 3.8) for typing the form-data in the backend. This section serves as a potential primer for that work.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: The following tables provide a non-exhausive list of the various fields which can be present in the JSON object grouped by the Explorer pane sections. These values were obtained by extracting the distinct fields from a legacy deployment consisting of tens of thousands of charts and thus some fields may be missing whilst others may be deprecated.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Note not all fields are correctly catagorized. The fields vary based on visualization type and may apprear in different sections depending on the type. Verified deprecated columns may indicate a missing migration and/or prior migrations which were unsucessful and thus future work may be required to clean up the form-data.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Datasource & Chart Type
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
| Field             | Type     | Notes                               |
| ----------------- | -------- | ----------------------------------- |
| database_name   | string | Deprecated?                       |
| datasource      | string | <datasouce_id>__<datasource_type> |
| datasource_id   | string | Deprecated? See datasource      |
| datasource_name | string | Deprecated?                       |
| datasource_type | string | Deprecated? See datasource      |
| viz_type        | string | The Visualization Type widget   |
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Time
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
| Field                  | Type            | Notes                                 |
| ---------------------- | --------------- | ------------------------------------- |
| druid_time_origin    | string        | The Druid Origin widget           |
| granularity          | string        | The Druid Time Granularity widget |
| granularity_sqla     | string        | The SQLA Time Column widget       |
| time_grain_sqla      | string        | The SQLA Time Grain widget        |
| time_range           | string        | The Time range widget             |
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: GROUP BY
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
| Field                     | Type            | Notes                       |
| ------------------------- | --------------- | --------------------------- |
| metrics                 | array(string) | See Query section           |
| order_asc               | -               | See Query section           |
| row_limit               | -               | See Query section           |
| timeseries_limit_metric | -               | See Query section           |
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: NOT GROUPED BY
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
| Field           | Type            | Notes                   |
| --------------- | --------------- | ----------------------- |
| order_by_cols | array(string) | The Ordering widget |
| row_limit     | -               | See Query section       |
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Y Axis 1
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
| Field           | Type | Notes                                              |
| --------------- | ---- | -------------------------------------------------- |
| metric        | -    | The Left Axis Metric widget. See Query section |
| y_axis_format | -    | See Y Axis section                                 |
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Y Axis 2
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Query
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
| Field                                                                                                  | Type                                              | Notes                                             |
| ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ | ------------------------------------------------- | ------------------------------------------------- |
| adhoc_filters                                                                                        | array(object)                                   | The Filters widget                            |
| columns                                                                                              | array(string)                                   | The Breakdowns widget                         |
| groupby                                                                                              | array(string)                                   | The Group by or Series widget             |
| limit                                                                                                | number                                          | The Series Limit widget                       |
| metricmetric_2metricspercent_merticssecondary_metricsizexy | string,object,array(string),array(object) | The metric(s) depending on the visualization type |
| order_asc                                                                                            | boolean                                         | The Sort Descending widget                    |
| row_limit                                                                                            | number                                          | The Row limit widget                          |
| timeseries_limit_metric                                                                              | object                                          | The Sort By widget                            |
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: The metric (or equivalent) and timeseries_limit_metric fields are all composed of either metric names or the JSON representation of the AdhocMetric TypeScript type. The adhoc_filters is composed of the JSON represent of the AdhocFilter TypeScript type (which can comprise of columns or metrics depending on whether it is a WHERE or HAVING clause). The all_columns, all_columns_x, columns, groupby, and order_by_cols fields all represent column names.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Chart Options
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
| Field                 | Type      | Notes                                            |
| --------------------- | --------- | ------------------------------------------------ |
| color_picker        | object  | The Fixed Color widget                       |
| label_colors        | object  | The Color Scheme widget                      |
| normalized          | boolean | The Normalized widget                        |
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Y Axis

Paragraph: Contribute code
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Before Coding
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Use master branch
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: The development of Weex is on master branch, you should write your code based on master branch.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Check License
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Weex adopts Apache License 2.0 as its open source license. Make sure your potential contribution obeys the requirement of Apache License 2.0.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Bug or Feature ?
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - If you are going to fix a bug of Weex, check whether it already exists in Github Issue. If it exists, make sure to write down the link of the corresponding Github issue in the PR you are going to create.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - If you are going to add a feature for weex, reference the following recommend procedure:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 1.  Writing a email to mailing list to talk about what you'd like to do.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 2.  Write the corresponding document
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Coding
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 1.  Fork the Github repository at https://github.com/apache/incubator-weex.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 2.  Clone the forked repository and create a new branch from master to push your commits to.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 3.  Develop your feature or bug fix in your new branch. Make sure your code meets the style guidelines.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 4.  Add the License below to the top of any new file(s) you've added.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Code Style Guidelines
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Objective-C
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Tabs should be used for indentation. Please do not use spaces.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - * operator goes with the variable name (e.g. Type *variable;)
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - For function definitions, place each brace on its own line.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - For all the other braces, place the open brace on the line preceding the code block and place the close brace on its own line.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Use #pragma marks to categorize methods into functional groupings and protocol implementations
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Follow other guidelines on GitHub Objective-C Style Guide
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Java & Android
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Use Google Java Style as basic guidelines of java code.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Follow AOSP Code Style for rest of android related code style.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: C & C++
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Use Google C++ Style   as basic guidelines of C++ code
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Weex defines a subset of the Google C++ development specification that covers some of the major C++ scenario usage specifications.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Publish your Change
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Open a pull request against the master branch of apache/incubator-weex. Make sure following guidelines are considered when creating a pull request.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 1.  One PR should solve only one problem.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 2.  The PR title should be the form of [COMPONENT] Summary:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - COMPONENT is one of the mentioned PR categories (android, iOS, JsFm, web, test, etc..).
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Summary should be a brief description of your change within one sentence.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 3.  Content description of PR
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - If the PR is about fixing a bug excluding crash, a demo is necessary in code's description.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - If the PR is about adding a new feature, another PR for documentation is necessary in codes' PR description.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Optional If the PR fixes an existing Github issue, you may add the link to the corresponding issue in the PR.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: There will be a static check program when you submit a PR,and the following rules will be checked:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 1.  Check if your PR is submitted to master branch, if not, you will failed.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 2.  Check if your PR is bounded with a milestone, if not, you will receive a warning message.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 3.  Check if your PR description contains keywords Documentation and it's corresponding http links. if not, you will receive a warning message.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 4.  Check if your PR description contains keywords Demo and it's corresponding http links. if not, you will receive a warning message.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 5.  Check if your PR modify the changelog.md, if not,you will receive a warning message.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Tip:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Reviewing PR may take a great deal of time, please be patient. If your PR doesn't get response over 96 hours, you might send an email to mailing list to ask the progress.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Development setup
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Gradle
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: You might find useful Gradle commands in gradle.md
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: IntelliJ IDEA
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: You require IntelliJ 2018.3.1 or newer.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 1.  Open the build.gradle.kts file with IntelliJ IDEA and choose Open as Project
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 2.  Make sure Create separate module per source set is selected
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 3.  Make sure Use default gradle wrapper is selected
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 4.  In the File already exists dialogue, choose Yes to overwrite
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 5.  In the Open Project dialogue, choose Delete Existing Project and Import
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Eclipse
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Eclipse can import Gradle projects automatically via Import...->Gradle project wizard.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Optionally you can generate Eclipse project by running
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: ./gradlew eclipse
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: The steps to import the sources (based on Eclipse 2019-06) into Eclipse are as follows:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 1.  Install Eclipse IDE for Java Developers
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 2.  Install the Groovy Eclipse plugin and select Groovy Compiler 2.4 (some tests are written in Groovy)
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 3.  Install Kotlin for Eclipse plugin (builds scripts are written in Kotlin)
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 4.  Make sure you have a Java 8 compatible JDK configured in your workspace
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 5.  Open File->Import...
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 6.  Select Existing Gradle Project and click Next
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 7.  Read How to experience the best Gradle integration and click Next
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 8.  Then you might just click Finish
Label: BW – Build local workspace

The best way to make sure your issue or feature is addressed is to submit a patch.
We accept patches through:

Paragraph: - Your coding style is similar to ours.

Paragraph: - Your patch is 100% tested. JUnit are welcome.

We do love to enhance Apache JMeter with you to become more powerful!
The best way to workout your idea is to discuss it first at our dev mailing list:

Please, if you can, don't just throw us the code of a new feature; lets figure first together

Paragraph: :closed_book: Want to write docs
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Documentation is very valuable to us.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: It is located in xdocs folder in XML format.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: You can contribute as you would for code through patch or PR (pull request).
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Lucene.NET Contributor's Guide
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: You have found a bug or you have an idea for a cool new enhancement? Contributing code is a great way to give something back to the open source community. Before you dig right into the code there are a few guidelines that we need contributors to follow so that we can have a chance of keeping on top of things.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Getting Started
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Read Open Source Contribution Etiquette and Don't "Push" Your Pull Requests.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Make sure you have a GitHub account. NOTE: Although this is a mirror of our Git repository, pull requests are accepted through GitHub.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - If you are thinking of adding a feature, we would appreciate you opening a discussion on our developer mailing list before you start writing. It could save both you and our team quite a bit of work if the code doesn't have to be rewritten to fit in with our overall objectives.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Submit a new issue on GitHub, assuming one doesn't exist already.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - If reporting a bug, clearly describe the issue including steps to reproduce, observed behavior, and expected behavior.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - If reporting a bug, provide source code that we can run without any alteration demonstrating the issue. Issues submitted with runnable code will be given a higher priority than those submitted without.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - If you will be submitting a pull request, fork the repository on GitHub.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Create a new branch with a descriptive name (tracking master) and submit a Pull Request.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: NOTE: In the past, the Lucene.NET project used the JIRA issue tracker, which has now been deprecated. However, we are keeping it active for tracking legacy issues. Please submit any new issues to GitHub.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Up For Grabs
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: There are several Open Issues on GitHub that are marked up-for-grabs that we could use help with.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: Other Ways To Help
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: - Be a power beta tester. Make it your mission to track down bugs and report them to us on GitHub.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Optimizing code. During porting we have ended up with some code that is less than optimal. We could use a hand getting everything up to speed (pun intended).
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: - Helping update the API, or at least just providing feedback on which API changes are affecting usability. There are several things on our radar, like integrating something like Lucene.Net.Linq directly into our project, converting the remaining public-facing iterator classes into IEnumerator<T> so they can be used with foreach loops, adding extension methods to remove the need for casting, etc.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: - Making demos and tutorials, blogging about Lucene.Net, etc. (and providing feedback on how we can make the API better!). If you write a helpful Lucene.Net post on your blog, be sure to let us know so we can link to it.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: - Helping out with documentation. We are still trying to make the API docs easily navigable (see #206), and there are many files that are not formatted correctly (links not appearing, tables not very readable, etc). Also, we need help getting all of the Java-related documentation converted to use .NET methodologies.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: - Fixing TODOs. There are several TODOs throughout the code that need to be reviewed and action taken, if necessary. Search for LUCENENET TODO|LUCENE TO-DO using the regular expression option in Visual Studio to find them. Do note there are a lot of TODOs left over from Java Lucene that are safe to ignore.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: - Reviewing code. Pick a random section, review line by line, comparing the code against the original Lucene 4.8.0 code. Many of the bugs have been found this way, as the tests are not showing them. Let us know if you find anything suspicious on the dev mailing list or submit a pull request with a fix.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: - Creating projects to make Lucene.Net easier to use with various .NET frameworks (ASP.NET MVC, WebApi, AspNetCore, WPF, EntityFramework, etc). In general, we would like common tasks as easy as possible to integrate into applications build on these frameworks without everyone having to write the same boilerplate code.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: - Building automation tools to eliminate some of the manual work of managing the project, updating information on various web pages, creating tools to make porting/upgrading more automated, etc.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: Or, if none of that interests you, join our dev mailing list and ask!
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: Thank You For Your Help!
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Again, thank you very much for your contribution. May the fork be with you!
Label: No categories identified.
