Paragraph: Contributing to Apache Shiro
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Summary
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: This document covers how to contribute to the Apache Shiro project. These instructions assume you have a GitHub.com account, so if you don't have one you will have to create one. Your proposed code changes will be published to your own fork of the Apache Shiro project and you will submit a Pull Request for your changes to be added.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Lets get started!!!
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Fork the code
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: In your browser, navigate to: https://github.com/apache/shiro
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Fork the repository by clicking on the 'Fork' button on the top right hand side.  The fork will happen and you will be taken to your own fork of the repository.  Copy the Git repository URL by clicking on the clipboard next to the URL on the right hand side of the page under 'HTTPS clone URL'.  You will paste this URL when doing the following git clone command.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: On your computer, follow these steps to setup a local repository for working on Apache Shiro:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
$ git clone https://github.com/YOUR_ACCOUNT/shiro.git
$ cd shiro
$ git remote add upstream https://github.com/apache/shiro.git
$ git checkout master
$ git fetch upstream
$ git rebase upstream/master
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Making changes
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: It is important that you create a new branch to make changes on and that you do not change the master branch (other than to rebase in changes from upstream/master).  In this example I will assume you will be making your changes to a branch called feature_x.  This feature_x branch will be created on your local repository and will be pushed to your forked repository on GitHub.  Once this branch is on your fork you will create a Pull Request for the changes to be added to the Apache Shiro project.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: It is best practice to create a new branch each time you want to contribute to the project and only track the changes for that pull request in this branch.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
$ git checkout -b feature_x
(make your changes)
$ git status
$ git add .
$ git commit -a -m "descriptive commit message for your changes"
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: The -b specifies that you want to create a new branch called feature_x.  You only specify -b the first time you checkout because you are creating a new branch.  Once the feature_x branch exists, you can later switch to it with only git checkout feature_x.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Rebase feature_x to include updates from upstream/master
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: It is important that you maintain an up-to-date master branch in your local repository.  This is done by rebasing in the code changes from upstream/master (the official Apache Shiro project repository) into your local repository.  You will want to do this before you start working on a feature as well as right before you submit your changes as a pull request.  I recommend you do this process periodically while you work to make sure you are working off the most recent project code.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: This process will do the following:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 1.  Checkout your local master branch
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 2.  Synchronize your local master branch with the upstream/master so you have all the latest changes from the project
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 3.  Rebase the latest project code into your feature_x branch so it is up-to-date with the upstream code
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
$ git checkout master
$ git fetch upstream
$ git rebase upstream/master
$ git checkout feature_x
$ git rebase master
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Now your feature_x branch is up-to-date with all the code in upstream/master.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Make a GitHub Pull Request to contribute your changes
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: When you are happy with your changes and you are ready to contribute them, you will create a Pull Request on GitHub to do so.  This is done by pushing your local changes to your forked repository (default remote name is origin) and then initiating a pull request on GitHub.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: IMPORTANT: Make sure you have rebased your feature_x branch to include the latest code from upstream/master before you do this.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
$ git push origin master
$ git push origin feature_x
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Now that the feature_x branch has been pushed to your GitHub repository, you can initiate the pull request.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: To initiate the pull request, do the following:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 1.  In your browser, navigate to your forked repository: https://github.com/YOUR_ACCOUNT/shiro
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 2.  Click the new button called 'Compare & pull request' that showed up just above the main area in your forked repository
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 3.  Validate the pull request will be into the upstream master and will be from your feature_x branch
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 4.  Enter a detailed description of the work you have done and then click 'Send pull request'
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: If you are requested to make modifications to your proposed changes, make the changes locally on your feature_x branch, re-push the feature_x branch to your fork.  The existing pull request should automatically pick up the change and update accordingly.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Cleaning up after a successful pull request
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Once the feature_x branch has been committed into the upstream/master branch, your local feature_x branch and the origin/feature_x branch are no longer needed.  If you want to make additional changes, restart the process with a new branch.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: IMPORTANT: Make sure that your changes are in upstream/master before you delete your feature_x and origin/feature_x branches!
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: You can delete these deprecated branches with the following:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
$ git checkout master
$ git branch -D feature_x
$ git push origin :feature_x
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: How to Contribute
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Thank you for your interest in contributing to the Apache Thrift project!  Information on why and how to contribute is available on the Apache Software Foundation (ASF) web site. In particular, we recommend the following to become acquainted with Apache Contributions:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Contributors Tech Guide
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Get involved!
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Legal aspects on Submission of Contributions (Patches)
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: GitHub pull requests
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
This is the preferred method of submitting changes.  When you submit a pull request through github,
it activates the continuous integration (CI) build systems at Appveyor and Travis to build your changesxi
on a variety of Linux and Windows configurations and run all the test suites.  Follow these requirements
for a successful pull request:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 1.  All significant changes require an Apache Jira THRIFT Issue ticket.  Trivial changes such as fixing a typo or a compiler warning do not.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 2.  All pull requests should contain a single commit per issue, or we will ask you to squash it.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 3.  The pull request title must begin with the Jira THRIFT ticket identifier if it has an associated ticket, for example:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: THRIFT-9999: an example pull request title
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 4.  Commit messages must follow this pattern for code changes (deviations will not be merged):
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
THRIFT-9999: [summary of fix, one line if possible]
Client: [language(s) affected, comma separated, for example: "cpp,erl,perl"]
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Instructions:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 1.  Create a fork in your GitHub account of http://github.com/apache/thrift
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 2.  Clone the fork to your development system.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 3.  Create a branch for your changes (best practice is issue as branch name, e.g. THRIFT-9999).
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 4.  Modify the source to include the improvement/bugfix, and:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Remember to provide tests for all submitted changes!
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Use test-driven development (TDD): add a test that will isolate the bug before applying the change that fixes it.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Verify that you follow Thrift Coding Standards (you can run 'make style', which ensures proper format for some languages).
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - [optional] Verify that your change works on other platforms by adding a GitHub service hook to Travis CI and AppVeyor.  You can use this technique to run the Thrift CI jobs in your account to check your changes before they are made public.  Every GitHub pull request into Thrift will run the full CI build and test suite on your changes.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 5.  Squash your changes to a single commit.  This maintains clean change history.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 6.  Commit and push changes to your branch (please use issue name and description as commit title, e.g. "THRIFT-9999: make it perfect"), with the affected languages on the next line of the description.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 7.  Use GitHub to create a pull request going from your branch to apache:master.  Ensure that the Jira ticket number is at the beginning of the title of your pull request, same as the commit title.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 8.  Wait for other contributors or committers to review your new addition, and for a CI build to complete.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 9.  Wait for a committer to commit your patch.  You can nudge the committers if necessary by sending a message to the Apache Thrift mailing list.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: If you want to build the project locally
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: For Windows systems, see our detailed instructions on the CMake README.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: For Windows Native C++ builds, see our detailed instructions on the WinCPP README.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: For unix systems, see our detailed instructions on the Docker README.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: If you want to review open issues...
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 1.  Review the GitHub Pull Request Backlog.  Code reviews are open to all.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 2.  Review the Jira issue tracker.  You can search for tickets relating to languages you are interested in or currently using with thrift, for example a Jira search (Issues -> Search For Issues) query of project = THRIFT AND component in ("Erlang - Library") and status not in (resolved, closed) will locate all the open Erlang Library issues.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: If you discovered a defect...
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 1.  Check to see if the issue is already in the Jira issue tracker.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 2.  If not, create a ticket describing the change you're proposing in the Jira issue tracker.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 3.  Contribute your code changes using the GitHub pull request method:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Contributing via Patch
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: To create a patch from changes in your local directory:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git diff > ../THRIFT-NNNN.patch
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: then wait for contributors or committers to review your changes, and then for a committer to apply your patch.  This is not the preferred way to submit changes and incurs additional overhead for committers who must then create a pull request for you.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: GitHub recipes for Pull Requests
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Sometimes commmitters may ask you to take actions in your pull requests.  Here are some recipes that will help you accomplish those requests.  These examples assume you are working on Jira issue THRIFT-9999.  You should also be familiar with the upstream repository concept.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Squash your changes
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: If you have not submitted a pull request yet, or if you have not yet rebased your existing pull request, you can squash all your commits down to a single commit.  This makes life easier for the committers.  If your pull request on GitHub has more than one commit, you should do this.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 1.  Use the command git log to identify how many commits you made since you began.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 2.  Use the command git rebase -i HEAD~N where N is the number of commits.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 3.  Leave "pull" in the first line.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 4.  Change all other lines from "pull" to "fixup".
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 5.  All your changes are now in a single commit.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: If you already have a pull request outstanding, you will need to do a "force push" to overwrite it since you changed your commit history:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git push -u origin THRIFT-9999 --force
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: A more detailed walkthrough of a squash can be found at Git Ready.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Rebase your pull request
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: If your pull request has a conflict with master, it needs to be rebased:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
git checkout THRIFT-9999
git rebase upstream master
(resolve any conflicts, make sure it builds)
git push -u origin THRIFT-9999 --force
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Fix a bad merge
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: If your pull request contains commits that are not yours, then you should use the following technique to fix the bad merge in your branch:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
git checkout master
git pull upstream master
git checkout -b THRIFT-9999-take-2
git cherry-pick ...
(pick only your commits from your original pull request in ascending chronological order)
squash your changes to a single commit if there is more than one (see above)
git push -u origin THRIFT-9999-take-2:THRIFT-9999
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: This procedure will apply only your commits in order to the current master, then you will squash them to a single commit, and then you force push your local THRIFT-9999-take-2 into remote THRIFT-9999 which represents your pull request, replacing all the commits with the new one.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Contributing to Apache Tomcat
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Firstly, thanks for your interest in contributing! I hope that this will be a
pleasant experience for you, and that you will return to continue
contributing.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Please visit our Get Involved page
for more information on how to contribute.

This project and everyone participating in it are governed by the Apache
software Foundation's
Code of Conduct. By
participating, you are expected to adhere to this code. If you are aware of

Reporting Guidelines page
and follow the instructions there.

Paragraph: How Can I Contribute?
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph:
Most of the contributions that we receive are code contributions, but you can
also contribute to the documentation, wiki, etc., or simply report solid bugs
for us to fix.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: Reporting Bugs
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Please review our guide on how to
submit a bug report. This page also has links to other resources to assist
you.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Your First Code Contribution
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: Trouble Deciding How to Contribute?
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph:
Unsure where to begin contributing to Tomcat? You can start by taking a look at
the issues marked 'Beginner', link below. Please note that the Beginner keyword
is pretty new to the project, so if there aren't any issues in the filter feel
free to ask on the dev list.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph:
- Beginner issues -
issues which should only require a few lines of code, and a test or two to
resolve.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph:
The list above shows all bugs that are marked 'Beginner' and are open in the
currently supported Tomcat versions (7, 8.5, and 9).
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph:
If you prefer C over Java, you may also take a look at the tomcat-native and
Tomcat Connectors products in Bugzilla.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: How to Provide Your First Patch
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Excited yet? This section will guide you through providing a patch to the
committers of the project for review and acceptance.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Choose Your Method of Submission
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: You can provide a patch in one of the following ways (in order of preference):
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - GitHub Pull Request
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Patch attachment to the Bugzilla issue
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Email the patch to the developer list. This is not preferred, but if no bug
is associated with the patch, or you would like a developer review, an email
may be appropriate.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Get the Sources
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
Now that you've chosen how you want to submit a patch, you need to get the
source code.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Download The Source Distribution
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
This method works if you want to submit a patch via email, but
the difference in using the sources distribution and a VCS is that you have to
manually generate the patch file by using diff. If this is what you want, you
can download the sources from the "Source Code Distributions" section of the
Download Page. There is one such page for every major Tomcat version:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: - Tomcat 9
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: - Tomcat 8
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: - Tomcat 7
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Manual Patch Generation
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
If you have chosen to attach a patch to the Bugzilla issue (or email
one), then you'll need to download the sources as noted above, make your
desired changes and then manually generate your patch using diff (or any
other tool).
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: GitHub
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
To submit a GitHub Pull Request you'll need to fork the
repository, clone your fork to do the work:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: $ git clone https://github.com/$USERNAME/tomcat.git
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: and then push your changes, and submit a Pull Request via the GitHub UI.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Submitting Your Patch!
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
After you've chosen your method of submission, retrieved the sources, and
fixed the issue it's time to submit your work. At this point, just follow
the method of submission you chose earlier.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- GitHub PR - after resolving the issue in your local fork and pushing to your
copy of the repository, open a GitHub PR for review.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Bugzilla attachment - attach the patch to the Bugzilla issue
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Email - again, not preferred, but you may send an email to the developer list
with a patch attached for review.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Waiting For Feedback
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
It may take a while for committers to review. Please be patient during this
time as all committers are volunteers on the project. If a significant amount
of time has lapsed since your submission, such as a couple of months, feel free
to either update your BZ, PR, or email the dev list with a message to bump your
issue. Sometimes things get lost in all the work and we need a reminder :smile:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Style Guide
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
Apache Tomcat has very loosely defined coding conventions, but the following
guidelines will be useful:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Use spaces for indenting, not tabs
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- 100 char line width for Java source, 80 char line width for documentation
source (.txt, .xml)
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Java source: { at end of line, 4 space indents
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - XML source: 2 space indents
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Did we miss something?
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph:
Have you reviewed this guide and found it lacking? Or are you confused about
some particular step? If so, please let us know! Or better yet, submit a PR to
address the issue :wink:
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Contributing
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: To contribute to apexcharts.js, fork the repository and clone it to your machine. See this GitHub help page for what forking and cloning means
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Setup packages
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Install this package's dependencies with npm:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: npm install
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Development
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Run the following to build this library and watch its source files for changes:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: npm run dev
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: You will now have a fully functioning local build of this library ready to be used. Leave the start script running, and continue with a new Terminal/shell window.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Send your changes back to us! :revolving_hearts:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: We'd love for you to contribute your changes back to apexcharts.js! To do that, it would be great if you could commit your changes to a separate feature branch and open a Pull Request for those changes.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Point your feature branch to use the master branch as the base of this PR. The exact commands used depends on how you've setup your local git copy, but the flow could look like this:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
# Inside your own copy of `apexcharts.js` package...
git checkout --branch feature/branch-name-here upstream/master
# Then hack away, and commit your changes:
git add -A
git commit -m "Few words about the changes I did"
# Push your local changes back to your fork
git push --set-upstream origin feature/branch-name-here
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: After these steps, you should be able to create a new Pull Request for this repository. If you hit any issues following these instructions, please open an issue and we'll see if we can improve these instructions even further.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Add tests for your changes
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: As of now, we have very less tests, and from now on, would like to pay extra attention to it. It would be great if the changes you did could be tested somehow. Our tests live inside the tests directory, and they can be run with the following command:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: npm run test
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Contributing to API Platform
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: First of all, thank you for contributing, you're awesome!
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: To have your code integrated in the API Platform project, there are some rules to follow, but don't panic, it's easy!
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Reporting Bugs
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: If you happen to find a bug, we kindly request you to report it. However, before submitting it, please:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Check the project documentation available online
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Then, if it appears that it's a real bug, you may report it using GitHub by following these 3 points:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Check if the bug is not already reported!
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - A clear title to resume the issue
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - A description of the workflow needed to reproduce the bug
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: NOTE: Don't hesitate giving as much information as you can (OS, PHP version extensions...)
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Pull Requests
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Writing a Pull Request
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
First of all, you must decide on what branch your changes will be based depending of the nature of the change.
See the dedicated documentation entry.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: To prepare your patch directly in the vendor/ of an existing project (convenient to fix a bug):
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 1.  Remove the existing copy of the library: rm -Rf vendor/api-platform/core
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 2.  Reinstall the lib while keeping Git metadata: composer install --prefer-source
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 3.  You can now work directly in vendor/api-platform/core, create a new branch: git checkout -b my_patch
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 4.  When your patch is ready, fork the project and add your Git remote: git remote add <your-name> git@github.com:<your-name>/core.git
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 5.  You can now push your code and open your Pull Request: git push <your-name> my_patch
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Alternatively, you can also work with the test application we provide:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
cd tests/Fixtures/app
./console assets:install --symlink
symfony serve
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
# or if you prefer using the PHP built-in web server
php -S localhost:8000 -t public/
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Matching Coding Standards
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
The API Platform project follows Symfony coding standards.
But don't worry, you can fix CS issues automatically using the PHP CS Fixer tool:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: php-cs-fixer.phar fix
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
And then, add the fixed file to your commit before pushing.
Be sure to add only your modified files. If any other file is fixed by cs tools, just revert it before committing.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Sending a Pull Request
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: When you send a PR, just make sure that:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - You add valid test cases (Behat and PHPUnit).
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Tests are green.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - You make a PR on the related documentation in the api-platform/docs repository.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- You make the PR on the same branch you based your changes on. If you see commits
that you did not make in your PR, you're doing it wrong.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Also don't forget to add a comment when you update a PR with a ping to the maintainers, so he/she will get a notification.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Squash your commits into one commit (see the next chapter).
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Tests
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: On api-platform/core there are two kinds of tests: unit (phpunit) and integration tests (behat).
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Both phpunit and behat are development dependencies and should be available in the vendor directory.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: PHPUnit and Coverage Generation
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: To launch unit tests:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: vendor/bin/phpunit --stop-on-failure -vvv
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: If you want coverage, you will need the pcov PHP extension and run:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: vendor/bin/phpunit --coverage-html coverage -vvv --stop-on-failure
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Sometimes there might be an error with too many open files when generating coverage. To fix this, you can increase the ulimit, for example:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: ulimit -n 4000
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Coverage will be available in coverage/index.html.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Behat
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: The command to launch Behat tests is:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: php -d memory_limit=-1 ./vendor/bin/behat --suite=default --stop-on-failure --format=progress
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: If you want to launch Behat tests for MongoDB, the command is:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: APP_ENV=mongodb php -d memory_limit=-1 ./vendor/bin/behat --suite=mongodb --stop-on-failure --format=progress
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: To get more details about an error, replace --format=progress by -vvv.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Squash your Commits
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: If you have 3 commits, start with:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git rebase -i HEAD~3
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: An editor will be opened with your 3 commits, all prefixed by pick.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Replace all pick prefixes by fixup (or f) except the first commit of the list.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Save and quit the editor.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: After that, all your commits will be squashed into the first one and the commit message will be the first one.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: If you would like to rename your commit message, type:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git commit --amend
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Now force push to update your PR:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git push --force-with-lease
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: License and Copyright Attribution
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
When you open a Pull Request to the API Platform project, you agree to license your code under the MIT license
and to transfer the copyright on the submitted code to K
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Be sure to you have the right to do that (if you are a professional, ask your company)!

Paragraph: If you include code from another project, please mention it in the Pull Request description and credit the original author.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: License
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: For each new file, please include a license at the top of the file.

Paragraph: - C++ code License example util.h;

Paragraph: Testing
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Please include unit tests for the contributed code to prove that your code works correctly,
and make sure that your code does not break existing tests. Test files are always named to end with _test.cc, and the test target names in the BUILD file always end with test.
Here is an example test file file_test.cc.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: You can use command bash apollo.sh test to run all unit tests.

Paragraph: Coding style
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - C/C++ coding style: Apollo adopted the Google C++ Style Guide. Make sure your code conforms to this style guide. You can use command bash apollo.sh lint to check if your code has any style problem.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Python coding style:  Apollo adopted the Google Python Style Guide. You can use the  yapf command yapf -i --style='{based_on_style: google}' foo.py to format a file foo.py.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Apollo best coding practice: Please also refer to Apollo Best Coding Practice for more coding practice disciplines.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - BUILD coding style : you can use command bash apollo.sh buildify to format your BUILD files before you submit.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Best coding practice: Follow this guide
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Documentation
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
If your code is not straightforward for other contributors to understand, it is recommended to implement the code in a clear and efficient way, and provide sufficient comments and documentation.
Apollo uses doxygen to help generate formatted API Document with command bash apollo.sh doc.
Document your code following this guide How to document code.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Commit Message
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
The first line of commit message should be a one-line summary of the change.
A paragraph can be added following the summary to clearly explain the details of the change.
If your code fixed an issue, add the issue number to your commit message.
An example of a good commit message is:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Replaced algorithm A with algorithm B in apollo/modules/control.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Algorithm B is faster than A because it uses binary search. The runtime is reduced from O(N) to O(log(N)).
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Fixes #1234
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Before Creating Pull Request
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
After you finish your code and ready to create a Pull Request, please make sure your
change don't break build/test/lint by running bash apollo.sh check, which is
equivalent to a combination of bash apollo.sh build, bash apollo.sh test and
bash apollo.sh lint.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Contributing
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Welcome to AppImage. A good starting point for most questions is our wiki at https://github.com/AppImage/AppImageKit/wiki
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: How to contribute
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: I would like to request an AppImage for an application
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: If there is no AppImage of your favorite application available, please request it from the author(s) of the application, e.g., as a feature request in the issue tracker of the application. For example, if you would like to see an AppImage of Mozilla Firefox, then please leave a comment at https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1249971. The more people request an AppImage from the upstream authors, the more likely is that an AppImage will be provided.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: I would like to provide an AppImage for my application
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: If you are an application author and would like to make your application available as an AppImage, please start here: https://github.com/AppImage/AppImageKit/wiki/Creating-AppImages. Feel free to open a GitHub Issue in the AppImageKit project if you need support using the tools provided by AppImageKit.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: I would like to have my AppImage included in the AppImageHub central directory of available AppImages
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Please see the AppImageHub Readme.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: I would like to contribute to AppImageKit development
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Your contribution is especially welcome in these ares:
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: - High-priority issues we need help with
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: - Issues we need help with
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: - Open bugs
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: If you would like to report issues with AppImageKit itself, or would like to contribute to its development, please see get in touch with us in #AppImage on irc.freenode.net. We welcome pull requests addressing any of the open issues and/or other bugfixes and/or feature additions. In the case of complex feature additions, it is best to contact us first, before you spend much time.

Paragraph: Rules for contributing
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - The only supported version is git master
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - We do not bugfix any versions other than git master
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Versions other than git master are considered outdated and obsolete
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Our software comes in AppImage format. Everything else is unsupported by us
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - If git master breaks, all other work stops and every contributor focuses exclusively on un-breaking master
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Every contribution shall be sent as a pull request, which must build "green" before it is merged
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Pinned issues shall be closed before other issues are being worked on
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Contributing to Appium
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
There are a lot of different ways to contribute to Appium. See below for
everything you can do and the processes to follow for each contribution method.
Note that no matter how you contribute, your participation is governed by our
Code of Conduct.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Make changes to the Appium code or docs
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
Fork the project, make a change, and send a pull request! Please have a look at
our Style Guide before
getting to work.  Please make sure the unit and functional tests pass before
sending a pull request; for more information on how to run tests, keep reading!
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
Make sure you read and follow the setup instructions in the README first. And note
that all participation in the Appium community (including code submissions) is
governed by our Code of Conduct. Then, have a look at our
running from source doc for more
information on how to get set up to run tests and start slinging code.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
You will probably also want to have a look at this more in-depth Developer's
Overview of the Appium
project, how Appium is architected, how to make changes to modules, and so on.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
Finally, before we accept your code, you will need to have signed our
Contributor License
Agreement.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Become an Appium Triager
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
You can help us manage our issue tracker! All you need is enough familiarity
with Appium to try and reproduce bugs. We triage issues by having conversations
with the issue creator and then either closing the issue or moving it into the
Bugs or
Features milestone. We
use these buckets as the backlogs for our upcoming releases.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: We use this "algorithm" for triaging issues, which anyone can jump in and follow:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 1.  If issue is a feature request, discuss amongst Appium devs.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - If we decide to build it, add to the Features milestone.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - If we decide not to build it, just close.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 2.  If issue is a bug report, attempt to verify
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - If it's a duplicate, close with link to bug already reported.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - If it ultimately can't be verified, close until we have enough information to verify (e.g., in most cases we need a full set of Appium logs to help diagnose an issue).
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - If the user hasn't provided enough information, keep asking for enough information to verify.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - If it's a verified new bug, add it to the Bugs milestone.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - If we have been waiting for a reply from the user for over 3 weeks, close.
Label: No categories identified.
No categories identified.

Paragraph: Help out on our forums
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
We can always use help on our forums at
discuss.appium.io! Hop on over and see if there
are any questions that you can answer.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Submit bug reports or feature requests
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Just use the GitHub issue tracker to submit your bug reports and feature
requests. If you are submitting a bug report, please follow the issue template.
Label: No categories identified.

CUPS is developed by Apple Inc. and distributed as open source software under
the Apache License, Version 2.0 with exceptions to allow linking to GPL2/LGPL2
code.  Significant contributions to CUPS must be licensed to Apple using the
Apple Contributor Agreement:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: https://www.cups.org/AppleContributorAgreement_2011-03-10.pdf

Paragraph:
Contributions should be submitted as attachments to bug reports on the
CUPS Github project.  Changes to existing
source files should be submitted as unified diffs while new source files
should be provided as-is or in an archive.  Github pull requests can also be
used to submit changes.

Paragraph: Community Guidelines
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: We want the FoundationDB community to be as welcoming and inclusive as possible, and have adopted a Code of Conduct that we ask all community members to read and observe.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Project Licensing
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: By submitting a pull request, you represent that you have the right to license your contribution to Apple and the community, and agree by submitting the patch that your contributions are licensed under the Apache 2.0 license.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Governance and Decision Making
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: At project launch, FoundationDB has a light governance structure. The intention is for the community to evolve quickly and adopt additional processes as participation grows. Stay tuned, and stay engaged! Your feedback is welcome.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: We draw inspiration from the Apache Software Foundation's informal motto: "community over code", and their emphasis on meritocratic rules. You'll also observe that some initial community structure is inspired by the Swift community.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: The project technical lead is Evan Tschannen (ejt@apple.com).
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Members of the Apple FoundationDB team are part of the core committers helping review individual contributions; you'll see them commenting on your pull requests.  As the FDB open source community has grown, some members of the community have consistently produced high quality code reviews and other significant contributions to FoundationDB.  The project technical lead maintains a list of external committers that actively contribute in this way, and gives them permission to review and merge pull requests.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Contributing
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Opening a Pull Request
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: We love pull requests! For minor changes, feel free to open up a PR directly. For larger feature development and any changes that may require community discussion, we ask that you discuss your ideas on the community forums prior to opening a PR, and then reference that thread within your PR comment.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: CI will be run automatically for core committers, and for community PRs it will be initiated by the request of a core committer.  Tests can also be run locally via ctest, and core committers can run additional validation on pull requests prior to merging them.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Reporting issues
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Please refer to the section below on using GitHub issues and the community forums for more info.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Security issues
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: To report a security issue, please DO NOT start by filing a public issue or posting to the forums; instead send a private email to fdb-oss-security@group.apple.com.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Project Communication
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Community Forums
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: We encourage your participation asking questions and helping improve the FoundationDB project. Check out the FoundationDB community forums, which serve a similar function as mailing lists in many open source projects. The forums are organized into three sections:
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: - Development: For discussing the internals and development of the FoundationDB core, as well as layers.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: - Using FoundationDB: For discussing user-facing topics. Getting started and have a question? This is the place for you.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: - Site Feedback: A category for discussing the forums and the OSS project, its organization, how it works, and how we can improve it.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Using GitHub Issues and Community Forums
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: GitHub issues and the community forums both offer features to facilitate discussion. To clarify how and when to use each tool, here's a quick summary of how we think about them:
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: GitHub Issues should be used for tracking tasks. If you know the specific code that needs to be changed, then it should go to GitHub Issues. Everything else should go to the Forums. For example:
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: - I am experiencing some weird behavior, which I think is a bug, but I don't know where exactly (mysteries and unexpected behaviors): Forums
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: - I see a bug in this piece of code: GitHub Issues
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: - Feature requests and design documents: Forums
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: - Implementing an agreed upon feature: GitHub Issues
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Project and Development Updates
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Stay connected to the project and the community! For project and community updates, follow the FoundationDB project blog. Development announcements will be made via the community forums' dev-announce section.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Contributing
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Contributions to Foundation are welcome! This project follows the contribution guidelines for the Swift project. If you are interested in contributing, please consult with our status page to see what work remains to be done. A few additional details are outlined below.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Licensing
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: By submitting a pull request, you represent that you have the right to license your contribution to Apple and the community, and agree by submitting the patch that your contributions are licensed under the Swift license.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Bug Reports
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: You can use the Foundation component in the bug reporter if you know your bug is specifically about Swift Foundation.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Please remember to include platform information with your report. If the bug is about the Foundation framework on Darwin, then please use Feedback Assistant.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Pull Requests
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Before embarking on a large amount of work to implement missing functionality, please double-check with the community on the swift-corelibs-dev mailing list. Someone may already be working in this area, and we want to avoid duplication of work.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: If your request includes functionality changes, please be sure to test your code on Linux as well as macOS. Differences in the compiler and runtime on each platform means that code that compiles and runs correctly on Darwin (where the Objective-C runtime is present) may not compile at all on Linux.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Review
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Each pull request will be reviewed by a code owner before merging.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Pull requests should contain small, incremental change.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Focus on one task. If a pull request contains several unrelated commits, we will ask for the pull request to be split up.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Please squash work-in-progress commits. Each commit should stand on its own (including the addition of tests if possible). This allows us to bisect issues more effectively.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - After addressing review feedback, please rebase your commit so that we create a clean history in the master branch.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Tests
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: All pull requests which contain code changes should come with a new set of automated tests, and every current test must pass on all supported platforms.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Documentation
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Most of the methods in Foundation are lacking documentation. We appreciate your help in filling out documentation when you implement a method. Use the markdown syntax in the Swift Naming Guidelines.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Implementation Status
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: We are currently keeping track of the implementation status and test coverage status of our public classes on our status page. If you make changes to our public interfaces, please take care to update the corresponding entries in that document.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: API Changes
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: The interface of Foundation is intended to be both stable and cross-platform. This means that when API is added to Foundation, it is effectively permanent.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: It is therefore critical that any code change that affects the public-facing API go through a full  swift-evolution review process. This gives us the chance to ensure several important requirements are satisfied:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - The proposal aligns with our current goals for the upcoming release.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - We are comfortable supporting the proposed API for the long term.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - We believe we can make the same change to the API of Darwin Foundation. This could be done via changes in the overlay, changes in the compiler, or changes in Darwin Foundation itself. This must be addressed in every proposal.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Contributing
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
We welcome bug fixes and patches from 3rd party contributors. Please
see the Contributor Agreement
for details.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Please follow these guidelines if you want to contribute to ArangoDB:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Reporting Bugs
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
When reporting bugs, please use our issue tracker on GitHub.  Please make sure
to include the version number of ArangoDB in your bug report, along with the
platform you are using (e.g. Linux OpenSuSE x86_64).  Please also include the
ArangoDB startup mode (daemon, console, supervisor mode) plus any special
configuration.  This will help us reproducing and finding bugs.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Please also take the time to check there are no similar/identical issues open
yet.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Contributing features, documentation, tests
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Create a new branch in your fork, based on the devel branch
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Develop and test your modifications there
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
- Commit as you like, but preferably in logical chunks. Use meaningful commit
messages and make sure you do not commit unnecessary files (e.g. object
files). It is normally a good idea to reference the issue number from the
commit message so the issues will get updated automatically with comments.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
- If the modifications change any documented behavior or add new features,
document the changes. It should be written in American English.
The documentation can be found at https://github.com/arangodb/docs
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
- When done, run the complete test suite and make sure all tests pass. You can
check README_maintainers.md for test run instructions.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
- When finished, push the changes to your GitHub repository and send a pull
request from your fork to the ArangoDB repository. Please make sure to select
the appropriate branches there. This will most likely be devel.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
- You must use the Apache License for your changes and have signed our
CLA. We cannot accept pull requests
from contributors that didn't sign the CLA.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
- Please let us know if you plan to work on a ticket. This way we can make sure
redundant work is avoided.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - ArangoDB website
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - ArangoDB on Twitter
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - General GitHub documentation
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - GitHub pull request documentation
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: CONTRIBUTING
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Contributions are welcome, and are accepted via pull requests. Please review these guidelines before submitting any pull requests.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Guidelines
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Please follow the PSR-2 Coding Standard, PHP-FIG Naming Conventions and the PSR-4 autoloading standard
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Ensure that the current tests pass, and if you've added something new, add the tests where relevant.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Remember that we follow SemVer. If you are changing the behaviour, or the public api, you may need to update the docs.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Send a coherent commit history, making sure each individual commit in your pull request is meaningful. If you had to make multiple intermediate commits while developing, please squash them before submitting.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - You may also need to rebase to avoid merge conflicts.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Translations :
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - After you made your translations, ensure that you added your locale key in alphabetical order at line in the tests/TestCase.php file for the tests.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - The locale key must be a ISO 639-1 code, check also caouecs/Laravel-lang package.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Running Tests
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: You will need an install of Composer before continuing.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: First, install the dependencies:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: $ composer install
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Then run phpunit:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: $ vendor/bin/phpunit
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: If the test suite passes on your local machine you should be good to go.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: When you make a pull request, the tests will automatically be run again by Travis CI.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Rules for Pull Requests
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Descriptive titles. Pull requests must have a title that gives the package name the PR is for, and a short description about the PR.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Detailed description. The body of the PR must contain a detailed description of what changes are being introduced, and most importantly, why this PR should be merged.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - One package per request. PRs must be for a single package only.  A PR addressing multiple packages without merit risks having a delayed merge or being closed.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Squash commits. Your commits must be meaningful. If you make incremental changes or fixes, they must be squashed before the pull request will be merged.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Check that your changes build. Your submission must build using the clean chroot method on all supported architectures that the package is to be built for.  No exceptions.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Work within one PR. Do not close a PR and open another with new changes.  Amend your commit and force push to your branch to update the changes in the pull request.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Ensure your PR addresses three of the most common problems:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Correctly update the pkgver or pkgrel of the package (see below).
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Update the checksums if external files have been added or modified.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Is the package only for specific architectures?  Set the buildarch variable (see the README)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Pull requests that fail to meet these requirements may be summarily closed without response.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Submitting new packages
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - If the pull request is for a new package, review the README to ensure the package is going into the correct repository and meets all the stated requirements.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Updating existing packages
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Upstream x86 Arch Linux packages
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - If you changed the PKGBUILD or related files, detail your changes in the comment header at the top.  Review the packages in this repository for examples of what this looks like.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Increment the pkgrel variable by a decimal number if the version of the package is already in the package repositories.  This is to prevent interference tracking against upstream versions.  For example:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - If pkgrel=1, change to pkgrel=1.1
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - If pkgrel=1.1, change to pkgrel=1.2
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - At no time should an upstream package tracked here exceed the version upstream.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - If the package is only supposed to be built for specific architectures, ensure the buildarch variable is set correctly (see the README)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Arch Linux ARM specific packages
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - If the change increases the version of the package, ensure pkgver is updated and pkgrel is reset to 1.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Otherwise, increment pkgrel by 1.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - If the package is only supposed to be built for specific architectures, ensure the buildarch variable is set correctly (see the README)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Contributing to CleanArchitecture
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
First: if you're unsure or afraid of anything, just ask or submit the
issue or pull request anyways. You won't be yelled at for giving your best
effort. The worst that can happen is that you'll be politely asked to change
something. We appreciate any sort of contributions, and don't want a wall of
rules to get in the way of that.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
However, for those individuals who want a bit more guidance on the best way to
contribute to the project, read on. This document will cover what we're looking
for. By addressing all the points we're looking for, it raises the chances we
can quickly merge or address your contributions.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Issues
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Reporting an Issue
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- Make sure you test against the latest released version. It is possible we
already fixed the bug you're experiencing.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- If you can, check and see if there is an existing open issue that is already
reporting the problem. Feel free to upvote this issue or comment on it to
describe your specific scenario (assuming it's the same underlying issue).
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- Provide a reproducible test case. If a contributor can't reproduce an issue,
then it dramatically lowers the chances it'll get fixed. And in some cases,
the issue will eventually be closed.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- Respond promptly to any questions made by the maintainers about your issue. Stale
issues will be closed (eventually).
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Pull Requests
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
- Pull requests are welcome but are most likely to be accepted when they address
an existing issue. A common workflow is to create an issue describing the problem
your PR would solve, and then volunteer to submit a PR addressing the issue as an
initial comment on the issue.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
- As much as possible, pull requests should follow the existing coding conventions
used by the project. This is generally true for any project. The only exception to
this would be a pull request whose purpose is to adjust the coding conventions used
by the project.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- When possible, issues will be marked with a help wanted tag if community contributions
are particularly welcome for them. This will often be the case for relatively simple
fixes that would make good initial contributions.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph:
- If your PR addresses an issue, please include "Fixes #NNN" in the summary for the PR
so that the issue is linked to the PR (and vice versa) and if/when the PR is merged,
the issue is automatically closed.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Thank you for reading this and for considering contributing to this project!
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Contributing Rules
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Thanks for your interest in contributing to this free open source project! Arduino welcomes help from the community. There are several ways you can get involved:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
| Type of contribution | Contribution method |
|-|-|
| - Support request- Question- Problem with your Arduino- Discussion | Post on the Arduino Forum |
| - Bug report- Arduino website issue or improvement- Feature request | Issue report (read the issue guidelines) |
| - Bug fix- Enhancement | Pull Request (read the pull request guidelines) |
| Translations for the Arduino IDE | transifex |
| Translations for the Language Reference | Reference repositories |
| Monetary | - Donate- Buy official products |
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Issues
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Do you need help or have a question about using Arduino? Support requests should be made to the appropriate section of the Arduino forum rather than an issue report. Issue reports are to be used to report bugs or make feature requests only.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Check if your issue has already been resolved in the hourly build.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Submit issue reports to the correct repository:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
| Issue topic | Report at |
|-|-|
| Arduino IDE, arduino.cc (but not the Arduino Forum), Library Manager additions | arduino/Arduino |
| Language Reference | Reference repositories |
| Arduino Forum | arduino/forum-issues |
| Arduino libraries | arduino-libraries |
| arduino-builder | arduino/arduino-builder |
| Arduino Web Editor | Create > Editor section of the Arduino Forum |
| Arduino AVR Boards (Uno, Mega, Leonardo, etc.) | arduino/ArduinoCore-avr |
| Arduino SAMD Boards (Zero, MKR1000, MKRZero, etc.) | arduino/ArduinoCore-samd |
| Arduino SAM Boards (Due) | arduino/ArduinoCore-sam |
| AVR Toolchain for Arduino | arduino/toolchain-avr |
| Arduino's build of AVRDUDE | arduino/avrdude-build-script |
| Security vulnerability | See: Coordinated Vulnerability Disclosure Policy |
| 3rd party libraries, hardware, or sketches | Report issues to the author of the software, not Arduino. |
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: When you're not sure where your issue belongs, report it at arduino/Arduino and we'll move it to where it belongs (but remember: Only bug reports and feature requests, do not ask for help with your own code there).
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Search existing pull requests and issues to be sure it hasn't already been reported. If you have additional information to provide about an existing issue then please comment on that issue. If you simply want to express your support then use the Reactions feature.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - State the newest version of the Arduino IDE you have verified the issue with and which operating system you are using.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - The issue title should be concise yet descriptive. Vague titles make it difficult to know the purpose of the issue when looking through the list of reports and may cause your issue to not be given proper attention.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- Describe the issue and what behavior you were expecting. Post complete error messages using Markdown code fencing, three backticks before and after the error message:
```
my error message here
```
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- Provide a full set of steps necessary to reproduce the issue. Demonstration code should be complete, correct, and simplified to the minimum amount of code necessary to reproduce the issue. Please use Markdown code fencing, three backticks before and after the code:
```
my code here
```
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Be responsive. We may need you to provide more information, please respond as soon as possible.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - If you find a solution to your problem update your issue report with an explanation of how you were able to fix it and close the issue.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Library Manager submissions: make sure your library meets all the requirements listed in the Library Manager FAQ.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Pull Requests
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Pull requests are an easy and effective way to submit a proposal for a change to the content of one of Arduino's repositories. The Arduino team can merge your change with a single click! You can find more information about pull requests here.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Big changes, changes to the API, or changes with backward compatibility trade-offs should be first discussed in the Arduino Developers Mailing List.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Search existing pull requests to see if one has already been submitted for this change. Search the issues to see if there has been a discussion on this topic and whether your pull request can close any issues.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Code formatting should be consistent with the style used in the existing code.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Don't leave commented out code. A record of this code is already preserved in the commit history.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Note that the Arduino core libraries support many boards and processors. When fixing or adding functionality for one of them, it's easy to break something on the others. Please test your changes on as many processors as possible. Even if you don't have a particular board, try compiling your patch for it to make sure that you haven't introduced any errors.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - All commits must be atomic. This means that the commit completely accomplishes a single task. Each commit should result in fully functional code. Multiple tasks should not be combined in a single commit, but a single task should not be split over multiple commits (e.g. one commit per file modified is not a good practice). For more information see http://www.freshconsulting.com/atomic-commits.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Each pull request should address a single bug fix or enhancement. This may consist of multiple commits. If you have multiple, unrelated fixes or enhancements to contribute, submit them as separate pull requests.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Commit messages:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Use the imperative mood in the title. For example: "Apply editor.indent preference"
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Capitalize the title.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Do not end the title with a period.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Separate title from the body with a blank line. If you're committing via GitHub or GitHub Desktop this will be done automatically.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Wrap body at 72 characters.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Completely explain the purpose of the commit. Include a rationale for the change, any caveats, side-effects, etc.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - If your pull request fixes an issue in the issue tracker, use the closes/fixes/resolves syntax in the body to indicate this.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - See http://chris.beams.io/posts/git-commit for more tips on writing good commit messages.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Pull request title and description should follow the same guidelines as commit messages.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Rebasing pull requests is OK and encouraged. After submitting your pull request some changes may be requested. Rather than adding unnecessary extra commits to the pull request, you can squash these changes into the existing commit and then do a force push to your fork. When you do a force push to your fork, the PR will be updated with your new changes, so there is no need to open a new PR to make changes. Leave a comment on the pull request thread to explain that the history has been changed. This will help to keep the commit history of the repository clean.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - After your pull request is merged please update the documentation if the changes require it:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Edit appropriate Wiki pages.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Submit an issue report requesting changes to the arduino.cc reference pages.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - For more contributing guidelines, see the Arduino Development Policy.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: How to contribute to the ArduPilot project?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: If you are reading this page, you are possibly interested in contributing to our project.  We have a very active (and friendly) developer group and would love to have the help!  Possible ways you can help:
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: - Testing the code
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: - Filing issues on github, when you see a problem (or adding detail to existing issues that effect you)
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Fixing issues
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: - Adding new features
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: - Reviewing existing pull requests, and notifying the maintainer if it passes your code review.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: How to make a good bug report...
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Make sure your bug is not a support issue. Support issues should go to the support forums and include a .bin log file if possible. If you're not sure you have a bug, you should seek support first.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Search for your bug, make sure it is not already reported. If it is already reported, make a comment on that issue.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Only report one bug per issue report.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Write a clear and concise summary. Be specific about what component of the software you are writing about, and follow the convention: "Copter: blah blah blah"
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Write a clear and concise description, with particularly clear steps to reproduce the problem. Include logs that display the bug. Try to report only facts in your issue report, keeping your assumptions out of it.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - The majority of issues open now are good or acceptable by these guidelines. Please refer to them for examples.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Submitting patches
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Please see our wiki article.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Development Team
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: The ArduPilot project is open source and maintained by a team of volunteers.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: To contribute, you can send a pull request on GitHub.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
New developers are recommended to join the #general channel on
Discord.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph:
You can also join the
development discussion on Discourse,
or Gitter.

Note that these are NOT for user tech support, and are moderated
for new users to prevent off-topic discussion.
