Paragraph: Contributing guidelines
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: When submitting pull requests
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Explain your thinking in why a change or addition is needed.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Is it a requested change or feature?
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - If not, open a feature request to get feedback before making a pull request.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - If it's a fix for a unreported bug, make a bug report and link the pull request.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Split up multiple unrelated changes in multiple pull requests.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Shellcheck your work. Current shellsheck exceptions at the beginning of bashtop.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Purely cosmetic changes won't be accepted without a very good explanation of its value.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - (Some design choices are for better configurability of syntax highlighting.)
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Formatting
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Follow the current syntax design
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Indent type: Tabs
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Tab size: 4
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Use the longer "if, elif, then, else, fi" statements and indent conditionals, loops etc.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Use "[[ ]]", "(( ))" for conditions and "$( ), <( )" for command substitution.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Create functions instead of repeating blocks of code.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Don't stack unrelated blocks of code, leave blank lines for better readability.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Comment new code that isn't very obvious in it's function.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Name new variables and functions in lower-case and after what purpose they serve.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - (Exception arithmetic with many variables, make sure to comment what's happening instead.)
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Optimization
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Avoid forks if possible.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Avoid writing to disk if possible.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Make sure variables/arrays are cleaned up if not reused.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Compare cpu and memory usage with and without your code and look for alternatives if they cause a noticeable negative impact.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: For questions contact Aristocratos at admin@qvantnet.com
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: For proposing changes to this document create a new issue.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Contributing
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Thanks you for your interest in contributing to Acr.UserDIalogs - Please see our our Code of Conduct.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Bug Fixes
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: If you're looking for something to fix, please browse open issues.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Follow the style used by the .NET Foundation, with a few exceptions:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Don't use the private keyword as it is the default accessibility level in C#
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Apply readonly on class level private variables that are assigned in the constructor
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - 4 SPACES - tabs do not exist :)
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Read and follow our Pull Request template if you are submitting fixes.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Feature Requests
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: To propose a change or new feature, please make use the feature request area in issues/
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Non-Starter Topics
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: The following topics should generally not be proposed for discussion as they are non-starters:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Large renames of APIs
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Large non-backward-compatible breaking changes
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Avoid clutter posts like "+1" which do not serve to further the conversation
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Proposal States
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Open
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Open proposals are still under discussion. Please leave your concrete, constructive feedback on this proposal. +1s and other clutter posts which do not add to the discussion will be removed.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Accepted
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Accepted proposals are proposals that both the community and core Shiny team agree should be a part of projects. These proposals are ready for implementation. These proposals are available for anyone to work on unless it is already assigned to someone.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: If you wish to start working on an accepted proposal, please reply to the thread so we can mark you as the implementor and change the title to In Progress. This helps to avoid multiple people working on the same thing. If you decide to work on this proposal publicly, feel free to post a link to the branch as well for folks to follow along.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: What "Accepted" does mean
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Any community member is welcome to work on the idea.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - The maintainers may consider working on this idea on their own, but has not done so until it is marked "In Progress" with a team member assigned as the implementor.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Any pull request implementing the proposal will be welcomed with an API and code review.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: What "Accepted" does not mean
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - The proposal will ever be implemented, either by a community member or maintainers.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - The maintainers are committing to implementing a proposal, even if nobody else does.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: In Progress
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Once a developer has begun work on a proposal, either from the maintainers or a community member, the proposal is marked as in progress with the implementors name and (possibly) a link to a development branch to follow along with progress.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Rejected
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Rejected proposals will not be implemented or merged into Shiny. Once a proposal is rejected, the thread will be closed and the conversation is considered completed, pending considerable new information or changes..
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Contribution Guide
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: This page describes how to contribute changes to PhantomJS.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Please do not create a pull request without reading this guide first. Failure to do so may result in the rejection of the pull request.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: For The Impatients
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
Work on a feature branch.
If your changes need to be modified due to some reviews, it is less clutter to tweak an isolated feature branch and push it again.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
Create a ticket in the issue tracker.
This serves as a placeholder for important feedback, review, or any future updates.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: In the commit message:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Keep the first line < 72 characters. Write additional paragraphs
if necessary.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Put the link to the issue (see above). This is important for cross-referencing purposes.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Communicate
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Second opinion is always important.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Bug fixing. If you have a fix for a bug, please attach your patch in the corresponding issue in the issue tracker. If there is no entry for the bug yet, then please create a new one. If you are confident working with Git, see the Get Ready section below on how to submit your change.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Improvement and feature request. If you have an improvement idea, please send an email to the mailing list (rather than contacting the developers directly) so that other people can give their insights and opinions. This is also important to avoid duplicate work.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Task management. Once the feature idea is agreed upon and translated into concrete actions and tasks, please use the issue tracker to create an issue for each individual task. Further technical discussion about the task and the implementation details should be carried out in the issue tracker.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Extending with new API. Whenever you want to introduce a new API, please send an email to the mailing list along with the link to the issue. Consider good API name for the object or function, read the API Design Principle article. It may require few iterations to agree on the final API and hence it is important to engage all interested parties as early as possible.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Get Ready
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: For your proposed change, you need to have:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - an issue (in the issue tracker) which describe your bug or feature
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - a feature branch in your git fork
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Make sure your code change follows the style guide. To format your code, run ./tools/format-code.sh.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Refer the Issue
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: The commit message needs to link to the issue. This cross-reference is very important for the following reasons.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: First, the commit log is frozen and can not be changed. If it contains a mistake or outdated information, the log can not be amended. However, further updates can be still posted to the linked issue, which can be followed from the commit log itself.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Second, it provides a placeholder for code review and other feedback.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: An example of a bad commit log:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Fix Mountain Lion
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: The above log is too short and useless in the long run. A better version (and note the issue link):
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Better support for OS X Mountain Lion.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: require('system').os.version should give "10.8 (Mountain Lion)".
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: https://github.com/ariya/phantomjs/issues/10688
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Use Feature Branch
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: To isolate your change, please avoid working on the master branch. Instead, work on a feature branch (often also known as topic branch). You can create a new branch (example here crash-fix) off the master branch by using:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git checkout -b crash-fix master
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Refer to your favorite Git tutorial/book for further detailed help.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Some good practices for the feature branch:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Give it a meaningful name instead of, e.g. prevent-zero-divide instead of just fix
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Make granular and atomic commits, e.g. do not mix a typo fix with some major refactoring
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Keep one branch for one specific issue. If you need to work on other unrelated issues, create another branch.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Review and Merge
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: When your branch is ready, send the pull request.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: While it is not always the case, often it is necessary to improve parts of your code in the branch. This is the actual review process.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Here is a check list for the review:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - It does not break the test suite
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - There is no typo
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - The coding style follows the existing one
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - There is a reasonable amount of comment
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - The license header is intact
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - All examples are still working
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Contributing
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: We gratefully accept bug reports and contributions from the community. There are some requirements we need to fulfill in order to be able to integrate contributions:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - As with any open source project, contributions will be reviewed by the project team and community and may need some modifications to be accepted.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - The contribution should not break API or ABI, unless there is a real justification for that. If there is an API change, the contribution, if accepted, will be merged only when there will be a major release.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Coding Standards
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - We would ask that contributions conform to our coding standards, and that contributions are fully tested before submission, as mentioned in the Tests and Continuous Integration sections.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - The code should be written in a clean and readable style.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - The code should be written in a portable generic way, that will benefit the whole community, and not only your own needs.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - The code should be secure, and will be reviewed from a security point of view as well.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Making a Contribution
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 1.  Check for open issues or start a discussion around a feature idea or a bug.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 2.  Fork the Mbed TLS repository on GitHub to start making your changes. As a general rule, you should use the "development" branch as a basis.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 3.  Write a test which shows that the bug was fixed or that the feature works as expected.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 4.  Send a pull request (PR) and work with us until it gets merged and published. Contributions may need some modifications, so a few rounds of review and fixing may be necessary. We will include your name in the ChangeLog :)
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 5.  For quick merging, the contribution should be short, and concentrated on a single feature or topic. The larger the contribution is, the longer it would take to review it and merge it.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 6.  All new files should include the Apache-2.0 standard license header where possible.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 7.  Ensure that each commit has at least one Signed-off-by: line from the committer. If anyone else contributes to the commit, they should also add their own Signed-off-by: line. By adding this line, contributor(s) certify that the contribution is made under the terms of the Developer Certificate of Origin. The contribution licensing is described in the License section of the README.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: API/ABI Compatibility
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: The project aims to minimise the impact on users upgrading to newer versions of the library and it should not be necessary for a user to make any changes to their own code to work with a newer version of the library. Unless the user has made an active decision to use newer features, a newer generation of the library or a change has been necessary due to a security issue or other significant software defect, no modifications to their own code should be necessary. To achieve this, API compatibility is maintained between different versions of Mbed TLS on the main development branch and in LTS (Long Term Support) branches.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: To minimise such disruption to users, where a change to the interface is required, all changes to the ABI or API, even on the main development branch where new features are added, need to be justifiable by either being a significant enhancement, new feature or bug fix which is best resolved by an interface change.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Where changes to an existing interface are necessary, functions in the public interface which need to be changed, are marked as 'deprecated'. This is done with the preprocessor symbols MBEDTLS_DEPRECATED_WARNING and MBEDTLS_DEPRECATED_REMOVED. Then, a new function with a new name but similar if not identical behaviour to the original function containing the necessary changes should be created alongside the existing deprecated function.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: When a build is made with the deprecation preprocessor symbols defined, a compiler warning will be generated to warn a user that the function will be removed at some point in the future, notifying users that they should change from the older deprecated function to the newer function at their own convenience.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Therefore, no changes are permitted to the definition of functions in the public interface which will change the API. Instead the interface can only be changed by its extension. As described above, if a function needs to be changed, a new function needs to be created alongside it, with a new name, and whatever change is necessary, such as a new parameter or the addition of a return value.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Periodically, the library will remove deprecated functions from the library which will be a breaking change in the API, but such changes will be made only in a planned, structured way that gives sufficient notice to users of the library.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Long Term Support Branches
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Mbed TLS maintains several LTS (Long Term Support) branches, which are maintained continuously for a given period. The LTS branches are provided to allow users of the library to have a maintained, stable version of the library which contains only security fixes and fixes for other defects, without encountering additional features or API extensions which may introduce issues or change the code size or RAM usage, which can be significant considerations on some platforms. To allow users to take advantage of the LTS branches, these branches maintain backwards compatibility for both the public API and ABI.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: When backporting to these branches please observe the following rules:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 1.  Any change to the library which changes the API or ABI cannot be backported.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 2.  All bug fixes that correct a defect that is also present in an LTS branch must be backported to that LTS branch. If a bug fix introduces a change to the API such as a new function, the fix should be reworked to avoid the API change. API changes without very strong justification are unlikely to be accepted.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 3.  If a contribution is a new feature or enhancement, no backporting is required. Exceptions to this may be additional test cases or quality improvements such as changes to build or test scripts.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: It would be highly appreciated if contributions are backported to LTS branches in addition to the development branch by contributors.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Currently maintained LTS branches are:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 1.  mbedtls-2.7
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 2.  mbedtls-2.16
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Tests
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: As mentioned, tests that show the correctness of the feature or bug fix should be added to the pull request, if no such tests exist.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Mbed TLS includes a comprehensive set of test suites in the tests/ directory that are dynamically generated to produce the actual test source files (e.g. test_suite_mpi.c). These files are generated from a function file (e.g. suites/test_suite_mpi.function) and a data file (e.g. suites/test_suite_mpi.data). The function file contains the test functions. The data file contains the test cases, specified as parameters that will be passed to the test function.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: A Knowledge Base article describing how to add additional tests is available on the Mbed TLS website.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: A test script tests/scripts/basic-build-test.sh is available to show test coverage of the library. New code contributions should provide a similar level of code coverage to that which already exists for the library.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Sample applications, if needed, should be modified as well.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Continuous Integration Tests
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Once a PR has been made, the Continuous Integration (CI) tests are triggered and run. You should follow the result of the CI tests, and fix failures.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: It is advised to enable the githooks scripts prior to pushing your changes, for catching some of the issues as early as possible.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Mbed TLS is well documented, but if you think documentation is needed, speak out!
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 1.  All interfaces should be documented through Doxygen. New APIs should introduce Doxygen documentation.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 2.  Complex parts in the code should include comments.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 3.  If needed, a Readme file is advised.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 4.  If a Knowledge Base (KB) article should be added, write this as a comment in the PR description.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 5.  A ChangeLog entry should be added for this contribution.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Your First Contribution
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Submitting code
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Any code change should be submitted as a pull request. Before start working on something make always a search in opened issues and pull requests, this might help you to avoid waisting time.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: A pull request could be a bug fix, new feature and much more, but in all cases, open a new issue and talk about what you want to do. Often happens to work on something already fixed (ready to release) or in progress.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: The title should be brief but comprehensive, the description contains a link to the opened issue and the proposed solution. The pull request should contain tests whenever possible. Keep in mind that the bigger is the pull request, the longer it will take to review and merge. Try to break down large pull requests in smaller chunks that are easier to review and merge.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Before submitting an expense contact core contributors via the current active chat room (Discord) and explain your intents

Paragraph: Code reviews
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
All submissions, including submissions by project members, require review. We
use Github pull requests for this purpose.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Some tips for good pull requests:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Use our code
When in doubt, try to stay true to the existing code of the project.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Write a descriptive commit message. What problem are you solving and what
are the consequences? Where and what did you test? Some good tips:
here
and here.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- If your PR consists of multiple commits which are successive improvements /
fixes to your first commit, consider squashing them into a single commit
(git rebase -i) such that your PR is a single commit on top of the current
HEAD. This make reviewing the code so much easier, and our history more
readable.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Submitting PRs
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Please follow the provided PR template when writing a description for your changes.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Do not take criticism personally. When you get feedback, it is about your work,
not your character, personality, etc. Keep in mind we all want to make the project better.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: When something is not clear, please ask questions to clear things up.

If you would like to introduce a big architectural changes or do a refactoring
either in the codebase or the development tools, please open an issue with a proposal
first. This way we can think together about the problem and probably come up
with a better solution.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Coding conventions and guidelines
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Commit messages
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Always write descriptive commit messages ("fix bug" is not acceptable).
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Use the present tense ("Add feature" not "Added feature").
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Use the imperative mood ("Move cursor to..." not "Moves cursor to...").
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Limit the first line to 72 characters or less.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Include the number of the issue you are fixing.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Coding guidelines
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: As a Python project, we must follow PEP 8 and PEP 20 guidelines.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
Furthermore, follow the Clean code conventions. The most important
in this project are the following rules:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Simpler is better. KISS principle
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Be consistent.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Every function must do one thing.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Use descriptive names for functions and variables.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Always look for the root cause.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Keep configurable data high level.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Avoid negative conditionals.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Prefer fewer arguments.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Do not add obvious comment to code.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Do not comment out code, just delete lines.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Open an issue in Github issue tracker.
Tell us what's the problem and include steps to reproduce it (reliably).

Paragraph: Requesting new features
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
We welcome all ideas.
If you believe most asciinema users would benefit from implementing your idea then feel free to open a Github issue.
However, as this is an open-source project maintained by a small team of volunteers we simply can't implement all of them due to limited resources. Please keep that in mind.

Github issue tracker is not a support forum.
If you need help then either join #asciinema IRC channel on freenode or drop us an email at support@asciinema.org.

For the benefit of all asciinema users please do not publish details of the vulnerability in a Github issue.

Paragraph: How to Contribute to asdf
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Did you find a bug?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Ensure the bug is actually an issue with asdf and not a plugin. If the bug
only occurs when using one tool installed by asdf and not others it's likely an
issue with the asdf plugin. Find the plugin repository on
asdf-vm/asdf-plugins and follow the
plugin creators instructions for reporting the bug.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Ensure the bug was not already reported by searching on GitHub under
Issues.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
If you are unable to find an open issue addressing the problem please open
a new one. Please be as specific
as possible when reporting the issue. Include the observed behavior as well as
what you thought should have happened. Please also provide environmental
details like asdf version, shell, OS, etc...
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Did you write a patch that fixes a bug?
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Open a new GitHub pull request with the patch. Refer to the Development
section of the README for the
details on how to run the unit tests. Please make sure that unit tests pass on
Travis CI.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Did you create a plugin for asdf?
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Please read the creating plugins guide.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Do you want to contribute the asdf documentation?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Documentation can always be improved! Right now there is just the
README and the creating plugins guide.
The wiki exists but is in a state of
disrepair. If you see something that can be improved please submit a pull
request or edit the wiki.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Thanks for contributing!
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Code of Conduct
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
We have a code of conduct that we all must
read. Be polite to everyone. If you are not in your best day, take a
deep breath and try again. Smile :smile:
Label: TC – Talk to the community

list of issues,
bug reports, or
feature requests.

click the Subscribe or Watching button to get notifications
via email.

If you have a compilation problem, you can ask in the

in the Community site for help
or creating a GitHub issue.

One of the easiest ways to contribute is writing articles,

to Aseprite e.g. naming Aseprite in your website and linking it to
https://www.aseprite.org/, following

documentation, and
contact us if you want to help

Paragraph: Hacking
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
The first thing to keep in mind if you want to modify the source code:
checkout the master branch. It is the branch that we use to
develop new features and fix issues that are planned for the next big
release. See the INSTALL guide to know how to compile.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
To start looking the source code, see how it is organized in
src/README.md
file.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Forking & Pull Requests
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
You can fork the GitHub repository using the Fork button at
https://github.com/aseprite/aseprite.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: The Pull Requests (PR) systems works in this way:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
1.  First of all you will need to sign our
Contributor License Agreement (CLA).
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
2.  Then you can start working on Aseprite. Create a new branch from master, e.g. fix-8 to fix the issue 8.
Check this guide about how to name your branch.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 3.  Start working on that new branch, and push your commits to your fork.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 4.  Create a new PR to merge your fix-8 branch to the official master.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
5.  If the PR is accepted (does not require review/comments/modifications),
your branch is merged into master.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
6.  You will need to pull changes from the official master branch, and
merge them in your own master branch. Finally you can discard your
own fix-8 branch (because those changes should be already merged
into master if the PR was accepted).
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 7.  Continue working from the new master head.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
To keep in mind: always start working from the master head, if you
want to fix three different issues, create three different branches
from master and then send three different PR. Do not chain all the
fixes in one single branch. E.g. fix-issues-3-and-8-and-25.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Community
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
You can use the Development category
to ask question about the code, how to compile, etc.
If you want to start working in something
(issue,
bug,
or feature),
post a comment asking if somebody is already working on that,
in that way you can avoid start programming in something that is already
done for the next release or which someone else is working on.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph:
And always remember to take a look at our
roadmap.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: ? Thank you for taking the time to contribute to the Boden Framework! ?

Paragraph: How can I Contribute?
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: There are many ways you can contribute to Boden. Here are some of them:
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: - Reporting Bugs
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: - Request an Enhancement
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: - Making your First Code Contribution
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: - Creating a Pull Request
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: Reporting Bugs
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Finding and reporting bugs in the Boden framework is an important contribution and we highly appreciate that you take the time to submit a meaningful bug report.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Here's how it works:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Create a GitHub issue to report a new bug.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Provide a clear and descriptive title that identifies the problem.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Let us know which version of Boden you used when you found the issue. If you've downloaded a release, please specify the release version, e.g. "v0.3". If you've cloned the boden git repository, please provide your current HEAD commit hash. (You can retrieve the current HEAD commit hash by executing git rev-parse HEAD in your local working tree.)
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Specify on which host and target operating system the problem occurred. Please include the version of the operating system(s) in your bug report. You can help us even more by checking whether the bug also occurs on other host/target platforms.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Specify the IDE (Xcode/Android Studio) you used when you found the problem.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Describe the exact steps that cause the problem. This allows us and others to reproduce the issue.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Describe the behavior you observed after following the steps and point out what exactly is the problem with that behavior.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Describe what behavior you expected to occur instead and why.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - If you are reporting a crash, please include a full stack trace.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Request an Enhancement
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Have you been looking for a certain feature in Boden and didn't find it in the framework yet? Did you use a Boden feature that works, but could be enhanced?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: In this case, please consider suggesting an enhancement. Feature and improvement requests help us a lot. They are one of the most important ways to help us determine whether we are on the right track with the framework. Even if you have only limited time, write us a line or two about what you think could be done to improve Boden.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Here's how you can submit an enhancement request:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Create a GitHub issue for each enhancement suggestion.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Use a clear and descriptive title that identifes the suggestion.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Explain why the enhancement would be useful to most Boden users.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Describe the current behavior and explain which behavior you expected to see and why.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Making your First Code Contribution
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: You want to develop an enhancement or fix a bug on your own? Great! Thank you for contributing to the Boden Framework.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Here are some resources to get you started:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Setting up a local build environment which you can use to work on Boden itself should be easy. Just follow the instructions on our Getting Started page.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: - We are currently working on a code style guide. Meanwhile, we may edit your PR to maintain consistency with the rest of the code.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Creating a Pull Request
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Important: Note that any code you submit to us is subject to our Contribution License Agreement.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Here's how to create a pull request:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Fork the boden repository.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Make your changes and commit them to the forked repository.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Create a pull request with base AshampooSystems/boden master (this should be the default).
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Please leave us a message describing what the PR is about.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - We'll review your PR as soon as possible and get back to you if needed.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Before Submitting an Issue
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: First, please do a search in open issues to see if the issue or feature request has already been filed.

Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: If you cannot find an existing issue that describes your bug or feature, submit an issue using the guidelines below.

Paragraph: Submitting an issue (bug)
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Be as clear and concise as possible.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Do not submit more than one bug in a single issue.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Clearly explain the following:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 1.  Action taken (what you did)
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 2.  Expected result (what you hoped would happen)
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 3.  Actual result (unexpected outcome)
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 4.  Your setup (any and all relevant technical facts, error messages, logs, etc)
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Feature requests
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - First consider if you yourself might be able to work on the feature?  If so, check out info on contributing code below.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - If you do not have the skills, then please take the time to clearly think through the request. Is is appropriate for all users of Gekko?  If so, create a new issue containing the following:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 1.  Write [request] as the first item in the title, followed by a short, concise description, eg: [request] Export data to CSV.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 2.  Fill in details explaining your request.  Be as clear and concise as possible and only 1 request at a time.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 3.  Add mock-ups, etc as needed to clearly demonstrate the idea.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Contributing to Astropy
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Reporting Issues
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
When opening an issue to report a problem, please try to provide a minimal code
example that reproduces the issue along with details of the operating
system and the Python, NumPy, and astropy versions you are using.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Contributing
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
So you are interested in contributing code to the Astropy Project? Excellent!
We love contributions! Astropy is open source, built on open source,
and we'd love to have you hang out in our community.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Imposter syndrome disclaimer: We want your help. No, really.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
There may be a little voice inside your head that is telling you that you're not
ready to be an open source contributor; that your skills aren't nearly good
enough to contribute. What could you possibly offer a project like this one?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
We assure you - the little voice in your head is wrong. If you can write code at
all, you can contribute code to open source. Contributing to open source
projects is a fantastic way to advance one's coding skills. Writing perfect code
isn't the measure of a good developer (that would disqualify all of us!); it's
trying to create something, making mistakes, and learning from those
mistakes. That's how we all improve, and we are happy to help others learn.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Being an open source contributor doesn't just mean writing code, either. You can
help out by writing documentation, tests, or even giving feedback about the
project (and yes - that includes giving feedback about the contribution
process). Some of these contributions may be the most valuable to the project as
a whole, because you're coming to the project with fresh eyes, so you can see
the errors and assumptions that seasoned contributors have glossed over.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Note: This disclaimer was originally written by
Adrienne Lowe for a
PyCon talk, and was adapted by
Astropy based on its use in the README file for the
MetPy project.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: How to Contribute, Best Practices
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
All contributions to Astropy are done via pull requests from GitHub users'
"forks" (i.e., copies) of the astropy repository. If you
are new to this style of development, you will want to read over our
development workflow.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
You may also/instead be interested in contributing to an
astropy affiliated package.
Affiliated packages are astronomy-related software packages that are not a part
of the astropy core package, but build on it for more specialized applications
and follow the Astropy guidelines for reuse, interoperability, and interfacing.
Each affiliated package has its own developers/maintainers and its own specific
guidelines for contributions, so be sure to read their docs.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
Once you open a pull request (which should be opened against the master
branch, not against any of the other branches), please make sure to
include the following:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
- Code: the code you are adding, which should follow
our coding guidelines as much as possible.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
- Tests: these are usually tests to ensure code that previously
failed now works (regression tests), or tests that cover as much as possible
of the new functionality to make sure it does not break in the future and
also returns consistent results on all platforms (since we run these tests on
many platforms/configurations). For more information about how to write
tests, see our testing guidelines.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
- Documentation: if you are adding new functionality, be sure to include a
description in the main documentation (in docs/). Again, we have some
detailed documentation guidelines to help you out.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
- Performance improvements: if you are making changes that impact astropy
performance, consider adding a performance benchmark in the
astropy-benchmarks
repository. You can find out more about how to do this
in the README for that repository.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
- Changelog entry: whether you are fixing a bug or adding new
functionality, you should add an entry to the CHANGES.rst file that
includes the PR number. If you are opening a pull request you may not know
the PR number yet, but you can add it once the pull request is open. If you
are not sure where to put the changelog entry, wait until a maintainer
has reviewed your PR and assigned it to a milestone.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
You do not need to include a changelog entry for fixes to bugs introduced in
the developer version and therefore are not present in the stable releases. In
general you do not need to include a changelog entry for minor documentation
or test updates. Only user-visible changes (new features/API changes, fixed
issues) need to be mentioned. If in doubt, ask the core maintainer reviewing
your changes.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Other Tips
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Behind the scenes, we conduct a number of tests or checks with new pull requests.
This is a technique that is called continuous integration, and we use Travis CI
and CircleCI. To prevent the automated tests from running, you can add [ci skip]
to your commit message. This is useful if your PR is a work in progress (WIP) and
you are not yet ready for the tests to run. For example:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: $ git commit -m "WIP widget [ci skip]"
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- If you already made the commit without including this string, you can edit
your existing commit message by running:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: $ git commit --amend
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - To skip only the tests running on Travis CI use [skip travis].
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- If your commit makes substantial changes to the documentation but no code
changes, then you can use [skip travis], which will skip Travis CI
because documentation build is done on CircleCI. The exception to this rule
is when your changes to documentation include code snippets that need to
be tested using doctest.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- When contributing trivial documentation fixes (i.e., fixes to typos, spelling,
grammar) that don't contain any special markup and are not associated with
code changes, please include the string [skip travis] in your commit
message.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: $ git commit -m "Fixed typo [skip travis]"
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Checklist for Contributed Code
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
A pull request for a new feature will be reviewed to see if it meets the
following requirements. For any pull request, an astropy maintainer can help
to make sure that the pull request meets the requirements for inclusion in the
package.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Scientific Quality (when applicable)
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Is the submission relevant to astronomy?
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Are references included to the origin source for the algorithm?
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Does the code perform as expected?
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Has the code been tested against previously existing implementations?
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Code Quality
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Are the coding guidelines followed?
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Is the code compatible with Python >=3.6?
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- Are there dependencies other than the astropy core, the Python Standard
Library, and NumPy 1.16.0 or later?
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Is the package importable even if the C-extensions are not built?
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Are additional dependencies handled appropriately?
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- Do functions that require additional dependencies raise an ImportError
if they are not present?
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Testing
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Are the testing guidelines followed?
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Are the inputs to the functions sufficiently tested?
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Are there tests for any exceptions raised?
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Are there tests for the expected performance?
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Are the sources for the tests documented?
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Have tests that require an optional dependency
been marked as such?
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Does tox -e test run without failures?
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Documentation
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Are the documentation guidelines followed?
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Is there a docstring in numpydoc format in the function describing:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - What the code does?
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - The format of the inputs of the function?
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - The format of the outputs of the function?
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - References to the original algorithms?
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Any exceptions which are raised?
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - An example of running the code?
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- Is there any information needed to be added to the docs to describe the
function?
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Does the documentation build without errors or warnings?
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: License
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Is the astropy license included at the top of the file?
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Are there any conflicts with this code and existing codes?
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Astropy requirements
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Do all the Travis CI and CircleCI tests pass?
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - If applicable, has an entry been added into the changelog?
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Can you check out the pull request and repeat the examples and tests?
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Contributor's Guide
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: If you're reading this, you're probably looking to contributing to Camelot. Time is the only real currency, and the fact that you're considering spending some here is very generous of you. Thank you very much!
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: This document will help you get started with contributing documentation, code, testing and filing issues. If you have any questions, feel free to reach out to Vinayak Mehta, the author and maintainer.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Code Of Conduct
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: The following quote sums up the Code Of Conduct.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Be cordial or be on your way. --Kenneth Reitz
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Kenneth Reitz has also written an essay on this topic, which you should read.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: As the Requests Code Of Conduct states, all contributions are welcome, as long as everyone involved is treated with respect.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Your first contribution
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: A great way to start contributing to Camelot is to pick an issue tagged with the help wanted tag or the good first issue tag. If you're unable to find a good first issue, feel free to contact the maintainer.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: Setting up a development environment
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: To install the dependencies needed for development, you can use pip:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Alternatively, you can clone the project repository, and install using pip:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Pull Requests
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Submit a pull request
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: The preferred workflow for contributing to Camelot is to fork the project repository on GitHub, clone, develop on a branch and then finally submit a pull request. Here are the steps:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 1.  Fork the project repository. Click on the
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 2.  Clone your fork of Camelot from your GitHub account:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 3.  Create a branch to hold your changes:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Always branch out from master to work on your contribution. It's good practice to never work on the master branch!
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Protip: git stash is a great way to save the work that you haven't committed yet, to move between branches.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 4.  Work on your contribution. Add changed files using git add and then git commit them:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 5.  Finally, push them to your GitHub fork:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Now it's time to go to the your fork of Camelot and create a pull request! You can follow these instructions to do this.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Work on your pull request
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: We recommend that your pull request complies with the following rules:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Make sure your code follows pep8.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - In case your pull request contains function docstrings, make sure you follow the numpydoc format. All function docstrings in Camelot follow this format. Moreover, following the format will make sure that the API documentation is generated flawlessly.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Make sure your commit messages follow the seven rules of a great git commit message:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Separate subject from body with a blank line
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Limit the subject line to 50 characters
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Capitalize the subject line
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Do not end the subject line with a period
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Use the imperative mood in the subject line
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Wrap the body at 72 characters
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Use the body to explain what and why vs. how
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Please prefix the title of your pull request with [MRG] (Ready for Merge), if the contribution is complete and ready for a detailed review. An incomplete pull request's title should be prefixed with [WIP] (to indicate a work in progress), and changed to [MRG] when it's complete. A good task list in the PR description will ensure that other people get a better idea of what it proposes to do, which will also increase collaboration.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - If contributing new functionality, make sure that you add a unit test for it, while making sure that all previous tests pass. Camelot uses pytest for testing. Tests can be run using:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Writing Documentation
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Writing documentation, function docstrings, examples and tutorials is a great way to start contributing to open-source software! The documentation is present inside the docs/ directory of the project repository.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: It is written in reStructuredText, with Sphinx used to generate these lovely HTML files that you're currently reading (unless you're reading this on GitHub). You can edit the documentation using any text editor and then generate the HTML output by running make html in the docs/ directory.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: The function docstrings are written using the numpydoc extension for Sphinx. Make sure you check out its format guidelines before you start writing one.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Filing Issues
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: We use GitHub issues to keep track of all issues and pull requests. Before opening an issue (which asks a question or reports a bug), please use GitHub search to look for existing issues (both open and closed) that may be similar.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Questions
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Please don't use GitHub issues for support questions. A better place for them would be Stack Overflow. Make sure you tag them using the python-camelot tag.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Bug Reports
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: In bug reports, make sure you include:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Your operating system type and Python version number, along with the version numbers of NumPy, OpenCV and Camelot. You can use the following code snippet to find this information:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - The complete traceback. Just adding the exception message or a part of the traceback won't help us fix your issue sooner.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Steps to reproduce the bug, using code snippets. See Creating and highlighting code blocks.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - A link to the PDF document that you were trying to extract tables from, telling us what you expected the code to do and what actually happened.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Thanks for considering contributing to react-beautiful-dnd! ??
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: There are a few categories of contribution so we'll go through them individually.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Documentation
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: If you think the docs could be improved - please feel free to raise a pull request!
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Bug
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: If you spot a bug you are welcome to raise it on our issue page. You are also welcome to take a crack at fixing it if you like! When you create an issue you will be prompted with the details we would like you to provide.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Feature request
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: If you would like to see a feature added to the library, here is what you do:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 1.  Have a read of README.md to understand the motivations of this library. It is fairly opinionated and is not intended to be a universal drag and drop library. As such, it will not support every drag and drop interaction.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 2.  Have a search through the open and closed issues to see if the feature you are requesting as already been requested.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 3.  Have a clear and general purpose keyboard story for any feature request
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 4.  Please create an issue to discuss it.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Please do not raise a pull request directly. There may be reasons why we will not add every feature to this library.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Large contributions
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: If you are interested in making a large contribution to this library there is some recommended reading / training we suggest. There is a large amount of different libraries, techniques and tools used in react-beautiful-dnd and we have created a list with resources about them. Not everything in the list will be applicable to everyone. But it is a great reference and starting point for those who do not know where to start.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: The online courses listed are no free - feel free to seek out alternatives if you want to. We recommend the egghead.io courses because they are quite comprehensive.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Drag and drop problem space
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: HTML5 drag and drop
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: How this library performs dragging is an implementation detail. The api is what users interact with. That said, this library does not use the html5 drag and drop api. The main reason is that html5 drag and drop does not allow the level of control we need to create our powerful and beautiful experiences. I could go into detail but this is not the right forum.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Here is some general reading about html5 drag and drop. It is worth having a read to get familiar with its ideas and api
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - HTML5 drag and drop api
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - HTML5 Rocks - dnd basics
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - The HTML5 drag and drop disaster
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - HTML5 drag and drop browser inconsistencies
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Prior work
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: It is worth looking at other libraries out there to see how they do drag and drop. Things to look at is their philosophy and api. react-beautiful-dnd is an opinionated, higher level abstraction than most drag and drop libraries. We do not need to support every use case. We need to find the right level of control while still maintaining a beautiful experience for the user, flexibility of use and a clean, powerful api.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - react-dnd - react-beautiful-dnd draws a fair amount of inspiration from react-dnd. Something to keep in mind is that react-dnd is designed to provide a set of drag and drop primitives which is a different set of goals to this project.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - react-sortable-hoc - on the surface this library looks similar to react-beautiful-dnd. I created a comparison blog that explains the differences
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - jQuery sortable - the king of drag and drop for a long time
Label: DC – Deal with the code
