Paragraph: What should I know before I get started?
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Atom and Packages
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Atom is a large open source project — it's made up of over 200 repositories. When you initially consider contributing to Atom, you might be unsure about which of those 200 repositories implements the functionality you want to change or report a bug for. This section should help you with that.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Atom is intentionally very modular. Nearly every non-editor UI element you interact with comes from a package, even fundamental things like tabs and the status-bar. These packages are packages in the same way that packages in the Atom package repository are packages, with one difference: they are bundled into the default distribution.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: atom-packages
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: To get a sense for the packages that are bundled with Atom, you can go to Settings > Packages within Atom and take a look at the Core Packages section.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Here's a list of the big ones:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - atom/atom - Atom Core! The core editor component is responsible for basic text editing (e.g. cursors, selections, scrolling), text indentation, wrapping, and folding, text rendering, editor rendering, file system operations (e.g. saving), and installation and auto-updating. You should also use this repository for feedback related to the Atom API and for large, overarching design proposals.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - tree-view - file and directory listing on the left of the UI.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - fuzzy-finder - the quick file opener.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - find-and-replace - all search and replace functionality.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - tabs - the tabs for open editors at the top of the UI.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - status-bar - the status bar at the bottom of the UI.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - markdown-preview - the rendered markdown pane item.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - settings-view - the settings UI pane item.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - autocomplete-plus - autocompletions shown while typing. Some languages have additional packages for autocompletion functionality, such as autocomplete-html.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - git-diff - Git change indicators shown in the editor's gutter.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - language-javascript - all bundled languages are packages too, and each one has a separate package language-[name]. Use these for feedback on syntax highlighting issues that only appear for a specific language.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - one-dark-ui - the default UI styling for anything but the text editor. UI theme packages (i.e. packages with a -ui suffix) provide only styling and it's possible that a bundled package is responsible for a UI issue. There are other bundled UI themes, such as one-light-ui.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - one-dark-syntax - the default syntax highlighting styles applied for all languages. There are other bundled syntax themes, such as solarized-dark-syntax. You should use these packages for reporting issues that appear in many languages, but disappear if you change to another syntax theme.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - apm - the apm command line tool (Atom Package Manager). You should use this repository for any contributions related to the apm tool and to publishing packages.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - atom.io - the repository for feedback on the Atom.io website and the Atom.io package API used by apm.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: There are many more, but this list should be a good starting point. For more information on how to work with Atom's official packages, see Contributing to Atom Packages.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Also, because Atom is so extensible, it's possible that a feature you've become accustomed to in Atom or an issue you're encountering isn't coming from a bundled package at all, but rather a community package you've installed. Each community package has its own repository too, the Atom FAQ has instructions on how to contact the maintainers of any Atom community package or theme.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Package Conventions
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: There are a few conventions that have developed over time around packages:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Packages that add one or more syntax highlighting grammars are named language-[language-name]
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Language packages can add other things besides just a grammar. Many offer commonly-used snippets. Try not to add too much though.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Theme packages are split into two categories: UI and Syntax themes
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - UI themes are named [theme-name]-ui
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Syntax themes are named [theme-name]-syntax
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Often themes that are designed to work together are given the same root name, for example: one-dark-ui and one-dark-syntax
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - UI themes style everything outside of the editor pane — all of the green areas in the packages image above
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Syntax themes style just the items inside the editor pane, mostly syntax highlighting
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Packages that add autocomplete providers are named autocomplete-[what-they-autocomplete] — ex: autocomplete-css
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Design Decisions
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: When we make a significant decision in how we maintain the project and what we can or cannot support, we will document it in the atom/design-decisions repository. If you have a question around how we do things, check to see if it is documented there. If it is not documented there, please open a new topic on Discuss, the official Atom message board and ask your question.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: How Can I Contribute?
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: Reporting Bugs
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: This section guides you through submitting a bug report for Atom. Following these guidelines helps maintainers and the community understand your report :pencil:, reproduce the behavior :computer: :computer:, and find related reports :mag_right:.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Before creating bug reports, please check this list as you might find out that you don't need to create one. When you are creating a bug report, please include as many details as possible. Fill out the required template, the information it asks for helps us resolve issues faster.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Note: If you find a Closed issue that seems like it is the same thing that you're experiencing, open a new issue and include a link to the original issue in the body of your new one.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Before Submitting A Bug Report
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Check the debugging guide. You might be able to find the cause of the problem and fix things yourself. Most importantly, check if you can reproduce the problem in the latest version of Atom, if the problem happens when you run Atom in safe mode, and if you can get the desired behavior by changing Atom's or packages' config settings.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Check the FAQs on the forum for a list of common questions and problems.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Determine which repository the problem should be reported in.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Perform a cursory search to see if the problem has already been reported. If it has and the issue is still open, add a comment to the existing issue instead of opening a new one.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: How Do I Submit A (Good) Bug Report?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Bugs are tracked as GitHub issues. After you've determined which repository your bug is related to, create an issue on that repository and provide the following information by filling in the template.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Explain the problem and include additional details to help maintainers reproduce the problem:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Use a clear and descriptive title for the issue to identify the problem.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Describe the exact steps which reproduce the problem in as many details as possible. For example, start by explaining how you started Atom, e.g. which command exactly you used in the terminal, or how you started Atom otherwise. When listing steps, don't just say what you did, but explain how you did it. For example, if you moved the cursor to the end of a line, explain if you used the mouse, or a keyboard shortcut or an Atom command, and if so which one?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Provide specific examples to demonstrate the steps. Include links to files or GitHub projects, or copy/pasteable snippets, which you use in those examples. If you're providing snippets in the issue, use Markdown code blocks.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Describe the behavior you observed after following the steps and point out what exactly is the problem with that behavior.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Explain which behavior you expected to see instead and why.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Include screenshots and animated GIFs which show you following the described steps and clearly demonstrate the problem. If you use the keyboard while following the steps, record the GIF with the Keybinding Resolver shown. You can use this tool to record GIFs on macOS and Windows, and this tool or this tool on Linux.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - If you're reporting that Atom crashed, include a crash report with a stack trace from the operating system. On macOS, the crash report will be available in Console.app under "Diagnostic and usage information" > "User diagnostic reports". Include the crash report in the issue in a code block, a file attachment, or put it in a gist and provide link to that gist.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - If the problem is related to performance or memory, include a CPU profile capture with your report.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - If Chrome's developer tools pane is shown without you triggering it, that normally means that you have a syntax error in one of your themes or in your styles.less. Try running in Safe Mode and using a different theme or comment out the contents of your styles.less to see if that fixes the problem.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - If the problem wasn't triggered by a specific action, describe what you were doing before the problem happened and share more information using the guidelines below.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Provide more context by answering these questions:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Can you reproduce the problem in safe mode?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Did the problem start happening recently (e.g. after updating to a new version of Atom) or was this always a problem?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - If the problem started happening recently, can you reproduce the problem in an older version of Atom? What's the most recent version in which the problem doesn't happen? You can download older versions of Atom from the releases page.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Can you reliably reproduce the issue? If not, provide details about how often the problem happens and under which conditions it normally happens.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - If the problem is related to working with files (e.g. opening and editing files), does the problem happen for all files and projects or only some? Does the problem happen only when working with local or remote files (e.g. on network drives), with files of a specific type (e.g. only JavaScript or Python files), with large files or files with very long lines, or with files in a specific encoding? Is there anything else special about the files you are using?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Include details about your configuration and environment:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Which version of Atom are you using? You can get the exact version by running atom -v in your terminal, or by starting Atom and running the Application: About command from the Command Palette.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - What's the name and version of the OS you're using?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Are you running Atom in a virtual machine? If so, which VM software are you using and which operating systems and versions are used for the host and the guest?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Which packages do you have installed? You can get that list by running apm list --installed.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Are you using local configuration files config.cson, keymap.cson, snippets.cson, styles.less and init.coffee to customize Atom? If so, provide the contents of those files, preferably in a code block or with a link to a gist.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Are you using Atom with multiple monitors? If so, can you reproduce the problem when you use a single monitor?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Which keyboard layout are you using? Are you using a US layout or some other layout?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Suggesting Enhancements
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: This section guides you through submitting an enhancement suggestion for Atom, including completely new features and minor improvements to existing functionality. Following these guidelines helps maintainers and the community understand your suggestion :pencil: and find related suggestions :mag_right:.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Before creating enhancement suggestions, please check this list as you might find out that you don't need to create one. When you are creating an enhancement suggestion, please include as many details as possible. Fill in the template, including the steps that you imagine you would take if the feature you're requesting existed.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Before Submitting An Enhancement Suggestion
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Check the debugging guide for tips the latest version of Atom and if you can get the desired behavior by changing Atom's or packages' config settings.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Check if there's already a package which provides that enhancement.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Determine which repository the enhancement should be suggested in.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Perform a cursory search to see if the enhancement has already been suggested. If it has, add a comment to the existing issue instead of opening a new one.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: How Do I Submit A (Good) Enhancement Suggestion?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Enhancement suggestions are tracked as GitHub issues. After you've determined which repository your enhancement suggestion is related to, create an issue on that repository and provide the following information:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Use a clear and descriptive title for the issue to identify the suggestion.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Provide a step-by-step description of the suggested enhancement in as many details as possible.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Provide specific examples to demonstrate the steps. Include copy/pasteable snippets which you use in those examples, as Markdown code blocks.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Describe the current behavior and explain which behavior you expected to see instead and why.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Include screenshots and animated GIFs which help you demonstrate the steps or point out the part of Atom which the suggestion is related to. You can use this tool to record GIFs on macOS and Windows, and this tool or this tool on Linux.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Explain why this enhancement would be useful to most Atom users and isn't something that can or should be implemented as a community package.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - List some other text editors or applications where this enhancement exists.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Specify which version of Atom you're using. You can get the exact version by running atom -v in your terminal, or by starting Atom and running the Application: About command from the Command Palette.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Specify the name and version of the OS you're using.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Pull Requests
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: The process described here has several goals:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Maintain Atom's quality
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Fix problems that are important to users
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Engage the community in working toward the best possible Atom
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Enable a sustainable system for Atom's maintainers to review contributions
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Please follow these steps to have your contribution considered by the maintainers:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: 1.  Follow all instructions in the template
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: 2.  Follow the styleguides
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: 3.  After you submit your pull request, verify that all status checks are passing What if the status checks are failing?If a status check is failing, and you believe that the failure is unrelated to your change, please leave a comment on the pull request explaining why you believe the failure is unrelated. A maintainer will re-run the status check for you. If we conclude that the failure was a false positive, then we will open an issue to track that problem with our status check suite.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: While the prerequisites above must be satisfied prior to having your pull request reviewed, the reviewer(s) may ask you to complete additional design work, tests, or other changes before your pull request can be ultimately accepted.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Styleguides
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Git Commit Messages
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Use the present tense ("Add feature" not "Added feature")
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Use the imperative mood ("Move cursor to..." not "Moves cursor to...")
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Limit the first line to 72 characters or less
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Reference issues and pull requests liberally after the first line
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - When only changing documentation, include [ci skip] in the commit title
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Consider starting the commit message with an applicable emoji:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - :art: :art: when improving the format/structure of the code
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - :racehorse: :racehorse: when improving performance
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - :non-potable_water: :non-potable_water: when plugging memory leaks
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - :memo: :memo: when writing docs
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - :penguin: :penguin: when fixing something on Linux
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - :apple: :apple: when fixing something on macOS
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - :checkered_flag: :checkered_flag: when fixing something on Windows
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - :bug: :bug: when fixing a bug
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - :fire: :fire: when removing code or files
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - :green_heart: :green_heart: when fixing the CI build
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - :white_check_mark: :white_check_mark: when adding tests
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - :lock: :lock: when dealing with security
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - :arrow_up: :arrow_up: when upgrading dependencies
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - :arrow_down: :arrow_down: when downgrading dependencies
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - :shirt: :shirt: when removing linter warnings
Label: SC – Submit the changes

# Public: Disable the package with the given name.
#

# * `options` (optional) The {Object} with disable options (default: {}):
#   * `trackTime`     A {Boolean}, `true` to track the amount of time taken.
#   * `ignoreErrors`  A {Boolean}, `true` to catch and ignore errors thrown.

#
# Returns `undefined`.
disablePackage: (name, options, callback) ->

Paragraph: Issue and Pull Request Labels
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: This section lists the labels we use to help us track and manage issues and pull requests. Most labels are used across all Atom repositories, but some are specific to atom/atom.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: GitHub search makes it easy to use labels for finding groups of issues or pull requests you're interested in. For example, you might be interested in open issues across atom/atom and all Atom-owned packages which are labeled as bugs, but still need to be reliably reproduced or perhaps open pull requests in atom/atom which haven't been reviewed yet. To help you find issues and pull requests, each label is listed with search links for finding open items with that label in atom/atom only and also across all Atom repositories. We  encourage you to read about other search filters which will help you write more focused queries.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: The labels are loosely grouped by their purpose, but it's not required that every issue have a label from every group or that an issue can't have more than one label from the same group.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Please open an issue on atom/atom if you have suggestions for new labels, and if you notice some labels are missing on some repositories, then please open an issue on that repository.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Type of Issue and Issue State
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
| Label name | atom/atom :mag_right: | atom?org :mag_right: | Description |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| enhancement | search | search | Feature requests. |
| bug | search | search | Confirmed bugs or reports that are very likely to be bugs. |
| question | search | search | Questions more than bug reports or feature requests (e.g. how do I do X). |
| feedback | search | search | General feedback more than bug reports or feature requests. |
| help-wanted | search | search | The Atom core team would appreciate help from the community in resolving these issues. |
| beginner | search | search | Less complex issues which would be good first issues to work on for users who want to contribute to Atom. |
| more-information-needed | search | search | More information needs to be collected about these problems or feature requests (e.g. steps to reproduce). |
| needs-reproduction | search | search | Likely bugs, but haven't been reliably reproduced. |
| blocked | search | search | Issues blocked on other issues. |
| duplicate | search | search | Issues which are duplicates of other issues, i.e. they have been reported before. |
| wontfix | search | search | The Atom core team has decided not to fix these issues for now, either because they're working as intended or for some other reason. |
| invalid | search | search | Issues which aren't valid (e.g. user errors). |
| package-idea | search | search | Feature request which might be good candidates for new packages, instead of extending Atom or core Atom packages. |
| wrong-repo | search | search | Issues reported on the wrong repository (e.g. a bug related to the Settings View package was reported on Atom core). |
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Topic Categories
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
| Label name | atom/atom :mag_right: | atom?org :mag_right: | Description |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| windows | search | search | Related to Atom running on Windows. |
| linux | search | search | Related to Atom running on Linux. |
| mac | search | search | Related to Atom running on macOS. |
| documentation | search | search | Related to any type of documentation (e.g. API documentation and the flight manual). |
| performance | search | search | Related to performance. |
| security | search | search | Related to security. |
| ui | search | search | Related to visual design. |
| api | search | search | Related to Atom's public APIs. |
| uncaught-exception | search | search | Issues about uncaught exceptions, normally created from the Notifications package. |
| crash | search | search | Reports of Atom completely crashing. |
| auto-indent | search | search | Related to auto-indenting text. |
| encoding | search | search | Related to character encoding. |
| network | search | search | Related to network problems or working with remote files (e.g. on network drives). |
| git | search | search | Related to Git functionality (e.g. problems with gitignore files or with showing the correct file status). |
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: atom/atom Topic Categories
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
| Label name | atom/atom :mag_right: | atom?org :mag_right: | Description |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| editor-rendering | search | search | Related to language-independent aspects of rendering text (e.g. scrolling, soft wrap, and font rendering). |
| build-error | search | search | Related to problems with building Atom from source. |
| error-from-pathwatcher | search | search | Related to errors thrown by the pathwatcher library. |
| error-from-save | search | search | Related to errors thrown when saving files. |

| work-in-progress | search | search | Pull requests which are still being worked on, more changes will follow. |
| needs-review | search | search | Pull requests which need code review, and approval from maintainers or Atom core team. |

Paragraph: Contribution Copyrights and Licensing

Paragraph: To make a code contribution to the Atomic Game Engine
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Fork the Atomic Game Engine Github repository and make your changes.  Use a well named topic branch for the changes, preferably with uppercase and dashes, use your initials at the beginning of the branch name e.g. JME-EDITOR-FIXES.  Fork off the master branch.  Avoid forking from repository work branches as they may get rebased.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Test your changes as thoroughly as possible.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Please follow the code style for the language you are working in and try to match the general structure of Atomic code.  Check that your diff looks as clean and minimal as possible.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Add yourself to the end of the "Contributors" list in AUTHORS.md if you're not already on the list.  By doing this you confirm that:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
- You own the rights to the contribution, or have the legal right to
license the contribution under the Atomic Game Engine Contribution License CONTRIBUTION_LICENSE.md on behalf of the copyright owner(s).
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - You, or the copyright owner(s), agree to irrevocably license the contribution under the Atomic Game Engine Contribution License CONTRIBUTION_LICENSE.md
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Please include a link to your GitHub profile to allow your contribution to be identified accurately.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
- Create a pull request in Github.  For now, the "base branch" should be
"master", i.e. the pull requests are merged directly to the master branch.
In the description:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Summarize the change and the motivation for the change.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Opening Issues
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Whenever you find a bug in atoum or think of a new feature you may open an issue in the bug tracker.

Paragraph: Reporting bug
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: When reporting a bug, you should provide as much relevant informations as possible. This includes (but is not limited to):
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - PHP Version (php -v),
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - xDebug version (if loaded),
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - atoum version (sha1, phar, tag): get it with bin/atoum --version or php atoum.phar --version or git rev-parse --short HEAD,
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - A minimum (non) working example,
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - A clear description of the problem,
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Expected and actual results.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: You must also provide a descriptive title.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Here is an example issue:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: # Chaining multiple hasConstant assertions fails
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
|               |              |
|---------------|--------------|
| atoum version | `dev-master` |
| atoum SHA1    | `cbf9821`    |
| PHP version   | `PHP 5.3.29` |
| xDebug        | not loaded   |
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: When chaining multiple `hasConstant` assertions atoum reports the following error: `Asserter 'hasConstant' does not exist`
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: ## Example
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: <?php
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: namespace atoum\shou\tests\units;
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: use atoum;
Label: No categories identified.
No categories identified.

Paragraph: ->testedClass
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: ->hasConstant('runStart')->isEqualTo('runnerStart')
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: ->hasConstant('runStop')->isEqualTo('runnerStop')
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: ->extends('atoum\shou\observable')
Label: No categories identified.
No categories identified.

Paragraph: ## Actual result
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
There is 1 error:
=> atoum\shou\tests\units\runner::testClass():
==> Error E_USER_ERROR in code.php on line 13, generated by file test.php on line 37:
Asserter 'hasConstant' does not exist
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: ## Expected result
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Test should either pass or fail nicely, without a non-handled error.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Requesting a new feature
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: When requesting a new feature you should ensute that it does not already exist in atoum or any extension.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: You must provide a valid use case for the feature and it must be compliant with atoum's mantra (modern, simple and intuitive).
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: You should also provide code snippets to illustrate your need and how the feature will be used from a user point of view.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: You may also link to external resources or other tools providing similar features to help reviewers.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Sending Pull Requests
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: To be accepted your code contribution must follow atoum's coding style.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: You must write unit tests to cover your modifications.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Your commit history should be as clean as possible:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - You should squash your commits to hide non-valudable commits (coding style fix, unit tests,
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - You should rebase your branch on top of master to make your pull-request fast-forward,
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - You must add a changelog entry.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
You must also provide a descriptive title and a description for your changes. It may include code snippets to illustrate how to use
the feature you added.

Paragraph: Coding style
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Coding style respects the PSR-2 recommendation, in addition to some other fixers provided by the PHP CS Fixer tool.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: To check the coding style, please run the following script:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Label: DC – Deal with the code

Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Check if method exists,
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: You must ensure a consistent behavior on all supported version. If it is not possible, you must ensure a correct behavior.

Paragraph: Naming Conventions

Protected or private properties and methods must not use an underscore prefix.

Paragraph: Bug Reports
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: If you encounter a bug in Attendize, please first search the list of current open Issues on the GitHub repository. You may add additional feedback on an existing bug report. If the issue you're having has not yet been reported, please open a new issue. There is a template available for new issues. Please fill out all information requested in the template so we can help you more easily.

Paragraph: Support
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Please note: support is not offered from the project maintainers through GitHub. Paid support is available by purchasing a license. You may submit support requests in a GitHub issue to see if someone in the community is able to offer help or advice. Support issues will be automatically closed after 7 days to keep the size of the issues list down.

Please ensure you add or update the tests along with your changes, as well as documentation if it's applicable.

Paragraph: Getting started
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Ready to get started? The below sections take you through the steps required to get the framework running on your local development environment, and run the associated tests.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Building The Code
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: To build the code, follow these steps.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 1.  Ensure that NodeJS is installed. This provides the platform on which the build tooling runs.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 2.  From the project folder, execute the following command:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: npm install
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 3.  Ensure that Gulp is installed. If you need to install it, use the following command:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: npm install -g gulp
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 4.  To build the code, you can now run:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: gulp build
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 5.  You will find the compiled code in the dist folder, available in several different module formats.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 6.  See gulpfile.js for other available tasks.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Running The Tests
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: To run the unit tests, first ensure that you have followed the steps above in order to install all dependencies and successfully build the library. Once you have done that, proceed with these additional steps:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 1.  Ensure that the Karma CLI is installed. If you need to install it, use the following command:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: npm install -g karma-cli
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 2.  Ensure that jspm is installed. If you need to install it, use the following command:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: npm install -g jspm
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 3.  Install the client-side dependencies with jspm:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: jspm install
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 4.  You can now run the tests with this command:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: karma start
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Filing issues
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
The best way to get your bug fixed is to be as detailed as you can be about the problem.
Providing a minimal project with steps to reproduce the problem is ideal.
Here are questions you can answer before you file a bug to make sure you're not missing any important information.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 1.  Did you read the documentation?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 2.  Did you include the snippet of broken code in the issue?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 3.  What are the EXACT steps to reproduce this problem (including source/destination types, mapping configuration and execution)?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: GitHub supports markdown, so when filing bugs make sure you check the formatting before clicking submit.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: We only accept PRs to the master branch.

Paragraph: Before submitting a feature or substantial code contribution please discuss it with the team and ensure it follows the product roadmap. Here's a list of blog posts that are worth reading before doing a pull request:

Label: SC – Submit the changes

Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - 10 tips for better Pull Requests by Mark Seemann
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - How to write the perfect pull request by GitHub

Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Redux and Typescript
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
The Redux store shall be fully-typed to provide safety and to enable auto-completion and automated bug-discovery in an IDE.
Please follow these examples when creating new parts of app state and when connecting through react-redux.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Importing Types
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Try to keep type imports consistent across different modules.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: action-types contains the list of possible action types, not surprisingly, as well as the helper types for writing action creators and reducers.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: import * as A from '../state/action-types';
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: state contains the shape of the global Redux state object and the helpers for using react-redux's connect() wrapper.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: import * as S from '../state';
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: types contains app-wide type definitions including those for the Simplenote data models, the UI behaviors, and common language/platform helpers.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: import * as T from '../types';
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Defining Component Prop Types
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
There are multiple legitimate ways to type a React component.
In this project we shall explicitly define the prop types by separating out the props we expect to be passed down from a parent component, to come from app state, to dispatch actions, and to be used internally in component state.
The names match the terminology used by react-redux
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: import * as T from '../types';
Label: DC – Deal with the code
DC – Deal with the code
DC – Deal with the code
DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: type Props = OwnProps & StateProps & DispatchProps;
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: export class MyComponent extends Component<Props> {
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
StateProps need not mirror the types of elements in the global app state.
These types are specifying the component API and so if we have mismatches we are responsible for transforming values inside mapStateToProps.
It can be convenient to draw a type from the Redux app state but doing so will weaken the contract for the component.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
DispatchProps identify what actions or side effects a component expects to be able to make.
In almost all cases these will be "fire and forget" functions with no specific demands on their return values.
For example, we might send spies in a test file and this is fine according to the component.
Leave the type of DispatchProps relaxed to keep this flexibility.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
Most components don't utilize any form of local state and so we don't need to define such a type for the sake of having the type.
Similarly, if there are no props being passed down from a parent component there's no need to creaet OwnProps.
As a general rule if you find yourself creating an empty type then you should be able to leave it out.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: In this example our component only depends on a single value from app state and so the only type we're creating is StateProps.
Label: DC – Deal with the code
DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: type Props = StateProps;
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Should we use this.state inside a component then we shall create its type.
Label: DC – Deal with the code
DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: For the special case of Refs create the type in the component and provide the optional node type dependent on what is receiving the ref.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
export class Input extends Component {
entry = createRef<HTMLInputElement>();
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Connecting React components to Redux
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Components shall use the helpers from state in combination with the defined component types to provide typing.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: import * as S from '../state';
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Prefer the object form of mapDispatchToProps over the function form unless you can't avoid it.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: If your prop-mapping functions don't depend on OwnProps it is safe to leave that out of the type annotation.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Creating Reducers
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
When adding new values into the global Redux app state we need to create a reducer to manage that data type.
Use the Reducer helper type to define the type of the property being added to state.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
import * as A from '../action-types';
import * as T from '../../types';
Label: DC – Deal with the code
DC – Deal with the code
DC – Deal with the code
DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
case 'TRASH_NOTE':
return null;
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
case 'FILTER_NOTES':
return action.filteredNotes.has(state) ? state : null;
Label: DC – Deal with the code
DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Creating Action Types
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
Each state transition in the app should follow a semantically-oriented Redux ction.
When creating new actions add the type specifying that action in action-types.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: import * as T from '../types';
Label: DC – Deal with the code
DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: After defining the named action type add it to the type of "any possible action."
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: export type ActionType = CreateNote | TrashNote | FilterNotes | SetListMode;
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Creating Action Creators
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
Action creators should return dispatch-able actions.
We should not create new thunk-returning actions.
We shall annotate our action-creators with the ActionCreator helper type and specify the types of actions it might return for dispatch.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
import * as A from '../action-types';
import * as T from '../../types';
Label: DC – Deal with the code
DC – Deal with the code
DC – Deal with the code

yarn

Paragraph: 3. Develop

Paragraph: 4. Test
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
Once you're done making your changes be sure to make some tests and run all of them. What I do is open up 3 different panes in the same iTerm2 window by pressing ? + D on mac 2 times. In the far left I do yarn build:watch, in the middle I do yarn test:browser:watch (where you'll probably be writing your tests) and in the 3rd window I do yarn test:server:watch. It looks like this.
image
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: How can I contribute?

Paragraph: Improve documentation
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: As a user of AVA you're the perfect candidate to help us improve our documentation. Typo corrections, error fixes, better explanations, more examples, etc. Open issues for things that could be improved. Help translate our docs. Anything. Even improvements to this document.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Use the scope:documentation label to find suggestions for what we'd love to see more documentation on.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Improve issues
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Some issues are created with missing information, not reproducible, or plain invalid. Help make them easier to resolve. Handling issues takes a lot of time that we could rather spend on fixing bugs and adding features.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Give feedback on issues
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: We're always looking for more opinions on discussions in the issue tracker. It's a good opportunity to influence the future direction of AVA.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: The needs triage and question labels are a good place to find ongoing discussions.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Help out
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: You can use issue labels to discover issues you could help out with:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - blocked issues need help getting unstuck
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - bug issues are known bugs we'd like to fix
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - enhancement issues are features we're open to including
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - performance issues track ideas on how to improve AVA's performance
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: The help wanted and good for beginner labels are especially useful.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: You may find an issue is assigned. Please double-check before starting on this issue because somebody else is likely already working on it.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: We'd like to fix priority issues first. We'd love to see progress on low-priority issues too. future issues are those that we'd like to get to, but not anytime soon. Please check before working on these since we may not yet want to take on the burden of supporting those features.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: Read on for tips on contributing code.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Hang out in our chat
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: We have a chat. Jump in there and lurk, talk to us, and help others.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Contributing code
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Once you find an issue you'd like to work on leave a comment so others are aware. We'll then assign you to the issue.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Of course you can work on things that do not yet have an issue. However if you're going to be putting in a lot of effort it's best to discuss it first.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: When you're ready to get feedback on your work, open a draft pull request. It's fine if the work's not yet done, but please do let us know what's remaining. This lets reviewers know not to nit-pick small details or point out improvements you already know you need to make.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Reviewing large pull requests can take a lot of time. Time that may not always be available. Smaller pull requests may land more quickly. If you're introducing a new feature think about how it might be broken up. It's OK to land features as opt-in experiments. These require less documentation and test coverage.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Try and avoid making breaking changes. Those take more time to ship. Instead make the new behavior opt-in. This way your feature can ship, and you can use it, on its own schedule.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Non-experimental features should be accompanied with tests and documentation.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Don't include unrelated changes in your pull request. Make sure tests pass on your machine by running npm test. You can run specific test files as well using npx tap test-tap/{file}.js or npx test-ava test/{file}.js.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: When you make a pull request please use a clear and descriptive title. Be specific about what's changed and why.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Please make sure the Allow edits from maintainers box is checked. That way we can make certain minor changes ourselves, allowing your pull request to be merged sooner.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: You might be asked to make changes to your pull request. There's never a need to open another pull request. Push more commits to your existing branch. We'll squash them when we merge the PR.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Dependencies are managed using npm. Only update dependencies when needed for your pull request. Don't rebuild the lockfile.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: And finally, have fun!
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Style
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: The codebase uses .net core coding style.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
Try to keep lines of code around 100 characters in length or less, though this is not a hard limit.
If you're a few characters over then don't worry too much.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: DO NOT USE #REGIONS full stop.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Pull requests
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
A single pull request should be submitted for each change. If you're making more than one change,
please submit separate pull requests for each change for easy review. Rebase your changes to make
sense, so a history that looks like:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Add class A
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Feature A didn't set Foo when Bar was set
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Fix spacing
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Add class B
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Sort using statements
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Should be rebased to read:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Add class A
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Add class B
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Again, this makes review much easier.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Please try not to submit pull requests that don't add new features (e.g. moving stuff around)
unless you see something that is obviously wrong or that could be written in a more terse or
idiomatic style. It takes time to review each pull request - time that I'd prefer to spend writing
new features!
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Prefer terseness to verbosity but don't try to be too clever.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Label: SC – Submit the changes

Unit test methods should be named in a sentence style, separated by underscores, that describes in
English what the test is testing, e.g.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

If you would like to implement support for a significant feature that is not yet available, please talk to us beforehand to avoid any duplication of effort.

Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Before submitting PR make sure to run yarn on the root of monorepo to ensure that commit lint and husky are installed.

Paragraph: Make sure you follow conventional commits commit message structure. You can automatically generate conventional commit message by running yarn commit in the root of the amplify mono repo. This will run through series of question shown below
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
? Select the type of change that you're committing: <type of commit (if its a feature, bug fix etc.,>
? What is the scope of this change (e.g. component or file name)? <package name if change is only in one package>
? Write a short, imperative tense description of the change: <short description with length less than 72 char>
? Provide a longer description of the change: (press enter to skip) <long description>
? Are there any breaking changes? Y/N
? Does this change affect any open issues? Y/N
? Add issue references (e.g. "fix #123", "re #123".): <issue number if exists>
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Please ensure that your change still passes unit tests, and ideally integration/UI tests. It's OK if you're still working on tests at the time that you submit, but be prepared to be asked about them. Wherever possible, pull requests should contain tests as appropriate. Bugfixes should contain tests that exercise the corrected behavior (i.e., the test should fail without the bugfix and pass with it), and new features should be accompanied by tests exercising the feature.

Paragraph: Our History and Ethos
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: AWS Amplify aims to enhance the development experience using JavaScript with AWS. Amplify codifies best practices through programmatic interfaces to help you effortlessly interact with cloud resources.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: First and foremost Amplify exposes to you WHAT things do and then HOW best to do them. The WHAT is at a functional use case with HOW being an opinionated implementation that you can override with
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Opinionated implementations: There are many ways to interface with AWS Services. Certain service interactions are favored over others. For instance, if sending and receiving JSON, we would prefer an API Gateway endpoint to other mechanisms. Amplify will programmatically help optimize for cost and performance through library decisions.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Declarative actions: Amplify will provide you a reference to a generic client object and the ability to perform common actions.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Cascading service interactions: Certain actions in a declarative style can have overlapping or ambiguous AWS Service implementations. With an opinionated implementation, we can decide which Services are "primary" and which are "secondary" depending on what is configured. For instance, sending an image will prefer S3 over API Gateway.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Simple, standard data objects: Sending & receiving data to AWS Services can have many parameters, which tend to show up in the SDKs. These are abstracted and inferred, where possible, with simple JSON that the implementation can reason about. Standard parameters (bucket names, stream names, partition keys, etc.) that are part of the implementation are extracted from a simplified configuration file and dynamically generated/updated in order to further allow focus on state and data types only.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Our Design
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: As more and more modules were introduced to AWS Amplify, it became necessary to modularize the library into smaller pieces so that users could avoid importing unnecessary parts into their app. The goal of this design is to make AWS Amplify modularized and also keep it backward-compatible to avoid breaking changes.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Modular import prevents unnecessary code dependencies from being included with the app, and thus decreases the bundle size while enabling added new functionality without the risk of introducing errors related to unused code.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Amplify has established the concepts of categories and plugins. A category is a collection of api calls that are exposed to the client to do things inside that category. For example, in the storage category, generally one wants to upload and download objects from storage so the apis exposed to the client will represent that functionality. Because Amplify is pluggable, a plugin of your choosing will provide the actual implementation behind that api interface. Using the same example of Storage, the plugin we choose might be AWSStoragePlugin which would then implement each api call from the category with a service call or set of service calls to S3, the underlying storage provider of the AWS plugin.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Development Process
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Our work is done directly on Github and PR's are sent to the github repo by core team members and contributors. Everyone undergoes the same review process to get their changes into the repo.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

$ git clone git@github.com:[username]/amplify-js.git

$ yarn bootstrap
$ yarn build

Yarn Linking

Paragraph: Verdaccio
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Verdaccio is a lightweight private npm proxy registry built in Node.js. Install Verdaccio. You can setup veradaccio to publish packages locally to test the changes.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: To publish in Verdaccio, start a verdaccio instance and then,
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
npm set registry http://localhost:4873/
yarn lerna publish --skip-git --force-publish
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: To publish a local version of a specific package,
Label: SC – Submit the changes

cd packages/<category>
npm publish --registry http://localhost:4873 (http://localhost:4873/)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Once you are done with Verdaccio, you can reset to npm registry by doing,
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: npm set registry https://registry.npmjs.com/
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Pull Requests
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: This is mostly the same as
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: [Skip step 1 to 3 if you have already done this]
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 1.  Fork aws-amplify/amplify-js
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 2.  Clone your fork locally: git clone git@github.com:YOUR_GITHUB_USERNAME/amplify-js.git
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 3.  Run yarn && yarn bootstrap in the repository root
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 4.  Within your fork, create a new branch based on the issue (e.g. Issue #123) you're addressing - git checkout -b "group-token/short-token-[branch-name]" or git checkout -b "short-token/[branch-name]"
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Use grouping tokens at the beginning of the branch names. _For e.g, if you are working on changes specific to amplify-ui-components, then you could start the branch name as ui-components/...
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - short token
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - feat
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - chore
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - bug
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - use slashes to seperate parts of branch names
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Hyphenate well defined branch name
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
5.  Once your work is committed and you're ready to share, run test yarn test.
Note: Manually test your changes in a sample app with different edge cases and also test across different browsers and platform
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 6.  Then, Push your branch git push origin -u
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 7.  This previous step will give you a URL to view a GitHub page in your browser. Copy-paste this, and complete the workflow in the UI. It will invite you to "create a PR" from your newly published branch. Fill out the PR template to submit a PR.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
8.  Finally, the Amplify JS team will review your PR. Add reviewers based on the core member who is tracking the issue with you or code owners.
In the meantime, address any automated check that fail (such as linting, unit tests, etc. in CI)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Debugging
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Sometimes the issue can be solved by doing a clean and fresh build. To do this, make sure to remove your node modules and clean your packages. You can run git clean -xdf in the repository root to achieve this.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Contributing Guidelines
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Thank you for your interest in contributing to our project. Whether it's a bug report, new feature, correction, or additional
documentation, we greatly value feedback and contributions from our community.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Please read through this document before submitting any issues or pull requests to ensure we have all the necessary
information to effectively respond to your bug report or contribution.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Reporting Bugs/Feature Requests
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: We welcome you to use the GitHub issue tracker to report bugs or suggest features.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
When filing an issue, please check existing open, or recently closed, issues to make sure somebody else hasn't already
reported the issue. Please try to include as much information as you can. Details like these are incredibly useful:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - A reproducible test case or series of steps
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - The version of our code being used
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Any modifications you've made relevant to the bug
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Anything unusual about your environment or deployment
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Contributing via Pull Requests
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Contributions via pull requests are much appreciated. Before sending us a pull request, please ensure that:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 1.  You are working against the latest source on the master branch.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 2.  You check existing open, and recently merged, pull requests to make sure someone else hasn't addressed the problem already.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 3.  You open an issue to discuss any significant work - we would hate for your time to be wasted.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: To send us a pull request, please:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 1.  Ensure you are considering a change to AWS source code (FreeRTOS kernel, AWS libraries).  Proposed changes to 3rd party code should be submitted instead to the 3rd party.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 2.  Fork the repository.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 3.  Modify the source; please focus on the specific change you are contributing. If you also reformat all the code, it will be hard for us to focus on your change.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 4.  Ensure local tests pass.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 5.  Commit to your fork using clear commit messages.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 6.  Send us a pull request, answering any default questions in the pull request interface.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 7.  Pay attention to any automated CI failures reported in the pull request, and stay involved in the conversation.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
GitHub provides additional document on forking a repository and
creating a pull request.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Getting Your Pull Request Merged
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: All Pull Requests must be approved by our review team before it can be merged in. We appreciate your patience while pull requests are reviewed as the time taken will depend on its complexity and wider implications.
Label: SC – Submit the changes
