Paragraph: Reporting Bugs/Feature Requests
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: We welcome you to use the GitHub issue tracker to report bugs or suggest features.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
When filing an issue, please check existing open, or recently closed, issues to make sure somebody else hasn't already
reported the issue. Please try to include as much information as you can. Details like these are incredibly useful:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - A reproducible test case or series of steps
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - The version of our code being used
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Any modifications you've made relevant to the bug
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Anything unusual about your environment or deployment
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Contributing via Pull Requests
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Contributions via pull requests are much appreciated. Before sending us a pull request, please ensure that:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 1.  You are working against the latest source on the master branch.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 2.  You check existing open, and recently merged, pull requests to make sure someone else hasn't addressed the problem already.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 3.  You open an issue to discuss any significant work - we would hate for your time to be wasted.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: To send us a pull request, please:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 1.  Fork the repository.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 2.  Modify the source; please focus on the specific change you are contributing. If you also reformat all the code, it will be hard for us to focus on your change.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 3.  Ensure local tests pass.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 4.  Commit to your fork using clear commit messages.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 5.  Send us a pull request, answering any default questions in the pull request interface.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 6.  Pay attention to any automated CI failures reported in the pull request, and stay involved in the conversation.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
GitHub provides additional document on forking a repository and
creating a pull request.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Label: CT – Choose a task

Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: Contribution Guide
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
cdk8s is licensed under Apache 2.0 and accepts contributions via
GitHub pull requests. This document outlines some of the conventions on commit
message formatting, contact points for developers, and other resources to help
get contributions into cdk8s.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
You can contribute to cdk8s in many ways. Contributions of all shapes and sizes are
welcome and celebrated:
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: - Reporting Issues
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: - Code Contributions
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: - RFCs
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: - For Maintainers
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph:
We follows the CNCF Community Code of
Conduct
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Reporting Issues
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
If any part of the project has bugs or documentation mistakes, please let us
know by raising an issue. We treat bugs and mistakes very seriously
and believe no issue is too small. Before creating a bug report, please check
that an issue reporting the same problem does not already exist.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
An issue can either be a bug report or a suggestion. If you wish to ask
a question or seek guidance, please consider one of the other support
channels.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Bug reports
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
To make the bug report accurate and easy to understand, please try to create bug
reports that are:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- Specific: Include as much details as possible: which version, what
environment, what configuration, etc.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- Reproducible: Include the steps to reproduce the problem. We understand
some issues might be hard to reproduce, please includes the steps that might
lead to the problem. If possible, please provide a minimal code snippet that
reproduces the bug.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- Isolated: Please try to isolate and reproduce the bug with minimum
dependencies. It would significantly slow down the speed to fix a bug if too
many dependencies are involved in a bug report.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Unique: Do not duplicate existing bug report.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- Scoped: One bug per report. Do not follow up with another bug inside one
report.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
We might ask for further information to locate a bug. A duplicated bug report
will be closed.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Submit a bug report here.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Suggestions
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
We also accept suggestions for new features or missing capabilities as GitHub
issues. The most important aspect of a suggestion issue is to provide as many
details as possible about your use case and less focus on the solution. It
is usually possible to support different use cases in many different ways, and
we need to understand the motivation before we dive into a solution.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
If you wish to suggest a major change to the project, please consider to submit
an RFC instead of a simple issue. An RFC also starts with a GitHub
issue.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Submit a suggestion here
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Code Contributions

Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 1.  Submit/find an issue
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 3.  Make your code change
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 4.  Write tests & update docs
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 6.  Submit a pull request
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 7.  (Iterate)
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 8.  Your PR will be approved and merged
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Tracking issue
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: All pull requests should be tracked with a GitHub issue.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph:
You should search for an existing
issue or raise a new
bug or suggestion.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph:
Add a comment indicating you are willing to pick it up in order to ensure no one
else is currently working on it.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph:
If this is a major contribution, consider submitting an RFC to obtain
feedback from the community and maintainers.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: Development environment
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Prerequisites:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Prepare your environment:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 1.  Fork this repo and obtain a local clone.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 2.  Install all dependencies: yarn install
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 3.  Run yarn build to build all modules.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Linking against this repository
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
The script ./tools/link-all.sh can be used to generate symlinks to all modules in this repository under some node_module
directory. This can be used to develop against this repo as a local dependency.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: One can use the postinstall script to symlink this repo:
Label: BW – Build local workspace
BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
This assumes this repo is a sibling of the target repo and will install the CDK as a linked dependency during
yarn install.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Testing
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: This project includes per-module unit tests and project-wide integration tests.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Unit tests
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Unit tests are located under the test/ directory within each module and use the jest framework.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: To run unit tests, execute yarn test either from the root of the repo (to unit test all modules) or from individual module directories:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: yarn test
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Out tests utilize jest snapshot testing. In case a snapshot needs to be updated, just run:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: yarn test -u
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Integration tests
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Integration tests are executed after we bundle the release. This means that in order to execute integration tests you'll need to create a bundle by running the following command from the root of the repo:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: yarn run package
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: This will result in ./dist that contains all the ready-to-publish artifacts.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Now, you can run integration tests via:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: yarn integ
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Our integration tests also utilize snapshot testing. To update integration test snapshots, run:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: yarn integ:update
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Read this for more details about integration testing in this project.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Pull Requests
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
We use the PR title when we automatically generate the change log for each
release. Therefore please following these guidelines to the letter:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - PR title:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Must adhere to conventional
commits.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - All lowercase with no period at the end of the title
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - If this is a fix (bug) the title should describe the bug
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - If this is a feat (feature) the title should describe the feature
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - PR description:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Describe how did you fix the bug or what changes you had to make in order to
implement the feature
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Indicate fixes #NNN or resolves #NNN with the tracking issue number.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- If you had to test your change manually, describe how you tested it and
paste the test results.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- If this is a breaking change, the last paragraph should describe the
breaking change with the prefix BREAKING CHANGE: xxxxxx.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: RFCs
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
An RFC (request for comments) is a document that proposes and details a change
or addition to cdk8s. It also is a process for reviewing and discussing the
proposal and tracking its implementation. "Request for comments" means a request
for discussion and oversight about the future of cdk8s from contributors and
users. It is an open forum for suggestions, questions, and feedback.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: To create an RFC follow this process:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 1.  Create an issue which will be the tracking issue for this RFC.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Title should represent the title of the RFC.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Description should provide the motivation for the RFC.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
2.  Create a markdown file based off of
rfc/0000-template.md under the
rfc/<nnnn>-<title-of-rfc> where <nnnn> is the tracking issue number and
<title-of-rfc> is a symbolic name for the title. For example:
rfc/0030-construct-operators.md.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
3.  File a pull request with this markdown file. The title of the PR should
indicate rfc: <nnnn> <same as issue title>.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
4.  The RFC will be reviewed as a pull request and once merged it means it is
ready for implementation.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: For Maintainers
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: This section includes information that is relevant for the maintainers of the project.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Version
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
The current version of the project is mastered in the root lerna.json file. All other
package.json files use 0.0.0. This allows bumping a new version without
needing to modify multiple files and avoid merge conflicts in post-release rebases.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Release Protocol
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: To release a new version of cdk8s following these steps:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: $ yarn bump
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
This will create a new CHANGELOG entry (from conventional commits), bump the version in
package.json and create a bump commit.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Now, push to master (in the future we will release from a release branch, but in the meantime we release directly from master):
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: $ git push origin master
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: This will trigger the release workflow which will release to all package managers and will also create a GitHub release with a tag.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Portions of this guide were adopted from the contribution guides of the AWS
CDK and etcd.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Contributing Guidelines
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Thank you for your interest in contributing to our project. Whether it's a bug report, new feature, correction, or additional
documentation, we greatly value feedback and contributions from our community.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Please read through this document before submitting any issues or pull requests to ensure we have all the necessary
information to effectively respond to your bug report or contribution.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Reporting Bugs/Feature Requests
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: We welcome you to use the GitHub issue tracker to report bugs or suggest features.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
When filing an issue, please check existing open, or recently closed, issues to make sure somebody else hasn't already
reported the issue. Please try to include as much information as you can. Details like these are incredibly useful:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - A reproducible test case or series of steps
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - The version of our code being used
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Any modifications you've made relevant to the bug
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Anything unusual about your environment or deployment
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Contributing via Pull Requests
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Contributions via pull requests are much appreciated. Before sending us a pull request, please ensure that:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 1.  You are working against the latest source on the master branch.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 2.  You check existing open, and recently merged, pull requests to make sure someone else hasn't addressed the problem already.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 3.  You open an issue to discuss any significant work - we would hate for your time to be wasted.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: To send us a pull request, please:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 1.  Fork the repository.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 2.  Modify the source; please focus on the specific change you are contributing. If you also reformat all the code, it will be hard for us to focus on your change.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 3.  Ensure local tests pass.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 4.  Commit to your fork using clear commit messages.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 5.  Send us a pull request, answering any default questions in the pull request interface.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 6.  Pay attention to any automated CI failures reported in the pull request, and stay involved in the conversation.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
GitHub provides additional document on forking a repository and
creating a pull request.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Finding contributions to work on
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: Looking at the existing issues is a great way to find something to contribute on. As our projects, by default, use the default GitHub issue labels ((enhancement/bug/duplicate/help wanted/invalid/question/wontfix), looking at any 'help wanted' issues is a great place to start.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: Contributing Guidelines
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Interested in contributing to the AWS Serverless Application Model (AWS SAM)?
Awesome! Read this document to understand how to report issues, contribute
features and participate in the development process. We want to create a
transparent and open process for evolving AWS SAM.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Please read through this document before submitting any issues or pull requests to ensure we have all the necessary information to effectively respond to your bug report or contribution.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Integrating AWS SAM into your tool
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: We encourage you to modify SAM to integrate it with other frameworks and deployment providers from the community for building serverless applications. If you're building a new tool that will use AWS SAM, let us know how we can help!
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Submitting feature requests
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: We love features that help developers build serverless applications faster and further simplify development of serverless applications. If you have ideas for new event sources, new resource types, and new parameters within SAM, follow these steps to submit your feature request:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
1.  Scan through the list
of
feature requests.
If you find your feature there, mark it +1. This is a good indication of
interest from the community.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
2.  If you don't find your feature in our backlog, create a new issue and assign
the Feature Request label to it.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Keep in mind that features should be driven by real use cases. Answer the
following questions in the issue that you create:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Does this feature simplify creating and deploying some aspect of a serverless application?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Is this feature solving a problem faced by other serverless application developers?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - How do developers work around this problem today?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - How is the proposed feature better than the work around?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Adding features to AWS SAM
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
We welcome pull requests to add new features to AWS SAM. Take a look at the
backlog of Feature Requests and pick an item that you find interesting. If the requirements have been well-scoped, feel free to make the change and send a pull request.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph:
If you don't find an item tracking what you have in mind, start a conversation with your plan for implementing
the feature. When defining your feature, keep in mind that one of the core
tenets of AWS SAM is to keep it easy to use while allowing customers access to
use more advanced components, should they so choose.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: This repository contains the SAM specification, the code that translates SAM templates into AWS CloudFormation stacks, general information about the model, and examples of common applications. Make enhancements to all of SAM: if you make a change to the specification, please also make the corresponding change to the implementation.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Here are some questions that you should answer in your plan:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - What is the problem you are solving?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Example: Creating API endpoints require 24 steps, most of which are boilerplate and repetitive.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- Describe persona of someone who is facing this problem? This will give you
an understanding of how big of a problem it actually is.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Example: John just finished coding bootcamp and wants to create a Serverless app. He has
basic coding skills and will be comfortable understanding infrastructure
concepts, but probably be intimidated by the 24 steps required to create an
API endpoint.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - How do developers work around this problem today?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Example: Manually click through every step on the website while referring to
"How To" resources on the internet.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Describe your proposed solution?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Example: We are creating a new AWS SAM resource called "API". Here is how it
will look:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Type: 'AWS::Serverless::Api'
Properties:
# Name of API endpoint
Name: <string>
# Path to their endpoint. Example: /hello
Path: <string>
# HTTP Method for their endpoint. Example: GET, POST etc
Method: <string>
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - How is the proposed feature better than what the work around?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Example: Developers can write a simple AWS SAM resource which will handle
generating the boilerplate for them.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Submitting Changes
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Coding style
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
As of version 2.15, Axel adopted a new coding style, very similar to that of the
Linux Kernel, with the additional requirement to insert a newline after the
return type of procedure declarations.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
To aid the transition for imported code, an .indent.pro file is provided in
the top level source directory.  It should work with both GNU and BSD
implementations of indent, although the results may be slightly different.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
Small variations are acceptable, and non-compliance in existing code, by
itself, is not something to fix.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: IDE setup
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
We recommend IntelliJ IDEA. There is a free community
edition available. Azkaban is a standard Gradle
project. You can import it into your IDE using the build.gradle file in the root directory. For IntelliJ, choose Open
Project from the Quick Start box or choose Open from the File menu and select the root build.gradle file.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Style guides
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
Azkaban follows the Google code style. The template file,
az-intellij-style.xml, can be found in the root directory. It's based on the
intellij-java-google-style.xml config file from the google/styleguide project.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
Follow the Intellij's code style help
to import and set up the style. Make sure to activate the AzkabanStyle by
"copy the IDE scheme to the current project, using the Copy to Project... command."
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
Install and enable the intellij's
save actions plugin
to reformat/refactor code automatically:

Label: DC – Deal with the code

Label: DC – Deal with the code

Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Coding conventions
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Automated tests are expected.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Exceptions should be rare.
An example is automated UI testing, until the test framework catches up.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Define configuration keys in the azkaban.Constants class.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Favor composition over inheritance.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Favor @Singleton notation over the bind method.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: See this example PR.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Favor JSR-330's annotations and Provider interface.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: e.g. import javax.inject.Inject; instead of import com.google.inject.Inject;
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Introduce an interface only when needed.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
When there is a single implementation, don't introduce an interface. When there is a need for a
second implementation, refactor the code to introduce an interface as needed.
The person making that change in the future will know more (two implementations) than you do now (one implementation)
and they will use that knowledge to make better API choices. Modern IDEs have good support for
such refactoring. There is less IDE support for removing an interface.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
This convention only applies to the code internal to this project. It's a good use of interfaces
for public APIs, which are used by the code that the project owners can't change and evolve
easily.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: See this blog post.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Favor small and focused classes, files, methods over large ones.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
It's ok to have many classes, files.
Here is a rule of 30 suggestion.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Use Mockito as the mocking framework in unit tests.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: It's an exception rather than the rule to create custom mocking classes.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Use AssertJ as the assertion library in unit tests.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Use slf4j instead of log4j.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Use the form:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: private static final Logger logger = LoggerFactory.getLogger($CLASS_NAME$.class);
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Add or update the copyright notice for most files. The year should be the year in which the file was originally created.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Contributing to AzuraCast
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: As a free and open-source software project, we eagerly welcome contributions from the community. There are many ways to help contribute to AzuraCast's development, so you can make a difference without being a seasoned developer.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Translating AzuraCast
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Do you speak both English and another language? You can help us in a big way by helping translate AzuraCast!
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: AzuraCast is used around the world, and we want our web application to be accessible to users who aren't familiar with English, our primary language.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Thanks to the help of our friends at CrowdIn, translating the strings used in our application is easy! Just follow this invite link and create an account, and you can start submitting translations. CrowdIn also provides suggested translations in case you are unsure of certain words or phrases.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: We do our best to incorporate translation changes as frequently as possible, but sometimes new updates are delayed. If you have completed a significant translation project, please feel free to give us a gentle reminder by creating a Github issue. Once the translations have been updated, we will close the issue to let you know.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Testing New Platforms
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Getting a project as large and complex as AzuraCast to work on many platforms is a huge effort, and is often far too complex for a single-developer project such as this.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Thankfully, we've adopted support for Docker, a tool that allows us to create prebuilt images with all of our software stack properly configured and arranged, which you can then run on just about any host that will run the latest version of Docker. It's portable, it's cross-platform, and pulling down new updates are far easier than before; for these reasons, we heavily emphasize using Docker over our older, Ubuntu-specific Ansible installation.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Although we use Docker in local development and on our testing and demonstration servers, sometimes a problem will occur that stops a particular host from working with our application. If you're a user affected by such an issue, we encourage you to advise us by creating a Github issue, especially if there is a known solution to the issue that we can apply.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Contributing Code Changes
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Despite AzuraCast's growing popularity, we almost never receive pull requests from contributors wanting to add functionality or resolve issues with our application's code. Don't let this discourage you, though; we highly encourage skilled developers to contribute their expertise to our codebase whenever possible.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Due in part to the rarity of third-party contributions, we don't currently have a well-defined style guide, but when working in the application's main language (PHP), we rely heavily on the PSR-1 and PSR-2 code standards established by PHP-FIG.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Accessibility, security, and modern best practices are very important in AzuraCast's development. As of this document's latest update (January 2018), we are using PHP 7.2 on all platforms, so any newly contributed code can, and should, take advantage of the full suite of new features made available in PHP 7.0 and newer.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Contributions are also welcome in the supporting technologies used to make AzuraCast possible, such as:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Dockerfiles (see our separate repositories for Docker containers)
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Ansible configuration for Ansible installs and Docker installation/updates
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Python for our auxiliary station monitoring scripts
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Instructions for developing with AzuraCast locally are available here.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: If you have questions about the guidelines above or about how to contribute to AzuraCast, please create a Github issue and we will be happy to assist you.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: The "Do Nots" of Contributing
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: While we appreciate everyone who is eager to contribute to this project and help it succeed, we must ask that some forms of interaction be avoided:
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: - Please do not e-mail the project developer directly with questions or issues specific to AzuraCast, unless you were specifically requested to do so as part of an ongoing issue. Contacting me directly prevents me from tracking all outstanding issues in one place, and harms the transparency that is essential to FOSS development. If, however, you are e-mailing me to offer me a paying job...go nuts.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: - Please do not create "this doesn't work" issues that are just one sentence long and don't provide any insight into the scope of the issue, what changes might have triggered it, or what platform you're running on. At the very minimum, please always include what host OS you're using (i.e. Ubuntu 16.04), whether you're using the Docker or Ansible installation, and whether the problem first occurred after a recent update. For visual issues, screenshots are also greatly appreciated.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: - Please refer to existing Github issues if you are curious about the status of outstanding bug reports or new enhancement requests. Always remember that this is a volunteer project primarily built and maintained by a single developer, and manage your expectations accordingly.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Financial contributions
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
We also welcome financial contributions in full transparency on our open collective.
Anyone can file an expense. If the expense makes sense for the development of the community, it will be "merged" in the ledger of our open collective by the core contributors and the person who filed the expense will be reimbursed.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: General
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - The host is currently going through a redesign for v2 which moves it onto .NET core and move languages out into their own separate repos. These guidelines are generally written for the work going on in dev which is v2. The master branch and a few others are still v1 and have a different workflow.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - The host has some dependencies on having some Azure resources provisioned, so before you get started, make sure you have reliable access to an Azure subscription. E2E tests require a lot of various services to be provisioned. If you're making large contributions which would affect E2E tests, it'll be expected that you can provision those services yourself.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Be nice :) Everyone is busy and sometimes it can take a bit to get responses on things. Just be patient and, if you do poke someone for help, please be courteous and respectful.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Questions & Help
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: If you have questions about Azure Functions, we encourage you to reach out to the community and Azure Functions dev team for help.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: - For all questions and technical help, our Q&A forums are an easy place to have a conversation with our engineering team.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: - For questions which fit the Stack Overflow format ("how does this work?"), we monitor the azure-functions tag.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: - You can also tweet/follow @AzureFunctions.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: While we do our best to help out in a timely basis, we don't have any promise around the above resources. If you need an SLA on support from us, it's recommended you invest in an Azure Support plan.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Issues & feature requests
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: We track functional issues in a variety of places for Azure Functions. If you have found an issue or have a feature request, please submit an issue to the below repositories.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
|Item|Description|Link|
|----|-----|-----|
|Documentation|Docs for Azure Functions features + getting started|File an Issue|
|Runtime|Script Host, Triggers & Bindings, Language Support|File an Issue|
|Core Tools|Command line interface for local development|File an Issue|
|Dev Tools|Visual Studio and VS Code|File an Issue|
|Portal|User Interface or Experience Issue|File an Issue|
|Templates|Code Issues with Creation Template|File an Issue|
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Before filing an issue, please check that it doesn't already exist. If you're not sure if you should file an issue, you can open up a Q&A forum question. We also have a uservoice feedback site which we can track your feature requests through.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Running locally (Visual Studio) (v2+)
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: First thing you'll want to try is to run the Function host locally.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 1.  Set the WebJobs.Script.WebHost to the startup project
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 2.  Change the debug configuration to "WebJobs.Script.WebHost.Core"
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 3.  Add AzureWebJobsScriptRoot setting pointing at your test project
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: - You can add this variable a few ways:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 1.  Add a Environment Variable via a global variable (have to restart VS afterwards)
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 2.  Add a setting to appsettings.json (be careful not to check it in)
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 3.  Add an environment variable via the Debug configuration for the project (be careful not to check it in)
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
- You can create a simple hello world function app via the function core tools CLI. In a sample directory just run:
func init
func new -l javascript -t httptrigger -n hello
echo $PWD
The output of $PWD is your current directory, use that full path
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 4.  Click debug - this should launch a new terminal and browser window. If you created a new http triggered function named "hello", you should be able to add "api/hello" to your base URL and see your Function's response and the context.log statement in the terminal.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: If you want to test anything other than HTTP, it will require the AzureWebJobsStorage and AzureWebJobsDashboard settings get set to an Azure Storage Account connection string. You'll also need to add settings for any non-storage services you might want to connect to. You can do this via the same 3 methods described above.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Running tests (Visual Studio)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: There are three test projects in the WebJobs.Script solution
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - WebJobs.Script.Tests
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - WebJobs.Script.Test.Integration
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: The only thing you need to set up for the tests is your Storage Account for the integration tests. You need to set the AzureWebJobsStorage and AzureWebJobsDashboard settings for WebJobs.Script.Tests.Integration project. The appsettings.json method is pretty clean, but you need to create it. Be sure "CopyToOutput" is true and rebuild afterwards for the appsettings.json file. To run end to end (E2E) tests, see the set up requirements for Samples under Home.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Then open up for your test explorer (CTRL+E, T) and click Run All. If any fail, you might have set something up wrong locally.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Change flow
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: The general flow for making a change to the script host is:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 1.  ? Fork the repo (add the fork via git remote add me <clone url here>
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 2.  ? Create a branch for your change (generally use dev) (git checkout -b my-change)
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 3.  ? Make your change
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 4.  ?? Test your changes
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 5.  ?? Push your changes to your fork (git push me my-change)
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 6.  ? Open a PR to the dev branch
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 7.  ? Address feedback and make sure tests pass (yes even if it's an "unrelated" test failure)
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 8.  ? Squash your changes into a meaningful commits (usually 1 commit) (git rebase -i HEAD~N where N is commits you want to squash)
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 9.  :shipit: Rebase and merge (This will be done for you if you don't have contributor access)
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 10. ?? Delete your branch (optional)
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: The following is a list of guidelines that pull requests opened in the Azure PowerShell repository must adhere to. You can find a more complete discussion of Azure PowerShell design guidelines here.

Paragraph: General guidelines
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: The following guidelines must be followed in EVERY pull request that is opened.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Title of the pull request is clear and informative
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - The appropriate ChangeLog.md file(s) has been updated:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - For any service, the ChangeLog.md file can be found at src/{{SERVICE}}/{{SERVICE}}/ChangeLog.md
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - A snippet outlining the change(s) made in the PR should be written under the ## Upcoming Release header -- no new version header should be added
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - There are a small number of commits that each have an informative message
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - All files shipped with a module should contain a proper Microsoft license header
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - For public API changes to cmdlets:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - a cmdlet design review was approved for the changes in this repository (Microsoft internal only)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - the markdown help files have been regenerated using the commands listed here
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Testing guidelines
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: The following guidelines must be followed in EVERY pull request that is opened.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Changes made have corresponding test coverage
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Tests should not include any hardcoded values, such as location, resource id, etc.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Tests should have proper setup of resources to ensure any user can re-record the test if necessary
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - No existing tests should be skipped

Paragraph: GENERAL THINGS TO KNOW:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Client Libraries are sdks used to interact with azure resources at application run time while Management Libraries are those used to manage (create/modify/delete) Azure resources.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Build Repo : To build all Client and Management libraries together. Invoke dotnet build build.proj from the root of the repo.To scope to a single service supply a scope property e.g. dotnet build build.proj /p:Scope=servicebus. This will build both client and management projects in the specified service. If using msbuild you must run restore first. See below for how to build the client or management libraries independently.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Path Length : To account for the 260 characters Path Length Limit encountered on windows OS, file paths within the repo is keep below 210 characters. This gives you a runway of 49 characters as clone path for your repo. Paths longer that 260 characters will cause the build to break on windows OS and on CI. Assuming you clone to the default VisualStudio location such that the root of your clone is C:\Users\\**USERNAME**\Source\Repos\azure-sdk-for-net your username will have to be 9 characters long to avoid build errors caused by long paths. Consider using C:\git as you clone path.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Dependencies : To ensure that the same versions of dependencies are used for all projects in the repo, package versions are managed from a central location in eng\Packages.Data.props. When adding package references you should first ensure that an Update reference of the package with the version exist in the Packages.Data.props then Include the reference without the version in your .csproj. Contact azuresdkengsysteam@microsoft.com if you need to change  versions for packages already present in Packages.Data.props
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Line Endings : If working on windows OS ensure git is installed with Checkout Windows-style, commit Unix-style option or core.autocrlf set to true in git config. If working on Unix based Linux or MacOS ensure git is installed with Checkout as-is, commit Unix-style option or core.autocrlf set to input in git config
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Management Libraries
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: TO BUILD:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 1.  Open any solution, eg "SDKs\Compute\Microsoft.Azure.Management.Compute.sln"
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 2.  Build solution from Visual Studio
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Single Service from Command Line
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 1.  Open Developer Command Prompt
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 2.  From the root directory
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 3.  Invoke msbuild eng\mgmt.proj /p:scope=Compute
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Build without any scope will build all management SDK's.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Create single nuget package
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
In order to build one package and run it's test
msbuild eng\mgmt.proj /t:CreateNugetPackage /p:scope=Compute
Nuget package will be created in root directory under \artifacts\packages\Debug (default configuration is Debug)
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: TO TEST:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Using Visual Studio:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 1.  Build project in Visual Studio.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 2.  Test Explorer window will get populated with tests. Select test and Run or Debug
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Using the command line:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Run e.g. msbuild eng\mgmt.proj /t:"Runtests" /p:Scope=Compute
In the above example RunTests will build and run tests for Compute only or you can use command line CLI
dotnet test Compute\Microsoft.Azure.Management.Compute\tests\Microsoft.Azure.Management.Tests.csproj
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Non-Windows command line build
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Now you can use the same command on non-windows as above for e.g. on Ubuntu you can do something like below:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - dotnet msbuild eng\mgmt.proj /t:Build /p:scope=Compute
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - dotnet msbuild eng\mgmt.proj /t:RunTests /p:scope=Compute
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - dotnet msbuild eng\mgmt.proj /t:CreateNugetPackage /p:scope=Compute
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - dotnet msbuild build.proj /t:Util /p:UtilityName=InstallPsModules
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Update build tools
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Build tools are now downloaded as part of a nuget package under root\restoredPackages\microsoft.internal.netsdkbuild.mgmt.tools
If for any reason there is an update to the build tools, you will then need to first delete directory root\restoredPackages\microsoft.internal.netsdkbuild.mgmt.tools and re-execute your build command. This will simply get the latest version of build tools.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 3.  Invoke dotnet test
Label: No categories identified.

Some live tests may have additional steps for setting up live testing resources.
See the CONTRIBUTING.md file for the service you wish to test for additional
information or instructions.

Paragraph: Testing Against Latest Versions of Client Libraries
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: In some cases, you might want to test against the latest versions of the client libraries. i.e. version not yet published to nuget. For this scenario you should make use of the UseProjectReferenceToAzureClients property which when set to true will switch all package references for client libraries present in the build to project references. This result in testing against the current version of the libraries in the repo. e.g. dotnet test eng\service.proj /p:ServiceDirectory=eventhub --filter TestCategory!=Live /p:UseProjectReferenceToAzureClients=true
Label: No categories identified.

See the following example of a snippet C# file and a snippet markdown file.

Paragraph: API Compatibility Verification
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: .NET is using the ApiCompat tool to enforce API compatibility between versions. Builds of GA'ed libraries will fail locally and in CI if there are breaking changes.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: How it works
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
We use a dummy project called ApiCompat to enforce API compatibility between the GA'ed libraries and the most recent version available on Nuget. This project includes package references to the GA'ed library and to Microsoft.DotNet.ApiCompat.
Each library needs to provide a ApiCompatVersion property which is set to the last GA'ed version of the library which is used to compare APIs with the current to ensure no breaks
have been introduced.
The ApiCompatVerification target defined in ApiCompat.csproj is referenced in the eng/Directory.Build.Data.targets which causes this target to be executed for each csproj that has the ApiCompatVersion property set. For libraries that wish to disable the APICompat check they can remove the ApiCompatVersion property from their project. Our version bump automation will automatically add or increment the ApiCompatVersion property to the project when it detects that the version it is changing was a GA version which usually indicates that we just shipped that GA version and so it should be the new baseline for api checks.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Releasing a new version of a GA'ed libary
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Since the eng/Packages.Data.props is currently maintained manually, you will need to update the version number for your library in this file when releasing a new version.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Dev Feed
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: We publish daily built packages to a dev feed which can be consumed by adding the dev feed as a package source in Visual Studio.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Follow instructions provided here and use https://pkgs.dev.azure.com/azure-sdk/public/_packaging/azure-sdk-for-net/nuget/v3/index.json as the source.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: You can also achieve this from the command line.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: nuget.exe sources add -Name "Azure SDK for Net Dev Feed" -Source "https://pkgs.dev.azure.com/azure-sdk/public/_packaging/azure-sdk-for-net/nuget/v3/index.json"
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: You can then consume packages from this package source, remember to check the Include prerelease box in Visual Studio when searching for the packages.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Project Structure
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: In sdk\< Service Name >, you will find projects for services that have already been implemented
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 1.  Client library projects needs to use the $(RequiredTargetFrameworks) (defined in eng/Directory.Build.Data.props) property in its TargetFramework while management library projects should use $(SdkTargetFx) (defined in AzSdk.reference.props)

Paragraph: 2.  Projects of related packages are grouped together in a folder following the structure specified in Repo Structure

Paragraph: - Management library packages are in a folder named like Microsoft.Azure.Management.< Resource Provider Name >

Paragraph: 3.  Each shipping package contains a project for their generated and /or Customization code

Paragraph: - The folder 'Generated' contains the generated code

Paragraph: - The folder 'Customizations' contains additions to the generated code - this can include additions to the generated partial classes, or additional classes that augment the SDK or call the generated code

Paragraph: - The file generate.cmd, used to generate library code for the given package, can also be found in this project

Paragraph: Standard Process
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 1.  Create fork of Azure REST API Specs
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 2.  Create fork of Azure SDK for .NET
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 3.  Create your Swagger specification for your HTTP API. For more information see Introduction to Swagger - The World's Most Popular Framework for APIs
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 4.  Install the latest version of AutoRest and use it to generate your C# client. For more info on getting started with AutoRest, see the AutoRest repository
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 5.  Create a branch in your fork of Azure SDK for .NET and add your newly generated code to your project. If you don't have a project in the SDK yet, look at some of the existing projects and build one like the others.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 6.  MANDATORY: Add or update tests for the newly generated code.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 7.  Once added to the Azure SDK for .NET, build your local package using client or management library instructions shown in the above sections.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 8.  For management libraries run eng\scripts\Update-Mgmt-Yml.ps1 to update PR include paths in eng\pipelines\mgmt.yml
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 9.  A Pull request of your Azure SDK for .NET changes against master branch of the Azure SDK for .NET
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 10. The pull requests will be reviewed and merged by the Azure SDK team
Label: No categories identified.

Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 1.  If you have never created an SDK for your service before, you will need the following things to get your SDK in the repo

Label: No categories identified.

sdk\<service name>\<package name>\README.md
sdk\<service name>\<package name>\*src*
sdk\<service name>\<package name>\*tests*
sdk\<service name>\<package name>\*samples*

Paragraph: e.g.

sdk\eventgrid\Microsoft.Azure.Management.EventGrid\tests\Microsoft.Azure.Management.EventGrid.Tests.csproj

Paragraph:
Ensure that your service name is the same as it is specified in the azure-rest-api-specs/specification Repo, that your csproj files starts with Microsoft.Azure
, that test files end with .Tests and that management plane project files contain .Management.
If you are adding a new service directory, ensure that it is mapped to a friendly name at ServiceMapping

Paragraph: 7.  Copy .csproj from any other .csproj and update the following information in the new .csproj

| Project Properties  |
| ------------------- |

| PackageReleaseNotes |

During SDK generation, this path helps to locate the REST API spec from the https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs

Paragraph: Code Review Process
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Before a pull request will be considered by the Azure SDK team, the following requirements must be met:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Prior to issuing the pull request:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - All code must have completed any necessary legal signoff for being publicly viewable (Patent review, JSR review, etc.)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - The changes cannot break any existing functional/unit tests that are part of the central repository.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - This includes all tests, even those not associated with the given feature area.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Code submitted must have basic unit test coverage, and have all the unit tests pass. Testing is the full responsibility of the service team
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Functional tests are encouraged, and provide teams with a way to mitigate regressions caused by other code contributions.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Code should be commented.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Code should be fully code reviewed.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Code should be able to merge without any conflicts into the dev branch being targeted.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Code should pass all relevant static checks and coding guidelines set forth by the specific repository.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - All build warnings and code analysis warnings should be fixed prior to submission.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - As part of the pull request (aka, in the text box on GitHub as part of submitting the pull request):
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Proof of completion of the code review and test passes requirements above.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Identity of QA responsible for feature testing (can be conducted post-merging of the pull request).
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Short description of the payload of pull request.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - After the pull request is submitted:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Our SLA is 48 hours. When your PR is submitted someone on our team will be auto assigned the PR for review. No need to email us
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - MS internal folks, please reach out to us via our Teams channel or
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: - Send an email to the Azure Developer Platform team adpteam@microsoft.com alias.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: - Include all interested parties from your team as well.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: - In the message, make sure to acknowledge that the legal signoff process is complete.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Once all of the above steps are met, the following process will be followed:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - A member of the Azure SDK team will review the pull request on GitHub.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - If the pull request meets the repository's requirements, the individual will approve the pull request, merging the code into the dev branch of the source repository.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - The owner will then respond to the email sent as part of the pull request, informing the group of the completion of the request.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - If the request does not meet any of the requirements, the pull request will not be merged, and the necessary fixes for acceptance will be communicated back to the partner team.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Checklist before creating a Pull Request
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Submit only relevant commits. We don't mind many commits in a pull request, but they must be relevant as explained below.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Use a feature branch The pull request should be created from a feature branch, and not from dev. See below for why.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- No merge-commits
If you have commits that looks like this "Merge branch 'my-branch' into dev" or "Merge branch 'dev' of https://github.com/Azure/DotNetty into dev" you're probaly using merge instead of rebase locally. See below on Handling updates from upstream.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Squash commits Often we create temporary commits like "Started implementing feature x" and then "Did a bit more on feature x". Squash these commits together using interactive rebase. Also see Squashing commits with rebase.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Descriptive commit messages If a commit's message isn't descriptive, change it using interactive rebase. Refer to issues using #issue. Example of a bad message ~~"Small cleanup"~~. Example of good message: "Removed Security.Claims header from FSM, which broke Mono build per #62". Don't be afraid to write long messages, if needed. Try to explain why you've done the changes. The Erlang repo has some info on writing good commit messages.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - No one-commit-to-rule-them-all Large commits that changes too many things at the same time are very hard to review. Split large commits into smaller. See this StackOverflow question for information on how to do this.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Tests Add relevant tests and make sure all existing ones still passes. Tests can be run using the command
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - No Warnings Make sure your code do not produce any build warnings.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: After reviewing a Pull request, we might ask you to fix some commits. After you've done that you need to force push to update your branch in your local fork.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Title and Description for the Pull Request
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Give the PR a descriptive title and in the description field describe what you have done in general terms and why. This will help the reviewers greatly, and provide a history for the future.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Especially if you modify something existing, be very clear! Have you changed any algorithms, or did you just intend to reorder the code? Justify why the changes are needed.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Getting started
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Make sure you have a GitHub account.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Fork, clone, add upstream to the dotNetty repository. See Fork a repo for more detailed instructions or follow the instructions below.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Fork by clicking Fork on https://github.com/Azure/DotNetty
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Clone your fork locally.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: git clone https://github.com/YOUR-USERNAME/DotNetty
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Add an upstream remote.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: git remote add upstream https://github.com/Azure/DotNetty
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: You now have two remotes: upstream points to https://github.com/Azure/DotNetty, and origin points to your fork on GitHub.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Make changes. See below.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Unsure where to start? Issues marked with up for grabs are things we want help with.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: See also: Contributing to Open Source on GitHub
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: New to Git? See https://help.github.com/articles/what-are-other-good-resources-for-learning-git-and-github
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Making changes
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Never work directly on dev or master and you should never send a pull request from master - always from a feature branch created by you.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Pick an issue. If no issue exists (search first) create one.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: - Get any changes from upstream.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
git checkout dev
git fetch upstream
git merge --ff-only upstream/dev
git push origin dev     #(optional) this makes sure dev in your own fork on GitHub is up to date
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: See https://help.github.com/articles/fetching-a-remote for more info
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Create a new feature branch. It's important that you do your work on your own branch and that it's created off of dev. Tip: Give it a descriptive name and include the issue number, e.g. implement-lengthframeencoder-323 or 295-implement-recvbuffer, so that others can see what is being worked on.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git checkout -b my-new-branch-123
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Work on your feature. Commit.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Rebase often, see below.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Make sure you adhere to Checklist before creating a Pull Request described above.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Push the branch to your fork on GitHub
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git push origin my-new-branch-123
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Send a Pull Request, see https://help.github.com/articles/using-pull-requests to the dev branch.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: See also: Understanding the GitHub Flow (we're using dev as our master branch)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Handling updates from upstream
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: While you're working away in your branch it's quite possible that your upstream dev may be updated. If this happens you should:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Stash any un-committed changes you need to
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git stash
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Update your local dev by fetching from upstream
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
git checkout dev
git fetch upstream
git merge --ff-only upstream/dev
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Rebase your feature branch on dev. See Git Branching - Rebasing for more info on rebasing
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
git checkout my-new-branch-123
git rebase dev
git push origin dev     #(optional) this makes sure dev in your own fork on GitHub is up to date
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: This ensures that your history is "clean" i.e. you have one branch off from dev followed by your changes in a straight line. Failing to do this ends up with several "messy" merges in your history, which we don't want. This is the reason why you should always work in a branch and you should never be working in, or sending pull requests from dev.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: If you're working on a long running feature then you may want to do this quite often, rather than run the risk of potential merge issues further down the line.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Making changes to a Pull request
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
If you realize you've missed something after submitting a Pull request, just commit to your local branch and push the branch just like you did the first time. This commit will automatically be included in the Pull request.
If we ask you to change already published commits using interactive rebase (like squashing or splitting commits or  rewriting commit messages) you need to force push using -f:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git push -f origin my-new-branch-123
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: All my commits are on dev. How do I get them to a new branch?
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: If all commits are on dev you need to move them to a new feature branch.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: You can rebase your local dev on upstream/dev (to remove any merge commits), rename it, and recreate dev
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
git checkout dev
git rebase upstream/dev
git branch -m my-new-branch-123
git branch dev upstream/dev
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Or you can create a new branch off of dev and then cherry pick the commits
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
git checkout -b my-new-branch-123 upstream/dev
git cherry-pick rev           #rev is the revisions you want to pick
git cherry-pick rev           #repeat until you have picked all commits
git branch -m dev old-dev     #rename dev
git branch dev upstream/dev   #create a new dev
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Developing
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Node: Check that Node is installed with version 10 and up. You can check this with node -v.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Yarn: Make sure that Yarn 1 is installed with version >= 1.19.0.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Make: If you are running Windows 10, you'll need to do one of the following:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: - Clone the repository and run the commands inside WSL 2.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: - Install Make for Windows.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Setup
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Fork the babel repository to your GitHub Account.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Then, run:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
$ git clone https://github.com/<your-github-username>/babel
$ cd babel
$ make bootstrap
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Then you can either run:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: $ make build
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: to build Babel once or:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: $ make watch
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: to have Babel build itself and incrementally build files on change.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: You can access the built files for individual packages from packages/<package-name>/lib.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: If you wish to build a copy of Babel for distribution, then run:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: $ make build-dist
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Running linting/tests
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: You can run lint via:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
# ~6 sec on a MacBook Pro (Mid 2015)
$ make lint
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: You can run eslint's autofix via:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: $ make fix
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: You can run tests + lint for all packages (slow) via:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
# ~46 sec on a MacBook Pro (Mid 2015)
$ make test
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: If you just want to run all tests:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
# ~40 sec on a MacBook Pro (Mid 2015)
$ make test-only
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: When working on an issue, you will most likely want to focus on a particular packages. Using TEST_ONLY will only run tests for that specific package.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: $ TEST_ONLY=babel-cli make test
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: TEST_ONLY will also match substrings of the package name:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
# Run tests for the @babel/plugin-transform-classes package.
$ TEST_ONLY=babel-plugin-transform-classes make test
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Use the TEST_GREP variable to run a subset of tests by name:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: $ TEST_GREP=transformation make test
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Substitute spaces for hyphens and forward slashes when targeting specific test names:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: $ TEST_GREP="arrow functions destructuring parameters" make test
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: To enable the Node.js debugger added in v6.3.0, set the TEST_DEBUG environment variable:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: $ TEST_DEBUG=true make test
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: You can combine TEST_DEBUG with TEST_GREP or TEST_ONLY to debug a subset of tests. If you plan to stay long in the debugger (which you'll likely do!), you may increase the test timeout by editing test/testSetupFile.js.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: To overwrite any test fixtures when fixing a bug or anything, add the env variable OVERWRITE=true
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: $ OVERWRITE=true TEST_ONLY=babel-plugin-transform-classes make test-only
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: To test the code coverage, use:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
$ BABEL_ENV=cov make build
$ ./scripts/test-cov.sh
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Troubleshooting Tests
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: In case you're not able to reproduce an error on CI locally, it may be due to
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Node Version: Travis CI runs the tests against all major node versions. If your tests use JavaScript features unsupported by lower versions of node, then use minNodeVersion option in options.json.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Timeout: Check the CI log and if the only errors are timeout errors and you are sure that it's not related to the changes you made, ask someone in the slack channel to trigger rebuild on the CI build and it might be resolved
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: In case you're locally getting errors which are not on the CI, it may be due to
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Updates in Dependencies: Make sure you run make bootstrap before you run make build or make watch before you run the tests.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Writing tests
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Most packages in /packages have a test folder, however some tests might be in other packages or in /packages/babel-core.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: @babel/plugin-x
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: All the Babel plugins (and other packages) that have a /test/fixtures are written in a similar way.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: For example, in @babel/plugin-transform-exponentiation-operator/test:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - There is an index.js file. It imports our test helper. (You don't have to worry about this).
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - There can be multiple folders under /fixtures
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - There is an options.json file whose function is similar to a .babelrc file, allowing you to pass in the plugins and settings you need for your tests.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - For this test, we only need the relevant plugin, so it's just { "plugins": ["@babel/plugin-transform-exponentiation-operator"] }.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - If necessary, you can have an options.json with different options in each subfolder.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - In each subfolder, you can organize your directory structure by categories of tests. (Example: these folders can be named after the feature you are testing or can reference the issue number they fix)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Generally, there are two kinds of tests for plugins
input.js file and an output.js file. This kind of test only works in sub-subdirectories of /fixtures, i.e. /fixtures/exponentian-operator/binary/input.js and not /fixtures/exponentian-operator/input.js.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - If you need to expect an error, you can ignore creating the output.js file and pass a new throws key to the options.json that contains the error string that is created.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - The second and preferred type is a test that actually evaluates the produced code and asserts that certain properties are true or false. We do this by creating an exec.js file.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: In a fixture test, you simply write out the code you want to transform in input.js.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
// input.js
2 ** 2;
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: and the expected output after transforming it with your options.json in output.js.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
// output.js
Math.pow(2, 2);
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: In an exec.js test, we run or check that the code actually does what it's supposed to do rather than just check the static output.
Label: SC – Submit the changes
SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: If you need to check for an error that is thrown you can add to the options.json
Label: SC – Submit the changes
SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: If the test requires a minimum Node version, you can add minNodeVersion (must be in semver format).
Label: SC – Submit the changes
SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: @babel/parser (babylon)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Writing tests for the babel parser is very
similar to the other packages.
Inside the packages/babel-parser/test/fixtures folder are categories/groupings of test fixtures (es2015, flow,
etc.). To add a test, create a folder under one of these groupings (or create a new one) with a
descriptive name, and add the following:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Create an input.js file that contains the code you want the babel parser to parse.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Add an output.json file with the expected parser output. For added convenience, if there is no output.json present, the test runner will generate one for you.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: After writing tests for @babel/parser, just build it by running:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: $ make build
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Then, to run the tests, use:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: $ TEST_ONLY=babel-parser make test-only
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Bootstrapping expected output
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: For both @babel/plugin-x and @babel/parser, you can easily generate an output.js/output.json automatically by just providing input.js and running the tests as you usually would.
Label: SC – Submit the changes
