Paragraph: Debugging code
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
A common approach to debugging JavaScript code is to walk through the code using the Chrome DevTools debugger.
For illustration purposes, we are going to assume that we need to get a better understanding of Generator.generate(), which is responsible for generating code for a given AST.
To get a better understanding of what is actually going on for this particular piece of code, we are going to make use of breakpoints.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: generate() {
Label: DC – Deal with the code
DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: To include the changes, we have to make sure to build Babel:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: $ make build
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
Next, we need to execute Generator.generate(), which can be achieved by running a test case in the @babel/generator package.
For example, we can run the test case that tests the generation of class declarations:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: $ TEST_DEBUG=true TEST_GREP=ClassDeclaration make test-only
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
./scripts/test.sh
Debugger listening on port 9229.
To start debugging, open the following URL in Chrome:
chrome-devtools://devtools/remote/serve_file/@60cd6e859b9f557d2312f5bf532f6aec5f284980/inspector.html?experiments=true&v8only=true&ws=127.0.0.1:9229/3cdaebd2-be88-4e7b-a94b-432950ab72d0
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
To start the debugging in Chrome DevTools, open the given URL.
The debugger starts at the first executed line of code, which is Mocha's first line by default.
Click Resume script execution  to jump to the set breakpoint.
Note that the code shown in Chrome DevTools is compiled code and therefore differs.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Creating a new plugin (spec-new)
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Example: https://github.com/babel/babel/pull/11640
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Create a new PR that describes the proposed AST shape in ESTree (ex: Decimal AST). The new AST should follow ESTree's design philosophy.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - After the ESTree PR is accepted, update ast/spec.md. Note that there are differences between Babel AST and ESTree. In these cases, consistency with current Babel AST outweighs alignment to ESTree. Otherwise it should follow ESTree.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - [ ] Implement parser plugins based on the new AST. The parser plugin name should be the unprefixed slug of the TC39 proposal URL in camelcase, i.e. exportDefaultFrom from https://github.com/tc39/proposal-export-default-from.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - [ ] Use the this.expectPlugin("newSyntax") check within @babel/parser to ensure your new plugin code only runs when that flag is turned on (not default behavior), and a friendly error is thrown if users forget to enable a plugin.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - [ ] Add failing/passing tests according to spec behavior
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - [ ] Add @babel/syntax-new-syntax package. You can copy packages/babel-plugin-syntax-decimal and replace decimal to new-syntax.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - [ ] Add @babel/syntax-new-syntax to @babel/standalone.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - [ ] Add @babel/syntax-new-syntax to package.json
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - [ ] Add @babel/syntax-new-syntax to pluginsConfig.json, run make generate-standalone.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - [ ] Add @babel/syntax-new-syntax to src/preset-stage-x.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - [ ] Add "newSyntax" to parser typings
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - [ ] Implement generator support in packages/babel-generator/src/generators. The generator converts AST to source code.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - [ ] If this feature can be transpiled, start working on the Babel transform.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Contributing to Babylon.js
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Golden rules
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Babylon.js is built upon 3 golden rules:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: 1.  You cannot add code that will break backward compatibility
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: 2.  You cannot add code that will slow down the rendering process
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: 3.  You cannot add code that will make things complex to use
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Backward compatibility
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: The first golden rule is a really important one because we want our users to trust Babylon.js. And when we need to introduce something that will break backward compatibility, we know that it will imply more work for our customers to switch to a new version. So even if something could be simpler to do by breaking the backward compatibility, we will not do it (exceptions may apply of course if there is a problem with performance or if this is related to a bug).
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Performance
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Babylon.js is a 3D rendering engine. So every piece of code has to be scrutinized to look for potential bottlenecks or slow downs. Ultimately the goal is to render more with less resources.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Simplicity
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: A developer should be able to quickly and easily learn to use the API.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Simplicity and a low barrier to entry are must-have features of every API. If you have any second thoughts about the complexity of a design, it is almost always much better to cut the feature from the current release and spend more time to get the design right for the next release.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: You can always add to an API, you cannot ever remove anything from one. If the design does not feel right, and you ship it anyway, you are likely to regret having done so.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: - Feature requests

Paragraph: We will try to enforce these rules as we consider the forum is a better place for discussions and learnings.

Paragraph: What should go where
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: In order to not bloat the core engine with unwanted or unnecessary features (that we will need to maintain forever), here is a list of questions you could ask yourself before submitting a new feature (or feature request) for Babylon.js core engine:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Does my feature belong to a framework library?
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Can my feature be used by multiple different applications?
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Is there a general use case for this feature?
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Does this feature already exist in a similar framework?
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: If your PR is does not fall into the core category you can consider using our Extensions repo for more high level features.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Backup contribution guide
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Thank you for your interest in contributing to Backup! Backup is community
driven project, which means it keeps existing and improves because you and
people like you decide to spend time improving it in the various ways described
below.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: The goal of this document is to create a contribution process that:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Encourages new contributions.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Encourages contributors to remain involved.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Avoids unnecessary processes and bureaucracy whenever possible.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- Creates a transparent decision making process which makes it clear how
contributors can be involved in decision making.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: This document is partially based on the Node.js Community Contributing Guide 1.0
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Vocabulary
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- A Contributor is any individual creating or commenting on an issue, pull
request or message on the project gitter channel
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - A Committer is a subset of contributors who have been given write access to the repository.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- A TC (Technical Committee) is a group of committers representing the
required technical expertise to resolve rare disputes and/or having the
credentials to perform administrative actions on the project ressources (like
releasing on rubygems.org). The list of current TC members can be found in the
TC.md file in the master branch of the project repository.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Code of Conduct
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Please be courteous and respectful. Remember: Matz is nice and so we are nice
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Bugs
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: To report a bug, use the GitHub issue tracker. Please check the Open issues, and create a new issue if you do not see a report that matches the bug that you have found.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Backup is used with many different systems and configurations, so the first step for us to solve a problem is knowing how to reproduce it. You can help us solve your issue by including the versions of Ruby,
Backup and the operating system on the computer that you used.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: To submit a bug fix, please refere to the Pull Requests section
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Asking for (or Giving) Help
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph:
If you would like to talk about either using Backup or writing code for it,
please leave a message in our Gitter room.
Committers & TC members are not online at all times, so please be patient.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Triage Issues Open Source Helpers
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Triaging issues is a great way to help the project. This can include reproducing bug reports or asking for additional information, such as version numbers or reproduction instructions. If you would like to start triaging issues, one easy way to get started is to subscribe to backup on CodeTriage.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Pull Requests
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Any change to resources in this repository must be through pull
requests. This applies
to all changes to documentation, code, binary files, etc. Even long term
committers and TC members must use pull requests.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
If you would like to discuss some details before you start working on a feature
or bug fix, open an issue.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph:
No pull request can be merged without being reviewed, except for critical
security fixes or administrative commits by TC members (e.g. version bumps for
release cutting)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
For non-trivial contributions, pull requests should sit for at least 36 hours to
ensure that contributors in other timezones have time to review. Consideration
should also be given to weekends and other holiday periods to ensure active
committers all have reasonable time to become involved in the discussion and
review process if they wish.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
The default for each contribution is that it is accepted once no committer has
an objection. During review committers may also request that a specific
contributor who is most versed in a particular area gives a "LGTM" before the PR
can be merged. There is no additional "sign off" process for contributions to
land. Once all issues brought by committers are addressed it can be landed by
any committer.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
In the case of an objection being raised in a pull request by another committer,
all involved committers should seek to arrive at a consensus by way of
addressing concerns being expressed by discussion, compromise on the proposed
change, or withdrawal of the proposed change.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
If a contribution is controversial and committers cannot agree about how to get
it to land or if it should land then it should be escalated to the TC. TC
members should regularly discuss pending contributions in order to find a
resolution. It is expected that only a small minority of issues be brought to
the TC for resolution and that discussion and compromise among committers be the
default resolution mechanism.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: PR standards
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: To help the committers review your code and speed up the merge:

Paragraph: Becoming a Committer
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
All contributors who land a non-trivial contribution should be on-boarded in a
timely manner, and added as a committer, and be given write access to the
repository.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Committers are expected to follow this policy and continue to send pull
requests, go through proper review, and have other committers merge their pull
requests.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: TC Process
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
The TC uses a "consensus seeking" process for issues that are escalated to the TC.
The group tries to find a resolution that has no open objections among TC members.
If a consensus cannot be reached that has no objections then a majority wins vote
is called. It is also expected that the majority of decisions made by the TC are via
a consensus seeking process and that voting is only used as a last-resort.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Resolution may involve returning the issue to committers with suggestions on how to
move forward towards a consensus. It is not expected that a meeting of the TC
will resolve all issues on its agenda during that meeting and may prefer to continue
the discussion happening among the committers.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Adding new TC members
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Members can be added to the TC at any time. Any committer can nominate another
committer to the TC and the TC uses its standard consensus seeking process to
evaluate whether or not to add this new member. Members who do not participate
consistently at the level of a majority of the other members are expected to
resign.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
TC members who wants to receive administrative access on the project's resources
(like rubygems.org push rights) are required to have the most secure possible
configuration on their respective accounts (e.g. unique, strong password with
2FA enabled when available)
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Release cutting
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Any committer can suggest the release of a new version of the software and the
TC uses its standard consensus seeking process to evaluate whether or not to
perform it. The releases are performed by a TC member with the required
administrative access.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Contributing to Shields
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Shields is a community project. We invite your participation through
financial contributions, issues, and pull requests!

Paragraph:
We welcome financial contributions in full transparency on our
open collective. Anyone can file an
expense. If the expense makes sense for the development of the community, it
will be "merged" into the ledger of our open collective by the core
contributors and the person who filed the expense will be reimbursed.

Paragraph:
You can help with code review, which reduces bugs, and over time has a
wonderful side effect of making the code more readable and therefore more
approachable. It's also a great way to teach and learn. Feel free to jump in!
Be welcoming, appreciative, and helpful. You can perform first reviews of
simple changes, like badge additions. These are usually tagged with

Paragraph: Checklist for pull-requests
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
1.  The project is licensed under LGPL (see LICENSE.md). When merged, your code will be under the same license.
So make sure you have read and understand it.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
2.  Please coordinate with one of the core developers before making a big pull-request.
It's a shame to make something big that doesn't fit the project.

Paragraph:
3.  Remember to make a separate branch on your fork. This makes it a lot easier for the core developers to help
getting your pull-request ready.

Paragraph: Bagisto Contribution Guide
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: BUGS:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: To encourage active collaboration, Bagisto encourages pull requests, not just bug reports. "Bug reports" may also be sent in the form of a pull request containing negative test.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: However, when filing a bug report, your issue should contain a title and a clear description of the issue. You should also include as much relevant information as possible and a code sample that demonstrates the issue. The goal of a bug report is to make it easy for yourself - and others - to replicate the bug and develop a fix.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Remember, bug reports are created in the hope that others with the same problem will be able to collaborate with you on solving it. Creating a bug report serves to help yourself and others start on the path of fixing the problem.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Which branch you should target?
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: All bug fixes should be sent to the latest staging branch i.e development branch. Bug fixes should never be sent to the master branch unless they fix features that exist only in the upcoming release.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Minor features that are fully backwards compatible with the current Laravel release may be sent to the latest stable branch.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Major new features should always be sent to the master branch, which contains the upcoming Bagisto release.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Compiling assets:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: If you are submitting a change that will affect a compiled file, such as most of the files in admin/resources/assets/sass or admin/resources/assets/js of the Bagisto repository, do not commit the compiled files. Due to their large size, they cannot realistically be reviewed by a maintainer. This could be exploited as a way to inject malicious code into Bagisto. In order to defensively prevent this, all compiled files will be generated and committed by Bagisto maintainers.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

dependency.

Label: BW – Build local workspace

you might have brought during development, or you are running older
dependencies because you come from another branch or reference.

Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: - Commit both package.json and npm-shrinkwrap.json.

Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Make sure you checkout our [architecture][ARCHITECTURE] guide, which aims to explain how all pieces fit together. It's a good starting point for understanding how we designed and built balenaSound.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Commit guidelines
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: We enforce certain rules on commits with the following goals in mind:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Be able to reliably auto-generate the CHANGELOG.md without any human intervention.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Be able to automatically and correctly increment the semver version number based on what was done since the last release.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Be able to get a quick overview of what happened to the project by glancing over the commit history.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Be able to automatically reference relevant changes from a dependency upgrade.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Our CI will run checks to ensure this guidelines are followed and won't allow merging contributions that don't adhere to them. Version number and changelog are automatically handled by the CI build flow after a pull request is merged. You only need to worry about the commit itself.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Commit structure
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Each commit message should consist of a header a body and a footer, structured in the following format:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: <scope (optional)>: <subject (mandatory)>
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
--BLANK LINE--
(optional) <body>
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
--BLANK LINE--
(optional) Connects-to: #issue-number
(mandatory) Change-type: major | minor | patch
(optional) Signed-off-by: Foo Bar <foobar@balena.io>
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Note that:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Blank lines are required to separate header from body and body from footer. You don't need to add two blank lines if you don't add a body.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - scope: If your commit touches a well defined component/part/service please addthe scope tag to clarify. Some examples: docs, airplay, multi-room.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - subject: The subject should contain a short description of the change. Use the imperative, present tense.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - body: A detailed description of changes being made and reasoning if necessary. This may contain several paragraphs.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Connects-to: If your commit fixes or is connected to an existing issue, link it by adding this tag with #issue-number. Example: Connects-to: #123
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Change-type: At least one of your commits on a PR needs to have this tag. You have the flexibility, and it's good practise, to use this tag in as many commits as you see fit; in the end, the resulting change type for the scope of the PR will be folded down to the biggest one as marked in the commits (major>minor>patch). Our version numbering adheres to Semantic Versioning.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Signed-off-by: Sign your commits by providing your full name and email address in the format: Name Surname <email@something.com>. This is an optional tag.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: The PR will only be able to be merged only after:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - It has been approved at least by one codeowner
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - All the checks and tests carried out by our CI are passed
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Commit squashing
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: If your PR contains multiple commits you might be asked to rebase your PR branch on top of the latest master and squash your commits before merging. This can be achieved with the following steps, assuming that the current branch is that to be merged to master in your local file system:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
git checkout master
git pull
git checkout your-branch
git rebase -i master
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: At this point git rebase will prompt you to choose an action for each commit and resolve any conflicts. You should pick one commit, reword it if necessary and squash the rest. The reason behind using rebase is that it makes for tidier git branching history. Push the rebased PR branch to the remote and you should be good to go:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git push --force-with-lease origin your-branch
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: We strongly encourage using the --force-with-lease option instead of --force when performing git push to a repository. The reason is that git push --force can accidentally overwrite work that has been pushed by a team member in the meantime.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: balena-ci bot
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: If for some reason it looks like the checks and tests for the PR have failed, add a comment to the PR with @balena-ci retest. This should force balenaCI to re-run all the tests again.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Submit your contribution
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 1.  Do your changes in the source code.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Ballerina grammar has been implemented using ANTLR plugin version 4.5.3. To get a basic understanding of ANTLR grammar syntax and concepts before working with Ballerina grammar, go to Parr, Terence (January 15, 2013), The Definitive ANTLR 4 Reference.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Ballerina grammar consists of two files:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - BallerinaLexer.g4: contains the lexer rules for Ballerina grammar. The lexer is responsible for tokenizing an input Ballerina source code.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - BallerinaParser.g4: contains the parser rules. Parser listens to the token stream generated by the lexer. High level grammar productions/abstractions are defined in the parser using those tokens.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Once a change is done to any of the grammar files, the lexer and the parser need to be re-generated. To generate the lexer and the parser, navigate to the <BALLERINA_PROJECT_ROOT>/compiler/ballerina-lang/src/main/resources/grammar/ directory, and execute the below command.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Tip: Download the antlr-complete-4.5.3.jar file and replace <PATH-TO-ANTLR-JAR> in the below command with the location in which you saved it.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: java -jar <PATH-TO-ANTLR-JAR>/antlr-4.5.3-complete.jar *.g4 -package org.wso2.ballerinalang.compiler.parser.antlr4 -o <BALLERINA_PROJECT_ROOT>/compiler/ballerina-lang/src/main/java/org/wso2/ballerinalang/compiler/parser/antlr4/
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Info: The above command will autogenerate some Java classes. The Ballerina AST builder is written on top of the auto-generated BallerinaParserBaseListener.java class. Thus, if any new rules are added to the BallerinaParser.g4, the above command will generate new methods in the BallerinaParserBaseListener.java and you need to override those newly-added methods inside the BLangParserListener.java accordingly.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: For more information about the Ballerina compiler, go to Ballerina Compiler .
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 2.  Add unit tests accordingly. (The build process will automatically execute all the tests.)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 3.  Commit the changes to your fork and push them to the corresponding original repo by sending a Pull Request (PR).
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Tip: Follow these commit message requirements:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Separate subject from the body with a blank line
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Limit the subject line to 50 characters
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Capitalize the subject line
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Do not end the subject line with a period
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Use the imperative mood in the subject line
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Wrap the body at 72 characters
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Use the body to explain what and why vs. how
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: For more information, go to How to Write a Git Commit Message.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 4.  Accept the Contributor License Agreement (CLA)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: You need to Accept the Ballerina Contributor License Agreement (CLA) when prompted by a GitHub email notification after sending your first Pull Request (PR). Subsequent PRs will not require CLA acceptance.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: If the CLA gets changed for some (unlikely) reason, you will be presented with the new CLA text after sending your first PR after the change.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Once your code is merged, it is available for free to everybody under the MIT License. Publishing your pull request on the PHPloy GitHub repository means that you agree with this license for your contribution.

Paragraph: Testing
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
The integration tests provide a docker configuration for a SFTP and FTP server you can use to test the synchronization.
A folder in /tmp is mounted into the docker container which can be used to compare the result after running PHPloy.

Paragraph: Executing tests
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: To get started with testing, please follow the steps below:

Paragraph: 1.  Install docker

Paragraph: 2.  Start the test server

Paragraph: vagrant@vagrant-ubuntu-trusty-64:/vagrant/PHPloy$ ./tests/start_test_server.sh
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 3.  run the tests
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
vagrant@vagrant-ubuntu-trusty-64:/vagrant/PHPloy$ vendor/bin/phpunit tests
PHPUnit 4.8.26 by Sebastian Bergmann and contributors.
...
Time: 2.32 seconds, Memory: 4.25MB
OK (3 tests, 4 assertions)
vagrant@vagrant-ubuntu-trusty-64:/vagrant/PHPloy$
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
protected $testHelper;
/**
Label: SC – Submit the changes

The PHPLoyTestHelper is parametrized to provide different configurations based on the type passed to the test method by the PHPunit framework.

Paragraph: Contribution Guidelines
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
When contributing a new feature, a bug fix, a new theme, or any other change to Bash-it, please consider the following guidelines.
Most of this is common sense, but please try to stick to the conventions listed here.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Issues
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - When opening a new issue in the issue tracker, please include information about which Operating System you're using, and which version of Bash.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- In many cases, it also makes sense to show which Bash-it plugins you are using.
This information can be obtained using bash-it show plugins.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- If the issue happens while loading Bash-it, please also include your ~/.bash_profile or ~/.bashrc file,
as well as the install location of Bash-it (default should be ~/.bash_it).
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- When reporting a bug or requesting a new feature, consider providing a Pull Request that fixes the issue or can be used as a starting point for the new feature.
Don't be afraid, most things aren't that complex...
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Pull Requests
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Fork the Bash-it repo, create a new feature branch from master and apply your changes there.
Create a Pull Request from your feature branch against Bash-it's master branch.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Limit each Pull Request to one feature.
Don't bundle multiple features/changes (e.g. a new Theme and a fix to an existing plugin) into a single Pull Request - create one PR for the theme, and a separate PR for the fix.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- For complex changes, try to squash your changes into a single commit before
pushing code. Once you've pushed your code and opened a PR, please refrain
from force-pushing changes to the PR branch
distributed project and your branch may be in use already.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- When in doubt, open a PR with too many commits. Bash-it is a learning project
for everyone involved. Showing your work provides a great history for folks
to learn what works and what didn't.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Code Style
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Try to stick to the existing code style. Please don't reformat or change the syntax of existing code simply because you don't like that style.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- Indentation is using spaces, not tabs. Most of the code is indented with 2 spaces, some with 4 spaces. Please try to stick to 2 spaces.
If you're using an editor that supports EditorConfig, the editor should automatically use the settings defined in Bash-it's .editorconfig file.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- When creating new functions, please use a dash ("-") to separate the words of the function's name, e.g. my-new-function.
Don't use underscores, e.g. my_new_function.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Internal functions that aren't to be used by the end user should start with an underscore, e.g. _my-new-internal-function.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- Use the provided meta functions to document your code, e.g. about-plugin, about, group, param, example.
This will make it easier for other people to use your new functionality.
Take a look at the existing code for an example (e.g. the base plugin).
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- When adding files, please use the existing file naming conventions, e.g. plugin files need to end in .plugin.bash.
This is important for the installation functionality.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - When using the $BASH_IT variable, please always enclose it in double quotes to ensure that the code also works when Bash-it is installed in a directory that contains spaces in its name: for f in "${BASH_IT}/plugins/available"/*.bash ; do echo "$f" ; done
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Bash-it supports Bash 3.2 and higher. Please don't use features only available in Bash 4, such as associative arrays.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Unit Tests
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
When adding features or making changes/fixes, please run our growing unit test suite to ensure that you did not break existing functionality.
The test suite does not cover all aspects of Bash-it, but please run it anyway to verify that you did not introduce any regression issues.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Any code pushed to GitHub as part of a Pull Request will automatically trigger a continuous integration build on Travis CI, where the test suite is run on both Linux and macOS.
The Pull Request will then show the result of the Travis build, indicating whether all tests ran fine, or whether there were issues.
Please pay attention to this, Pull Requests with build issues will not be merged.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Adding new functionality or changing existing functionality is a good opportunity to increase Bash-it's test coverage.
When you're changing the Bash-it codebase, please consider adding some unit tests that cover the new or changed functionality.
Ideally, when fixing a bug, a matching unit test that verifies that the bug is no longer present, is added at the same time.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: To run the test suite, simply execute the following in the directory where you cloned Bash-it:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: test/run
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
This command will ensure that the Bats Test Framework is available in the local test_lib directory (Bats is included as a Git submodule) and then run the test suite found in the test folder.
The test script will execute each test in turn, and will print a status for each test case.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: When adding new test cases, please take a look at the existing test cases for examples.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: The following libraries are used to help with the tests:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Test Framework: https://github.com/bats-core/bats-core
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Support library for Bats-Assert: https://github.com/ztombol/bats-support
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - General assert functions: https://github.com/ztombol/bats-assert
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - File assert functions: https://github.com/ztombol/bats-file
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: When verifying test results, please try to use the assert functions found in these libraries.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Features
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
- When adding new completions or plugins, please don't simply copy existing tools into the Bash-it codebase, try to load/integrate the tools instead.
An example is using nvm: Instead of copying the existing nvm script into Bash-it, the nvm.plugin.bash file tries to load an existing installation of nvm.
This means an additional step for the user (installing nvm from its own repo, or through a package manager),
but it will also ensure that nvm can be upgraded in an easy way.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Themes
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
- When adding a new theme, please include a screenshot and a short description about what makes this theme unique in the Pull Request's description field.
Please do not add theme screenshots to the repo itself, as they will add unnecessary bloat to the repo.
The project's Wiki has a Themes page where you can add a screenshot if you want.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Ideally, each theme's folder should contain a README.md file describing the theme and its configuration options.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Before reporting an issue, please use the search feature on the issues
page to see if an issue matching the one you've observed has already
been filed.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Updating or filing a new issue
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Information to include
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Try to be as specific as possible about your environment and the problem you're
observing. At a minimum, include:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Installation issues
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 1.  State the version of Bash you're using bash --version
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 2.  State your operating system and its version
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
3.  If you're installing through homebrew, run brew doctor, and attach the
output of brew info bats-core
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Bugs/usage issues
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 1.  State the version of Bash you're using bash --version
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 2.  State your operating system and its version
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 3.  Command line steps or code snippets that reproduce the issue
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 4.  Any apparently relevant information from the Bash changelog
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Also consider using:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Bash's time builtin to collect running times
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - a regression test to add to the suite
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- memory usage as reported by a tool such as
memusg
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: On existing issues
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 1.  DO NOT add a +1 comment: Use the reactions provided instead
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
2.  DO add information if you're facing a similar issue to someone else, but
within a different context (e.g. different steps needed to reproduce the issue
than previous stated, different version of Bash or BATS, different OS, etc.)
You can read on how to do that here: [Information to include][#information-to-include]
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
3.  DO remember that you can use the Subscribe button on the right side of the
page to receive notifications of further conversations or a resolution.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Updating documentation
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: We love documentation and people who love documentation!
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
If you love writing clear, accessible docs, please don't be shy about pull
requests. Remember: docs are just as important as code.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Also: no typo is too small to fix! Really. Of course, batches of fixes are
preferred, but even one nit is one nit too many.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Environment setup
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
Make sure you have Bash installed per the Environment setup in the
README.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Workflow
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
The basic workflow for submitting changes resembles that of the GitHub Git
Flow (a.k.a. GitHub Flow), except that you will be working with
your own fork of the repository and issuing pull requests to the original.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 1.  Fork the repo on GitHub (look for the "Fork" button)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 2.  Clone your forked repo to your local machine
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 3.  Create your feature branch (git checkout -b my-new-feature)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 4.  Develop and test your changes as necessary.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 5.  Commit your changes (git commit -am 'Add some feature')
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 6.  Push to the branch (git push origin my-new-feature)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
7.  Create a new GitHub pull request for your feature branch based
against the original repository's master branch
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
8.  If your request is accepted, you can delete your feature branch
and pull the updated master branch from the original repository into your
fork. You may even delete your fork if you don't anticipate making
further changes.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Coding conventions
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Formatting
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Naming
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Variable and parameter declarations
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Command substitution
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Conditions and loops
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Gotchas
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Formatting
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Keep all files 80 characters wide.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Indent using two spaces.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- Enclose all variables in double quotes when used to avoid having them
interpreted as glob patterns (unless the variable contains a glob pattern)
and to avoid word splitting when the value contains spaces. Both scenarios
can introduce errors that often prove difficult to diagnose.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- This is especially important when the variable is used to generate a
glob pattern, since spaces may appear in a path value.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- If the variable itself contains a glob pattern, make sure to set
IFS=$'\n' before using it so that the pattern itself and any matching
file names containing spaces are not split apart.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- Exceptions: Quotes are not required within math contexts, i.e. (( )) or
$(( )), and must not be used for variables on the right side of the =~
operator.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Enclose all string literals in single quotes.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Exception: If the string contains an apostrophe, use double quotes.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Use quotes around variables and literals even inside of [[ ]] conditions.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- This is because strings that contain '[' or ']' characters may fail to
compare equally when they should.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- Exception: Do not quote variables that contain regular expression patterns
appearing on the right side of the =~ operator.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- Only quote arguments to the right of =~ if the expression is a literal
match without any metacharacters.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: The following are intended to prevent too-compact code:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Declare only one item per declare, local, export, or readonly call.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- Note: This also helps avoid subtle bugs, as trying to initialize one
variable using the value of another declared in the same statement will
not do what you may expect. The initialization of the first variable will
not yet be complete when the second variable is declared, so the first
variable will have an empty value.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- Do not use one-line if, for, while, until, case, or select
statements.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Do not use && or || to avoid writing if statements.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Do not write functions entirely on one line.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- For case statements: put each pattern on a line by itself; put each command
on a line by itself; put the ;; terminator on a line by itself.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Naming
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Use snake_case for all identifiers.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Function declarations
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Declare functions without the function keyword.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- Strive to always use return, never exit, unless an error condition is
severe enough to warrant it.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- Calling exit makes it difficult for the caller to recover from an error,
or to compose new commands from existing ones.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Variable and parameter declarations
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- Gotcha: Never initialize an array on the same line as an export or
declare -g statement. See the Gotchas section below for more
details.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Declare all variables inside functions using local.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- Declare temporary file-level variables using declare. Use unset to remove
them when finished.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- Don't use local -r, as a readonly local variable in one scope can cause a
conflict when it calls a function that declares a local variable of the same
name.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- Don't use type flags with declare or local. Assignments to integer
variables in particular may behave differently, and it has no effect on array
variables.
Label: DC – Deal with the code
DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Command substitution
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- If possible, don't. While this capability is one of Bash's core strengths,
every new process created by Bats makes the framework slower, and speed is
critical to encouraging the practice of automated testing. (This is especially
true on Windows, where process creation is one or two orders of magnitude
slower. See bats-core/bats-core#8 for an illustration of
the difference avoiding subshells makes.) Bash is quite powerful; see if you
can do what you need in pure Bash first.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- If you need to capture the output from a function, store the output using
printf -v instead if possible. -v specfies the name of the variable into
which to write the result; the caller can supply this name as a parameter.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- If you must use command substituion, use $() instead of backticks, as it's
more robust, more searchable, and can be nested.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Process substitution
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- If possible, don't use it. See the advice on avoiding subprocesses and using
printf -v in the Command substitution section above.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- Use wherever necessary and possible, such as when piping input into a while
loop (which avoids having the loop body execute in a subshell) or running a
command taking multiple filename arguments based on output from a function or
pipeline (e.g.  diff).
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- Warning: It is impossible to directly determine the exit status of a process
substitution; emitting an exit status as the last line of output is a possible
workaround.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Conditionals and loops
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- Always use [[ and ]] for evaluating variables. Per the guideline under
Formatting, quote variables and strings within the brackets, but not
regular expressions (or variables containing regular expressions) appearing
on the right side of the =~ operator.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Generating output
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- Use printf instead of echo. Both are Bash builtins, and there's no
perceptible performance difference when running Bats under the time builtin.
However, printf provides a more consistent experience in general, as echo
has limitations to the arguments it accepts, and even the same version of Bash
may produce different results for echo based on how the binary was compiled.
See Stack Overflow: Why is printf better than echo? for
excruciating details.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Signal names
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
Always use upper case signal names (e.g. trap - INT EXIT) to avoid locale
dependent errors. In some locales (for example Turkish, see
Turkish dotless i) lower
case signal names cause Bash to error. An example of the problem:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
$ echo "tr_TR.UTF-8 UTF-8" >> /etc/locale.gen && locale-gen tr_TR.UTF-8 # Ubuntu derivatives
$ LC_CTYPE=tr_TR.UTF-8 LC_MESSAGES=C bash -c 'trap - int && echo success'
bash: line 0: trap: int: invalid signal specification
$ LC_CTYPE=tr_TR.UTF-8 LC_MESSAGES=C bash -c 'trap - INT && echo success'
success
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Gotchas
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- If you wish to use command substitution to initialize a local variable, and
then check the exit status of the command substitution, you must declare the
variable on one line and perform the substitution on another. If you don't,
the exit status will always indicate success, as it is the status of the
local declaration, not the command substitution.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- To work around a bug in some versions of Bash whereby arrays declared with
declare -g or export and initialized in the same statement eventually go
out of scope, always export the array name on one line and initialize it the
next line. See:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - https://lists.gnu.org/archive/html/bug-bash/2012-06/msg00068.html
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - ftp://ftp.gnu.org/gnu/bash/bash-4.2-patches/bash42-025
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - http://lists.gnu.org/archive/html/help-bash/2012-03/msg00078.html
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - ShellCheck can help to identify many of these issues
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Contributing to CodeIgniter
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: CodeIgniter is a community driven project and accepts contributions of code and documentation from the community. These contributions are made in the form of Issues or Pull Requests on the CodeIgniter repository on GitHub.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Issues are a quick way to point out a bug. If you find a bug or documentation error in CodeIgniter then please check a few things first:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 1.  There is not already an open Issue
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 2.  The issue has already been fixed (check the develop branch, or look for closed Issues)
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 3.  Is it something really obvious that you can fix yourself?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Reporting issues is helpful but an even better approach is to send a Pull Request, which is done by "Forking" the main repository and committing to your own copy. This will require you to use the version control system called Git.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Guidelines
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Before we look into how, here are the guidelines. If your Pull Requests fail
to pass these guidelines it will be declined and you will need to re-submit
when you
for us to maintain quality of the code-base.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: PHP Style
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
All code must meet the Style Guide, which is
essentially the Allman indent style, underscores and readable operators. This makes certain that all code is the same format as the existing code and means it will be as readable as possible.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Documentation
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: If you change anything that requires a change to documentation then you will need to add it. New classes, methods, parameters, changing default values, etc are all things that will require a change to documentation. The change-log must also be updated for every change. Also PHPDoc blocks must be maintained.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Compatibility
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
CodeIgniter recommends PHP 5.5 or newer to be used, but it should be
compatible with PHP 5.2.4 so all code supplied must stick to this
requirement. If PHP 5.3 (and above) functions or features are used then
there must be a fallback for PHP 5.2.4.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Branching
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
CodeIgniter uses the Git-Flow branching model which requires all pull requests to be sent to the "develop" branch. This is
where the next planned version will be developed. The "master" branch will always contain the latest stable version and is kept clean so a "hotfix" (e.g: an emergency security patch) can be applied to master to create a new version, without worrying about other features holding it up. For this reason all commits need to be made to "develop" and any sent to "master" will be closed automatically. If you have multiple changes to submit, please place all changes into their own branch on your fork.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: One thing at a time: A pull request should only contain one change. That does not mean only one commit, but one change - however many commits it took. The reason for this is that if you change X and Y but send a pull request for both at the same time, we might really want X but disagree with Y, meaning we cannot merge the request. Using the Git-Flow branching model you can create new branches for both of these features and send two requests.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Signing
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: You must sign your work, certifying that you either wrote the work or otherwise have the right to pass it on to an open source project. git makes this trivial as you merely have to use --signoff on your commits to your CodeIgniter fork.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git commit --signoff
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: or simply
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git commit -s
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: This will sign your commits with the information setup in your git config, e.g.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Signed-off-by: John Q Public <john.public@example.com>
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: If you are using Tower there is a "Sign-Off" checkbox in the commit window. You could even alias git commit to use the -s flag so you don
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: By signing your work in this manner, you certify to a "Developer's Certificate of Origin". The current version of this certificate is in the DCO.txt file in the root of this repository.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: How-to Guide
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: There are two ways to make changes, the easy way and the hard way. Either way you will need to create a GitHub account.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Easy way GitHub allows in-line editing of files for making simple typo changes and quick-fixes. This is not the best way as you are unable to test the code works. If you do this you could be introducing syntax errors, etc, but for a Git-phobic user this is good for a quick-fix.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Hard way The best way to contribute is to "clone" your fork of CodeIgniter to your development area. That sounds like some jargon, but "forking" on GitHub means "making a copy of that repo to your account" and "cloning" means "copying that code to your environment so you can work on it".
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 1.  Set up Git (Windows, Mac & Linux)
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 2.  Go to the CodeIgniter repo
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 3.  Fork it
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 4.  Clone your forked CodeIgniter repo: git@github.com:/CodeIgniter.git.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 5.  Checkout the "develop" branch. At this point you are ready to start making changes.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 6.  Fix existing bugs on the Issue tracker after taking a look to see nobody else is working on them.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 7.  Commit the files
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 8.  Push your develop branch to your fork
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 9.  Send a pull request
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: The Reactor Engineers will now be alerted about the change and at least one of the team will respond. If your change fails to meet the guidelines it will be bounced, or feedback will be provided to help you improve it.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Once the Reactor Engineer handling your pull request is happy with it they will merge it into develop and your patch will be part of the next release.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Keeping your fork up-to-date
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Unlike systems like Subversion, Git can have multiple remotes. A remote is the name for a URL of a Git repository. By default your fork will have a remote named "origin" which points to your fork, but you can add another remote named "codeigniter" which points to git://github.com/bcit-ci/CodeIgniter.git. This is a read-only remote but you can pull from this develop branch to update your own.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: If you are using command-line you can do the following:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Contributing
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Hi, I'm Jason, my online nickname is "smathy" which I use on IRC, twitter,
StackOverflow, here on github, and a few other places on the internet.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Oleg is the creator of acl9, but other commitments have meant that he's had
very little time to maintain this project and so I've basically taken over as
the primary maintainer.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
I like to start by introducing myself so that you know that I'm just a human
being, a normal guy, and that if you have something you want to contribute to
acl9 then I'm more than happy to hear from you.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
There really aren't any hard and fast rules here for contributing. Feel free to
raise issues, you can even just ask questions in an issue if you'd like,
although IRC or StackOverflow is probably a much better forum for that. You can
ping me on twitter, or even email me at jk@handle.it
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph:
Also see the README for information on getting in contact with the rest of the
community.

Paragraph: Dev Stuff
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
If you're going to contribute code then just fork our repo, write your thing,
and submit a pull request.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Setup
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
We have a .ruby-version file, so if you use a ruby manager that
understands that then you might need to install that version of ruby, but you
should know how to do that yourself.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
You should be able to just fork the repo and run bundle && rake to see the
tests running.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
We use Appraisal to test against multiple versions of
Rails, so you can read up on that and use it to test against all the Rails
versions we support or against a specific one.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: How to
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
If you're fixing a bug then please arrange your pull request in two commits, the
first one will be a test that demonstrates the bug, that test will be failing
when you create it. The second commit will be the code change that fixes the
bug.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Don't let this be a blocker for you, I'm not saying you have to do TDD. I don't
care whether you actually write the test first, or the code first, I just care
about the order of the commits. Those with experience in reviewing PRs will know
why. I can grab your PR, roll it back to HEAD^ and run the test, seeing it
fail and confirming that your test works, then roll it back to the head of your
branch and see your code fixing the test. It makes it very easy to review a PR.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
You can submit a bugfix without a test, although those take MUCH longer to
review because it's often hard to work out what problem you're solving.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Also, it's up to you whether you want to create an issue in github first. I'd
recommend that you do because it gives a good place to discuss the details of
the issue.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
Also, feel free to submit ideas as PRs, just make sure you put it clearly in the
text that this is not ready for merge yet.
Label: No categories identified.

the demanding, high-volume production environment of the servers
of many organizations around the world.

Label: SC – Submit the changes

When opening a pull request, try to keep the changes focused on
one topic and avoid unrelated changes (even small things, like
editing punctuation or whitespace in comments).
Label: SC – Submit the changes

If you're making big changes, consider discussing it on the
mailing list first. You might save yourself a lot of time if it
turns out that the changes you want to make aren't a good fit for
the project. This is especially true if you are adding new
functionality.

Paragraph: Code standards
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: We have a worldwide community and respect everyones backgrounds and languages, however Forge Networking is primarily developed by English (US) speakers. Because of this the variables, names, functions, comments, and everything else for this code base should be exclusively in English (US).
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: .editorconfig
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: We use .editorconfig to help with conforming to our coding conventions. Please make sure your chosen editor has this enabled. Check editorconfig.org to see if you need to install a plugin or your IDE has this built in.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Anything not listed here should follow the C# standard
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Tabs vs spaces?
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Sorry space fans, we are tabs. Though I know that this is an age old argument in computer science, we had to go with one or the other.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Accessors
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Yes, we are aware that if you do not provide an accessor that it will default to private. However, we like knowing that others are doing what they do on purpose. For this reason you are required to put private in front of your private members.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Member fields are to be camel case starting with an alpha character. For the most part people don't write C# in notepad so do not worry about any prefixes with underscores, or special things like b_ or any of that
Label: DC – Deal with the code
DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Member properties are to be pascal case starting with an alpha character. Also their brackets are to be on 1 line if the behavior is simple. Otherwise you are to use the hanging brackets coding standards
Label: DC – Deal with the code
DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Brackets
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: For single line conditional statements we do not have any brackets, just the line. Preferrably we put the code on the line following the if statement but for simple things like a return a single line is acceptable
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
if (1 == 1)
DoSomethingFancy();
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: For multiple line conditional statements we put "hanging brackets" only"
Label: DC – Deal with the code
DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: For infinite loops, while loops, and do-while loops, we need these to be exceptionally clear. So in the case of any of these we will use hanging brackets.
Label: DC – Deal with the code
DC – Deal with the code
DC – Deal with the code
DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: For lambda expressions we have hanging brackets
Label: DC – Deal with the code
DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: For initializer lists we have hanging brackets (no parenthisis needed)
Label: DC – Deal with the code
DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Comments
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Single line comments should include a space after the slashes
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: // Notice the space after the two slashes
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Commenting out code should not include a space after the slashes
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: //noSpace.Code();
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: TODO comments should include the space after the slashes and then 2 spaces after the colon following the TODO
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: // TODO:  Notice the space after the slashes and the 2 spaces after the colon of todo
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Line length
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: We try to keep our line lengths short, try to stick around 90 characters maximum in the horizontal space and do not go any further than 120 characters. Or goals are to prevent any kind of horizontal scrolling or automatic line wrapping.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Var vs type name
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Though we accept code with var being used, it is hard to code review things listed as just var especially if they are the result of a function. If you are creating a new instance of something you can use var since the type name is in the line of declariation, otherwise please try to type the explicit type of the variable when it is the result of a function.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Function length
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: We prefer very small, descriptive functions over long monolythic functions. Try to keep your functions to something around 4-9 lines. If your functions are longer than 9 lines, it probably is a good chance for breaking it into smaller local private methods or turning what is being processed into a class and handling the logic more inside of there. This is not only for code clarity and readability, but also it makes it much easier to debug knowing the names of functons and produces clear stack traces.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Testing and TDD
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: We are currently trying out the Unity unit testing tools and they look promising so far. My hope is that we will be able to fall more into the TDD (test driven development) flow of programming so that we have many tests for the code to make sure it continues to work as expected for all of the functionality. Of course, I know it is very difficult to unit test a multi-threaded, network based application, but it is important for us to try as much as possible to achieve a full test coverage of the system.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Please make sure that you either create a new file in the ForgeUnity/Assets/BeardedManStudios/Scripts/Editor/Tests folder. Or if you are adding new tests that are either missing or covering new functionality of a class, feel free to update existing tests.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 1. Build and Test Locally
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
This repository holds two mostly identical implementations of the beautifiers: a JavaScript implementation and a Python implementation.
While developing, you may locally build and test the JavaScript or Python (or both). The HTML beautifier is only implemented in JavaScript.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Familiarize yourself with the folder structure and code style before you dive in.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Make changes to the implementation of your choice.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - If working in the JavaScript implementation:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Run make js to build and run unit tests
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Run make static to manually test changes locally at http://localhost:8080
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - To load a debug (human readable) version of the beautifier source, open http://localhost:8080/?debug
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - If working in the Python implementation:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Run make py to build and run unit tests
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Add tests to /test/data/*/test.js.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Run make jstest or make pytest to run style checks, and to generate and run tests.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Include all changed files in your commit - The generated test files are checked in along with changes to the test data files.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 2. Ensure Feature Parity
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Any changes made to one implementation must be also made to the other implementation.  This is required.  Every time we make an exception to this requirement the project becomes harder to maintain.  This will become painfully clear, should you find yourself unable to port changes from one implementation to the other due to implementations being out of sync. We made this a requirement several years ago and there are still open issues for changes that people promised to port "in the next week or two".  The entire HTML beautifier is an example of this. :(
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: The implementations are already very similar and neither Python nor JavaScript are that hard to understand.  Take the plunge, it is easier than you think.  If you get stuck, go ahead and file a Pull Request and we can discuss how to move forward.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Run make (with no parameters) to run style checks, and to generate and run tests on both implementations.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Include all changed files in your commit - The generated test files are checked in along with changes to the test data files.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 3. Update Documentation and Tools
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Update documentation as needed.  This includes files such as the README.md, internal command-line help, and file comments.
Also, check if your change needs any tooling updates.  For example, the CDN URLs required additional scripting to update automatically for new releases.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 4. Submit a Pull Request
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Run make ci locally after commit but before creation of Pull Request.  You may start a Pull Request even if this reports errors, but the PR will not be merged until all errors are fixed.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Include description of changes. Include examples of input and expected output if possible.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Pull requests must pass build checks on all platforms before being merged. We use Travis CI and AppVeyor to run tests on Linux and Windows across multiple versions of Node.js and Python.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Generic Eval Unpacker
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
The attic-genericeval branch includes an unpacker that calls eval on whatever source is passed to it.
This file may be useful when working with source that unpacks itself when eval is called on it, but is also very unsafe.
We have isolated it on this separate branch to keep it from hurting the other children.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - When making an issue, ensure the issue template is filled out, failure to do so can and will result in a closed ticket and a delay in support.

Paragraph: - We now have a two-week of unresponsiveness period before closing a ticket, if this happens, just comment responding to the issue which will re-open the ticket. Ensure to make sure all information requested is provided.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Ensure cross-platform compatibility for every change that's accepted. Mac and Linux are currently supported.
