Paragraph: - Identifiers (variables, functions, methods, keys, enums, etc.) should be clear and unambiguous. Make them as long as necessary to ensure that your code is understandable to others.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Types (classes, structs, enums, typedefs...) should be named with UpperCamelCase.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Functions and methods should be named with lowerCamelCase.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Variables should be either named with lowerCamelCase or better with lower_underscores to avoid conflicts.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Enum values should be named with UPPER_UNDERSCORES.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Be consistent, even when not sticking to the rules.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Code may be run through astyle version 3 or newer. If using astyle, it is important that the astyle changes go into their own commit, so that style changes are not mixed with actual code changes. Command: astyle --options=rawtherapee.astylerc code.cc
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
Behat is an open source, community-driven project. We would love you to contribute to
this awesome project, but remember to follow the few simple rules defined in this
document.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Submitting an Issue
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
1.  State clearly if it is a feature, a problem or refactoring. You can even use one
of the GitHub labels we carefully created
just for that purpose. That makes our life easier as we tend to focus on resolving
issues quicker than adding new features
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
2.  Outline clearly in one/two sentences why that feature is important to you or why
that problem causes you grief (and at what scale). This helps us properly prioritise
what we're working on
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
3.  Behat is automatically tested on every change.
If you have a problem, chances are high it is something very specific to your context
and the more we know about it the more likely we would be able help. At the very least
provide us with enough information about your feature files, context classes and local
environment
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
4.  Make sure you stay professional and do not use offensive language in your issue.
Positive tone in the text of issues is known to reduce lead time to help
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph:
5.  If asked for clarification,
we expect to hear back from you in 7 days. If no answer is given in 7 days, issue will
be automatically closed. You can easily open new issue again later and this rule helps
us reduce the clutter of "silent issues"
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Submitting a Pull Request
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 1.  Make your feature addition, bug fix or refactoring
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
2.  Add new Scenario into one of existing features or create a new .feature file describing
the changes. Check the features/ folder for examples. This is important so we don't break the
changes you introduced in a future version unintentionally
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
3.  Make sure your changes adhere to Backwards Compatibility rules. This is important
so that we adhere to Semantic Versioning v2.0.0
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
4.  Explain the kind of change you made under the [Unreleased] section of the
CHANGELOG.md. You'd make our life even easier if you stick to Keep a Changelog format
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 5.  Do not mess with the BehatApplication::VERSION version
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
6.  Make sure you ran tests and didn't break anything. That will save some time for
Travis
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
7.  Commit your code and submit a Pull Request, providing a clear description of a change,
similar to the one you did in the changelog
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Backwards compatibility
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Starting from v3.0.0, Behat is following Semantic Versioning v2.0.0.
This means that we take backwards compatibility of public API very seriously. So unless you want your PR to start a
new major version of Behat (v4.0.0 for example), you need to make sure that either you do not change existing
interfaces and their usage across the system or that you at least introduce backwards compatibility layer together with
your change. Not following these rules will cause a rejection of your PR. Exception could be an extremely rare case
where BC break is introduced as a measure to fix a serious issue.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: You can read detailed guidance on what BC means in Symfony2 BC guide.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Running tests
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Make sure that you don't break anything with your changes by running the test
suite with your locale set to english:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: $> LANG=C bin/behat --format=progress
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Contributing to Word To Markdown
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Hi there! We're thrilled that you'd like to contribute to Word To Markdown. Your help is essential for keeping it great.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Word To Markdown is an open source project supported by the efforts of an entire community and built one contribution at a time by users like you. We'd love for you to get involved. Whatever your level of skill or however much time you can give, your contribution is greatly appreciated. There are many ways to contribute, from writing tutorials or blog posts, improving the documentation, submitting bug reports and feature requests, helping other users by commenting on issues, or writing code which can be incorporated into Word To Markdown itself.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Following these guidelines helps to communicate that you respect the time of the developers managing and developing this open source project. In return, they should reciprocate that respect in addressing your issue, assessing changes, and helping you finalize your pull requests.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: How to report a bug
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Think you found a bug? Please check the list of open issues to see if your bug has already been reported. If it hasn't please submit a new issue.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Here are a few tips for writing great bug reports:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Describe the specific problem (e.g., "widget doesn't turn clockwise" versus "getting an error")
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Include the steps to reproduce the bug, what you expected to happen, and what happened instead
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Check that you are using the latest version of the project and its dependencies
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Include what version of the project your using, as well as any relevant dependencies
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Only include one bug per issue. If you have discovered two bugs, please file two issues
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Include screenshots or screencasts whenever possible
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Even if you don't know how to fix the bug, including a failing test may help others track it down
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: If you find a security vulnerability, do not open an issue. Please email ben@balter.com instead.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: How to suggest a feature or enhancement
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: If you find yourself wishing for a feature that doesn't exist in Word To Markdown, you are probably not alone. There are bound to be others out there with similar needs. Many of the features that Word To Markdown has today have been added because our users saw the need.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Feature requests are welcome. But take a moment to find out whether your idea fits with the scope and goals of the project. It's up to you to make a strong case to convince the project's developers of the merits of this feature. Please provide as much detail and context as possible, including describing the problem you're trying to solve.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Open an issue which describes the feature you would like to see, why you want it, how it should work, etc.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: What should I do if my document doesn't convert correctly
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 1.  Strip the Word Document down to isolate the troublesome part (e.g., remove the parts that are converting correctly)
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 2.  Upload the .doc or .docx file to someplace like DropBox
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 3.  Open a new issue describing the particular problem. Be sure to include a link to the uploaded file.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: A few tips for reporting conversion issues:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Explain the expected output, actual output, and steps to reproduce
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Include screenshots of the expected and actual output
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Issues should be limited to one conversation error and describe it in detail
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Issues that report "My document won't convert" or "I have these three problems" are less likely to be resolved quickly
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Be sure to include what version of Microsoft Word was used to create the document
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Your first contribution
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: We'd love for you to contribute to the project. Unsure where to begin contributing to Word To Markdown? You can start by looking through these "good first issue" and "help wanted" issues:
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: - Good first issues - issues which should only require a few lines of code and a test or two
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: - Help wanted issues - issues which may be a bit more involved, but are specifically seeking community contributions
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: p.s. Feel free to ask for help; everyone is a beginner at first :smiley_cat:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: How to propose changes
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Here's a few general guidelines for proposing changes:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - If you are changing any user-facing functionality, please be sure to update the documentation
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - If you are adding a new behavior or changing an existing behavior, please be sure to update the corresponding test(s)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Each pull request should implement one feature or bug fix. If you want to add or fix more than one thing, submit more than one pull request
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Do not commit changes to files that are irrelevant to your feature or bug fix
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Don't bump the version number in your pull request (it will be bumped prior to release)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Write a good commit message
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: At a high level, the process for proposing changes is:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 1.  Fork and clone the project
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 2.  Configure and install the dependencies: script/bootstrap
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 3.  Make sure the tests pass on your machine: script/cibuild
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 4.  Create a descriptively named branch: git checkout -b my-branch-name
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 5.  Make your change, add tests and documentation, and make sure the tests still pass
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 6.  Push to your fork and submit a pull request describing your change
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 7.  Pat your self on the back and wait for your pull request to be reviewed and merged
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Interesting in submitting your first Pull Request? It's easy! You can learn how from this free series How to Contribute to an Open Source Project on GitHub
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Contributing to Gunicorn
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Want to hack on Gunicorn? Awesome! Here are instructions to get you
started. They are probably not perfect, please let us know if anything
feels wrong or incomplete.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Contribution guidelines
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Pull requests are always welcome
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
We are always thrilled to receive pull requests, and do our best to
process them as fast as possible. Not sure if that typo is worth a pull
request? Do it! We will appreciate it.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
If your pull request is not accepted on the first try, don't be
discouraged! If there's a problem with the implementation, hopefully you
received feedback on what to improve.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
We're trying very hard to keep Gunicorn lean and focused. We don't want it
to do everything for everybody. This means that we might decide against
incorporating a new feature. However, there might be a way to implement
that feature on top of Gunicorn.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Discuss your design on the mailing list
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
We recommend discussing your plans on the mailing
list before starting to code -
especially for more ambitious contributions.  This gives other
contributors a chance to point you in the right direction, give feedback
on your design, and maybe point out if someone else is working on the
same thing.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Create issues...
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Any significant improvement should be documented as a github
issue before anybody starts
working on it.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: ...but check for existing issues first!
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Please take a moment to check that an issue doesn't already exist
documenting your bug report or improvement proposal. If it does, it
never hurts to add a quick "+1" or "I have this problem too". This will
help prioritize the most common problems and requests.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Conventions
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Don't comment on closed issues or PRs, instead open a new issue and link it to
the old one.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Fork the repo and make changes on your fork in a feature branch:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- If it's a bugfix branch, name it XXX-something where XXX is the number
of the issue
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- If it's a feature branch, create an enhancement issue to announce your
intentions, and name it XXX-something where XXX is the number of the
issue.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Submit unit tests for your changes. Python has a great test framework built
in; use it! Take a look at existing tests for inspiration. Run the full
test suite on your branch before submitting a pull request.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Make sure you include relevant updates or additions to documentation
when creating or modifying features.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
If you are adding a new configuration option or updating an existing one,
please do it in gunicorn/config.py, then run make -C docs html to update
docs/source/settings.rst.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Write clean code.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
Pull requests descriptions should be as clear as possible and include a
reference to all the issues that they address.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Code review comments may be added to your pull request. Discuss, then
make the suggested modifications and push additional commits to your
feature branch. Be sure to post a comment after pushing. The new commits
will show up in the pull request automatically, but the reviewers will
not be notified unless you comment.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Before the pull request is merged, make sure that you squash your
commits into logical units of work using git rebase -i and git push -f. After every commit the test suite should be passing. Include
documentation changes in the same commit so that a revert would remove
all traces of the feature or fix.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Commits that fix or close an issue should include a reference like
Closes #XXX or Fixes #XXX, which will automatically close the issue
when merged.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Add your name to the THANKS file, but make sure the list is sorted and
your name and email address match your git configuration. The THANKS
file is regenerated occasionally from the git commit history, so a
mismatch may result in your changes being overwritten.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Decision process
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: How are decisions made?
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Short answer: with pull requests to the gunicorn repository.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Gunicorn is an open-source project under the MIT License with an open
design philosophy. This means that the repository is the source of truth
for EVERY aspect of the project, including its philosophy, design,
roadmap and APIs. If it's part of the project, it's in the repo. It's
in the repo, it's part of the project.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
As a result, all decisions can be expressed as changes to the
repository. An implementation change is a change to the source code. An
API change is a change to the API specification. A philosophy change is
a change to the relevant documentation. And so on.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: All decisions affecting gunicorn, big and small, follow the same 3 steps:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Step 1: Open a pull request. Anyone can do this.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Step 2: Discuss the pull request. Anyone can do this.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Step 3: Accept or refuse a pull request. The relevant maintainer does this (see below "Who decides what?")
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Who decides what?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
So all decisions are pull requests, and the relevant maintainer makes
the decision by accepting or refusing the pull request.  But how do we
identify the relevant maintainer for a given pull request?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Gunicorn follows the timeless, highly efficient and totally unfair system
known as Benevolent dictator for
life, with
Benoit Chesneau (aka benoitc), in the role of BDFL.  This means that all
decisions are made by default by me. Since making every decision myself
would be highly unscalable, in practice decisions are spread across
multiple maintainers.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: The relevant maintainer for a pull request is assigned in 3 steps:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Step 1: Determine the subdirectory affected by the pull request. This might be src/registry, docs/source/api, or any other part of the repo.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Step 2: Find the MAINTAINERS file which affects this directory. If the directory itself does not have a MAINTAINERS file, work your way up the the repo hierarchy until you find one.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Step 3: The first maintainer listed is the primary maintainer who is assigned the Pull Request. The primary maintainer can reassign a Pull Request to other listed maintainers.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: I'm a maintainer, should I make pull requests too?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Primary maintainers are not required to create pull requests when
changing their own subdirectory, but secondary maintainers are.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Who assigns maintainers?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: benoitc.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: How can I become a maintainer?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Step 1: learn the component inside out
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Step 2: make yourself useful by contributing code, bugfixes, support etc.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Step 3: volunteer on the irc channel (#gunicorn@freenode)
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Don't forget: being a maintainer is a time investment. Make sure you
will have time to make yourself available.  You don't have to be a
maintainer to make a difference on the project!
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: What are a maintainer's responsibility?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: It is every maintainer's responsibility to:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - 1)  Expose a clear roadmap for improving their component.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - 2)  Deliver prompt feedback and decisions on pull requests.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - 3)  Be available to anyone with questions, bug reports, criticism etc. on their component. This includes irc, github requests and the mailing list.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - 4)  Make sure their component respects the philosophy, design and roadmap of the project.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: How is this process changed?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Just like everything else: by making a pull request :)
Label: No categories identified.

Have a new feature? You can start off by writing some tests that detail

Fixing a bug? The best way to ensure it is fixed for good and never comes
back is to write a failing test for it and then make it pass. If you can

failing test.

Paragraph: Debugging Issues
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: By default, Berkshelf will only give you the top-level output from a failed command. If you're working deep inside the core, an error like:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Berkshelf Error: wrong number of arguments (2 for 1)
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: isn't exactly helpful...

Paragraph: Releasing
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Once you are ready to release Berkshelf, perform the following:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 1.  Update CHANGELOG.md with a new header indicating the version to be released
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 2.  Examine the diff (example) between master and the previous version.  Add all merged Pull Requests to the CHANGELOG.md
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 3.  Update version.rb to the desired release version
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 4.  Run bundle update berkshelf
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 5.  Create a PR and review the version.rb changes and CHANGELOG.md changes
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 6.  Once the PR is merged to master, run rake release on the master branch
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Contributing
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Hey there! Glad you want to chime in. Here's what you need to know.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Support Requests
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: There's now a dedicated support channel in Slack. Visit this page to get an invite. Support requests won't be handled through the repository anymore.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: If you have a question, make sure it wasn't already answered. If it wasn't, please refer to the Slack chat. To get an invite, use the badge in the demo page.

Paragraph: Bugs
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Bug reports are tricky. Please provide as much context as possible, and if you want to start working on a fix, we'll be forever grateful! Please try and test around for a bit to make sure you're dealing with a bug and not an issue in your implementation.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: If possible, provide a demo where the bug is isolated and turned into its smallest possible representation. That would help a lot!
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Thanks for reporting bugs, we'd be lost without you.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Feature Requests
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: We're still considering feature requests. Note that we might not implement the feature you want, or exactly how you want it. The goal here is to keep making dragula awesome while not making it too bloated.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: We also dislike overly specific features and favor more abstract ones you the consumer can build other features upon.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Build
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: To compile a standalone browserify module, use the following command. A minified version will also be produced. The compiled bundles are placed inside dist. Since these are autogenerated, please don't include them in your pull requests.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: npm run build
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: You can also run the build continuously, to facilitate development, with this command.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: npm start
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Test
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Run the command below to execute all tests in a DevTools window through Electron. Note that the DevTools will get reloaded whenever your test files change, making tests a breeze!
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: npm run test-watch
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: To run tests a single time, simply run the following command. This is used in CI testing.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: npm test

Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Contributing to JSONView
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: The goal of JSONView is to be a very simple, straightforward add-on that formats JSON. Given that, even though I'm very appreciative of the time and thought put into contributions, I regularly reject them because they add complexity to the add-on that I don't think should be there. Please consider filing an issue before doing any work, so you don't accidentally waste time on something I won't accept.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: There are no hard and fast rules for what I will and will not accept - please just ask via an issue before implementing. Generally, things I have rejected in the past:
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: - Adding new MIME types to the set supported by JSONView. I have an open issue for how I'd like to see additional MIME types handled, and will not accept patches that add arbitrary new MIME types.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Adding new options. While I'm not opposed to adding an option if it really makes sense, the bar is very high for adding anything configurable to the add-on.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Interpreting JSON in any application-specific way. While in the past I've allowed a few feature additions that attempt to interpret JSON (such as recognizing and linkifying URLs), I want JSONView to be a general JSON viewer, and as such will reject any patch that seeks to priviledge specific interpretations of JSON structure.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Adding switches or options to the screen that shows JSON. I don't want to clutter up the JSON view itself with control panels and options, so anything that relies on adding such a thing is likely to be rejected.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Please, don't let this discourage you! Just file an issue first so we can discuss the change you plan to make.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Code Guidelines
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Please match the formatting of existing code - that includes whitespace, documentation, code style, and naming conventions. Look at the code around your patch and just copy that style.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: How to contribute
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 1.  Fork the project in your account and create a new branch: your-great-feature.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 2.  Open an issue in the repository describing the feature contribution you'd like to make. This will help us get you started on the right foot.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 3.  Commit changes in your feature branch.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 4.  Open a pull request and reference the initial issue in the pull request message.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Coding standards
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: This project follows the PSR-2 coding style guidelines. There are many ways to check your code for PSR-2. An excellent tool is PHP_CodeSniffer. The command line tool phpcs can be run against any single file. Phing, a PHP build tool, integrates nicely with phpcs to automate PSR-2 checks across all source files in a project.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Development process
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Development processes used by contributors to the project are described on this page. It does not endorse one over the other; rather it is meant to share two different approaches.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Development
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Most local development should be done using the oldest supported version of
ruby. See required_ruby_version in the gemspec.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Testing
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Tests can be run against different versions of Rails:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
BUNDLE_GEMFILE=gemfiles/rails_6.0.rb bundle install
BUNDLE_GEMFILE=gemfiles/rails_6.0.rb bundle exec rake
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: To run a single test:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
BUNDLE_GEMFILE=gemfiles/rails_6.0.rb \
bundle exec ruby -I test path/to/test.rb
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Bundler can be omitted, and the latest installed version of a gem dependency
will be used. This is only suitable for certain unit tests.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: ruby
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Test MySQL
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
mysql -e 'drop database authlogic; create database authlogic;' && \
DB=mysql BUNDLE_GEMFILE=gemfiles/rails_5.2.rb bundle exec rake
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Test PostgreSQL
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
psql -c 'create database authlogic;' -U postgres
DB=postgres BUNDLE_GEMFILE=gemfiles/rails_6.0.rb bundle exec rake
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Linting
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
Running rake also runs a linter, rubocop. Contributions must pass both
the linter and the tests. The linter can be run on its own.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: BUNDLE_GEMFILE=gemfiles/rails_6.0.rb bundle exec rubocop
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: To run the tests without linting, use rake test.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: BUNDLE_GEMFILE=gemfiles/rails_6.0.rb bundle exec rake test
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Version Control Branches
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
We've been trying to follow the rails way, stable branches, but have been
inconsistent. We should have one branch for each minor version, named like
4-3-stable. Releases should be done on those branches, not in master. So,
the "stable" branches should be the only branches with release tags.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: A normal release (no backport)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 1.  git checkout 4-3-stable # the latest "stable" branch (see above)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 2.  git merge master
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 3.  Update version number in lib/authlogic/version.rb
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 4.  In the changelog,
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Add release date to entry
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Add a new "Unreleased" section at top
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 1.  In the readme,
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Update version number in the docs table at the top
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - For non-patch versions, update the compatibility table
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 1.  Commit with message like "Release 4.3.0"
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 2.  git push origin 4-3-stable
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 3.  CI should pass
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 4.  gem build authlogic.gemspec
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 5.  gem push authlogic-4.3.0.gem
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 7.  git push --tags origin 4-3-stable
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 8.  update the docs in the master branch, because that's what people look at
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - git checkout master
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - git cherry-pick abcd1234 # the SHA from the stable branch
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - commit and push with [ci skip]
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Install Node.js
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: - Install Yarn
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Useful Commands:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Install project dependencies: yarn
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: - Link together all the packages: yarn setup
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: - Compile all the packages (needed once): yarn compile
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: - Watch the prime-core and prime-ui packages for changes and recompile: yarn start
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: - Reset the repository to a clean state and re-install everything: yarn reset
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Pull Requests
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Requirements
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
For non-bug-fixes, please open an issue first and discuss your idea to make sure we're on the same page.
Alternatively, prepend your PR title with [discuss] to have a conversation around the code.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: All PRs:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 1.  Must not break the test suite (yarn test), nor reduce test coverage (yarn coverage). If you're fixing a bug, include a test that would fail without your fix.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 2.  Must respect the tslint.json (yarn lint).
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: 3.  Must be isolated. Avoid grouping many, unrelated changes in a single PR.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 4.  GitHub now allows auto-squashing of commits in a PR, so no need to rebase your commits before final submission. All commit messages must follow conventional commit (angular).
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Tests locally
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: All tests should run locally by default.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Integration tests for @primecms/core need env at ./packages/prime-core/.env.test.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Submission
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 1.  From Getting Started, your work should ideally be in its own feature branch.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 2.  git push your branch to git and create a new pull request for the appropriate branch.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Contributing to Bitcoin Core
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
The Bitcoin Core project operates an open contributor model where anyone is
welcome to contribute towards development in the form of peer review, testing
and patches. This document explains the practical process and guidelines for
contributing.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
First, in terms of structure, there is no particular concept of "Bitcoin Core
developers" in the sense of privileged people. Open source often naturally
revolves around a meritocracy where contributors earn trust from the developer
community over time. Nevertheless, some hierarchy is necessary for practical
purposes. As such, there are repository "maintainers" who are responsible for
merging pull requests, as well as a "lead maintainer" who is responsible for the
release cycle as well as overall merging, moderation and appointment of
maintainers.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Getting Started
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: New contributors are very welcome and needed.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Reviewing and testing is highly valued and the most effective way you can contribute
as a new contributor. It also will teach you much more about the code and
process than opening pull requests. Please refer to the peer review
section below.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph:
Before you start contributing, familiarize yourself with the Bitcoin Core build
system and tests. Refer to the documentation in the repository on how to build
Bitcoin Core and how to run the unit tests, functional tests, and fuzz tests.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
There are many open issues of varying difficulty waiting to be fixed.
If you're looking for somewhere to start contributing, check out the
good first issue
list or changes that are
up for grabs.
Some of them might no longer be applicable. So if you are interested, but
unsure, you might want to leave a comment on the issue first.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph:
You may also participate in the weekly
Bitcoin Core PR Review Club meeting.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: Good First Issue Label
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph:
The purpose of the good first issue label is to highlight which issues are
suitable for a new contributor without a deep understanding of the codebase.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph:
However, good first issues can be solved by anyone. If they remain unsolved
for a longer time, a frequent contributor might address them.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph:
You do not need to request permission to start working on an issue. However,
you are encouraged to leave a comment if you are planning to work on it. This
will help other contributors monitor which issues are actively being addressed
and is also an effective way to request assistance if and when you need it.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: Communication Channels
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph:
Most communication about Bitcoin Core development happens on IRC, in the
#bitcoin-core-dev channel on Freenode. The easiest way to participate on IRC is
with the web client, webchat.freenode.net. Chat
history logs can be found
on http://www.erisian.com.au/bitcoin-core-dev/
and http://gnusha.org/bitcoin-core-dev/.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph:
Discussion about codebase improvements happens in GitHub issues and pull
requests.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph:
The developer
mailing list
should be used to discuss complicated or controversial consensus or P2P protocol changes before working on
a patch set.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Contributor Workflow
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
The codebase is maintained using the "contributor workflow" where everyone
without exception contributes patch proposals using "pull requests" (PRs). This
facilitates social contribution, easy testing and peer review.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: To contribute a patch, the workflow is as follows:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 1.  Fork repository (only for the first time)
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 2.  Create topic branch
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 3.  Commit patches
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
For GUI-related issues or pull requests, the https://github.com/bitcoin-core/gui repository should be used.
For all other issues and pull requests, the https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin node repository should be used.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: The master branch for all monotree repositories is identical.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
As a rule of thumb, everything that only modifies src/qt is a GUI-only pull
request. However:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
- For global refactoring or other transversal changes the node repository
should be used.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
- For GUI-related build system changes, the node repository should be used
because the change needs review by the build systems reviewers.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
- Changes in src/interfaces need to go to the node repository because they
might affect other components like the wallet.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
For large GUI changes that include build system and interface changes, it is
recommended to first open a pull request against the GUI repository. When there
is agreement to proceed with the changes, a pull request with the build system
and interfaces changes can be submitted to the node repository.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
The project coding conventions in the developer notes
must be followed.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Committing Patches
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
In general, commits should be atomic
and diffs should be easy to read. For this reason, do not mix any formatting
fixes or code moves with actual code changes.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Make sure each individual commit is hygienic: that it builds successfully on its
own without warnings, errors, regressions, or test failures.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Commit messages should be verbose by default consisting of a short subject line
(50 chars max), a blank line and detailed explanatory text as separate
paragraph(s), unless the title alone is self-explanatory (like "Corrected typo
in init.cpp") in which case a single title line is sufficient. Commit messages should be
helpful to people reading your code in the future, so explain the reasoning for
your decisions. Further explanation here.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
If a particular commit references another issue, please add the reference. For
example: refs #1234 or fixes #4321. Using the fixes or closes keywords
will cause the corresponding issue to be closed when the pull request is merged.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Commit messages should never contain any @ mentions (usernames prefixed with "@").
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Please refer to the Git manual for more information
about Git.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Push changes to your fork
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Create pull request
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Creating the Pull Request
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
The title of the pull request should be prefixed by the component or area that
the pull request affects. Valid areas as:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - consensus for changes to consensus critical code
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - doc for changes to the documentation
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - qt or gui for changes to bitcoin-qt
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - log for changes to log messages
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - mining for changes to the mining code
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - net or p2p for changes to the peer-to-peer network code
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - refactor for structural changes that do not change behavior
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - rpc, rest or zmq for changes to the RPC, REST or ZMQ APIs
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - script for changes to the scripts and tools
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - test, qa or ci for changes to the unit tests, QA tests or CI code
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - util or lib for changes to the utils or libraries
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - wallet for changes to the wallet code
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - build for changes to the GNU Autotools or reproducible builds
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Examples:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
consensus: Add new opcode for BIP-XXXX OP_CHECKAWESOMESIG
net: Automatically create hidden service, listen on Tor
qt: Add feed bump button
log: Fix typo in log message
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
The body of the pull request should contain sufficient description of what the
patch does, and even more importantly, why, with justification and reasoning.
You should include references to any discussions (for example, other issues or
mailing list discussions).
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
The description for a new pull request should not contain any @ mentions. The
PR description will be included in the commit message when the PR is merged and
any users mentioned in the description will be annoyingly notified each time a
fork of Bitcoin Core copies the merge. Instead, make any username mentions in a
subsequent comment to the PR.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Translation changes
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Note that translations should not be submitted as pull requests. Please see
Translation Process
for more information on helping with translations.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Work in Progress Changes and Requests for Comments
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
If a pull request is not to be considered for merging (yet), please
prefix the title with [WIP] or use Tasks Lists
in the body of the pull request to indicate tasks are pending.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Address Feedback
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
At this stage, one should expect comments and review from other contributors. You
can add more commits to your pull request by committing them locally and pushing
to your fork until you have satisfied all feedback.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Note: Code review is a burdensome but important part of the development process, and as such, certain types of pull requests are rejected. In general, if the improvements do not warrant the review effort required, the PR has a high chance of being rejected. It is up to the PR author to convince the reviewers that the changes warrant the review effort, and if reviewers are "Concept NACK'ing" the PR, the author may need to present arguments and/or do research backing their suggested changes.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Squashing Commits
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
If your pull request contains fixup commits (commits that change the same line of code repeatedly) or too fine-grained
commits, you may be asked to squash your commits
before it will be merged. The basic squashing workflow is shown below.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
git checkout your_branch_name
git rebase -i HEAD~n
# n is normally the number of commits in the pull request.
# Set commits (except the one in the first line) from 'pick' to 'squash', save and quit.
# On the next screen, edit/refine commit messages.
# Save and quit.
git push -f # (force push to GitHub)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Please update the resulting commit message, if needed. It should read as a
coherent message. In most cases, this means not just listing the interim
commits.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
If you have problems with squashing or other git workflows, you can enable
"Allow edits from maintainers" in the right-hand sidebar of the GitHub web
interface and ask for help in the pull request.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Please refrain from creating several pull requests for the same change.
Use the pull request that is already open (or was created earlier) to amend
changes. This preserves the discussion and review that happened earlier for
the respective change set.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
The length of time required for peer review is unpredictable and will vary from
pull request to pull request.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Rebasing Changes
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
When a pull request conflicts with the target branch, you may be asked to rebase it on top of the current target branch.
The git rebase command will take care of rebuilding your commits on top of the new base.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
This project aims to have a clean git history, where code changes are only made in non-merge commits. This simplifies
auditability because merge commits can be assumed to not contain arbitrary code changes. Merge commits should be signed,
and the resulting git tree hash must be deterministic and reproducible. The script in
/contrib/verify-commits checks that.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
After a rebase, reviewers are encouraged to sign off on the force push. This should be relatively straightforward with
the git range-diff tool explained in the productivity
notes. To avoid needless review churn, maintainers will
generally merge pull requests that received the most review attention first.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Pull Request Philosophy
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Patchsets should always be focused. For example, a pull request could add a
feature, fix a bug, or refactor code; but not a mixture. Please also avoid super
pull requests which attempt to do too much, are overly large, or overly complex
as this makes review difficult.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Features
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
When adding a new feature, thought must be given to the long term technical debt
and maintenance that feature may require after inclusion. Before proposing a new
feature that will require maintenance, please consider if you are willing to
maintain it (including bug fixing). If features get orphaned with no maintainer
in the future, they may be removed by the Repository Maintainer.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Refactoring
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
Refactoring is a necessary part of any software project's evolution. The
following guidelines cover refactoring pull requests for the project.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
There are three categories of refactoring: code-only moves, code style fixes, and
code refactoring. In general, refactoring pull requests should not mix these
three kinds of activities in order to make refactoring pull requests easy to
review and uncontroversial. In all cases, refactoring PRs must not change the
behaviour of code within the pull request (bugs must be preserved as is).
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
Project maintainers aim for a quick turnaround on refactoring pull requests, so
where possible keep them short, uncomplex and easy to verify.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
Pull requests that refactor the code should not be made by new contributors. It
requires a certain level of experience to know where the code belongs to and to
understand the full ramification (including rebase effort of open pull requests).
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
Trivial pull requests or pull requests that refactor the code with no clear
benefits may be immediately closed by the maintainers to reduce unnecessary
workload on reviewing.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: "Decision Making" Process
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
The following applies to code changes to the Bitcoin Core project (and related
projects such as libsecp256k1), and is not to be confused with overall Bitcoin
Network Protocol consensus changes.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Whether a pull request is merged into Bitcoin Core rests with the project merge
maintainers and ultimately the project lead.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Maintainers will take into consideration if a patch is in line with the general
principles of the project; meets the minimum standards for inclusion; and will
judge the general consensus of contributors.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: In general, all pull requests must:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Have a clear use case, fix a demonstrable bug or serve the greater good of
the project (for example refactoring for modularisation);
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Be well peer-reviewed;
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Have unit tests, functional tests, and fuzz tests, where appropriate;
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Follow code style guidelines (C++, functional tests);
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Not break the existing test suite;
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Where bugs are fixed, where possible, there should be unit tests
demonstrating the bug and also proving the fix. This helps prevent regression.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Change relevant comments and documentation when behaviour of code changes.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Patches that change Bitcoin consensus rules are considerably more involved than
normal because they affect the entire ecosystem and so must be preceded by
extensive mailing list discussions and have a numbered BIP. While each case will
be different, one should be prepared to expend more time and effort than for
other kinds of patches because of increased peer review and consensus building
requirements.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Peer Review
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Anyone may participate in peer review which is expressed by comments in the pull
request. Typically reviewers will review the code for obvious errors, as well as
test out the patch set and opine on the technical merits of the patch. Project
maintainers take into account the peer review when determining if there is
consensus to merge a pull request (remember that discussions may have been
spread out over GitHub, mailing list and IRC discussions).
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Conceptual Review
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: A review can be a conceptual review, where the reviewer leaves a comment
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Concept (N)ACK, meaning "I do (not) agree with the general goal of this pull
request",
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Approach (N)ACK, meaning Concept ACK, but "I do (not) agree with the
approach of this change".
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
A NACK needs to include a rationale why the change is not worthwhile.
NACKs without accompanying reasoning may be disregarded.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Code Review
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
After conceptual agreement on the change, code review can be provided. A review
begins with ACK BRANCH_COMMIT, where BRANCH_COMMIT is the top of the PR
branch, followed by a description of how the reviewer did the review. The
following language is used within pull request comments:
Label: SC – Submit the changes
SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- "I have not tested the code, but I have reviewed it and it looks
OK, I agree it can be merged";
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - A "nit" refers to a trivial, often non-blocking issue.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Project maintainers reserve the right to weigh the opinions of peer reviewers
using common sense judgement and may also weigh based on merit. Reviewers that
have demonstrated a deeper commitment and understanding of the project over time
or who have clear domain expertise may naturally have more weight, as one would
expect in all walks of life.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Where a patch set affects consensus-critical code, the bar will be much
higher in terms of discussion and peer review requirements, keeping in mind that
mistakes could be very costly to the wider community. This includes refactoring
of consensus-critical code.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Where a patch set proposes to change the Bitcoin consensus, it must have been
discussed extensively on the mailing list and IRC, be accompanied by a widely
discussed BIP and have a generally widely perceived technical consensus of being
a worthwhile change based on the judgement of the maintainers.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Finding Reviewers
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
As most reviewers are themselves developers with their own projects, the review
process can be quite lengthy, and some amount of patience is required. If you find
that you've been waiting for a pull request to be given attention for several
months, there may be a number of reasons for this, some of which you can do something
about:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- It may be because of a feature freeze due to an upcoming release. During this time,
only bug fixes are taken into consideration. If your pull request is a new feature,
it will not be prioritized until after the release. Wait for the release.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- It may be because the changes you are suggesting do not appeal to people. Rather than
nits and critique, which require effort and means they care enough to spend time on your
contribution, thundering silence is a good sign of widespread (mild) dislike of a given change
(because people don't assume others won't actually like the proposal). Don't take
that personally, though! Instead, take another critical look at what you are suggesting
and see if it: changes too much, is too broad, doesn't adhere to the
developer notes, is dangerous or insecure, is messily written, etc.
Identify and address any of the issues you find. Then ask e.g. on IRC if someone could give
their opinion on the concept itself.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- It may be because your code is too complex for all but a few people, and those people
may not have realized your pull request even exists. A great way to find people who
are qualified and care about the code you are touching is the
Git Blame feature. Simply
look up who last modified the code you are changing and see if you can find
them and give them a nudge. Don't be incessant about the nudging, though.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Finally, if all else fails, ask on IRC or elsewhere for someone to give your pull request
a look. If you think you've been waiting for an unreasonably long time (say,
more than a month) for no particular reason (a few lines changed, etc.),
this is totally fine. Try to return the favor when someone else is asking
for feedback on their code, and the universe balances out.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: - Remember that the best thing you can do while waiting is give review to others!
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Backporting
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
Security and bug fixes can be backported from master to release
branches.
If the backport is non-trivial, it may be appropriate to open an
additional PR to backport the change, but only after the original PR
has been merged.
Otherwise, backports will be done in batches and
the maintainers will use the proper Needs backport (...) labels
when needed (the original author does not need to worry about it).
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: A backport should contain the following metadata in the commit body:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Github-Pull: #<PR number>
Rebased-From: <commit hash of the original commit>
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Have a look at an example backport PR.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Also see the backport.py script.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Release Policy
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: The project leader is the release manager for each Bitcoin Core release.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Copyright
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
By contributing to this repository, you agree to license your work under the
MIT license unless specified otherwise in contrib/debian/copyright or at
the top of the file itself. Any work contributed where you are not the original
author must contain its license header with the original author(s) and source.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Contributing to bitcoinjs-lib
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Firstly in terms of structure, there is no particular concept of "bitcoinjs developers" in a sense of privileged people.
Open source revolves around a meritocracy where contributors who help gain trust from the community.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: For practical purpose, there are repository "maintainers" who are responsible for merging pull requests.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: We are always accepting of pull requests, but we do adhere to specific standards in regards to coding style, test driven development and commit messages.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Communication Channels

Paragraph: GitHub is the preferred method of communication between members.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Otherwise, in order of preference:
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: - bitcoinjs.slack.com
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: - #bitcoinjs-dev on Freenode IRC
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Workflow
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
The codebase is maintained using the "contributor workflow" where everyone without exception contributes patch proposals using "pull requests".
This facilitates social contribution, easy testing and peer review.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: To contribute a patch, the workflow is as follows:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 1.  Fork repository
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 2.  Create topic branch
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 3.  Commit patches
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 4.  Push changes to your fork
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 5.  Submit a pull request to https://github.com/bitcoinjs/bitcoinjs-lib
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Commits should be atomic and diffs easy to read.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: If your pull request is accepted for merging, you may be asked by a maintainer to squash and or rebase your commits before it is merged.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Please refrain from creating several pull requests for the same change.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Patchsets should be focused:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: * Adding a feature, or
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: * Fixing a bug, or
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: * Refactoring code.

Paragraph: If you combine these, the PR may be rejected or asked to be split up.

Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Regarding TypeScript
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: This library is written in TypeScript with tslint, prettier, and the tsc transpiler. These tools will help during testing to notice improper logic before committing and sending a pull request.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Some rules regarding TypeScript:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Modify the typescript source code in an IDE that will give you warnings for transpile/lint errors.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Once you are done with the modifications, run npm run format then npm test
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Running the tests will transpile the ts files into js and d.ts files.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Use git diff or other tools to verify that the ts and js are changing the same parts.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Commit all changes to ts, js, and d.ts files.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Add tests where necessary.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Submit your pull request.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Using TypeScript is for preventing bugs while writing code, as well as automatically generating type definitions. However, the JS file diffs must be verified, and any unverified JS will not be published to npm.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: We adhere to Bitcoin-Core policy
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Bitcoin script payment/script templates are based on community consensus,  but typically adhere to bitcoin-core node policy by default.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - bitcoinjs.script.decompile is consensus bound only,  it does not reject based on policy.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - bitcoinjs.script.compile will try to adhere to bitcoin-core IsStandard policies rules. (eg. minimalpush in https://github.com/bitcoinjs/bitcoinjs-lib/pull/638)
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Any elliptic curve sign operations should adhere to IsStandard policies, like LOW_S, but verify should not reject them [by default].
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: If you need non-standard rejecting decoding, you should use an external module,  not this library.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: TLDR
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Where "standards compliant" refers to the default policies of bitcoin-core,  we adhere to the following:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Any "creation" event must create standards-compliant data (standards bound)
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Any "validation" event must allow for non-standards compliant data (consensus bound)
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: For stricter validation,  use an external module which we [may have] provided.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Contributing to Copay
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Please take a moment to review this document in order to make the contribution
process easy and effective for everyone involved.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Following these guidelines helps to communicate that you respect the time of
the developers managing and developing this open source project. In return,
they should reciprocate that respect in addressing your issue or assessing
patches and features.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Using the issue tracker
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
The issue tracker is the preferred channel for bug reports,
features requests, support requests (#support) and submitting pull
requests, but please respect the following restrictions:
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph:
- Please do not derail or troll issues. Keep the discussion on topic and
respect the opinions of others.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Bug reports
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
A bug is a demonstrable problem that is caused by the code in the repository.
Good bug reports are extremely helpful - thank you!
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Guidelines for bug reports:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
1.  Use the GitHub issue search — check if the issue has already been
reported.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
2.  Check if the issue has been fixed — try to reproduce it using the
latest master or development branch in the repository.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
3.  Isolate the problem — create a reduced test
case and a live example.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
A good bug report shouldn't leave others needing to chase you up for more
information. Please try to be as detailed as possible in your report. What is
your environment? What steps will reproduce the issue? What browser(s) and OS
experience the problem? What would you expect to be the outcome? All these
details will help people to fix any potential bugs.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Example:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Short and descriptive example bug report title
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
A summary of the issue and the browser/OS environment in which it occurs. If
suitable, include the steps required to reproduce the bug.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 1.  This is the first step
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 2.  This is the second step
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 3.  Further steps, etc.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: <url> - a link to the reduced test case
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Any other information you want to share that is relevant to the issue being
reported. This might include the lines of code that you have identified as
causing the bug, and potential solutions (and your opinions on their
merits).
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Feature requests
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Feature requests are welcome. But take a moment to find out whether your idea
fits with the scope and aims of the project. It's up to you to make a strong
case to convince the project's developers of the merits of this feature. Please
provide as much detail and context as possible.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Support requests
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
If you are having particular problem with your Copay instalation, please first search older
issues in order to learn if the issue is already reported. It could be fixed already.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Please also check our FAQ.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
When requesting support describe the issue as much in detail as possible. Consider to
provide the following information:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Which platform are you using? (Which device and operating system)
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Which version of Copay are you using? (Check Copay version on the side menu)
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Please import your wallet on a different platform. Does the problem persist?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - What type of wallet are you using? (multisig or singlesig)
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - When the wallet was created? On which device / operating system
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- Please check Copay logs (General Settings -> About Copay -> Session Logs). Look for
any errors reported there (errors are shown in red)
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - If possible, please provide a screenshot of the error / issue.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
If you need to provide personal / sensitive data to solve the issue (like the Wallet Id), do not use Github Issues.
We will provide a better channel (like an BitPay email address) so you can send the information. If possible, please
encrypt your emails using GnuPG.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: To open an issue go to Github Issues.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Pull requests
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Good pull requests - patches, improvements, new features - are a fantastic
help. They should remain focused in scope and avoid containing unrelated
commits.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Please ask first before embarking on any significant pull request (e.g.
implementing features, refactoring code, porting to a different language),
otherwise you risk spending a lot of time working on something that the
project's developers might not want to merge into the project.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
Please adhere to the coding conventions used throughout Copay (indentation, tests, etc.). You can
check and fix your code patch with:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
npm run test:link         # Check if the code matches style rules
npm run fix:prettier      # Modify files to match style rules
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
IMPORTANT: By submitting a patch, you agree to allow the project owner to
license your work under the same license as that used by the project.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Contributing to Tiled
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: All kinds of contributions are very appreciated, be it documentation, code or build system improvements, be it a small patch, a feature or maybe even becoming a co-maintainer of Tiled. Bug reports and feature requests are of course welcome too!
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Reporting an Issue
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Make sure to mention the following things:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - How the issue can reproduced
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - What behavior you expected instead
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - What actually happened
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Tiled version, operating system, etc. if possibly relevant.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Also, please consider adding a screenshot or video if it helps illustrate the issue.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Requesting a Feature
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: First of all, look around the already open issues to see if the feature was already requested in some form. In that case it's better to comment on the existing feature instead.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: If you're not entirely sure about what feature you need, consider to post your problem on the forum instead.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: In any case, be sure to describe the feature in enough detail, to consider its implications on existing parts of the software if relevant and to describe how it would help you in particular. Also, please consider including a mockup if the issue includes UI changes.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Submitting a Patch
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Ideally, start with something small to get familiar with the review process and work up from there.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Make an effort to follow the overal coding style, which is roughly based on the Qt Creator coding style.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Be prepared for detailed feedback on your patch and to make several revisions.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Each pull request will be built automatically for Windows, Linux and macOS. If the build fails anywhere, please check if it may be a problem with your patch.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Code Conduct
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: We're all friends! Please try and adhere to our simple rules
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Be friendly and patient.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Be welcoming: We strive to be a community that welcomes and supports people of all backgrounds and identities. This includes, but is not limited to members of any race, ethnicity, culture, national origin, colour, immigration status, social and economic class, educational level, sex, sexual orientation, gender identity and expression, age, size, family status, political belief, religion, and mental and physical ability.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Be considerate: Your work will be used by other people, and you in turn will depend on the work of others. Any decision you take will affect users and colleagues, and you should take those consequences into account when making decisions. Remember that we
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Be respectful: Not all of us will agree all the time, but disagreement is no excuse for poor behavior and poor manners. We might all experience some frustration now and then, but we cannot allow that frustration to turn into a personal attack. It
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Be careful in the words that we choose: we are a community of professionals, and we conduct ourselves professionally. Be kind to others. Do not insult or put down other participants. Harassment and other exclusionary behavior aren
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Try to understand why we disagree: Disagreements, both social and technical, happen all the time. It is important that we resolve disagreements and differing views constructively. Remember that we
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Contributing to blazingSQL
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Contributions to blazingSQL fall into the following three categories.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
1.  To report a bug, request a new feature, or report a problem with
documentation, please file an issue
describing in detail the problem or new feature. The BlazingSQL team evaluates
and triages issues, and schedules them for a release. If you believe the
issue needs priority attention, please comment on the issue to notify the
team.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
2.  To propose and implement a new Feature, please file a new feature request
issue. Describe the
intended feature and discuss the design and implementation with the team and
community. Once the team agrees that the plan looks good, go ahead and
implement it, using the code contributions guide below.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
3.  To implement a feature or bug-fix for an existing outstanding issue, please
Follow the code contributions guide below. If you
need more context on a particular issue, please ask in a comment.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Code contributions
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 1.  Follow the guide in our documentation for Building From Source.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 2.  Comment on the issue stating that you are going to work on it.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 3.  Code! Make sure to update unit tests!
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 4.  When done, create your pull request.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 5.  Wait for other developers to review your code and update code as needed.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 6.  Once reviewed and approved, a BlazingSQL developer will merge your pull request.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
Remember, if you are unsure about anything, don't hesitate to comment on issues
and ask for clarifications!
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Discussing the current state of the code
