Paragraph: We Develop with Github
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: We use GitHub to host code, to track issues and feature requests, and to accept Pull Requests.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Report Bugs using Github's issues
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: If you find bugs, mistakes, or inconsistencies in this project's code or documents, please let us know by opening a new issue, but consider searching through existing issues first to check and see if the problem has already been reported. If it has, it never hurts to add a quick "+1" or "I have this problem too". This helps prioritize the most common problems and requests.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Write Bug Reports with Detail, Background, and Sample Code
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: This is an example of a good bug report by @briandk. Here's another example from craig.hockenberry.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Great Bug Reports tend to have:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - A quick summary and/or background
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Steps to reproduce
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Be specific!
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Give sample code if you can. The stackoverflow bug report includes sample code that anyone with a base R setup can run to reproduce what I was seeing
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - What you expected would happen
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - What actually happens
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Notes (possibly including why you think this might be happening, or stuff you tried that didn't work)
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: People love thorough bug reports. I'm not even kidding.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Submit Code Changes through Pull Requests
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Simple Pull Requests to fix typos, to document, or to fix small bugs are always welcome.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: We ask that more significant improvements to the project be first proposed before anybody starts to code as an issue or as a draft Pull Request, which is a nice new feature that gives other contributors a chance to point you in the right direction, give feedback on the design, and maybe discuss if related work is already under way.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Use a Consistent Coding Style
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - We indent using two spaces (soft tabs)
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - We ALWAYS put spaces after list items and method parameters ([1, 2, 3], not [1,2,3]), around operators (x += 1, not x+=1), and around hash arrows.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - This is open-source software. Consider the people who will read your code, and make it look nice for them. It's sort of like driving a car: Perhaps you love doing donuts when you're alone, but with passengers the goal is to make the ride as smooth as possible.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Use Github Flow for Pull Requests
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: We use Github Flow. When you submit Pull Requests, please:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 1.  Fork the repo and create your branch from master.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 2.  If you've added code that should be tested, add tests.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 3.  If you've changed APIs, update the documentation.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 4.  Ensure the test suite passes.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 5.  Make sure your code lints.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 6.  Issue that Pull Request!
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Submit Under the BSD-2-Clause Plus Patent License
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: In short, when you submit code changes, your submissions are understood to be available under the same CC-BY license that covers the project. We also ask all code contributors to GPG sign the Contributor License Agreement (CLA.md) to protect future users of this project. Feel free to contact the maintainers if that's a concern.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Community Contribution Guidelines
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: As the creators and maintainers of this project, we want to ensure that the project lives and continues to grow. Not blocked by any singular person's computer time. One of the simplest ways of doing this is by encouraging a larger set of shallow contributors. Through this, we hope to mitigate the problems of a project that needs updates, but there is no-one who has the power to do so.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Development Process
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: We maintain two permanent, protected branches: master and development.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: master is for the current release. It has already been distributed to jcenter and can't be modified at this point (except for docs that may be incorrect for the current release!).
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: development is where we stage work for the next release. Pull requests should be directed to this branch.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: When working on a new feature or fix that may span multiple commits, please do so in a feature branch (ex: feature/my_cool_thing). Please clean up these feature branches once merged into development.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: When a new version is ready to be released, please create a pull request to merge development into master, named something like "Release 10.0". Then we can have some final discussion before we merge it into master and push the release out to the public.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Since development is a shared branch, it is important not to ever rebase this branch onto master. If a bug fix is applied to master it can be merged into development using good old simple git checkout development && git merge master. Yes this will clutter the history a little bit, but it also provides important context to know how/when a patch was applied. Merge commits can be considered necessary historical data, not warts on an idealized history graph.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Testing
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: To run tests locally, just run ./gradlew test. Tests should always be run before pushing anything to the repo.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Ownership
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: If you get a merged pull-request of substance (ie not just a typo fix), then you are eligible for push access to this repo. Simply request access via a new GitHub issue.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Offhand, it is easy to imagine that this would make code quality suffer, but in reality it offers fresh perspectives to the codebase and encourages ownership from people who are depending on the project. If you are building a project that relies on this codebase, then you probably have the skills to improve it and offer valuable feedback. At the end of the day, there isn't too much risk in this, as the master branch is still locked, and jcenter access is still being restricted.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Everyone comes in with their own perspective on what a project could/should look like, and encouraging discussion can help expose good ideas sooner.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Why do we give out push access?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: It can be overwhelming to be offered the chance to wipe the source code for a project. Do not worry, we do not let you push to master. All code is peer-reviewed, and we have the convention that someone other than the submitter should merge non-trivial pull requests.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: As a contributor, you can merge other people's pull requests, or other contributors can merge yours. You will not be assigned a pull request, but you are welcome to jump in and take a code review on topics that interest you.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: This project is not continuously deployed, there is space for debate after review too. Offering everyone the chance to revert, or make an amending pull request. If it feels right, merge.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: How can we help you get comfortable contributing?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: It is normal for a first pull request to be a potential fix for a problem, and moving on from there to helping the project's direction can be difficult. We will try to help contributors cross that barrier by offering good first step issues. These issues can be fixed without feeling like you are stepping on toes. Ideally, these are non-critical issues that are well defined. They will be purposely avoided by mature contributors to the project, to make space for others.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: We aim to keep all project discussion inside GitHub issues. This is to make sure valuable discussion is accessible via search. If you have questions about how to use the library, or how the project is running - GitHub issues are the goto tool for this project.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Our expectations on you as a contributor
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: To quote @alloy from this issue:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Do not ever feel bad for not contributing to open source.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: We want contributors to provide ideas, keep the ship shipping and to take some of the load from others. It is non-obligatory; we
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: The fact that you will have push access will allow you to:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Avoid having to fork the project if you want to submit other pull requests, as you will be able to create branches directly on the project.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Help triage issues and merge pull requests.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Pick up the project if other maintainers move their focus elsewhere.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: It is up to you to use those superpowers or not though ?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: If someone submits a pull request that is not perfect, and you are reviewing, it is better to think about the PR's motivation rather than the specific implementation. Having braces on the wrong line should not be a blocker. Though we do want to keep test coverage high, we will work with you to figure that out together.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: What about if you have problems that cannot be discussed in a public issue?
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Eric Kuck has a contactable email on his GitHub profile, and is happy to talk about any problems.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: How to Contribute
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Thank you for inquiring facil.io's contribution guide. It's people like you and me, that are willing to share our efforts, who help make the world of open source development so inspiring and wonderful.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Guidelines
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: General Guidelines
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: "Facil" comes from the Spanish word "easy", and this is embedded in facil.io's DNA.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: facil.io contributions should (ideally) be:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Easy to use:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: clear and concise API, with macros that emulate "named arguments" when appropriate.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Easy to maintain:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Modular: even at the price of performance and even (although less desired) at the price of keeping things DRY.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Developers should be able to simply remove the module from their implementation if they're not using it.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: To clarify, a module should have as small a responsibility as possible without requiring non-core modules. This makes the module easier to maintain and minimizes code fragility and code entanglement.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Succinctly Commented: Too much commenting is noise (we can read code), but too little and a future maintainer might not understand why the code was written in the first place.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Easy to port:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: When possible, code should be portable. This is both true in regards to CPU architecture and in regards to OS and environment.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: The project currently has the following limitation that might be addressed in the future:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - The code requires kqueue or epoll services from the OS, which means Linux / BSD / macOS.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - The code assumes a Unix environment (file naming etc').
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Some of the code (namely some HTTP parts) uses unaligned memory access (requiring newer CPUs and possibly introducing undefined behavior).
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Easy to compile:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: The code uses GNU make and although we have CMake support, neither CMake nor configure should be required at any point.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Easy to manage:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: See the License section below. Contributions must relinquish ownership of contributed code, so licensing and copyright can be managed without the need to reach out to every contributer.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Community Guideline - Play Nice
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: As a child, I wasn't any good with people (I'm not sure I'm any better now that I'm older)... which is how come I became good with computers and why we have facil.io and other open source projects ;-)
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: However, I promise to do my best to be a respectful communicator and I ask that you do your best as well.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: No matter if discussing a PR (where we might find ourselves entering a heated discussion) or answering an issue (where sometime we find ourselves wondering why people think we work for them)... we should all remember that a little compassion and respect goes a long way.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Style Guide and Guidelines
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: A few pointers about code styling (pun intended).
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Use clang-format with the LLVM style.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Initialize all variables during declaration - even if it's redundant.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Use goto to move code branches to the end of a function's body.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: It makes the main body of the function more readable (IMHO) and should help with branch prediction (similar to how unlikely might help, but using a different approach)
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: A quick run-down
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: facil.io is comprised of the following module "families":
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - The Core:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: This module family comprises facil.io's core. Although it can (mostly) be used outside of facil.io, none of the modules in this family can be removed.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: The module in comprised of two files: fio.h and fio.c.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: The fio.h file can be included more then once and includes some core types, such as binary String support, Arrays, Hash Maps, spinlocks, etc' (see documentation).
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Dynamic Types (FIOBJ) with native JSON support.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: This soft type system was designed to make some network oriented tasks easier and is therefore used by many of the other modules.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Unlike most modules, this module is only optional if the core is used independently.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - HTTP / WebSockets:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: The http folder refers to the inter-connected HTTP/WebSocket extension / module.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Although this module family seems very entangled, I did my best to make it easy to maintain and extend with a minimum of entanglement.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: HTTP request and response modules support virtual function tables for future HTTP/2 extensions. The actual request/response implementations might vary between protocol implementation, but their interface should be version agnostic.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Like most modules, it is optional and can be removed from facil.io without any side-effects.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Redis:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: The redis engine is in it's own folder, both because it's clearly an "add-on" (even though it's a pub/sub add-on) and because it's as optional as it gets.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: This is also a good example for my preference for modular design. The RESP parser is a single file library. It can be easily ported to different projects and is totally separate from the network layer.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - CLI:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: The command line interface extension / module is in the folder cli and should be considered and optional add-on. Other modules shouldn't rely on it's existence or absence.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: This too, much like the Redis module, is a good example of the preferred modular approach.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Where to start / Roadmap
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Before you start working on a feature, I consider opening a PR to edit this CONTRIBUTING file and letting the community know that you took this feature upon yourself.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Add the feature you want to work on to the following list (or assign an existing feature to yourself). This will also allow us to discuss, in the PR's thread, any questions you might have or any expectations that might effect the API or the feature.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Once you have all the information you need to implementing the feature, the discussion can move to the actual feature's PR.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: These are the features that have been requested so far. Even if any of them are assigned, feel free to offer your help:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
|      Feature      |      assigned      |      remarks               |
|-------------------|--------------------|----------------------------|
|   Documentation   |     ? Help ?    | Placed at docs/_SOURCE |
|       Tests       |    Never enough    | run through tests.c but implement in source files. |
| Early Hints HTTP/1.1 |               |                            |
|      SSL/TLS      |                    | See fio_tls_missing.c for example. |
|  WebSocket Client |                    | Missing cookie retention.  |
|    HTTP Client    |                    | Missing SSL/TLS, cookie retention and auto-redirect(?)  |
|      HTTP/2       |                    |                            |
|    HTTP Router    |                    | RESTfuk without RegEx. i.e.: /users/(:id) |
|     PostgreSQL    |                    | Wrap libpq.h for events + pub/sub engine (?) |
|     Gossip (?)    |                    | For Pub/Sub engine scaling |
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: License
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: The project requires that all the code is licensed under the MIT license (though that may change).
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Please refrain from using or offering code that requires a change to the licensing scheme or that might prevent future updates to the licensing scheme (I'm considering ISC).
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: I discovered GitHub doesn't offer a default CLA (Copyright and Licensing Agreement), so I adopted the one used by BearSSL, meaning:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - the resulting code uses the MIT license, listing me (and only me) as the author. You can take credit by stating that the code was written by yourself, but should attribute copyright and authorship to me (Boaz Segev). This is similar to a "work for hire" approach.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - I will list meaningful contributions in the CHANGELOG and special contributions will be listed in the README and/or here.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: This allows me to circumvent any future licensing concerns and prevent contributors from revoking the license attached to their code.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Notable Contributions

Paragraph: - @area55git (Area55) contributed the logo under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License..
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - @cdkrot took the time to test some of the demo code using valgrind, detecting a shutdown issue with in core defer library and offering a quick fix.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - @madsheep and @nilclass took the time to expose a very quite issue (#16) that involved a long processing on_open websocket callback and very short network roundtrips, exposing a weakness in the HTTP/1.x logic.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - @64 took the time to test the pre-released 0.6.0 version and submit PR #25, fixing a silent error and some warnings.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Florian Weber (@Florianjw) took time to challenge the RiskyHash draft and exposed a byte ordering error (last 7 byte reading order).
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Chris Anderson (@injinj) did amazing work exploring a 128 bit variation and attacking RiskyHash using a variation on a Meet-In-The-Middle attack, written by Hening Makholm (@hmakholm) on his (SMHasher fork). The RiskyHash dfraft was updated to address this attack.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Development requirements
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: You'll need Ruby. Ruby 1.9.x would be best. After you've got Ruby, clone the repo and install dependencies:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
git clone https://github.com/bobthecow/genghis
cd genghis
git submodule update --init
gem install bundle
bundle install
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Building Genghis
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Genghis is... a bit weird.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- The two app files, genghis.rb and genghis.php are built via Rake. To regenerate them, run rake build from the
project directory.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: - If you just want to build one or the other, you can run rake build:php or rake build:rb.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: - For development, it's usually best to use non-minified assets. Run rake build NOCOMPRESS=1 to skip minification.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: - Be sure to commit the compiled genghis.rb and genghis.php along with your source changes.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Opening a pull request
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: You can do some things to increase the chance that your pull request is accepted the first time:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Open all pull requests against the develop branch.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Submit one pull request per fix or feature.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - To help with that, do your work in a feature branch (e.g. feature/my-alsome-feature).
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Follow the conventions you see used in the project. This is especially important when switching between languages,
since Genghis is essentially a Ruby server, an PHP server, and a JavaScript client. Make your code look like the code
around it.

- Don't bump version numbers. Those will be updated semver
master.

Paragraph: Here's a quick guide:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 1.  Fork the repo on GitHub.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 2.  Update submodules: git submodule update --init
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 3.  Run the test suite. We only take pull requests with passing tests, and it's great to know that you have a clean slate. Make sure you have PHPUnit 3.5+, then run phpunit from the project directory.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 4.  Add tests for your change. Only refactoring and documentation changes require no new tests. If you are adding functionality or fixing a bug, add a test!
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 5.  Make the tests pass.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 6.  Push your fork to GitHub and submit a pull request against the dev branch.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: You can do some things to increase the chance that your pull request is accepted the first time:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Submit one pull request per fix or feature.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - To help with that, do all your work in a feature branch (e.g. feature/my-alsome-feature).
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Follow the conventions you see used in the project.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Use phpcs --standard=PSR2 to check your changes against the coding standard.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Write tests that fail without your code, and pass with it.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Don't bump version numbers. Those will be updated semver master.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Update any documentation: docblocks, README, examples, etc.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - ... Don't update the wiki until your change is merged and released, but make a note in your pull request so we don't forget.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: How to contribute
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
We welcome users' contributions! However, we do have some requests for how contributions
should be made. Please read these guidelines in order to avoid surprises down the road.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Getting Set Up
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
For information about setting up a development environment, building from source, etc.,
see the Developer Guide
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Choosing something to work on
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: The issue tracker has a list of items that you can start working on, classified by the labels:
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: - type:feature
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: - type:task
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: - type:bug
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph:
In order to avoid duplication of effort, it's always a good idea to comment on an issue
and let everybody know that you intend to work on it.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: Opening a new issue
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
1.  Avoid duplicate reports. Search GitHub and
the Discourse for similar or identical issues. Keyword
searches for your error messages are usually effective.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 2.  The issue may already be resolved. Always try to reproduce the issue in the latest stable release.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
3.  Always include a minimal, self-contained, reproducible test case or example. It is not
possible to investigate issues that cannot be reproduced.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 4.  Include relevant system information. At minimum, you should provide output of:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: python -c "import bokeh; print(bokeh.__version__)"
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
5.  Include relevant browser information (if the issue is browser-related). Just saying that you
use Chrome is generally not sufficient. We may ask you for additional information to
reproduce and fix the issue.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 6.  Include relevant JavaScript console and/or bokeh serve logs.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
7.  If the problem is user interface related, it is always good to include a screenshot or
screen video capture.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 8.  State the expected behavior.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Creating a pull request (PR)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
1.  Make sure that there is a corresponding issue for your change first. If there isn't yet,
create one.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 2.  Create a fork of the Bokeh repository on GitHub (this is only done before first) contribution).
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
3.  Create a branch off the master branch with a meaningful name. Preferably include issue number
and a few keywords, so that we will have a rough idea what the branch refers to, without looking
up the issue. As an example: 786_property_names.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 4.  Commit your changes and push them to GitHub.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
5.  Create a pull request against the default base branch. The PR must have a meaningful title
and a message explaining what was achieved, what remains to be done, maybe an example, etc.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
6.  We don't accept code contributions without tests. If there are valid reasons for not including a
test, please discuss this in the issue.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
7.  We will review your PR as time permits. Reviewers may comment on your contributions, ask
you questions regarding the implementation or request changes. If changes are requested, push
new commits to the existing branch. Do NOT rebase, amend, or cherry-pick published commits.
Any of those actions will make us start the review from scratch. If you need updates from master,
just merge it into your branch.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: DOs and DON'Ts
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - DO match the existing coding style.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - DO include new tests when adding new features.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - DO include regression tests when fixing bugs.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- DO keep the discussions focused. When a new or related topic comes up it's often better to
create new issue than to side track the discussion.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: - DO have a look at BEP-1 to see how we manage issues and pull requests in bokeh.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- DON'T surprise us with big pull requests. Instead, file an issue and start a discussion so we
can agree on a direction before you invest a large amount of time.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- DON'T commit code that you didn't write. If you find BSD license compatible code that you
think would be useful to add to this project, file an issue and start a discussion first.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

If you are reading this, you must be considering opening an issue for help with
a bug, to suggest a new feature or help out with a Pull Request. Great!

For questions about working with Bolt or support issues, please post on the
forum instead. If you post these kinds of topics there,
we can keep the issues list organized, with actual issues that need to be
handled in the Bolt source code itself.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph:
To streamline this process, we've made this small document, to help you report
your issue or feature more efficiently. We did our best to keep it brief, so
please read it carefully.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Jump to the relevant section below:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - 1. I'm reporting a bug
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - 2. I'd like to request/propose a feature
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - 3. I'm making a pull request
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Note: Please don't use our main GitHub repository for reporting bugs
with extensions. If you have found a bug in an extension, the best place to
report this would be in the extension's own repository, so that the original
author can look into it.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 1. I'm reporting a bug
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
If you think you've found a bug, try to make sure it's actually a bug, and not
the result of something else going wrong. For example, make sure your web server
is functioning correctly, and try the issue in another browser, if possible. Be
sure to search for similar bugs. Perhaps somebody has already reported the
issue. If so, you should add any additional information to the existing bug. It
might make it easier for us to fix, and at the very least it'll get bumped
higher onto the list.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
After you've done these things, and you are fairly certain you've found a new
bug, please open an issue to report it. Create a GitHub account,
if you don't have one yet.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: When posting your bug, please include the following:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 1.  Bug summary:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Write a short summary of the bug??
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Try to pinpoint it as muc??h a possible
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- Try to state the actual problem, and not just what you think the
solution might be.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 2.  Specifics:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Mention the URL where this bug occurs, if applicable
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - What version of Bolt are you using (down to the very last digit!)
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - What method did you use to install Bolt
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - What browser and version you are using
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Please mention if you've checked it in other browsers as well
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Please include full error messages and screenshots if possible
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 3.  Steps to reproduce:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Clearly mention the steps to reproduce the bug
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 4.  Expected result:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - What did you expect that would happen on your Bolt site?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Describe the intended outcome after you did the steps mentioned before
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 5.  Actual result:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - What is the actual result of the above steps?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Describe the behaviour of the bug
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- Please, please include error messages and screenshots. They might mean
nothing to you, but they are very helpful to us.
to us.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Further reading: 10 tips for better Pull Requests
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Reporting security issues
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
If you wish to contact us privately about any possible security issues in Bolt,
please contact us at security@bolt.cm. Your email
will be handled confidentially. After fixing them, you will be credited for any
security issues that you may have discovered.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 2. I'd like to request/propose a feature
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
We get a lot of feature requests for Bolt, and we can't do them all, even if we
wanted to. In fact, since Bolt is designed to be 'simple, sophisticated and
straightforward', not all feature requests might be a good fit for Bolt. Be sure
to read our manifesto to get an idea of our
goals and values.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
If you're proposing an idea, with the intent to work on it yourself, please open
an issue with a title like [RFC] Wouldn't it be swell, if we had [X]?. That
will make it obvious that you're open for discussion about the feature, and that
it'll be a good fit for Bolt itself, or that it might be better suited as an
extension. If you want to discuss your idea first, before 'officially' posting
it, you can always join us on Slack or IRC.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
On the other hand, if you have a suggestion for a cool new feature, but don't
have the skill to work on it yourself, we'll gladly read it, and comment on it,
but we can't make any promises as to when/if it'll be realised.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 3. I'm making a pull request
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Your contributions to the project are very welcome. If you would like to fix a
bug or implement a proposed feature, you can submit a Pull Request.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Make sure you read our guide on Contributing to
Bolt, the page on Code
Quality and the page describing
our Release process.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Bug fixes & "mini" features
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: To help us merge your Pull Request, please make sure you follow these points:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 1.  Describe the problem clearly in the Pull Request description.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
2.  Please refer to a bug report on the issue list. An example of a good title
is "Fixes problem [x] by doing [y]. Fixes #1555"
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
3.  Do not edit compiled asset files such as bolt.js or bolt.css.
Instead, edit the source JavaScript and Sass files inside the /app/src/
directory. We'll handle the updated compiled files.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
4.  For any change that you make, please try to also add a test case(s) in
the tests directory.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
5.  If you're doing a PR for a non-trivial new feature, see the Features
section below.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Features
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Bolt has a warm, welcoming, and helpful team of core developers who can, collectively,
help you to get a new feature into Bolt.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
New features should have a "sponsor" on the core-team. You are welcome to, ask a
specific team member to sponsor your work (ask around on Slack or IRC), or we'll try
to match someone to your feature based on their area of expertise.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph:
We have some simple processes to assist in getting new features from the concept stage,
right though to a released and maintained Bolt.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 1.  Open an RFC issue following these criteria:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Prefix the title with "[RFC]"
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Briefly describe the use case
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - If requireing new libraries, a brief justification of why that one was chosen
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 2.  Be assigned a "sponsor" from the core team
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 3.  Submit the PR
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 4.  Celebrate with your new friends in the Bolt community!
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: New features should also be accompanied with:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Unit and/or acceptance tests
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Documentation
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Your sponsor is there to help you, as is a large and helpful community of people
on both Slack and IRC, should you have troubles with any of this.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph:
NOTE: Sponsors help out in their own personal time, so please be patient and respectful
of their available time. We will do our best to do the same with you.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Development Environment Setup
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
You'll need to have git installed obviously. Begin by forking the
main repository and then getting the code from your forked copy:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: git clone git@github.com:yourusername/bookshelf.git
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Afterwards go to the bookshelf directory that was just created and install the dependencies:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: npm install
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
At this point the only thing missing are the databases that will be used for running some of the tests of the automated
test suite.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: There are three options for setting up this part:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: - The first one is to use docker containers for the database servers. This is explained below.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
- Alternatively you can provide configuration options of the database servers and set them up manually. This is also
explained further down.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
- Last option is to use a config file in case you already have your servers configured and don't want to change any of
their configurations.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Using Docker Containers
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
You can install Docker and docker-compose easily
on any Operating System. After picking the correct operating system installer (via package manager or download) just
run the following command on the root of your cloned Bookshelf repository:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
# This starts the test databases
docker-compose up -d
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: You can also teardown the databases with:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: docker-compose down --remove-orphans
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: When using Docker you may run the tests many times against the same DB instances. The tests reset DB state on each run.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Note: admin privileges are needed, so you should act according to your chosen Operating System.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Manual Database Servers Setup
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
The two sections below deal with manually setting up the database servers needed for running tests. If you prefer an
easier alternative you can use Docker containers instead, as explained in the previous section.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: MySQL
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
You can install MySQL easily on most linux distros by using their package manager. With Ubuntu
this should do it:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: sudo apt-get install mysql-server mysql-client
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
On OSX you can download a disk image directly from the MySQL Downloads page, or
use one of the popular package managers like homebrew or MacPorts.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
To run the test suite you will need to make sure it is possible to connect as the user root without the need for a
password.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
It is strongly recommended that you use the command line mysql client to access your MySQL instance since there can be
problems connecting as the root user with some graphical clients like phpMyAdmin. To check if you can connect as root
without needing a password use the following command:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: mysql -u root
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: If you see an error like:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: ERROR 1045 (28000): Access denied for user 'root'@'localhost' (using password: NO)
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
that means you can't login as root without a password. If you do know the root user's password just login with the known
password like this:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: mysql -u root -p
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: and enter the password when asked. Then just set an empty password for root like so:
Label: BW – Build local workspace
BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: If you see an error like:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: ERROR 1054 (42S22): Unknown column 'authentication_string' in 'field list'
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
It's because you are using an MySQL version older than 5.7. The authentication_string column has replaced the
password column in this newer version. If you are using an older version just use password instead of
authentication_string in the example above.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
Note that you'll probably need to set the password to NULL instead of an empty string in MySQL versions 5.5 and older.
The above example should work with versions 5.7 and newer.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
If you have forgotten the root password you'll need to take some extra steps to reset it. Take a look at
this Stack Overflow answer for further details.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
If you still can't access the MySQL server without a root password after all this trouble then
this answer on Ask Ubuntu has another alternative approach to the problem.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: PostgreSQL
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
You can install PostgreSQL easily on most linux distros by using their package manager.
With Ubuntu this should do it:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: sudo apt-get install postgresql postgresql-client
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
On OSX the easiest way is probably by using PosgresApp. It should also be available to
install via homebrew or MacPorts if you prefer.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
In the case of PostgreSQL the requirement is to be able to connect as the postgres user on localhost also without the
need for a password. This can be achieved by editing or adding the following line in the pg_hba.conf file:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: host    all             all             127.0.0.1/32            trust
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
This file can be found in /etc/postgresql/9.4/main/ on most linux systems. The 9.4 part could be different depending
on the version that is available in your distro. On OSX the location of this file will depend on the installation method
chosen, but for the recommended PostgresApp install it will be in /Users/[yourusername]/Library/Application Support/Postgres/var-9.3/. Again, the var-9.3 part may be different depending on the version you installed.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
The trust in the example above tells the locally running PostgreSQL server to ignore user passwords and always grant
access on clients connecting locally. Do not use this setting in a production environment.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: After editing the pg_hba.conf file you'll need to restart the PostgreSQL server for the changes to take effect.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Using a Configuration File
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
If you don't want to go to the trouble of performing the changes explained in the previous two sections you can instead
use a config file that tells the test suite about your current database setup.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
The tests will look for a BOOKSHELF_TEST environment variable that points to a config.js file with the connection
details for each database server. This file must not be the same database config file you use for any other application,
otherwise you risk data loss in that application.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Example config file:
Label: BW – Build local workspace
BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
postgres: {
user: 'myusername',
database: 'bookshelf_test',
password: 'secretpassword',
host: 'localhost',
port: 5432,
charset: 'utf8',
ssl: false
},
Label: BW – Build local workspace
BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
This file can be placed anywhere on your system and can have any name that you like, as long as the environment variable
is pointing correctly to it. For convenience you can put it in your home directory and add the following line to your
.bashrc or .zshrc:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: export BOOKSHELF_TEST='/home/myusername/.bookshelf_config.js'
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Database Creation
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
After having ensured the test suite can access both database servers just create a new database on each that will be
used exclusively by Bookshelf.js:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: CREATE DATABASE bookshelf_test;
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Note that this step isn't necessary when using Docker.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Running the Tests
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: The easiest way to run the tests is by using docker & docker-compose as explained above.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
The test suite requires that both MySQL and PostgreSQL servers have a database named bookshelf_test. See the sections
above for further instructions.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Once you have your development environment properly setup, you can run the tests:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: npm test
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Always make sure all the tests are passing before sending a pull request.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Publishing a New Release
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
The release process is fairly well automated. You do need publishing rights to the npmjs.com
bookshelf package and write access to the GitHub repository. Once that's set
just make sure to follow the process explained below in the correct order.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
1.  You should draft a new release on GitHub. This isn't strictly necessary, but is highly recommended. At this time you
shouldn't publish it yet, but just save it as a draft instead.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 2.  Make sure you're in the master branch with all the latest changes: git pull.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
3.  Update the CHANGELOG.md file and update the version number of package.json. For the changelog just follow the
format of the previous update. In general you should link to PRs instead of issues when mentioning changes. If the PRs'
descriptions are well written they should already include any associated issues. At this point there is no need to
commit and/or push these changes since that is taken care of automatically by the release scripts.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 4.  Just run npm publish and sit back.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Ways to Contribute
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph:
No contribution to Beast is too big or too small! We are
always happy to see user participation in all of its forms.
Here are some of the ways that you can contribute (this is
by no means an exhaustive list):
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph:
- Submit a
bug report.
We love hearing about broken things, so
that we can fix them. Any problem is fair game, this includes
the documentation examples, tests, and repository as well as the
library itself. Bug reports should be opened on the
Issues page.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- Provide
feedback.
about the library. If you have used, are using,
or are thinking about using the library we want to hear about it!
The more information you provide, the better we will be able
to ensure that Beast meets your needs. You can provide feedback
as an issue, or email the author directly.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- Test Beast. When changes are made, they are submitted as a
Pull Request.
Everyone is welcome to examine these upcoming changes, test them,
and report on the results. This form of quality assurance is very
helpful so we can keep delivering a great product. Consider
subscribing to repository notifications to get alerted to new
pull requests.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph:
- Code Review on
Pull Requests.
This is one of the most valuable ways to contribute, because it helps
to improve code and features, and helps to find bugs, before the code
gets merged. A little bit of time investment from just a few people on
each pull request goes a long way to increasing the quality of the
final product. For tips on how to participate in pull requests please
view the
README.md.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph:
- Use Beast in your next application! At the end of the day, it is the
goal of the library to provide utility to users so the best way you
can contribute is simply to use the library!
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: Code Contributions
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Here's a quick guide for code contributions:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 1. Check if issue or feature is available to work on
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
Make sure no one else is working on the same issue or feature. Search the issues
and pull requests for anything that looks like the issue or feature you want to
address. If no one else is working on your issue or feature, carry on with the
following steps.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: 2. (Optional) Create an issue, and wait a few days for someone to respond
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: If you create an issue for your feature request or bug, it gives the maintainers a chance to comment on your ideas before you invest a lot of work on a contribution. It may save you some re-work compared to simply submitting a pull request. It's up to you whether you submit an issue.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: 3. Fork the repo
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Fork the project. Optionally, create a branch you want to work on.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 4. Get it running locally
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Install the required dependencies with bundle install
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: - Run tests via: bundle exec rake
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 5. Hack away
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Try to keep your changes small. Consider making several smaller pull requests if your changes are extensive.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Don't forget to add necessary tests.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Update the README if necessary.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Add a line to the CHANGELOG for your bug fix or feature.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Read the Coding Guidelines section and make sure that rake lint doesn't find any offences.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: You may find the demo application useful for development and debugging.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - cd demo
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - rake db:schema:load
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - rails s
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Navigate to http://localhost:3000
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 6. Make a pull request
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - If you've never made a pull request (PR) before, read this: https://help.github.com/articles/about-pull-requests/.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - If your PR fixes an issues, be sure to put "Fixes #nnn" in the description of the PR (where nnn is the issue number). Github will automatically close the issue when the PR is merged.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - When the PR is submitted, check if Travis CI ran all the tests successfully, and didn't raise any issues.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 7. Done!
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
Somebody will shortly review your pull request and if everything is good, it will be
merged into the master branch. Eventually the gem will be published with your changes.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Coding guidelines
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
This project uses RuboCop to enforce standard Ruby coding
guidelines.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Test that your contribution passes with rake rubocop.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - RuboCop is also run as part of the full test suite with bundle exec rake.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Note the Travis build will fail and your PR cannot be merged if RuboCop finds offences.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Note that most editors have plugins to run RuboCop as you type, or when you save a file. You may find it well worth your time to install and configure the RuboCop plugin for your editor. Read the RuboCop documentation.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Supported Versions of Ruby and Rails
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: The goal of bootstrap_form is to support all versions of Rails currently supported for bug fixes and security issues. We do not test against versions supported for severe security issues. We test against the minimum version of Ruby required for those versions of Rails.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: The Ruby on Rails support policy is here.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Documentation Contributions
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Contributions to documentation are always welcome. Even fixing one typo improves the quality of bootstrap_form. To make a documentation contribution, follow steps 1-3 of Code Contributions, then make the documentation changes, then make the pull request (step 6 of Code Contributions).
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: If you put [ci skip] in the commit message of the most recent commit of the PR, you'll be a good citizen by not causing Travis CI to run all the tests when it's not necessary.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Reviewing Pull Requests
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: We are an entirely volunteer project. Sometimes it's hard for people to find the time to review pull requests. You can help! If you see a pull request that's waiting to be merged, it could be because no one has reviewed it yet. Your review could help move the pull request forward to be merged.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Troubleshooting
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Models and Database Tables
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: bootstrap_form needs a few models and tables to support testing. It appears that the necessary tables were created via the demo/db/schema.rb file. To support rich_text_area, Rails 6 creates some migrations. These migrations had to be run in the existing database (not an empty one) to create a new schema.rb that creates the bootstrap_form test tables, and the tables needed by Rails 6. The schema.rb file was checked in to GitHub, but the migrations were not.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: In the future, any new Rails functionality that creates tables would likely have to be prepared the same way:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
cd demo
rails db:setup # create the databases from `schema.rb`
rails db:migrate # add the new tables and create a new `schema.rb`
Label: No categories identified.

that link in issues.

Paragraph: How Do I Submit A (Good) Bug Report?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Use a clear and descriptive title for the issue to identify the problem.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Describe the exact steps which reproduce the problem in as many details as possible.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Provide specific examples to demonstrate the steps.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Describe the behavior you observed after following the steps and point out what exactly is the problem with that behavior.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Explain which behavior you expected to see instead and why.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Submitting changes
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Please send a GitHub Pull Request with a clear list of what you've done (read more about pull requests). Please follow coding conventions (below) and make sure all of your commits are atomic (one feature per commit).
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Always write a clear log message for your commits. One-line messages are fine for small changes, but bigger changes should look like this:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
$ git commit -m "A brief summary of the commit
>
> A paragraph describing what changed and its impact."

:oncoming_police_car: Ground Rules
:baby: First-time contributors
? Getting Started
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: If you are reading this, you must really like what we are doing and thank you for that. Giving time to a community is the most meaningful way to contribute. In that sense, we want to make sure contributors, maintainers and everyone else working on this project can make the biggest impact possible with the time they have to give.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: The following information is here to walk you through your first and future contributions. Following these guidelines also helps to communicate that you respect the time of the developers managing and developing this open-source project. In return, they should reciprocate that respect in addressing your issue, assessing changes, and helping you finalize your pull requests.

Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Submitting Feature Requests
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: If you find yourself wishing for a feature that doesn't exist in Botpress, you are probably not alone. There are bound to be others out there with similar needs. Many of the features that Botpress has today have been added because our users saw the need. Open an issue on our issues list on GitHub which describes the feature you would like to see, why you need it, and how it should work.

Paragraph: However as Botpress has a great module system consider whether the feature you're requesting would be better as a module, rather than expanding the core platform.

Paragraph: Setting up Your Local Dev Environment
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: If you are interested in contributing to Botpress, you will need to create a local development environment. These instructions were tested on macOS using iTerm for CLI.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: These instructions assume a parent directory bar and we will be adding two child directories: botpress and foobot.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 1.  Fork the botpress repo & copy the link. (If you are new to open-source, GitHub, or Git, check out the excellent egghead.io link in 'New to contributing to open-source?' for additional important Git commands, such as checking out a branch, setting your upstream repo, keeping your local copy in sync, and making your pull request).
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 2.  Open a new terminal/CLI tab, and run commands
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: # botpress terminal window
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
# create and navigate to the `bar` directory
$ mkdir bar && cd bar
# Clone the forked repo locally
bar $ git clone https://github.com/YOURNAME/botpress.git
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 3.  Continue running commands in the botpress terminal window
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
# Install Yarn globally
bar $ npm install --global yarn
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
# Navigate to the botpress directory
bar $ cd botpress
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
# Setup the dev environment
bar/botpress $ yarn run bootstrap
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
# Start the botpress server
bar/botpress $ yarn start
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 4.  Open a new terminal/CLI tab (foobot), and run commands
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
# Create our test bot called `foobot`
bar $ yarn --cwd=botpress run init-foobot
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
# Navigate to the foobot directory
bar $ cd foobot
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
# Start the bot normally
bar/foobot $ bp start
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Next Steps
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 5.  You will note that if you want to access the CLI while botpress and foobot are running, you will need to open a third tab.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 6.  If you want to confirm that your local copy is working, a straightforward method is to make a change to botpress's React code on your local copy, restart both botpress and foobot
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: - edit code in botpress
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
- in: botpress terminal window
# Ctl-C to end watch
# Start botpress
bar/botpress $ yarn start
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
- in: foobot terminal window
# Ctl-C to stop bot
bar/foobot $ bp start
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: - visit localhost:3000 in a browser to confirm your change was implemented
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: How to contribute
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - File an issue - if you found a bug, want to request an enhancement, or want to implement something (bug fix or feature).
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Send a pull request - if you want to contribute code. Please be sure to file an issue first.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Pull request best practices
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: We want to accept your pull requests. Please follow these steps:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Step 1: File an issue
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Before writing any code, please file an issue stating the problem you want to solve or the feature you want to implement. This allows us to give you feedback before you spend any time writing code. There may be a known limitation that can't be addressed, or a bug that has already been fixed in a different way. The issue allows us to communicate and figure out if it's worth your time to write a bunch of code for the project.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Step 2: Fork this repository in GitHub
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: This will create your own copy of our repository.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Step 3: Add the upstream source
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: The upstream source is the project under the Box organization on GitHub. To add an upstream source for this project, type:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: git remote add upstream git@github.com:box/spout.git
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: This will come in useful later.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Step 4: Create a feature branch
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Create a branch with a descriptive name, such as add-search.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Step 5: Push your feature branch to your fork
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: As you develop code, continue to push code to your remote feature branch. Please make sure to include the issue number you're addressing in your commit message, such as:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git commit -m "Adding search (fixes #123)"
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: This helps us out by allowing us to track which issue your commit relates to.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Keep a separate feature branch for each issue you want to address.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Step 6: Rebase
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Before sending a pull request, rebase against upstream, such as:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
git fetch upstream
git rebase upstream/master
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: This will add your changes on top of what's already in upstream, minimizing merge issues.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Step 7: Run the tests
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Make sure that all tests are passing before submitting a pull request.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Step 8: Send the pull request
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Send the pull request from your feature branch to us. Be sure to include a description that lets us know what work you did.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Keep in mind that we like to see one issue addressed per pull request, as this helps keep our git history clean and we can more easily track down issues.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 2.  Specify the details of vv and your system. ( vv --debug-vv to get this.)

Paragraph: Thanks for taking the time to contribute to brain.js. Follow these guidelines to make the process smoother:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 1.  Clone master branch
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 2.  One feature per pull request. Each PR should have one focus, and all the code changes should be supporting that one feature or bug fix. Using a separate branch for each feature should help you manage developing multiple features at once.

Paragraph: 3.  Add/update a test for the feature or fix, if possible. See the __tests__ directory for existing tests. To run these tests:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: How can you contribute?
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: Brave welcomes contributions of all kinds! You can make a huge impact without writing a single line of code
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Help triage issues
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: One of the easiest ways to help is to look through our issues tab
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Does the issue still happen? Sometimes we fix the problem and don't always close the issue
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Are there clear steps to reproduce the issue? If not, let's find and document some
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Is the issue a duplicate? If so, share the issue that is being duplicated in the conversation
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - See our Triage Guidelines page for more info about this process
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Making sure issues that are fixed have the appropriate milestone set. There may be pull requests fixing the bug on the different product channels and sometimes the issues are forgotten about (and aren't updated)
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Updating documentation
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Documentation is extremely important. There are lots of areas we can improve:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Having more clear or up-to-date instructions in the README for both brave-browser and brave-core.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Capturing/updating helpful information in our wiki. You'll need to reach out to a Brave team member to request permission - you can do this by creating a new issue or tagging a Brave team member in an existing issue.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Helping to propose a way to bring documentation to other languages. Right now, everything is in English
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Improving this document :smile:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Help with translations
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
All text being added to Brave is done initially in English (en-US) and then is translated by real people into other languages.
We're missing translations for many languages and some translations might be incomplete or poor quality.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: For everything you'd need to get started, check out https://www.transifex.com/brave/brave/ :smile:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Work on the code

Paragraph: - The repo's wiki has instructions for cloning the repo and getting setup on your platform of choice
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: - Check out the troubleshooting page if you get stuck
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: - Once you're up and running, find an interesting issue to fix. Check out issues labelled with good first issue

Paragraph: Getting started
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Make sure you have a GitHub account.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Submit a ticket for your issue if one does not already exist. Please include the Brave version, operating system, and steps to reproduce the issue.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Fork the repository on GitHub (this might be brave-browser, brave-core, or both).
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - For changes to JavaScript files, we recommend installing a Standard plugin for your preferred text editor in order to ensure code style consistency.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - For C++ changes, you can consider setting up clang-format for your editor.

Paragraph: - For changes which involve patches, please check out our Patching Chromium guide.
