Paragraph: Making changes
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Once you've cloned the repo to your computer, you're ready to start making edits!
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Please note that there are two repositories here:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - the root project (this repo, brave-browser), which pulls down all of the Chromium code into src/
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - brave-core is basically a sub-module (repo in a repo) which is located on disk under the root at src/brave
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
Depending on which you're editing, you'll need to add your fork to the remotes list. By default, origin is set to upstream.
For example, here's how GitHub user bsclifton would add BOTH remotes brave-browser and brave-core:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
# root where project is cloned
cd ~/brave-browser/
git remote add bsclifton git@github.com:bsclifton/brave-browser.git
git fetch bsclifton
# root for the `brave-core` repo
cd src/brave
git remote add bsclifton git@github.com:bsclifton/brave-core.git
git fetch bsclifton
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Once you're setup, there's a few tips we can suggest:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Make a new branch for your work. It helps to have a descriptive name, like fix-fullscreen-issue.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Make commits in logical units. If needed, run git rebase -i to squash commits before opening a pull request.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - New features and most other pull requests require a new test to be written before the pull request will be accepted.  Some exceptions would be a tweak to an area of code that doesn't have tests yet, text changes, build config changes, things that can't be tested due to test suite limitations, etc.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Use GitHub auto-closing keywords in the commit message, and make the commit message body as descriptive as necessary. Ex:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Add contributing guide
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
This is a first pass at a contributor's guide so now people will know how to
get pull requests accepted faster.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Fix https://github.com/brave/brave-browser/issues/108
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Run the tests by running npm run test brave_unit_tests and npm run test brave_browser_tests
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - JavaScript unit tests can be ran from the src/brave directory using npm run test-unit
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Keeping your fork up to sync
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: - Both brave-browser and brave-core clone themselves with the remote origin being upstream, so you can update either using git pull.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
- Once origin is fetched, you can rebase your master branch against origin/master
git fetch origin
git fetch bsclifton
git checkout -b fork_master bsclifton/master
git rebase origin/master
git push bsclifton fork_master:master
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: An easier strategy might be to keep origin in sync and then create branches based on that (and push those to your fork).
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Pull requests
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: After the changes are made in your branch, you're ready to submit a patch. Patches on GitHub are submitted in the format of a pull request.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Considerations before submitting a pull request
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Some helpful things to consider before submitting your work
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Did you manually test your new change?
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Does your pull request fix multiple issues? If so, you may consider breaking into separate pull requests.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Did you include tests? (we currently have unit tests, browser tests, and JavaScript unit tests)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - If you made a design or layout change, was there a mock-up provided? Do your changes match it?
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - If your change affects session or preferences, did you include steps to test? You may also consider manually testing an upgrade.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Each pull request should include
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - a descriptive title; this gets used in the release notes (desktop or android)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - a short summary of the changes
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - a reference to the issue that it fixes
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - steps to test the fix (if applicable)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - for design-related changes, it is helpful to include screenshots
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Once you submit a pull request, you should tag reviewers and add labels if needed. If you do not have the necessary GitHub permissions to do so, a Brave member will take care of this for you.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Employees should
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Ensure the owner is tagged using the Assignees field
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Ensure at least one other employee or contributor is tagged using the Reviewers field
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Go through the checklist that's provided in the pull request template and check the appropriate boxes
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Closing issues
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Issues should be assigned the milestone when the PR is merged (and the fix is landed in Nightly aka master).
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Some issues may need to be uplifted to other channels (Dev / Beta / Release). Please see our notes on uplifting a pull request.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - If an issue is closed without a fix, because it was a duplicate, or perhaps it was invalid, then any milestone markers should be removed.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - If a bug is not fully fixed after its issue is closed, open a new issue instead of re-opening the existing one (unless the code has been reverted).
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Triage help
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Invalid bugs should be closed, tagged with invalid, or a comment should be added indicating that they should if you do not have permission.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Asking for more detail in an issue when it is needed is helpful.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Adding applicable labels to an issue is helpful.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Adding and finding duplicates, and linking them together is helpful.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Creating tracking issues for an area of work with multiple related issues is helpful.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Calling out things which seem important for extra attention is helpful.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Improving steps to reproduce is helpful.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Testing and adding a comment with "Could not reproduce" if an issue seems obscure is helpful.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Testing open pull requests.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - You can be granted write permission if you've helped a lot with triage by pinging @bbondy, @bsclifton, @kjozwiak, or another Brave team member.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Helping make sure issues have a clear and understandable name (ex: not something like "Brave is broken").
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - The first comment in an issue ideally would have a clear description of the issue and describe the impact to users. Asking folks for screenshots, steps to reproduce, and more information is highly recommended so that the issue is as clear as possible.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - If the issue is a duplicate, please let the issue creator know in a polite way how they can follow and track progress of the parent issue (including an ETA if it's marked with a milestone).
Label: No categories identified.

The bigger the pull request, the longer it will take to review and merge. Try to break down large pull requests in smaller chunks that are easier to review and merge.
It is also always helpful to have some context for your pull request. What was the purpose? Why does it matter to you?

Paragraph: Develop locally, then submit changes
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Fork the GitHub project and download it locally:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
git clone https://github.com/<username>/Carbon.git
cd Carbon
git remote add upstream https://github.com/briannesbitt/Carbon.git
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Replace <username> with your GitHub username.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Then, you can work on the master or create a specific branch for your development:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: You can now edit the "Carbon" directory contents.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Before committing, please set your name and your e-mail (use the same e-mail address as in your GitHub account):
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
git config --global user.name "Your Name"
git config --global user.email "your.email.address@example.com"
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
The --global argument will apply this setting for all your git repositories, remove it to set only your Carbon
fork with those settings.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Now you can commit your modifications as you usually do with git:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
git add --all
git commit -m "The commit message log"
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: If your patch fixes an open issue, please insert # immediately followed by the issue number:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git commit -m "#21 Fix this or that"
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Use git rebase (not git merge) to sync your work from time to time:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
git fetch origin
git rebase origin/master
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Please add some tests for bug fixes and features (so it will ensure next developments will not break your code),
then check all is right with phpunit:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Install PHP if you haven't yet, then install composer:
https://getcomposer.org/download/

Label: SC – Submit the changes

Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Versioning
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Note about Semantic Versioning and breaking changes
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
As a developer, you must understand every change is a breaking change. What is a bug for someone
is expected in someone else's workflow. The consequence of a change strongly depends on the usage.
Semantic Versioning relies to public API. In PHP, the public API of a class is its public
methods. However, if you extend a class, you can access protected methods, then if you use reflexion, you can
access private methods. So anything can become a public API if you force it to be. That doesn't mean we should handle
any possible usage, else we would have to publish a major release for each change and it would no longer make sense.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
So before any complain about a breaking change, be warned, we do not guarantee a strict Semantic Versioning as you
may expect, we're following a pragmatic interpretation of Semantic Versioning that allows the software to evolve in a
reliable way with reasonable maintenance effort.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Concretely, we consider a change as breaking if it makes fail one of our unit test. We will do our best to avoid
incompatibilities with libraries that extends Carbon classes (such as Laravel that is continuously tested thanks to
Travis CI, see the compatibility matrix).
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
If you're the owner of a library that strongly depends on Carbon, we recommend you to run unit tests daily requiring
"nesbot/carbon": "dev-master" (for ^2) or "nesbot/carbon": "dev-version-1.next" (for ^1), this way you can
detect incompatibilities earlier and report it to us before we tag a release. We'll pay attention and try to fix it to
make update to next minor releases as soft as possible.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
We reserve the right to publish emergency patches within 24 hours after a release if a tag that does not respect
this pattern would have been released despite our vigilance. In this very rare and particular case, we would mark the
tag as broken on GitHub and backward compatibility would be based on previous stable tag.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Last, you must understand that Carbon extends PHP natives classes, that means Carbon can be impacted by any change
that occurs in the date/time API of PHP. We watch new PHP versions and handle those changes as quickly as possible
when detected, but as PHP does not follow the semantic versioning pattern, it basically means any releases (including
patches) can have unexpected consequences on Carbon methods results.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Long term support
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
To benefit the better support, require Carbon using major version range (^1 or ^2). By requiring 1.26.*,
~1.26.0 or limited range such as >=1.20 <1.33, you fall to low priority support (only security and critical issues
will be fixed), our prior support goes to next minor releases of each major version. It applies to bug fixes and
low-cost features. Other new features will only be added in the last stable release. At the opposite, we recommend you
to restrain to a major number, as there is no compatibility guarantee from a major version to the next. It means
requiring >=2, as it allows any newer version, will probably leads to errors on releasing our next major version.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Open milestones can be patched if a minor bug is detected while if you're on a closed milestone, we'll more likely
ask you to update first to an open one. See currently open milestones:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: https://github.com/briannesbitt/Carbon/milestones
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Getting Started
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Making Changes
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Make sure you have the latest version
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Submit a ticket for the issue, using the GitHub Issue Tracker
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - It's worth checking first to see if someone else has raised your issue. We might have responded to them, or someone might be fixing it.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - If you want to add a feature, as opposed to fixing something that is broken, you should still raise an issue.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - That helps us understand what you want to add, so we can give more specific advice and check it does not conflict with some work in progress on a branch etc.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - If someone else is already working on the suggestion, then hopefully you can collaborate with them.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Add a comment to an issue if you pick it up to work on, so everyone else knows.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - If you have a defect please include the following:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Steps to reproduce the issue
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - A failing test if possible (see below)
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - The stacktrace for any errors you encountered
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: To safeguard the project we ask you to sign a Contributor Licence Agreement. The goal is to let you keep your copyright, but to assign it to the project so that it can use it in perpetuity. It is still yours, but the project is not at risk from having multiple contributors holding the copyright, with anyone able to hold it to ransom by removing their grant of licence.

Paragraph: When submitting PRs, please:

Paragraph: Coding Style
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Code should be formatted using clang-format. By configuring Conky with cmake -DCHECK_CODE_QUALITY=ON, you will be able to run make clang-format to automatically format code. If code in your PR is not formatted according to .clang-format, the checks will not pass.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Unit Testing
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Conky uses the Catch2 unit testing framework. If you are adding new functions or methods, please consider adding unit tests for that code. Additionally, if you'd like to add tests for existing code, that would be a welcome contribution.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Contributing to Browsersync
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
We'd love for you to contribute to Browsersync and help make it even better than it is
today! Here are the guidelines we'd like you to follow:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Question or Problem?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Issues and Bugs
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Tips for a creating a great issue report
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Feature Requests
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Pull Requests
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Coding Rules
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Thank you
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Got a Question or Problem?
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph:
If you have questions about how to use Browsersync, or about your particular setup, please
ask on Stack Overflow. We're trying to keep the Issues thread
for actual bugs with code & implementation.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Found an Issue?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
On that note, if you think you have found a bug in Browsersync, please report
it via Github Issues.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Tips for a creating a great issue report
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Whilst we do try to look at each and every issue as soon as possible, there are certain
aspects about your report that will determine how quickly/deeply we'll delve into it. A great
issue will contain at least the following:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Operating System + Version
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Use case for Browsersync - are you using the built-in server, proxying your own server, or just using the snippet mode?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- Example configuration - show us your full gulpfile.js, Gruntfile.js, bs-config.js or any other code related to how you're using
Browsersync. If we have to respond to your very first issue report with "please provide information about how you're using Browsersync"
then it's very likely to fall to the bottom of the heap. Help us out by providing as much detail as possible!
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- Provide a reduced test case. "Browsersync is not working with my app" is far less helpful than "Here's a example project showing the problem".
An example project might contain a single index.html file with some JS/CSS from CDNs & a short description of the issue. If we
can just pull a repo/gist and see the problem for ourselves, your issue will jump straight to the top of the stack.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- Screencast or GIF - not always appropriate, but can be very helpful where possible. (non-issue related gifs are always welcome, we'll often
respond with something from giphy :p)
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Want a Feature?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
You can request a new feature by submitting an issue to our Github Issues page.
Prefix the title of your issue with "Feature Request:".
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Want a Doc Fix?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Head over to the Browsersync Website Repo & submit issues there.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Submitting a Pull Request
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Pull requests should always be branched off the main Master branch. (There's no guarantee that what lives on the develop
branch will ever make it back to master, I do a lot of experimentation).
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Never commit directly to the master branch, instead create a new branch and submit a PR. This applies to users who have write access also.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Note: If your first PR is merged, you'll get write access to all Browsersync repos.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Coding Advice
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: To ensure consistency throughout the source code, keep these rules in mind as you are working.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - If you're not sure how to provide tests for a feature or bug fix, you should still submit it and we'll help you complete the PR in one of the following ways:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - we can advise you how to go about it
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - we can write the test, and then explain them to you.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - This project has a .editorconfig file to help with code style; go to EditorConfig.org and download the plugin for your IDE.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Don't introduce any extra 3rd party libraries unless you're creating a brand new feature that requires it.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Try to keep your code simple and readable.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- Improve my code! Browsersync has a lot of moving parts and I don't pretend to be skilled in any particular area.
If you have particular experience though, then feel free to rip my code apart and tell me a better way to do something - I'll be extremely grateful (as will the growing number of users!).
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Thank you!
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
If you contribute to Browsersync, or any other Open Source project, you're awesome! This project has been vastly improved
by community input & contributions and we look forward to continuing that trend.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Contributing to Brunch
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Did you find a bug?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: First, make sure it was not already reported by taking a look at the currently open Issues on GitHub.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
If nothing resembling what you are experiencing was reported, feel free to open a new issue.
Make sure your description of the issue is clear and contains as much relevant information as possible.
The issue will be handled more quickly if it includes a link to a sample repo that demonstrates incorrect behavior.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
We never ask you to share your private, possibly NDA'd, application with us.
Just create a tiny application that includes a resembling config as well as just enough code to reproduce the issue.A
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Do you want to write a patch yourself?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: The Process
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Open a new Pull Request with the patch.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Clearly describe what is being fixed. If possible, reference a bug report or a feature request.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Update the docs if the new functionality is added.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Brunch internals overview
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Brunch, the tool, is split across several modules:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- brunch/brunch is the main repo.
It ties everything together to provide the build tool you'll love.
Generally, if something doesn't fit into the other repos, it goes here.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- brunch/deppack is at heart of Brunch 2's new NPM integration.
If it has to do with exposing NPM modules to the browser, it most likely belongs here.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- brunch/node-browser-modules exposes browser shims for Node modules.
This one is used by deppack.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- brunch/commonjs-require-definition is the CommonJS runtime.
It handles how modules are registered and required.
This probably shouldn't be touched unless there is a new deppack feature that needs some changes to the runtime.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- brunch/init-skeleton helps you create new Brunch apps.
It uses the list of skeletons from brunch/skeletons
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Some more:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - paulmillr/loggy is a lightweight logging library.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - paulmillr/chokidar is behind Brunch's file watching magic.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - paulmillr/pushserver is the default HTTP server.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Where the documentation lives:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - brunch/brunch.github.io
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - brunch/brunch-guide
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: How to set up the dev env
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
It won't make much sense to blindly edit the Brunch's sources and get no feedback on whether you are heading in the right direction.
If you are making changes, you most likely are either a) fixing a bug, or b) adding a feature
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: To use your local fork of Brunch, as you need to do is:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 1.  run npm link in the Brunch fork directory. This will make your fork the globally available Brunch on your system.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 2.  run npm link brunch in your sample application. This will make node_modules/brunch in your app a symlink to your Brunch fork.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Additionally, if your changes span past brunch/brunch, you will also need to:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 1.  run npm link from the forked module.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 2.  run npm link <module name> from the Brunch fork directory to link it to Brunch.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Contributing
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Contributions of all types are welcome.
We use GitHub as our bug and feature tracker both for code and for other aspects of the library (documentation, the wiki, etc.).
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Asking Questions
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: The best way to ask general questions is to send an email to our mailing list, or join #glide-library on freenode.org.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Filing issues
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
When in doubt, file an issue. We'd rather close a few duplicate issues than let a problem go unnoticed.
Similarly if you support a particular feature request, feel free to let us know by commenting on the issue or subscribing to the issue.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
To file a new issue, please use our issue template and fill out the template as much as possible (remove irrelevant parts).
The more information you can provide, the more likely we are to be able help.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Contributing code
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Pull requests are welcome for all parts of the codebase, especially the integration libraries.
You can find instructions on building the project in README.md.
Our code style is defined in Intellij project files in the repo and also by our Checkstyle config.
If you'd like to submit code, but can't get the style checks to pass, feel free to put up your pull request anyway and we can help you fix the style issues.
If you'd like to contribute code, you will need to sign Google's individual contributor license agreement which will be asked when you create the PR by googlebot should you forget it.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Labels
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Labels on issues are managed by contributors, you don't have to worry about them. Here's a list of what they mean:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - bug: feature that should work, but doesn't
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - enhancement: minor tweak/addition to existing behavior
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - feature: new behavior, bigger than enhancement, it gives more bang to Glide
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - question: no need to modify Glide to fix the issue, usually a usage problem
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - reproducible: has enough information to very easily reproduce, mostly in form of a small project in a GitHub repo
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - repro-needed: we need some code to be able to reproduce and debug locally, otherwise there's not much we can do
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - duplicate: there's another issue which already covers/tracks this
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - wontfix: working as intended, or won't be fixed due to compatibility or other reasons
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - invalid: there isn't enough information to make a verdict, or unrelated to Glide
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - non-library: issue is not in the core library code, but rather in documentation, samples, build process, releases
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - v4: problem originated in v4, or question about v4 (while v3 is in wide use)
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: bug + enhancement: feature that doesn't work, but it's an edge case that either has a workaround or doesn't affect many users
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Contributing Guide
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Check the GitHub Issues for open issues that need attention.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: - Follow the How to submit a contribution Guide.

Paragraph: - Make sure unit tests pass. Please read how to run unit tests below.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - If you are fixing a bug:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - If you are resolving an existing issue, reference the issue id in a commit message (fixed #XXX).
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - If the issue has not been reported, please add a detailed description of the bug in the PR.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Please add a regression test case.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - If you are adding a new feature:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Provide a convincing reason to add this feature and have it greenlighted before working on it.

Paragraph: - Add tests to cover the functionality.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Please follow Style Guide for Python Code.

Paragraph: Testing
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 1.  Obtain OAuth2 credentials from Google Developers Console
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 2.  Install test requirements:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: pip install -r test-requirements.txt
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 3.  Run tests:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: GS_CREDS_FILENAME=<YOUR_CREDS.json> nosetests -vv tests/test.py
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: where YOUR_CREDS.json is a path to the file you downloaded in step 1.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Tip: To run a specific test method append its name in the form of :TestClassName.test_method_name to tests/test.py.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Example:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: GS_CREDS_FILENAME=<YOUR_CREDS.json> nosetests -vv tests/test.py:WorksheetTest.test_find
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Note: gspread uses Betamax to record and replay HTTP interactions with Sheets API.
You can control Betamax's Record Mode using GS_RECORD_MODE environment variable:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: GS_RECORD_MODE=all GS_CREDS_FILENAME=<YOUR_CREDS.json> nosetests -vv tests/test.py
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Render Documentation
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: The documentation uses reStructuredText markup and is rendered by Sphinx.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: To build the documentation locally, install Sphinx:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: pip install Sphinx
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Then from the project directory, run:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: sphinx-build -b html docs html
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Once finished, the rendered documentation will be in html folder. index.html is an entry point.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Bug Reports | Features Requests | Submitting Pull Requests | Running Local Demo | Running Tests
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Contributing to this project
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Please take a moment to review this document in order to make the contribution process easy and effective for everyone involved.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Following these guidelines helps to communicate that you respect the time of the developers managing and developing this open source project.
In return, they should reciprocate that respect in addressing your issue or assessing patches and features.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Using the issue tracker
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: The issue tracker is the preferred channel for bug reports but please respect the following restrictions:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Please do not use the issue tracker for personal support requests (use Slack).
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Please do not derail or troll issues. Keep the discussion on topic and respect the opinions of others.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Bug reports
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
A bug is a demonstrable problem that is caused by the code in the repository.
Good bug reports are extremely helpful - thank you!
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Guidelines for bug reports:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 1.  Use the GitHub issue search — check if the issue has already been reported.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 2.  Check if the issue has been fixed — try to reproduce it using the latest master or development branch in the repository.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 3.  Isolate the problem — create a reduced test case and a live example (using a site like Plunker).
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
A good bug report shouldn't leave others needing to chase you up for more information.
Please try to be as detailed as possible in your report.
Which versions of react-virtualized and react are you using?
What steps will reproduce the issue? What browser(s) and OS experience the problem?
What would you expect to be the outcome?
All these details will help people to fix any potential bugs.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Example:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Short and descriptive example bug report title
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
A summary of the issue and the browser/OS environment in which it occurs.
If suitable, include the steps required to reproduce the bug.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 1.  This is the first step
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 2.  This is the second step
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 3.  Further steps, etc.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: <url> - a link to the reduced test case
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Any other information you want to share that is relevant to the issue being reported.
This might include the lines of code that you have identified as causing the bug,
and potential solutions (and your opinions on their merits).
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Feature requests
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Feature requests are welcome.
But take a moment to find out whether your idea fits with the scope and aims of the project.
It's up to you to make a strong case to convince the project's developers of the merits of this feature.
Please provide as much detail and context as possible.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Pull requests
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Good pull requests - patches, improvements, new features - are a fantastic help.
They should remain focused in scope and avoid containing unrelated commits.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Please ask first before embarking on any significant pull request (e.g. implementing features, refactoring code, porting to a different language),
otherwise you risk spending a lot of time working on something that the project's developers might not want to merge into the project.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Please adhere to the coding conventions used throughout a project (indentation, accurate comments, etc.) and any other requirements (such as test coverage).
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Follow this process if you'd like your work considered for inclusion in the project:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 1.  Fork the project, clone your fork, and configure the remotes:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
# Clone your fork of the repo into the current directory
git clone https://github.com/<your-username>/react-virtualized
# Navigate to the newly cloned directory
cd react-virtualized
# Assign the original repo to a remote called "upstream"
git remote add upstream https://github.com/bvaughn/react-virtualized
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 2.  If you cloned a while ago, get the latest changes from upstream:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
git checkout master
git pull upstream master
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 3.  Install/update dependencies:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: yarn install
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
4.  Create a new topic branch (off the main project development branch) to
contain your feature, change, or fix:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: git checkout -b <topic-branch-name>
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
5.  Commit your changes in logical chunks.
Please adhere to these git commit message guidelines
or your code is unlikely be merged into the main project.
Use Git's interactive rebase
feature to tidy up your commits before making them public.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 6.  Locally merge (or rebase) the upstream development branch into your topic branch:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: git pull [--rebase] upstream master
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 7.  Push your topic branch up to your fork:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: git push origin <topic-branch-name>
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
8.  Open a Pull Request
with a clear title and description.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: IMPORTANT: By submitting a patch, you agree to allow the project owner to license your work under the same license as that used by this project (MIT).
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Running Local Demo
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: You can run the local demo with NPM like so:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
cd <root>
yarn start
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: The local app will then be available at http://localhost:3001
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Running Tests
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
All unit tests must pass before a pull request will be approved.
You can run unit tests with NPM like so:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
cd <root>
yarn test
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Contributing
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Below you will find a collection of guidelines for submitting issues as well as contributing code to the Caffe repository.
Please read those before starting an issue or a pull request.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Issues
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Specific Caffe design and development issues, bugs, and feature requests are maintained by GitHub Issues.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Please do not post installation, build, usage, or modeling questions, or other requests for help to Issues.
Use the caffe-users list instead.
This helps developers maintain a clear, uncluttered, and efficient view of the state of Caffe.
See the chapter caffe-users below for guidance on posting to the users list.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: When reporting an issue, it's most helpful to provide the following information, where applicable:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - How does the problem look like and what steps reproduce it?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Can you reproduce it using the latest master, compiled with the DEBUG make option?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - What hardware and software are you running? In particular:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - GPU make and model, if relevant,
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - operating system/distribution,
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - compiler; please also post which version (for example, with GCC run gcc --version to check),
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - CUDA version, if applicable (run nvcc --version to check),
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - cuDNN version, if applicable (version number is stored in cudnn.h, look for lines containing CUDNN_MAJOR, CUDNN_MINOR and CUDNN_PATCHLEVEL),
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - BLAS library,
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Python version, if relevant,
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - MATLAB version, if relevant.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - What have you already tried to solve the problem? How did it fail? Are there any other issues related to yours?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - If this is not a build-related issue, does your installation pass make runtest?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - If the bug is a crash, provide the backtrace (usually printed by Caffe; always obtainable with gdb).
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - If you are reporting a build error that seems to be due to a bug in Caffe, please attach your build configuration (either Makefile.config or CMakeCache.txt) and the output of the make (or cmake) command.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
If only a small portion of the code/log is relevant to your issue, you may paste it directly into the post, preferably using Markdown syntax for code block: triple backtick ( ``` ) to open/close a block.
In other cases (multiple files, or long files), please attach them to the post - this greatly improves readability.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
If the problem arises during a complex operation (e.g. large script using pycaffe, long network prototxt), please reduce the example to the minimal size that still causes the error.
Also, minimize influence of external modules, data etc. - this way it will be easier for others to understand and reproduce your issue, and eventually help you.
Sometimes you will find the root cause yourself in the process.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Try to give your issue a title that is succinct and specific. The devs will rename issues as needed to keep track of them.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Caffe-users
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Before you post to the caffe-users list, make sure you look for existing solutions.
The Caffe community has encountered and found solutions to countless problems - benefit from the collective experience.
Recommended places to look:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - the users list itself,
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - caffe tag on StackOverflow,
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - GitHub issues tracker (some problems have been answered there),
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - the public wiki,
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - the official documentation.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Found a post/issue with your exact problem, but with no answer?
Don't just leave a "me too" message - provide the details of your case.
Problems with more available information are easier to solve and attract good attention.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
When posting to the list, make sure you provide as much relevant information as possible - recommendations for an issue report (see above) are a good starting point.
Please make it very clear which version of Caffe you are using, especially if it is a fork not maintained by BVLC.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Formatting recommendations hold: paste short logs/code fragments into the post (use fixed-width text for them), attach long logs or multiple files.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Pull Requests
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Caffe welcomes all contributions.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: See the contributing guide for details.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Briefly: read commit by commit, a PR should tell a clean, compelling story of one improvement to Caffe. In particular:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - A PR should do one clear thing that obviously improves Caffe, and nothing more. Making many smaller PRs is better than making one large PR; review effort is superlinear in the amount of code involved.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Similarly, each commit should be a small, atomic change representing one step in development. PRs should be made of many commits where appropriate.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Please do rewrite PR history to be clean rather than chronological. Within-PR bugfixes, style cleanups, reversions, etc. should be squashed and should not appear in merged PR history.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Anything nonobvious from the code should be explained in comments, commit messages, or the PR description, as appropriate.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Contributing
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
When contributing to this repository, please first discuss the change you wish to make via issue,
Gitter, or any other method with the owner of this repository before opening a pull request.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Aim of the project
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
The aim of Julius is to re-create the exact same logic that the original Caesar 3 uses, with full savegame compatibility, but with some small user interface enhancements, like widescreen support. The same logic also means that any gameplay bugs present in Caesar 3 will also be present in Julius.
It is meant as a drop-in replacement for Caesar 3, with the same look and feel, so there will be no major UI changes.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Later on there may be an 'enhanced' edition with new features, but for now any pull requests which change the game logic or alter the UI in a major way will be declined.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: Versioning
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: BWAPI versioning is categorized as follows: major.minor.patch [Beta]
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Version Component | Description
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
------------------|----------------
major             | Increased when massive structural changes are made.
minor             | Increased when breaking changes are made. Modules will need to be recompiled.
patch             | Increased when non-breaking changes are made.
Beta              | Appended to a major version increase until stability has been verified.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Coding Standards
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Spacing
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Use double-spaces instead of tabs. You should be able to convert tabs to spaces automatically in your editor's settings.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Always indent for each scope level.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Always put a space between all arithmetic, binary, and conditional operators.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Don't put a space between function names and the open parenthesis.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Put a space after a comma.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Examples of spacing
Label: No categories identified.
No categories identified.
No categories identified.
No categories identified.
No categories identified.

Paragraph: Formatting
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Use ANSI style braces.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Break up large single-line if statements to be multi-line if statements.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Format constructor initializer lists as follows (so that the colon is in the same column as the commas):
Label: DC – Deal with the code
No categories identified.

Paragraph: Naming
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Use meaningful names. If a variable's purpose cannot be identified by another project member without analysing the code, then the variable needs to be renamed.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - In local looping scopes, single-letter variable names are generally used as follows:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - b for Bullet
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - f for Force
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - p for Player
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - r for Region
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - u for Unit
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - i for iterator/index
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Member variables and member function names should be in lower camel case. Examples: getUnitsInRectangle, wasSeenByBWAPIPlayer.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Constants and macros should be in ALL CAPS and words separated by underscores. Example: PLAYER_COUNT
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Use upper Camel Case for classes, structures, enums, and namespaces.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Hacking
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Offsets must be in hexadecimal. Example: 0x00408CF0.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Offsets must be placed in BW/offsets.h.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Avoid using inline assembly unless it is impossible to do so.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Always perform version checking before making code patches, to maintain partial cross-version compatibility.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Documentation
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Use the triple slash (///) format.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Try to include as much details on the function as possible. Redundancy can express clarity.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Include example code if possible.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Wrap lines before the 100th column.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Doxygen Generation
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Use @ for doxygen commands.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Use @see to refer to other functions/classes.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - When introducing a new function, include a @since tag with the version number.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Include @returns, and @retval where necessary.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - When specifying @param, also specify if the argument is optional. Present an indented description on the next line, and also specify its default value if applicable.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Intellisense Compatibility
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Use the summary tag to wrap the function/class/enum description.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Use the param tag to identify all of the parameters.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Identify if an argument is optional with (optional) on the same line as the tag.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Put parameter descriptions indented on the next line, between the tags.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Examples of documentation:
Label: No categories identified.
No categories identified.
No categories identified.

Paragraph: Language Features
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Use the nullptr keyword instead of NULL.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Create move constructors if appropriate.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Use the const keyword where appropriate.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Use std::array instead of C-style arrays.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Use explicit enum types (preferably enum class) instead of ints.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Use in-class member initialization.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Use the keywords default, delete, override, final, etc.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Changing the API
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Adding a Virtual Function
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 1.  Add it after all other virtual functions.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 2.  Label it with Doxygen @since tag, indicating the version it was introduced.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Note: Virtual functions are implementation defined, but Visual Studio appears to maintain some consistency regarding the use of virtual functions. Adding a new function to the end will maintain some backwards compatibility.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Renaming a Function
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 1.  Rename the function.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 2.  Create a non-virtual function with the old name that calls the new function.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 3.  Label it with Doxygen @deprecated tag and refer to the new function.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 4.  Optionally add a compiler deprecation warning (until we move to VS 2015).
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 5.  Remove it after the next 2 minor versions or next major version, whichever comes first.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Deprecating a Function
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 1.  Label it with Doxygen @deprecated tag.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 2.  Provide reason for the deprecation and alternatives if applicable.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 3.  Optionally add a compiler deprecation warning (until we move to VS 2015).
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 4.  Remove it after the next 2 minor versions or next major version, whichever comes first.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Contributing to WAMR
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
As an open-source project, we welcome and encourage the community to submit patches directly to the project. In our collaborative open source environment, standards and methods for submitting changes help reduce the chaos that can result from an active development community.
We want to make contributing to this project as easy and transparent as possible, whether it's:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Reporting a bug
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - the current state of the code
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Submitting a fix
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Proposing new features
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: License
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
WAMR uses the same license as LLVM: the Apache 2.0 license with the LLVM
exception. See the LICENSE file for details. This license allows you to freely
use, modify, distribute and sell your own products based on WAMR.
Any contributions you make will be under the same license.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Code changes
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: We Use Github Flow, So All Code Changes Happen Through Pull Requests. Pull requests are the best way to propose changes to the codebase. We actively welcome your pull requests:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - If you've added code that should be tested, add tests. Ensure the test suite passes.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Avoid use macros for different platforms. Use seperate folder of source files to host diffeent platform logic.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Put macro definitions inside share_lib/include/config.h if you have to use macro.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Make sure your code lints and compliant to our coding style.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Extend the application library is highly welcome.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Coding Style
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
Please use K&R coding style, such as 4 spaces for indentation rather than tabs etc.
We suggest use Eclipse like IDE or stable coding format tools to make your code compliant to K&R format.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Report bugs
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: We use GitHub issues to track public bugs. Report a bug by open a new issue.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Code of Conduct
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: WAMR is a Bytecode Alliance project, and follows the Bytecode Alliance's Code of Conduct and Organizational Code of Conduct.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Contributions
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: First of all thank you for considering contributing to this open source project!
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: I am always welcoming contributions of any type. Please open an issue or create a PR if you find an issue with any of the following.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - An issue with Documentation (typo, incorrect code example)
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - You found the documentation lacking in some way
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: If you have an issue with the library please include the following
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - A description of the problem
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Does this issue occur while formatting or parsing a csv.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - A short example of how to reproduce (if applicable)
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - A sample csv
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Sample code to reproduce the issue
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Without those basics it can be difficult to reproduce your issue locally. You may be asked for more information but that is a good starting point.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: New Features
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: New features and/or enhancements are great and I encourage you to either submit a PR or create an issue. In both cases include the following as the need/requirement may not be readily apparent.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 1.  The use case
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 2.  A short example
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: If you are issuing a PR also also include the following
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 1.  Tests - otherwise the PR will not be merged
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 2.  Documentation - otherwise the PR will not be merged
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 3.  Examples
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: If you find an issue you want to work on please comment on it letting other people know you are looking at it and I will assign the issue to you.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: If want to work on an issue but dont know where to start just leave a comment and I'll be more than happy to point you in the right direction.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Filing an issue
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Before filing an issue, please search the queue to make sure it hasn't already been reported.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: If a bug, please include the following
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 1.  What version of C3?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 2.  What browsers have you confirmed it in?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 3.  Can you isolate the issue by providing a jsFiddle demonstrating it in a minimalist capacity?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Please do not ask for support using the issue queue. For support, please ask on chat or the mailing list.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Setup
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 1.  Clone the repo from GitHub
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
git clone https://github.com/c3js/c3.git
cd c3
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 2.  Acquire build dependencies. Make sure you have Node.js installed on your workstation. This is only needed to build C3 from sources. C3 itself has no dependency on Node.js once it is built. Now run:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
npm install -g grunt-cli
npm install
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: The first npm command sets up the popular Grunt build tool. You might need to run this command with sudo if you're on Linux or Mac OS X, or in an Administrator command prompt on Windows. The second npm command fetches the remaining build dependencies.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Building C3 from sources
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: npm run build
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Distribution
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: npm run dist
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Now you'll find the built files in c3.js, c3.min.js, c3.css & c3.min.css.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Running the tests
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: npm run test
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: This command will automatically run the specification suite and report its results.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: If you want to see specs running live in browser (e.g., for debugging), simply open http://localhost:9876/ in your browser when phantomjs starts.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Building the document site (c3js.org)
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: First you need ruby and bundler to build the documentation site.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Note: Currently the site doesn't build with ruby 2.5.x, so you need ruby 2.4.4 or below. (rbenv is useful for switching between ruby versions.)
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: $ gem install bundler
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Then you need to install bundler dependencies.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: $ bundle install
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Then hit the following command to build the site.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: $ npm run watch:docs
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Then access http://0.0.0.0:4567.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Contributing your changes
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Add something about PRs here, indicate that PRs should not bump the version number & the build output files (c3.js, c3.min.js, c3.css & c3.min.css) should be excluded
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Definition of trivial contributions
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
It's hard to define what is a trivial contribution. Sometimes even a 1 character change can be considered significant.
Unfortunately because it can be subjective, the decision on what is trivial comes from the maintainers of the project
and not from folks contributing to the project.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: What is generally considered trivial:
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: - Fixing a typo.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: - Documentation changes.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: - Fixes to non-production code - like fixing something small in the build code.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: What is generally not considered trivial:
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph:
- Changes to any code that would be delivered as part of the final product.
This includes any scripts that are delivered, such as the PowerShell bootstrapper.
Yes, even 1 character changes could be considered non-trivial.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Normal .NET coding guidelines apply.
See the Framework Design Guidelines for more information.

Paragraph: Dependencies
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: The assemblies Cake.Core and Cake.Common should have no dependencies except the .NET BCL library.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
Dependencies for the Cake executable is acceptable in specific circumstances.
If you want to introduce a dependency to the Cake executable, make sure you bring it
up in an issue or a pull request, so it can be properly discussed.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Label: SC – Submit the changes

Make sure to run all unit tests before creating a pull request.
Any new code should also have reasonable unit test coverage.

Paragraph: Contributing process
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Get buyoff or find open community issues or features
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
- Through GitHub, or through the Gitter chat (preferred),
you talk about a feature you would like to see (or a bug), and why it should be in Cake.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph:
- If approved through the Gitter chat, ensure an accompanying GitHub issue is created with
information and a link back to the discussion.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Once you get a nod from one of the Cake Team, you can start on the feature.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
- Alternatively, if a feature is on the issues list with the
Up For Grabs label,
it is open for a community member (contributor) to patch. You should comment that you are signing up for it on
the issue so someone else doesn't also sign up for the work.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Set up your environment
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: - You create, or update, a fork of cake-build/cake under your GitHub account.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: - From there you create a branch named specific to the feature.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - In the branch you do work specific to the feature.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Please also observe the following:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - No reformatting
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - No changing files that are not specific to the feature.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - More covered below in the Prepare commits section.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Test your changes and please help us out by updating and implementing some automated tests.
It is recommended that all contributors spend some time looking over the tests in the source code.
You can't go wrong emulating one of the existing tests and then changing it specific to the behavior you are testing.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Please do not update your branch from the develop unless we ask you to. See the responding to feedback section below.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Prepare commits
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: This section serves to help you understand what makes a good commit.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: A commit should observe the following:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - A commit is a small logical unit that represents a change.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Should include new or changed tests relevant to the changes you are making.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - No unnecessary whitespace. Check for whitespace with git diff --check and git diff --cached --check before commit.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - You can stage parts of a file for commit.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Submit pull request
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Prerequisites:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - You are making commits in a feature branch.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - All code should compile without errors or warnings.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - All tests should be passing.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Submitting PR:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Once you feel it is ready, submit the pull request to the cake-build/cake repository against the develop branch
unless specifically requested to submit it against another branch.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- In the case of a larger change that is going to require more discussion,
please submit a PR sooner. Waiting until you are ready may mean more changes than you are
interested in if the changes are taking things in a direction the maintainers do not want to go.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- In the pull request, outline what you did and point to specific conversations (as in URLs)
and issues that you are resolving. This is a tremendous help for us in evaluation and acceptance.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Once the pull request is in, please do not delete the branch or close the pull request
(unless something is wrong with it).
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- One of the Cake team members, or one of the maintainers, will evaluate it within a
reasonable time period (which is to say usually within 1-3 weeks). Some things get evaluated
faster or fast tracked. We are human and we have active lives outside of open source so don't
fret if you haven't seen any activity on your pull request within a month or two.
We don't have a Service Level Agreement (SLA) for pull requests.
Just know that we will evaluate your pull request.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Respond to feedback on pull request
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
We may have feedback for you to fix or change some things. We generally like to see that pushed against
the same topic branch (it will automatically update the Pull Request). You can also fix/squash/rebase
commits and push the same topic branch with --force (it's generally acceptable to do this on topic
branches not in the main repository, it is generally unacceptable and should be avoided at all costs
against the main repository).
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
If we have comments or questions when we do evaluate it and receive no response, it will probably
lessen the chance of getting accepted. Eventually, this means it will be closed if it is not accepted.
Please know this doesn't mean we don't value your contribution, just that things go stale. If in the
future you want to pick it back up, feel free to address our concerns/questions/feedback and reopen
the issue/open a new PR (referencing old one).
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Sometimes we may need you to rebase your commit against the latest code before we can review it further.
If this happens, you can do the following:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - git fetch upstream (upstream would be the mainstream repo or cake-build/cake in this case)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - git checkout develop
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - git rebase upstream/develop
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - git checkout your-branch
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - git rebase develop
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Fix any merge conflicts
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- git push origin your-branch (origin would be your GitHub repo or your-github-username/cake in this case).
You may need to git push origin your-branch --force to get the commits pushed.
This is generally acceptable with topic branches not in the mainstream repository.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: The only reasons a pull request should be closed and resubmitted are as follows:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - When the pull request is targeting the wrong branch (this doesn't happen as often).
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- When there are updates made to the original by someone other than the original contributor.
Then the old branch is closed with a note on the newer branch this supersedes #github_number.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Other general information
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
If you reformat code or hit core functionality without an approval from a person on the Cake Team,
it's likely that no matter how awesome it looks afterwards, it will probably not get accepted.
Reformatting code makes it harder for us to evaluate exactly what was changed.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
If you do these things, it will be make evaluation and acceptance easy.
Now if you stray outside of the guidelines we have above, it doesn't mean we are going to ignore
your pull request. It will just make things harder for us.
Harder for us roughly translates to a longer SLA for your pull request.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: How to contribute
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: CakePHP loves to welcome your contributions. There are several ways to help out:
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: - Create an issue on GitHub, if you have found a bug
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: - Write test cases for open bug issues
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: - Write patches for open bug/feature issues, preferably with test cases included
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: - Contribute to the documentation
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph:
There are a few guidelines that we need contributors to follow so that we have a
chance of keeping on top of things.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Code of Conduct
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Help us keep CakePHP open and inclusive. Please read and follow our Code of Conduct.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Getting Started
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Make sure you have a GitHub account.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Submit an issue, assuming one does not already exist.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Clearly describe the issue including steps to reproduce when it is a bug.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Make sure you fill in the earliest version that you know has the issue.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Fork the repository on GitHub.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Making Changes
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Create a topic branch from where you want to base your work.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - This is usually the master branch.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Only target release branches if you are certain your fix must be on that
branch.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- To quickly create a topic branch based on master; git branch master/my_contribution master then checkout the new branch with git checkout master/my_contribution. Better avoid working directly on the
master branch, to avoid conflicts if you pull in updates from origin.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Make commits of logical units.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Check for unnecessary whitespace with git diff --check before committing.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Use descriptive commit messages and reference the #issue number.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Core test cases should continue to pass. You can run tests locally or enable
travis-ci for your fork, so all tests and codesniffs
will be executed.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Your work should apply the CakePHP coding standards.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Which branch to base the work
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Bugfix branches will be based on master.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - New features that are backwards compatible will be based on the appropriate 'next' branch. For example if you want to contribute to the next 3.x branch, you should base your changes on 3.next.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - New features or other non backwards compatible changes will go in the next major release branch. Development on 4.0 has not started yet, so breaking changes are unlikely to be merged in.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Submitting Changes
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Push your changes to a topic branch in your fork of the repository.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Submit a pull request to the repository in the CakePHP organization, with the
correct target branch.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Test cases and codesniffer
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
CakePHP tests requires PHPUnit.
To install PHPUnit use composer:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: php composer.phar require "phpunit/phpunit:*"
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: To run the test cases locally use the following command:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: vendor/bin/phpunit
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
You can copy file phpunit.xml.dist to phpunit.xml and modify the database
driver settings as required to run tests for particular database.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
You can also register on Travis CI and from your
profile page enable the service hook for your
CakePHP fork on GitHub for automated test builds.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: To run the sniffs for CakePHP coding standards:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: vendor/bin/phpcs -p --extensions=php --standard=vendor/cakephp/cakephp-codesniffer/CakePHP ./src
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Check the cakephp-codesniffer
repository to setup the CakePHP standard. The README contains installation info
for the sniff and phpcs.
Label: SC – Submit the changes
