Paragraph: How to contribute to Phinx
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Phinx relies heavily on external contributions in order to make it the best database migration
tool possible. Without the support of our 130+ contributors, we wouldn't be where we are today!
We encourage anyone to submit documentation enhancements and code.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Issues, feature requests, and bugs should be submitted using the Github issue tool:
https://github.com/cakephp/phinx/issues.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: This document briefly outlines the requirements to contribute code to Phinx.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Considerations
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Before you submit your pull request take a moment to answer the following questions.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Answering 'YES' to all questions will increase the likelihood of your PR being accepted!
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Have I implemented my feature for as many database adapters as possible?
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Does my new feature improve Phinx's performance or keep it consistent?
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Does my feature fit within the database migration space?
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Is the code entirely my own and free from any commercial licensing?
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Am I happy to release my code under the MIT license?
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Is my code formatted using the PSR-2 coding standard?
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Note: We accept bug fixes much faster into our development branch than new features.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Getting Started
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Great, so you want to contribute. Let's get started:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 1.  Start by forking Phinx on GitHub: https://github.com/cakephp/phinx
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 2.  Clone your repository to a local directory on your development box.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 3.  If you do not have Composer set up already, install it:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: curl -sS https://getcomposer.org/installer | php
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 4.  Change to your Phinx clone directory and pull the necessary dependencies:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: php composer.phar install
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 5.  Copy the phpunit.xml.dist template to phpunit.xml:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: cp phpunit.xml.dist phpunit.xml
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: And change the configuration to suit your environment. If you are not using any particular adapter you can disable it in the phpunit.xml file.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 6.  Run the unit tests locally to ensure they pass:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: php vendor/bin/phpunit --config phpunit.xml
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 7.  Write the code and unit tests for your bug fix or feature.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 8.  Add any relevant documentation.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 9.  Run the unit tests again and ensure they pass.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 10. Open a pull request on the Github project page. Ensure the code is being merged into master.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 2.  Install dependencies:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: composer update
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 3.  Run unittest:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: vendor/bin/phpunit
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: How to Contribute

Paragraph: Thanks for wanting to contribute to Caliburn.Micro. Contributions don't need to take the form of code, submitting issues and writing documentation is just as important.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: FAQ: I see an error when opening the solution
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: error  : The expression "[System.IO.Path]::GetDirectoryName('')" cannot be evaluated. The path is not of a legal form.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: To find the version of the SDK that Caliburn Micro requires go to src/global.json.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: e.g.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Once this version listed in the global.json file is installed the solution will open with all the projects loaded. If the correct versions of the SDKs for Android, UAP and Xamarin are not installed there are error messages at build time that contain instructions on how to proceed.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Raising Issues
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Basic support is provided by the community on [Stack Overflow][http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/caliburn.micro] including the core contributors.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: The following information is incredibly helpful when raising issues:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Platform(s) - Caliburn.Micro runs on a lot of platforms and is tightly coupled with their UI stacks, knowing which platform or platforms you're experiencing the issue on helps immensely.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Steps - Steps on recreating the issue.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Sample Project - Even better that reproduction steps is a sample project that highlights the issue.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Getting started with the source
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
You can clone this repository locally from GitHub using the "Clone in Desktop"
button from the main project site, or run this command in the Git Shell:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: git@github.com:Caliburn-Micro/Caliburn.Micro.git Caliburn.Micro
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: If you want to make contributions to the project, forking the project is the easiest way to do this. You can then clone down your fork instead:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: git clone git@github.com:MY-USERNAME-HERE/Caliburn.Micro.git Caliburn.Micro
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Documentation of building the code is currently available on the Caliburn.Micro website.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: How is the codebase organised?
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: The Caliburn.Micro is broken up into three groups of assemblies.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Core - This contains the building blocks of any MVVM solution such PropertyChangedBase, Screen & EventAggregator. It's a Portable Class Library designed to work on as many platforms as possible. However due to some limitations we create the Core assembly for Silverlight 5 and .NET 4.0 separately although they share code using linked files and compilation symbols.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Platform - For each platform Caliburn.Micro runs on we have a platform assembly, this contains the code that makes direct use of the appropriate UI stack and any code that could not be made portable. Most of the code is shared between the various platform projects using linked files and compilation symbols.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Making Changes
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
When you're ready to make a change,
create a branch
off the master branch. We use master as the default branch for the
repository, and it holds the most recent contributions, so any changes you make
in master might cause conflicts down the track.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
If you make focused commits (instead of one monolithic commit) and have descriptive
commit messages, this will help speed up the review process.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Submitting Changes
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
You can publish your branch from GitHub for Windows, or run this command from
the Git Shell:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git push origin MY-BRANCH-NAME
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Once your changes are ready to be reviewed, publish the branch to GitHub and
open a pull request
against it.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: A few little tips with pull requests:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- prefix the title with [WIP] to indicate this is a work-in-progress. It's
always good to get feedback early, so don't be afraid to open the PR before it's "done".
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- use checklists
to indicate the tasks which need to be done, so everyone knows how close you are to done.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - add comments to the PR about things that are unclear or you would like suggestions on
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Don't forget to mention in the pull request description which issue/issues are
being addressed.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Some things that will increase the chance that your pull request is accepted.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Follow existing code conventions. Most of what we do follows standard .NET
conventions except in a few places.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- Include unit tests that would otherwise fail without your code, but pass with
it.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Update the documentation, the surrounding one, examples elsewhere, guides,
whatever is affected by your contribution
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Code of Conduct

Paragraph: Our Development Process
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: The core team works directly on GitHub and all work is public.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Development workflow
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Working on your first pull request? You can learn how from this free series: How to Contribute to an Open Source Project on GitHub.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 1.  Fork the repo and create your branch from master (a guide on how to fork a repository).
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 2.  Linaria uses Yarn for running development scripts. If you haven't already done so, please install yarn.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 3.  Run yarn bootstrap to setup the development environment.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Commit message convention
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: We follow the conventional commits specification for our commit messages:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - fix: bug fixes, e.g. fix wrong classname generated by babel plugin.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - feat: new features, e.g. add support for a config file.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - refactor: code refactor, e.g. split the babel plugin into multiple visitors.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - docs: changes into documentation, e.g. add usage example for styled tag.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - test: adding or updating tests, eg unit, snapshot testing.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - chore: tooling changes, e.g. change the eslint config.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - BREAKING CHANGE: for changes that break existing usage, e.g. change the API or behaviour.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Our pre-commit hooks verify that your commit message matches this format when committing. If you are working on some in progress commits and don't care about the pre-commit hook, pass the --no-verify (-n) flag to git when committing (e.g. git commit -n -m "wip").
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Linting and tests
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: We use flow for type checking, eslint with prettier for linting and formatting the code, and jest for testing. Our pre-commit hooks verify that the linter and tests pass when commiting. You can also run the following commands manually:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - yarn flow: run flow on all files.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - yarn typescript: run tests for typescript definitions.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - yarn lint: lint files with eslint and prettier.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - yarn test: run unit tests with jest.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - yarn test:integration: run integration tests with jest and puppeteer.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Sending a pull request
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: When you're sending a pull request:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Prefer small pull requests focused on one change.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Verify that flow, eslint and all tests are passing.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Preview the documentation to make sure it looks good.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Follow the pull request template when opening a pull request.

cd /path/to/your/linaria_clone/
yarn
yarn link

Paragraph: Debugging and deep dive into babel plugin
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
To understand what is actually going in under the hood of Linaria we recommend to first read the top-level How it works.
Then you can run Linaria in debug mode for a specific file from you project and see step-by-step logs informing what is happening.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: DEBUG=linaria* LINARIA_LOG=debug npx babel -d dist PATH_TO_COMPONENT
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: In example we use npx to run babel, but you can also put this script into package.json with removed npx to run it.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: You will see how the babel part of Linaria work, result JS file will be stored in dist directory. You will not see the resulting CSS file, because this is the role of next layer - bundlers (CSS content is stored in babel metadata to be consumed by bundler).
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Ruby versions
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
You can see the current ruby versions we support in .travis.yml.
Obviously, any language features you use must be available in the oldest version we support.
Therefore, it's often helpful to develop / test against the oldest version to avoid accidentally
using unsupported features.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Tests
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
SSHKit has a unit test suite and a functional test suite. Some functional tests run against
Vagrant VMs. If possible, you should make sure that the
tests pass for each commit by running rake in the sshkit directory. This is in case we
need to cherry pick commits or rebase. You should ensure the tests pass, (preferably on
the minimum and maximum ruby version), before creating a PR.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Pull requests are much more likely to be accepted if you write a tests for the new functionality
you are adding. If you are fixing a bug, it would be great if you could add a test to
expose the bug you are fixing to show that the behaviour is fixed by your changes.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
We use Travis CI to run the tests on different
ruby versions.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
The Travis build does not run the functional tests,
so make sure all the tests pass locally before creating your PR.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Coding guidelines
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
This project uses RuboCop to enforce standard Ruby coding
guidelines. Currently we run RuboCop's lint rules only, which check for readability issues
like indentation, ambiguity, and useless/unreachable code.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Test that your contributions pass with rake lint
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - The linter is also run as part of the full test suite with rake
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Note the Travis build will fail and your PR cannot be merged if the linter finds errors
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Most changes should have an accompanying entry in the CHANGELOG, unless they
are minor documentation / config changes. This is incredibly important so that our users can
see the affect of new versions without having to trawl through the commits.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Breaking changes
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
We adhere to semver so breaking changes will require a major release.
For breaking changes, it would normally be helpful to discuss them by raising a 'Proposal' issue
or PR with examples of the new API you're proposing
before doing a lot of work.
Bear in mind that breaking changes may require many hundreds / thousands of users to update their
code.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
You can use the BREAKING_API_WISHLIST to record issues / PRs where
API changes have been discussed, and not implemented.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

When contributing to this repository, please first discuss the change you wish to make via issue,

Paragraph: IMPORTANT: CapRover Goals & Scope
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Since the birth of CapRover, there has been many contributions and suggestions that shaped CapRover as we know it today. One of the very important factor in the contribution you make is to stick with CapRover design philosophy.- CapRover is not an enterprise grade application like Kubernetes. Do not patch it with half-done features that make it look like one - it will eventually fail as we don't have resources to support such features.- CapRover scope is a helper around Docker, nginx and Let's Encrypt.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: The goal is to make the common use-cases exposed via simple controls on UI while allowing further customizations to be done through hooks and scripts. If a new feature is doable via the existing features, or a basic tool, do not add it to CapRover. We do not want to bloat this application. One example is: "Add a flag to customize the placement constraints of containers". This is definitely doable in Docker, but we don't want to mirror every single functionality of Docker to CapRover. If we do that, CapRover becomes a very hard to maintain project. Instead we should add customization hooks for these advanced and rare use cases. For example, instead of mirroring every single nginx config, we added the ability of customizing the nginx config for advanced users.- Last but not least AVOID LARGE PULL REQUESTS at all cost as they won't get reviewed unless they are discussed in the Slack channel beforehand.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Pull Request Process
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
1.  IF APPLICABLE: Update the docs (https://github.com/caprover/caprover-website) with details of changes to the interface, this includes new environment
variables, exposed ports, useful file locations and container parameters.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 2.  Make sure your commit comments are self explanatory.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 3.  Discuss the changes you want to make beforehand.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 4.  Please avoid making opinion-based changes if it's just a code-style change - this includes, but not limited to, changes to how we work with promises, class inheritence and etc.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
5.  To keep the process simple with just a few contributors, development happens directly on the master branch
and releases will be deployed on the same branch.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 6.  By creating a Pull Request, you agree to all terms in https://github.com/caprover/caprover/blob/master/contrib.md
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Running dev environment
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
First, you need a Captain instance running in debug mode, this can be a remote server, a VM on your local machine,
or your local machine itself. Needless to say, Docker is required (same minimum version as mentioned in README). Ubuntu is the best dev environment for CapRover.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
Docker for Mac users: You need to add /captain to shared paths.
To do so, click on the Docker icon -> Preferences -> File Sharing and add /captain
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Log in to your machine, clone the git repo and run the following lines:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
$   npm install
$   npm run build
$   ./dev-scripts/dev-clean-run-as-dev.sh
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: You are good to go! You can run the following line to see the logs for the back-end service.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: npm run dev
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: The main differences between the release and debug mode are:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - docker image is created from the local source file, instead of getting pulled from Docker hub
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - security is much weaker is debug due to a static salt
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - self health monitoring is disabled in debug so that we can see possible crashes
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - same origin policy is disabled in debug mode to make front end development easier
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - an additional endpoint is available at /force-exit which force restarts the backend service
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - static resources (including front end app) are not being served in debug build.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Captain by default uses captain.localhost as its root domain. It's not always needed, but if you need a root
domain for your development, you can simply run a local DNS server on your local machine and point
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: *.captain.localhost (wild card domain) to your local IP. A simple hosts change won't be useful as we need a wildcard entry.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
On ubuntu 16, it's as simple of editing this file:
/etc/NetworkManager/dnsmasq.d/dnsmasq-localhost.conf (create if does not exist)
And add this line to it: address=/captain.localhost/192.168.1.2 where 192.168.1.2 is your local IP address.
To make sure you have dnsmasq, you can run which dnsmasq on your terminal, if it's available,
path of it will be printed on the terminal, otherwise, there won't be anything printed on your terminal.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: front end development:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: See https://github.com/caprover/caprover-frontend
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: CLI development:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: See https://github.com/caprover/caprover-cli
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Backend development:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Start the debug build for the backend service as explained above. To see any changes you make,
first save the changes, then you need to restart the service either by sending a request to /force-exit endpoint,
or by running npm run dev.
Label: No categories identified.

Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph:
In the interest of fostering an open and welcoming environment, we as
contributors and maintainers pledge to making participation in our project and
our community a harassment-free experience for everyone, regardless of age, body
size, disability, ethnicity, gender identity and expression, level of experience,
nationality, personal appearance, race, religion, or sexual identity and
orientation.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Our Standards
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph:
Examples of behavior that contributes to creating a positive environment
include:
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: - Using welcoming and inclusive language
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: - Being respectful of differing viewpoints and experiences
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: - Gracefully accepting constructive criticism
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: - Focusing on what is best for the community
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: - Showing empathy towards other community members
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Examples of unacceptable behavior by participants include:
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph:
- The use of sexualized language or imagery and unwelcome sexual attention or
advances
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: - Trolling, insulting/derogatory comments, and personal or political attacks
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: - Public or private harassment
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph:
- Publishing others' private information, such as a physical or electronic
address, without explicit permission
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph:
- Other conduct which could reasonably be considered inappropriate in a
professional setting
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Our Responsibilities
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Project maintainers are responsible for clarifying the standards of acceptable
behavior and are expected to take appropriate and fair corrective action in
response to any instances of unacceptable behavior.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Project maintainers have the right and responsibility to remove, edit, or
reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, and other contributions
that are not aligned to this Code of Conduct, or to ban temporarily or
permanently any contributor for other behaviors that they deem inappropriate,
threatening, offensive, or harmful.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Scope
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
This Code of Conduct applies both within project spaces and in public spaces
when an individual is representing the project or its community. Examples of
representing a project or community include using an official project e-mail
address, posting via an official social media account, or acting as an appointed
representative at an online or offline event. Representation of a project may be
further defined and clarified by project maintainers.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Enforcement
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Instances of abusive, harassing, or otherwise unacceptable behavior may be
reported by contacting the project team. All
complaints will be reviewed and investigated and will result in a response that
is deemed necessary and appropriate to the circumstances. The project team is
obligated to maintain confidentiality with regard to the reporter of an incident.
Further details of specific enforcement policies may be posted separately.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Project maintainers who do not follow or enforce the Code of Conduct in good
faith may face temporary or permanent repercussions as determined by other
members of the project's leadership.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Attribution
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
This Code of Conduct is adapted from the Contributor Covenant, version 1.4,
available at http://contributor-covenant.org/version/1/4
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 1.  Fork this repository to your own GitHub account and then clone it to your local device

Paragraph: 2.  Make sure yarn is globally installed (npm install -g yarn)

Paragraph: 4.  Build and start the application: yarn dev

Paragraph: 6.  Finally, submit a pull request with your changes!

Paragraph: Development
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
###Tools
We use the following tools for development:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Qunit for tests.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - NodeJS required to run grunt.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Grunt for task management.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
###Getting started
Install NodeJS.
Install globally grunt-cli using the following command:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: $ npm install -g grunt-cli
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Browse to the project root directory and install the dev dependencies:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: $ npm install -d
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: To execute the build and tests run the following command in the root of the project:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: $ grunt
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: You should see a green message in the console:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Done, without errors.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
###Tests
You can also run the tests in the browser.
Start a test server from the project root:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: $ grunt connect:tests
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: This will automatically open the test suite at http://127.0.0.1:9998 in the default browser, with livereload enabled.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Note: we recommend cleaning all the browser cookies before running the tests, that can avoid false positive failures.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
###Automatic build
You can build automatically after a file change using the following command:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: $ grunt watch
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Contributing to CarrierWave
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: CarrierWave thrives on a large number of contributors,
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: and pull requests are very welcome. Before submitting a pull request, please make sure that your changes are well tested.

Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: bundle exec rake

Paragraph: You can also run the remote specs by creating a ~/.fog file:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: :carrierwave:
Label: No categories identified.

Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: :aws_secret_access_key: yyy
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: :rackspace_username: xxx
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: :rackspace_api_key: yyy
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: :google_storage_access_key_id: xxx
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: :google_storage_secret_access_key: yyy

Paragraph: You should now be able to run the remote tests:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: REMOTE=true bundle exec rake
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Contribution Guide
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
All contributions (in the form of pull requests, issues and proposals) are always welcomed.
Please see the contributors page for a list of all contributors.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Please check below the standards and practices that this project adheres to.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Etiquette
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: This project is open source, and as such, the maintainers give their free time to build and maintain the source code held within. They make the code freely available in the hope that it will be of use to other developers. It would be extremely unfair for them to suffer abuse or anger for their hard work.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Please be considerate towards maintainers when raising issues or presenting pull requests. Let's show the world that developers are civilized and selfless people.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: It's the duty of the maintainer to ensure that all submissions to the project are of sufficient quality to benefit the project. Many developers have different skillsets, strengths, and weaknesses. Respect the maintainer's decision, and do not be upset or abusive if your submission is not used.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Versioning
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: This package is versioned under the Semantic Versioning guidelines as much as possible.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Releases will be numbered with the following format:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: <major>.<minor>.<patch>
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: And constructed with the following guidelines:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Breaking backward compatibility bumps the major and resets the minor and patch.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - New additions without breaking backward compatibility bumps the minor and resets the patch.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Bug fixes and misc changes bumps the patch.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Coding Standards
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
This package is compliant with the PSR-1, PSR-2 and PSR-4.
If you notice any compliance oversights, please send a patch via pull request.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Issues \ Bugs
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: If you believe you've found a bug on this project, but you're not sure how to fix it, you may create an issue with [Bug] prefixed in the title.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Procedure
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Before filing an issue:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Attempt to replicate the problem, to ensure that it wasn't a coincidental incident.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Check the issues tab to ensure that the bug was not already reported.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Check the pull requests tab to ensure that the bug doesn't have a fix in progress.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Which Branch?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: ALL bug fixes should be made to the branch which they belong to. Bug fixes should never be sent to the master branch unless they fix features that exist only in the upcoming release.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: If a bug is found on a minor version 1.1 and it exists on the major version 1.0, the bug fix should be sent to the 1.0 branch which will be afterwards merged into the 1.1 branch.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Note: Pull requests which do not follow these guidelines will be closed without any further notice.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Proposals
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: If you have a proposal or a feature request, you may create an issue with [Proposal] prefixed in the title.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
The proposal should also describe the new feature, as well as implementation ideas.
The proposal will then be reviewed and either approved or denied. Once a proposal is approved, a pull request may be created implementing the new feature.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: When requesting or submitting new features, first consider whether it might be useful to others. Open source projects are used by many developers, who may have entirely different needs to your own. Think about whether or not your feature is likely to be used by other users of the project.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Procedure
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Before create a feature request:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Check the codebase to ensure that your feature doesn't already exist.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Check the issues tab to ensure that the feature request was not requested already.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Check the pull requests tab to ensure that the feature isn't already in progress.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Contributing to Catch2
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Contents
Using Git(Hub)
Testing your changes
Writing documentation
Writing code
CoC
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
So you want to contribute something to Catch2? That's great! Whether it's
a bug fix, a new feature, support for additional compilers - or just
a fix to the documentation - all contributions are very welcome and very
much appreciated. Of course so are bug reports, other comments, and
questions, but generally it is a better idea to ask questions in our
Discord, than in the issue tracker.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph:
This page covers some guidelines and helpful tips for contributing
to the codebase itself.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Using Git(Hub)
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Ongoing development happens in the master branch for Catch2 v2, and in
dev-v3 for the next major version, v3.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
Commits should be small and atomic. A commit is atomic when, after it is
applied, the codebase, tests and all, still works as expected. Small
commits are also prefered, as they make later operations with git history,
whether it is bisecting, reverting, or something else, easier.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
When submitting a pull request please do not include changes to the
single include. This means do not include them in your git commits!
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
When addressing review comments in a MR, please do not rebase/squash the
commits immediately. Doing so makes it harder to review the new changes,
slowing down the process of merging a MR. Instead, when addressing review
comments, you should append new commits to the branch and only squash
them into other commits when the MR is ready to be merged. We recommend
creating new commits with git commit --fixup (or --squash) and then
later squashing them with git rebase --autosquash to make things easier.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Testing your changes
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Note: Running Catch2's tests requires Python3
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Catch2 has multiple layers of tests that are then run as part of our CI.
The most obvious one are the unit tests compiled into the SelfTest
binary. These are then used in "Approval tests", which run (almost) all
tests from SelfTest through a specific reporter and then compare the
generated output with a known good output ("Baseline"). By default, new
tests should be placed here.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
However, not all tests can be written as plain unit tests. For example,
checking that Catch2 orders tests randomly when asked to, and that this
random ordering is subset-invariant, is better done as an integration
test using an external check script. Catch2 integration tests are written
using CTest, either as a direct command invocation + pass/fail regex,
or by delegating the check to a Python script.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
There are also two more kinds of tests, examples and "ExtraTests".
Examples serve as a compilation test on the single-header distribution,
and present a small and self-contained snippets of using Catch2 for
writing tests. ExtraTests then are tests that either take a long time
to run, or require separate compilation, e.g. because of testing compile
time configuration options, and take a long time because of that.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Both of these are compiled against the single-header distribution of
Catch2, and thus might require you to regenerate it manually. This is
done by calling the generateSingleHeader.py script in scripts.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Examples and ExtraTests are not compiled by default. To compile them,
add -DCATCH_BUILD_EXAMPLES=ON and -DCATCH_BUILD_EXTRA_TESTS=ON to
the invocation of CMake configuration step.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Bringing this all together, the steps below should configure, build,
and run all tests in the Debug compilation.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 1.  Regenerate the single header distribution
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
$ cd Catch2
$ ./scripts/generateSingleHeader.py
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 2.  Configure the full test build
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: $ cmake -Bdebug-build -H. -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Debug -DCATCH_BUILD_EXAMPLES=ON -DCATCH_BUILD_EXTRA_TESTS=ON
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 3.  Run the actual build
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: $ cmake --build debug-build
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 4.  Run the tests using CTest
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
$ cd debug-build
$ ctest -j 4 --output-on-failure -C Debug
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Writing documentation
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
If you have added new feature to Catch2, it needs documentation, so that
other people can use it as well. This section collects some technical
information that you will need for updating Catch2's documentation, and
possibly some generic advise as well.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Technicalities
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: First, the technicalities:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- If you have introduced a new document, there is a simple template you
should use. It provides you with the top anchor mentioned to link to
(more below), and also with a backlink to the top of the documentation:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: # Cool feature
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Text that explains how to use the cool feature.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: [Home](Readme.md#top)
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- Crosslinks to different pages should target the top anchor, like this
[link to contributing](contributing.md#top).
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- We introduced version tags to the documentation, which show users in
which version a specific feature was introduced. This means that newly
written documentation should be tagged with a placeholder, that will
be replaced with the actual version upon release. There are 2 styles
of placeholders used through the documentation, you should pick one that
fits your text better (if in doubt, take a look at the existing version
tags for other features).
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- > [Introduced](link-to-issue-or-PR) in Catch X.Y.Z - this
placeholder is usually used after a section heading
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - > X (Y and Z) was [introduced](link-to-issue-or-PR) in Catch X.Y.Z
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- this placeholder is used when you need to tag a subpart of something,
e.g. a list
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- For pages with more than 4 subheadings, we provide a table of contents
(ToC) at the top of the page. Because GitHub markdown does not support
automatic generation of ToC, it has to be handled semi-manually. Thus,
if you've added a new subheading to some page, you should add it to the
ToC. This can be done either manually, or by running the
updateDocumentToC.py script in the scripts/ folder.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Contents
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Now, for some content tips:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- Usage examples are good. However, having large code snippets inline
can make the documentation less readable, and so the inline snippets
should be kept reasonably short. To provide more complex compilable
examples, consider adding new .cpp file to examples/.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- Don't be afraid to introduce new pages. The current documentation
tends towards long pages, but a lot of that is caused by legacy, and
we know that some of the pages are overly big and unfocused.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- When adding information to an existing page, please try to keep your
formatting, style and changes consistent with the rest of the page.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- Any documentation has multiple different audiences, that desire
different information from the text. The 3 basic user-types to try and
cover are:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - A beginner to Catch2, who requires closer guidance for the usage of Catch2.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Advanced user of Catch2, who want to customize their usage.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Experts, looking for full reference of Catch2's capabilities.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Writing code
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
If want to contribute code, this section contains some simple rules
and tips on things like code formatting, code constructions to avoid,
and so on.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Formatting
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
To make code formatting simpler for the contributors, Catch2 provides
its own config for clang-format. However, because it is currently
impossible to replicate existing Catch2's formatting in clang-format,
using it to reformat a whole file would cause massive diffs. To keep
the size of your diffs reasonable, you should only use clang-format
on the newly changed code.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Code constructs to watch out for
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
This section is a (sadly incomplete) listing of various constructs that
are problematic and are not always caught by our CI infrastructure.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Naked exceptions and exceptions-related function
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
If you are throwing an exception, it should be done via CATCH_ERROR
or CATCH_RUNTIME_ERROR in catch_enforce.h. These macros will handle
the differences between compilation with or without exceptions for you.
However, some platforms (IAR) also have problems with exceptions-related
functions, such as std::current_exceptions. We do not have IAR in our
CI, but luckily there should not be too many reasons to use these.
However, if you do, they should be kept behind a
CATCH_CONFIG_DISABLE_EXCEPTIONS macro.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Unqualified usage of functions from C's stdlib
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
If you are using a function from C's stdlib, please include the header
as <cfoo> and call the function qualified. The common knowledge that
there is no difference is wrong, QNX and VxWorks won't compile if you
include the header as <cfoo> and call the function unqualified.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Community Guidelines
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: This project follows Google's Open Source Community Guidelines.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: CefSharp Project Contribution Guide
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Thanks for your interest in contributing to the project! Please follow these simple guidelines:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: General
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: - Please use Gitter as your first point of call for basic/simple questions.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: - When creating an issue please use the issue template provided.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: - Please read the full contents of the FAQ before submitting an issue. Also searching the GitHub project is a must. It's quite likely your question has already been answered before. If something is unclear in the FAQ, of course feel free to ask; the idea is just to reduce the level of "noise" we have to go through, reading the same questions over and over again.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: - Please make sure to test out the current version of CefSharp to see whether the problem you are encountering still exists.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Don't cross-post: if you create an issue, and all the information is contained there, that's enough. There's no reason to also post it to Stackoverflow; it just creates "line noise". The project maintainers are very busy people like you and me, and things will sometimes take a few weeks (or in worst case, more) to answer. If you are in a rush - do your very best to investigate the problem thoroughly; if possible, fix the bug yourself and submit a pull request.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Before creating a GitHub issue or pull request, try looking through the list & issue archives to make sure the issue at hand hasn't been raised before. Google can also be helpful: just typing "cefsharp appdomain" for example (when trying to see whether AppDomain support has been discussed before) will often give you helpful results.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - We do appreciate cultural/languages differences, that being said never demand that someone help you, this is not a commercial application with paid support! Please and thank you go a long way.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - This is a volunteer project, we give of our time freely and we ask for you to do the same. Contributions can be simple like updating/adding new entries in the FAQ, creating new pages in the WIKI, updating the examples. (Anyone with a GitHub account can edit the WIKI)
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: CefSharp vs Chromium Embedded Framework(CEF)
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
CefSharp simply takes the building blocks provided by CEF and attempts to provide a usable '.Net' implementation.
The upstream CEF forum is a valuable resource, if your issues seems fairly low level, then please conduct some research before posting.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: It maybe helpful to run the cefclient application and compare output with CefSharp. The WinForms and WPF versions use two different rendering modes, WPF uses Offscreen Rendering (OSR). OffScreen also uses OSR mode.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Download one of the following:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - For x86 download http://opensource.spotify.com/cefbuilds/cef_binary_81.3.10%2Bgb223419%2Bchromium-81.0.4044.138_windows32_client.tar.bz2
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - For x64 download http://opensource.spotify.com/cefbuilds/cef_binary_81.3.10%2Bgb223419%2Bchromium-81.0.4044.138_windows64_client.tar.bz2
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Extract and run cefclient.exe
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- If you are using WPF/OffScreen run
cefclient.exe --multi-threaded-message-loop --off-screen-rendering-enabled --enable-gpu --no-sandbox --disable-site-isolation-trials
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- If you are using WinForms run
cefclient.exe --multi-threaded-message-loop --no-sandbox --disable-site-isolation-trials
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - MAKE SURE TO TEST WITH THE COMMAND LINE ARGS LISTED ABOVE
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - If you can reproduce the problem with cefclient then you'll need to report the bug on https://bitbucket.org/chromiumembedded/cef/overview there is no point opening an issue here. (Make sure you search before opening an issue)
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: What should I include when creating an Issue?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: When creating an issue please use the provided by report template (the field will be pre-populated).
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: A bug is a demonstrable problem that is caused by the code in the repository. Ideally each issue is a useful resource for references purposes (Don't take offence if someone edits your description).
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Your bug report should always follow this template:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - What is the expected output? What do you see instead?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - What steps will reproduce the problem?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Are you using WinForms, WPF or OffScreen?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - What version of the product are you using? On what operating system? x86 or x64?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - What version are you using? Nuget? CI Nuget? build from a branch? If so which branch?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Win7, Win 8, Win10, etc?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Please provide any additional information below.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - A stack trace if available, any Exception information.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Does the cef log provide any relevant information? (By default there should be a debug.log file in your bin directory)
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Any other background information that's relevant? Are you doing something out of the ordinary? 3rd party controls?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Does this problem also occur in the CEF Sample Application from http://opensource.spotify.com/cefbuilds/index.html?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Your bug report should include what you were doing in the software when you encountered it, what you were expecting to happen and what happened instead.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: BE AWARE THAT BUG REPORTS MUST PROVIDE ALL OF THE INFORMATION STATED ABOVE!
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Help us help you
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 1.  Asking the same questions over and over again is Wasting our time, search open/closed issues to see if your issue has already been addressed.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 2.  Having to constantly query users to gather information is very frustrating! Use the bug template provided above.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 3.  We have very limited active contributors so please spend as much time looking into your own problem as possible, the more you help yourself, the quicker things will get fixed.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 4.  Please don't hijack issues, if your problem is distinct then please create a unique issue (after searching previous issues).
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 5.  Good bug reports are extremely helpful. The more information you provide, the more likely your issue will be resolved.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
6.  Good bug reports shouldn't leave others needing to chase you up for more information. Be sure to include the
details of your environment.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 7.  'Ask Don't Tell' : Ask how to achieve something, don't say it's broken just because you haven't got it working yet!
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 8.  Isolate the problem — ideally create a reproducible example.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 9.  Include a screencast if relevant - Is your issue about a design or front end feature or bug? The most helpful thing in the world is if we can see what you're talking about. Use LICEcap to quickly and easily record a short screencast (24fps) and save it as an animated gif! Embed it directly into your GitHub issue.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 10. When including code limit to small chunks, large blocks post as a Gist or similar
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 11. Please no links to binaries, e.g. zip files, either contribute your example as a github project, a gist or another public code sharing service.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Change Requests
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Change requests cover both architectural and functional changes to how CefSharp works. If you have an idea for a refactor, or an improvement to a feature, etc - please be sure to:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 1.  Use the GitHub search and check someone else didn't get there first
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 2.  Take a moment to think about the best way to make a case for, and explain what you're thinking as it's up to you to convince the project's leaders the change is worthwhile. Some questions to consider are:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Is it really one idea or is it many?
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - What problem are you solving?
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Why is what you are suggesting better than what's already there?
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Pull Requests/Feature Branches
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Pull requests are awesome. If you're looking to raise a PR for something which doesn't have an open issue, please think carefully about raising an issue which your PR can close, especially if you're fixing a bug. This makes it more likely that there will be enough information available for your PR to be properly tested and merged.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Please limit your changes to a logical grouping, keeping changesets small increases the likelihood they will be merged
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - If you then want to make subsequent changes, it's actually best to not do them before the feature is merged. Please wait for feedback/review before progressing. This greatly improves our ability to review your changes and dramatically increases the likelihood they will be merged in a timely fashion.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - If you wish to keep progressing on your work, please maintain a feature branch independent of the branch referenced by your pull request. From your WIP branch you can selectively merge in changes to the PR branch as required.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - In general, it's much better to be "too granular" with PR's that contain "change-the-world"-kind of changes, which usually tend to lag behind a lot longer before getting merged (if they ever will...).
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Small (really, minimalistic) commits. Each individual commit only adds one specific thing. The basic approach to achieving this is to read your commit message. Do you feel the need to add multiple lines? Then you're doing too much at the same time.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Keep the first line of commit message short (max 50 characters), then a blank line, then a full description if needed. Good example:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Run tests in the default appdomain
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Due to limitations of VC++ we must run our tests in the default appdomain, it's possible to use xunit for testing. Re-add CefSharp.Test.csproj to solution Add some very basic unit tests using xunit, DisableTestParallelization, Set xunit.appDomain to denied in app.config to disable using appdomains (https://xunit.github.io/docs/configuring-with-xml.html) Add xunit vs test running packages, using 2.2.0 version as 2.3.0 was throwing an exception similar to https://github.com/xunit/xunit/issues/1514 TODO: Take a look at https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/tree/master/tests/NuGetGallery.Facts for some ideas on structuring xunit tests (look at implementing Theory)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Coding Style
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Please follow existing coding style when submitting pull requests.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Most importantly, use spaces - do not use tabs (which is the default setting for C++ projects in Visual Studio).
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - The "preview" function when creating a Pull Request on GitHub is very useful for identifying whitespace issues (and for checking out the impact of your changes) - please use it.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Max number of columns are 132, please format your code accordingly
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Please don't add #Regions to the code
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - When adding new files, please prepend the standard license disclaimer (just copy and paste from another source file)
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Do your best to follow these guidelines but don't be afraid to make mistakes when trying to apply them. We are all novices in the beginning.

Paragraph: DEBUGGING

Paragraph: Thanks for helping us squashing bugs! Please be patient.

Paragraph: Important Bug Submission Rules:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 1.  SAFETY FIRST: Remove CID, LAT, IMEI, IMSI and phone number from logs you submit!
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 2.  ALWAYS use the latest release. Preferrably  build the development branch from source.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 3.  If you use Xprivacy read and understand THIS first! Give our app another try after reading.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 4.  App still mocking around? See our open Issues and look if your Issue already exists.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 5.  If your Issue does not exist yet, open a new Issue and give it a short descriptive title.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 6.  Describe your Issue as thoroughly as possible and add logs so that we can reproduce it.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 7.  Maintain your filed Issues! Nothing is more annoying than unresponsive bug reporters.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: In all cases, you MUST include the following:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - AIMSICD version (see the About-Tab within our app)
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Your exact FW specification (ROM, AOS API, etc.)
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Your exact HW specification (processor, model number, etc.)
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - The output of getprop command to a Pastebin-Site such as PIE-Bin
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Logcat from button Debugging in Navigation Drawer (remove personal data)
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Feel free to attach any other logs made by a logcat tool like MatLog
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Command line junkie?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Then you can use the following shell function to help you get only relevant logcat entries. Copy and paste the following to your terminal shell:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: alias logrep='logcat -d -v time -b main -b system -b radio|grep -iE $@'
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Furthermore, here are some great commands that will:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 1.  Create a log directory in: /sdcard/aimsicd_log/
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 2.  cd into that directory
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 3.  Clear all the existing logcats
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 4.  Run AIMSICD and wait for a key press to kill it
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 5.  Save a full logcat (excluding radio) into /sdcard/aimsicd_log/aimdump.log
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Copy and paste the following to your android rooted shell:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
alias cdaim='mkdir /sdcard/aimsicd_log; cd /sdcard/aimsicd_log'
alias logclr='logcat -c -b main -b system -b radio -b events'
alias logdmp='logcat -d -v threadtime -b main -b system -b events -f /sdcard/aimsicd_log/aimdump.log'
export DUMTXT="When bug occurs, press any key to kill app and dump logcat to file..."
alias aimrun='cdaim; logclr; am start -n com.SecUpwN.AIMSICD/.AIMSICD; read dummy?"${DUMTXT}"; am force-stop com.SecUpwN.AIMSICD; logdmp;'
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
To run it, just type: aimrun.
If you want to also supply radio logcat, add -b radio somewhere in the logdmp alias, but know that your GPS location and cell info may be included when you do that.
Label: No categories identified.
