Paragraph: Code of Conduct
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Our Pledge
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
In the interest of fostering an open and welcoming environment, we as
contributors and maintainers pledge to making participation in our project and
our community a harassment-free experience for everyone, regardless of age, body
size, disability, ethnicity, gender identity and expression, level of experience,
nationality, personal appearance, race, religion, or sexual identity and
orientation.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Our Standards
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Examples of behavior that contributes to creating a positive environment
include:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Using welcoming and inclusive language
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Being respectful of differing viewpoints and experiences
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Gracefully accepting constructive criticism
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Focusing on what is best for the community
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Showing empathy towards other community members
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Examples of unacceptable behavior by participants include:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- The use of sexualized language or imagery and unwelcome sexual attention or
advances
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Trolling, insulting/derogatory comments, and personal or political attacks
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Public or private harassment
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- Publishing others' private information, such as a physical or electronic
address, without explicit permission
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- Other conduct which could reasonably be considered inappropriate in a
professional setting
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Our Responsibilities
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Project maintainers are responsible for clarifying the standards of acceptable
behavior and are expected to take appropriate and fair corrective action in
response to any instances of unacceptable behavior.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Project maintainers have the right and responsibility to remove, edit, or
reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, and other contributions
that are not aligned to this Code of Conduct, or to ban temporarily or
permanently any contributor for other behaviors that they deem inappropriate,
threatening, offensive, or harmful.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Scope
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
This Code of Conduct applies both within project spaces and in public spaces
when an individual is representing the project or its community. Examples of
representing a project or community include using an official project e-mail
address, posting via an official social media account, or acting as an appointed
representative at an online or offline event. Representation of a project may be
further defined and clarified by project maintainers.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Enforcement
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Instances of abusive, harassing, or otherwise unacceptable behavior may be
reported by contacting the project maintainer. All
complaints will be reviewed and investigated and will result in a response that
is deemed necessary and appropriate to the circumstances. The project team is
obligated to maintain confidentiality with regard to the reporter of an incident.
Further details of specific enforcement policies may be posted separately.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Project maintainers who do not follow or enforce the Code of Conduct in good
faith may face temporary or permanent repercussions as determined by other
members of the project's leadership.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Attribution
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: This Code of Conduct is adapted from the Contributor Covenant, Version 1.4
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Contribution Guidelines
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: If you are seeking support, or for discussions about Celluloid, you can use the mailing list or the IRC channel, #celluloid on freenode.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: If you encounter an issue with Celluloid itself, you should go through the following checklist:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Is this a known bug or are you falling into a common trap? Check the Gotchas wiki page.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Is there already an issue filed which looks like your issue? Check the issue tracker.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Is the problem present in the latest released version of Celluloid? Upgrade and check!
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Is the problem present on the master branch of Celluloid? Run pre-release from source control and check!
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: If you don't get anywhere with this checklist, please feel free to file a bug report.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Running pre-release Celluloid
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: If you encounter a bug, it's entirely possible that it has already been fixed but not yet included in a released version. You can establish this by trying to run your application with a pre-release version of Celluloid direct from source control. You can do this by modifying your application's Gemfile as follows:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: gem 'celluloid', github: 'celluloid', submodules: true
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: If it is suggested to you that you try a different branch, add branch: 'somebranch'.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: If the problem is resolved, feel free to voice your desire for a new release of Celluloid on IRC (irc.freenode.net/#celluloid).
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: If it persists, you should consider filing a bug report.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Filing a bug report
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Bug reports should be filed on the GitHub issue tracker. Bug reports should contain the following things:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - A sensible subject that helps quickly identify the issue.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Full steps to reproduce the issue, including minimal reproduction code. A minimal reproduction means only what is necessary to display the problem and nothing more. This is perhaps the most important thing, don't skip it!
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Output from a reproduction.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Full references for version numbers (of Celluloid, dependencies, Ruby, Operating System, etc). One easy way to do this is to post your Gemfile.lock, though you will still need to tell us what version of Ruby is in use.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - See: Triage Process
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Some more guidelines on filing good bug reports:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - http://www.chiark.greenend.org.uk/~sgtatham/bugs.html
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - http://itscommonsensestupid.blogspot.com/2008/07/tips-to-write-good-bug-report.html
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - http://timheuer.com/blog/archive/2011/10/12/anatomy-of-a-good-bug-report.aspx
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Contributing to ceph-container
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 1.  Become familiar with the project structure.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 2.  Follow the appropriate contribution workflow
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 3.  Follow the commit guidelines
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Project structure
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
The primary deliverables of this project are two container images: daemon-base, and daemon. As
such, the project structure is influenced by what files and configurations go into each image. The
main source base (including configuration files and build specifications) of the project is located
in src/ and is further specified in src/daemon-base and src/daemon.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
Because this project supports several different Ceph versions and many OS distros, the structure
also allows individual Ceph versions, individual distros, and combinations of
Ceph-version-and-distro (we will call these flavors) to override the base source, configuration,
and specification files by specifying their own versions of the files or new files entirely.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
Mentally modeling the end result of overrides for any given flavor is difficult. Similarly,
programmatically selecting the correct files for each flavor build is also difficult. In order to
effectively work with this project structure, we introduce the concept of staging.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: The concept of staging
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
Special tooling has been built to collect all source files with appropriate overrides into a unique
staging directory for each flavor (each staging directory is also specified by a target
architecture). From a staging directory, containers can be built directly from the
<staging>/daemon-base/ and <staging>/daemon/ image directories. Additionally, developers can
inspect a staging directory's files to view exactly what will be (or has been) built into the
container images. Additionally, in order to maintain a core source base that is as reusable as
possible for all flavors, staging also supports a very basic form of templating. Some tooling has
been developed to make working with staging as easy as possible.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Staging override order
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
It is key that staging is deterministic; therefore, a clear definition of override priority is
needed. More specific files will override (overwrite) less specific files when staging. Note here
that FILE may be a file or a directory containing further files.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
# Most specific
ceph-releases/<ceph release>/<base os repository>/<base os release>/{daemon-base,daemon}/FILE
ceph-releases/<ceph release>/<base os repository>/<base os release>/FILE
ceph-releases/<ceph release>/<base os repository>/{daemon-base,daemon}/FILE
ceph-releases/<ceph release>/<base os repository>/FILE
ceph-releases/<ceph release>/{daemon-base,daemon}/FILE
ceph-releases/<ceph release>/FILE
ceph-releases/ALL/<base os repository>/<base os release>/{daemon-base,daemon}/FILE
ceph-releases/ALL/<base os repository>/<base os release>/FILE
ceph-releases/ALL/<base os repository>/{daemon-base,daemon}/FILE
ceph-releases/ALL/<base os repository>/FILE
ceph-releases/ALL/{daemon-base,daemon}/FILE
ceph-releases/ALL/FILE
src/{daemon-base,daemon}/FILE
src/FILE
# Least specific
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Basic templating in staging
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Variable file replacements
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
In any source file, a special variable in the form __VAR_NAME__ (two leading and trailing
underscores with capital letters, digits, and underscores between) can be placed. Once all files are
staged, the __VAR_NAME__ variable will be replaced with the raw contents of the file with the
named __VAR_NAME__. Trailing whitespace is stripped from the variable file before insertion.
__VAR_NAME__ files are allowed to be empty, but they are not allowed to be nonexistent if a file
declares them. A __VAR_NAME__ definition file may contain nested __OTHER_VAR_NAME__ variables as
well as nested __ENV_[ENV_VAR]__ variables (documented below).
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
If the __DO_STUFF__ file is supposed to contain actions that need done it generally needs to
return true. As an example, echo 'first' && __DO_STUFF__ && echo 'last' will print 'first' and
'last' correctly only if __DO_STUFF__ returns true. A take-no-action override needs to have the
content /bin/true, as an empty file will cause an error.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Environment variable replacements
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
In any source file, a special variable in the form __ENV_[ENV_VAR]__ can placed. Once all files
are staged, the __ENV_[ENV_VAR]__ variable will be replaced with the raw contents of the
environment variable named ENV_VAR. Only environment variables with all-caps, underscores, and
digits are supported. Staging will report an error if an environment variable's value is unset.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Environment variable replacements can also be nested inside of other environment variable
replacements. both __ENV_[]__ definitions and __VAR__ file definitions may specify environment
variable replacements.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
A typical usage is to use __ENV_[HOST_ARCH]__ when you need to specify the building
architecture.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Staging development aids
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: To practically aid developers, helpful tools have been built for staging:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - To create all default staging directories: make stage
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - To create specific staging directory(-ies): make FLAVORS=<flavors> stage
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Find the source of a staged file: cd <staging dir> ; ./find-src <file-path>
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - List of staged files and their sources: <staging dir>/files-sources
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - List of all possible buildable flavors: make show.flavors
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Show flavors affected by branch changes: make flavors.modified
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Stage log: stage.log
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Building images from staging
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
It is possible (but not usually necessary) to build container images directly from staging in the
event that make build is not appealing. Simply stage the flavor(s) to be built, and then execute
the desired build command for daemon-base and daemon.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
# Example
cd <staging>
docker build -t <daemon base tag> daemon-base/
docker build -t <daemon tag> daemon/
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Where does (should) source code live?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Core source base of ceph-container - src/
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
The src/ directory contains the core code that is applicable for all flavors -- all Ceph versions
and all distros -- and is the "least specific" definition of source files for this project. This
includes the ceph-container-specific code that is built into the container images as well as build
configuration files. src/ should be viewed as the base set of functionality all flavors must
implement. To maximize reuse and keep the core source base in one place, care should be taken to try
to make the core source applicable to all flavors whenever possible. Note the existence of the
"CEPH_VERSION" environment variable (and other similar variables) built into the containers.
ceph-container source code can use container environment variables to execute code paths
conditionally, making an override of source files for specific Ceph versions unnecessary.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Where possible src/ provides a specification of a "sane default" that may need to be
overridden for certain flavors. For example, the src/daemon/__DAEMON_PACKAGES__ file defines the
daemon packages which should be installed in the base image. A distro is not required to install
these packages via its package manager or to use this list (though it is recommended to gain as much
reuse as possible), as each distro may have a different preferred method of installation. This list
should, however, serve as a a guide to what must be installed.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Source shared by all Ceph releases - ceph-releases/ALL/
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
The ceph-releases/All/ directory contains code that is generic to all Ceph releases. It is more
specific than src/. Source that is shared between distros (but is not part of ceph-container's
core functionality) can be placed in this directory.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Distro-specific source is placed in ceph-releases/ALL/<distro> and is yet more specific.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Source specific to a single Ceph release - ceph-releases/<ceph release>
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
A ceph-releases/<ceph release> directory is more specific than ceph-releases/ALL and contains
source that is specific to a particular Ceph release but is generic for all distros.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
A ceph-releases/<ceph release>/<distro> directory is the most specific source directory and
contains source that is specific to a particular Ceph-release-and-distro combination.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Contribution workflow
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
The goal when adding contributions should be to make modifications or additions to the least
specific files in order to reuse as much code as possible. Only specify specific changes when they
absolutely apply only to the specific flavor(s) and not to others.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: General suggestions
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Make use of already-defined __VAR__ files when possible to maximize reuse.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- Make changes in the least specific (see override order) directory as
makes sense for the flavor to maximize reuse across flavors.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Fixing a bug
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 1.  Stage the flavor on which the bug was found (make FLAVORS=<bugged flavor> stage).
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 2.  Use the find-src script or files-sources list to locate the bugged file's source location.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 3.  Edit the source location to fix the bug.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 4.  Build test versions of the images (make FLAVORS=<bugged flavor> build).
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 5.  Test the images you built in your environment.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 6.  Make a PR of your changes.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Adding a feature
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 1.  Determine the scope of the feature
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - To which Ceph versions should the feature be added?
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - To which distros should the feature be added?
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - As a general guideline, new features should usually be added to all Ceph versions and distros.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
2.  Add relevant changes to files in the project structure such that they will be added to only the
Ceph versions and distros in scope for the feature.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 3.  Build test versions of the images (make FLAVORS=<in-scope-flavors> build).
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 4.  Test the images in your environment.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 5.  Make a PR of your changes.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Adding a Ceph release
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Ideally, adding a new Ceph release is fairly easy. In the best case, all that needs done is adding
flavors for the new Ceph version to the Makefile. At minimum, ALL_BUILDABLE_FLAVORS must be
updated in the Makefile. If distro source is properly configured to support multiple Ceph releases
and there are no special updates required, they are likely to work with just this minimal change.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Note the $CEPH_VERSION and $CEPH_POINT_RELEASE variables usually used in __DOCKERFILE_INSTALL__
are extracted from the first field of the flavor name.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: In this example, luminous,centos,7, $CEPH_VERSION will be set to luminous.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Adding a new flavor name like mimic,centos,7 is enough to create a new mimic
Ceph release.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: In the worst case, trying to make as few modifications as possible:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 1.  Add flavors for new Ceph versions to the Makefile.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - At minimum: ALL_BUILDABLE_FLAVORS.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
2.  Edit src/ files to support the new version if necessary, making sure not to break previous
versions. Keep container environment variables in mind here.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
3.  Edit ceph-releases/ALL/<distro> files to support the new version if necessary, making sure not
to break previous versions.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 4.  Add ceph-releases/<new ceph version> files to support the new version if necessary.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 5.  Build test versions of the images (make FLAVORS=<new release flavors> build).
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 6.  Test the images in your environment.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 7.  Make a PR of your changes.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Adding a distro build
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 1.  Add flavors for the new distro to the Makefile.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - At minimum: ALL_BUILDABLE_FLAVORS.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 2.  Add a ceph-releases/ALL/<new distro> directory for the new distro
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
- Make sure to install all the required packages for daemon-base (see
src/daemon-base/__CEPH_BASE_PACKAGES__) and for daemon (see
src/daemon/__DAEMON_PACKAGES__).
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Make sure to specify all __VAR__ files without sane defaults for the container builds.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Make sure to override any __VAR__ file sane defaults that do not apply to the new distro.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Refer to other distros for inspiration.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
3.  If necessary, add a ceph-release/<ceph release>/<new distro> directory for the new distro. Try
to avoid this as much as possible and focus on code reuse from the less specific dirs.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 4.  Build test versions of the images (make FLAVORS=<new distro flavors> build).
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 5.  Test the images in your environment.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 6.  Make a PR of your changes.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Commit guidelines
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - All commits should have a subject and a body
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - The commit subject should briefly describe what the commit changes
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - The commit body should describe the problem addressed and the chosen solution
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - What was the problem and solution? Why that solution? Were there alternative ideas?
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Wrap commit subjects and bodies to 72 characters
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Sign-off your commits
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Add a best-effort scope designation to commit subjects. This could be a directory name, file name,
or the name of a logical grouping of code. Examples:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - [dir] ceph-releases: change flavor specification(s) in the ceph-container dir
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - [dir] mimic: change flavor spec for mimic
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - [dir] kubernetes: edit a Kubernetes example in examples/kubernetes
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - [file] osd_disk_activate: edit the src/daemon/osd_scenarios/osd_disk_activate.sh file
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - [logical group] osd prep: change how OSDs are prepared, with changes in multiple files
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - [combinations] mimic osd prep: change how OSDs are prepared only in mimic
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Suggested reading: https://chris.beams.io/posts/git-commit/
Label: SC – Submit the changes

If you don't want to run a build for a particular pull request, because all you are changing is the

Label: No categories identified.

If you're a developer, we have some helpful information in our
Developer's Guide to get you
started. In particular, we recommend you read these sections

Paragraph: Chai Contribution Guidelines
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: We like to encourage you to contribute to the Chai.js repository. This should be as easy as possible for you but there are a few things to consider when contributing. The following guidelines for contribution should be followed if you want to submit a pull request or open an issue.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Following these guidelines helps to communicate that you respect the time of the developers managing and developing this open source project. In return, they should reciprocate that respect in addressing your issue or assessing patches and features.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Creating an Issue or Pull Request requires a GitHub account.

Paragraph: - Issue reports should be clear, concise and reproducible. Check to see if your issue has already been resolved in the master branch or already reported in Chai's GitHub Issue Tracker.
Label: No categories identified.

Label: DC – Deal with the code

The issue tracker is the preferred channel for bug reports,
feature requests and submitting pull
requests, but please respect the following restrictions:

- Please do not use the issue tracker for personal support requests (use
Google Group or IRC).

- Please do not derail or troll issues. Keep the discussion on topic and
respect the opinions of others

Paragraph: Bug Reports
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: A bug is a demonstrable problem that is caused by the code in the repository.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Guidelines for bug reports:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 1.  Use the GitHub issue search — check if the issue has already been reported.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 2.  Check if the issue has been fixed — try to reproduce it using the latest master or development branch in the repository.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 3.  Isolate the problem — create a test case to demonstrate your issue. Provide either a repo, gist, or code sample to demonstrate you problem.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: A good bug report shouldn't leave others needing to chase you up for more information. Please try to be as detailed as possible in your report. What is your environment? What steps will reproduce the issue? What browser(s) and/or Node.js versions experience the problem? What would you expect to be the outcome? All these details will help people to fix any potential bugs.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Example:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Short and descriptive example bug report title
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: A summary of the issue and the browser/OS environment in which it occurs. If suitable, include the steps required to reproduce the bug.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 1.  This is the first step
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 2.  This is the second step
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 3.  Further steps, etc.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: <url> - a link to the reduced test case OR
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
expect(a).to.equal('a');
// code sample
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Any other information you want to share that is relevant to the issue being reported. This might include the lines of code that you have identified as causing the bug, and potential solutions (and your opinions on their merits).
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Feature Requests
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Feature requests are welcome. But take a moment to find out whether your idea fits with the scope and aims of the project. It's up to you to make a strong case to convince the project's developers of the merits of this feature. Please provide as much detail and context as possible.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Furthermore, since Chai.js has a robust plugin API, we encourage you to publish new Assertions as plugins. If your feature is an enhancement to an existing Assertion, please propose your changes as an issue prior to opening a pull request. If the core Chai.js contributors feel your plugin would be better suited as a core assertion, they will invite you to open a PR in chaijs/chai.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Pull Requests
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - PRs for new core-assertions are advised against.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: - PRs for core-assertion bug fixes are always welcome.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: - PRs for enhancing the interfaces are always welcome.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: - PRs that increase test coverage are always welcome.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: - PRs are scrutinized for coding-style.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Good pull requests - patches, improvements, new features - are a fantastic help. They should remain focused in scope and avoid containing unrelated commits.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Please ask first before embarking on any significant pull request (e.g. implementing features, refactoring code), otherwise you risk spending a lot of time working on something that the project's developers might not want to merge into the project.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Please adhere to the coding conventions used throughout a project (indentation, accurate comments, etc.) and any other requirements (such as test coverage). Please review the Chai.js Coding Style Guide.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Follow this process if you'd like your work considered for inclusion in the project:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 1.  Fork the project, clone your fork, and configure the remotes:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
# Clone your fork of the repo into the current directory
git clone https://github.com/<your-username>/<repo-name>
# Navigate to the newly cloned directory
cd <repo-name>
# Assign the original repo to a remote called "upstream"
git remote add upstream https://github.com/<upstream-owner>/<repo-name>
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 2.  If you cloned a while ago, get the latest changes from upstream:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
git checkout <dev-branch>
git pull upstream <dev-branch>
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 3.  Create a new topic branch (off the main project development branch) to contain your feature, change, or fix:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git checkout -b <topic-branch-name>
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 4.  Commit your changes in logical chunks. Use Git's interactive rebase feature to tidy up your commits before making them public.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 5.  Run you code to make sure it works. If you're still having problems please try to run make clean and then test your code again.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
npm test
# when finished running tests...
git checkout chai.js
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 6.  Locally merge (or rebase) the upstream development branch into your topic branch:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git pull [--rebase] upstream <dev-branch>
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 7.  Push your topic branch up to your fork:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git push origin <topic-branch-name>
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 8.  Open a Pull Request with a clear title and description.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: IMPORTANT: By submitting a patch, you agree to allow the project owner to license your work under the same license as that used by the project.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Releasing
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Releases can be prepared by anyone with access to the code.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Simply run make release-major, make release-minor, or make-release-patch
and it will automatically do the following:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Build chai.js
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Bump the version numbers across the project
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Make a commit within git
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: All you need to do is push the commit up and make a pull request, one of the core contributors will merge it and publish a release.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Publishing a Release
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Anyone who is a core contributor (see the Core Contributors Heading in the Readme) can publish a release:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 1.  Go to the Releases page on Github
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 2.  Hit "Draft a new release" (if you can't see this, you're not a core contributor!)
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 3.  Write human-friendly Release Notes based on changelog.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - The release title is "x.x.x / YYYY-MM-DD" (where x.x.x is the version number)
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - If breaking changes, write migration tutorial(s) and reasoning.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Callouts for community contributions (PRs) with links to PR and contributing user.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Callouts for other fixes made by core contributors with links to issue.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 4.  Hit "Save Draft" and get other core contributors to check your work, or alternatively hit "Publish release"
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 5.  That's it!
Label: No categories identified.

without first reading the following notes.

Paragraph: ChaiScript is Too Slow
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
We are actively working on constently improving the runtime performance of ChaiScript. With the performance being
monitored with each commit.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
If you feel you must post an issue about performance, please post a complete example that illustrates the exact case you
feel should be better optimized.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Any issue request regarding performance without a complete example of the issue experienced will be closed.

on the discourse site.

Paragraph: Setup

Paragraph: The following steps will get you setup to contribute changes to this repo:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
1.  Fork the repo (click the Fork button at the top right of
this page)
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 2.  Clone your fork locally
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
# in a terminal, cd to parent directory where you want your clone to be, then
git clone https://github.com/<your_github_username>/chakra-ui.git
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: cd chakra-ui
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
3.  Setup all dependencies and build. Chakra UI uses yarn and lerna, so run
yarn bootstrap. This command will install dependencies, bootstrap the repo
using lerna and build all packages.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
If you run into any issues during this step, kindly reach out to the Chakra UI
React team here: https://discord.gg/dQHfcWF
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Development
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
To improve our development process, we've setup a couple of systems. Chakra UI
uses a monorepo structure, this means each component is it's own package and can
use consumed independently.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Tooling
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- Lerna to manage installation of dependencies and
running various scripts. We also have yarn workspaces enabled by default.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- Storybook for rapid UI component development and
testing
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- Testing Library for testing components and
hooks
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- Gatsby for a blazing fast documentation website.
versioning and changelogs
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Commands
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
yarn boot: bootstraps the entire project, symlinks all dependencies for
cross-component development and builds all components.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
yarn bootstrap: bootstraps the entire project and symlinks all
dependencies for cross-component development
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
yarn storybook: starts storybook server and loads stories in files that
ends with .stories.tsx
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: yarn docs:start: run the documentation site locally
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: yarn build: run build for all component packages
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: yarn test: run test for all component packages
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: yarn release: publish changed packages
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
yarn [package] <cmd>: Run a command on the specific package you're working
on. You can run build, test, lint commands
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Package Aliasing and Yarn Workspace
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
Since we're using lerna monorepo + yarn workspaces by default, this enables us
to run commands within component package directly from the root.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
Each component is named this way @chakra-ui/[component]. Let's say we want to
build the checkbox component. Here's how to do it:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: yarn workspace @chakra-ui/button build
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: # or
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: lerna run build --scope @chakra-ui/button
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
Shortcut: To make this shorter and more convenient, we've added an alias for
each component in the root package.json. Now you can simple do:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
# to build
yarn button build
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
# to test
yarn button test
yarn button test --watch
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
# to lint
yarn button lint
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
This alias is particularly useful when you're working on a specific component
and want to avoid running the command for all components.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Making a Pull Request?
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Pull requests need only the :+1: of two or more collaborators to be merged; when
the PR author is a collaborator, that counts as one.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Commit Convention
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Before you create a Pull Request, please check whether your commits comply with
the commit conventions used in this repository.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
When you create a commit we kindly ask you to follow the convention
category(scope or module): message in your commit message while using one of
the following categories:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- feat / feature: all changes that introduce completely new code or new
features
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- fix: changes that fix a bug (ideally you will addtionally reference an issue
if present)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - refactor: any code related change that is not a fix nor a feature
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- docs: changing existing or creating new documentation (i.e. README, docs for
usage of a lib or cli usage)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- build: all changes regarding the build of the software, changes to
dependencies or the addition of new dependencies
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- test: all changes regarding tests (adding new tests or changing existing
ones)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- ci: all changes regarding the configuration of continous integration (i.e.
github actions, ci system)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- chore: all changes to the repository that do not fit into any of the above
categories
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
If you are interested in the detailed specification you can visit
https://www.conventionalcommits.org/ or check out the
Angular Commit Message Guidelines.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Steps to PR
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Fork of the chakra-ui repository and clone your fork
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Create a new branch out of the develop branch. We follow the convention
[type/scope]. For example fix/accordion-hook, docs/menu-typo
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- type can be either docs, fix, feat, build, or any other
conventional commit type
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - scope is just a short id that describes the scope of work.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Tests
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: All commits that fix bugs or add features need a test.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Dear Chakra team: Please do not merge code without tests
Label: SC – Submit the changes

That would be amazing! Reach out to the core team here:
https://discord.gg/dQHfcWF. We would love to support you anyway we can.

Paragraph: License
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
By contributing your code to the chakra-ui GitHub repository, you agree to
license your contribution under the MIT license.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: In order to contribute please maintain following rules:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - For any new changes use dev_for_new_features this branch.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Make a Pull Request to dev_for_new_features this branch not to master so that master branch can only have stable changes.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Before making any pull request discuss about the change in a New Issue.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Describe the current behavior and explain which behavior you expected to see and why
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Explain why this changes will be useful to most Unifiedtransform users
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - If you have changes on different features seperate them in different commits and pull requests
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Make one feature change at a time
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Share screenshots of your changes. It will make review process faster
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Share the reason behind your changes
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Opening a PR
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Once you open a pull request, ChaosBot will give it X seconds (where X is determined by github_api.voting.get_voting_window) before collecting votes. During this time, you should let people know about your contribution, so that they may vote for it and ensure your hard work gets merged in. If you do not wish for ChaosBot to consider your PR for merging just yet, add "WIP" somewhere in your PR title. Remove it when you're ready for voting.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Changing your PR
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: You may change your PR at any time without losing votes, but keep in mind, any new changes will reset the vote window for additional time.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Merging your PR
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: At the end of the voting window, ChaosBot will review the votes, and if your PR crosses a threshold, your changes will be merged in. To thank you for your merged contribution, ChaosBot will then follow you on GitHub. If your changes are not merged in, take the time to consider the feedback you received, and create a new PR with changes you believe people will be willing to vote for.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: path: "/docs/contributing-guide" title: "Contributing Guide"
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Thank you for taking an interest in contributing to Chatwoot. Before submitting your contribution, please make sure to take a moment and read through the following guidelines:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Code of Conduct
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: - Development Setup
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: - Environment Setup
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Pull Request Guidelines
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - We use git-flow branching model. The base branch is develop.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Comment on an issue before you start work on it. This helps to avoid multiple people working on similar issues.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Please raise the PR against develop branch
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - It's okay and encouraged to have multiple small commits as you work on the PR - we will squash the commits before merging.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - If adding a new feature:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Please create the branch in the format feature/<issue-id>-<issue-name> (eg: feature/235-contact-panel)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Add accompanying test case.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Provide a convincing reason to add this feature. Ideally, you should open a suggestion issue first and have it approved before working on it.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - If fixing bug:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - If you are resolving a special issue, add Bug: Fix xxxx (#xxxx is the issue) in your PR title.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Provide a detailed description of the bug in the PR.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Add appropriate test coverage if applicable.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Contributing
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: HI! Thanks you for your interest in Puppeteer Recorder! We'd love to accept your patches and contributions, but please remember that this project was started first and foremost to serve the users of the Checkly API and Site transaction monitoring service.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: New feature guidelines
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: When authoring new features or extending existing ones, consider the following:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - All new features should be accompanied first with a Github issues describing the feature and its necessity.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - We aim for simplicity. Too many options, buttons, panels etc. detract from that.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Features should serve the general public. Very specific things for your use case are frowned upon.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Getting set up
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 1.  Clone this repository
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
git clone https://github.com/checkly/puppeteer-recorder
cd puppeteer-recorder
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 2.  Install dependencies
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: npm install
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Code reviews
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
All submissions, including submissions by project members, require review. We
use GitHub pull requests for this purpose. Consult
GitHub Help for more
information on using pull requests.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Note: one pull request should cover one, atomic feature and/or bug fix. Do not submit pull requests with a plethora of updates, tweaks, fixes and new features.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Code Style
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Coding style is fully defined in .eslintrc
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Comments should be generally avoided. If the code would not be understood without comments, consider re-writing the code to make it self-explanatory.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: To run code linter, use:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: npm run lint
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Commit Messages
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Commit messages should follow the Semantic Commit Messages format:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: label(namespace): title
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: description
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: footer
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 1.  label is one of the following:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - fix - puppeteer bug fixes.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - feat - puppeteer features.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - docs - changes to docs, e.g. docs(api.md): .. to change documentation.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - test - changes to puppeteer tests infrastructure.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - style - puppeteer code style: spaces/alignment/wrapping etc.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - chore - build-related work, e.g. doclint changes / travis / appveyor.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 2.  namespace is put in parenthesis after label and is optional.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 3.  title is a brief summary of changes.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 4.  description is optional, new-line separated from title and is in present tense.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Example:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: fix(code-generator): fix page.pizza method
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: This patch fixes page.pizza so that it works with iframes.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Fixes #123, Fixes #234
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Adding New Dependencies
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: For all dependencies (both installation and development):
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Do not add a dependency if the desired functionality is easily implementable.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - If adding a dependency, it should be well-maintained and trustworthy.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: A barrier for introducing new installation dependencies is especially high:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Do not add installation dependency unless it's critical to project success.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Writing Tests
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Every feature should be accompanied by a test.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Every public api event/method should be accompanied by a test.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Tests should be hermetic. Tests should not depend on external services.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: We use Jest for testing. Tests are located in the various __test__ folders.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - To run all tests:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: npm run test
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: How to contribute to CRIU
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
CRIU project is (almost) the never-ending story, because we have to always keep up with the
Linux kernel supporting checkpoint and restore for all the features it provides. Thus we're
looking for contributors of all kinds -- feedback, bug reports, testing, coding, writing, etc.
Here are some useful hints to get involved.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - We have both -- very simple and more sophisticated coding tasks;
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: - CRIU does need extensive testing;
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Documentation is always hard, we have some information that is to be extracted from people's heads into wiki pages as well as some texts that all need to be converted into useful articles;
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Feedback is expected on the GitHub issues page and on the mailing list;
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph:
- We accept GitHub pull requests and this is the preferred way to contribute to CRIU. If you prefer to send patches by email, you are welcome to send them to CRIU development mailing list.
Below we describe in more detail recommend practices for CRIU development.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Spread the word about CRIU in social networks;
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - If you're giving a talk about CRIU -- let us know, we'll mention it on the wiki main page;
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Setting up the development environment
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Although criu could be run as non-root (see Security), development is better to be done as root. For example, some tests require root. So, it would be a good idea to set up some recent Linux distro on a virtual machine.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Get the source code
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: The CRIU sources are tracked by Git. Official CRIU repo is at https://github.com/checkpoint-restore/criu.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: The repository may contain multiple branches. Development happens in the criu-dev branch.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: To clone CRIU repo and switch to the proper branch, run:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
git clone https://github.com/checkpoint-restore/criu criu
cd criu
git checkout criu-dev
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Compile
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: First, you need to install compile-time dependencies. Check Installation dependencies for more info.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: To compile CRIU, run:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: make
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: This should create the ./criu/criu executable.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Edit the source code
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: If you use ctags, you can generate the ctags file by running
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: make tags
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: When you change the source code, please keep in mind the following code conventions:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - we prefer tabs and indentations to be 8 characters width
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - CRIU mostly follows Linux kernel coding style, but we are less strict than the kernel community.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
Other conventions can be learned from the source code itself. In short, make sure your new code
looks similar to what is already there.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Test your changes
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: CRIU comes with an extensive test suite. To check whether your changes introduce any regressions, run
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: make test
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: The command runs ZDTM Test Suite. Check for any error messages produced by it.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
In case you'd rather have someone else run the tests, you can use travis-ci for your
own GitHub fork of CRIU. It will check the compilation for various supported platforms,
as well as run most of the tests from the suite. See https://travis-ci.org/checkpoint-restore/criu
for more details.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Describe your changes
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Describe your problem.  Whether your change is a one-line bug fix or
5000 lines of a new feature, there must be an underlying problem that
motivated you to do this work.  Convince the reviewer that there is a
problem worth fixing and that it makes sense for them to read past the
first paragraph.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Once the problem is established, describe what you are actually doing
about it in technical detail. It's important to describe the change
in plain English for the reviewer to verify that the code is behaving
as you intend it to.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Solve only one problem per commit. If your description starts to get
long, that's a sign that you probably need to split up your commit.
See Separate your changes.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Describe your changes in imperative mood, e.g. "make xyzzy do frotz"
instead of "[This commit] makes xyzzy do frotz" or "[I] changed xyzzy
to do frotz", as if you are giving orders to the codebase to change
its behaviour.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
If your change fixes a bug in a specific commit, e.g. you found an issue using
git bisect, please use the Fixes: tag with the abbreviation of
the SHA-1 ID, and the one line summary. For example:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Fixes: 9433b7b9db3e ("make: use cflags/ldflags for config.h detection mechanism")
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
The following git config settings can be used to add a pretty format for
outputting the above style in the git log or git show commands:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
[pretty]
fixes = Fixes: %h (\"%s\")
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: If your change address an issue listed in GitHub, please use Fixes: tag with the number of the issue. For instance:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Fixes: #339
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
You may refer to How to Write a Git Commit
Message article for
recommendations for good commit message.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Separate your changes
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Separate each logical change into a separate commit.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
For example, if your changes include both bug fixes and performance
enhancements for a single driver, separate those changes into two
or more commits.  If your changes include an API update, and a new
driver which uses that new API, separate those into two commits.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
On the other hand, if you make a single change to numerous files,
group those changes into a single commit.  Thus a single logical change
is contained within a single commit.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
The point to remember is that each commit should make an easily understood
change that can be verified by reviewers.  Each commit should be justifiable
on its own merits.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
When dividing your change into a series of commits, take special care to
ensure that CRIU builds and runs properly after each commit in the
series.  Developers using git bisect to track down a problem can end up
splitting your patch series at any point; they will not thank you if you
introduce bugs in the middle.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Sign your work
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
To improve tracking of who did what, we ask you to sign off the commits in
your fork of CRIU or the patches that are to be emailed.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
The sign-off is a simple line at the end of the explanation for the
patch, which certifies that you wrote it or otherwise have the right to
pass it on as an open-source patch.  The rules are pretty simple: if you
can certify the below:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Developer's Certificate of Origin 1.1
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: By making a contribution to this project, I certify that:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
(a) The contribution was created in whole or in part by me and I
have the right to submit it under the open source license
indicated in the file; or
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
(b) The contribution is based upon previous work that, to the best
of my knowledge, is covered under an appropriate open source
license and I have the right under that license to submit that
work with modifications, whether created in whole or in part
by me, under the same open source license (unless I am
permitted to submit under a different license), as indicated
in the file; or
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
(c) The contribution was provided directly to me by some other
person who certified (a), (b) or (c) and I have not modified
it.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
(d) I understand and agree that this project and the contribution
are public and that a record of the contribution (including all
personal information I submit with it, including my sign-off) is
maintained indefinitely and may be redistributed consistent with
this project or the open source license(s) involved.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: then you just add a line saying
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Signed-off-by: Random J Developer <random at developer.example.org>
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
using your real name (please, no pseudonyms or anonymous contributions if
it possible).
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Hint: you can use git commit -s to add Signed-off-by line to your
commit message. To append such line to a commit you already made, use
git commit --amend -s.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
From: Random J Developer <random at developer.example.org>
Subject: [PATCH] Short patch description
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Long patch description (could be skipped if patch
is trivial enough)
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Signed-off-by: Random J Developer <random at developer.example.org>
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
---
Patch body here
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Submit your work upstream
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
We accept GitHub pull requests and this is the preferred way to contribute to CRIU.
For that you should push your work to your fork of CRIU at GitHub and create a pull request
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Pull request guidelines
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Pull request comment should contain description of the problem your changes
solve and a brief outline of the changes included in the pull request.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Please avoid pushing fixup commits to an existent pull request. Each commit
should be self contained and there should not be fixup commits in a patch
series. Pull requests that contain one commit which breaks something
and another commit which fixes it, will be rejected.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Please merge the fixup commits into the commits that has introduced the
problem before creating a pull request.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
It may happen that the reviewers were not completely happy with your
changes and requested changes to your patches. After you updated your
changes please close the old pull request and create a new one that
contains the following:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Description of the problem your changes solve and a brief outline of the
changes
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Link to the previous version of the pull request
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Brief description of the changes between old and new versions of the pull
request. If there were more than one previous pull request, all the
revisions should be listed. For example:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
v3: rebase on the current criu-dev
v2: add commit to foo() and update bar() coding style
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
If there are only minor updates to the commits in a pull request, it is
possible to force-push them into an existing pull request. This only applies
to small changes and should be used with care. If you update an existing
pull request, remember to add the description of the changes from the
previous version.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Mailing list submission
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Historically, CRIU worked with mailing lists and patches so if you still prefer this way continue reading till the end of this section.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Make a patch
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: To create a patch, run
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git format-patch --signoff origin/criu-dev
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
You might need to read GIT documentation on how to prepare patches
for mail submission. Take a look at http://book.git-scm.com/ and/or
http://git-scm.com/documentation for details. It should not be hard
at all.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: We recommend to post patches using git send-email
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git send-email --cover-letter --no-chain-reply-to --annotate \
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: --confirm=always --to=criu@openvz.org criu-dev
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Note that the git send-email subcommand may not be in
the main git package and using it may require installation of a
separate package, for example the "git-email" package in Fedora and
Debian.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
If this is your first time using git send-email, you might need to
configure it to point it to your SMTP server with something like:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git config --global sendemail.smtpServer stmp.example.net
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
If you get tired of typing --to=criu@openvz.org all the time,
you can configure that to be automatically handled as well:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git config sendemail.to criu@openvz.org
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
If a developer is sending another version of the patch (e.g. to address
review comments), they are advised to note differences to previous versions
after the --- line in the patch so that it helps reviewers but
doesn't become part of git history. Moreover, such patch needs to be prefixed
correctly with --subject-prefix=PATCHv2 appended to
git send-email (substitute v2 with the correct
version if needed though).
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Mail patches
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: The patches should be sent to CRIU development mailing list, criu AT openvz.org. Note that you need to be subscribed first in order to post. The list web interface is available at https://openvz.org/mailman/listinfo/criu; you can also use standard mailman aliases to work with it.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Please make sure the email client you're using doesn't screw your patch (line wrapping and so on).
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Note: When sending a patch set that consists of more than one patch, please, push your changes in your local repo and provide the URL of the branch in the cover-letter
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Wait for response
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Be patient. Most CRIU developers are pretty busy people so if
there is no immediate response on your patch
sometimes a patch may fly around a week before it gets reviewed.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Continuous integration
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Wiki article: Continuous integration
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: CRIU tests are run for each series sent to the mailing list. If you get a message from our patchwork that patches failed to pass the tests, you have to investigate what is wrong.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: We also recommend you to enable Travis CI for your repo to check patches in your git branch, before sending them to the mailing list.
Label: SC – Submit the changes
