Paragraph: Contributing to Cheerio
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Thanks for your interest in contributing to the project! Here's a rundown of
how we'd like to work with you:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
1.  File an issue on GitHub describing the contribution you'd like to make. This
will help us to get you started on the right foot.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 2.  Create a single commit that addresses the issue:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 1.  Follow the project's code style (see below)
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 2.  Add enough unit tests to "prove" that your patch is correct
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 3.  Update the project documentation as needed (see below)
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
4.  Describe your approach with as much detail as necessary in the git
commit message
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
3.  Open a pull request, and reference the initial issue in the pull request
message.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Documentation
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Any API change should be reflected in the project's README.md file. Reuse
jQuery's documentation wherever possible, but take
care to note aspects that make Cheerio distinct.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Code Style
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Please make sure commit hooks are run, which will enforce the code style.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: When implementing private functionality that isn't part of the jQuery API, please opt for:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- Static methods: If the functionality does not require a reference to a
Cheerio instance, simply define a named function within the module it is
needed.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- Instance methods: If the functionality requires a reference to a Cheerio
instance, informally define the method as "private" using the following
conventions:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Define the method as a function on the Cheerio prototype
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Prefix the method name with an underscore (_) character
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Include @api private in the code comment the documents the method
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Contributing to Chef Projects
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: We're glad you want to contribute to a Chef project! This document will help answer common questions you may have during your first contribution.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Submitting Issues
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Not every contribution comes in the form of code. Submitting, confirming, and triaging issues is an important task for any project. At Chef we use GitHub to track all project issues.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: If you are familiar with Chef and know the component that is causing you a problem, you can file an issue in the corresponding GitHub project. All of our Open Source Software can be found in our Chef GitHub organization. All projects include GitHub issue templates to help gather information needed for a thorough review.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: We ask you not to submit security concerns via GitHub. For details on submitting potential security issues please see https://www.chef.io/security/
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: In addition to GitHub issues, we also utilize a feedback site that helps our product team track and rank feature requests. If you have a feature request, this is an excellent place to start https://www.chef.io/feedback/
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Contribution Process
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: We have a 3 step process for contributions:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 1.  Commit changes to a git branch, making sure to sign-off those changes for the Developer Certificate of Origin.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 2.  Create a GitHub Pull Request for your change, following the instructions in the pull request template.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 3.  Perform a Code Review with the project maintainers on the pull request.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Pull Request Requirements
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Chef Projects are built to last. We strive to ensure high quality throughout the experience. In order to ensure this, we require that all pull requests to Chef projects meet these specifications:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 1.  Tests: To ensure high quality code and protect against future regressions, we require all the code in Chef Projects to have at least unit test coverage. We use RSpec for unit testing.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 2.  Green CI Tests: We use Buildkite to test all pull requests. We require these test runs to succeed on every pull request before being merged.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Code Review Process
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Code review takes place in GitHub pull requests. See this article if you're not familiar with GitHub Pull Requests.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Once you open a pull request, project maintainers will review your code and respond to your pull request with any feedback they might have. The process at this point is as follows:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 1.  Two or more members of the owners, approvers, or reviewers groups must approve your PR. See the Chef Infra OSS Project for a list of all members.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 2.  Your change will be merged into the project's master branch
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 3.  Our Expeditor bot will automatically increment the version and update the project's changelog with your contribution. For projects that ship as a package, Expeditor will kick off a build which will publish the package to the project's current channel.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: If you would like to learn about when your code will be available in a release of Chef, read more about Chef Release Cycles.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Developer Certification of Origin (DCO)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Licensing is very important to open source projects. It helps ensure the software continues to be available under the terms that the author desired.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Chef uses the Apache 2.0 license to strike a balance between open contribution and allowing you to use the software however you would like to.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: The license tells you what rights you have that are provided by the copyright holder. It is important that the contributor fully understands what rights they are licensing and agrees to them. Sometimes the copyright holder isn't the contributor, such as when the contributor is doing work on behalf of a company.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: To make a good faith effort to ensure these criteria are met, Chef requires the Developer Certificate of Origin (DCO) process to be followed.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: The DCO is an attestation attached to every contribution made by every developer. In the commit message of the contribution, the developer simply adds a Signed-off-by statement and thereby agrees to the DCO, which you can find below or at http://developercertificate.org/.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Developer's Certificate of Origin 1.1
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: By making a contribution to this project, I certify that:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
(a) The contribution was created in whole or in part by me and I
have the right to submit it under the open source license
indicated in the file; or
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
(b) The contribution is based upon previous work that, to the
best of my knowledge, is covered under an appropriate open
source license and I have the right under that license to
submit that work with modifications, whether created in whole
or in part by me, under the same open source license (unless
I am permitted to submit under a different license), as
Indicated in the file; or
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
(c) The contribution was provided directly to me by some other
person who certified (a), (b) or (c) and I have not modified
it.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
(d) I understand and agree that this project and the contribution
are public and that a record of the contribution (including
all personal information I submit with it, including my
sign-off) is maintained indefinitely and may be redistributed
consistent with this project or the open source license(s)
involved.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: For more information on the change see the Chef Blog post Introducing Developer Certificate of Origin
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: DCO Sign-Off Methods
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: The DCO requires a sign-off message in the following format appear on each commit in the pull request:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Signed-off-by: Julia Child <juliachild@chef.io>
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: The DCO text can either be manually added to your commit body, or you can add either -s or --signoff to your usual git commit commands. If you are using the GitHub UI to make a change you can add the sign-off message directly to the commit message when creating the pull request. If you forget to add the sign-off you can also amend a previous commit with the sign-off by running git commit --amend -s. If you've pushed your changes to GitHub already you'll need to force push your branch after this with git push -f.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Chef Obvious Fix Policy
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Small contributions, such as fixing spelling errors, where the content is small enough to not be considered intellectual property, can be submitted without signing the contribution for the DCO.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: As a rule of thumb, changes are obvious fixes if they do not introduce any new functionality or creative thinking. Assuming the change does not affect functionality, some common obvious fix examples include the following:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Spelling / grammar fixes
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Typo correction, white space and formatting changes
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Comment clean up
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Bug fixes that change default return values or error codes stored in constants
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Adding logging messages or debugging output
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Changes to 'metadata' files like Gemfile, .gitignore, build scripts, etc.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Moving source files from one directory or package to another
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Whenever you invoke the "obvious fix" rule, please say so in your commit message:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Fix typo in the README.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Obvious fix.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Release Cycles
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Our primary shipping vehicle is operating system specific packages that includes all the requirements of Chef. The packages are built with our Omnibus packing project.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: We also release our software as gems to Rubygems but we strongly recommend using Chef packages since they are the only combination of native libraries & gems required by Chef that we test thoroughly.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Our version numbering roughly follows Semantic Versioning standard. Our standard version numbers look like X.Y.Z which mean:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - X is a major release, which may not be fully compatible with prior major releases
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Y is a minor release, which adds both new features and bug fixes
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Z is a patch release, which adds just bug fixes
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: After shipping a release of Chef we bump the Minor version by one to start development of the next minor release. All merges to master trigger an increment of the Patch version, and a build through our internal testing pipeline. We do a Minor release approximately every month, which consist of shipping one of the already auto-incremented and tested Patch versions. For example after shipping 12.10.24, we incremented Chef to 12.11.0. From there 18 commits where merged bringing the version to 12.11.18, which we shipped as an omnibus package.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Announcements of releases are made to the chef mailing list when they are available and are mirrored to the #announcements channel on the Chef Community Slack.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Chef Community
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Chef is made possible by a strong community of developers and system administrators. If you have any questions or if you would like to get involved in the Chef community you can check out:
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: - Chef Community Slack

Paragraph: Contributing to ChefSpec
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Pull requests are merged via Github, you can find the documentation about how to fork a repository and start contributing to ChefSpec here https://help.github.com/articles/fork-a-repo.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: All contributions are welcome to be submitted for review for inclusion, but before they will be accepted, we ask that you follow these simple steps:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Coding standards
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Testing
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Documentation
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Also, please be patient as not all items will be tested or reviewed immediately by the core team.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Please be receptive and responsive to feedback about your additions or changes. The core team and/or other community members may make suggestions or ask questions about your change. This is part of the review process, and helps everyone to understand what is happening, why it is happening, and potentially optimizes your code.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: If you're looking to contribute but aren't sure where to start, check out the open issues.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: Will Not Merge
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: This section details, specifically, Pull Requests or features that will not be merged:
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: 1.  Matchers for non-Chef core resources. ChefSpec 3.0 introduced a way for cookbook maintainers to package matchers with their cookbooks at distribution time.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: 2.  New features without accompanying unit tests, cucumber tests, and documentation.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: Coding Standards
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: The submitted code should be compatible with the standard Ruby coding guidelines. Here are some additional resources:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Ruby Style Guide
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Github Styleguide
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: There is a tool called Cane that allows you to validate your code's ABC complexity and documentation.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Testing
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Whether your pull request is a bug fix or introduces new classes or methods to the project, we kindly ask that you include tests for your changes. Even if it's just a small improvement, a test is necessary to ensure the bug is never re-introduced.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: We understand that not all users submitting pull requests will be proficient with RSpec. The maintainers and community as a whole are a helpful group and can help you with writing tests. The Better Specs site should provide some helpful resources to get you started.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: ChefSpec is tested on Travis CI against multiple Chef Versions and Ruby Versions. Your patches must work for all Chef and Ruby Versions on Travis. This is in an effort to maintain backward compatibility as long as possible. For more information on which Chef and Ruby versions to support, checkout the .travis.yml file.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Documentation
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Documentation is a crucial part to ChefSpec, especially given its broad depth of features. All documentation is placed inline on the method matcher so it can be generated with Yard. Please see existing matchers for an example and check out the Yard documentation
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: When contributing new features, please ensure adequate documentation and examples are present.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: This contributing guide is based off of the Joomla Contributing Guide.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Contribution Guide
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: If you want to contribute to a Cherow repo, please use a GitHub pull request. This is the fastest way for us to evaluate your code and to merge it into the code base. Please don't file an issue with snippets of code. Doing so means that we need to manually merge the changes in and update any appropriate tests. That decreases the likelihood that your code is going to get included timely. Please use pull requests.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Please do not create a pull request without reading this guide first. Failure to do so may result in the rejection of the pull request.
And also keep in mind that performance is the main priority. The "fastest" way to solve an issue, isn't the fastest one, but the slowest one!
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Set up a development environment
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: If you'd like to work on a pull request and you've never submitted code before, follow these steps:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Step 1: Install Node.js
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Go to https://nodejs.org/ to download and install the latest stable version for your operating system.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Most of the installers come with npm already installed, but if for some reason it doesn't work on your system, you can install it manually using the instructions on the site.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Step 2: Install yarn & lerna
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: npm i yarn lerna -g
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Step 3: Fork and checkout your own Cherow repository
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Go to https://github.com/cherow/cherow and click the "Fork" button. Follow the GitHub documentation for forking and cloning.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Once you've cloned the repository, run yarn install to get all the necessary dependencies:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
$ cd cherow
$ yarn install
$ lerna bootstrap
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: You must be connected to the Internet for this step to work. You'll see a lot of utilities being downloaded.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Step 4: Add the upstream source
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: The upstream source is the main Cherow repository that active development happens on. While you won't have push access to upstream, you will have pull access, allowing you to pull in the latest code whenever you want.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: To add the upstream source for Cherow, run the following in your repository:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: git remote add upstream git@github.com:cherow/cherow.git
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Now, the remote upstream points to the upstream source.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Step 5: Run the tests
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Running the tests is the best way to ensure you have correctly set up your development environment. Make sure you're in the cherow directory and run:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: $ lerna run test
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: The testing takes a few minutes to complete. If some tests fail, that likely means one or more parts of the environment setup didn't complete correctly. The upstream tests always pass.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: After that, you're ready to start working on code.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Working with Code
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: The process of submitting a pull request is fairly straightforward and generally follows the same pattern each time:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 1.  Create a new branch
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 2.  Make your changes
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 3.  Rebase onto upstream
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 4.  Run the tests
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 5.  Double check your submission
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 6.  Push your changes
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 7.  Submit the pull request
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Details about each step are found below.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Step 1: Create a new branch
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: The first step to sending a pull request is to create a new branch in your Cherow fork. Give the branch a descriptive name that briefly explains what you are trying to fix, for example:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: $ git checkout -b issue1234
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: You should do all of your development for the issue in this branch.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Note: Do not combine fixes for multiple issues into one branch. Use a separate branch for each issue you're working on.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Step 2: Make your changes
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Make the changes to the code and tests, following the code conventions as you go. Once you have finished, commit the changes to your branch:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
$ git add -A
$ git commit
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Our commit message follows Conventional Commits, format is as follows:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: <type>[optional scope]: <description>
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: [optional body]
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: [optional footer]
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: The commit message format is important because these messages are used to create a changelog for each release. The tag and issue number help to create more consistent and useful changelogs.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Step 3: Rebase onto upstream
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Before you send the pull request, be sure to rebase onto the upstream source. This ensures your code is running on the latest available code.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
git fetch upstream
git rebase upstream/master
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Step 4: Run the tests
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: After rebasing, be sure to run all of the tests once again to make sure nothing broke:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: $ lerna run test
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: If any of the tests fail, update your code until all tests pass.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Step 5: Double check your submission
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: With your code ready to go, this is a good time to double-check your submission to make sure it follows our conventions. Here are the things to check:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Make sure your commit is formatted correctly.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - The pull request must have a description. The description should explain what you did and how its effects can be seen.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - The commit message is properly formatted.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - The change introduces no functional regression. Be sure to run lerna run test to verify your changes before submitting a pull request.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Make separate pull requests for unrelated changes. Large pull requests with multiple unrelated changes may be closed without merging.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - All changes must be accompanied by tests, even if the feature you're working on previously had no tests.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - All user-facing changes must be accompanied by appropriate documentation.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Step 6: Push your changes
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Next, push your changes to your clone:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git push origin issue1234
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: If you are unable to push because some references are old, do a forced push instead:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git push -f origin issue1234
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Step 7: Send the pull request
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Now you're ready to send the pull request. Go to your Cherow fork and then follow the GitHub documentation on how to send a pull request.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Following Up
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Once your pull request is sent, it's time for the team to review it. As such, please make sure to:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 1.  Monitor the status of the Travis CI build for your pull request. If it fails, please investigate why. We cannot merge pull requests that fail Travis for any reason.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 2.  Respond to comments left on the pull request from team members. Remember, we want to help you land your code, so please be receptive to our feedback.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 3.  We may ask you to make changes, rebase, or squash your commits.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Updating the Commit Message
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: If your commit message is in the incorrect format, you'll be asked to update it. You can do so via:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: $ git commit --amend
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: This will open up your editor so you can make changes. After that, you'll need to do a forced push to your branch:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: $ git push origin issue1234 -f
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Updating the Code
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: If we ask you to make code changes, there's no need to close the pull request and create a new one. Just go back to the branch on your fork and make your changes. Then, when you're ready, you can add your changes into the branch:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
$ git add -A
$ git commit
$ git push origin issue1234
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: When updating the code, it's usually better to add additional commits to your branch rather than amending the original commit, because reviewers can easily tell which changes were made in response to a particular review. When we merge pull requests, we will squash all the commits from your branch into a single commit on the master branch.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Rebasing
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: If your code is out-of-date, we might ask you to rebase. That means we want you to apply your changes on top of the latest upstream code. Make sure you have set up a development environment and then you can rebase using these commands:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
$ git fetch upstream
$ git rebase upstream/master
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: You might find that there are merge conflicts when you attempt to rebase. Please resolve the conflicts and then do a forced push to your branch:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: $ git push origin issue1234 -f
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Submitting a PR
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Excellent! You've chosen to help advance the project by either fixing a bug, or implementing a new feature.  Before you put forth any work on a PR, please follow these steps:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 1.  Ensure a similar PR has not already been opened or closed.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 2.  Clearly define the intent of the PR.  The more detail, the more likelihood of it getting merged.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 3.  Is this a feature that would benefit the majority of users?  This is a small library, and it intends to stay that way.  If you do not believe most users of the project will benefit from your work, it should probably be added in your own application.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 4.  Be sure to include test cases that cover all newly introduced code.  This part is essential, as any PRs without tests will be closed.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 5.  Link any issues that are addressed by the PR.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Submitting a bug report
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: If you believe you've found a bug in the source code, and are unable to fix it yourself (by submitting a PR) please follow these steps:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 1.  Ensure the bug has not already been reported by searching the issues
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 2.  Submit a reduced test case that clearly demonstrates the bug. This means submitting a plunker or jsfiddle with the bare minimum of code necessary to reproduce the bug. Without this, your issue may be closed as invalid.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 3.  Include any relevant browser information
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 4.  If you're unable to fix this bug yourself, but can point to why it is occuring, please send that information along (line# or commit)
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Translate
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: You can help us to translate the PeerTube interface to many languages! See the documentation to know how.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Give your feedback
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
You don't need to know how to code to start contributing to PeerTube! Other
contributions are very valuable too, among which: you can test the software and
report bugs, you can give feedback on potential bugs, features that you are
interested in, user interface, design, decentralized architecture...
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Write documentation
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
You can help to write the documentation of the REST API, code, architecture,
demonstrations.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
For the REST API you can see the documentation in /support/doc/api directory.
Then, you can just open the openapi.yaml file in a special editor like http://editor.swagger.io/ to easily see and edit the documentation. You can also use redoc-cli and run redoc-cli serve --watch support/doc/api/openapi.yaml to see the final result.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Some hints:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Routes are defined in /server/controllers/ directory
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Parameters validators are defined in /server/middlewares/validators directory
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Models sent/received by the controllers are defined in /shared/models directory
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Improve the website
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: PeerTube's website is joinpeertube.org, where people can learn about the project and how it works
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: You can help us improve it too!
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: It is not hosted on GitHub but on Framasoft's own GitLab instance, FramaGit: https://framagit.org/framasoft/peertube/joinpeertube
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Develop
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Don't hesitate to talk about features you want to develop by creating/commenting an issue
before you start working on them :).
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Prerequisites
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: First, you should use a server or PC with at least 4GB of RAM. Less RAM may lead to crashes.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
Make sure that you have followed
the steps
to install the dependencies.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
Fork the github repository,
and then clone the sources and install node modules:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
$ git clone https://github.com/Chocobozzz/PeerTube
$ git remote add me git@github.com:YOUR_GITHUB_USERNAME/PeerTube.git
$ cd PeerTube
$ yarn install --pure-lockfile
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
Note that development is done on the develop branch. If you want to hack on
Peertube, you should switch to that branch. Also note that you have to repeat
the yarn install --pure-lockfile command.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
When you create a new branch you should also tell to use your repo for upload
not default one. To do just do:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: $ git push --set-upstream me <your branch name>
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
Then, create a postgres database and user with the values set in the
config/default.yaml file. For instance, if you do not change the values
there, the following commands would create a new database called peertube_dev
and a postgres user called peertube with password peertube:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
# sudo -u postgres createuser -P peertube
Enter password for new role: peertube
# sudo -u postgres createdb -O peertube peertube_dev
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Then enable extensions PeerTube needs:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
$ sudo -u postgres psql -c "CREATE EXTENSION pg_trgm;" peertube_dev
$ sudo -u postgres psql -c "CREATE EXTENSION unaccent;" peertube_dev
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: In dev mode, administrator username is root and password is test.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Online development
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: You can get a complete PeerTube development setup with Gitpod, a free one-click online IDE for GitHub:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Open in Gitpod
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Server side
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: You can find a documentation of the server code/architecture here.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: To develop on the server-side:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: $ npm run dev:server
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
Then, the server will listen on localhost:9000. When server source files
change, these are automatically recompiled and the server will automatically
restart.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Client side
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
You can find a documentation of the client code/architecture
here.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: To develop on the client side:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: $ npm run dev:client
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
The API will listen on localhost:9000 and the frontend on localhost:3000.
Client files are automatically compiled on change, and the web browser will
reload them automatically thanks to hot module replacement.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Client and server side
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
The API will listen on localhost:9000 and the frontend on localhost:3000.
File changes are automatically recompiled, injected in the web browser (no need to refresh manually)
and the web server is automatically restarted.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: $ npm run dev
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Testing the federation of PeerTube servers
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Create a PostgreSQL user with the same name as your username in order to avoid using the postgres user.
Then, we can create the databases (if they don't already exist):
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
$ sudo -u postgres createuser you_username --createdb
$ createdb -O peertube peertube_test{1,2,3}
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Build the application and flush the old tests data:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
$ npm run build -- --light
$ npm run clean:server:test
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: This will run 3 nodes:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: $ npm run play
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Then you will get access to the three nodes at http://localhost:900{1,2,3}
with the root as username and test{1,2,3} for the password.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Instance configurations are in config/test-{1,2,3}.yaml.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Unit tests
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Create a PostgreSQL user with the same name as your username in order to avoid using the postgres user.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Then, we can create the databases (if they don't already exist):
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
$ sudo -u postgres createuser you_username --createdb --superuser
$ npm run clean:server:test
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Build the application and run the unit/integration tests:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
$ npm run build -- --light
$ npm test
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: If you just want to run 1 test:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: $ npm run mocha -- --exit -r ts-node/register -r tsconfig-paths/register --bail server/tests/api/index.ts
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Instance configurations are in config/test-{1,2,3,4,5,6}.yaml.
Note that only instance 2 has transcoding enabled.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Are You In the Right Place?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Chocolatey is a large ecosystem and each component has their own location for submitting issues and enhancement requests. While the website (the community package repository) may be all you know for packages, it represents only a tiny fraction of existing packages (organizations typically maintain and host their own packages internally). This is the repository for choco.exe (the client CLI tool) for Chocolatey, which spans multiple types of environments.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Please follow these decision criteria to see if you are in the right location or if you should head to a different location to submit your request.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Reporting an Issue/Bug?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: submitting issues
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Submitting an Issue (or a Bug)? See the Submitting Issues section in the README.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: SolutionVersion.cs
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Do not submit issues for missing SolutionVersion.cs. Please see Compiling / Building Source.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Package Issue?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Please see Request Package Fixes or Updates / Become a maintainer of an existing package.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Package Request? Package Missing?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: If you are looking for packages to be added to the community feed (aka https://chocolatey.org/packages), please see Package Requests.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Submitting an Enhancement / Feature Request?
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: If this is for choco (the CLI tool), this is the right place. See below. Otherwise see Submitting Issues for enhancements to the website, enhancements to the ChocolateyGUI, etc.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Submitting an Enhancement For Choco
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Log a github issue. There are fewer constraints on this versus reporting issues.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Contributing
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: The process for contributions is roughly as follows:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Prerequisites
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Submit the Enhancement ticket. You will need the issue id for your commits.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Ensure you have signed the Contributor License Agreement (CLA) - without this we are not able to take contributions that are not trivial.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Sign the Contributor License Agreement.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - You must do this for each Chocolatey project that requires it.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - If you are curious why we would require a CLA, we agree with Julien Ponge - take a look at his post.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - You agree to follow the etiquette regarding communication.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Definition of Trivial Contributions
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: It's hard to define what is a trivial contribution. Sometimes even a 1 character change can be considered significant. Unfortunately because it can be subjective, the decision on what is trivial comes from the committers of the project and not from folks contributing to the project. It is generally safe to assume that you may be subject to signing the CLA and be prepared to do so. Ask in advance if you are not sure and for reasons are not able to sign the CLA.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: What is generally considered trivial:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Fixing a typo
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Documentation changes
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Fixes to non-production code - like fixing something small in the build code.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: What is generally not considered trivial:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Changes to any code that would be delivered as part of the final product. This includes any scripts that are delivered, such as PowerShell scripts. Yes, even 1 character changes could be considered non-trivial.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Is the CLA Really Required?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Yes, and this aspect is not up for discussion. If you would like more resources on understanding CLAs, please see the following articles:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - In defense of Contributor License Agreements
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Contributor License Agreements
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Dissenting opinion - Why your project doesn't need a Contributor License Agreement
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Overall, the flexibility and legal protections provided by a CLA make it necessary to require a CLA. As there is a company and a licensed version behind Chocolatey, those protections must be afforded. We understand this means some folks won't be able to contribute and that's completely fine. We prefer you to know up front this is required so you can make the best decision about contributing.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: If you work for an organization that does not allow you to contribute without attempting to own the rights to your work, please do not sign the CLA.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Contributing Process
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Start with Prerequisites and make sure you can sign the Contributor License Agreement (CLA).
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Get Buyoff Or Find Open Community Issues/Features
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Through a Github issue (preferred), through the mailing list, or through Gitter, talk about a feature you would like to see (or a bug fix), and why it should be in Chocolatey.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - If approved through the mailing list or in Gitter chat, ensure the accompanying GitHub issue is created with information and a link back to the mailing list discussion (or the Gitter conversation).
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Once you get a nod from one of the Chocolatey Team, you can start on the feature.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Alternatively, if a feature is on the issues list with the Up For Grabs label, it is open for a community member (contributor) to patch. You should comment that you are signing up for it on the issue so someone else doesn't also sign up for the work.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: Set Up Your Environment
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: - Visual Studio 2010+ is recommended for code contributions.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: - For git specific information:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 1.  Create a fork of chocolatey/choco under your GitHub account. See forks for more information.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 2.  Clone your fork locally.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 3.  Open a command line and navigate to that directory.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 4.  Add the upstream fork - git remote add upstream git@github.com:chocolatey/choco.git
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 5.  Run git fetch upstream
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 6.  Ensure you have user name and email set appropriately to attribute your contributions - see Name / Email.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 7.  Ensure that the local repository has the following settings (without --global, these only apply to the current repository):
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: - git config core.autocrlf false
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: - git config core.symlinks false
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: - git config merge.ff false
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: - git config merge.log true
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: - git config fetch.prune true
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 1.  From there you create a branch named specific to the feature.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 2.  In the branch you do work specific to the feature.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 3.  For committing the code, please see Prepare Commits.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 4.  See Submit Pull Request (PR).
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Please also observe the following:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Unless specifically requested, do not reformat the code. It makes it very difficult to see the change you've made.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Do not change files that are not specific to the feature.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - More covered below in the Prepare commits section.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Test your changes and please help us out by updating and implementing some automated tests. It is recommended that all contributors spend some time looking over the tests in the source code. You can't go wrong emulating one of the existing tests and then changing it specific to the behavior you are testing.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - While not an absolute requirement, automated tests will help reviewers feel comfortable about your changes, which gets your contributions accepted faster.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Please do not update your branch from the master unless we ask you to. See the responding to feedback section below.

Paragraph: Code Format / Design
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: CSharp
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - If you are using ReSharper, all of this is already in the shared resharper settings.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Class names and Properties are PascalCase - this is nearly the only time you start with uppercase.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Namespaces (and their representative folders) are lowercase.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Methods and functions are lowercase. Breaks between words in functions are typically met with an underscore (_, e.g. run_actual()).
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Variables and parameters are camelCase.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Constants are UPPER_CASE.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - There are some adapters over the .NET Framework to ensure some additional functionality works and is consistent. Sometimes this is completely seamless that you are using these (e.g. Console).
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: PowerShell
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - PowerShell must be CRLF and UTF-8. Git attributes are not used, so Git will not ensure this for you.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - The minimum version of PowerShell this must work with is v2. This makes things somewhat more limited but compatible across the board for all areas Chocolatey is deployed. It is getting harder to find a reference for PowerShell v2, but this is a good one: http://adamringenberg.com/powershell2/table-of-contents/.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - If you add a new file, also ensure you add it to the Visual Studio project and ensure it becomes an embedded resource.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - The last parameter in every function must be [parameter(ValueFromRemainingArguments = $true)][Object[]] $ignoredArguments. This allows for future expansion and compatibility - as new parameters are introduced and used, it doesn't break older versions of Chocolatey.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Do not add new positional elements to functions. We want to promote using named parameters in calling functions.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Do not remove any existing positional elements from functions. We need to maintain compatibility with older versions of Chocolatey.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - One of the first calls in a function is to debug what was passed to it - Write-FunctionCallLogMessage -Invocation $MyInvocation -Parameters $PSBoundParameters
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Debugging / Testing
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: When you want to manually verify your changes and run Choco, you have some options.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: NOTE: Chocolatey behaves differently when built with Debug and Release configurations. Release is always going to seek out the machine installation ($env:ChocolateyInstall), where Debug just runs right next to wherever the choco.exe file is.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Visual Studio
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: When you are using Visual Studio, ensure the following:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Use Debug configuration - debug configuration keeps your local changes separate from the machine installed Chocolatey.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - chocolatey.console is the project you are looking to run.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - If you make changes to anything that is in chocolatey.resources, delete the folder in chocolatey.console\bin\Debug that corresponds to where you've made changes as Chocolatey does not automatically detect changes in the files it is extracting from resource manifests.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - The automated testing framework that Chocolatey uses is NUnit, TinySpec, Moq, and Should. Do not be thrown off thinking it using something else based on seeing Fact attributes for specs/tests. That is TinySpec.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - For a good understanding of all frameworks used, please see CREDITS
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Automated Tests
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: "Testing doesn't prove the absence of bugs, they can only prove code works in the way you've tested."
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: The design of our automated test suite is to get the testing framework out of the way and make it easy to swap out should it ever need to be (the former is the important goal). We test behaviors of the system, which doesn't simply mean ensuring code coverage. It means we want to see how the system behaves under certain behaviors. As you may see from looking over the tests, we have an interesting way of setting up our specs. We recommend importing the ReSharper templates in docs\resharper_templates. This will make adding specs and new spec files quite a bit easier.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: The method of testing as you will see is a file that contains many test classes (scenarios) that set up and perform a behavior, then perform one or more validations (tests/facts) on that scenario. Typically when in a unit test suite, there would be a file for every representative class in the production code. You may not see this as much in this codebase as there are areas that could use more coverage.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: We recognize the need for a very tight feedback loop (running and debugging tests right inside Visual Studio). Some great tools for running and debugging automated tests are TestDriven.NET and ReSharper (you only need one, although both are recommended for development). We recommend TestDriven over other tools as it is absolutely wonderful in what it does.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: With the way the testing framework is designed, it is helpful to gain an understanding on how you can debug into tests. There are a couple of known oddities when it comes to trying to run tests in Visual Studio:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - You can run a test or tests within a class.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - You can also right click on a folder (and solution folder), a project, or the solution and run tests.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - You can not click on a file and attempt to run/debug automated tests. You will see the following message: "The target type doesn't contain tests from a known test framework or a 'Main' method."
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - You also cannot run all tests within a file by selecting somewhere outside a testing class and attempting to run tests. You will see the message above.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Some quick notes on testing terminology (still a WIP):
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Testing - anything done to test, whether manual, automated, or otherwise.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Automated Testing - Any type of written test that can be run in an automated way, typically in the form of C# tests.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Spec / Fact / Observation - these are synonyms for a test or validation.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - System Under Test (SUT) - the code or concern you are testing.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Mock / Fake / Stub / Double - an object that provides a known state back to the system under test when the system under test interacts with other objects. This can be done with unit and whitebox integration testing. This allows for actual unit testing as most units (classes/functions) depend on working with other units (classes/functions) to get or set information and state. While each of these are slightly different, the basic functionality is that they are standing in for other production code.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Concern - an area of production code you are testing in e.g. "Concern for AutoUninstallerService".
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Regression Test Suite / Regression Suite - The automated tests that are in the form of code.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Whitebox Testing - tests where you access the internals of the application.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Unit Testing - We define a unit as a class and a method in C#. In PowerShell this is per function. If it involves another class or function, you have graduated to an integration. This is where Mocks come in to ensure no outside state is introduced.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Whitebox Integration Testing - testing anything that is more than a unit.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - System Integration Testing - testing anything that goes out of the bounds of the written production code. Typically when running the code to get or set some state is where you will see this. And yes, even using DateTime.Now counts as system integration testing as it accesses something external to the application. This is why you will see we insulate those calls to something in the application so they can be easily tested against.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Blackbox Testing - tests where you do not access internals of the application
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Physical Integration Testing - This is where you are testing the application with other components such as config files.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Blackbox Integration Testing / End to End Testing - This is where you are testing inputs and outputs of the system.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: As far as testing goes, unit tests are extremely quick feedback and great for longer term maintenance, where black box tests give you the most coverage, but are the slowest feedback loops and typically the most frail. Each area of testing has strengths and weaknesses and it's good to understand each of them.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: NOTE: One of the hardest forms of automated testing is unit testing, as it almost always requires faking out other parts of the system (also known as mocking).
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Chocolatey Build
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: NOTE: When you are doing this, we almost always recommend you take the output of the build to another machine to do the testing, like the Chocolatey Test Environment.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Run build.bat.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - There is a detailed log of the output in both build_output and code_drop\build_artifacts. The build_artifacts folders contain a lot of detail with each individual tool's output and reporting (helpful when wanting to see a visual of what tests failed).
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - There are two folders created - build_output and code_drop. You are looking for code_drop\chocolatey\console or code_drop\nuget. The choco.exe file contains everything it needs, but it does unpack the manifest on first use, so you could run into #1292.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - You will need to pass --allow-unofficial-build for it to work when built with release mode.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - You can also try build.debug.bat - note that it is newer and it may have an issue or two. It doesn't require --allow-unofficial-build as the binaries are built for debugging.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Use .\choco.exe to point to the local file. By default in PowerShell.exe, if you have Chocolatey installed, when you call choco, that is using the installed choco and not the one in the folder you are currently in. You must be explicit. This catches nearly everyone.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Prepare Commits
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: This section serves to help you understand what makes a good commit.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: A commit should observe the following:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - A commit is a small logical unit that represents a change.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Should include new or changed tests relevant to the changes you are making.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - No unnecessary whitespace. Check for whitespace with git diff --check and git diff --cached --check before commit.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - You can stage parts of a file for commit.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: A commit message should observe the following (based on "A Note About Git Commit Messages"):
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - The first line of the commit message should be a short description around 50 characters in length and be prefixed with the GitHub issue it refers to with parentheses surrounding that. If the GitHub issue is #25, you should have (GH-25) prefixed to the message.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - If the commit is about documentation, the message should be prefixed with (doc).
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - If it is a trivial commit or one of formatting/spaces fixes, it should be prefixed with (maint).
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - After the subject, skip one line and fill out a body if the subject line is not informative enough.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Sometimes you will find that even a tiny code change has a commit body that needs to be very detailed and make take more time to do than the actual change itself!
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - The body:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Should wrap at 72 characters.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Explains more fully the reason(s) for the change and contrasts with previous behavior.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Uses present tense. "Fix" versus "Fixed".
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: A good example of a commit message is as follows:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: (GH-7) Installation Adds All Required Folders
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Previously the installation script worked for the older version of
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Chocolatey. It does not work similarly for the newer version of choco
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: due to location changes for the newer folders. Update the install
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: script to ensure all folder paths exist.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Without this change the install script will not fully install the new
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: choco client properly.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Submit Pull Request (PR)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Prerequisites:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - You are making commits in a feature branch.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - All specs should be passing.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Submitting PR:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Once you feel it is ready, submit the pull request to the chocolatey/choco repository against the master branch (more information on this can be found here) unless specifically requested to submit it against another branch (usually stable in these instances).
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - In the case of a larger change that is going to require more discussion, please submit a PR sooner. Waiting until you are ready may mean more changes than you are interested in if the changes are taking things in a direction the committers do not want to go.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - In the pull request, outline what you did and point to specific conversations (as in URLs) and issues that you are are resolving. This is a tremendous help for us in evaluation and acceptance.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Once the pull request is in, please do not delete the branch or close the pull request (unless something is wrong with it).
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - One of the Chocolatey Team members, or one of the committers, will evaluate it within a reasonable time period (which is to say usually within 2-4 weeks). Some things get evaluated faster or fast tracked. We are human and we have active lives outside of open source so don't fret if you haven't seen any activity on your pull request within a month or two. We don't have a Service Level Agreement (SLA) for pull requests. Just know that we will evaluate your pull request.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Respond to Feedback on Pull Request
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: We may have feedback for you in the form of requested changes or fixes. We generally like to see that pushed against the same topic branch (it will automatically update the PR). You can also fix/squash/rebase commits and push the same topic branch with --force (while it is generally acceptable to do this on topic branches not in the main repository, a force push should be avoided at all costs against the main repository).
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: If we have comments or questions when we do evaluate it and receive no response, it will probably lessen the chance of getting accepted. Eventually this means it will be closed if it is not accepted. Please know this doesn't mean we don't value your contribution, just that things go stale. If in the future you want to pick it back up, feel free to address our concerns/questions/feedback and reopen the issue/open a new PR (referencing old one).
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Sometimes we may need you to rebase your commit against the latest code before we can review it further. If this happens, you can do the following:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - git fetch upstream (upstream would be the mainstream repo or chocolatey/choco in this case)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - git checkout master
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - git rebase upstream/master
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - git checkout your-branch
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - git rebase master
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Fix any merge conflicts
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - git push origin your-branch (origin would be your GitHub repo or your-github-username/choco in this case). You may need to git push origin your-branch --force to get the commits pushed. This is generally acceptable with topic branches not in the mainstream repository.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: The only reasons a pull request should be closed and resubmitted are as follows:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - When the pull request is targeting the wrong branch (this doesn't happen as often).
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - When there are updates made to the original by someone other than the original contributor (and the PR is not open for contributions). Then the old branch is closed with a note on the newer branch this supersedes #github_number.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Other General Information
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: The helpers/utility functions that are available to the packages are what we consider the API. If you are working in the API, please note that you will need to maintain backwards compatibility. If you plan to rename a function or make it more generic, you must provide an alias in the chocolateyInstaller.psm1 as part of what gets exported. You should not remove or reorder parameters, only add optional parameters to the end. They should be named and not positional (we are moving away from positional parameters as much as possible).
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: If you reformat code or hit core functionality without an approval from a person on the Chocolatey Team, it's likely that no matter how awesome it looks afterwards, it will probably not get accepted. Reformatting code makes it harder for us to evaluate exactly what was changed.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: If you do these things, it will be make evaluation and acceptance easy. Now if you stray outside of the guidelines we have above, it doesn't mean we are going to ignore your pull request. It will just make things harder for us.  Harder for us roughly translates to a longer SLA for your pull request.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Prerequisites

Paragraph: - Ensure you have signed the Contributor License Agreement (CLA) - without this we are not able to take contributions that are not trivial.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Sign the Contributor License Agreement.

Paragraph: - You must do this for each Chocolatey project that requires it.

Paragraph: - If you are curious why we would require a CLA, we agree with Julien Ponge - take a look at his post.

Paragraph: Contributing Process
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Get Buyoff Or Find Open Community Issues/Features
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Through GitHub, or through the mailing list (preferred), you talk about a feature you would like to see (or a bug), and why it should be in Chocolatey.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - If approved through the mailing list, ensure the accompanying GitHub issue is created with information and a link back to the mailing list discussion.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Once you get a nod from one of the Chocolatey Team, you can start on the feature.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Alternatively, if a feature is on the issues list with the community tag, it is open for a patch. You should comment that you are signing up for it on the issue so someone else doesn't also sign up for the work.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - In the branch you do work specific to the feature.

Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - No changing files that are not specific to the feature

It is recommended that all contributors spend some time looking over the tests in the source code. You can't go wrong emulating one of the existing tests and then changing it specific to the behavior you are testing.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: All bugs and non-trivial changes must have an associated issue. So, step one should be making sure that your issue doesn't already exist. If you find a relevant issue, feel free to add a comment with any additional details or problems specific to your use case. Otherwise, open a new issue and fill out the template in its entirety.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: An exception to this rule is for any "trivial" change such as language additions, documentation fixes, typo corrections, etc.. no issue is required for these. Just include a good description / overview in your PR.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Development Overview
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: All development and pull requests should be made against the current release branch. Master is reserved for the last stable working version of the code. As such, it will often be outdated.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Release branches take the form of {semvar}-release. For example:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - 1.0.2-release
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - 2.0.0-release
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: You can find the current release branch by checking out the branches page.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Making Changes:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Create a branch for your changes
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Use the current release branch
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Don't branch from master! This will cause you pain!
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Ideal branch naming would reference the issue number it is resolving (e.g. issue-xxx-enabling-cool-feature ).
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Group your commits into coarse feature-level chunks (preferably one) and reference the issue number in the message (e.g. "closes #322 - added cool feature XXX")
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Make your commits about One Thing.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Avoid stream of consciousness style commits as they'll just be asked to be cleaned up during code review
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Make sure you've added tests for your feature / bug fix
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Make sure it works on both Python 2.7 and Python 3.x (this is often overlooked!)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Backwards compatibility must be honored
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: When to PEP8:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: The vast majority of Gooey's code does not follow PEP8. This is because the vast majority of Gooey's code is build on top of WxPython code, which does not follow PEP8. Everything in Gooey's core honors the general camelCase style used throughout Wx.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: The exception to this rule is for everything in the python_bindings/ package. This package holds the public API for Gooey, and thus honors PEP8. So the general rule is that if you're making a change to the public bindings: use PEP8. For all other internal Gooey code, honor the house style you find.
Label: DC – Deal with the code
