Paragraph: Contributing
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: We welcome contibutions in the form of pull requests, issues, or code reviews. Here are some quick guidelines to help ensure we can make use of your effort.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Reporting Issues
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: If you stumble upon a bug or something seems odd, please file an issue in the issue tracker.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Submitting Pull Requests
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Fork, then clone the repo:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git clone --recursive git@github.com:your-username/cinder/Cinder.git
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Push to your fork and submit a pull request. When describing your pull request, it is best to explain the problem you are solving or feature you are adding, some reasoning behind it, and how the code can be verified. If your modifications affect multiple platforms, please make a note of which platforms and OS versions you have tested on and which ones still need to be tested. If your contribution has already been discussed in an issue or forum post, linking to that may be a sufficient explanation.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Some things to facilitate acceptance of your pull request:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Provide a way to test the changes. Examples can be within a sample, the test folder, a gist, or by explaining how a reviewer can make some edits locally to test.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Keep the changes as concise as possible. It is best if a pull request addresses a single issue.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Follow our style guide as described below.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Write clear and concise commit messages.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - For sample / test code, try to keep binary data to a minimum. For test assets, the folder samples/data contains some assets you can possibly make use of, or adding new assets there means they can be used by future samples. App icons should also be referenced from this folder, reducing our overall binary weight and also making it easy to update in the future.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: In general, we review pull requests first that best adhere to these suggestions.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Style Guide
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Please make sure your code conforms to the following general guidelines. If something is unclear or undocumented, the rule of thumb is to try to make the source code easy to read, concise, and match the code around it.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Naming
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Use camelCase; classes begin with upper case and variables with lower case.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Member variables begin with an 'm' prefix (mVariable).
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Static variables begin with an 's' prefix (sInstance).
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - enum types are all upper case with underscore separators
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - ex. enum Types { TYPE_1, TYPE_2, TYPE_UNKNOWN }.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Spacing and Line Breaks
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Use tabs for indentation, with a tab stop value of 4.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Anything inside a namespace starts with no indentation.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Place spaces between braces, braces and arguments, etc.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Place a space between ! and variables to negate them
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - ex. if( ! mEnabled ) { ...
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Brackets for class methods and functions begin on a new line. Brackets for everything else (class declarations, if / for / while loops, etc. ) begin on the same line following a space.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - The contents of an if, for, or while statement should always be on a new line. This not only makes it easier to read but also prevents some ambiguities that come up in some debugging situations, where you can't tell if you've jumped into the body of the statement or not.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - else statements should be placed on a new line for vertical readability.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Types
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Adhere to const correctness wherever possible. See this and this for explanation.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - For small, built-in types (ex. int, float, double, size_t) pass by value
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - For larger types (ex. STL containers, really anything other than built-in types or similar), pass in by const &.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - If a parameter is expected to be modified by a method, it should be a pointer (not reference) so it is clear at the call site. An exception is when you are using private utility methods.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Class inheritance
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - When an object doesn't have clear copy semantics (ex. a system resource or gl::Texture, inherit from ci::Noncopyable so it is obvious that the object cannot be copied.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - When overriding a virtual method in a subclass, do not use the virtual keyword a second time, instead use override, which has the added benefit of the compiler checking that the override took place.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Unless it is templated or performance critical code, place method implementations in the .cpp to try to keep the header more concise. The exception to this rule is simple getters
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - ex. getWidth() const   { return mWidth; }.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Comments
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Place comments in the header files (in the form of doxygen for public or protected interfaces) and leave the implementations as concise as possible.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - If there is something you think is not obvious in an implementation, then comments can help clarify, but in general it is nice to let the code do the explaining.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - We generate reference documentation using doxygen, so you are encouraged to give descriptions to as much of the public interface as possible in order to fill out the reference documentation.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - To make it easier to distinguish the end of a namespace, place a comment after the namespace's closing bracket
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - ex. } // namespace ci::gl
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Example: Class Declaration
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: #pragma once
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: #inclue "cinder/includes/first.h"
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: #include <system/includes/next>
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: namespace cinder {
Label: No categories identified.
No categories identified.

Paragraph:
//! Place spaces in between braces and arguments.
void someMethod( int argA, const Rectf &bounds );
Label: No categories identified.
No categories identified.

Paragraph:
//! Getters are usually declared as const.
int 	getVar1() const 		{ return mVar1; }
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
private:
void 	doSomething( int arg );
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
int mVar1, mVar2;
};
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: } // namespace cinder
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Example: Class Implementation
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: #include "cinder/SomeClass.h"
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: using namespace std;
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: namespace cinder {
Label: No categories identified.
No categories identified.
No categories identified.

Paragraph: } // namespace cinder
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Notes on shared_ptr usage
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: We use shared_ptrs a lot. Usually they are in the form of a typedef'ed ObjectRef to save the user a bit of typing (the Ref suffix is short for 'reference counted object'):
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: typedef shared_ptr<class Object>	ObjectRef;
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Here are a couple rules of thumb regarding how to pass around these shared_ptr objects:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Pass in by const &:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: void setObject( const ObjectRef &object );
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: However, return by value:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: ObjectRef getObject() const;
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: This is to avoid some nasty bugs that can be caused when the actual object returned is a subclass of Object and the method unwittingly returns a reference to an already destroyed temporary.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Error Handling
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Avoid silent failures. In general, we use exceptions for cases that an application can recover from, such as when image decoding or glsl compilation fails. For situations that a user cannot possibly recover from, it is better to use assertions and the handy CI_ASSERT macro. However, as is the case many times, there are no rules set in stone for choosing one technique over the other, or choosing a different way to handle an error altogether (such as logging). When in doubt, post your code for peer review.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Exceptions in core cinder code should all inherit from ci::Exception.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Commit Message Guidelines
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
We have very precise rules over how our git commit messages can be formatted.  This leads to more
readable messages that are easy to follow when looking through the project history.  But also,
we use the git commit messages to generate the Angular Tree Component change log.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Commit Message Format
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Each commit message consists of a header, a body and a footer. The header has a special
format that includes a type, a scope, and a subject:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
<type>(<scope>): <subject>
<BLANK LINE>
<body>
<BLANK LINE>
<footer>
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: The header is mandatory and the scope of the header is optional.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Any line of the commit message cannot be longer 100 characters! This allows the message to be easier
to read on GitHub as well as in various git tools.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: The footer should contain a closing reference to an issue if any.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Samples: (even more samples)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: docs(changelog): update changelog to beta.5
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: fix(release): need to depend on latest rxjs and zone.js
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: The version in our package.json gets copied to the one we publish, and users need the latest of these.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Revert
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: If the commit reverts a previous commit, it should begin with revert:, followed by the header of the reverted commit. In the body it should say: This reverts commit <hash>., where the hash is the SHA of the commit being reverted.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Type
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Must be one of the following:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - build: Changes that affect the build system or external dependencies (example scopes: gulp, broccoli, npm)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - ci: Changes to our CI configuration files and scripts (example scopes: Travis, Circle, BrowserStack, SauceLabs)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - docs: Documentation only changes
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - feat: A new feature
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - fix: A bug fix
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - perf: A code change that improves performance
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - refactor: A code change that neither fixes a bug nor adds a feature
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - style: Changes that do not affect the meaning of the code (white-space, formatting, missing semi-colons, etc)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - test: Adding missing tests or correcting existing tests
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Scope
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: The scope should be the name of the npm package affected (as perceived by the person reading the changelog generated from commit messages).
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: The following is the list of supported scopes:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - component
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - directive
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - model
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - mobx
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Subject
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: The subject contains a succinct description of the change:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - use the imperative, present tense: "change" not "changed" nor "changes"
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - don't capitalize the first letter
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - no dot (.) at the end
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Body
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Just as in the subject, use the imperative, present tense: "change" not "changed" nor "changes".
The body should include the motivation for the change and contrast this with previous behavior.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Footer
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
The footer should contain any information about Breaking Changes and is also the place to
reference GitHub issues that this commit Closes.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Breaking Changes should start with the word BREAKING CHANGE: with a space or two newlines. The rest of the commit message is then used for this.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: feat(scope): commit message

Paragraph: Getting and building
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Mac
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 1.  Install Xcode
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 2.  Install packages with Homebrew
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
brew update
brew install git postgresql
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 3.  Get, build, and test the code
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: git clone https://github.com/citusdata/citus.git
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
cd citus
./configure
make
make install
cd src/test/regress
make check
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Debian-based Linux (Ubuntu, Debian)
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 1.  Install build dependencies
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
echo "deb http://apt.postgresql.org/pub/repos/apt/ $(lsb_release -cs)-pgdg main" | \
sudo tee /etc/apt/sources.list.d/pgdg.list
wget --quiet -O - https://www.postgresql.org/media/keys/ACCC4CF8.asc | \
sudo apt-key add -
sudo apt-get update
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
sudo apt-get install -y postgresql-server-dev-11 postgresql-11 \
libreadline-dev libselinux1-dev libxslt-dev  \
libpam0g-dev git flex make libssl-dev    \
libicu-dev \
libkrb5-dev libcurl4-gnutls-dev autoconf
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 2.  Get, build, and test the code
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
git clone https://github.com/citusdata/citus.git
cd citus
./configure
make
sudo make install
cd src/test/regress
make check
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Red Hat-based Linux (RHEL, CentOS, Fedora)
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 1.  Find the RPM URL for your repo at yum.postgresql.org
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 2.  Register its contents with Yum:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: sudo yum install -y <url>
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 3.  Register EPEL and SCL repositories for your distro.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: On CentOS:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: yum install -y centos-release-scl-rh epel-release
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: On RHEL, see this RedHat blog post to install set-up SCL first. Then run:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: yum install -y epel-release
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 4.  Install build dependencies
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
sudo yum update -y
sudo yum groupinstall -y 'Development Tools'
sudo yum install -y postgresql11-devel postgresql11-server     \
libxml2-devel libxslt-devel openssl-devel  \
pam-devel readline-devel git libcurl-devel \
llvm5.0 llvm-toolset-7-clang
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
git clone https://github.com/citusdata/citus.git
cd citus
PG_CONFIG=/usr/pgsql-11/bin/pg_config ./configure
make
sudo make install
cd src/test/regress
make check
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Following our coding conventions
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
CircleCI will automatically reject any PRs which do not follow our coding
conventions. The easiest way to ensure your PR adheres to those conventions is
to use the citus_indent
tool. This tool uses uncrustify under the hood.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
# Uncrustify changes the way it formats code every release a bit. To make sure
# everyone formats consistently we use version 0.68.1:
curl -L https://github.com/uncrustify/uncrustify/archive/uncrustify-0.68.1.tar.gz | tar xz
cd uncrustify-uncrustify-0.68.1/
mkdir build
cd build
cmake ..
make -j5
sudo make install
cd ../..
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
git clone https://github.com/citusdata/tools.git
cd tools
make uncrustify/.install
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Once you've done that, you can run the make reindent command from the top
directory to recursively check and correct the style of any source files in the
current directory. Under the hood, make reindent will run citus_indent and
some other style corrections for you.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
You can also run the following in the directory of this repository to
automatically format all the files that you have changed before committing:
Label: DC – Deal with the code
No categories identified.

Paragraph: Making SQL changes
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
Sometimes you need to make change to the SQL that the citus extension runs upon
creations. The way this is done is by changing the last file in
src/backend/distributed/sql, or creating it if the last file is from a
published release. If you needed to create a new file, also change the
default_version field in src/backend/distributed/citus.control to match your
new version. All the files in this directory are run in order based on
their name. See this page in the Postgres
docs for more
information on how Postgres runs these files.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Changing or creating functions
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
If you need to change any functions defined by Citus. You should check inside
src/backend/distributed/sql/udfs to see if there is already a directory for
this function, if not create one. Then change or create the file called
latest.sql in that directory to match how it should create the function. This
should be including any DROP (IF EXISTS), COMMENT and REVOKE statements for this
function.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
Then copy the latest.sql file to {version}.sql, where {version} is the
version for which this sql change is, e.g. {9.0-1.sql}. Now that you've
created this stable snapshot of the function definition for your version you
should use it in your actual sql file, e.g.
src/backend/distributed/sql/citus--8.3-1--9.0-1.sql. You do this by using C
style #include statements like this:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: #include "udfs/myudf/9.0-1.sql"
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Other SQL
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
Any other SQL you can put directly in the main sql file, e.g.
src/backend/distributed/sql/citus--8.3-1--9.0-1.sql.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Using Issues
Label: CF – Contribution flow

pg_shard's maintainers prefer that bug reports, feature requests, and pull
requests are submitted as GitHub Issues. If you think you require personal
assistance, please do not open an issue: email the pg_shard Google Group
instead.

Label: No categories identified.

Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 2.  Check whether the bug remains in the latest master or develop commit
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 3.  Create a reduced test case: remove code and data not relevant to the bug
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
A contributor should be able to begin work on your bug without asking too many
followup questions. If you include the following information, your bug will be
serviced more quickly:

Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Your OS

Paragraph:
Once the background information is out of the way, you are free to present the
bug itself. You should explain:

Paragraph: - The expected outcome

Paragraph: - What actually occurred
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Feature Requests
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
We are open to adding features but ultimately control the scope and aims of the
project. If a proposed feature is likely to incur high testing, maintenance, or
performance costs it is also unlikely to be accepted. If a strong case exists
for a given feature, we may be persuaded on merit. Be specific.

Paragraph: Welcome to Clasp
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Clasp is a very fast-moving project, but that speed still currently relies mostly on one person: drmeister. Clasp still has a very long way to go too, there's a plethora of issues and missing features. As such there should be plenty of room for other people to join in and help us out to make Clasp the amazing project it has the potential to be.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: If you would like to get acquainted with the current developers and the status of Clasp in general, you are more than welcome to check by our IRC channel #clasp on Freenode. It is also a good place to be if you just want to lurk around and watch the development happen before your very eyes.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: This document is for those who would like to become an actual contributor to Clasp, meaning adding or cleaning up code, or helping out with organisation and testing.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Submission Constraints
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: While we welcome submissions very much, we nevertheless need to enforce some rules and guidelines in order to keep things from looking like a plate of cold spaghetti. As Clasp does not have a big developer team at the moment, these rules are not too strict or roundabout. Submissions that do not follow them will be rejected however.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Setting up Your Work Area
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: You will want to fork the Clasp repository, clone that to your machine and set up the upstream remote using git remote add upstream https://github.com/drmeister/clasp. While developing you should periodically synchronise your fork with the upstream as otherwise things can get too out of sync to still be mergeable. In case of updates from upstream, you should pull those in using git pull --rebase upstream dev while on your local dev or feature branch. Only create merge commits if there is a conflict; we'd like to keep a somewhat clean history.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Code Style
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Please follow the LLVM style standard, in the very least concerning code formatting, indentation, and brace-style. There is a .dir-locals.el file at the Clasp root that should automatically configure the proper rules, if you happen to use Emacs. Otherwise you can run clang-format on your code with the settings from the .clang-format file, which you can find at the Clasp root as well.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Branching and Committing
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: You should never, ever commit to testing or preview. These branches are solely for build testing and should not receive any commits. If you do commit to them by mistake, switch to the dev branch, cherry-pick the commit, and then reset the testing/preview branch to the commit before that.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: You should also never commit to master unless you have the permission to do so. master is guarded for releases and only hotfixes or documentation changes should be pushed on there between releases. Not to mention that it is very likely for master to be heavily out of date, so developing against it is a bad idea anyway.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: If you are only fixing minor things or adding small features, it is Ok to commit to dev. Otherwise, if you are planning something bigger like a refactoring of some files, changing the architecture, adding a component to Clasp, or something like that, then you must create a feature branch. The branch's name should be prefixed with dev- followed by a somewhat descriptive name that tells us what you're doing in that branch.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Please use descriptive commit messages that tell us what you did. Please also avoid committing huge amounts of changes in one go-- create multiple smaller commits where possible and applicable. This makes bisecting in case of regressions much easier. If your changes are related to an issue ticket, please reference it in your commit message.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Pull Requests
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Once you are done with your changes, make sure that all upstream changes are present on your branch and verify that you did not break anything by running a full build against a clean clone of your fork. If everything passed and Clasp launches successfully, you can submit a pull request. You should usually PR against dev or the corresponding feature branch if one exists. Please choose a fitting title and write a short description that summarises your changes and notes that you successfully build-tested everything to work.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: When your PR has been approved and merged in, things will be pushed out to testing, where our CI machines will hopefully verify that everything is still just fine and dandy. If that comes to pass, you are free to celebrate and rejoice!
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Contributing to this project
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: First of all, thanks for contributing! Please take a moment to review this document in order to make the contribution process easy and effective for everyone involved.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Following these guidelines helps to communicate that you respect the time of the developers managing and developing this open source project. In return, they should reciprocate that respect in addressing your issue or assessing patches and features.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Using the issue tracker
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: The issue tracker is the preferred channel for bug reports but please respect the following restrictions:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Please try not to use the issue tracker for personal support requests (use Gitter).
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Please do not derail or troll issues. Keep the discussion on topic and respect the opinions of others.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Feature requests
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Feature requests are welcome.
But take a moment to find out whether your idea fits with the scope and aims of the project.
It's up to you to make a strong case to convince the project's developers of the merits of this feature.
Please provide as much detail and context as possible.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Pull requests
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Good pull requests - patches, improvements, new features - are a fantastic help.
They should remain focused in scope and avoid containing unrelated commits.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Please ask first before embarking on any significant pull request (e.g. implementing features, refactoring code, porting to a different language),
otherwise you risk spending a lot of time working on something that the project's developers might not want to merge into the project.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Please adhere to the coding conventions used throughout a project (indentation, accurate comments, etc.)

Paragraph: Issues and Support.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Please remember the issue tracker on github is not for user support.  Please also do not email developers directly for support.  Instead please use IRC or the forums first, then if the problem is confirmed create an issue that details how to repeat the problem so it can be investigated.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Issues created without steps to repeat are likely to be closed.  E-mail requests for support will go un-answered; All support needs to be public so that other people can read the problems and solutions.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Remember that issues that are due to mis-configuration, wiring or failure to read documentation just takes time away from the developers and can often be solved without developer interaction by other users.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Please search for existing issues before creating new ones.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Thanks for considering to write a Pull Request (PR) for CLI11! Here are a few guidelines to get you started:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Make sure you are comfortable with the license; all contributions are licensed under the original license.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Adding functionality
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Make sure any new functions you add are are:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Documented by /// documentation for Doxygen
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Mentioned in the instructions in the README, though brief mentions are okay
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Explained in your PR (or previously explained in an Issue mentioned in the PR)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Completely covered by tests
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: In general, make sure the addition is well thought out and does not increase the complexity of CLI11 needlessly.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Things you should know:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Once you make the PR, tests will run to make sure your code works on all supported platforms
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - The test coverage is also measured, and that should remain 100%
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Formatting should be done with pre-commit, otherwise the format check will not pass. However, it is trivial to apply this to your PR, so don't worry about this check. If you do want to run it, see below.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Everything must pass clang-tidy as well, run with -DCLI11_CLANG_TIDY=ON (if you set -DCLI11_CLANG_TIDY_OPTIONS="-fix", make sure you use a single threaded build process, or just build one example target).
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Your changes must also conform to most of the Google C++ Style Guide rules checked by cpplint. For unused cpplint filters and justifications, see CPPLINT.cfg.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Pre-commit
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Format is handled by pre-commit. You should install it:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: python3 -m pip install pre-commit
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Then, you can run it on the items you've added to your staging area, or all files:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
pre-commit run
# OR
pre-commit run --all-files
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: And, if you want to always use it, you can install it as a git hook (hence the name, pre-commit):
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: pre-commit install
Label: SC – Submit the changes

conan remove '*' # optional, I like to be clean
conan create . cliutils/stable
conan upload "*" -r cli11 --all

Paragraph: Here I've assumed that the remote is cli11.

Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: In a commit to a PR, just add "@all-contributors please add <username> for <contributions>" or similar (see https://allcontributors.org). Use code for code, bug if an issue was submitted, platform for packaging stuff, and doc for documentation updates.

Paragraph: To run locally, do:

yarn add --dev all-contributors-cli

Paragraph: Developer guidelines
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: The OpenXML specification is a large and complicated beast. In order for ClosedXML, the wrapper around OpenXML, to support all the features, we rely on community contributions. Before opening an issue to request a new feature, we'd like to urge you to try to implement it yourself and log a pull request.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Here are some tips.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Before starting a large pull request, log an issue and outline the problem and a broad outline of your solution. The maintainers will discuss the issue with you and possibly propose some alternative approaches to align with the ClosedXML development conventions.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Please submit pull requests that are based on the develop branch.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Where possible, pull requests should include unit tests that cover as many uses cases as possible.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - We recommend Visual Studio 2019 or higher as the development environment. If you do use Visual Studio, please install these extensions:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - CodeMaid, for ensuring consistent code syntax, whitespace convention, etc.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - If you use a version of Visual Studio lower than 2017, you should install editorconfig support. Read more about EditorConfig.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - We use 4 spaces for code indentation. This is the default in Visual Studio. Don't leave any trailing white space at the end of lines or files.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Working with Excel file internals
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Excel files (.xlsx and .xlsm) are zip packages. You can easily verify this by renaming the extension any Excel file to .zip and opening the file in your favourite .zip file editor.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Internally, the file contains files (also known as parts) that represent different entities in the Excel framework, for example workbook.xml and table1.xml. The OpenXML specification documents all these parts and their contents.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Making changes to the ClosedXML code may change the input or output of the package parts. For example if you add support for a currently unsupported element, you will have to ensure that you read the appropriate package part into the ClosedXML model and also support writing of the package parts to the file.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Comparing the internals of Excel files
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: A ClosedXML developer will often want to compare the internals of 2 similar Excel files. For example if you want to compare the output of a specific package part before and after your code changes. The long, difficult way would be to extract the package parts of the 2 files and manually compare the relevant parts. To ease this, we recommend this tooling stack:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Total Commander
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - WinMerge version 2.14.0, because subsequent versions for some reason excludes the required DisplayXMLFiles.dll plugin.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Set Total Commander to use WinMerge as its compare tool.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - In WinMerge, enable Plugins > Automatic Prediffer
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Now, to compare 2 similar, but not exact Excel files:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - In Total Commander, navigate to the 1st file in the left-hand pane and the 2nd file in the right-hand pane.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Press Ctrl+PageDown to "enter" the package. You should see, among others, a [Content_Types].xml file in both panes.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - You can now compare all package parts by selecting Commands > Synchronise Dirs.... Press Compare. This will do a full, recursive comparison. You can filter out parts that are identical.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - You can select an item that differs and press Ctrl+F3 to open the two parts in WinMerge and see the exact comparison of the part's contents. The XML files should automatically reformat/reindent to ease the comparison instead of showing the entire XML contents on a single line. This is the reason for requiring the DisplayXMLFiles.dll plugin.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - In Total Commander, you can also navigate to specific files in the left-hand and right-hand panes and select File > Compare by Content.... This will open WinMerge directly.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Note that since WinMerge reformats the XML, it does so in a temporary file. If you make changes to the contents of any of the 2 panes in WinMerge and save the file, it will not be saved back into the Excel file.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Code conventions
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: ClosedXML has a fairly large codebase and we therefore want to keep code revisions as clean and tidy as possible. It is therefore important not to introduce unnecessary whitespace changes in your commits.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: To ensure you follow the coding conventions, please do the following steps before you commit your code:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - In Visual Studio, run CodeMaid > Cleanup Active Document or Ctrl+M, Space on each file that you have altered. This will ensure the correct whitespace consistency.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Some files, not all, have a header in the first line: // Keep this file CodeMaid organised and cleaned. For these files, also run CodeMaid > Reorganize Active Document or Ctrl+M, Z. This will reorder properties and methods alphabetically into a predetermined order. For example, public properties and methods will be organized before private properties and methods. Not all files require this yet. Please take note of the headers.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: CloudCompare Coding rules
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Naming
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Names in CloudCompare should be as descriptive as possible, without abbreviations, apart for very clear or common ones (such as fw instead of forward, etc.). Most of variable names should begin with a lower case letter. If the name is composed of multiple words, the first letter of each word should be in upper case (apart for the first one of course).
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Example: numberOfPoints, ptsCount (or even ptsNum for the laziest ;-)
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Specific cases
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - static variables: should always begin with prefix s_ (in lower case s_defaultFilename
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - static methods: should always begin with a upper case letter (like InitGLEW)
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - classes: should always begin with prefix cc (in lower case ccConsole)
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - enumerators:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - all letters in upper case
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - should always begin with prefix CC_
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - words are separated by underscore (like CC_OBJECT_FLAG)
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - macros: begin with prefix MACRO_ followed by a standard method name (like MACRO_SkipUnselected)
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - const variables:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - all letters in upper case
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - words are separated by underscore (like NORMALS_QUANTIZE_LEVEL)
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - macro const (#define): should be avoided; same syntax as const
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Files
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - File naming follows the same rule as most CloudCompare elements (first letter in lower case, etc.)
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Each class should be saved alone in a header + source file couple. Exceptionally, very small classes that are used by a single class may be saved along with this class. The header + source filename should be the same as the main class.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Example: ccConsole saved in ccConsole.h and ccConsole.cpp
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Filenames shouldn
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - All data-related classes (data models, database, etc) should be saved in db directory.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Images (icons) should all be saved in the images directory (or one of its subdirectories).
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - GUI templates (mainly .ui Qt files) should be saved in the ui_templates directory
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Tabs and indentation
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Indentation is expected to be made in Tabs only, each of size 4.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Summary
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Element | Example
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
------- | -------
Class | ccMyClass
File  |  ccMyClass.h and ccMyClass.cpp
Attribute/variable | myAttribute
Static attribute/variable | s_myAttribute
Method | getMethod()
Static method | GetMethod()
Structure | myStruct
Enumerator | CC_MY_ENUMERATOR
Macro | MACRO_myMethod
Const variables | MY_CONSTANT
Const (#define) | MY_CONSTANT
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Designing a new qCC plugin
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Introduction
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Designing a new plugin is an easy way to extend qCC (CloudCompare) functionalities, without the pain of having to modify its core and do all the connections.
One can easily design a new function, that may be applied on one or several entities currently loaded in CloudCompare. Moreover, the plugin can display its own dialog.
A dummy plugin structure (the sources and the corresponding Code::Blocks project) is provided as a template.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: First steps
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Here are the first mandatory steps to create a new plugin. In fact these following setps are basically meant to build up a working Code::Blocks project for your new plugin based on the qDummyPlugin template.
The different plugins projects are located in the plugins folder. You should see a folder named qDummyPlugin inside.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 1.  Simply qDummyPlugin folder it in the same directory (trunk\plugins)
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 2.  You should see now a new folder (
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 3.  Rename this directory with you own plugin name (for instance
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 4.  browse to this directory
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 5.  you should see the following files inside:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - qDummyPlugin.h  & qDummyPlugin.cpp: the source files
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - qDummyPlugin.qrc: a Qt resource file (for icons, etc.)
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - icon.png: a fake icon file
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - CMakeLists.txt: CMake configuration script
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 6.  Rename all the qDummyPlugin.* files with you own project name
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - qDummyPlugin.h  => qMyPlugin.h
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - qDummyPlugin.cpp => qMyPlugin.cpp
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 7.  Edit the CMakeLists.txt:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Replace all occurrences of DUMMY with your plugin name (don
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - If your plugin relies on additional libraries, you should also add them here. See for instance the equivalent files for the qHPR or qPCV plugins.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Modifying the sources
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: You can now begin with the real work: implementing the plugin action. There are some modifications that have to be done first however.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Header file
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Open the header file (qMyPlugin.h).
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 1.  at the top of the file you should see first a standard CloudCompare header. You can change inside the plugin name (qDummy => qMyPlugin) and the copyright owner.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 2.  below this header, we have a standard C++ class declaration.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - you should modify the macro word Q_DUMMY_PLUGIN_HEADER with your own (for instance: Q_MY_PLUGIN_ HEADER). Do it on both lines.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - you should also update the class description (Doxygen style)
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - and eventually rename the class itself (qDummyPlugin  qMyPlugin)
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 3.  This is all that has to be done for the header file.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Source file
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Open the source file (qMyPlugin.cpp).
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 1.  Same thing: you may update the header (plugin name and copyright owner).
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 2.  then, read carefully all the comments (there are basically the same information as below):
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - replace all occurrences of qDummyPlugin by your plugin class name (qDummyPlugin  qMyPlugin). You may use the replacing tool to do this (Menu Search > Replace or CTRL+R). Make sure the Whole word and Match case checkboxes are checked, and then click on the Replace button, and eventually on the All button.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - now only two mandatory steps remain:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - update the getDescription method (especially, you should replace the Dummy Plugin string by your plugin name and the Dummy Action string by a short description of your plugin action).
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- put your code in the doAction method (between the two  /*** HERE STARTS THE MAIN PLUGIN ACTION ***/ delimiters).
Whenever the user clicks on your plugin icon, CloudCompare will call this method.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Optionally:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - You can access most of CloudCompare resources through the m_app member (an interface to the main application: data base, main window, 3D view(s), etc.).
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - To determine which entities were selected when the user clicked on the icon(s) or if the icon should be enabled or not, you should add custom code to the onNewSelection method (this method is called whenever the selection changes).
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Using CCLIb and CloudCompare database/algorithms
All algorithms (in CCLib) and 3D entities (in CCLib, qCC_db, qCC_io and qCC_gl) are accessible inside the plugin. Check the doxygen documentation of those projects for more information.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - CCLib doxygen documentation
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- qCC doxygen documentation
Once again, the other plugin projects are a good source of hints, as the CloudCompare project itself.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: General Workflow
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 1.  Collaborate with the team before you start work
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 2.  Fork the repository and make a local clone
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 3.  Create a feature branch from the development branch
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
cd cf-release
git checkout develop
./scripts/update
git checkout -b better_cf-release
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
4.  Build and deploy the checked out version of
cf-release. We recommend using
bosh-lite for this.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
cd cf-release
./scripts/generate-bosh-lite-dev-manifest
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
bosh create release
bosh upload release
bosh deploy
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 5.  Make changes on your branch.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 6.  Update and run manifest generation tests and other basic tests ./scripts/test.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 7.  Re-deploy your version of cf-release.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
8.  Run Cloud Foundry Acceptance Tests (CATS).  We recommend
running the tests as a bosh errand (bosh run errand acceptance_tests). You won't see any output from the tests
until the errand completes.  If you choose to run them manually, please follow the instructions in the
CATS README.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
9.  Set up git hooks by running ./scripts/setup-git-hooks and commit your work.  This will ensure that the same set of tests
as ./scripts/test run as a pre-commit hook before any commit.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
10. Push to your fork (git push origin better_cf-release) and
submit a pull request
selecting develop as the target branch.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: We favor pull requests with very small, single commits with a single purpose.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Your pull request is much more likely to be accepted if:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Your pull request includes tests. The runtime development team uses test driven development to help ensure high
quality code and excellent test coverage.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Your pull request is small and focused with a clear message that conveys the intent of your change.

Paragraph: Commit messages
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Please follow the rules of writing good Git commit
messages:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Separate subject from body with a blank line
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Limit the subject line to 50 characters
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Capitalize the subject line
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Do not end the subject line with a period
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Use the imperative mood in the subject line
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Wrap the body at 72 characters
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Use the body to explain what and why vs. how
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
In addition to those rules, we also like to include references to external
resources, such as Pivotal Tracker stories and GitHub issues. For example, at
the bottom of your commit messages:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
[GH: Fixes #123, Related: #432, #111]
[finishes #3494307298](https://www.pivotaltracker.com/story/show/3494307298)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Also, if you're pairing or working with more people on your commit, we encourage
you to use the Co-authored-by line in order to attribute credit to everyone
that contributed. For example (yes you can have as many of those as you want):
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Co-authored-by: Rob Boshman <rboshman@cloudfoundry.org>
Co-authored-by: Alice Boshington <aboshington@cloudfoundry.org>
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Before You Do Any Work
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: A goal of this project is to be accepted into the .NET Foundation. Probably this will only be possible if/when this project becomes popular. However, it will be a goal to transfer copyright ownership of all project code for all of the cloudscribe projects to the foundation. This means that to contribute any code to this project, you must also be willing and able to transfer copyright ownership of any code you submit to this project so that we will have the ability to later transfer it to the .NET Foundation.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: For any contributions of more than a few lines of code, we will need a signed copyright transfer statement before we can review your submission. Later, if these projects do become part of the .NET Foundation, the process will change and you will need to have a contribution agreement on file with the foundation.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Please do not do any work that you plan to submit as a pull request before discussing it first. Before you do any significant work you should first open an issue indicating what you specifically are interested in working on. We can then have a discussion about whether what you propose is in line with our plans and direction for the project as well as whether the timing is right for the specifc changes you have in mind or whether there may be other planned things that should be done first. Later this issue can be referenced by a pull request.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
Until we get to know each other, it is probably a good idea for new contributors to pick something relatively focused and small that they would like to work on.
Try to follow good open source contribution etiquette, and try not to be a code wanderer.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: At the moment this set of projects has very little unit test code. That is something we would like to change and I can tell you that starting out by contributing some unit test code would be a very good way to to make a first positive impact on this project and begin to earn recognition and trust from the project maintainers.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: Contributing to CMB2
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Thank you for your interest in contributing back to CMB2. Please help us review your issues and/or merge your pull requests by following the below guidelines.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: NOTE: The issues section is for bug reports and feature requests only.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Support is not offered for this library, and the likelihood that the maintainers will respond is very low. If you need help, please use stackoverflow, or the wordpress.org plugin forums.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Before reporting a bug
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 1.  Please review the documentation. Most questions revolve around the field types, field parameters, or are addressed in the troubleshooting section.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 2.  Search issues to see if the issue has been previously reported.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 3.  Install the develop version of CMB2 and test there.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: How to report a bug
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 1.  Specify the version number for both WordPress and CMB2.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 2.  Describe the problem in detail. Explain what happened, and what you expected would happen.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 3.  Provide a small test-case and a link to a gist containing your entire metabox registration code.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 4.  If helpful, include a screenshot. Annotate the screenshot for clarity.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: How to contribute to CMB2
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: All contributions welcome. If you would like to submit a pull request, please follow the steps below.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 1.  Make sure you have a GitHub account.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 2.  Fork the repository on GitHub.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 3.  Check out the develop version of CMB2. If you submit to the master branch, the PR will be closed with a link back to this document.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 4.  Verify your issue still exists in the develop branch.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 5.  Make changes to your clone of the repository.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 1.  Please follow the WordPress code standards.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: 2.  If possible, and if applicable, please also add/update unit tests for your changes.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 3.  Please add documentation to any new functions, methods, actions and filters.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: 4.  When committing, reference your issue (if present) and include a note about the fix.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 6.  Submit a pull request.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Note: You may gain more ground and avoid unecessary effort if you first open an issue with the proposed changes, but this step is not necessary.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Translations
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: If you are looking to provide language translation files, Please do so via WordPress Plugin Translations.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Creating/Running Tests
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: We use PHPUnit and the WordPress test suite for our unit/integration tests.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 1.  You can install the WordPress test suite using the installer: bash tests/bin/install-wp-tests.sh wordpress_test root ''. (this will install the test suite in the temp folder on your computer, using a test database with those given credentials)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 2.  Install PHPUnit via composer, composer install.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 3.  Once Composer and the WordPress test sutie are installed, you can run phpunit via ./vendor/bin/phpunit in the CMB2 directory.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: How to contribute
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Unfortunately we all can't work on cmder every day of the year, so I have decided to write some guidelines for contributing.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: If you follow them your contribution will likely be pulled in quicker.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Getting Started
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Fork the repository on GitHub (It's that easy)
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Create a feature branch based on the master branch.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Making Changes
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Make changes in your separate branch.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Check for unnecessary whitespace with git diff --check before committing.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Make sure your commit messages are easy to understand
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Squash your 'Correcting mistakes' commits if you have a lot of them. (See the 'Squashing Commits' link below)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Make sure your changes won't affect new users or user without a customised system, try out your changes on a fresh Windows VM to see if it would affect a new user's experience.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Sometimes a change that helps you with your cmder experience and tools doesn't always mean other people may need/want it.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Making Trivial Changes
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Documentation
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - If the documentation is about a currently available feature in cmder or correcting already created documentation, you can safely make your changes on the master branch and pull request them onto master.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Submitting Changes
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Push your changes to the branch in your fork of the repository.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Submit a pull request to the develop branch of the cmder repository (unless it's a change in documentation [see above]).
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Make sure you explicitly say to not complete the pull request if you are still making changes.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: File an issue
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Please check peloton's GitHub issue tracker for known issues.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: You can report bugs and feature requests to GitHub Issues.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: When you file a bug, please try to follow these simple rules if applicable:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Make sure you've read the README carefully.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Add debug information to the issue by building Peloton with the --enable-debug option
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Provide information about your environment: versions of your OS, compiler, etc.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Make sure that the issue is reproducible with your description.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: It's likely that your bug gets resolved faster if you provide as much information as possible.
Label: No categories identified.

Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: DCO Requirements
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: This project welcomes contributions and suggestions. To contribute to the specification, you must sign off every commit you contributed as acknowledgement of the DCO. The repository's DCO bot will check to ensure that every commit is signed, and will block any unsigned commits.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: The easiest way to sign-off a commit is to use the Git --signoff/-s flag: git commit -s.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Specifications subject to the Open Web Foundation Agreements.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
In addition, by making a contribution to specifications in this repository, you, on behalf of yourself, your employer, and its affiliates, are making those contributions subject to the obligations set forth in the OWF Contributor License Agreement 1.0 - Copyright and Patent.
Final specifications developed in this repository will be subject to the Open Web Foundation Final Specification Agreement (.  OWFa 1.0 will be applied as follows:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - The maintainer will notify all contributors to a designated specification in writing via provided contact information of the start of a 30 day review period, after which the specification will be subject to the OWFa 1.0.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - During that 30 day period, contributors may provide written notice to the maintainer that the contributor is not making the forgoing commitment under OWFa 1.0 for the designated specification (
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Upon the end of that 30 day notice period, those contributors who have not issued an Exclusion, on behalf of themselves, their employer, and its affiliates, will, without further action, be subject to the obligations set forth in the OWFa 1.0 for the designated specification.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Contributing Guide
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Hi! I'm really excited that you are interested in contributing to Canvas. The following guide will help you get your environment set up to begin making changes.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Table of Contents
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - OS Tools
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Development Setup
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Git
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Database
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Authentication
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Directories
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Installation
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Developing
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Before you get started
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Make sure the Vue DevTools extension is installed in your Chrome browser
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: - Add the following function from Caleb Porzio to your ~/.bashrc, ~/.bash_profile or ~/.zshrc:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: composer-link() {composer config repositories.local '{"type": "path", "url": "'$1'"}' --file composer.json}
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Development Setup
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Git
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Fork the project on https://github.com/cnvs/canvas to your own account. Then clone the fork with the following command:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: git clone https://github.com/your-account/canvas.git
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: In an adjacent directory from where you cloned the repo, create a new Laravel project with the following command:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: composer create-project --prefer-dist laravel/laravel blog
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Database
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: The fastest way to get a database up and running is to issue the following command:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: touch database/database.sqlite
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Now update your .env file to reflect the new database:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: DB_CONNECTION=sqlite
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Authentication
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Note: It's assumed we're developing on Laravel 6.* since that's the current LTS
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: From your Laravel app, create the authentication system and run the following commands:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: composer require laravel/ui
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
php artisan ui vue --auth
php artisan migrate
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Directories
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: From your Laravel app, link the local version of Canvas using the composer-link() function:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
composer-link ../canvas/
composer require cnvs/canvas @dev
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Installation
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Now that the projects are linked, run the following installation steps:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
php artisan canvas:install
php artisan storage:link
php artisan canvas:ui
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Statistics are a core component to the app, so it's best to have a large dataset in place when developing. To generate some, add the following snippets to your Laravel app:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Create a new class named CanvasTrackingDataSeeder and add this to the run() method:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
\Illuminate\Support\Facades\DB::table('canvas_views')->truncate();
\Illuminate\Support\Facades\DB::table('canvas_visits')->truncate();
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
factory(\Canvas\View::class, 2500)->create();
factory(\Canvas\Visit::class, 2500)->create();
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: In the run() method of the DatabaseSeeder:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: $this->call(CanvasTrackingDataSeeder::class);
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Create a new factory named ViewFactory and add this definition:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
$factory->define(\Canvas\View::class, function (\Faker\Generator $faker) {
$timestamp = today()->subDays(rand(0, 60))->toDateTimeString();
Label: BW – Build local workspace
BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Create a new factory named VisitFactory and add this definition:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
$factory->define(\Canvas\Visit::class, function (\Faker\Generator $faker) {
$timestamp = today()->subDays(rand(0, 60))->toDateTimeString();
Label: BW – Build local workspace
BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: You can now run php artisan db:seed and you will have a substantial amount of views for each post.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Developing
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Instead of making and compiling frontend changes in the package, then having to re-publish the assets in the Laravel app again and again, we can utilize a symlink:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
# remove the existing assets from the Laravel app
rm -rf public/vendor/canvas/*
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
# go inside the empty directory and create a symlink
cd public/vendor/canvas
ln -s ../../../../canvas/public/* .
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Once you've made your changes, create a pull request from your fork to the develop branch of the project repository.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Do
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Search the solutions in the troubleshooting guide. Or any of the many other guides.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Search tickets before you file a new one. Add to tickets if you have new information about the issue.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- Only file tickets about the CocoaPods tool itself. This includes CocoaPods,
CocoaPods/Core, and Xcodeproj.
If your question is regarding a library (to be) distributed through CocoaPods, refer to the spec repo.
If your question is StackOverflow or our mailing-list.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Keep tickets short but sweet. Make sure you include all the context needed to solve the issue. Don't overdo it. Great tickets allow us to focus on solving problems instead of discussing them.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Take care of your ticket. When you spend time to report a ticket with care we'll enjoy fixing it for you.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Use GitHub-flavored Markdown. Especially put code blocks and console outputs in backticks (```). That increases the readability. Bonus points for applying the appropriate syntax highlighting. (Tip: Podfiles are written in a Ruby DSL.)
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Do not litter. Donunless specifically asked for and don
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Spell the name of the project correctly. It's CocoaPods. In upper camel case.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Bug Reports
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: In short, since you are most likely a developer, provide a ticket that you yourself would like to receive.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
We are not here to support your individual projects. We depend on you (the community)
to contribute in making the tool better for everyone. So debug and reduce your own issues
before creating a ticket and let us know of all the things you tried and their outcome.
This applies double if you cannot share a reproduction with us because of internal company
policies.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
First check if you are using the latest CocoaPods version before filing a ticket.
You can install the latest version with $ [sudo] gem install cocoapods.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Then check if the same problem applies with the same Podfile but in a completely new
and empty application Xcode project, thus excluding whether or not there is an issue with
conflicting settings.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Please include steps to reproduce and all other relevant information, including the
version of CocoaPods and any template printed by the tool.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
If questions in the error template are left unanswered, the issue will be closed
as a bad bug report.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
If there is a regression in the projects generated by CocoaPods please include
the output (redacted if needed) of one of the following commands:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
$ xcodeproj target-diff
$ xcodeproj project-diff
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
If you are familiar with Ruby, making a pull request with a failing test case
can speed up the resolution of the bug. If the issue is more complex you can
add an integration test
which doesn't require any ruby knowledge.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Feature Requests
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Please try to be precise about the proposed outcome of the feature and how it
would related to existing features.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: From the CocoaPods blog:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Fighting feature creep in CocoaPods is not easy. We hear about a lot of great ideas and many of them don't make the cut as they would not be useful for at least 80% of our users.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Should you require a feature isn't suited for mainstream users, consider suggesting a CocoaPods plugin instead.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Pull Requests
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
We love pull requests and if a contribution is significant we tend to offer
push access. We suggest you take a look at our Contributing guide for info on development setup, and some of our best practices.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: All contributions will be licensed under the MIT license.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Code/comments should adhere to the following rules:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Names should be descriptive and concise.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Use two spaces and no tabs.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- All changes require test coverage to ensure it does not break during refactor
work. (There are a few exceptions to this, which can be recognised by there
not being any coverage for similar code.)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- CocoaPods uses bacon as a test runner.
To run all tests, use bundle exec rake spec in the root of the
Rainforest repo. If you want to run
a specific test instead, use bundle exec bacon spec/[folder]/[name]_spec.rb
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - All enhancements and bug fixes need to be documented in the CHANGELOG.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- When writing comments, use properly constructed sentences, including
punctuation.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- When documenting APIs and/or source code, don't make assumptions or make
implications about race, gender, religion, political orientation or anything
else that isn't relevant to the project.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- Remember that source code usually gets written once and read often: ensure
the reader doesn't have to make guesses. Make sure that the purpose and inner
logic are either obvious to a reasonably skilled professional, or add a
comment that explains it.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- The message of the commit should be prefixed by the name of the file which is
the main focus of the patch enclosed by square brackets (.e.g. [Installer] install pods).
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: No Brown M&M
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
If you made it all the way to the end, bravo dear user, we love you. You can include
this emoji in the top of your ticket to signal to us that you did in fact read this
file and are trying to conform to it as best as possible: ?
Label: No categories identified.
