Paragraph: Submitting patches
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: If you want to contribute code, please follow these steps:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: (If you are new to git and/or GitHub, you should read Pro Git , especially the section on Contributing to a project:Small/Large Public Project )
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Download the latest cocos2d-x develop branch from github:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
$ git clone git://github.com/cocos2d/cocos2d-x.git
$ cd cocos2d-x
$ git checkout v3
$ ./download-deps.py
$ git submodule update --init
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: - Apply your changes in the recently downloaded repository
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Commit your changes in your own repository
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Create a new branch with your patch: $ git checkout -b my_fix_branch
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Push your new branch to your public repository
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: "- Send a “pull request” to user “cocos2d”"
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - It must be complete. See the definition below
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - It must follow the Releases rules. See the definition below
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Only complete patches will be merged
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: The patch must be complete. And by that, we mean:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - For C++ code follow the Cocos2d C++ Coding Style
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - For Python code follow the PEP8 guidelines
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Describe what the patch does
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Include test cases if applicable
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Include unit tests if applicable
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Must be tested in all supported platforms [*]
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Must NOT degrade the performance
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Must NOT break existing tests cases
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Must NOT break the Continuous Integration build
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Must NOT break backward compatibility
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Must compile WITHOUT warnings
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - New APIs MUST be easy to use, familiar to cocos2d-x users
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Code MUST be easy to extend and maintain
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Must have documentation: C++ APIs must use Doxygen strings, tools must have a README.md file that describe how to use the tool
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Must be efficient (fast / low memory needs)
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - It must not duplicate existing code, unless the new code deprecates the old one
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Patches that refactor key components will only be merged in the next major versions.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: [*]: If you don't have access to test your code in all the supported platforms, let us know.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: TBD: Is this applicable for big features ? What is the best way to merge big features ?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: How to contribute
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
We like to encourage you to contribute to the repository.
This should be as easy as possible for you but there are a few things to consider when contributing.
The following guidelines for contribution should be followed if you want to submit a pull request.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Contributor License Agreement
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Please also sign the Codebox contributor license agreement so we can accept your pull requests. It is easy, you can do it using your CodeboxIO account.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: How to prepare
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - You need a GitHub account
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Submit an issue ticket for your issue if the is no one yet.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Describe the issue and include steps to reproduce if it's a bug.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Make Changes

Paragraph: - In your forked repository, create a topic branch for your upcoming patch. (e.g. feature--autoplay or bugfix--ios-crash)

Paragraph:
Following these guidelines helps to communicate that you respect the time of
the developers managing and developing this open source project. In return,
they should reciprocate that respect in addressing your issue or assessing
patches and features.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Using the issue tracker
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
The issue tracker is the preferred channel for bug reports,
features requests and
submitting pull requests, but please respect the
following restrictions:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- Please do not use the issue tracker for personal support requests. Stack
Overflow is a better place to get help.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- Please do not derail or troll issues. Keep the discussion on topic and
respect the opinions of others.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- Please do not open issues or pull requests which belongs to third party
components.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Bug reports
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
A bug is a demonstrable problem that is caused by the code in the repository.
Good bug reports are extremely helpful, so thanks!
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Guidelines for bug reports:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
1.  Use the GitHub issue search — check if the issue has already been
reported.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
2.  Check if the issue has been fixed — try to reproduce it using the
latest master or development branch in the repository.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
3.  Isolate the problem — ideally create an
SSCCE and a live example.
Uploading the project on cloud storage (OneDrive, DropBox, et al.)
or creating a sample GitHub repository is also helpful.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
A good bug report shouldn't leave others needing to chase you up for more
information. Please try to be as detailed as possible in your report. What is
your environment? What steps will reproduce the issue? What browser(s) and OS
experience the problem? Do other browsers show the bug differently? What
would you expect to be the outcome? All these details will help people to fix
any potential bugs.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Example:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Short and descriptive example bug report title
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
A summary of the issue and the Visual Studio, browser, OS environments
in which it occurs. If suitable, include the steps required to reproduce the bug.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 1.  This is the first step
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 2.  This is the second step
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 3.  Further steps, etc.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: <url> - a link to the project/file uploaded on cloud storage or other publicly accessible medium.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Any other information you want to share that is relevant to the issue being
reported. This might include the lines of code that you have identified as
causing the bug, and potential solutions (and your opinions on their
merits).
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Feature requests
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Feature requests are welcome. But take a moment to find out whether your idea
fits with the scope and aims of the project. It's up to you to make a strong
case to convince the project's developers of the merits of this feature. Please
provide as much detail and context as possible.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Pull requests
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Good pull requests, patches, improvements and new features are a fantastic
help. They should remain focused in scope and avoid containing unrelated
commits.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Please ask first before embarking on any significant pull request (e.g.
implementing features, refactoring code, porting to a different language),
otherwise you risk spending a lot of time working on something that the
project's developers might not want to merge into the project.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph:
Please adhere to the coding guidelines used throughout the
project (indentation, accurate comments, etc.) and any other requirements
(such as test coverage).
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
Adhering to the following process is the best way to get your work
included in the project:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
1.  Fork the project, clone your fork,
and configure the remotes:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
# Clone your fork of the repo into the current directory
git clone https://github.com/codecadwallader/codemaid.git
# Navigate to the newly cloned directory
cd <folder-name>
# Assign the original repo to a remote called "upstream"
git remote add upstream https://github.com/codecadwallader/codemaid.git
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 2.  If you cloned a while ago, get the latest changes from upstream:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
git checkout master
git pull upstream master
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
3.  Create a new topic branch (off the main project development branch) to
contain your feature, change, or fix:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git checkout -b <topic-branch-name>
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
4.  Commit your changes in logical chunks. Please adhere to these git commit
message guidelines
or your code is unlikely be merged into the main project. Use Git's
interactive rebase
feature to tidy up your commits before making them public. Also, prepend name of the feature
to the commit message. For instance: "SCSS: Fixes compiler results for IFileListener.\nFixes #123"
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 5.  Locally merge (or rebase) the upstream development branch into your topic branch:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git pull [--rebase] upstream master
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 6.  Push your topic branch up to your fork:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git push origin <topic-branch-name>
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
7.  Open a Pull Request
with a clear title and description against the master branch.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Contributions
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
We expect all contributions to conform to our style guide, be commented (inside the PHP source files),
be documented (in the user guide), and unit tested (in the test folder).
There is a Contributing to CodeIgniter section in the repository which describes the contribution process; this page is an overview.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Note, we expect all code changes or bug-fixes to be accompanied by one or more tests added to our test suite to prove the code works. If pull requests are not accompanied by relevant tests, they will likely be closed. Since we are a team of volunteers, we don't have any more time to work on the framework than you do. Please make it as painless for your contributions to be included as possible. If you need help with getting tests running on your local machines, ask for help on the forums. We would be happy to help out.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: The Open Source Guide is a good first read for those new to contributing to open source!

Paragraph: Issues
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Issues are a quick way to point out a bug. If you find a bug or documentation error in CodeIgniter then please make sure that:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 1.  There is not already an open Issue
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 2.  The Issue has not already been fixed (check the develop branch or look for closed Issues)
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 3.  It's not something really obvious that you can fix yourself
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Reporting Issues is helpful, but an even better approach is to send a Pull Request, which is done by Forking the main repository and making a Commit to your own copy of the project. This will require you to use the version control system called Git.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Guidelines
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Before we look into how to contribute to CodeIgniter4, here are some guidelines. If your Pull Requests fail
to pass these guidelines, they will be declined, and you will need to re-submit
when you
for us to maintain the quality of the codebase.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: PHP Style
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
All code must meet the Style Guide.
This makes certain that all submitted code is of the same format as the existing code and ensures that the codebase will be as readable as possible.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Documentation
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: If you change anything that requires a change to documentation, then you will need to add to the documentation. New classes, methods, parameters, changing default values, etc. are all changes that require a change to documentation. Also, the changelog must be updated for every change, and PHPDoc blocks must be maintained.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Compatibility
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: CodeIgniter4 requires PHP 7.2.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Branching
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
CodeIgniter4 uses the Git-Flow branching model which requires all
Pull Requests to be sent to the "develop" branch; this is where the next planned version will be developed.
The "master" branch will always contain the latest stable version and is kept clean so a "hotfix" (e.g. an
emergency security patch) can be applied to the "master" branch to create a new version, without worrying
about other features holding it up. For this reason, all commits need to be made to the "develop" branch,
and any sent to the "master" branch will be closed automatically. If you have multiple changes to submit,
please place all changes into their own branch on your fork.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
One thing at a time: A pull request should only contain one change. That does not mean only one commit,
but one change - however many commits it took. The reason for this is that if you change X and Y,
but send a pull request for both at the same time, we might really want X but disagree with Y,
meaning we cannot merge the request. Using the Git-Flow branching model you can create new
branches for both of these features and send two requests.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
A reminder: please use separate branches for each of your PRs - it will make it easier for you to keep changes separate from
each other and from whatever else you are doing with your repository!
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Signing
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: You must GPG-sign your work, certifying that you either wrote the work or otherwise have the right to pass it on to an open-source project. This is not just a "signed-off-by" commit, but instead, a digitally signed one.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: How-to Guide
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: The best way to contribute is to fork the CodeIgniter4 repository, and "clone" that to your development area. That sounds like some jargon, but "forking" on GitHub means "making a copy of that repo to your account" and "cloning" means "copying that code to your environment so you can work on it".
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 1.  Set up Git (Windows, Mac, & Linux).
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 2.  Go to the CodeIgniter4 repository.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 3.  Fork it (to your Github account).
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 4.  Clone your CodeIgniter repository: git@github.com:\<your-name>/CodeIgniter4.git
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 5.  Create a new branch in your project for each set of changes you want to make.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 6.  Fix existing bugs on the Issue tracker after confirming that no one else is working on them.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 7.  Commit the changed files in your contribution branch.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 8.  Push your contribution branch to your fork.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 9.  Send a pull request.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: The codebase maintainers will now be alerted to the submission and someone from the team will respond. If your change fails to meet the guidelines, it will be rejected or feedback will be provided to help you improve it.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Once the maintainer handling your pull request is satisfied with it they will approve the pull request and merge it into the "develop" branch; your patch will now be part of the next release!
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Keeping your fork up-to-date
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Unlike systems like Subversion, Git can have multiple remotes. A remote is the name for the URL of a Git repository. By default, your fork will have a remote named "origin", which points to your fork, but you can add another remote named "codeigniter", which points to git://github.com/codeigniter4/CodeIgniter4.git. This is a read-only remote, but you can pull from this develop branch to update your own.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: If you are using the command-line, you can do the following to update your fork to the latest changes:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 1.  git remote add codeigniter git://github.com/codeigniter4/CodeIgniter4.git
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 2.  git pull codeigniter develop
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 3.  git push origin develop
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Your fork is now up to date. This should be done regularly and, at the least, before you submit a pull request.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
Community discussion, questions, and informal bug reporting is done on the

Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Submitting bug reports
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
The preferred way to report bugs is to use the
GitHub issue tracker. Before
reporting a bug, read these pointers.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Note: The issue tracker is for bugs, not requests for help. Questions
should be asked on the
discuss.CodeMirror forum instead.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Reporting bugs effectively
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- CodeMirror is maintained by volunteers. They don't owe you anything, so be
polite. Reports with an indignant or belligerent tone tend to be moved to the
bottom of the pile.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- Include information about the browser in which the problem occurred. Even
if you tested several browsers, and the problem occurred in all of them,
mention this fact in the bug report. Also include browser version numbers and
the operating system that you're on.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- Mention which release of CodeMirror you're using. Preferably, try also with
the current development snapshot, to ensure the problem has not already been
fixed.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- Mention very precisely what went wrong. "X is broken" is not a good bug
report. What did you expect to happen? What happened instead? Describe the
exact steps a maintainer has to take to make the problem occur. We can not
fix something that we can not observe.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- If the problem can not be reproduced in any of the demos included in the
CodeMirror distribution, please provide an HTML document that demonstrates
the problem. The best way to do this is to go to
jsbin.com, enter it there, press save, and
include the resulting link in your bug report.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Contributing code
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Note that we are not accepting any new addons or modes into the main
distribution. If you've written such a module, please distribute it as
a separate NPM package.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Make sure you have a GitHub Account
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
- Fork CodeMirror
(how to fork a repo)
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Make your changes
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
- If your changes are easy to test or likely to regress, add tests.
Tests for the core go into test/test.js, some modes have their own
test suite under mode/XXX/test.js. Feel free to add new test
suites to modes that don't have one yet (be sure to link the new
tests into test/index.html).
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Follow the general code style of the rest of the project (see
below). Run bin/lint to verify that the linter is happy.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- Make sure all tests pass. Visit test/index.html in your browser to
run them.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Submit a pull request
(how to create a pull request).
Don't put more than one feature/fix in a single pull request.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: By contributing code to CodeMirror you
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- agree to license the contributed code under CodeMirror's MIT
license.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- confirm that you have the right to contribute and license the code
in question. (Either you hold all rights on the code, or the rights
holder has explicitly granted the right to use it like this,
through a compatible open source license or through a direct
agreement with you.)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Coding standards
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - 2 spaces per indentation level, no tabs.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- Note that the linter (bin/lint) which is run after each commit
complains about unused variables and functions. Prefix their names
with an underscore to muffle it.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- CodeMirror does not follow JSHint or JSLint prescribed style.
Patches that try to 'fix' code to pass one of these linters will be
unceremoniously discarded.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: How to work on Coderwall using Vagrant on VirtualBox
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Sure you could download and install all the dependencies, services, and what not on to your local workstation but ain't nobody got time for that mess.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: To save time and headaches we use Vagrant. Vagrant is a automation tool for VirtualBox that will help you spin up a virtual environment with pretty much everything in place and ready for you to start hacking (even on Windows!)
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Here's everything you need to get started working on Coderwall with Vagrant TODAY!
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: At the time of writing this document we were using VirtualBox 4.3.20 and Vagrant 1.6.5.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: WE ARE USING VIRTUALBOX 4.3.20 DUE TO COMPATABILITY ISSUES WITH VBOX GUEST ADDITIONS.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Vagrant! I already know what to do.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: If you're an experienced Vagrant user then you can fetch the base box and register it yourself.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: There's only a VirtualBox basebox right now.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: vagrant box add coderwall_v3 https://s3.amazonaws.com/coderwall-assets-0/vagrant/coderwall_v3.box
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Vagrant? VirtualBox? Let's take this one step at a time.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: If you're running Windows, here's a guide written by one of our members on how to get set up.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 1.  Install VirtualBox
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Grab the VirtualBox installer from here.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Download the Vbox installer and extensions from here
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: The required version is VirtualBox 4.3.20.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: I recommend installing VirtualBox 4.3.20 Oracle VM VirtualBox Extension Pack for the extra drivers.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 2.  Install Vagrant
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
Vagrant is the recommended way to run Coderwall on your own machine. You need to download and install.
Grab the Vagrant installer from here.
At the time of writing this documentation the current version is Vagrant 1.6.5.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Follow the installation instructions for your platform on the Vagrant download page.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: After installing Vagrant we need to add a couple plugins.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: If you're on a OS X/Linux system you can install the plugins by running:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
vagrant plugin install vagrant-vbguest
vagrant plugin install vagrant-cachier
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: The vagrant-vbguest plugin will each help with keeping the VirtualBox Guest Additions up-to-date.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 3.  Git assemblymade/coderwall
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Fork the code if you haven't already done so.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
mkdir -p ~/assemblymade
cd ~/assemblymade
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Depending on your choice of protocols: (this will take a while to run so you may want to grab some coffee)
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: - git clone https://github.com/your_username/coderwall.git coderwall
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: - git clone git@github.com:your_username/coderwall.git coderwall
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Add upstream:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: - git remote add upstream https://github.com/assemblymade/coderwall.git
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: - git remote add upstream git@github.com:assemblymade/coderwall.git
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: I am going to assume that the project is cloned into your home directory in and into a directory structure like ~/assemblymade/coderwall.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 4.  Fire it up! Fire it up! Fire it up!
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Now that you've got VirtualBox and Vagrant installed with the source code cloned in ~/assemblymade/coderwall we can start up the Vagrant instance.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
cd ~/assemblymade/coderwall
./run.sh # or run.bat if you're on Windows
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Since this is probably the first time you're running this command it's going to take a VERY long time (bandwidth willing) to run. This is because Vagrant needs to fetch the Coderwall base box from the Internet and it's about 1.4GB.  Fortunately that really only has to be done once (unless the base box get's updated but that's another story).
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Once Vagrant reports that you're booted up and ready to go then you'll be able to SSH into the local vm similiar to any other remote box.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
# still in ~/assemblymade/coderwall
vagrant ssh
# whoa!
pwd
hostname
ls -al
# We're not in localhost any longer... well, you get what I mean
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Now that you're SSH'ed into the Vagrant VM it's time to run the app.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
# we're still SSH'ed into Vbox
cd ~/web
rvm current # should be ruby-2.1.2@coderwall
bundle check # should be 'The Gemfile's dependencies are satisfied'
rails s
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: If all went well the Rails server should start up on PORT 3000.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Now go open your favorite web browser on you host machine and navigate to http://localhost:3000.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: If all goes well (and if it doesn't then check if another app is running on port 3000 and if there's any logging output being displayed in the window you were running Vagrant in) then you're going to be looking at the Coderwall homepage.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Congratulations! NOW GET TO WORK! Enough dilly-dallying with your DEV env.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 5.  Hackety Hack!
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Vagrant is powerful not just because it can abstract away the mess of managing a crazy, complicated development environment while ensuring everyone has a common platform to work on. It's also powerful because it will still let you have whatever crazy, complicated editors and tools to work on your code while abstracting away the nasty details of installing and configuring Postgres.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: If you're on your host computer and navigate to ~/assemblymade/coderwall (we're all there, right?) and make changes to your code while Vagrant is running you'll be able to see the changes reflected in Vagrant immediately. Try this.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
cd ~/assemblymade/coderwall
echo Hello, `whoami` from `hostname` >> HELLO.txt
vagrant ssh
cd ~/assemblymade
cat HELLO.txt #whoa.
echo Hello, `whoami` from `hostname` >> HELLO.txt
exit
cat HELLO.txt # wah-wah-wee-wa!
rm -f HELLO.txt # yeah, it's deleted in the other spot too.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Yeah, that's pretty awesome. Remember that NFS thing we glossed over earlier? That's the mechanism that Vagrant set up with VirtualBox to transparently synchronize your local folder with the folder on the VM. Now you can edit and manage your files from the comfort of your favorite OS without having to worry about copying them to the VM.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 6.  All done for the day - Turning your Vagrant VM off
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: When you're ready to call it a day and want to turn the VM off you have two options.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: You can either "turn the VM off" using vagrant halt or you can suspend the VM using vagrant suspend.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Either way when you're ready to resume working just vagrant up and you're good to go.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 7.  Gems Installation and Database Migration
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Remember that you are using Vagrant, so if you run bundle install or rake db:migrate directly in your terminal it will not affect the virtual machine where Coderwall is running.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: In order to run these commands, in the virtual machine, all you have to do is to run vagrant provision.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 8.  Environment Variables
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: If you need to change any environment variable you have to edit .env file properly and restart Rails server running:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: vagrant reload ; ./run.sh
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 9.  Thanks
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: I hope you enjoy working with Vagrant as much as we do and feel free to ask questions if you get stuck or have a problem. You're probably not alone and even if you're the first to encounter a rough patch you won't be the last.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Code of Conduct
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph:
We have a code of conduct you can find here and every
contributor is expected to obey the rules therein. Any issues or PRs that don't
abide by the code of conduct may be closed.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Code Organization
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
The CodeSandbox client is currently divided in to 5 parts. We use lerna to
share dependencies between these parts.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - app: The editor, the search, profile page, the embed and the sandbox.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - homepage: The Gatsby website of the homepage.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - common: All common parts between these packages, reusable JS.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- codesandbox-api: The npm package that's responsible for communication
between the sandbox and the editor.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- codesandbox-browserfs: An in-browser file system that emulates the Node JS
file system API and supports storing and retrieving files from various
backends. Forked from
https://github.com/jvilk/BrowserFS, with
an additional
CodeSandbox backend.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
This version of CodeSandbox is using the production server as source of truth,
this is specified by the environment variable LOCAL_SERVER. If you're working
on a feature that needs you to be logged in, you can login on
https://codesandbox.io/ and copy the contents of the
jwt local storage key over to your development environment on
http://localhost:3000/. Be very careful with how you
handle the token, as anyone who knows it can login as you and have read/write
access to all your CodeSandbox content!
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
Working on your first Pull Request? You can learn how from this free
series
How to Contribute to an Open Source Project on GitHub
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Setting Up the project locally
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: To install the project you need to have yarn and node
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
1.  Fork the project, clone
your fork:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
# Clone your fork
git clone https://github.com/<your-username>/codesandbox-client.git
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
# Navigate to the newly cloned directory
cd codesandbox-client
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 2.  Your environment needs to be running Node v. 10
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: - .nvmrc config exists in the repo root, specifying a v.10.x.x version
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
- you can use fnm (fnm use) to change
your current node version to the one specified in .nvmrc
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 3.  from the root of the project: yarn to install all dependencies
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: - make sure you have latest yarn version
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 4.  from the root of the project: yarn start
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
- this builds the dependencies (codesandbox-api and
codesandbox-browserfs) and runs the app development environment,
available on http://localhost:3000/s/new
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
- on subsequent runs you can also bypass dependencies building and use
yarn start:fast
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
- if you want to work on the homepage, start it with yarn start:home, it
will be available on http://localhost:8000/
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
Tip: Keep your master branch pointing at the original repository and make
pull requests from branches on your fork. To do this, run:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
git remote add upstream https://github.com/codesandbox/codesandbox-client.git
git fetch upstream
git branch --set-upstream-to=upstream/master master
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
This will add the original repository as a "remote" called "upstream," then
fetch the git information from that remote, then set your local master
branch to use the upstream master branch whenever you run git pull. Then you
can make all of your pull request branches based on this master branch.
Whenever you want to update your version of master, do a regular git pull.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
5.  If you want to debug the state of the app, install the
Cerebral Debugger
and connect it to the port 8383. After that, if you refresh the app, you
should be able to see the state, the sequences executed and so on. See
documentation for
reference.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Pull Requests
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: The pull request process differs for new features and bugs. Before sending a pull request for a new feature, you should first create an issue with [Proposal] in the title. The proposal should describe the new feature, as well as implementation ideas. The proposal will then be reviewed and either approved or denied. Once a proposal is approved, a pull request may be created implementing the new feature. Pull requests which do not follow this guideline will be closed immediately.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Pull requests for bugs may be sent without creating any proposal issue. If you believe that you know of a solution for a bug that has been filed, please leave a comment detailing your proposed fix.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Feature Requests
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: If you have an idea for a new feature you would like to see added to the package, you may create an issue with [Request] in the title. The feature request will then be reviewed by a core contributor.
Label: No categories identified.

$ brew install redis memcached && brew cask install phantomjs

Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: - URL: http://localhost:3000

Paragraph: - Callback URL: http://localhost:3000/users/auth/github/callback

Paragraph: Then add the credentials to your .env file:

Paragraph: Tests
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
$ bin/rake db:create RAILS_ENV=test
$ bin/rake db:schema:load RAILS_ENV=test
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: You may need a github API token to run tests locally. You can get this by spinning your local server, clicking the "sign in" button and going through the OAuth flow.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Note you may need to create your own app on GitHub for CodeTriage
here, and replace the values
previously set (via the above) for GITHUB_APP_ID and GITHUB_APP_SECRET in
order to complete the OAuth flow locally.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Once you've done this spin down your server and run this:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
$ bin/rails c
> `echo GITHUB_API_KEY=#{User.last.token} >> .env`
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Make sure it shows up in your .env:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: > puts File.read(".env")
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Now you should be able to run tests
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: $ bin/rake test
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Writing tests
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: If you need to mock out some github requests please use VCR. Put anything that may create an external request inside of a vcr block:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
VCR.use_cassette('my_vcr_cassette_name_here') do
# ... code goes here
end
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Make sure to name your cassette something unique. The first time you run tests you'll need to set a record mode. This will make a real-life request to github using your GITHUB_API_KEY you specified in the .env and record the result. The next time you run your tests it should use your "cassette" instead of actually hitting github. All secrets including your GITHUB_API_KEY are filtered out, so you can safely commit the resultant. When running on travis the VCR cassettes are used to eliminate/minimize actual calls to Github.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: The benefit of using VCR over stubbing/mocking methods is that we could swap out implementations if we wanted.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Make sure to remove any record modes from your VCR cassette before committing.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Modifying Tests
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: If you need to modify a test locally and the VCR cassette doesn't have the correct information, you can run with new episodes enabled.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Make sure to remove any record modes from your VCR cassette before committing.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Flow
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - A user subscribes to a repo
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Consume API: Once a day, find all the repos that haven't been updated in 24 hours, produce issue subscription.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Issue Assigning [repo]: Find all users subscribed to that repo that haven't been assigned an issue in 24 hours, pick a random issue that the user is not a part of and send them an email.
Label: No categories identified.

By contributing, you agree that your contributions will be licensed under its MIT License.

Paragraph: How to contribute
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
We like to encourage you to contribute to the repository.
This should be as easy as possible for you but there are a few things to consider when contributing.
The following guidelines for contribution should be followed if you want to submit a pull request.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: How to prepare
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - You need a GitHub account
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Submit an issue ticket for your issue if the is no one yet.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Describe the issue and include steps to reproduce if it's a bug.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Ensure to mention the earliest version that you know is affected.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - If you are able and want to fix this, fork the repository on GitHub
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Make Changes
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - In your forked repository, create a topic branch for your upcoming patch. (e.g. better favorites detection or failed-to-edit-window-fix)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Usually this is based on the master branch.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Create a branch based on master; git branch   fix/master/my_contribution master then checkout the new branch with git   checkout fix/master/my_contribution.  Please avoid working directly on the master branch.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Make sure you stick to the coding style that is used already.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Make commits of logical units and describe them properly.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Syntax:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Two spaces, no tabs.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - No trailing whitespace. Blank lines should not have any space.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - a = b and not a=b.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Follow the conventions you see used in the source already.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Submit Changes
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Push your changes to a topic branch in your fork of the repository.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Open a pull request to the original repository and choose the right original branch you want to patch.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - If not done in commit messages (which you really should do) please reference and update your issue with the code changes. But please do not close the issue yourself.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Even if you have write access to the repository, do not directly push or merge pull-requests. Let another team member review your pull request and approve.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: ##Installing the dev environment
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 1.  Fork the repo
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 2.  Clone the repo to local
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 3.  Install dependencies: composer install (this assumes you have 'composer' aliased to whereever your composer.phar lives)
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
4.  Run the tests. We only take pull requests with passing tests, and it's great to know that you have a clean slate:
./bin/phpspec run --format=pretty
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: ##The actual contribution
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 1.  Make the changes/additions to the code, committing often and making clear what you've done
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 2.  Make sure you write tests for your code, located in the folder structure spec/Coduo/PHPHumanizer/...
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 3.  Run your tests (often and while coding): ./bin/phpspec run --format=pretty
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Contributing to PetaPoco
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: There are a number of ways you can contribute to the PetaPoco project:
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: - Identifying issues - report them.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Identifying defects - Report as an issue, then PR (to development) a failing unit test(s).

Paragraph: Contribution guidelines
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Thanks for taking the time to contribute to the collectd
project! This document tries to give some guidance to
make the process of contributing to collectd as pleasant as possible.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Bug reports
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Please report bugs as GitHub
Issues. Try to answer the
following questions:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Which version of collectd are you using?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Which operating system (distribution) are you using at which version?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - What is the expected behavior / output?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - What is the actual (observed) behavior / output?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - How can we reproduce the problem you're having?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- If collectd crashes, try to get a
stack trace.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Please monitor your issue for a couple of days and reply to questions. To keep
the project manageable, we have to do some housekeeping; meaning we will close
issues that have become stale.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Code contributions
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Please open a GitHub Pull Request
(PR) to contribute bug fixes, features, cleanups, new plugins,
the mailing list have a tendency to fall through the cracks.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
- Focus: Fix one thing in your PR. The smaller your change, the faster it
will be reviewed and merged.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Coding style: Please run clang-format -style=file -i $FILE after editing
.c, .h and .proto files. If you don't want to install clang-format
locally or your version produces a different result than the formatting
check on Github, use contrib/format.sh to format files using the same web
service used by our check.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- Documentation: New config options need to be documented in two places: the
manpage (src/collectd.conf.pod) and the example config
(src/collectd.conf.in). New plugins need to be added to the README file.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- Continuous integration: Once your PR is created, our continuous
integration environment will try to build it on a number of platforms. If
this reports a failure, please investigate and fix the problem. We will at
best do a very casual review for failing PRs.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Don't rebase: Rebasing your branch destroys the review history. If a
review takes a long time, we may ask you to rebase on a more recent
master, but please don't do that without being asked.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- types.db: One of the most common mistakes made by new contributors is the
addition of (many) new types in the file src/types.db. The majority of
usecases can be met with one of the existing entries. If you plan to add new
entries to src/types.db, you should talk to us early in the design
process.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: ChangeLog
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
PRs need to have a one-line summary in the PR description. This information
is used to automatically generate release notes. If you got here after creating
the PR, you need to go to the PR description (shown as the first "comment" on
the PR, made by yourself) and edit that description. Editing a PR will
trigger the "ChangeLog" status to be updated.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: For the summary itself, follow this style:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: ChangeLog: Foo plugin: A specific issue people had has been fixed.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
The summary must be on a line of its own, with a "ChangeLog:" prefix at the
beginning of the line. The text should start with "Foo plugin" to give the
reader context for the information. Other common contexts are "collectd" for
the core daemon, "Build system", and "Documentation". Use past tense and
passive voice the for remainder, e.g. "a bug has been fixed", "a feature has
been added".
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Some PRs should be excluded from the release notes, e.g. changes to project
internal documentation (such as this file). Those changes are not interesting
for external users of the project and would reduce the value of the release
notes. Maintainers may use the Unlisted Change label to mark those PRs.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Contributing to Colmena
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Thanks for your interest in contributing to Colmena.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: As a contributor, here are the guidelines we would like you to follow:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Code of Conduct
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Question or Problem?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Issues and Bugs
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Feature Requests
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Submission Guidelines
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Commit Message Guidelines
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Code of Conduct
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Help us keep Colmena open and inclusive. Please read and follow our Code of Conduct.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Got a Question or Problem?
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph:
Please, do not open issues for the general support questions as we want to keep GitHub issues for bug reports and
feature requests. You've got much better chances of getting your question answered on Slack.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: If you have a generic question about Angular or LoopBack or one of the include projects, please refer to those projects to get help.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Found a Bug?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
If you find a bug in the source code, you can help us by
submitting an issue to our GitHub Repository. Even better, you can
submit a Pull Request with a fix.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Missing a Feature?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
You can request a new feature by submitting an issue to our GitHub
Repository. If you would like to implement a new feature, please submit an issue with
a proposal for your work first, to be sure that we can use it.
Please consider what kind of change it is:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- For a Major Feature, first open an issue and outline your proposal so that it can be
discussed. This will also allow us to better coordinate our efforts, prevent duplication of work,
and help you to craft the change so that it is successfully accepted into the project.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Small Features can be crafted and directly submitted as a Pull Request.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Submission Guidelines
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Submitting an Issue
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Before you submit an issue, please search the issue tracker, maybe an issue for your problem already exists and the
discussion might inform you of workarounds readily available.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
We want to fix all the issues as soon as possible, but before fixing a bug we need to reproduce and confirm it.
In order to reproduce bugs we might ask you to provide a minimal reproduction scenario in a fork of this project on
GitHub. Having a live, reproducible scenario gives us wealth of important information without going back & forth to you
with additional questions like:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - version of Colmena used
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - 3rd-party libraries and their versions
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - and most importantly - a use-case that fails
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
A minimal fork of the project allows us to quickly confirm a bug (or point out coding problem) as well as confirm that
we are fixing the right problem.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
We will be insisting on a minimal reproduce scenario in order to save maintainers time and ultimately be able to fix
more bugs. We understand that sometimes it might be hard to extract essentials bits of code from a larger code-base but
we really need to isolate the problem before we can fix it.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Unfortunately we are not able to investigate / fix bugs without a minimal reproduction, so if we don't hear back from
you we are going to close an issue that don't have enough info to be reproduced.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: You can file new issues by filling out our new issue form.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Submitting a Pull Request (PR)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Before you submit your Pull Request (PR) consider the following guidelines:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Don't combine multiple changes in one PR! Use multiple PR's if you have multiple changes that are not very closely
related. This will greatly enhance the chance of the PR being merged as is.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Please discuss on Slack before making large changes to the codebase. The smaller the change, the bigger the chance it
will be merged. This also prevents wasting effort on writing code that does not gets merged.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Search GitHub for an open or closed PR that relates to your submission.
You don't want to duplicate effort.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Make your changes in a new git branch:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git checkout -b my-fix-branch master
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Commit your changes using a descriptive commit message that follows our
commit message conventions. Adherence to these conventions
is necessary because release notes are automatically generated from these messages.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git commit -a
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Note: the optional commit -a command line option will automatically "add" and "rm" edited files.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Push your branch to GitHub:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git push origin my-fix-branch
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - In GitHub, send a pull request to colmena:develop.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - If we suggest changes then:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Make the required updates.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Re-run the Colmena test suites to ensure tests are still passing.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Rebase your branch and force push to your GitHub repository (this will update your Pull Request):
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
git rebase master -i
git push -f
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: That's it! Thank you for your contribution!
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: After your pull request is merged
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
After your pull request is merged, you can safely delete your branch and pull the changes
from the main (upstream) repository:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Delete the remote branch on GitHub either through the GitHub web UI or your local shell as follows:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git push origin --delete my-fix-branch
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Check out the master branch:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git checkout master -f
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Delete the local branch:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git branch -D my-fix-branch
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Update your master with the latest upstream version:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git pull --ff upstream master
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Commit Message Guidelines
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
We have very precise rules over how our git commit messages can be formatted.  This leads to more
readable messages that are easy to follow when looking through the project history.  But also,
we use the git commit messages to generate the Colmena change log.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Commit Message Format
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Each commit message consists of a header, a body and a footer.  The header has a special
format that includes a type, a scope and a subject:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
<type>(<scope>): <subject>
<BLANK LINE>
<body>
<BLANK LINE>
<footer>
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: The header is mandatory and the scope of the header is optional.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Any line of the commit message cannot be longer 100 characters! This allows the message to be easier
to read on GitHub as well as in various git tools.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Footer should contain a closing reference to an issue if any.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Samples:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: docs(changelog): update change log to beta.5
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: feat(api): add support for MongoDB
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: fix(release): need to depend on latest rxjs and zone.js
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: The version in our package.json gets copied to the one we publish, and users need the latest of these.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Revert
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: If the commit reverts a previous commit, it should begin with revert: , followed by the header of the reverted commit. In the body it should say: This reverts commit <hash>., where the hash is the SHA of the commit being reverted.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Type
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Must be one of the following:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - build: Changes that affect the build system or external dependencies (example scopes: npm, nps, Angular CLI)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - ci: Changes to our CI configuration files and scripts (example scopes: Travis, Circle, BrowserStack, SauceLabs)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - docs: Documentation only changes
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - feat: A new feature
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - fix: A bug fix
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - perf: A code change that improves performance
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - refactor: A code change that neither fixes a bug nor adds a feature
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - style: Changes that do not affect the meaning of the code (white-space, formatting, missing semi-colons, etc)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - test: Adding missing tests or correcting existing tests
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Scope
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: The scope should be the name of the npm package affected (as perceived by person reading changelog generated from commit messages.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: The following is the list of supported scopes:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - admin: changes to the Admin component
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - api: changes to the API component
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - general: changes that are not Admin or API
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - changelog: used for updating the release notes in CHANGELOG.md
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - none/empty string: useful for style, test and refactor changes that are done across all packages (e.g. style: add missing semicolons)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Subject
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: The subject contains succinct description of the change:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - use the imperative, present tense: "change" not "changed" nor "changes"
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - don't capitalize first letter
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - no dot (.) at the end
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Body
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Just as in the subject, use the imperative, present tense: "change" not "changed" nor "changes".
The body should include the motivation for the change and contrast this with previous behavior.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Footer
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
The footer should contain any information about Breaking Changes and is also the place to
reference GitHub issues that this commit Closes.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Breaking Changes should start with the word BREAKING CHANGE: with a space or two newlines. The rest of the commit message is then used for this.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Before you go ahead please search existing issues for your problem, chances are someone else already reported it.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: To make sure that we can help you quickly please include and check the following information:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Include how you run your tests and which testing framework or frameworks you are running.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - please ensure you are requiring and starting SimpleCov before requiring any application code.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- If running via rake, please ensure you are requiring SimpleCov at the top of your Rakefile
For example, if running via RSpec, this would be at the top of your spec_helper.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Have you tried using a .simplecov file?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Include the SimpleCov version you are running in your report.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- If you are not running the latest version (please check), and you cannot update it,
please specify in your report why you can't update to the latest version.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Include your ruby -e "puts RUBY_DESCRIPTION".
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Please also specify the gem versions of Rails (if applicable).
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Include any other coverage gems you may be using and their versions.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Include as much sample code as you can to help us reproduce the issue. (Inline, repo link, or gist, are fine. A failing test would help the most.)
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: This is extremely important for narrowing down the cause of your problem.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Thanks!
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Did you find a bug?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Do not open up a GitHub issue if the bug is a security vulnerability in Colyseus, and instead send us an email at endel@gamestd.io.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Ensure the bug was not already reported by searching on GitHub under Issues.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - If you're unable to find an open issue addressing the problem, open a new one. Be sure to include a title and clear description, as much relevant information as possible, and a code sample or an executable test case demonstrating the expected behavior that is not occurring.

Paragraph: Contributing
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Contribute your code to ComfortableMexicanSofa in 5 easy steps:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 1. Fork it
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Fork the project. Optionally, create a branch you want to work on.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 2. Get it running locally
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Install gem dependencies with bundle install
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
- There's nothing to configure, by default database is SQLite so it will be
created for you. Just run bundle exec rake db:migrate
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: - Make sure that existing tests are passing by running bundle exec rake test
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
- There are system tests that can be run with bundle exec rake test:system.
You need to have chromedriver installed for that.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: - You should be able to start the app via bin/rails s and navigate to http://localhost:3000/admin
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 3. Hack away
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Create a few small pull requests instead of a humoungous one. I can merge small stuff faster.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - When adding new code just make sure it follows the same slyle as the existing code.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Avoid adding 3rd party dependencies if you can.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Tests please, but nothing complicated. UnitTest / Fixtures all the way. Make sure all tests pass.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Run bundle exec rubocop and fix any issues raised.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 4. Make a pull request
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - If you never done it before read this: https://help.github.com/articles/using-pull-requests
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - When PR is submitted check if TravisCI ran all tests successfully and Rubocop didn't raise any issues
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 5. Done!
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
If everything is good your changes will be merged into master branch. Eventually
a new version of gem will be published.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Developing commitizen
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
You consider contributing changes to commitizen
Please consider these guidelines when filing a pull request:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Commits follow the Angular commit convention
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - JavaScript is written using ES2015 features
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Features and bug fixes should be covered by test cases
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Creating releases
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
commitizen uses semantic-release
to release new versions automatically.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Commits of type fix will trigger bugfix releases, think 0.0.1
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Commits of type feat will trigger feature releases, think 0.1.0
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Commits with BREAKING CHANGE in body or footer will trigger breaking releases, think 1.0.0
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: All other commit types will trigger no new release.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Gotchas
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Atom removes lines with just spaces, breaking tests
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
When using Atom, if you edit some of our tests, atom will remove the whitespace on some lines. Unfortunately we wanted this whitespace to
able to test multiline commits and their difference across operating
systems. Atom has decided to keep the stripping of whitespace as a
default. Although we understand this decision, it has the unfortunate
side effect of editing parts of the file that you might not have
intended. We think this should be left up to more configurable tools
like eslint.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
For now, in order to work around this, you can take the steps outlined
here to temporarily disable automatic whitespace removal in Atom.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Found an Issue?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: If you find a bug in the source code or a mistake in the documentation, you can help us by submitting an issue to our GitHub Repository. Even better, you can  submit a Pull Request with a fix.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Want a Feature?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
You can request a new feature by submitting an issue to our GitHub
Repository. If you would like to implement a new feature, please submit an issue with a proposal for your work first, to be sure that we can use it.
First open an issue and outline your proposal so that it can be discussed. This will also allow us to better coordinate our efforts, prevent duplication of work, and help you to craft the change so that it is successfully accepted into the project.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Submission Guidelines
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Submitting an Issue
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Before you submit an issue, please search the issue tracker, maybe an issue for your problem already exists and the discussion might inform you of workarounds readily available.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: We want to fix all the issues as soon as possible, but before fixing a bug we need to reproduce and confirm it. In order to reproduce bugs we will systematically ask you to provide a minimal reproduction scenario. Having a reproducible scenario gives us wealth of important information without going back & forth to you with additional questions like:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - version of compodoc, Node.js used
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - .tsconfig.json configuration
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - and most importantly - a use-case that fails
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: A minimal reproduce scenario using allows us to quickly confirm a bug (or point out coding problem) as well as confirm that we are fixing the right problem.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: We will be insisting on a minimal reproduce scenario in order to save maintainers time and ultimately be able to fix more bugs. Interestingly, from our experience users often find coding problems themselves while preparing a minimal repository. We understand that sometimes it might be hard to extract essentials bits of code from a larger code-base but we really need to isolate the problem before we can fix it.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Unfortunately we are not able to investigate / fix bugs without a minimal reproduction, so if we don't hear back from you we are going to close an issue that don't have enough info to be reproduced.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: You can file new issues by filling out our new issue form.
Label: No categories identified.

- Search GitHub for an open or closed Pull Request
that relates to your submission.

cd test-pr
compodoc -p src/tsconfig.json

- Commit your changes using a descriptive commit message that follows our
commit message conventions.

Paragraph: Note: the optional commit -a command line option will automatically "add" and "rm" edited files.

Paragraph: - Push your branch to GitHub:

Paragraph: - In GitHub, send a pull request to compodoc/compodoc:develop.

Paragraph: - If i suggest changes then
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Make the required updates.

Paragraph: - Re-run the tests and retest your sample generated project to ensure tests are still passing.

Paragraph: - Rebase your branch and force push to your GitHub repository (this will update your Pull Request):

After your pull request is merged, you can safely delete your branch and pull the changes
from the main (upstream) repository:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Delete the remote branch on GitHub either through the GitHub web UI or your local shell as follows:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git push origin --delete my-fix-branch

Paragraph: - Check out the develop branch:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git checkout develop -f
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Delete the local branch:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git branch -D my-fix-branch
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Update your develop with the latest upstream version:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git pull --ff upstream develop
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Coding Rules
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: To ensure consistency throughout the source code, keep these rules in mind as you are working:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - All features or bug fixes must be tested by one or more specs (unit-tests or e2e-tests).
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - All public API methods must be documented. (Details TBC).
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- We follow Google's JavaScript Style Guide, but wrap all code at
100 characters.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Commit Message Guidelines
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
We have very precise rules over how our git commit messages can be formatted.  This leads to more
readable messages that are easy to follow when looking through the project history.  But also,
we use the git commit messages to generate the Angular CLI change log.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Commit Message Format
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Each commit message consists of a header, a body and a footer.  The header has a special
format that includes a type, a scope and a subject:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
<type>(<scope>): <subject>
<BLANK LINE>
<body>
<BLANK LINE>
<footer>
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: The header is mandatory and the scope of the header is optional.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Any line of the commit message cannot be longer 100 characters! This allows the message to be easier
to read on GitHub as well as in various git tools.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Revert
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: If the commit reverts a previous commit, it should begin with revert: , followed by the header of the reverted commit. In the body it should say: This reverts commit <hash>., where the hash is the SHA of the commit being reverted.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Type
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Must be one of the following:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - build: Changes that affect the build system or external dependencies
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - ci: Changes to our CI configuration files and scripts
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - docs: Documentation only changes
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - feat: A new feature
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - fix: A bug fix
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - perf: A code change that improves performance
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - refactor: A code change that neither fixes a bug nor adds a feature
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- style: Changes that do not affect the meaning of the code (white-space, formatting, missing
semi-colons, etc)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - test: Adding missing tests or correcting existing tests
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Scope
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: The scope should be the name of the npm package affected as perceived by the person reading changelog generated from the commit messages.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Subject
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: The subject contains succinct description of the change:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - use the imperative, present tense: "change" not "changed" nor "changes"
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - don't capitalize first letter
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - no dot (.) at the end
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Body
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Just as in the subject, use the imperative, present tense: "change" not There are currently a few exceptions to the "use package name" rule:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - packaging: used for changes that change the npm package layout in all of our packages, e.g. public path changes, package.json changes done to all packages, d.ts file/format changes, changes to bundles, etc.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - changelog: used for updating the release notes in CHANGELOG.md
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - none/empty string: useful for style, test and refactor changes that are done across all packages (e.g. style: add missing semicolons)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Breaking Changes should start with the word BREAKING CHANGE: with a space or two newlines. The rest of the commit message is then used for this.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: A detailed explanation can be found in this document.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Reporting Issues
