Paragraph:
When reporting issues, please try to be as descriptive as possible, and include
as much relevant information as you can. A step by step guide on how to
reproduce the issue will greatly increase the chances of your issue being
resolved in a timely manner.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
For example, if you are experiencing a problem while running one of the
commands, please provide full output of said command in very very verbose mode
(-vvv, e.g. composer install -vvv).
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
If your issue involves installing, updating or resolving dependencies, the
chance of us being able to reproduce your issue will be much higher if you
share your composer.json with us.

Paragraph: Installation from Source
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
Prior to contributing to Composer, you must be able to run the test suite.
To achieve this, you need to acquire the Composer source code:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 1.  Run git clone https://github.com/composer/composer.git
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 2.  Download the composer.phar executable
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 3.  Run Composer to get the dependencies: cd composer && php ../composer.phar install
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
You can run the test suite by executing vendor/bin/phpunit when inside the
composer directory, and run Composer by executing the bin/composer. To test
your modified Composer code against another project, run php /path/to/composer/bin/composer inside that project's directory.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Fork the project, create a feature branch, and send us a pull request.

To ensure a consistent code base, you should make sure the code follows
the PSR-2 Coding Standards. You can also
run php-cs-fixer with the
configuration file that can be found in the project root directory.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Contributing to Conan
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: The following summarizes the process for contributing to the Conan project.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Community
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Conan is an Open Source MIT licensed project.
Conan is developed by the Conan maintainers and a great community of contributors.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Dev-flow & Pull Requests
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Conan follows the "GitFlow" branching model.
Issues are triaged and categorized mainly by type (feature, bug...) complexity (high, medium...) and priority (high, medium...) using GitHub
labels. Then they are moved to a stage called "queue" when they are considered to be ready for implementation.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: To contribute follow the next steps:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
1.  Comment in the corresponding issue that you want to contribute the feature/fix proposed. If there is no open issue, we strongly suggest
to open one to gather feedback.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
2.  Check that the issue has been staged to "queue" or ask @conan-io/barbarians to do it. This helps in terms of validation and discussion of
possible implementation of the feature/fix.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
3.  Fork the Conan main repository and create a feature/xxx branch from the develop branch and develop
your fix/feature as discussed in previous step.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 4.  Try to keep your branch updated with the develop branch to avoid conflicts.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 5.  Open a pull request, and select develop as the base branch. Never open a pull request to release/xxx branches.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 6.  Add the text (besides other comments): "fixes #IssueNumber" in the body of the PR, referring to the issue of step 1.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 7.  Submit a PR to the Conan documentation about the changes done providing examples if needed.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: The conan-io organization maintainers will review and help with the coding of tests. Finally it will be assigned to milestone.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
Each milestone corresponds to a Conan release, a branch release/xxx will be opened from the develop branch.
When the branch is ready, a tag corresponding to the version will be pushed and it will be merged into develop branch.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
The release plan is done monthly but dates are not fixed, the conan-io organization maintainers reserve the right of altering the issues
of each milestone as well as the release dates.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Issues
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: If you think you found a bug in Conan open an issue indicating the following:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Explain the Conan version, Operating System, compiler and any other tool that could be related to the issue.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Explain, as detailed as possible, how to reproduce the issue. Use git repos to contain code/recipes to reproduce issues.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Include the expected behavior as well as what actually happened.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Provide output captures (as text).
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Feel free to attach a screenshot or video illustrating the issue if you think it will be helpful.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: For any suggestion, feature request or question open an issue indicating the following:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Questions and support requests are always welcome.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Use the [question] or [suggestion] tags in the title.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Try to explain the motivation, what are you trying to do, what is the pain it tries to solve.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - What do you expect from Conan.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: We use the following tags to control the status of the issues:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- triaging: Issue is being considered or under discussion. Maintainers are trying to understand the use case or gathering the necessary
information.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - queue: Issue has been categorized and is ready to be done in a following release (not necessarily in the next one).
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - in-progress: A milestone has previously been assigned to the issue and is now under development.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- review: Issue has a PR associated that solves it (remember to use the GitHub keywords "closes #IssueNumber", "fixes #IssueNumber"...
in the description of the PR).
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - closed via PR: A PR with the fix or new feature has been merged to develop and the issue will be fixed in the next monthly release.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Code of conduct
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Try to be polite, Conan maintainers and contributors are really willing to help and we enjoy it.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Please keep in mind these points:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - There are limited resources/time and not all issues/pull requests can be considered as well as we would like.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- conan-io maintainers can tag/close/modify any opened issue and it should not be interpreted as a rude or disrespectful action. It
always responds to organizational purposes. A closed issue can be perfectly reopened or further commented.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- It is very hard to keep the project in good health in terms of technical debt, usability, serviceability, etc. If the proposed feature is
not clearly stated, enough information is not provided or it is not sure that would be a good feature for the future development of the project, it won't be accepted. The community plays a very important role during this discussion so it strongly encouraged to
explain the value of a feature for the community, the needed documentation and its use cases.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Backwards compatibility and not breaking users' packages is very important and it won't be done unless there are very good reasons.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- You should not get bothered if you feel unattended, Conan is an Open Source project, not a commercial product. Try to explain what you
really need and we will try to help you.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Code style
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - In general, follow pep8
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Limit all lines to a maximum of 101 characters (Right margin setting in PyCharm)

Paragraph: - Start new files with encoding declaration:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: # -*- coding: utf-8 -*-
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Specify imports in the following order: system, blank line, 3rd-party, blank line, own; all sorted alphabetically:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
import os
import platform
import shutil
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
from nose.plugins.attrib import attr
from tqdm import tqdm
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
from conans.client.tools import which
from conans.errors import ConanException
from conans.model.version import Version
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Write unit tests, if possible

Paragraph: Developing KSQL
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Building and running KSQL locally
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: To build and run KSQL locally, run the following commands:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
$ mvn clean package -DskipTests
$ ./bin/ksql-server-start -daemon config/ksql-server.properties
$ ./bin/ksql
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
This will start the KSQL server in the background and the KSQL CLI in the
foreground. Check the logs folder for the log files that the server writes
including any errors.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
If you would rather have the KSQL server logs spool to the console, then
drop the -daemon switch, and start the CLI in a second console.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: How to Contribute
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Reporting Bugs and Issues
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Report bugs and issues by creating a new GitHub issue.
Prior to creating an issue, please search through existing issues so that you are not creating duplicate ones.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Guidelines for Contributing Code, Examples, Documentation
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Any change to the public API of ksqlDB, especially the SQL syntax, requires a KsqlDB
improvement proposal (KLIP) to be raised and approved.
See the KLIP Readme for more info.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Code changes are submitted via a pull request (PR). When submitting a PR use the following guidelines:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Follow the style guide below
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Add/update documentation appropriately for the change you are making. For more information, see the docs readme.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Non-trivial changes should include unit tests covering the new functionality and potentially function tests.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - All SQL syntax changes and enhancements should come with appropriate function tests.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Bug fixes should include a unit test or integration test potentially function tests proving the issue is fixed.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Try to keep pull requests short and submit separate ones for unrelated features.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Keep formatting changes in separate commits to make code reviews easier and distinguish them from actual code changes.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Code Style

The project uses GoogleStyle code formatting.
You can install this code style into your IDE to make things more automatic:

Paragraph: - Eclipse code style xml file

Paragraph: The project also uses immutable types where ever possible. If adding new type(s), ideally make them immutable.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Commit messages
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
The project uses [Conventional Commits][https://www.conventionalcommits.org/en/v1.0.0-beta.4/] for commit messages
in order to aid in automatic generation of changelogs. As described in the Conventional Commmits specification,
commit messages should be of the form:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: <type>[optional scope]: <description>
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: [optional body]
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: [optional footer]
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: where the type is one of
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - "fix": for bug fixes
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - "feat": for new features
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - "refactor": for refactors
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - "test": for test-only changes
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - "docs": for docs-only changes
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - "revert": for reverting other changes
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - "perf", "style", "build", "ci", or "chore": as described in the [Angular specification][https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/22b96b9/CONTRIBUTING.md#type] for Conventional Commits.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
The (optional) scope is a noun describing the section of the codebase affected by the change.
Examples that could make sense for KSQL include "parser", "analyzer", "rest server", "testing tool",
"cli", "processing log", and "metrics", to name a few.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
The optional body and footer are for specifying additional information, such as linking to issues fixed by the commit
or drawing attention to breaking changes.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Breaking changes
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
A commit is a "breaking change" if users should expect different behavior from an existing workflow
as a result of the change. Examples of breaking changes include deprecation of existing configs or APIs,
changing default behavior of existing configs or query semantics, or the renaming of exposed JMX metrics.
Breaking changes must be called out in commit messages, PR descriptions, and upgrade notes:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Commit messages for breaking changes must include a line (in the optional body or footer)
starting with "BREAKING CHANGE: " followed by an explanation of what the breaking change was.
For example,
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: feat: inherit num partitions and replicas from source topic in CSAS/CTAS
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
BREAKING CHANGE: `CREATE * AS SELECT` queries now create sink topics with partition
and replica count equal to those of the source, rather than using values from the properties
`ksql.sink.partitions` and `ksql.sink.replicas`. These properties are now deprecated.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- The breaking change should similarly be called out in the PR description.
This description will be copied into the body of the final commit merged into the repo,
and picked up by our automatic changelog generation accordingly.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- [Upgrade notes][https://github.com/confluentinc/ksql/blob/master/docs/installation/upgrading.rst]
should also be updated as part of the same PR.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Commitlint
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
This project has [commitlint][https://github.com/conventional-changelog/commitlint] configured
to ensure that commit messages are of the expected format.
To enable commitlint, simply run npm install from the root directory of the KSQL repo
(after [installing npm][https://www.npmjs.com/get-npm].)
Once enabled, commitlint will reject commits with improperly formatted commit messages.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: GitHub Workflow
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 1.  Fork the confluentinc/ksql repository into your GitHub account: https://github.com/confluentinc/ksql/fork.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: 2.  Clone your fork of the GitHub repository, replacing <username> with your GitHub username.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Use ssh (recommended):
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: git clone git@github.com:<username>/ksql.git
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Or https:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: git clone https://github.com/<username>/ksql.git
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 3.  Add a remote to keep up with upstream changes.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: git remote add upstream https://github.com/confluentinc/ksql.git
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: If you already have a copy, fetch upstream changes.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git fetch upstream
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 4.  Create a feature branch to work in.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: git checkout -b feature-xxx remotes/upstream/master
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 5.  Work in your feature branch.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: git commit -a
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 6.  Periodically rebase your changes
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: git pull --rebase
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 7.  When done, combine ("squash") related commits into a single one
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: git rebase -i upstream/master
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: This will open your editor and allow you to re-order commits and merge them:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Re-order the lines to change commit order (to the extent possible without creating conflicts)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Prefix commits using s (squash) or f (fixup) to merge extraneous commits.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 8.  Submit a pull-request
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: git push origin feature-xxx
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Go to your fork main page
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: https://github.com/<username>/ksql
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: If you recently pushed your changes GitHub will automatically pop up a Compare & pull request button for any branches you recently pushed to. If you click that button it will automatically offer you to submit your pull-request to the confluentinc/ksql repository.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Give your pull-request a meaningful title that conforms to the Conventional Commits specification
as described above for commit messages.
You'll know your title is properly formatted once the Semantic Pull Request GitHub check
transitions from a status of "pending" to "passed".
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- In the description, explain your changes and the problem they are solving. Be sure to also call out
any breaking changes as described above.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 9.  Addressing code review comments
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Repeat steps 5. through 7. to address any code review comments and rebase your changes if necessary.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Push your updated changes to update the pull request
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: git push origin [--force] feature-xxx
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
--force may be necessary to overwrite your existing pull request in case your
commit history was changed when performing the rebase.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Note: Be careful when using --force since you may lose data if you are not careful.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: git push origin --force feature-xxx
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Contributing to Robo
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Thank you for your interest in contributing to Robo! Here are some of the guidelines you should follow to make the most of your efforts:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Code Style Guidelines
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Robo adheres to the PSR-2 Coding Style Guide for PHP code. An .editorconfig file is included with the repository to help you get up and running quickly. Most modern editors support this standard, but if yours does not or you would like to configure your editor manually, follow the guidelines in the document linked above.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: You can run the PHP Codesniffer on your work using a convenient command built into this project's own RoboFile.php:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: robo sniff src/Foo.php --autofix
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: The above will run the PHP Codesniffer on the src/Foo.php file and automatically correct variances from the PSR-2 standard. Please ensure all contributions are compliant before submitting a pull request.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Tests
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Note that in the past, Robo used Codeception / Aspect Mock etc. in its unit tests. These components proved to be difficult to maintain when testing on mutiple PHP versions, so they were removed. The tests formerly in tests/cli were all ported to straight phpunit tests in the tests/integration directory. Some of the unit tests from tests/unit were ported to tests/phpunit; however, a number of tests that still use AspectMock still exist in tests/unit, although these are not currently being used.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Pull requests that touch parts of the code formerly tested by these disabled tests must also convert the AspectMock test to Prophecy or some other mocking system. Alternately, getting AspectMock working again on the master and 1.x branches is another option, if someone wants to stand up to do that work.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: How to Contribute to this Project
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Code of conduct
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: The core team members and the project's community adopt an inclusive Code of Conduct that you can read in the CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md file.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: Reporting an issue
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: The prefered way to report any bug is opening an issue in the project's repo.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Try to use a descriptive and to-the-point title
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - It's a good idea to include some of these sections:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Steps to reproduce the bug
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Expected behaviour/response
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Actual response
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Sometimes it is also helpful if you mention your operating system, browser version and installed plugins.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Thanks! :heart: :heart: :heart:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Solving an issue
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Issues labeled with help wanted are well defined features ready to be implemented by whoever wants to do it.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: If you want to contribute code to solve an issue:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Add a comment to tell everyone you are working on the issue.
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: - Open a pull request to the main repository describing what issue you are addressing and following our coding conventions
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Working on your first Pull Request? You can learn how from this free series How to Contribute to an Open Source Project on GitHub
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: Coding conventions
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: If you'd like us to review your pull request in good spirits, please follow our coding conventions:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Include specs to test any changes you've made
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Travis CI will check whether the rest of the application is still working properly; check its build and make sure all tests are passing
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Your pull request will be automatically reviewed by Hound CI; fix any issues it reports
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Follow the seven rules of a great commit message
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: When we review your pull request and ask for changes, if you're proficient using git rebase edit existing commits instead of adding new ones. If you aren't proficient with git rebase, ignore this point.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Code Contributions
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Do you have a new cool feature that you'd like to contribute to
Contiki? Or a fix for a bug? Great! The Contiki project loves code
contributions, improvements, and bugfixes, but we require that they
follow a set of guidelines and that they are contributed in a specific
way.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Additional rules apply for contributions of a new hardware platform.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: General Advice
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
The chance of getting your pull request accepted increases considerably
if you adhere to the following rules in addition to the aforementioned
formatting and naming standards:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Ensure that all contributed files have a valid copyright statement
and an open-source license.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Do not bundle commits that are unrelated to each other -- create
separate pull requests instead.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Adhere to ISO C99 in all C language source files. Exceptions are
allowed for those platform-dependent source files that rely on the
extensions of a specific set of compilers.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Clean up the commit history. "git rebase -i" is useful for this purpose.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Do not include executable binary files, because they are usually
rejected for security reasons. Instead, provide instructions for how
to compile the file, so that a trusted member of the merge team can
commit it.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Write a descriptive pull request message. Explain the advantages and
disadvantages of your proposed changes.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Before starting to work on a major contribution, discuss your idea
with experienced Contiki programmers (e.g., on the contiki-developers
mailing list) to avoid wasting time on things that have no chance of
getting merged into Contiki.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Source code that goes into the mainline Contiki repository must be of
interest to a large part of the Contiki community. It must be
well-tested and the merge team must have confidence that the code can
be maintained over a longer period. See below for more details
pertaining to platform contributions.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Contributions that have been made in research projects, and typically
do not get maintained thereafter, are better suited for inclusion in
the Contiki projects repository.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Structuring Commits
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Write descriptive commit messages. They don't have to be very long,
but you should mention what the commit achieves. Commit messages
like "modified foo/bar.c" are not helpful, should not be used, and
are likely to result in you having to re-write them.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Please do not add / remove irrelevant new line markers. Don't remove
the new line marker at the EOF.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Please, make sure that your patch doesn't add lines with trailing
whitespaces. If you run uncrustify as discussed above, this should
get taken care of for you automatically.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- More generally speaking, make sure that each commit in your history
only includes changes necessary to implement whatever it is the
commit is trying to achieve. All changes should be mentioned in the
commit message.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Code Formatting
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
We require that all code contributed to the Contiki tree follows the
same code formatting as the existing Contiki code. We are very strict
on this.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
Code must be formatted according to
contiki/doc/code-style.c.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
The Contiki source tree contains scripts to assist with correct code formatting
and we recommend Uncrustify as the
preferred auto formatter. Everything is under
tools/code-style.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
If you wish, you can format all changed resources in your working tree
automatically if the
tools/code-style/uncrustify-changed.sh
script is added as a Git pre-commit
hook to your Git
configuration.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Here are some examples of what you can do:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- To check a file's style without changing the file on disk, you can run this:
./tools/code-style/uncrustify-check-style.sh <path-to-file>
This script will only accept a single file as its argument.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- To auto format a file (and change it on disk) you can run this:
./tools/code-style/uncrustify-fix-style.sh <path-to-file>
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- uncrustify-fix-style.sh will accept a space-delimited list of files as its argument. Thus, you can auto-format an entire directory by running something like this:
./tools/code-style/uncrustify-fix-style.sh `find cpu/cc2538 -type f -name "*.[ch]"`
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: This is not a silver bullet and developer intervention is still required. Below are some examples of code which will get misformatted by uncrustify:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Math symbol following a cast to a typedef
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
a = (uint8_t) ~P0_1; /* Cast to a typedef. Space gets added here (incorrect) */
a = (int)~P0_1;      /* Cast to a known type. Space gets removed (correct) */
a = (uint8_t)P0_1;   /* Variable directly after the cast. Space gets removed (correct) */
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - while(<condition>); will become while(<condition>) ; (space incorrectly added after closing paren)
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - ??asm("wfi"); becomes asm ("wfi");: A space gets added before the opening paren, because the asm keyword stops this from getting interpreted as a normal function call / macro invocation. This is only a problem with asm. For instance, ??foo("bar"); gets formatted correctly.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Naming
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
We require that all code contributed to the Contiki tree follow the
Contiki source code naming standard:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- File names are composed of lower-case characters and dashes. Like
this: simple-udp.c
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- Variable and function names are composed of lower-case characters
and underscores. Like this: simple_udp_send();
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- Variable and function names that are visible outside of their module
must begin with the name of the module. Like this:
simple_udp_send(), which is in the simple-udp module, declared in
simple-udp.h, and implemented in simple-udp.c.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- C macros are composed of upper-case characters and underscores. Like
this: PROCESS_THREAD().
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- Configuration definitions begin with the module name and CONF_. Like
this: PROCESS_CONF_NUMEVENTS.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: How to Contribute Code
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
When your code is formatted according to the Contiki code style and
follows the Contiki naming standard, it is time to send it to the
Contiki maintainers to look at!
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
All code contributions to Contiki are submitted as Github pull
requests. Pull
requests will be reviewed and accepted according to the guidelines
found in the next section.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: The basic guidelines to to start a Pull-Request:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Create a new branch for your modifications. This branch should be based on the latest contiki master branch.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - If you already added the commits to another branch you can cherry-pick them onto your new branch.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Push the new branch to github.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Raise the new Pull Requests on this new branch. Raising a Pull Request for the master branch is almost always a bad idea.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - If changes are requested do not close the pull request but rewrite your history. Details about rewriting your history
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - You now force-push the changes to github. The pull-request is automatically updated.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: In Git terminology this is equivalent to:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Make sure you have the original contiki repo as origin.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
$ git remote -v
contiki-orig     https://github.com/contiki-os/contiki.git
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - If not add it
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: $ git remote add contiki-orig https://github.com/contiki-os/contiki.git
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Make sure you have the latest version of your remotes
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: $ git remote update
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Create a new branch "my_new_feature" based on the latest contiki master branch
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: $ git checkout contiki-orig/master -b my_new_feature
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Add your work. For example by cherry-picking your changes from another branch.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: $ git cherry-pick <HASH OF COMMIT>
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Push to your github repository
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: $ git push origin my_new_feature
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Make a Pull Request for that branch
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Rewrite your history if requested
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: $ git rebase -i contiki-orig/master
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - As rewriting your history can break things you must force-push the changes. Warning: Force-pushing normally is dangerous and you might break things. Make sure you are never force-pushing branches other people are supposed to work with.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: $ git push origin my_new_feature -f
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - NOTE: To avoid all the pain of selectively picking commits, rebasing and force-pushing - begin your development with a branch OTHER THAN your master branch, and push changes to that branch after any local commits.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Pull Request Merging Policy
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Pull requests (PRs) are reviewed by the merge team.
Generally, PRs require two "+1" before they can be merged by someone on the merge team.
The since Contiki 3.0, the merging policy is the following:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - The PR receives one "-1" from a merge team member (along with specific feedback). The PR is closed. A "-1" must be accompanied with a clear explanation why the PR will not be considered for inclusion.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - The PR receives two "+1" from merge team members. The PR is merged.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - The PR was inactive for two months. A team member may either:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Comment "Is there any interest for this PR? Is there any work pending on it? If not I will close it in one month." Back to initial state in case of activity, close otherwise.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Comment "I approve this PR. If nobody disapproves within one month, I will merge it." Back to initial state in case of activity, merge otherwise.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
There is an exception to the rule.
Code that requires esoteric expertise such as some applications, platforms or tools can be merged after a single "+1" from its domain expert.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Travis / Regression testing
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Travis is a service that runs regression
tests. If you make a pull-request for Contiki this is automatically
forwarded to Travis and regression tests are run. A box with
information about the state of you pull request should show up after a
minute or two.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
If the test fails it is likely that something is wrong with your
code. Please look carefully at the log. It might also be that some
package on the testing VM was updated and causes the build to fail. If
you are sure that is is not your code causing the tests to fail start
a new issue describing the problem. Also note this in your pull
request.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
You can also register at Travis for
free. Once you activated your Contiki repository, every push will be
tested at Travis. The configuration is part of the contiki repository
and testing will therefore work out-of-the-box. At Travis you then get
an overview of the state of each of your branches.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: New Platforms
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
A new hardware port will be considered for inclusion in mainline Contiki
if it satisfies the following rules:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- There must be at least one person willing and committed to maintain it.
They may but do not have to be the people who wrote the code. Similarly,
they may but do not have to be affiliated with the hardware manufacturer.
In the first instance, code maintenance would mean keeping the port up to
speed by submitting pull requests as Contiki moves forward. In the longer
term, people who maintain a reasonable level of commitment and who demonstrate
that they know what they're doing may be invited to become repo collaborators.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- The hardware must be commercially available and of interest to a wide audience.
In other words, ports for bespoke hardware built for e.g. a specific project /
a single customer / niche markets are more suitable for a Contiki fork.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - The code must strictly adhere to the Contiki code style, as discussed above.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- The new files must have a clear copyright notice and license header. Contiki's
preferred software license is the
3-clause BSD.
Other licenses may also be considered
as long as they are compatible with the 3-clause BSD (e.g. the Apache 2.0 license).
Conversely, code distributed under GPL cannot be considered. The same applies to
bespoke licenses, such as those allowing use or redistribution only together with
certain kinds of hardware.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- The port must demonstrate a certain degree of completeness and maturity. Common sense
applies here.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- The port must be accompanied by examples demonstrating basic functionality. This could
be a set of examples under examples/<new-hardware-port> and/or documentation of
which existing examples are meant to work.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- The port must provide compile regression tests by extending the existing travis
integration testing framework. Again, we can't specify explicitly
what those tests should be, but something more interesting than hello-world is expected.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- The work must be documented. The documentation could be README.md files
under the platform / cpu / example dirs or wiki pages. Doxygen comments are
also encouraged. The documentation should include:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- A getting started guide, including a list of tools required to use the platform
(e.g. toolchain, software to program the device), where to get them from and brief notes
how to install them (can simply be a list of links to external guides)
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - A list of things which will work off the shelf
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - A list of things which are not meant to work, if any
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Additional reading resources (e.g. datasheets, hardware user guides, web resources)
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - A ToDo list, if applicable.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- It must be possible to use the port using free software. We do not discourage the
use of commercial software (e.g. support for a commercial toolchain), quite the opposite.
However, we will insist on the existence of a free alternative for everything.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
After the port has been accepted, things meant to work off the shelf should
keep working off the shelf as Contiki moves forward.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
We appreciate that, for many people, contributing to Contiki is a spare time
activity and our expectations from port maintainers take this into
consideration. All we ask from maintainers is to comment on and address
relevant pull requests at a reasonable frequency and to make sure travis keeps
passing. In other words, we just want platforms to stay healthy over time and
to thus avoid becoming very broken / obsolete.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Create Cookiecutter Templates
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Some other Cookiecutter templates to list in the README would be great.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: If you create a Cookiecutter template, submit a pull request adding it to README.md.

Paragraph: Report Bugs
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Report bugs at https://github.com/cookiecutter/cookiecutter/issues.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: If you are reporting a bug, please include:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Your operating system name and version.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Any details about your local setup that might be helpful in troubleshooting.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - If you can, provide detailed steps to reproduce the bug.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - If you don't have steps to reproduce the bug, just note your observations in as much detail as you can. Questions to start a discussion about the issue are welcome.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Fix Bugs
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: Look through the GitHub issues for bugs. Anything tagged with "bug" is open to whoever wants to implement it.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: Implement Features
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: Look through the GitHub issues for features. Anything tagged with "enhancement" and "please-help" is open to whoever wants to implement it.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: Please do not combine multiple feature enhancements into a single pull request.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Note: this project is very conservative, so new features that aren't tagged with "please-help" might not get into core. We're trying to keep the code base small, extensible, and streamlined. Whenever possible, it's best to try and implement feature ideas as separate projects outside of the core codebase.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: Write Documentation
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: If you want to review your changes on the documentation locally, you can do:

Paragraph:

make servedocs

Paragraph: This will compile the documentation, open it in your browser and start watching the files for changes, recompiling as you save.

Paragraph: Setting Up the Code for Local Development
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Here's how to set up cookiecutter for local development.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 1.  Fork the cookiecutter repo on GitHub.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 2.  Clone your fork locally:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: git clone git@github.com:your_name_here/cookiecutter.git
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 3.  Install your local copy into a virtualenv. Assuming you have virtualenvwrapper installed, this is how you set up your fork for local development:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph:
mkvirtualenv cookiecutter
cd cookiecutter/
python setup.py develop
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 4.  Create a branch for local development:
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: git checkout -b name-of-your-bugfix-or-feature
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: Now you can make your changes locally.
Label: BW – Build local workspace

Paragraph: 5.  When you're done making changes, check that your changes pass the tests and lint check:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
pip install tox
tox
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Please note that tox runs lint check automatically, since we have a test environment for it.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: If you feel like running only the lint environment, please use the following command:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: tox -e lint
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: 6.  Ensure that your feature or commit is fully covered by tests. Check report after regular tox run. You can also run coverage only report and get html report with statement by statement highlighting:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: tox -e cov-report
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: You report will be placed to htmlcov directory. Please do not include this directory to your commits. By default this directory in our .gitignore file.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 7.  Commit your changes and push your branch to GitHub:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
git add .
git commit -m "Your detailed description of your changes."
git push origin name-of-your-bugfix-or-feature
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 8.  Submit a pull request through the GitHub website.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Contributor Guidelines
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Pull Request Guidelines
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Before you submit a pull request, check that it meets these guidelines:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 1.  The pull request should include tests.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 2.  If the pull request adds functionality, the docs should be updated. Put your new functionality into a function with a docstring, and add the feature to the list in README.md.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 3.  The pull request must pass all CI/CD jobs before being ready for review.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 4.  If one CI/CD job is failing for unrelated reasons you may want to create another PR to fix that first.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Testing with tox
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Tox uses py.test under the hood, hence it supports the same syntax for selecting tests.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: For further information please consult the pytest usage docs.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: To run a particular test class with tox:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: tox -e py '-k TestFindHooks'
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: To run some tests with names matching a string expression:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: tox -e py '-k generate'
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Will run all tests matching "generate", test_generate_files for example.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: To run just one method:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: tox -e py '-k "TestFindHooks and test_find_hook"'
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: To run all tests using various versions of python in virtualenvs defined in tox.ini, just run tox:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: tox
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: This configuration file setup the pytest-cov plugin and it is an additional dependency. It generate a coverage report after the tests.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: It is possible to tests with some versions of python, to do this the command is:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: tox -e py36,pypy3
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Will run py.test with the python3.6 and pypy3 interpreters, for example.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Command-Line Accessible
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Provides a command-line utility that creates projects from cookiecutters
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Extremely easy to use without having to think too hard
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Flexible for more complex use via optional arguments
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: API Accessible

Paragraph: Fast and Focused

If an issue is a bug that needs an urgent fix, mark it for the next patch release.
Then either fix it or mark as please-help.

Paragraph: For other issues: encourage friendly discussion, moderate debate, offer your thoughts.

Paragraph: Process: Your own code changes
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
All code changes, regardless of who does them, need to be reviewed and merged by someone else.
This rule applies to all the core committers.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Exceptions:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Minor corrections and fixes to pull requests submitted by others.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - While making a formal release, the release manager can make necessary, appropriate changes.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Small documentation changes that reinforce existing subject matter. Most commonly being, but not limited to spelling and grammar corrections.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Responsibilities
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Ensure cross-platform compatibility for every change that's accepted. Windows, Mac, Debian & Ubuntu Linux.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Ensure that code that goes into core meets all requirements in this checklist: https://gist.github.com/audreyr/4feef90445b9680475f2
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Create issues for any major changes and enhancements that you wish to make. Discuss things transparently and get community feedback.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Don't add any classes to the codebase unless absolutely needed. Err on the side of using functions.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Keep feature versions as small as possible, preferably one new feature per version.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Be welcoming to newcomers and encourage diverse new contributors from all backgrounds. Look at Code of Conduct.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Becoming a Core Committer
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Contributors may be given core commit privileges. Preference will be given to those with:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 1.  Past contributions to Cookiecutter and other open-source projects. Contributions to Cookiecutter include both code (both accepted and pending) and friendly participation in the issue tracker. Quantity and quality are considered.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 2.  A coding style that the other core committers find simple, minimal, and clean.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 3.  Access to resources for cross-platform development and testing.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 4.  Time to devote to the project regularly.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: What should I Contribute?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: There are at least three different ways to contribute to Coral:
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: - Writing Code
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: - Reviewing pull requests
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: - Localization
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: - Documentation
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph:
Typically these take the form of creating a Pull Request for Coral, and
submitting it to be reviewed by a member of our team and the greater Coral
community.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Working on your first Pull Request? You can learn how from this free video
series:
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph: How to Contribute to an Open Source Project on GitHub
Label: CF – Contribution flow

Paragraph:
If you decide to fix an issue, please be sure to check the comment thread in
case somebody is already working on a fix. If nobody is working on it at the
moment, please leave a comment stating that you intend to work on it so other
people don
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph:
If somebody claims an issue but doesn
fine to take it over but you should still leave a comment.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: Writing Code
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph:
Conversation surrounding contributions begins when you can create an issue
describing your issue or suggestion.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: When should I create an issue?
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph:
File an issue as soon as you have an idea of something you'd like to contribute.
We would love to hear what you're thinking and help refine the idea to make it
into the Coral ecosystem.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: What should I include in my issue?
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph:
Coral has adopted an iterative, agile development philosophy. All contributions
that make it into the Coral repository should start with a user story in this
form:
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: As a [type of Coral user] I'd like to [do something] so that I can [get some result/value].
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: This exercise does two things:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Allows us to ground our technical choices in a clear, simple product need.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- Expresses that product need in a way that doesn't imply a specific technical
solution allowing for debate as to the best way to solve the problem.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Please feel free to provide as much detail as possible when filing the issue but
please do keep the initial issue specific to one need and try to avoid including
technical or design solutions.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
If you have a specific technical or design solution in mind, please submit it as
the first comment on the thread.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: When should I create a pull request?
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
File a pull request if you've created an issue in our issues
page and have heard back from a member or contributor to Coral. This allows our
team to review the proposed changes prior to time being spent if the team
already has the feature/fix in the road map.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: What should I include in my pull request?
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
When you create a pull request, the template will describe the required
components needed for it to be reviewed by a member of the Coral team. You
should end up filling out:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - What does this PR (pull request) do?
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - How do I test this PR?
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
You should describe what Github issue or ticket that the PR is associated with
to assist the review process. If this PR is resolving a particular bug, a
testing strategy should be described in the testing section. If this PR is
contributing a new feature, a description should describe a scenario to test or
verify the new functionality.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Reviewing pull requests
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Reviewing pull requests in Coral is generally completed by the core Coral team
that is composed of developers employed by Vox Media Inc, but external reviews
or suggestions are also welcomed.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Our review process generally follows a few core principles:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Ensure contributions are linted and tested
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
It is the job of CI linting and tests to notify of style issues within the
codebase. If it is not possible for style issues to be encapsulated as a
linting rule, it shouldn't be concretely enforced during the review process.
This can ensure that code reviews contain more meaningful feedback tied to the
contribution rather than nit-picking on stylistic choices.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Reviewers must ensure that linting and tests pass in CI and locally prior to a
review taking place. You can do this by running npm run generate followed by
npm run lint and npm run test.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Review the feature/fixes
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Any new features added to Coral should be reviewed for bugs through a manual
verification process to ensure that they function on your machine. If possible
you should review any automated tests that were added (or not added) related to
the feature.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
While the Coral team is not strict on test driven development (or TDD), any
contributions that include tests are greatly appreciated, and preferred over
those that do not.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Review architectural decisions
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Any substantial changes made to the codebase should be reviewed to ensure
that they conform to the current way code/services are laid out.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Architecture Decision Records (or ADR) are now being used to describe architectural decisions and can be found in the src/docs/architecture/decisions directory.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Verify localizations
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
While we don't have any automated tools at the time of writing that will
verify this in CI, any strings
should be wrapped in localization components to support other languages.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Localization
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
We use the fluent library and store our
translations in FTL files in
src/locales/ and src/core/server/locales/.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Strings are added or removed from localization bundles in the translation files
as needed. Strings MUST NOT be changed after they've been committed and
pushed to master. Changing a string requires creating a new ID with a new name
(preferably descriptive instead of incremented) and deletion of the obsolete ID.
It's often useful to add a comment above the string with info about how and
where the string is used.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Once a language has enough coverage, it should be added to
src/core/common/helpers/i18n/locales.ts.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
The Perspective API
also supports comments in specific languages. When the language is supported in
Coral and supported by the Perspective API, the language should be added to the
language map in src/core/server/services/comments/pipeline/phases/toxic.ts.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
To assist with the translation process, we have a script that is based on the
work by @cristiandean in https://github.com/coralproject/talk/pull/2949 that
will detect missing, new, or changed translation keys for the specified
language. You can use this with:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
# usage: ./scripts/i18n/validate.ts <locale>
./scripts/i18n/validate.ts pt-BR
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Documentation
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Documentation that is publicly shown on
docs.coralproject.net is stored under
the release/4 branch as it contains information for versions 4.0 onwards of
Coral.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
To contribute new docs, you can either click the "Suggest Edits" in the top
right of each page, or you can edit directly via source. We suggest that for
individual fixes or contributions to the documentation.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
If you want to contribute via source files, you can follow the procedure
outlined below:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 1.  Clone the Talk repository via git clone https://github.com/coralproject/talk.git
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 2.  Switch to the release/4 branch via git checkout release/4
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 3.  Follow the procedure outlined on that branch's CONTRIBUTING.md file for contributing documentation changes
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: 4.  Create a pull request to merge your changes back into the release/4 branch
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Design Principles
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: GraphQL
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Coral relies heavily on GraphQL as the query language for
the API and the runtime on the server that powers resolving data from data
sources. This heavily influences a lot of the decisions around how we create and
consume it's API internally and how we expose it to others to interact with.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
There are many GraphQL types in our schema.graphql
that define the way we handle data in our API. We'll try to outline a few of
them here with examples to help you understand their uses.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Types
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Similar to defining an interface or a struct definition, GraphQL has flexible
types that can be used to define data types that are used for querying data from
the API. This retrieval can happen directly via a query, or after executing an
action using a mutation and querying its response result.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
An example of these types is the Comment and its nested CommentRevision
type:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
"""
Comment is a comment left by a User on an Story or another Comment as a reply.
"""
type Comment {
"""
id is the identifier of the Comment.
"""
id: ID!
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
"""
body is the content of the Comment, and is an alias to the body of the
`revision.body`.
"""
body: String
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
"""
revision is the current revision of the Comment's body.
"""
revision: CommentRevision
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
"""
revisionHistory stores the previous CommentRevision's, with the most recent
edit last.
"""
revisionHistory: [CommentRevision!]!
@auth(
roles: [MODERATOR, ADMIN]
userIDField: "author_id"
permit: [SUSPENDED, BANNED, PENDING_DELETION]
)
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
"""
status represents the Comment's current status.
"""
status: COMMENT_STATUS!
}
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Notice how the Comment type can nest more custom defined types. A Comment
can have a current CommentRevision named revision. It also has a list of its
historical revisionHistory:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
type CommentRevision {
"""
id is the identifier of the CommentRevision.
"""
id: ID!
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
"""
comment is the reference to the original Comment associated with the current
Comment.
"""
comment: Comment!
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
"""
actionCounts stores the counts of all the actions for the CommentRevision
specifically.
"""
actionCounts: ActionCounts! @auth(roles: [MODERATOR, ADMIN])
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
"""
body is the content of the CommentRevision. If null, it indicates that the
body text was deleted.
"""
body: String
}
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Another thing to note, see how CommentRevision is not only referenced by
revision and revisionHistory on the Comment type. The CommentRevision
also references back to its parent Comment via the comment: Comment!
property. This is how defined types interact between each other in the GraphQL
schema.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Our naming scheme is upper camel case (also known as Pascal Case) for these
types:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Start with a capital letter
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Following characters are lower case
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Every new word in the type name begins with a new capital letter
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- Acronyms are always capitalized (with the only exception being the
clientMutationId: String! field in mutation input/payload types)
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Some of the properties have an ! beside their type (i.e id: ID!) which
indicates that this property is required and is non-nullable. GraphQL will
validate the input request for these properties and ensure they are provided
during the GraphQL request.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: You can learn more about GraphQL types in their documentation:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Learn GraphQL: Schemas and Types
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Enumeration Types
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
In the previous example with the Comment type. We also had a property called
status which was of type COMMENT_STATUS.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
This is another kind of defined type, an Enumeration Type,
also called enums.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
enum COMMENT_STATUS {
NONE
APPROVED
REJECTED
PREMOD
SYSTEM_WITHHELD
}
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Like all enumeration types this definition enumerates out typed, named values
that are reusable for state elsewhere on other types.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Our naming scheme for enumeration types and values in those types as:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - All capital letters
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Spaces delimited with underscores
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
This is because they are treated as shared constant values across the schema.
Rather than storing strings or numbers to capture selected state, we prefer
using enumeration types because they are much more stricter in terms of value.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: You can learn more about GraphQL Enumeration types in their documentation:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Learn GraphQL: Enumeration Types
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Mutation Types
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Mutations are a request to GraphQL to initiate an action which will result in a response. As such,they're broken up into an Input and Payload pair that matches a mutation's request and response pair.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: An example is the CreateCommentInput and CreateCommentPayload:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
"""
CreateCommentInput provides the input for the createComment Mutation.
"""
input CreateCommentInput {
"""
storyID is the ID of the Story where we are creating a comment on.
"""
storyID: ID!
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
"""
nudge when true will instead return an error related to recoverable moderation
faults such as a toxic comment or spam comment to provide user feedback to
nudge the user to correct the comment.
"""
nudge: Boolean = false
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
"""
body is the Comment body, the content of the Comment.
"""
body: String!
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
"""
clientMutationId is required for Relay support.
"""
clientMutationId: String!
}
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
"""
CreateCommentPayload contains the created Comment after the createComment
mutation.
"""
type CreateCommentPayload {
"""
edge is the possibly created comment edge.
"""
edge: CommentEdge!
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
"""
clientMutationId is required for Relay support.
"""
clientMutationId: String!
}
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
The CreateCommentInput type contains some parameters that allow us to execute
the mutation. These are:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - storyID - the story we are submitting the comment to.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - body - the body of our comment.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- nudge - whether we should return validation prompts to the user about
improper comment language.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- clientMutationId - the identifier used by Relay to identify this mutation,
our front-end state cache to process the mutation request. This is the only
place in the code-base that we do not capitalize the acronym when written in
camel-case, this is unfortunately due to legacy reasons from within Relay.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
The returned response for a mutation is a what we call a Payload, in this case
it's CreateCommentPayload. This usually has a response that is the full data
type of whatever was modified by the earlier called mutation action. The
properties on this type are:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- edge - we return the full comment edge that was created by the previous
input. This is done so that the mutation request can query whatever it needs
to from the returned input to update state on the client.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- clientMutationId - an identifier used by Relay (our front-end client state
cache) to process the mutation request.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Access Permissions On Types
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Sometimes, you only want specific users to be allowed to view certain
information. For instance, we have roles that are defined in our schema so we
can filter who can have access to what.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
These roles are used with directives on our schema that GraphQL then enforces
when trying to resolve requests a user makes. If the user has the specified role
associated with their signed-in account, they are given access to the requested
data.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: An example of this is the revisionHistory on the Comment type:
Label: No categories identified.
No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Here we see the @auth directive. It has documentation describing the various
parameters allowed located in the schema.graphql
file, we'll discuss below what this particular set of parameters can be read as:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- The roles that are allowed to access this information are MODERATOR and
ADMIN as defined by the roles argument.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- We let the directive know that the author of the comment is author_id from
the Comment by defining the userIDField. It's a rule of thumb in Coral if
the Author created the document, they have permission to view it. A Comment
for example is authored by a user, with the underlying field associated with
the id of that author living on the author_id field. You can see how this
is related if you look at the resolver for the Comment type to see that it
is based off of the Comment interface from src/core/server/models/comment.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
- We permit returning comments when the author has the following conditions
associated with their account: SUSPENDED, BANNED, or PENDING_DELETION.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
These directives can be simpler, for example the metadata property on the
CommentRevision:
Label: No categories identified.
No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Here we see an auth directive with only roles defined. This is sufficient to
make sure that the metadata property is only accessible to ADMIN and
MODERATOR user roles.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Note: Wondering how the user roles are defined? They're simply an enumeration
type that is also defined in the schema.
Label: No categories identified.
No categories identified.

Paragraph: Arrays of Items
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Sometimes you don't want a singular property, your property is instead a
collection of items.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: The revisionHistory from the Comment is again useful as an example:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
fragment on Comment {
"""
revisionHistory stores the previous CommentRevision's, with the most recent
edit last.
"""
revisionHistory: [CommentRevision!]!
}
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
The interior type CommentRevision is required using the ! and the outer
array is also required using !.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: We do this for a couple of reasons:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - This ensures that we do not return null/undefined values within the array.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Why would we return a null when we can just return nothing for null values?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - We want the array to always be defined, if empty, we return and empty array (i.e. []).
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - This can be handled nicely in our resolvers. We simply check if the retrieved values is null or undefined and simply return an empty array in its stead.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
These little tweaks aren't necessary, but they ease the use of our API by making
the results for arrays predictable and strongly typed.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Documenting
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: As you may have noticed, there is quite a bit of documentation in the schema examples listed here.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: We typically follow these two rules in commenting our GraphQL types:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Always comment the property within a type describing its purpose on its parent type
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: i.e. createdAt on our Setting type:
Label: No categories identified.
No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Always comment the purpose of each type
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: i.e. the Comment type:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
"""
Comment is a comment left by a User on an Story or another Comment as a reply.
"""
type Comment { }
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Filing a bug report
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: I accept bug reports for the Creative Cloud script, but please note that I can't do anything about most bugs. The Wine compatibility layer is used to run the Creative Cloud installer and all downloaded Adobe programs. If you have issues with getting certain programs to run, you should file a bug report with Wine.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: When filing a Wine bug, please include the following information in your report to help the developers:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - You are using 32-bit Wine 2.20-staging
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - You have the msxml3, atmlib, and corefonts winetricks installed
Label: No categories identified.

For specific proposals, please provide them as
pull requests
or
issues
via our
GitHub site.
For general discussion, feel free to use the
cii-badges mailing list.
Label: TC – Talk to the community

Paragraph: The "doc/" directory has information you may find helpful, for example:

- governance.md describes our governance model
(how we decide things)

You can see the entire set of "passing" criteria in the generated file

The documentation for higher-level badge criteria is in

If you want change the criteria, see below.

The INSTALL.md file explains how to install the program

It also provides a quick start guide.

Paragraph:
If you're new to the project (or FLOSS in general), the
Up-for-grabs
issues are smaller tasks that may typically take 1-3 days.
You are welcome aboard!
The roadmap.md file provides an overview of future plans.
