Paragraph: Before creating bug reports, please check this list as you might find out that you don't need to create one. When you are creating a bug report, please include as much detail as possible. Fill out the required template, the information it asks for helps us resolve issues faster.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Note: If you find a Closed issue that seems like it's the same thing that you're experiencing, open a new issue and include a link to the original issue in the body of your new one.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Before Submitting A Bug Report
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Check the Troubleshooting Guide. You might be able to find the cause of the problem and fix it yourself. Most importantly, check if you can reproduce the problem in the latest version (a.k.a. 'master') of the library.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Perform a cursory search to see if the problem is already reported. If it has and the issue is still open, add a comment to the existing issue instead of opening a new one.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: How Do I Submit A (Good) Bug Report?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Bugs are tracked as GitHub issues. Create an issue and provide the following information by filling in the template.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Explain the problem and include any additional details to help maintainers reproduce the problem:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Use a clear and descriptive title for the issue to identify the problem.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Describe the exact steps which reproduce the problem in as much detail as possible.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Provide specific examples to demonstrate the steps. Include links to files or GitHub projects, or copy/pasteable snippets, which you use in those examples. If you're providing snippets in the issue, use Markdown code blocks.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Describe the behavior you observed after following the steps and point out what exactly is the problem with that behavior.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Explain which behavior you expected to see instead and why.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - If the problem wasn't triggered by a specific action, describe what you were doing before the problem happened and share more information using the guidelines below.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Provide more context by answering these questions:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Can you reproduce the problem in one of the code examples?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Did the problem start happening recently (e.g. after updating to a new version of Arduino or the library) or was this always a problem?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - If the problem started happening recently, can you reproduce the problem in an older version of the library? What's the most recent version in which the problem doesn't happen? You can download older versions of the library from the releases page.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Can you reliably reproduce the issue? If not, provide details about how often the problem happens and under which conditions it normally happens.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Include details about your configuration, circuit and environment:
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Which version of the library are you using? You can get the exact version by inspecting the library.json file in the root directory of the library.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - What board are you running this on?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: There are a few stylistic conventions followed in the code:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - The Format Document command in vanilla VS2017 is used to apply code formatting after every code edit (shortcut Ctrl+K, Ctrl+D)
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Simplicity is king, with modularity favoured when it does not hurt readability or workflows
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Member variables follow lower camel case with a single underscore prefix: _exampleVariable
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Single blank line between functions and between logically separate bits of code
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Tweakable/serialised variables are private and tagged with SerializeField
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Documentation comments preferred when useful for documentation, except when member variable is exposed to the Inspector GUI, in which case the comment is placed in Tooltip string so that it can aid users.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Comments placed on their own line above the relevant code
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Public member variables typically ordered together before private ones in class definitions
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - No dead or commented code in the master branch, unless it is instructive to include it and not distracting for readers. Experimental or unfinished code belongs in development branches.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Commit messages contain a 50 char summary line (see git-style-guide for details on this)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: How to add a dictionary
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: For safety and maintainability reason, Saladict will not support adding dictionaries on the fly. All dictionaries must be merged to this project via pull requests.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: If dictionary implementation makes use of private API please move it to an independent project, release on NPM, then import it to Saladict.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: 1.  Create a directory at src/components/dictionaries/, with the name of the dict ID.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: 1.  Use any existing dictionary as guidance, e.g. Bing. Copy files to the new directory.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: 2.  Replace the favicon with a new LOGO.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: 3.  Edit config.ts to change default options. See the DictItem type and explanation for more details. Register the dictionary in app config so that TypeScript generates the correct typings. Dict ID MUST follow alphabetical order.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: 4.  Update _locales.json with the new dictionary name. Add locales for options, if any.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: 5.  engine.ts MUST export at least two functions:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: 1.  getSrcPage function which is responsible for generating source page url base on search text and app config. Source page url is opened when user clicks the dictionary title.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: 2.  search function which is responsible for fetching, parsing and returning dictionary results. See the typings for more detail.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Extracting information from a webpage MUST use helper functions in ../helpers.ts for data cleansing.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - If the dictionary supports pronunciation:
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: 1.  Register the ID at config.autopron.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: 2.  Include an audio field in the object which search engine returns.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: 3.  Other exported functions can be called from View.tsx via 'DICT_ENGINE_METHOD' message channel. See src/typings/message for typing details and search DICT_ENGINE_METHOD project-wise for examples. Messages MUST be sent via message from '@/_helpers/browser-api' instead of the native sendMessage function.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: 6.  Search result will ultimately be passed to a React PureComponent in View.tsx, which SHOULD be a dumb component that renders the result accordingly.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: 7.  Selectors in _style.scss SHOULD follow ECSS-ish naming convention.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Develop the dictionary UI live
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: To develop the component in Storybook we need to intercept http requests from dictionary engines and replace with the downloaded results.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: 1.  Add fixtures.js at test/specs/components/dictionaries/[dictID].
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - See other dictionaries for example.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - You can offer url or axios config (See mojidict dictionary). All results from previous requests will be passed to the next request as array.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: 2.  Run yarn fixtures to download fixtures.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: 3.  Edit test/specs/components/dictionaries/[dictID]/request.mock.ts. It will intercept requests and return the downloaded fixtures.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: 4.  Run yarn storybook.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: 1.  Add [dictID]/engine.spec.ts to test the engine.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Contributing to Crosswalk
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Thanks a lot for contributing to Crosswalk, you rock!
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
This page lists some guidelines for the contribution process to help you send
an awesome patch that gets reviewed and merged quickly.
Crosswalk's website also has a
whole section dedicated to this, be sure to check it out.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: License
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Crosswalk is licensed under the
3-clause BSD license. When you
submit a patch, you agree to license your contribution to Intel under this
license.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Submitting pull requests
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- If it applies, add the platform your change affects in both the commit
message and the pull request title. For example, "[Android] Update target
SDK to android-21" or "[Windows] Add unit test for metadata element
handler".
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- If you know them, be sure to mention the people you would like to review your
patch in a comment. You can check the OWNERS files in the tree to know the
best people to look at your changes.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Do not use your master branch in your pull request. This means you will not
be able to send multiple pull requests at the same time without changing all
of them at once, and they will also be changed when you update your branch to
track Crosswalk's latest changes. Instead, use a separate branch for each
pull request.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- If someone asks you to make a change to your pull request, DO NOT close
it and open a new one. Instead, make the changes to your branch, amending and
rebasing when necessary, and then use git push -f to push the changes to
the same branch you have used in your existing pull request.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Commit messages
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Use the present tense ("Add feature" not "Added feature").
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Use the imperative mood ("Move cursor to..." not "Moves cursor to...").
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Limit the first line to 72 characters or less.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- If your pull request fixes an open issue in
our bug tracker, please reference it in
your commit message as well as your pull request message, like this:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Fix something.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Yadda, yadda, yadda.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: BUG=XWALK-123456
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
This way, the issue will be updated when the pull request is sent and, once
it is merged, the issue will be closed automatically.
If you simply want the issue to be updated but do not want it to be
closed, use a different construct in your message, like "Related to:
XWALK-123".
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Coding style
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- C++: We follow
Chromium's coding style,
which basically mean's
Google's.
Please take some time to get familiar with it, particularly with the amount
of space used for indentation and the position of asterisks and braces. If in
doubt, check the rest of the code around what you are changing.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- Java: We also follow
Chromium's guidelines,
which are very similar to
Android's style guide, so
there should not be any big surprises.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- Python: Just like
Chromium's, our Python
code mostly follows PEP-8, the
exceptions being the amount of space used for indentation (2 instead of 4)
and the use of MixedCase functions and methods instead of
lower_case_ones.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
The Crunchy Container Suite is an open source project primarily authored and
maintained by the team at Crunchy Data. All contributions are welcome: the
Crunchy Container Suite uses the Apache 2.0 license and does not require any
contributor agreement to submit patches.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Our contributors try to follow good software development practices to help
ensure that the code that we ship to our users is stable. If you wish to
contribute to the Crunchy Container Suite, be it code or documentation, please
follow the guidelines below.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Thanks! We look forward to your contribution.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: General Contributing Guidelines
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
All ongoing development for an upcoming release gets committed to the
master branch. The master branch technically serves as the "development"
branch as well, but all code that is committed to the master branch should be
considered stable, even if it is part of an ongoing release cycle.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
All fixes for a supported release should be committed to the supported release
branch. For example, the 4.3 release is maintained on the  REL_4_3 branch.
Please see the section on Supported Releases for more information.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Ensure any changes are clear and well-documented. When we say "well-documented":
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- If the changes include code, ensure all additional code has corresponding
documentation in and around it. This includes documenting the definition of
functions, statements in code, sections.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- The most helpful code comments explain why, establish context, or efficiently
summarize how. Avoid simply repeating details from declarations,. When in doubt,
favor overexplaining to underexplaining.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- Code comments should be consistent with their language conventions. For
example, please use GoDoc conventions for Go source code.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- Any new features must have corresponding user documentation. Any removed
features must have their user documentation removed from the documents.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Do not submit commented-out code. If the code does not need to be used
anymore, please remove it.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- While TODO comments are frowned upon, every now and then it is ok to put a
TODO to note that a particular section of code needs to be worked on in the
future. However, it is also known that "TODOs" often do not get worked on, and
as such, it is more likely you will be asked to complete the TODO at the time
you submit it.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph:
- Write clear, descriptive commit messages. A guide for this is featured later
on in the documentation.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Please provide unit tests with your code if possible. If you are unable to
provide a unit test, please provide an explanation as to why in your pull
request, including a description of the steps used to manually verify the
changes.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Ensure your commits are atomic. Each commit tells a story about what changes
are being made. This makes it easier to identify when a bug is introduced into
the codebase, and as such makes it easier to fix.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
All commits must either be rebased in atomic order or squashed (if the squashed
commit is considered atomic). Merge commits are not accepted. All conflicts must
be resolved prior to pushing changes.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
All pull requests should be made from the master branch unless it is a fix
for a specific supported release.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Once a major or minor release is made, no new features are added into the
release branch, only bug fixes. Any new features are added to the master
branch until the time that said new features are released.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Commit Messages
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Commit messages should be as descriptive and should follow the general format:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: A one-sentence summary of what the commit is.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Further details of the commit messages go in here. Try to be as descriptive of
possible as to what the changes are. Good things to include:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - What the changes is.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Why the change was made.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - What to expect now that the change is in place.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- Any advice that can be helpful if someone needs to review this commit and
understand.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
If you wish to tag a Github issue or another project management tracker, please
do so at the bottom of the commit message, and make it clearly labeled like so:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Issue: #123
Issue: [ch1234]
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Submitting Pull Requests
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
All work should be made in your own repository fork. When you believe your work
is ready to be committed, please follow the guidance below for creating a pull
request.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Upcoming Releases / Features
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Ongoing work for new features should occur in branches off of the master
branch. It is suggested, but not required, that the branch name should reflect
that this is for an upcoming release, i.e. upstream/branch-name where the
branch-name is something descriptive for what you're working on.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Supported Releases / Fixes
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
While not required, it is recommended to make your branch name along the lines
of: REL_X_Y/branch-name where the branch-name is something descriptive
for what you're working on.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Releases & Versioning
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Overall, release tags attempt to follow the
semantic versioning scheme. The Crunchy Container Suite is
closely related to the
PostgreSQL Operator and in
some cases may not fully follow semantic versioning if a change in the
PostgreSQL Operator project necessitates a major or minor version change.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
"Supported releases" (described in the next section) occur on "minor" release
branches (e.g. the x.y portion of the x.y.z).
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
One or more "patch" releases can occur after a minor release. A patch release is
used to fix bugs and other issues that may be found after a supported release.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Fixes found on the master branch can be backported to a support release
branch. Any fixes for a supported release must have a pull request off of the
supported release branch, which is detailed below.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Supported Releases
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
When a "minor" release is made, the release is stamped using the vx.y.0 format
as denoted above, and a branch is created with the name REL_X_Y. Once a
minor release occurs, no new features are added to the REL_X_Y branch.
However, bug fixes can (and if found, should) be added to this branch.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
To contribute a bug fix to a supported release, please make a pull request off
of the supported release branch. For instance, if you find a bug in the 4.3
release, then you would make a pull request off of the REL_4_3 branch.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Unsupported Releases
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
When a release is no longer supported, the branch will be renamed following the
pattern REL_X_Y_FINAL with the key suffix being FINAL. For example,
REL_3_2_FINAL indicates that the 3.2 release is no longer supported.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Nothing should ever be pushed to a REL_X_Y_FINAL branch once FINAL is on
the branch name.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Alpha, Beta, Release Candidate Releases
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
At any point in the release cycle for a new release, there could exist one or
more alpha, beta, or release candidate (RC) release. Alpha, beta, and release
candidates should not be used in production environments.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Alpha is the early stage of a release cycle and is typically made to test the
mechanics of an upcoming release. These should be considered relatively
unstable. The format for an alpha release tag is v4.3.0-alpha.1, which in this
case indicates it is the first alpha release for 4.2.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Beta occurs during the later stage of a release cycle. At this point, the
release should be considered feature complete and the beta is used to
distribute, test, and collect feedback on the upcoming release. The betas should
be considered unstable, but as mentioned feature complete. The format for an
beta release tag is v4.3.0-beta.1, which in this case indicates it is the
first beta release for 4.2.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
Release candidates (RCs) occur just before a release. A release candidate should
be considered stable, and is typically used for a final round of bug checking
and testing. Multiple release candidates can occur in the event of serious bugs.
The format for a release candidate tag is v4.3.0-rc.1, which in this
case indicates it is the first release candidate for 4.2.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
After a major or minor release, no alpha, beta, or release candidate releases
are supported. In fact, any newer release of an alpha, beta, or RC immediately
deprecates any older alpha, beta or RC. (Naturally, a beta deprecates an alpha,
and a RC deprecates a beta).
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph:
If you are testing on an older alpha, beta or RC, bug reports will not be
accepted. Please ensure you are testing on the latest version.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Testing
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
We greatly appreciate any and all testing for the project. When testing, please
be sure you do the following:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- If testing against a release, ensure your tests are performed against the
latest minor version (the last number in the release denotes the minor version,
e.g. the "3" in the 4.3.3)
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- If testing against a pre-release (alpha, beta, RC), ensure your tests are
performed against latest version
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
- If testing against a development (master) or release (REL_X_Y) branch,
ensure your tests are performed against the latest commit
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph:
Please do not test against unsupported versions (e.g. any release that is marked
final).
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: There are several ways to help with the testing effort:
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph:
- Manual testing: testing particular features with a series of manual commands
or custom scripts
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: - Writing unit tests: testing specific sections of the code
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph:
- Writing integration tests: automatically testing scenarios that require a
defined series of steps, such as end-to-end tests
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph:
- Environmental & workload testing: testing the code against specific workloads,
deployment platforms, deployment models, etc.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: How to contribute to CTFd
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Did you find a bug?
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Do not open up a GitHub issue if the bug is a security vulnerability in CTFd. Instead email the details to us at support@ctfd.io.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - Ensure the bug was not already reported by searching on GitHub under Issues.
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: - If you're unable to find an open issue addressing the problem, open a new one. Be sure to fill out the issue template with a title and clear description, and as much relevant information as possible (e.g. deployment setup, browser version, etc).
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Did you write a patch that fixes a bug or implements a new feature?
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Open a new pull request with the patch.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Ensure the PR description clearly describes the problem and solution. Include the relevant issue number if applicable.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Ensure all status checks pass. PR's with test failures will not be merged. PR's with insufficient coverage may be merged depending on the situation.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Did you fix whitespace, format code, or make a purely cosmetic patch?
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: Changes that are cosmetic in nature and do not add anything substantial to the stability, functionality, or testability of CTFd will generally not be accepted.
Label: CT – Choose a task

Paragraph: Contributing to apollo
Label: No categories identified.

Paragraph: Apollo is released under the non-restrictive Apache 2.0 license, and follows a very standard Github development process, using Github tracker for issues and merging pull requests into master. If you want to contribute even something trivial please do not hesitate, but follow the guidelines below.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Sign the Contributor License Agreement
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Before we accept a non-trivial patch or pull request we will need you to sign the Contributor License Agreement. Signing the contributor
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: Code Conventions
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: Our code style is in line with Google Java Style Guide.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: We provide template files intellij-java-google-style.xml for IntelliJ IDEA and eclipse-java-google-style.xml for Eclipse. If you use other IDEs, then you may config manually by referencing the template files.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Make sure all new .java files have a simple Javadoc class comment with at least an @author tag identifying you, and preferably at least a paragraph on what the class is for.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Add yourself as an @author to the .java files that you modify substantially (more than cosmetic changes).
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - Add some Javadocs and, if you change the namespace, some XSD doc elements.
Label: DC – Deal with the code

Paragraph: - A few unit tests should be added for a new feature or an important bug fix.
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - If no-one else is using your branch, please rebase it against the current master (or other target branch in the main project).
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - Normally, we would squash commits for one feature into one commit. There are 2 ways to do this:
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 1.  To rebase and squash based on the remote branch
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - git rebase -i <remote>/master
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - merge commits via fixup, etc
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: 2.  Create a new branch and merge these commits into one
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - git checkout -b <some-branch-name> <remote>/master
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - git merge --squash <current-feature-branch>
Label: SC – Submit the changes

Paragraph: - When writing a commit message please follow these conventions: if you are fixing an existing issue, please add Fixes #XXX at the end of the commit message (where XXX is the issue number).
Label: SC – Submit the changes
